title: Unusual Alliance Battles California Ballot Proposal
description: In a rare alliance, Gov. George Deukmejian and legislative leaders of both parties have joined to oppose a sweeping measure that would restrict campaign spending in California.

title: KEY RATES
Geodyne Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss Year-ago figures are restated to include Snyder Exploration Co.

title: Boston Five Cents Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $1,498,000 for both the quarter and 6 months from the forgiveness of debt.

title: Tanana Finding the Best of Times Are With the Tigers
description: You can't fool all the hitters all the time, but you can fool many of them much of the time.

title: Group Offers $2.8 Billion For Centel
description: An investor group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier, and George L. Lindemann, the chairman of Metro Mobile CTS Inc. today offered to pay $2.8 billion in cash for a negotiated purchase of the Centel Corporation.

title: 3 Are Charged In the Slaying Of a Woman
description: Three men were charged yesterday in the slaying of a Queens woman who was killed Saturday as she stood in her kitchen, talking on the telephone with her infant in her arms.

title: Valley Forge Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $17,000 for the latest first quarter and $368,000 for the year-ago period.

title: DISCOUNT STORES WIN A 5-4 RULING IN SUPREME COURT
description: In a victory for discount retailers that compete with the authorized distributors of some costly foreign-made goods, the Supreme Court ruled today that the bulk of ''gray market'' imports are legal.

title: Bridge
description: The world's biggest charity event celebrated its 25th birthday last Thursday. The event, the annual Pro-Am at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street in Manhattan, generated a record $63,000 for U.J.A.-Federation and marked the completion of a quarter of a century of brilliant organization by Tubby Stayman of Manhattan.

title: Computer's X-Ray Movies Make Heart Procedure Faster and Safer
description: A computer developed for high-resolution satellite photography is now producing detailed X-ray movies of the heart. The movies are being used by cardiologists to help them perform angioplasty, an alternative to coronary bypass surgery.

title: U.S. Rig Count Rises
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States increased by 13 last week, to 905, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 758 a year ago.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Increased 3.1% in May
description: Farmers received 3.1 percent more for their raw products in May than in April, and 4.7 percent more than in May 1987, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 26 Killed in Punjab Bombings Blamed on Sikh Separatists
description: Sikh separatists set off bombs at a Hindu temple and in a crowded market in the northern Indian state of Punjab, killing at least 26 people and injuring nearly 100, the police said today.

title: New Century Entertainment reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,170,000 on the acquisition of convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I was Governor of California, I could start a riot just by going to a campus. But that has all changed, and I could be looking out at an American student body as well as I'm looking out here, and would not be able to tell the difference between you.'' - President Reagan, at Moscow State University. [ A12:5. ]

title: Supreme Court Roundup Small Errors Do Not Require Reversal in Death Sentences
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 3 today that convicted murderers whose constitutional rights were violated at their sentencing hearings may nonetheless be executed if the prosecution can prove that the violations had no effect on the sentence.

title: Education; Lessons
description: Textbook bashing, great sport to some, has in recent years been practiced widely by the advocates of educational reform. And with each publishing season, there seems to be plenty new to pillory.

title: Chicago
description: THE National Restaurant Association Show, an annual event now in its 69th year, is a restaurateurs' marathon, through miles of products. This year's show, held last week in the McCormick Place Exhibition Halls, included 1,900 exhibitors promoting their wares to more than 100,000 people from the food service and hospitality industries around the world.

title: Baseball Draft
description: Andy Benes, a pitcher from Don Mattingly's hometown of Evansville, Ind., is expected to be the first player selected today in baseball's annual draft of high school and college players. The San Diego Padres have the first pick, and they were believed to be leaning toward Benes, who had a 16-3 record this season with Evansville University. Following Benes, who also had a 1.42 earned run average and 188 strikeouts in 146 innings, the players whom scouts expect to be chosen are Mark Lewis, a high school shortstop from Hamilton, Ohio, by the Cleveland Indians; Steve Avery, a high school pitcher from Michigan, by the Atlanta Braves, and Gregg Olson, an Auburn University pitcher, by the Baltimore Orioles. The Mets are 21st and the Yankees 22d in the selection order, but the Yankees won't get to select anyone until 104 players are drafted, late in the fourth round. They lost their first three picks as compensation for signing three free agents: Jack Clark (St. Louis), Jose Cruz (Houston) and John Candelaria (Mets).(AP)

title: Kidnapping Suspect Helps Syria To Enforce Cease-Fire in Beirut
description: A man suspected of kidnapping is the representative of the pro-Iranian Party of God in a committee supervising the enforcement of a cease-fire in Beirut's southern district.

title: British Airways reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS); one ADS equals 10 U.K. ordinary shares. Results are in U.S. dollars. The U.S. dollar amounts for 1988 results have been translated at the exchange rate on March 31 of $1.88 equals one pound sterling and the 1987 results at the rate of $1.61 equals one pound sterling.

title: Review/Theater; The Changing Fortunes Of 'Titus Andronicus'
description: ''Titus Andronicus'' was Shakespeare's first tragedy, and for nearly 300 years, from the Restoration to the mid-20th century, it was widely regarded as his worst play. It is certainly not for the squeamish.

title: Brown Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Reviews/Film; Bruce Burger Berserk
description: Is Ronald McDonald beyond parody? The clownish hamburger spokesman has already taken a giant advertising step away from any ordinary circus character. Is there a fresh spoof of ''The Godfather'' left? Anything is possible, but the creators of ''Funland'' have tossed some trite satiric targets - organized crime, advertising, a psycho clown - into a grab bag, then lazily let them tumble out any old way.

title: Undercover Talk
description: Steven Emerson, an expert on intelligence, recently gave a talk on covert operations to intelligence officers in a soundproof, secure room in the Army's Intelligence and Security Command in Arlington, Va.

title: French Open; Darkness Halts a Brilliant Lendl-McEnroe Match
description: Cold rain continued to disrupt the French Open today, delaying the schedule and making conditions soggy, dim and difficult for the players in Roland Garros Stadium. After waiting two days, spectators huddled under umbrellas to watch Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe trade tie breakers between rain showers before darkness set in during the third set.

title: MacDermid Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Assessing Health Care
description: Preliminary findings of the nation's largest, most detailed survey of how Americans use and pay for health care may become available this fall.

title: Real Estate; Ritz-Carlton Style Coming To Jersey, Too
description: Until recently a stay at a Ritz-Carlton hotel, a name long associated with the epitome of hotel comfort, traditional style and urban elegance, meant a visit to Boston, New York, Washington or Chicago. Now a Ritz-Carlton hotel is coming to suburban New Jersey, and the project is regarded as a high-risk venture.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rally
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged a healthy rally in very quiet trading yesterday. But most analysts said the gains were due more to technical factors than a change in underlying economic fundamentals, and they questioned whether the price rise could be sustained.

title: United Coasts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $74,356.

title: REAGAN IMPRESSES SOVIET ELITE; The Vintage Actor Gets Great Reviews
description: After President Reagan's lunch with Soviet cultural figures today, it was Roy A. Medvedev, a historian with a dramatist's eye, who noticed the essential paradox.

title: Xoma Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sunlite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $72,612 for the quarter and $1,033,764 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after tax benefits of $56,353 for the quarter and $119,404 for the 9 months.

title: Review/Organ; Kei Koito's Spirited Bach
description: Unusually spirited and rythmically alert Bach playing was the unifying thread of a stimulating organ recital by Kei Koito at the Church of St. John the Evangelist Monday evening.

title: When Aides Aid Incumbents
description: Caught in an embarrassing scandal last year, New York's Legislature appointed a blue ribbon commission to recommend clear rules governing the use of legislative employees for campaign work. The panel's report, finally issued this month, offers a thoughtful program for reform.

title: Tech-Sym Stake
description: Two Washington investors have purchased 5.4 percent of the Tech-Sym Corporation and said that they might seek control of the Houston-based electronics manufacturer. Melvyn J. Estrin and Charles P. Aboud, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had bought their shares for an average price of $15.07 each. Tech-Sym's shares gained $1.75 each, to $17.50, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Choice Drug Systems reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and share earnings is less than one cent a share. The company said results include the operations of J&J Drug & Medical Services since its acquisition in November 1987. Latest year includes $211,000 of expenses related to incomplete and terminated acquisitions.

title: Codercard reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Niagara Mohawk Power Corp reports earnings for 12mo April 30
description: b-Net loss and after a $140,100,000 writeoff of Nine Mile II costs and a $615,000,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: New Center In Italy for Modern Art
description: A new museum of contemporary art is to open late this month in Prato, Italy, just outside of Florence.

title: Antarctic Fare That Rates a 'Yum Yum'
description: LIVING in Lake Hoare is the ultimate test of culinary skills. Situated in the Taylor Valley, inland from McMurdo Sound, it has no plants or animals to speak of, not even a 24-hour vegetable stand.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Women Are Moving Up In One Area
description: FIVE years ago, a top ad agency executive recalls, he prophesied that by the year 2000 half the chief executives of advertising agencies would be women.

title: Economic Scene; Warsaw's Failure Haunts Moscow
description: DETERMINED to pare waste and channel resources into more productive uses, the Government cuts food subsidies and declares that obsolete, unprofitable heavy industries must fend for themselves. Workers, already discontented by years of austerity, go on strike to recoup their lost purchasing power and to demand an independent voice for trade unions. The strikes are easily smashed by the paramilitary forces, but badly shaken party leaders agree to inflationary wage increases and quietly shelve other plans to discipline the failing economy with free market incentives.

title: Rose to Return
description: Pete Rose, having completed a 30-day suspension, will return to the dugout today when the Cincinnati Reds play the Cubs in Chicago. ''I've seen every pitch, I've made out every lineup,'' said Rose, who was with the team in the clubhouse before and after every game. ''All June 1 means is I can come back. I don't look at it as a big deal. I hope it's the kind of game where the people of Chicago don't even know I'm in the dugout.'' Rose was suspended and fined $10,000 for shoving and bumping the umpire Dave Pallone in a game against the Mets April 30 in Cincinnati. The incident resulted in rowdy crowd behavior that forced Pallone to leave the field. Under Tommy Helms, who filled in for Rose, the Reds had a 12-15 record. They were 11-12 with Rose managing.(AP)

title: Los Angeles Plans New Concert Hall
description: Los Angeles finds itself in the midst of a contradiction - on the one hand a continuing suburban expansion threatens to pave over much of southern California; on the other a cultural implosion is turning a retreat out of the city into a retreat back into it. Residential and office space is beginning to bloom again downtown, but the glue holding this renewal together is artistic.

title: Review/Books; When U.S. Kept Tabs on Writers
description: Dangerous Dossiers Exposing the Secret War Against America's Greatest Authors By Herbert Mitgang 331 pages. Donald I. Fine. $18.95.

title: Tempest Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports of The Times; Bermuda Triangle Monday
description: CALL the lost-and-found. People and things are disappearing all over North America. You could call it the Ziegler Syndrome. Monday night's Met game vanished twice, first from its scheduled starting time, and then from one of our major networks with hardly a trace.

title: Baseball; Stieb Blanks Brewers on 1 Hit
description: Dave Stieb pitched a one-hitter tonight, allowing a fourth-inning single to B. J. Surhoff, as the Toronto Blue Jays routed the Milwaukee Brewers, 9-0.

title: Kimmins Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Prisoner Holds Doctor Hostage for Six Hours
description: An inmate at Trenton State Prison who took five hostages last year held a homemade weapon to the throat of a doctor for six hours today before releasing him, officials said.

title: Food as Preventive Medicine: Concept Finds Receptive Minds
description: FOR most people, food serves many purposes: it fuels the body, pleases the palate and satisfies the soul. But increasingly, Americans are also looking to food to prevent disease and promote good health. They cut out egg yolks to avoid cholesterol, load up on fresh vegetables and high-fiber cereals to reduce cancer risks and drink low-fat milk to stave off osteoporosis.

title: Marsh Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
New York Tries to Press Pace of Shoreham Talks
description: State officials pressed today to settle the remaining details of their accord with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the utility's Shoreham Nuclear Power Station so that the agreement could be presented to other state agencies within a week.

title: TVI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Western Health Plans reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bay Banks Inc., Boston, a bank holding company, elected Steven P. Erwin treasurer.

title: Review/Theater; New 'Cherry Orchard' Uses Radical Approach To the Popular Classic
description: Some directors revive classics, others deconstruct them. A few such as Lucian Pintilie and Peter Brook are theatrical explorers reinventing classics. Coincidentally, Mr. Pintilie and Mr. Brook each recently applied his wizardry to ''The Cherry Orchard.'' Mr. Brook's version, produced earlier this season by the Brooklyn Academy of Music, stripped the play of its non-essential trappings, distilling it to its emotional core. Mr. Pintilie's version, currently at the Arena Stage, is equally fascinating but even more radical.

title: Universal Voltronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree to Widen Student Exchange
description: The United States and the Soviet Union reached an agreement in principle today to increase the number of high school exchange students over the next two years.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Run Past Mavericks
description: While it's generally conceded that the home team has a significant advantage in the National Basketball Association playoffs, the turnabout that has occurred between the Dallas Mavericks and the Los Angeles Lakers has been dramatic.

title: Jackson Says He Deserves Thought as Running Mate
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he deserved to be considered for the Vice-Presidential nomination but that he did not know whether he would accept if Michael S. Dukakis offered it.

title: Luria, L & Son Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $357,000 from an accounting change.

title: Electronic Data Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Virginia Ram, Episcopal Leader, Dies at 65
description: Virginia Ram, program director of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in East Los Angeles and a former national Episcopal leader, died May 18 at her home in Los Angeles, apparently of heart failure. She was 65 years old.

title: Mitsubishi Motors Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; 1988 figures are translated at the exchange rate on March 31, 1988 of 125 yen equals U.S. $1.00, and the 1987 figures at the exchange rate of 146 yen equals U.S. $1.

title: Ethiopia to Let the U.N. Monitor Famine Aid
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has won permission from the Ethiopian Government to send United Nations observers to monitor the distribution of food to starving people in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, officials reported today.

title: New Zealand Wineries Present 21 of Their Best
description: IN an impressive effort intended primarily to establish an East Coast beachhead, a delegation of seven New Zealanders representing a handful of the country's 122 wineries came to New York last week to show 21 ambitious wines.

title: ADC Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Japan's Trade Surplus Dips
description: Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus plunged to $1.63 billion in the first 20 days of May from $2.84 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today. The figure compares with a $3.23 billion surplus in the corresponding period in April.

title: Pregnant Women Received Drug Without Consent, Hospital Says
description: Scores of pregnant patients were given a drug without their knowledge or consent as part of a study to test the use of the drug in Caesarean deliveries, according to officials at Cook County Hospital.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Kimberly Kubiak has been named a partner at Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago.

title: Next, Beware Demon Hamburger?
description: A California inventor claims to have developed a process for treating alcohol so that it will not burn off during cooking. ''I've made 60-proof chili, 40-proof mayonnaise and 44-proof bread,'' said Hana Chaus, a chemist in Ridgecrest, Calif. ''The possibilities are endless.''

title: Kellwood Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. to Enforce Sanctions for Hiring Illegal Aliens
description: Beginning Wednesday, immigration officials are stepping up enforcement against employers who knowingly hire aliens who are in the country illegally.

title: Shades of the 50's! The 'Little' Fur Will Be Big Again
description: THE diverse appeal of furs started with the warmth factor, following the fig leaf as a body covering way back when. But while women still insist that they buy furs to keep them warm, that is by no means the only reason. Conspicuous consumption and sybaritic elegance also count.

title: To Our Readers
description: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas. These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue. We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

title: 2 Facing Ouster in Furor Over A's
description: Two faculty members accused of offering A grades to students at California State University's Northridge campus in exchange for selling $100 in raffle tickets have been notified they will be dismissed, their attorney said.

title: Excerpts From the President's Talks to Artists and Students
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech to Soviet cultural and artistic figures today, and from his speech to students at Moscow State University and a question-and-answer session with them. Remarks to Artists

title: Buy G.M.? Iacocca Pondered It in '87
description: Top executives of Chrysler and Allied-Signal seriously considered a $40 billion hostile takeover of General Motors last year. The discussions came while G.M. was reeling from a sharp loss of market share and the turmoil surrounding the ouster of H. Ross Perot from the board of directors.

title: Floor Traders Had Big Profit Despite Crash
description: Even after being hit with huge losses in last October's stock market crash, the traders appointed by the New York Stock Exchange to monitor and smooth the flow of trading in individual stocks had their most profitable year ever in 1987, according to confidential exchange financial records.

title: Retailers Say Ruling Will Tend to Stabilize Prices
description: Both discounters and other retailers said yesterday that the Supreme Court's decision yesterday to continue to allow many gray-market imports would encourage such imports and tend to stabilize prices of many goods.

title: Entertaining In Moscow: A Guest List
description: Following are the guests who attended a dinner given tonight by the President and Nancy Reagan at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, as released by the White House. SOVIET GUESTS Yuri N. Afanasyev, historian, and his wife. Bella Akhmadulina, writer and poet, and Boris Messerer, painter. Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, armed forces Chief of Staff, and his wife. Nina Ananiashvili, Bolshoi Ballet dancer. Irina Antonova, director of the Pushkin Museum. Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, a Deputy Foreign Minister, and his wife. Fyodor M. Burlatsky, political commentator and biographer, and his wife. Anatoly F. Dobrynin, a secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee, and his wife, Irina. Nina L. Dorliak, wife of Svyatoslav Richter, pianist. Yuri V. Dubinin, Ambassador to the United States, and his wife, Liana. Dr. Svyatoslav N. Fyodorov, director, Eye Microsurgery Clinic, and his wife. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, and his wife, Raisa. Yuri N. Grigorovich, director of the Bolshoi Ballet, and Natalya Bessmertnova, prima ballerina. Yekaterina Gordeyeva, 1988 Olympic gold medalist in pairs figure skating. Andrei A. Gromyko, President of the Supreme Soviet, and his wife. Gary Kasparov, world chess champion. Elem G. Klimov, head of Soviet cinematographers' union. Vitaly A. Korotich, editor of Ogonyok, and his wife. Anatoly G. Kovalev, a First Deputy Foreign Minister, and his wife. Andris Liepa, Bolshoi Ballet dancer. Yegor K. Ligachev, a secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee, and his wife. Dmitri S. Likhachev, chairman, Cultural Fund, and his wife. Guri I. Marchuk, president of the Academy of Sciences, and his wife. Yuri D. Maslyukov, a Deputy Prime Minister, and his wife. Arkady B. Migdal, nuclear physicist and member of the Academy of Sciences, and his wife. Vsevolod S. Murakhovsky, a Deputy Prime Minister and chairman of the State Committee for the Agro-Industrial Complex, and his wife. Bulat Okudzhava, balladeer and poet, and his wife. Sergei Paradzhanov, Armenian filmmaker. Lyudmila Petrushevskaya, playwright, and Boris Pavlov. Yevgeny M. Primakov, director, Institute of World Economy and International Relations of the Academy of Sciences. Georgi P. Razumovsky, a secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee, and his wife. Gennadi Rozhdestvensky, conductor, and Veronika Posnikova. Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Prime Minister, and his wife. Roald Z. Sagdeyev, director, Institute of Space Research, and his wife. Andrei D. Sakharov, Nobel Peace laureate and physicist, and Yelena G. Bonner, also a human rights advocate. Alfred Schnitke, composer, and his wife. Rodion Shchedrin, composer. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Foreign Minister, and his wife, Nanuli. Dr. Nikolai P. Shmelev, economist, U.S.A. and Canada Institute, and his wife. Valentina Tereshkova, former astronaut, chairman, All-Union Friendship Society, full member of the Central Committee. Tatyana Tolstaya, writer. Vladislav Tretyak, hockey goaltender, and his wife. Yevgeny P. Velikhov, vice president of Soviet Academy of Sciences, and wife. Anatoly and Irina Virgiansky, daughter and son-in-law of Mr. and Mrs. Gorbachev. Yuli M. Vorontsov, a First Deputy Foreign Minister, and his wife. Andrei Vosnesensky, poet, and Zoya Boguslavskaya, writer. Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, member of Secretariat, and his wife. Yegor Yakovlev, editor of Moscow News, and his wife, Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov, Defense Minister, and his wife. Oleg Yefremov, Moscow Art Theater. Viktor Yerofeyev, writer, and his wife. Lev N. Zaikov, Politburo member and first secretary of Moscow Party Committee, and his wife. Mark Zakharov, director, and his wife. Vasily G. Zakharov, Minister of Culture, and his wife. Tatyana Zaslavskaya, economist. AMERICAN GUESTS Howard H. Baker Jr., White House chief of staff. Dr. James H. Billington, Librarian of Congress. Peter Brown, producer, ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' Dave Brubeck, pianist, and his wife, Iola. Robert C. Byrd, Senate majority leader. Frank C. Carlucci 3d, Secretary of Defense. Jack L. Courtemanche, chief of staff to Mrs. Reagan. Rhett B. Dawson, White House operations director. Bob Dole, Senate minority leader. Kenneth M. Duberstein, deputy White House chief of staff. Marlin Fitzwater, White House spokesman. Thomas C. Griscom, White House communications director. John M. Joyce, deputy chief of mission, United States Embassy, and his wife. Max M. Kampelman, counselor of the State Department and chief arms control negotiator. Nelson Ledsky, White House deputy senior director for national security affairs. Jack F. Matlock Jr., Ambassador to the Soviet Union, and his wife, Rebecca. Arthur Mitchell, artistic director, Dance Theatre of Harlem. Paul H. Nitze, Ambassador at large. Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, national security adviser. Rozanne L. Ridgway, Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs. Selwa Roosevelt, chief of protocol. Edward L. Rowny, special representative for arms control and disarmament negotiations. George P. Shultz, Secretary of State, and his wife, Helena. Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency. OTHER GUEST Andrew Lloyd Webber, British composer.

title: What a Relief, Allen Goes 9
description: Neil Allen, summoned from the bullpen in the first inning and asked to pitch in emergency relief, offered the Yankees an emotional lift at a difficult time tonight. The veteran right-hander retired the first 19 batters he faced, pitched nine innings and took the Yanks to a 5-0 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

description: Pietro Valot, the chef at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, prepared the meal for the dinner there tonight. Here is the menu. Lobster Bisque Supreme of Chicken With Truffle Sauce Cherry Tomatoes With Fleurons Carrot Souffle June Peas Mixed Green Salad Brie Frozen Chocolate Mousse With Vanilla Sauce The Wines La Crema Reserve chardonnay 1986 Chalone pinot noir 1981 Scharffenberger Summit Cuvee 1984

description: Despite rising mortgage interest rates, sales of new single-family homes rose in April for the third straight month, the Commerce Department said today.

description: The Dutch police have recovered three paintings that were stolen less than two weeks ago from this city's Stedelijk (Municipal) Museum, a police spokesman said today.

description: b-Net loss

Supply-Side Revolution Alive and Well
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Abbreviated Social Register
description: The century-old Social Register Association, which consolidated its 11 city editions into one volume in 1977, now says it will bow to subscriber demand and bring out an abbreviated directory next March for New York only. This does not mean an end to the regular edition.

title: Education; Teacher Shortage? Recruit Abroad
description: With a real shortage of teachers in many school districts and little chance that the supply will match the demand anytime soon, some districts are turning to foreign sources.

title: First 100 Days
description: In less than eight months the next President will take office and the first 100 days of his Administration will begin. With that in mind, the Economic Policy Institute is preparing to focus public attention on some of the issues that the new President will face in ''the traditional 'honeymoon' period that sets the tone for a new Administration.''

title: Alphabet Soup
description: When the Strategic Defense Initiative Organization recently sent Congress a report on its program for a defense against missiles, it included a glossary to explain its alphabet soup from ABE to XRL.

title: Measures Are Announced to Curb School Violence
description: Students who attack school workers will be expelled for the remainder of the school year under sweeping security measures announced yesterday by Mayor Koch and Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Congress's Salary Plan
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a law that gave Congress a $12,000 pay raise last year.

title: Whiting Petroleum Corp () reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Digital Optronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Walters Settlement
description: The University of Alabama and the sports agent Norby Walters have reportedly reached a settlement that is expected to result in dismissal of criminal charges against Walters, who signed contracts with two Alabama basketball players before their eligibility expired. Walters faces misdemeanor charges of tampering with a sports event, commercial bribery and deceptive trade practices because he had signed contracts with Derrick McKey and Terry Coner while they were playing basketball for Alabama. The Atlanta Constitution reported today that the university had reached a $200,000 settlement with Walters and was to receive the first $50,000 payment Wednesday. As part of the settlement, the newspaper said, Walters transmitted a signed consent decree yesterday in which he promised never to conceal any dealings with an eligible student-athlete from the Southeastern Conference. Don Valeska, an assistant attorney general for Alabama, said the settlement and the decree would lead to the charges being dropped against Walters in Tuscaloosa County today or tomorrow.(AP)

title: Colors of the Moon
description: Tuesday morning's blue moon was a welcome sight: something to restart the brain after a lazy, prematurely summery holiday weekend. People who take the heavens for granted learned on this occasion that a blue moon is the second of two full moons in the same month - a phenomenon that recurs only, well, once in a blue moon. The last time was July 31, 1985; the next time will be Dec. 31, 1990.

title: Macmillan Will Split Into 2 Parts
description: In a move that caught few Wall Street professionals by surprise, Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information company, took strong defensive moves yesterday in response to a takeover offer from the Robert Bass Group of Texas.

title: Books of The Times; Two Faces of Picasso, Predominantly the Darker
description: Picasso Creator and Destroyer By Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington Illustrated. 558 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: President Charms Students, But His Ideas Lack Converts
description: President Reagan gave a lesson in American civics today to about 600 students and faculty members at Moscow State University, the alma mater of both Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa.

title: The Summit Schedule
description: All times are local. Moscow is eight hours ahead of Eastern daylight time. 10 A.M. President Reagan meets with Mikhail S. Gorbachev at St. Catherine's Hall in the Kremlin. They exchange formal documents of ratification of the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles. 10:30 A.M. Nancy Reagan tours the Tretyakov Gallery, accompanied by Raisa Gorbachev. Noon The President returns to Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence. 1 P.M. Mr. Gorbachev holds a news conference at the Foreign Ministry. 4 P.M. Mr. Reagan holds a news conference at Spaso House. 6 P.M. Mr. and Mrs. Reagan and Mrs. and Mrs. Gorbachev attend a special performance of the Bolshoi Ballet. 7:55 P.M. The Reagans arrive at the Gorbachev dacha on the outskirts of Moscow for dinner. 10:35 P.M. The Reagans return to Spaso House.

title: Data Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax credits of $1,155,000 for the quarter and $1,973,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago results are restated to include the operations of Compac Microelectronics Inc., merged with the company in December on a pooling-of-interests basis. Acquisition costs of Compac are included in the expenses of the fourth quarter.

title: New Zealand Hoists Sail Off California Coast
description: Michael Fay is, by choice, not a sailor, but he looked every bit the yachtsman today as he clung to the rail of his 123-foot America's Cup challenger, New Zealand, which was under sail for the first time in United States waters.

title: Campbell Bids For Freshbake
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it had offered 162 pence a share, or $2.99, for the British frozen food organization Freshbake Foods Group P.L.C. The bid values the company at $:109 million, or about $200 million. Campbell, based in Camden, N.J., said it had received commitments for 20.94 million of Freshbake's ordinary shares, or 31.12 percent of the company's common shares outstanding.

title: F.T.C. Tentatively Backs Lucky Pact
description: The Federal Trade Commission has tentatively accepted an agreement for the American Stores Company to acquire Lucky Stores Inc., but it said that American must sell up to 37 of its California stores. Under the proposed deal, American agreed to give up at least 31, and possibly as many as 37, California stores. American, based in Salt Lake City, may sell either its stores or those of Lucky in the designated areas, the F.T.C. said. Lucky has its headquarters in Dublin, Calif.

title: Redken Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $688,000 from the sale of land for the quarter and 9 months.

title: CoastAmerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
New Schools Chief Lifting Spirits But Some Say He Lags in Albany
description: Dr. Richard R. Green has spent his first three months as Schools Chancellor telling New Yorkers that he intends to change the face of the city schools. In speeches, often revivalist in style, he has stressed that the city cannot survive with what he calls an ill-educated underclass.

title: INSIDE
description: The 9-Year-Old Murder

title: Dynamic Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-earlier quarter sales included a one-time $332,000 commercial project.

title: J Higby's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Certron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $16,000.

title: Right to Privacy Is Thrown Out With the Trash; Ends and Means
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: Soccer West Germany in Olympics: West Germany, helped by two goals from Juergen Klinsmann, beat Rumania, 3-0, in Dortmund, West Germany, yesterday and clinched the 16th and final berth in the Seoul Olympics tournament. The West Germans pressed from the start and took the lead in the 37th minute.(AP) Ultramarathon World Record Set: Yiannis Kouros, the Greek ultramarathon runner who is considered the best in the world at all distances beyond 100 miles, enhanced his reputation Monday night when he broke the world mark for 1,000 miles by more than a day and a half, winning the Sri Chinmoy 1,000-mile world championship at Flushing Meadow Park. Kouros, 32 years old, finished in 10 days 10 hours 35 minutes, breaking the record held by Stu Mittelman of New York (11 days 20 hours 36 minutes). Mittelman did not compete in this year's race. Boxing Leon Spinks Knocked Out: Tony Morrison, a last-minute replacement for Phil Brown, knocked out Leon Spinks in 33 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 10-round bout Monday night at the Marriott Hotel in Trumbull, Conn. Morrison, who is from Nova Scotia, finished the 34-year-old Spinks with the first barrage of punches he threw. Spinks, who was wearing knee pads, was up at the count of 8, but was glassy-eyed. So the referee, Matt Mullaney, waved an end to the bout. (AP)

title: Right to Privacy Is Thrown Out With the Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Glints of Hope for U.N. Food Agency
description: The head of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization is displaying a new willingness to cooperate with the United States and other Western members in introducing administrative changes, diplomats and officials of the Rome-based agency say.

title: Thousand Trails reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter earnings included a tax loss carryforward credit of $643,000.

title: Velveeta Has Birthday; Some Celebrate
description: IT has been 60 years since Velveeta, the pasteurized process cheese spread, was introduced by Kraft, and many Americans have grown up with it.

title: Vista Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Five Go on Trial In the Burning Of Foster Home
description: Five homeowners from Flushing, Queens, went on trial yesterday on charges that they set fire to a house on their block in an effort to keep New York City from using it as a shelter for foster-care infants.

title: Guilty Plea From W. R. Grace In a Case of Water Pollution
description: W. R. Grace & Company, which two years ago was reported to have paid $8 million for polluting wells in suburban Woburn, pleaded guilty today to lying about the amount of a chemical it used at a plant there.

title: Three-Star Cuisine Deep in Burgundy
description: MICHEL LORAIN is a robust, outgoing man of 54 with a harmonica-size mustache and a lyrical sentimentality for traditional Burgundian cooking. Jean-Michel Lorain, his 29-year-old son, is soft-spoken and contemplative, a widely traveled, inquisitive chef with perfect pitch for popular tastes. Irving Berlin paired with Andrew Lloyd Webber.

title: Reagan and Gorbachev Toasts: 'Voice' of Peace and a Vision of the Future
description: Following are excerpts from the toasts by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a dinner in honor of Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, at Spaso House. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by a Soviet interpreter. Reagan Toast

title: Concept 90 Marketing reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Boxing Notebook; ESPN Has Share Of Arum's Card
description: The last major pay-per-view card that Bob Arum ran was last October when he had the World Boxing Council middleweight title match between Thomas Hearns and Juan Roldan as his headline bout.

title: Vortec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $140,476.

title: Bellevue Once Again Needs a Manager Before Drift Sets In
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco Pupils Told About AIDS by Victims
description: Hene Kelly, a teacher at Woodrow Wilson High School, stood at the front of her classroom and put her arms around Christian Haren and Edgardo Rodriguez, two men who have AIDS.

title: Writers' Readings
description: A reading by the novelist Mary Gordon will open a four-part series of free readings by writers on June 8 in Barnard Hall of Barnard College, 3009 Broadway, at 117th Street. Others who will read from their work are the poet Sharon Olds (June 14); Hugh Nissenson and Ann Birstein (June 22), and the poet David Ignatow (June 28). All readings are at 8 P.M. Information: 280-8693.

title: Beazer Said to Reach Deal With Koppers at $61 a Share
description: After months of fighting off a takeover bid from Beazer P.L.C., the Koppers Corporation has reached an understanding with it for a merger under which Beazer would pay $61 a share for Koppers, up from a bid of $60, people familiar with the deal said yesterday.

title: Elster's Homer Lifts Mets
description: To Dave Johnson, the master of understatement, it was ''a good ending.'' To Wally Backman, who knocked in three runs, it was ''the right stuff, and we needed it.'' To Keith Hernandez, who knocked in the tying run in the 10th inning, it was ''uplifting.'' To Jesse Orosco, who was there in the good old days, it was ''definitely 1986, all over again.''

title: From Trump to Fish Farming, Bookmobile Has It
description: Diane Monroe has a vague memory of last going to a public library 14 years ago, before she moved to this Adirondacks hamlet. Her 10-year-old daughter, Jennifer, ''has never been in a real library,'' she said.

title: Rates Rise Again In Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper, which have been rising for well over a month, increased again yesterday, as the bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.4737 percent, up from 7.2694 percent last week.

title: David J. Fitzgibbons Drug Executive, 82
description: David J. Fitzgibbons, retired president of Sterling Drug Inc., died Friday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: United Sets Pact With Italian Airline
description: The Italian state-owned airline, Alitalia, and United Airlines Inc. of the United States have entered a partnership to give United's passengers more access to Europe and make Alitalia a leading competitor in a deregulated world aviation industry. The agreement, similar to one reached between United Airlines and British Airways P.L.C. last December, will make North America more accessible to Italians, while giving United, which does not fly to Europe, access to the southern part of the Continent through Alitalia's flights.

title: New Flyers Coach
description: Paul Holmgren, a former Flyers player, will be hired as coach of Philadelphia today, according to several broadcast reports. Bob Clarke, the general manager, has said Holmgren, 32, now an assistant coach for the Flyers, or John Paddock, coach of the club's affiliate in the American Hockey League, would replace Mike Keenan, who was dismissed May 11. Holmgren was a fan favorite as a right wing with the team from 1975 to 1984. He is the Flyers' career penalty-minute leader with 1,600. (AP)

title: Review/Television; Sills and New York City Opera on Tour in Taiwan
description: In the promotional manner of a school composition about ''What I Did on My Summer Vacation,'' a half-hour film called ''On Tour: New York City Opera'' recounts the company's trip to Taiwan last year. On Channel 31 tonight at 10:30, and on Channel 13 Friday at 10:30, the essay opens with Beverly Sills asking, ''Have you ever wondered what it's like to take a whole opera company - all 225 of us - half way around the world?'' Well, no, actually, but let's get on with it.

title: Stop and Shop Sets Sale of 58 Bradlees
description: The Stop and Shop Companies will sell the Southern division of its Bradlees Department Stores unit, which operates 58 stores in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Washington, Virginia and North Carolina. The stores are strong performers, Stop and Shop said, but the company intends to concentrate its supermarket and department store operations in the Northeast.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Corp., Detroit, will postpone the debut of its Italian-made Maserati TC sports car until July.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Dukakis's Wife Set to Return To Boston for Hospital Care
description: Kitty Dukakis will return home from California on Wednesday to enter Massachusetts General Hospital for tests on what are believed to be two herniated disks in the neck area, the Presidential campaign of her husband, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, announced today.

title: N.C.A.A. Baseball; Freshman Pitcher Leads Stanford to Omaha Series
description: Stanford University reached the College World Series for the fifth time in seven years today. A 16-2 victory over Kentucky, the second over the Wildcats in two days, allowed the defending champion Cardinal to win the Northeast region of the national collegiate tournament and continue a tradition that is as challenging as it is happy.

title: Top Positions Filled By Allied/Federated
description: The combined Allied/Federated department store organization, which has been looking for a leader in the last few weeks during a crucial time in its formation, filled its top posts yesterday with two Federated executives.

title: WINE TALK
description: BESET by the trend toward moderate drinking, wine sales continued to decline for the fifth straight year in 1987, and the slide is expected to continue this year. According to figures compiled by Impact, a trade newsletter, the wine market declined 1.8 percent last year, to 192.3 million cases. That was almost 28 million cases below the 1982 high of 220 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a technical error, the front-page picture of President and Mrs. Reagan with Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev appeared in mirror image in some copies yesterday. In the actual scene, the Reagans appeared at the right.

title: River Oaks Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $341,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months; a reversal of a tax credit of $150,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $114,000 for the 9 months. c-After a gain of $3,883,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $11,000.

title: Right to Privacy Is Thrown Out With the Trash; 'The Tiny Minority'
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Gas Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes about $180,000 of non-recurring charges related to the company's Clinton American merger.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Wins Campaign For British Reserves
description: Young & Rubicam, which is the agency for Army recruiting in the United States, has been named by the Central Office of Information in London to do the advertising for Britain's Volunteer Reserve Forces.

title: CML Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
New York City and M.A.C. Get Higher Bond Ratings
description: The debt ratings for about $18 billion of New York City and Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds were increased yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Chinese Mine Blast Kills 49
description: A gas explosion tore through a coal mine in central China and killed at least 49 people, the official press agency reported today. The agency said only seven people survived the blast Sunday at the Shengfo mine in Huoxian County, Shanxi Province. One person was in serious condition. The explosion caused cave-ins and damaged ventilation facilities, the agency said. The cause of the accident was under investigation. Coal mine accidents are frequent in China, particularly in small mines where safety regulations are ignored.

title: Opening for Democracy in Pakistan
description: When Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, declared himself a democrat four years ago and held the first elections since his 1977 coup, skeptics dismissed his move as cosmetic. A more substantive change could result from the steps he has just taken, sacking his Prime Minister and dissolving the National Assembly - for alleged corruption, indifference to growing lawlessness and delay in transforming Pakistan into an Islamic society.

title: Nuclear Data reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a $2,421,000 charge related to the sale of the company's Danish subsidiary, Molsgaard Medical AS. c-Includes various charges for reserves totaling $1,465,000 for the quarter and $4,465,000 for the year.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Truvel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Surprise Market Rally Sends Dow Up 74.68
description: LEAD: The stock market moved sharply higher yesterday, taking traders and market analysts by surprise.

title: Focus Put on Poindexter in Iran-Contra Case
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, outlining some of his case in court papers, argued today that John M. Poindexter, the President's former national security adviser, played a prominent role in a broad conspiracy to defraud the Government.

title: Don't Open Any Doors For Iran's Mullahs
description: To the Editor:

title: Gladys Shultz Sanders, Consultant, 69
description: Gladys Shultz Sanders, a public relations consultant and writer, died of cancer Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Crazy Eddie Shows Deficit For 4th Quarter and Year
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the chain of electronics stores whose new management is trying to sort out questionable past financial statements and inventory counts, yesterday reported losses for the final quarter and year ended Feb. 28.

title: Synercom Technology reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $29,000 related to the reduction of the federal tax provision due to the quarter's pretax loss.

title: Eve Poulson Purvis, Women's Rights Leader, 69
description: Eve Poulson Purvis, a former member of the Woman's Commission on Civil Rights, has died at the age of 69. Mrs. Purvis died Sunday in Community Hospital.

title: Black Hat, Farewell
description: Call me slow on the uptake, but I am still baffled about what was going on in ''The Bourne Identity,'' a mini-series that kept me so tightly glued to the TV tube last month that wild horses were needed to tear me away.

title: Review/Ballet; New Dancers in Balanchine's 'Jewels'
description: Darci Kistler, Lindsay Fischer and Peter Boal, who all stepped into new roles in George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, typify the thoroughbred elegance the Balanchine style infuses into the best of the New York City Ballet's dancers.

title: Dining With Toddlers
description: To The Living Section:

title: HWC Distribution reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington
description: WASHINGTON will raise its California food consciousness this month at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Pauley Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said results for earlier periods have not been restated to reflect Pauley's acquisition of all of the outstanding shares of Hondo Oil & Gas Co. on Jan. 19, so figures for the latest and prior fiscal years are not comparable. Fiscal 1988 earnings reflect 6 months' operations of Hondo and one month's operations of the Fletcher Oil & Refining Co., acquired March 1. The company also said that in 1988 Pauley's fiscal year was changed to close on Sept. 30 rather than Aug. 31.

title: Duarte Seeks Treatment of Stomach Disease
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte left for Washington today for treatment of a stomach disease that he described as an ulcer ''of a malignant nature.''

title: The Old China, and the New
description: LEAD: This year marks the 15th anniversary of China's reopening of cultural and business ties with the United States, a period that has seen monumental shifts in China as well as in our perceptions of it. Just for starters, six technocrats in dapper business suits have replaced the Gang of Five. Economic pragmatism has displaced the Cultural Revolution.

title: South Africa Clerics Back Protest Strikes
description: Agreeing on a campaign of nonviolent action to end apartheid, a group of religious leaders decided today to back protest strikes next week, apparently in defiance of Government restrictions.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Mikhail Gorbachev expressed frustration over the lack of progress in work on a treaty reducing strategic nuclear weapons. President Reagan called on Soviet citizens to support Mr. Gorbachev's programs. Page A1 President Reagan found his audience in meetings with intellectuals and students, who found Mr. Reagan's charm and self-assuredness refreshing. Their laughter and applause seemed heartfelt. A1

title: Winthrop Insured Mortgage reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,236,838 from a defaulted mortgage. The share earnings are in cents a unit.

title: Austin Mayor Is Unseated
description: A former City Councilman, Lee Cooke, has defeated Mayor Frank Cooksey in his bid for a second three-year term. With all the vote in, Mr. Cooke had 36,985 votes, or 58.4 percent, to 26,308, or 41.6 percent, for Mayor Cooksey. At issue in the campaign were the city's sagging economy and rising taxes and utility rates.

title: Iowa Tire Concern Buys 6.6% of Hon
description: Bandag Inc. has purchased 6.6 percent of Hon Industries and said that it intended to raise its stake in the metal and wood office furniture manufacturer to up to 10 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Bandag said that it purchased the shares for investment purposes only. Hon has more than 20 million shares outstanding. At today's closing price of $18.75 a share, the company, whose stock is traded over the counter, is worth more than $375 million.

title: Cassini Awarded $16 Million
description: Oleg Cassini, the fashion designer, was awarded $16 million yesterday by a Federal jury in his lawsuit against Jovan Inc., which had an exclusive license to market Cassini perfumes and cosmetics.

title: About New York; Joel Zeltzer: An Alternative To Rikers Island
description: Anthony is a schizophrenic who smokes crack, a deadly combination. Two years ago, for no apparent reason, Anthony blew his brother's head off with a shotgun.

title: Richard W. Morin, Envoy and Librarian, 85
description: Richard Wedge Morin, a former State Department official and later Dartmouth College's librarian, died Sunday at the age of 85.

title: Unit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: TEN years ago in Seattle, when Rinjing Dorje was down to his last $350, he had few skills to offer. True, he was a published author, whose work drew on folklore from his Tibetan culture. But ''Tales of Uncle Tompa,'' a collection of folktales of a rather ribald cast, wasn't exactly moving up the sales charts.

title: Steinberg Doctor Admits Guilt
description: A doctor pleaded guilty yesterday to his role in the unlawful adoption two years ago of a newborn boy by Joel Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum, the Greenwich Village couple charged in the death of Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old girl they raised.

title: Soviet People Are Waiting
description: This city is in a state of what can be called suspended inanimation. The Reagan-Gorbachev summit provided a few days of sunny spectacle, which should not be underestimated, even though there were no major new agreements.

title: Plea on Savings Industry Funds
description: A senior Treasury Department official said when the Federal fund that insures deposits in savings institutions needs more money, the industry - not taxpayers - should make the first contribution.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Halt in AIDS Virus Growth Is Discovered in 4 Patients
description: Researchers studying the course of infection with the AIDS virus have discovered four cases in which the virus apparently became entirely dormant in patients' bodies.

title: Marion Armbruster Pierce, Educator, 79
description: Dr. Marion Armbruster Pierce, an educator and research scientist, died of a stroke Thursday at the Wilmington (Del.) Medical Center. She was 79 years old and lived in Wilmington.

title: Stock Prices Rise Sharply
description: The stock market soared, surprising experts. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 74.68 points, or 3.82 percent, to close at 2,031.12. Page D1.

title: Danish Leader Asked To Form Government
description: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark asked acting Prime Minister Poul Schlueter today to form a new Government, three weeks after an inconclusive election.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: THE microwave oven can speed up your barbecuing duties and can produce succulent results without any loss of flavor. Partly precook spareribs, chicken and even some vegetables - but not steak - in the microwave oven, with or without a sauce or marinade, and then put them on the grill.

title: Telling What's in Your Food
description: A lack of coordination among Federal agencies is to blame for inconsistent and sometimes misleading information about the thousands of new food products marketed every year, according to the General Accounting Office, the investigative research arm of Congress.

title: Democrats Friendly, Not Feuding, In New York
description: As their party prepares for its biennial state convention in Albany tomorrow, New York State Democrats are in a stronger and more harmonious position than they have been for at least a half century.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Barbecue Buys

title: Stockholder Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-President of Sterling Gets Key Beecham Job
description: James G. Andress, who resigned as president and chief operating officer of Sterling Drug after it was taken over by the Eastman Kodak Company, has joined the big British Beecham Group as chairman of its Beecham Pharmaceuticals unit.

title: Corrections
description: A schematic drawing of an electron microscope yesterday with the obituary of its developer, Ernst Ruska, described the process of magnification incorrectly. A specimen is placed above the magnetic objective lens, which produces a magnified image.

title: Trail Blazers Deal
description: Larry Weinberg, the majority owner of the Portland Trail Blazers, said yesterday that the club would be sold to Paul Allen, a Seattle businessman. Weinberg said that Allen, 35 years old, would be sole owner and would be ''committed to keeping the franchise in this area.'' Details of the sale were not disclosed. Weinberg said he expected the National Basketball Association to approve the deal within two to three weeks. Weinberg, 62, a Los Angeles resident, became majority owner and president of the team in 1975.(AP)

title: Petrie Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary after-tax gain of $8.3 million from the extinguishment of long-term debt. Petrie said the first quarter results included the company's net equity interest in Paul Harris Stores, in which Petrie holds a 23 1/2 percent stake. The company also said its equity results in Paul Harris amounted to a loss of $1,036,000 for the latest first quarter, compared with a net of $227,000 for year-ago period.

title: Dry Weather Raises Prices Of All Crops
description: Continued hot and dry weather over the Grain Belt sent prices of all basic farm crops and livestock soaring yesterday. If the weather does not improve soon, the resultant higher food costs could ignite another bout of inflation next fall, analysts said.

title: Delphi Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Icahn Suit Charges Texaco Greenmail Bid
description: Carl C. Icahn amended his lawsuit against Texaco Inc. yesterday to include an accusation he had made publicly last week: that the company offered him ''greenmail'' to sell his 14.8 percent share.

title: Bank Officers Suspended
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation announced yesterday that it had suspended three officers in its corporate trust division, which handles record keeping and payment of funds for corporate and local government bond issues.

title: Yugoslav Communists End Raucous Meeting
description: A three-day Communist Party conference, during which delegates castigated party leaders and demanded their removal, ended today with a final statement saying that the Communist Party is capable of repairing Yugoslavia's chaotic economy.

title: Cato Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,433,000.

title: Smoke Alarm Law Is Signed
description: Governor Cuomo signed a law today requiring smoke detectors in all one- and two-family homes. State law already requires smoke alarms in multiple dwellings, in new homes and in one- and two-family homes when they are sold. The new law takes effect in 180 days. Legislators who sponsored the measure have said they would rely on voluntary compliance and public education on smoke alarms to enforce the law.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Less Investing by Foreigners
description: Spending by foreign investors on United States business enterprises last year declined from the record 1986 level but remained well above the levels of earlier years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Court Fails To Consider Big Awards
description: The Supreme Court today signaled great reluctance to confront one of the most significant new issues brought before it in years: whether the Constitution curbs multimillion-dollar awards of ''punitive'' damages in civil suits.

title: St. Regis to Be Closed for at Least a Year
description: The marble bannisters leading from the main lobby still have about them a pale shine. The iron plating in the fireplace of the Louis XIV Room still bears the engraving of fleurs-de-lis, untarnished. And Old King Cole still stares down from his throne in a Maxfield Parrish oil. All the understated touches are in place that have given the St. Regis its status in as one of the grand European-style hotels in New York.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Esterline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $247,000 for the quarter and $715,000 for the 6 months.

title: Edna Boyne Campbell, Library Founder, 80
description: Edna Boyne Campbell, known to generations of Morningside Heights residents through her association with the Morningside Junior Library, died of cancer May 10 at her home in Manhattan. She was 80 years old.

title: Torres Successor Picked
description: Administration sources for Governor Cuomo said today that John C. McGinley, a 26-year veteran of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, would be named to succeed Jose Torres as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: British Magazine Plants Flag in U.S.
description: Even in conversation, William Buford sifts through his words gingerly, picking them with care and seriousness. The literary magazine he edits, Granta, may come out four times a year, but it is no quarterly to Mr. Buford. ''I'd never call it a quarterly,'' he says. ''It sounds like death.''

title: Education; Fourth Graders Writing Biography And Opening a Door to History
description: In an unusual approach to learning history and writing, the children in Milly Sturman's fourth-grade class are spending the entire year writing biographies of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The biographies are full of facts and anecdotes and the pristine sense of injustice of 9-year-olds.

title: More Threats to Privacy Seen As Computer Links Broaden
description: Computer-based technologies that have brought sweeping changes in the way Americans work and play have also increased - by several orders of magnitude - threats to their privacy. Taken in isolation, each new technology, like a computerized supermarket checkout system, is reasonably harmless. But drawn together, they create the potential for sketching a detailed electronic profile of virtually every American citizen.

title: Pakistanis Barely Fazed by Shake-Up
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's abrupt dismissal of his Cabinet and Parliament came as a complete surprise here, and to no one more than to his Prime Minister, Mohammed Khan Junejo.

title: Dynatrend Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
EATING WELL
description: LEAD: IN this, the high season of fat, cholesterol and calories, it is quite easy to ignore the quiet seas within you. Yet when the weather grows warm, issues of thirst, dehydration, electrolyte balance and more come to the fore.

title: National Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated. The bank said it received $23 million in interest payments from Brazil since the beginning of the year, which was recorded in the second quarter. The bank also said an identical amount of $23 million was added to the general provisions for losses on Brazilian loans and to the provision for loan losses for the second quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jersey May Pay For Heart Drug
description: Hospitals in New Jersey have been told that they can request Federal Medicare reimbursements this year for T.P.A., the expensive new heart drug made by Genentech Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about television coverage of the Moscow summit meeting referred incorrectly to ABC's coverage of President Reagan's meeting on Monday with 100 Soviet dissidents at the United States Ambassador's residence. The coverage was interrupted only for periodic comments on the proceedings.

title: Watsco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Prosecutor Is Reported to Rule Out Seeking Any Indictment of Meese
description: James C. McKay, the independent prosecutor who has been investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for a year, will not seek an indictment of Mr. Meese when he submits his final report within the next two weeks, people familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Wedgestone Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Italian Support Cited on Irving Bid
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana said that Italian regulators had indicated that they would approve its bid to buy 51 percent of the Irving Bank Corportion at $80 a share. The offer has the approval of Irving's management and directors and is competing with a hostile offer from the Bank of New York Company. Banca Commerciale's bid must still be approved by the Federal Reserve Board, which is expected to take several months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bathroom Journal Fails, But a New Idea Is Due
description: The Bathroom Journal has gone down the tube. But the disaster has taught a valuable lesson to Michael Cohen, public relations man turned publisher.

title: Weltman Signs
description: Harry Weltman has signed a new multiyear contract as the vice president and general manager of the Nets, who finished the season at 19-63, the second-worst record in the National Basketball Association. The Nets did not disclose contract terms, but sources close to the team said the new contract was for two years. Weltman, who joined the club late in the 1986-87 season, was in the final year of his contract.(AP)

title: Track and Field; N.C.A.A. Title Meet a Test for Olympics
description: With the Olympic trials six weeks away and the Seoul Games eight weeks after that, the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships will open here Wednesday with the special appeal and importance attached every fourth year.

title: The Pop Life
description: Boz Scaggs Ends Hiatus

title: Market Place; Quiet Redemption Of Bearer Bonds
description: ONE of Wall Street's anachronisms will be replayed today, when newspapers around the country are full of legal advertisements announcing redemptions of tax-exempt bonds.

title: Bronx Democratic Chairman Refuses to Support Prosecutor
description: The Bronx Democratic leader, Assemblyman George Friedman, said yesterday that he would not support District Attorney Paul T. Gentile for a full term. Mr. Gentile said that as a result he would reconsider his candidacy.

title: With Lenin Watching
description: It may have been Ronald Reagan's finest oratorical hour. For this President especially, the setting alone was stunning - an audience of students at Mikhail Gorbachev's own alma mater, beneath a huge bust of Lenin, in front of a mural of the Russian revolution. And the speech Mr. Reagan made on that stage yesterday was equally remarkable, a tribute to the maturing of his own views, to the daring of Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms and to the normalizing of American-Soviet relations.

title: Reviews/Film; In Austria After the War, Unabated Anti-Semitism
description: ''Welcome in Vienna'' is remarkable for its fierce indictment of moral disarray in post-World War II Austria and for its gritty recapturing of 1945 Vienna, as people began to dig out of the rubble, black-market operators bought chocolate bars from American soldiers and sold Mickey Mouse watches to Soviet soldiers, and careerists changed their politics to suit their new masters.

title: Cardiac Control Systems reports earnings for Year to March 31
General Public Utilities reports earnings for 12mo April 30
3 Get Maximum Terms In 'Heinous' Park Killing
description: Calling the crime ''senseless, heinous and abhorrent,'' a judge yesterday sentenced three white men to maximum prison terms for beating to death a Hispanic man they found sleeping on a park bench in Brooklyn.

title: COMMENCEMENT
description: Bernard M. Baruch College

title: Key Geller Clients May Quit, Executive Testifies
description: Several important clients of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein advertising agency have said that they are considering whether to move to another agency, Lord, Geller's chief operating officer, Timothy C. Elliott, has said in secret testimony.

title: Coated Sales Notes Inaccurate Results
description: Coated Sales Inc., one of the fastest-growing companies in recent years, admitted that it had reported inaccurate financial results. Coated Sales, which makes parachutes and textiles for military and industrial use, said it had found ''material irregularities'' in the booking of accounts receivable in an investigation by a committee of its board and its consulting auditor, Coopers & Lybrand.

title: Warsaw Journal; The Very Young Decide to Form a Cutting Edge
description: ''We were very disappointed,'' said Aleksander Wolicki, a 21-year-old history student whose silken curls and wire-rimmed spectacles seemed more typical of a 1960's hippie than a supporter of the outlawed Solidarity movement.

title: Nine Years After Slaying: 'We Think We Got the Guy'
description: The years passed. The woman's greatest fear was that she would go to her grave never knowing who killed her only child.

title: Local Stations Reject Live Reagan Talk
description: President Reagan's speech at Moscow State University yesterday provided a convenient opportunity for live coverage by American morning-news broadcasts, but most local radio stations and at least one television network, CBS, declined to carry the speech live.

title: First Connecticut Small Busiess Investment reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a realized gain on investment of $125,221 and a reduction of $440,884 from a change in unrealized investment depreciation. c-Includes a realized loss on investments of $193,960 plus a change in unrealized appreciation on investments of $205,346.

title: Koch Lesion Is Linked to a Form of Cancer
description: One of five skin lesions removed from Mayor Koch's face last week was found to be a common form of cancer that is rarely life threatening, Mr. Koch said yesterday. It was identical to the type removed from President Reagan's nose last year, he said.

title: Evergood Products reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The latest year loss included an extraordinary credit of $246,585 net of income taxes and related expenses, as a result of the company's settlement of unbilled shipments during an 11-year period.

title: The Crash Of '88? It Almost Happened.
description: LEAD: Throughout the week of March 28th, with nobody paying much attention, the stock market teetered on the edge of another crash. Indeed, if all were known then that is known today, stocks probably would have fallen out of bed again.

title: Crazy Eddie Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income Crazy Eddie said this is its first financial report since new management assumed control of the company on Nov. 6, 1987. The company said current management believes the year-ago fourth quarter and full year figures are inaccurate and should not be relied upon. The latest fourth quarter loss was attributable principally to certain adjustments arising from new management's completion of its evaluation of the company's assets, liabilities and operations and certain business practices and policies of former management, particularly related to reserves for obsolete, slow moving, or damaged inventory, and the understatement of accounts payable arising from former management's issuance of improper debit memos. The loss for the latest year was attributable principally to a $65 million shortfall from book inventory revealed by a physical merchandise inventory conducted on Nov. 9, 1987.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SEA scallops have taken the place of bay scallops in many of my dishes because a devastating brown tide this year has all but eliminated the prized bay scallops I have used from Long Island Sound. But the substitution is no tragedy, since sea scallops can be deliciously tender and sweet if cooked properly.

title: An Ex-P.O.W. Leads Drive for Hanoi Ties
description: When John McCain arrived here as a freshman Republican Congressman in 1983, one of the issues very much on his mind was how the United States should deal with Vietnam. For him it was also a personal matter.

title: Spring Offensive for City Schools
description: At a highly publicized ''summit'' meeting last December, New York State and City education officials set forth a bold agenda to revitalize the city's schools. The city's Board of Education followed up weeks later by selecting Richard Green, a man with a reputation for two-fisted reforms in Minneapolis, as its new Chancellor.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Forced Apart in Russia, Couple Reunites in Style
description: Seventeen years ago, the first time Tanya and Tolya Kodner married, it was a simple event, ''student-like,'' Tanya recalled. There was a quick civil ceremony in Leningrad, a small reception for family and friends, a brief honeymoon.

title: Datapoint Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,043,000 and $2,682,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and in the 9 months there were no common share earnings because the net did not cover preferred dividend requirements. c-Net loss d-Includes extraordinary credits of $87,000 in the quarter and $664,000 in the 9 months.

title: Pritzkers Transfer Stake in Ramada
description: Members of the Pritzker family of Chicago have transferred their 7.2 percent stake in Ramada Inc. to the HCC Corporation, a holding company under their control that has been licensed by gambling regulators in Nevada and New Jersey. The Phoenix-based Ramada has been the subject of takeover rumors, and the Pritzkers, who also control the Hyatt Corporation and Braniff Inc., have said that they were discussing a possible acquisition of Ramada.

title: Forerunner to Trilling
description: To the Editor:

title: Istec Industries & Technoloies Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. The company said dollar figures are translated from new Israeli shekels at the rate of 1.5596 shekels a dollar.

title: Bush Dismisses Advice To Revamp Campaign
description: Vice President Bush brushed aside the concern of some staff and Republican strategists today and said he would not change the style of his Presidential campaign.

title: Hewlett-Packard In Zenith Accord
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would purchase and market a version of the Zenith Data Systems' Supersport 286 Model 20, a battery-operated portable computer based on the 80286 microprocessor of the Intel Corporation. Terms were not disclosed, but Hewlett-Packard said the accord was an extension of a relationship under which it has provided support for Zenith Data Systems, a subsidiary of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, on contracts with important commercial and governmental accounts.

title: Reagans' Dinner in Moscow Draws Diverse Soviet Crowd
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, entertained Mikhail S. Gorbachev, his wife, Raisa, and a variety of Soviet officials, artists and athletes tonight with dinner at the American Ambassador's residence here.

title: Star Classics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jiffy Lube International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $219,000.

title: Continental Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Lady's Day of Poise and Pause
description: Nancy Reagan gently stormed the winter palace today, taking in the art of the Italian Renaissance masters and the gilded life of the Russian czars on a tour whose speed was set at fast forward.

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its latest earnings represent $5.65 a share for approximately 15 million shares of outstanding participating preferred stock and $83.06 a share for 100,000 shares of outstanding common stock. A year-ago the company reported first quarter share earnings of $3.81 for preferred stock and $52.31 for common stock. Reclassifications have been made in these financial statements to certain 1987 amounts as previously reported in order to make them consistent with the presentation of 1988 amounts.

title: Azerbaijani City Shut By Armenian Strikers
description: Thousands of Armenians in the Azerbaijan republic stayed away from work today in a general strike that shut factories and mass transportation in a city at the center of an ethnic dispute, a resident of the area said.

title: Houston
description: THE potato-chip market is getting hotter - as in spicier -thanks largely to a Houston company, Bob's Texas Style Chips, whose goal is to ''make your eyes water,'' its president, Robert Rod, said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Magazine Ad Pages Up
