description: In April, magazine members of the Publishers Information Bureau carried 15,102 pages of advertising, an increase of 5.2 percent from April 1987, while their advertising revenues were up 9.7 percent, to $533.7 million.

title: AM International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,649,000 for the quarter and $453,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After gains from discontinued operations of $1,386,000 and $3,934,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said in the year-ago 9 months preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Dispute Threatens P.L.O.-Syrian Reconciliation
description: A recent reconciliation between Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization has suffered a setback as a new dispute has broken out between Yasir Arafat and the Damascus Government.

title: CBS-TV Sets Restructuring
description: The CBS Broadcast Group yesterday announced a restructuring of its television network, with the creation of two new units, one for marketing and one for affiliate relations.

title: Mobile America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $4,009 for the latest first quarter and $36,985 for the year-ago period.

title: Southeastern Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
HIGH-PROTEIN DRINK
description: LEAD: Marty Liquori, 39, one-time track star who is now a leader in the fitness industry and a sports broadcaster, has agreed to become a marketing consultant and spokesman for Go!, a high-protein milk drink concocted by Dr. J. Robert Cade, who invented Gatorade. He signed the contract with Phoenix Advanced Technology whose Nutri-Products subsididary has Go!

title: Novo Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An obituary of Edna Boyne Campbell in some editions yesterday gave the date of her death incorrectly. She died on Monday.

title: New Low for Mexico City Corruption
description: It began on May 13 with a fusillade on a busy expressway here. Two police operatives were shot to death as they sat in their unmarked patrol car.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Badger Co., Cambridge, Mass., a unit of Raytheon Co. engaged in engineering and construction, named L. G. Modigliani senior vice president and chief operating officer. In addition, it elected him president of its operating unit, Badger Engineers Inc.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The ITT Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation, offered $200 million worth of 9 percent four-year senior notes yesterday.

title: Laurence Kaye, 84, Furrier in Manhattan
description: Laurence H. Kaye, a prominent figure in the fur industry for several decades, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: Democracies Held Hostage
description: It's mid-October. A candidate for President trails badly in the polls. But then he dramatically announces the freeing of several hostages in Beirut. He insists this came about because of his skillful, informal diplomacy. He promised no more in return, he says, than to normalize diplomatic ties with Iran and to release Iranian funds still blocked in U.S. accounts. Only after the election does the rest come out - that he also promised ransom to Iranian-backed gangs in Lebanon.

title: Topics of The Times; Cops, Kids and Drugs
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward points with justifiable pride to a promising program that brings police officers into New York City school classrooms to help keep kids off drugs and away from crime.

title: One Seabrook Owner Stops Paying Upkeep
description: Directors of the Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, owner of 11.6 percent of the idle nuclear plant in Seabrook, N.H., today halted monthly upkeep payments and called on other Seabrook owners to buy its interest in the plant.

title: Sprinter Sidelined
description: According his doctor, Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who holds the 100-meter world record, has a partial tear of his left hamstring that will keep him out of action until August, forcing postponement of a race against Carl Lewis that had been tentatively scheduled for June 27 in Paris. Johnson is undergoing treatment in St. Kitt's, where his physician, Dr. Mario Astaphan, lives. Dr. Astaphan said in a telephone interview with Reuters that Johnson should be ready to meet Lewis on Aug. 17 in Zurich, but added: ''What he's gunning for is the gold in the Olympics. He can't take any chances.''(AP)

title: Joseph Bostic, 79, A Sports Journalist And a Disk Jockey
description: Joseph Bostic, a former newspaperman, broadcaster and promoter who fought against racism in the sports world, died of a heart attack Sunday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Northwest Teleproductions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Top Negotiator Wants to Continue U.S. Efforts to Drive Noriega Out
description: The State Department official who led the abortive negotiations with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, said today that removing him from power ''will not be an overnight occurrence.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Long Shot Wins Epsom Derby: Kahyasi, an 11-1 shot ridden by Ray Cochrane, rallied in the final strides yesterday to set an electronically timed course record in winning the 209th running of the Epsom Derby by 1 1/2 lengths. Kayhasi's time for the mile-and-a-half race was 2:33.84, bettering by six-hundredths of a second the record established in the English classic last year by Reference Point.

title: Furniture That's Plain-Spoken
description: AT first glance, the furniture looks ordinary enough. The plain four-poster bed borders on dullness; the chests of drawers are understated and sober; the coffee tables need piles of magazines to relieve their bareness.

title: Q&A
description: Q.A year ago I put two coats of tung oil on my teak-veneer table. Recently I spilled olive oil on the surface, and although I wiped it up promptly, a stain remains. How can I fix this?

title: Talking Deals; Negotiating To Buy Airplanes
description: TRUST is an essential ingredient in any deal.

title: Mets Play Catch-Up, Yanks Play June Classic, but Both Lose; Athletics 4, Yankees 3
description: They gave the Oakland Athletics their grudging respect, nothing more. Even after the Yankees had lost today - and lost the three-game series - they would not concede that the A's, the team with the best record in baseball, were their equal.

title: Hitler's Bunker Demolished As East Berlin Park Is Built
description: The concrete bunker where Adolf Hitler shot himself as the Russians advanced into Berlin is being demolished to make way for a park, East Berlin building officials said today.

title: Braves' Mahler Wins 7th Straight, 14-2
description: Rick Mahler equaled his career high tonight with his seventh consecutive victory, all in a 24-day stretch, and Gerald Perry had five hits, including a two-run home run, as the Atlanta Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 14-2.

title: Drownings Ruled Accidental
description: The drowning of six young women and a man who tried to rescue them when a boat overturned at a Memorial Day outing has been ruled an accident. Sheriff's deputies found that no foul play was involved in the capsizing 30 yards from the shore of a lake, the Yalobush County coroner, Stanley True, said Tuesday. The operator of the 16-foot flat-bottom boat swam safely to shore, and another occupant was rescued as he clung to the craft.

title: KEY RATES
Kinshasa Journal; Hunger Competes With a Thirst for Knowledge
description: Malaika, a 23-year-old law student at the University of Kinshasa, often has the money to eat just one meal a day. Indeed, professors at the 8,000-student university complain that it is hard to teach when many students faint during class because of hunger.

title: Peter Hurkos, 77, a Psychic Used by Police
description: Peter Hurkos, a professional psychic who sought clues in the Manson family murders and the Boston Strangler case, died of a heart attack today, his publicist said. He was 77 years old.

title: OMI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $8,650,000 from insurance proceeds related to a vessel casualty and from the subsequent sale of the vessel for scrap, and a loss of $2,437,000 from the sale of two vessels. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $2,047,000 from a premium on financing of long-term debt.

title: Koppers at Last Accepts Beazer's Bid
description: Ending its bitter fight against a hostile takeover bid by Beazer P.L.C., the Koppers Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the British-based company for $61 a share, or $1.8 billion.

title: Personal Diagnostics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXPERT PANEL SEES POOR LEADERSHIP IN U.S. AIDS BATTLE
description: A committee of experts appointed by the National Academy of Sciences today strongly criticized ''the absence of strong Federal leadership'' in the fight against the AIDS epidemic, which was first recognized seven years ago.

title: Wick Finds a High Profile Need Not Be a Target
description: There is something reminiscent of an old-time Hollywood producer in Charles Z. Wick: an intensity that causes his tongue to get twisted around words as he rat-a-tat-tats his thoughts to a visitor, the speed at which he perambulates, leaving his security guards breathing hard, his grand enthusiasms befitting the born impresario. He hasn't changed, he and his friends say, but his image has.

title: For Literacy Volunteers, More Challenges
description: Calvin Miles grew up on a peanut farm in North Carolina, moved to New York City and got a $35,000-a-year job installing cable television. But he never felt secure in his success. He lived in fear that someday, someone would find out that he could not read or write.

title: U.S. Favors Open Flow of Science Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn Traffic Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Syntrex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income

title: MOSCOW SUMMIT: Review/Television; Summit Coverage: Is Camera Turning Cruel?
description: The images that linger from television's coverage of the final hours of the Moscow summit meeting are mainly of Ronald Reagan.

title: TATE NOW HAS 90% OF STALEY'S SHARES
description: Staley Continental Inc. shareholders have tendered about 31.5 million shares of their common stock to Tate & Lyle P.L.C. The shares were tendered by the expiration on Tuesday of the $36.50-a-share offer, Mary Conway, a Tate & Lyle spokeswoman, said. With those shares, plus the 1.5 million common shares that Tate & Lyle already owned, the British company had more than 90 percent of Staley's outstanding common stock, Ms. Conway said. Staley has guaranteed Tate & Lyle delivery of all other outstanding shares.

title: Reggae Artist Appeals Jagger Copyright Case
description: The reggae musician who charged that Mick Jagger stole his music has appealed the jury verdict against him, the musician's lawyer said.

title: United Stockyards Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The year-earlier figures are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Boatmen's Lifts Centerre Bid
description: Boatmen's Bancshares Inc., the bank holding company that in May made an unsolicited offer to acquire the Centerre Bancorporation, raised its offer to $55 a share from $50.

title: Drexler Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $926,000 and $2,353,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $541,000 for the quarter and $1,890,000 for the year. The company said fiscal 1988 results reflect a $2.4 million gain on the sale of the photochemical division, for which it received $3.25 million in cash.

title: Track and Field; Devers's Choices Are All Good
description: Gail Devers's friends kid her all the time about her height, insisting she's only 5 feet 2 1/2 inches tall when she knows very well she's a full 5 feet 2 3/4 inches.

title: Review/Theater; Brian Bedford as Shylock In Washington 'Merchant'
description: Over the years, there have been attempts to make Shylock more acceptable to 20th-century society. But in Michael Langham's production of ''The Merchant of Venice'' at the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger, Brian Bedford plunges to the heart of this problematic character.

title: Drivers End 3-Week Slowdown at The Times
description: The unionized truck drivers who deliver The New York Times ended their three-week work slowdown on Tuesday night, and negotiations on a new contract are to resume next Thursday.

title: Leading Indicators: Component Analysis
description: Components of the index of leading economic indicators and their net weighted contribution to the index's change in April.

title: Islandes Sign a Finn
description: The Islanders signed the Finnish center Raimo Helminen to a multiyear contract yesterday. The Islanders acquired the rights to Helminen from Minnesota as part of a March 8 trade that sent a defenseman, Gord Dineen, to the North Stars. Helminen, who broke into the National Hockey League with the Rangers in 1985, was traded to Minnesota in March 1987. He played for Ilves of the Finnish League last season and also skated for Finland's Olympic Team.(AP)

title: Wedco Technology reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $862,327 from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting for income taxes. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $898,851.

title: PANAMA DRUG RING SAID TO BE BROKEN
description: A state trooper who stopped a car in Moultrie, Ga., last week caught a key member of a cocaine-smuggling ring that operated through American military bases in Panama, drug officials said today.

title: Disruption in MCI Service
description: Telephone service into and out of San Francisco over the MCI Communications Corporation's network was disrupted today for about five hours after a road grader broke an optical fiber cable.

title: Wyle Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago figure adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in October 1987.

title: Borland Deal for Surpass
description: Surpass Software Systems Inc., a company founded by Seymour Rubenstein, a pioneer in the personal computer industry, is selling its software to a rival, Borland International Inc., and will cease operating by year-end. The purchase price, in cash and stock, was not disclosed. Borland said it would incorporate technology from Surpass's computer spreadsheet program into future versions of its own personal spreadsheet program, known as Quattro.

title: Review/Television; For Some Vietnam Veterans, a Battle With Stress
description: Post traumatic stress disorder, the subject of ''The Wall Within,'' is the cumbersome designation for an ailment that, according to tonight's hourlong special on CBS at 8, afflicts Vietnam veterans exclusively. Almost a million veterans reportedly suffer from such symptoms as hallucinations, nightmares, alcoholism, bursts of uncontrollable violence and feelings of alienation.

title: Clamps: Necessities For Fixing Furniture
description: LEAD: THE purpose of clamping is to hold work in position while glue sets. Beginners, unfortunately, sometimes think clamps can do everything, even compress irregular opposing faces into a good fit.

title: WARD AND STANLEY
description: The boards of Ward White Group P.L.C. and A. G. Stanley Holdings P.L.C. reached agreement on an increased Ward buyout offer that Stanley will recommend to its shareholders. The offer values Stanley, a leading hardware and home tools group, at $:130 million ($237.7 million), compared with an earlier offer of $:107 million ($195.7 million).

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
MAGAZINE INDUSTRY CAMPAIGN
description: LEAD: DETECTING weaknesses in its archfoe, television, the magazine industry will mount a huge attack - a $50 million advertising campaign - during the remainder of the year. And it will be pro-magazines rather than anti-television.

title: Korean Strikes Disrupt Hyundai's Operations
description: The management of the Hyundai Motor Company locked out 20,000 striking workers today and said there was little chance of quickly settling the strike for higher wages.

title: Deficit Slows San Francisco Mayor
description: With the submission of a stringent $1.91 billion budget to the Board of Supervisors, Mayor Art Agnos today answered the first major challenge of his term, a huge inherited deficit.

title: Fleming to Buy Malone & Hyde
description: The Fleming Companies said today that it had agreed to acquire the food wholesaler Malone & Hyde Inc. for $225 million in cash.

title: Psychotherapists Zero In on Making Too Much of Failure
description: Psychotherapists searching for traits of the most destructive behavior are increasingly singling out the tendency to magnify failure as a factor likely to cause emotional disability.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
PEOPLE MAGAZINE HAS DEAL WITH WALT DISNEY
description: LEAD: People magazine, one of the Time Inc. stable, has made a two-pronged money-making deal with the Walt Disney Company pegged to Mickey Mouse's 60th birthday.

title: Toll Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
McNally Play Wins Prize
description: Terrence McNally has been named the winner of the Hull-Warriner Award for his play ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune.'' The prize, which carries a cash award of about $10,000, is given by the council of the Dramatists Guild for a play that deals with controversial subjects involving politics, religion or the social mores of the times. The two-character play, with Bruce Weitz and Carol Kane, is running at the Westside Arts Theater, on 43d Street west of Ninth Avenue.

title: His Goal Is TV
description: ''It's a dream come true, it's the best of both worlds,'' said Mick Luckhurst, an Englishman, announcing that he was leaving his job as the place-kicker with the Atlanta Falcons after seven seasons to become the host of a twice-weekly National Football League television show that will be broadcast in prime time in England.

title: INSIDE
description: Expanding Cancer Trials

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,975,000 and $5,025,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $2,540,000 for the quarter and $5,500,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago periods are restated to conform to current year's presentation.

title: Telecast Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Doorstep Gardening, for the Unlanded
description: OPEN to view but not public, within the property line but not private, a landscaped urban front door enriches an entire street. City folk wanting a touch of greenery still have time to prepare for summer by decorating their doorsteps.

title: Claire's Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $530,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Year-ago first quarter has been restated to account for a reduction in deferred tax liabilities.

title: Pratt, at Its Centennial, to Get a Mall
description: He's a graduate of the school (Bachelor of Fine Arts in Interior Design, 1953) and has been on the board since 1983. And Bruce Newman decided the centennial celebration of the Pratt Institute was the right impetus for him to underwrite an outdoor walkway and amphitheater there.

title: High Court To Weigh Custody Of Twins
description: The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on an appeal from a Choctaw Indian tribe that is seeking custody of 2 1/2-year-old twins adopted by outsiders.

title: Excerpts From Report
description: Following are excerpts from ''Confronting AIDS: Update 1988,'' issued today by the National Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Medicine, a branch of the academy: AIDS and IV Drug Abuse

title: French Open; Lendl Is Perfect, and McEnroe Is Out
description: The game of tennis is played not only between the lines, but on the lines as well. And Ivan Lendl, playing picture-perfect tennis at the French Open, used every inch of fair territory today to defeat John McEnroe, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4, 6-4, in their fourth-round match.

title: Jersey Court Upholds Limits On Shelter Aid for Homeless
description: A state appeals court ruled in a 2-to-1 decision released today that New Jersey has no duty to provide homeless families with unlimited motel or shelter assistance. But the ruling was suspended until the State Supreme Court can hear arguments on the case.

title: Redman Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year are 13 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively, compared with 14 weeks and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: BIG CHANGES AT TIME UNIT
description: The corporate executive offices of American Television and Communications, the nation's second-largest cable company, will move to New York City from Denver later this year, bringing about a shift in the company's top management.

title: End the Losing War on Drugs by Legalizing Them; The Cost of Prohibition
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVANCED MICRO SETS SIEMENS DEAL
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Siemens A.G. said they would cooperate in the development, production and marketing of integrated circuits for advanced telecommunications networks.

title: INDIA'S POPULATION TOPS 800 MILLION
description: India's population has reached more than 800 million, and top Government officials say they are alarmed by the failure to bring a sharp drop in the nation's birth rate.

title: Guokas Joins Magic
description: The Orlando Magic, an expansion team in the National Basketball Association, signed Matt Guokas, the former Philadelphia 76er coach to a three-year contract as coach. Guokas will take over the club when it begins play in the fall of 1989. Pat Williams, the president of the Magic, hired Guokas, 44 years old, as the Sixers' coach in 1985 when Williams was general manager in Philadelphia. Guokas was dismissed last February. (AP)

title: Comair Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Miller and Green Disagree Over New Agency
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and the New York City Schools Chancellor clashed today over the role that organized labor and Civil Service employees would play in a new school construction agency.

title: Ethiopia Denies Food Is Weapon
description: President Mengistu Haile Mariam has denied that his Government is using food as a weapon in northern provinces where secessionist insurgencies and crop failures threaten the lives of 3.2 million people.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said weighted average number of shares ouststanding has been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in May 1986.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM IN COLORADO DEAL
description: First Bank System Inc. of Minneapolis has agreed to help bail out 9,000 industrial bank depositors in Colorado in return for the right to enter the state and acquire a leading bank holding company. First Bank said it was in the final stages of negotiating to buy Ameritrust's 87 percent interest in the Central Bancorporation of Denver, a $1.95 billion holding company with 19 banks. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the Ameritrust Corporation, based in Cleveland, said it hopes to complete the deal by July 1.

title: DUKAKIS PONDERS ROLE OF JACKSON
description: Michael S. Dukakis said today that the Rev. Jesse Jackson deserved to be considered for the Vice-Presidential nomination, just as other Presidential candidates did, but that Mr. Jackson merited no ''special or greater consideration'' for consistently running second.

title: Zenith Responds to Rumors
description: In response to rumors of an impending sale of its consumer electronics division, the Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that it was continuing to explore options to improve corporate profitability.

title: Future-Trend Index Gained 0.2% in April
description: The index put together by the Government to forecast the economy edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in April, its third straight advance.

title: RALLY IN BOND PRICES CONTINUES
description: The bond market's rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose by as much as 1 3/4 points in light trading.

title: Risks Worth Taking for Oil
description: Can Big Oil and its Government regulators be trusted with the fragile environment of Alaska's Arctic Wildlife Refuge? Congress, pressed by the Reagan Administration to allow exploratory drilling in what may be North America's last great oil reserve, has been wrestling with the question for years. Then, last month, opponents' skepticism was heightened by a leaked report from the Fish and Wildlife Service saying that environmental disruption in the nearby North Slope oil fields is far worse than originally believed.

title: Soup Kitchen Gets a Kennedy Visit
description: Just after 1 P.M., Senator Edward M. Kennedy strode to the entrance of a Brooklyn soup kitchen, accompanied by Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President. On the stoops of the dilapidated brownstones across the street - some boarded-up, some covered with graffiti - people waved and shouted greetings.

title: Bid to Rename Courthouse
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said today that he would ask the County Legislature to name a courthouse for slain Federal Judge Richard Daronco. The $33 million county courthouse, a block from the Michaelian County Office Building, was completed in 1975. Judge Daronco, 56 years old, was slain outside his home in Pelham, N.Y., on May 21 by a former New York City policeman who was distraught over the judge's dismissal of a discrimination suit filed by his daughter.

title: Currents; Isozaki Wins an Award For His Architectural Art
description: THE Japanese architect Arata Isozaki received the 1988 Arnold W. Brunner Memorial Prize at the annual awards ceremony of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: Dream Season Ends For Brooklyn School
description: Wait till next year.

title: End the Losing War on Drugs by Legalizing Them; Won't Stop Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: Sahara Casino Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparative results are unavailable because the company was formed in July 1987.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING UP 0.1% IN APRIL
description: Construction spending advanced one-tenth of 1 percent in April as a boom in factory construction helped offset weakness in government projects.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Contempt Charges Urged On Lord, Geller Testimony
description: Expanding its legal battle against a rival advertising firm started by some of its former executives, Lord, Geller, Federico & Einstein asked a state judge yesterday to declare the rival's law firm and its largest investor in contempt of court.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I CAN'T tell you what a kick I get out of Little League these days. It's not that I'm a mother now, and can place my own stifled competitive spirit in the little mitts of my sons. They are too young for baseball, and who knows if they will have much interest when they grow older? It's not even that Little League seems to have improved greatly since my brothers played: back then, most coaches seemed to feel that the point of the exercise was to humiliate children and ram their shortcomings down their throats.

title: No Bed of Feathers for a Goose in Hungary
description: The geese of the Hungarian-Soviet Friendship Cooperative Farm live short and unhappy lives.

title: Bush Says He Has Earned Support of Right Wing
description: Risking a clash with his party's right wing, Vice President Bush today scorned two outspoken conservatives, Richard A. Viguerie and Howard J. Phillips, as part of a ''fringe'' element whose backing he did not need to court.

title: Prime Medical Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the losses were primarily attributable to increases in the allowance for doubtful accounts receivable, adjustments to property and equipment, the reduction in the carrying amount of investments in affiliates and a writedown in fixed assets, office equipment and leaseholds.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a California proposal to limit campaign spending described Walter Zelman and the other pictured volunteers incorrectly. They are working on behalf of the proposal.

title: Size of U.S. Family Continues To Drop, Census Bureau Says
description: The American family has declined to its smallest size on record, according to a Census report released Wednesday.

title: Cancer Agency Seeks Patients for Clinical Trials
description: The National Cancer Institute has begun a four-year drive to double the number of patients who receive experimental treatments, providing an opportunity for far more patients than ever before to receive the most advanced therapies for many forms of cancer.

title: Topics of The Times; Disembodied Melodies
description: Earlier this century, the home entertainment center in many American homes was a piano -often a player piano. The instrument's punched-paper rolls gave even poor sheet-music readers a chance to hear music performed ''live'' by composers like George Gershwin and Fats Waller. Player pianos eventually became casualties of the radio revolution, and today are curiosities.

title: MASSACHUSETTS DEFICIT GROWS
description: The administration of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, already stung by charges of fiscal mismanagement, disclosed today that the state's budget deficit would reach $300 million this year, $50 million more than estimates of several weeks ago.

title: And Nearby, Real Hardball
description: Aleksei Koshevoi became the first Soviet baseball player to score a run against an American team. But the Russians still lost, 15-2. Page A16.

title: Corrections
description: The main article yesterday about the summit meeting in Moscow incorrectly reported the status of American-Soviet talks on Angola. No agreement was reached on a Cuban troop withdrawal over the next 12 months or on ending South African control over South-West Africa. Developments in the situation are discussed in today's main summit article, on page A17.

title: Revival at Tulane
description: Tulane University, which dropped men's basketball in April 1985 after a scandal involving National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations and point-shaving, will revive the sport in the 1989-90 season. The move comes after an N.C.A.A. decision to give formal approval to reinstating the program and the recent start of a $25 million fund-raising drive for all sports at Tulane. (AP)

title: Out With Aggressive Decor
description: ''ITALIAN design: I can't stand it,'' said Diana Agrest, a New York architect. ''It's all so 'designy.' '' Sitting amid the floppy pillows of a roomy sofa she designed for her Upper East Side apartment, she added, ''When I designed this couch, I didn't want a designer's couch but one that was just a couch, not an object of design fetishism.''

title: Minntech reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $210,000.

title: Bridge
description: The playoff matches that began here tonight differ in a major way from the similar event a year ago. In the next four days, the American Contract Bridge League will determine not only its open team for the World Team Olympiad in Venice in October but also its women's team.

title: Ex-Premier Seeks to Emerge From Ruins of French Right
description: Raymond Barre is savoring the prescience of the prediction he made back in April when it became clear that he would not become the standard-bearer of the right in the French presidential election. ''He who laughs last laughs best,'' the portly former Prime Minister cautioned at the time.

title: Edison Brothers Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 23
description: b-After a gain of $8.7 million from an accounting change.

title: Federal Judge Rules on 'Arc'
description: Efforts by the General Services Administration in New York to remove ''Tilted Arc,'' the sculpture by Richard Serra in a plaza in downtown Manhattan, do not deprive the artist of his right to free speech and to due process of law, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Seymour Goeld, Casino Executive, 71
description: Seymour Goeld, who gave Caesars Palace its name and ran promotions for the Las Vegas resort and casino, died of heart failure Monday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 71.

title: Marathon Office Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: American City Business Journals Inc., Kansas City, Mo., said it had sold six weekly business newspapers and one legal publication to an affiliate of MCP Inc. for $46.3 million.

title: Fighting Pollution in the Sound: A Seagoing Sentinel
description: There is a world here on Long Island Sound of marsh grass bending in the breeze, mud flats and tidal pools carpeted with mussels. Next to it is another world, an expanding one of office complexes, condominiums, boat basins and sewage treatment plants.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: A group affiliated with Kohlberg & Company made a cash bid of $26 a share, or a total of about $440 million, for the Alco Health Services Corporation, a drug wholesaler based in Valley Forge, Pa. That valuation included the offer for the company's 12.6 million common shares outstanding as well as options and $100 million in convertible debentures, according to Gordon Cooney, a lawyer for the special committee of the company's board that is examining the proposal.

title: Doomed to Cooperate?
description: The pressure to embrace Mikhail Gorbachev as the apostle of democratization and disarmament proved too much for Ronald Reagan this week.

title: OPEC Meeting Delayed
description: OPEC's twice-yearly conference, which had been scheduled to start next Wednesday in Vienna, has been postponed by a few days to avoid overlapping with an Arab summit meeting in Algiers, the conference's president, Rilwanu Lukman, said today. The conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is now likely to begin toward the end of next week, probably Saturday, June 11. The Arab summit meeting will start on Tuesday and will go on for several days.

title: Boy Gets 30-Day Suspension in Attack on Teacher
description: A 15-year-old student accused of punching a mathematics teacher in a Manhattan high school on Tuesday has been suspended for 30 days, the principal of the school said yesterday.

title: Skyline Chili reports earnings for Qtr to May 8
Review/Architecture; Sardonic Designs in 'City for Sale'
description: If anything can be considered more disturbing than the design of the awkward and overbearing skyscraper proposed a couple of years ago for the site of the Coliseum at Columbus Circle, it is the way the project came to be - the fact that New York City's decision to sell off a piece of its land for the greatest possible revenue, whatever the consequences, made inevitable a building far too large for this crucial midtown Manhattan site. The Coliseum tower quickly became a rallying point for civic activists concerned about overbuilding in Manhattan. The Municipal Art Society, supported by other civic groups, went so far as to file a suit aimed at preventing the city from proceeding - which it won at the lower court level last December, thus blocking the project, at least temporarily.

title: Hope, But No Promises
description: The strategic arms treaty that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have pledged to seek appears to have scant chance of completion this year despite hopeful statements by the two leaders at their summit meeting.

title: Metro Matters; Ask Not For Whom The Beeper Tolls
description: Several young men, oblivious to the blazing sun, were playing baseball. A dozen teen-agers lounged along the fence eating lunch. Still others stood in clusters across the street in front of two-story brick homes, most with meticulously-tended gardens and a few with creches or white plaster statues of the Madonna (not the singer). A young man, a boy really, ambled by, a beeper affixed to his belt.

title: CUT IN CAPITAL GAINS TAX BACKED
description: Providing new ammunition for Vice President Bush and other advocates of lower tax rates on capital gains, the Treasury Department released a staff study today suggesting that lowering the rates would increase Government revenues rather than reduce them as other studies have indicated.

title: Bowne & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Trout Fishing Tape An Aid to Anglers
description: AS is usual, or even unavoidable, for one who views most new things with skepticism, I have been tardy in getting around to listening to the Greycliff Publishing Company's ''River Rap Series'' of audio cassette tapes.

title: Gorbachev's Words: 'Soviet-U.S. Relations on Healthy Track'
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's news conference today, as translated by an interpreter: Opening Statement

title: Japanese Income Up
description: Japan's average household income has topped $40,000 a year, but nearly half of the country's households report difficulties in making ends meet, according to a survey released today. The survey, conducted by the Health and Welfare Ministry, showed that the average income had climbed by 2.5 percent from the previous year.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
AMMIRATI & PURIS ENDS FUJI PHOTO ACCOUNT BID
description: LEAD: Ammirati & Puris announced yesterday that it had withdrawn from the competition for the Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. account because of a conflict with its G.E./RCA consumer electronics, which went on the client roster in January.

title: Review/Theater; In 'Zero Positive,' Tragedy of AIDS Keeps Buckling Into Farce
description: If the time has come for a second wave of AIDS plays, Harry Kondoleon's striking though exasperatingly inconsistent new comedy at the Public Theater, ''Zero Positive,'' may lead the way. Although two of its characters test seropositive - positive for the AIDS virus, if not necessarily for the disease - ''Zero Positive'' contains no facts and figures about the epidemic, no debates about public health, no pleas for tolerance. Mr. Kondoleon's play is about as far away from journalism as the theater of social concern can get. Act I ends with a striptease by a philanthropically minded heiress emulating a porno novel about the erotic mythology of nurses. In Act II, a hospital solarium becomes an amphitheater for Greek mythology so the characters can perform a classical play-within-the-play titled ''The Ruins of Athens.''

title: Campaign Trail
description: Bush Woos Journalists

title: End the Losing War on Drugs by Legalizing Them; Same Old Song
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Ready to Vie for Power
description: The announcement today by the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, that he would not seek re-election has set the stage for a power struggle within the Senate's Republican caucus that has political significance far beyond the internal workings of the house.

title: Currents; A Sophisticated Show, Slightly Tongue in Chic
description: EACH June, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art turns its entire main building, at East Seventh Street and Third Avenue, into a seven-story gallery for an end-of-year display of students' work. And each year, this is one of New York's most provocative but least publicized shows.

title: Max & Erma's Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to May 8
Argentina Loan Proposal
description: A new proposal for easing Argentina's debt crisis has been outlined by the President of Argentina, Raul Alfonsin, in a meeting in New York with Barber B. Conable Jr., the president of the World Bank, and Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Not All New York Antismoking Bills Are Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO RUMORS GIVE TEXACO STOCK A LIFT
description: The stock price of Texaco Inc. jumped $2.125 a share yesterday, to $52.375, on two distinctly different rumors. In the morning the company was said to have found a giant oil deposit in Brazil, and in the afternoon there was talk that Royal Dutch/Shell was preparing to make a bid, possibly in partnership with Carl C. Icahn. Analysts expect new details today on how Mr. Icahn will finance his $60-a-share bid for the company.

title: CUC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Home Improvement
description: SINGLE-LEVER faucets, which allow one to control both the temperature and the flow of water with one hand, are convenient. But when repairs are necessary because of leaks or wear, some types can be tricky to work on.

title: Japanese Shifting on U.S. Realty
description: After paying extraordinary sums for premier office buildings in New York, Los Angeles and other big American cities, many Japanese real estate companies are adopting a more conservative investment strategy, and it is having a significant impact on the price of commercial real estate in this country.

title: Van Buren's House Is a Home Once More
description: IT doesn't have the stateliness of Mount Vernon or the splendor of Monticello, but to Martin Van Buren it was home. And to the National Park Service, which purchased the eighth President's oddly eclectic house in 1973, that was apparently enough.

title: June Buchanan, College Co-founder, 100
description: June Buchanan, who co-founded Alice Lloyd College in the 1920's and was mayor of this Appalachian Mountain valley town, died Tuesday at Our Lady of the Way Hospital in Martin, according to a college spokesman. She was 100 years old.

title: Uribe's Wife Dies Of Heart Attack
description: The wife of Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants shortstop, died today of a heart attack she suffered less than two days after the premature birth of the couple's third child, hospital officials said.

title: Ex-British Coal Chief Heads Trusthouse Unit
description: Sir Ian MacGregor, former chairman of British Coal and British Steel, has agreed to become executive chairman of Trusthouse Forte Inc., the North American operating company of the British hotel chain, effective June 15.

title: Nabisco Brands Is Reorganized
description: Nabisco Brands Inc., a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., said today that it had reorganized into a holding company with four relatively autonomous operating companies.

title: Scholar's Time as Taxi Chief: Politics Made It a Hard Ride
description: Two years after becoming New York City's chief taxicab regulator and ushering in a period of hope for fundamental service improvements, Gorman Gilbert is leaving with persistent problems of taxi service - among them safety, availability and courtesy - largely unresolved.

title: Bay Quits Yanks
description: Rick Bay has resigned as chief operating officer of the Yankees to join a new television group, The Associated Press reported. It was the second front-office departure from the Yankees this week. Lou Piniella stepped down as general manager Sunday after less than a year on the job. Piniella said he would remain with the Yankees as an adviser. Bay was appointed executive vice president and chief operating officer shortly before the start of the 1988 season. He had been the athletic director at Ohio State from 1984-87 but resigned last November in protest over the dismissal of the football coach, Earle Bruce. Bay is leaving to join the StarBright Group Inc., an organization formed by Ric LaCivita, former senior producer of collegiate sports for CBS-TV, ''to produce and package quality events for distribution at the network, cable or syndication level.''(AP)

title: Terra Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. Results for the year-ago first quarter include pre-production revenue from the company's Bullmoose Lake Gold Exploration project which was terminated during 1987.

title: Dow Jumps 32.89 More, To 2,064.01
description: Stock prices surged further yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.89 points to close at 2,064.01.

title: It's Not a Mud-Wrestling Match, It's a Rent Guidelines Meeting
description: In a typically unruly exercise, punctuated by chants, catcalls, jeers and constant crosstalk, landlords and tenants debated yesterday whether rents should go up in New York City, and, if so, by how much.

title: America's Cup; Catamaran Crew: Baptism by Water
description: When Dennis Conner left here Tuesday for an America's Cup sponsor's meeting in New York, he said to his replacement skipper, Cam Lewis, ''Don't break it.''

title: Reagan's Words: 'Differences Continue to Recede'
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's news conference today at Spaso House: Opening Statement

title: Medicare-Glaser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $168,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: A Monkey Is Trained to Help the Disabled
description: A monkey born at a breeding colony started by Walt Disney World has begun a three-year stay with a family, where it will begin training to help disabled people with household tasks.

title: Keep an Eye on Chile
description: For the first time in 15 years, the Chilean people stand a fighting chance of ridding themselves of their tyrant, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. But they cannot defeat General Pinochet at the polls without support from abroad to halt electoral fraud that, with the vote still months away, is already widespread.

title: Critic's Notebook; Keeping Up With Campaign Biographies: 8 to Go
description: It might appear that with the dramatic narrowing of the field of Presidential candidates, there would be fewer books one had to read to learn about the next chief executive of the United States. Yet while the total number of declared and viable aspirants to the Presidency has now been reduced by 10 - from 13 to 3 (Vice President Bush, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson) - the number of books about those candidates has dropped by only 5, from 13 to 8.

title: PUBLISHERS LOOK TO WEST COAST PUBLICITY FIRMS
description: The stereotyped images of the West Coast may include freeways and fun in the sun. But the major American book publishers, clustered along the East Coast, know the region between Seattle and San Diego as one of the best book markets in the nation, and they are beginning to rely more on publicity firms there to trumpet their messages.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Wes Gardner, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up Zach Crouch, pitcher, from Pawtucket of the International League. OAKLAND (AL) - Activated Terry Steinbach, catcher. Optioned Todd Burns, pitcher, to Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Austin Manahan, shortstop, and assigned him to Princeton of the Appalachian League. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Steve Balboni, designated hitter. Sent Dennis Powell, pitcher, to Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. TORONTO (AL) - Reactivated Manny Lee, infielder, from the disabled list. Optioned Alexis Infante, infielder, to Syracuse of the International League. BASKETBALL ORLANDO (NBA) - Named Matt Guokas coach and signed him to a three-year contract. PHOENIX (NBA) - Named Barry Ringel media-relations director and Bob Huhn assistant public-relations director. FOOTBALL GREEN BAY (NFC) - Named Robert J. (Bobo) Cegelski to the scouting staff. JETS (AFC) - Signed Keith Neubert, tight end. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Signed Raimo Helminen, center, to multiyear contract. MONTREAL (NHL) - Named Pat Burns coach. PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Named Paul Holmgren coach. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Named Tony Esposito vice president and general manager; Eddie Johnston assistant general manager and director of player personnel, and Ken Schinkel director of player development. VANCOUVER (NHL) - Signed Jeff Noble, center, and Steve Herniman, defenseman. Released Steve Tambellini and Jean-Marc Lanthier, forwards.

title: Emerson Buchanan, Educator, 78
description: Dr. Emerson Buchanan, an educator and managing editor of The Journal of Philosophy from 1952 to 1961, died Sunday at Pella (Iowa) Community Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Pella.

title: Mets Play Catch-Up, Yanks Play June Classic, but Both Lose; Dodgers 4, Mets 3
description: The beanball feud flared in Shea Stadium last night, and it cost the Los Angeles Dodgers one pitcher and one manager. But it didn't cost them one game.

title: THATCHER SALUTE TO REAGAN YEARS
description: The talk between President Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at 10 Downing Street on Thursday promises to be a bittersweet occasion, more important as a historical marker in the Reagan-Thatcher relationship than as a meeting of substance.

title: More Jews Reported Leaving Soviet Union
description: Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union reached a seven-year high in May as 1,145 Jews were allowed to leave, a resettlement agency said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS Stock prices surged further, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.89 points, to close at 2,064.01. In the last two sessions, the Dow has risen 107.57 points, or 5.5 percent. Volume was strong for the second day in a row, and traders said institutional and foreign investors were active in the market. [ Page D1. ] The bond market's rally continued, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose by as much as 1 3/4 points in light trading. Participants said the market was reacting to having fallen too far too fast rather than to any specific economic news. [ D17. ] The S.E.C. put off until next month a proposal asking Congress to ban forced arbitration of disputes between brokerage firms and their customers. [ D5. ] Rep. John D. Dingell asked the Big Board to provide him with data that showed that specialists had had their most profitable year in 1987 despite the market crash. It was not clear why Mr. Dingell did not have the information, which had been given to another Congressional committee. [ D7. ] A rally in U.S. financial markets helped sustain the dollar against major foreign currencies. Gold rose $2.60 an ounce on the Comex, to $457.60. [ D15. ] The price of soybeans from last year's harvest closed above $8 a bushel for the first time since June 1984. [ D15. ] Yields were slightly higher on money market mutual funds, C.D.'s and bank money market accounts. [ D20. ] THE ECONOMY The index of leading indicators rose 0.2 percent in April, its third straight advance. Analysts said the modest rise pointed to further expansion as the fall elections approach. [ D1. ] Orders received by manufacturers surged in April for the second consecutive month. [ D6. ] Construction spending advanced 0.1 percent in April as a boom in factory construction helped offset weakness in government projects. [ D6. ] A lower rate on capital gains taxes would increase revenues, a Treasury study found. It provides ammunition for Vice President Bush and other advocates of lowering the tax rate. The new study was not prepared by the Treasury Department divisions that normally assess the impact of tax policy issues. [ D6 ] Genetically altered fish that will grow faster have been developed by scientists who introduced a growth hormone gene from rainbow trout into common carp. [ A20. ] Broadway theaters took in 21 percent more last season than in the previous year. Their $253 million in receipts was the best ever at the box office. [ C21. ] COMPANIES Koppers agreed to be acquired by Beazer for $61 a share, or $1.8 billion, ending a long, heated takeover battle. The Pittsburgh-based building materials company will merge with BNS Inc., a company formed by Beazer, of Britain. [ D1. ] H. Ross Perot will sign a Postal Service contract today. What Mr. Perot's new company will do for the Postal Service, and how much it was paid, was not clear. [ D1. ] Lord, Geller asked for contempt citations against the Skadden Arps law firm and the Young & Rubicam advertising agency because secret testimony by a Lord, Geller executive had been disclosed to news organizations. [ D1. ] Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric halted payments on the idle nuclear plant in Seabrook, N.H., and called on other owners of the plant to buy its 11.6 percent stake. [ D5. ] Boatmen's Bancshares raised its offer for Centerre to $55 a share, from $50. [ D5. ] Fleming agreed to acquire Malone & Hyde, the food wholesaler, for $225 million in cash. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS International Lease Finance and Boeing took unusual steps in agreeing to the largest airline deal ever. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Investors rarely complain about volatility when prices go up. Nonetheless the last two days' advances in the stock market were a jolting reminder of how volatile prices can be. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: FARGO COMPLETES BARCLAYS PURCHASE
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it had completed its purchase of Barclays Bank of California for $125.7 million. Wells Fargo agreed in January to buy the unit from Barclays Bank P.L.C. The company has been aggressively expanding its retail franchise across California.

title: Audio/Video Affiliates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Royal Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian dollars. The provision for loan losses for the latest periods totaled $230 million for the quarter and $425 million for the 6 months, compared with the year-ago periods of $225 million for the quarter and $450 million for the 6 months. The year-ago periods' results have been restated.

title: Telefonica reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and the share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts.

title: Blast in West German Mine Kills at Least 16
description: An explosion killed at least 16 miners in a coal shaft in central West Germany today and trapped 40 others more than 300 feet underground.

title: STREET WATCHES STOCK VOLATILITY
description: INVESTORS rarely complain about volatility when prices go up. The two-day surge of 107.57 points in the Dow Jones industrial average Tuesday and yesterday is not likely to bring calls for new Congressional investigations or ways to restore investor confidence.

title: Kidder, Peabody Is Chosen to Aid in Israel Refinancing
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company said yesterday that it had been selected as the financial adviser by Israel for the refinancing of up to $5.5 billion of the Foreign Military Sales debt advanced to the country by the United States.

title: JACKSON, CAMPAIGNING IN JERSEY, CRITICIZES REAGAN ON ENVIRONMENT
description: Visiting a beach strewn with trash, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today deplored what he called the Reagan Administration's ''abandonment of the environment.''

title: Best Energy Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company was not public a year earlier so comparable figures are not available.

title: Wedtech Witness Sticks to Account
description: An important witness against Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, stuck yesterday to his account of illegal payments to Mr. Simon by the Wedtech Corporation and others despite a dogged cross-examination that seemed intended to confuse him.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
ANGOTTI THOMAS HEDGE FOUNDER IS RETURNING
description: LEAD: After not quite a year away, Tony Angotti is returning to Angotti Thomas Hedge, the agency he founded in January 1985, and which in his absence has doubled in billings to $28 million.

title: JUDGE SETS JUNE 20 FOR ALLEGHENY VOTE
description: A Federal judge scheduled for June 20 a proxy vote to decide who will control the consumer products maker Allegheny International Inc. District Judge Alan Bloch set the date for the company's annual meeting, at which shareholders will choose between slates of directors put forth by management and dissident shareholders.

title: THE TEMPERING OF MICHAEL DUKAKIS: HOW HE REBOUNDED FROM '78 DEFEAT
description: The tall central doors of the Massachusetts Statehouse are rarely opened, but on Jan. 4, 1979, in keeping with tradition in a state transfixed by the getting and the losing of political power, the doors parted for the expulsion of Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Mills Jennings Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Nytest Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about four patients in whom the AIDS virus had become dormant misstated the affiliation of Dr. Alfred Saah, an author of the new study. He is at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health in Baltimore.

title: The Cubs' New Name
description: AS the Chicago Cubs' manager at the time, Jim Frey was sitting in on their June 1985 draft of college and high-school players. When it was the Cubs' turn, their scouting director, Gordy Goldsberry, chose Rafael Palmeiro, a Cuban-born leftfielder who grew up in Miami before playing college baseball at Mississippi State, where the year before he had been the Southeastern Conference's first triple crown hitter.

title: Reagan Says He Was Moved By Contacts With Russians
description: President Reagan said today that his summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had accomplished ''a good deal of important work'' and that he had found his contacts with the Soviet people in his four days here ''deeply moving.''

title: Vote Delayed On Forced Arbitration
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to set aside until next month a proposal asking Congress to ban forced arbitration of disputes between brokerage firms and their customers.

title: BAKER AND DRESSER TO SELL BJ-TITAN
description: Baker Hughes Inc. and Dresser Industries have put their jointly owned pumping services company, BJ-Titan Services, up for sale, the two companies said. Baker Hughes, which owns 72.5 percent of BJ-Titan, also announced that it was seeking a buyer for its international pumping operation, BJ Services International, a wholly owned unit.

title: Events: Tenement Tour and Garden Art
description: Craft Classes, Y.W.C.A. of the City of New York, 610 Lexington Avenue (53d Street); 212-751-3335.

title: Review/Ballet; Mark Morris Matches Quirks With Thomson
description: American Ballet Theater's latest novelty is ''Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes,'' an unusually quirky and inventive ballet by Mark Morris set to 13 of Virgil Thomson's Etudes for Piano.

title: New Microsoft Word Program
description: The Microsoft Corporation has announced a new version of its word-processing program for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh personal computers.

title: An Era Erased By Paint
description: LEAD: It's gone.

title: 2 Vie to Be First Jersey Black in Congress
description: Councilmen Donald M. Payne and Ralph T. Grant Jr. occupy the same suite of offices on the third floor of City Hall and share the same ambition: to be New Jersey's first black Congressman.

title: U.S. Chides Company On Herbicide-Sale Ban
description: Eli Lilly & Co. has set back the Reagan Administration's anti-cocaine program by refusing to allow use of a ''safe and effective herbicide'' against coca-producing areas in South America, the State Department said today.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in some editions yesterday, about a nine-year police hunt for a killer in New York, reversed the identifications of two detectives. The detective with the mustache was Gerard Dunn; the other was John Hennessy.

title: Cigarette Maker Blameless in Death, Lawyer Says
description: The manufacturer of Chesterfield and L & M cigarettes was blameless in the lung-cancer death of Rose Cipollone because she chose to smoke despite awareness of the risks, a lawyer for the company said in Federal District Court today.

title: Bob Evans Farms Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Insituform Southeast reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sporting Life Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: SCHERING-COOPER
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said it had again terminated its agreement to buy the contact lens and contact lens solution business of the Cooper Companies of Palo Alto, Calif. The sale agreement, which had met with opposition from the Federal Trade Commission, had been terminated and then revised in a manner the companies hoped would get around the F.T.C. objections. But the companies said today that it did not appear that F.T.C. approval could be speedily obtained.

title: In Diamond Diplomacy, First Round to the Yanks
description: Today, in the fifth inning, at his home field at the auto factory of Lenin's Komsomol, Aleksei Koshevoy, a 24-year-old pitcher, stepped on home plate and into sports history, the bane of trivia buffs yet unborn.

title: U.S. Discloses Debt Plan For 'Poorest' Countries
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d today announced a new, limited debt initiative to help the world's poorest nations.

title: Australian Court Throws Out British Move to Block Book
description: The Australian High Court unanimously rejected today a British attempt to ban further publication in Australia of the memoirs of a former secret agent and to seize the profits.

title: SCHOLAR WILL FILL JUSTICE DEPT. POST
description: David L. Shapiro, a highly respected Harvard law professor and scholar whose views contrast with those of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, will become a deputy to Solicitor General Charles Fried in November or December, Mr. Fried said today.

title: Maverick Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Donna L. Ellis, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Mitchell F. Senft
description: Donna Louise Ellis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ellis of New York, was married yesterday to Mitchell Freeman Senft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Senft of Flushing, Queens. Justice Karla Moskowitz of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony in her courtroom in Manhattan.

title: Record Regards for Broadway
description: Fueled by the success of the megamusical, business was boffo on Broadway last season, according to figures released yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers.

title: Currents; Honoring a Polo Grandstand With Royal Appeal
description: ONE of the touchy issues facing the community of nations after the Falklands war in 1982 was the question of just where, exactly, the English and Argentines would play polo, if not in each other's countries. Since then, Greenwich, Conn., has emerged as neutral territory for world-class matches.

title: Parent & Child
description: FOR two weeks Dr. Antoinette Saunders, a clinical psychologist at the Stress Education Center for Children and Their Families in Winnetka, Ill., has been receiving calls from worried parents. The center is a few miles from the school where an 8-year-old boy was shot to death May 20, in a case that received wide publicity.

title: New Perot Company in Postal Deal
description: H. Ross Perot is starting a company whose first contract will be with the United States Postal Service and whose first employees will be former colleagues from the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the company he sold to the General Motors Corporation.

title: Poverty in the Country
description: The deteriorating economy of rural America has been accompanied by a decline in health services, according to two leading groups concerned with rural health. ''Since 1979, reversing a historic trend, the rural unemployment rate has been consistently higher than the urban unemployment rate,'' according to a report to the Joint Task Force of the National Rural Health Association and the National Association of Community Health Centers.

title: Study Finds Rate of Abortion Is High Among U.S. Women
description: American women have more unplanned pregnancies and more abortions than women in many other industrialized countries, according to a study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute of New York.

title: Review/Recital; Soprano Sings Handel Arias
description: Nan Guptill, a soprano, made her New York debut at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening, and for the occasion she concocted a nicely balanced program that included a pair of Handel arias (with a chamber ensemble), Dvorak's ''Love Songs,'' Debussy's ''Ariettes Oubliees'' and songs by Strauss and Gerald Ginsburg.

title: Petroleum Investments Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In the largest of several tax-exempt general obligation serial bond issues priced yesterday, the State of Georgia sold $181.9 million worth of bonds in two parts.

title: 40 German Tourists Robbed
description: Two armed men held up 40 West German tourists early today and made off with their money, jewelry and suitcases, the French police said. The robbery occurred while the tourists were sitting in a bus at a rest stop between Nimes and Avignon in southern France. The police said the two robbers, their faces hidden with hoods, boarded the bus and robbed the passengers. They then escaped in a waiting car.

title: Fellowes M. Pruyn, Physician, 79
description: Dr. Fellowes Morgan Pruyn, a physician and founder of one of the nation's first group medical practices, died Monday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Ex-Shearson Aide Leads New Minority-Run Firm
description: The formation of a new minority- and women-owned municipal securities firm was announced yesterday, with Bernard B. Beal, a former Shearson Lehman Hutton officer, as chief executive.

title: DINGELL ASKS THE BIG BOARD TO GIVE DATA ON SPECIALISTS
description: Representative John D. Dingell requested yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange provide him with data that had been given to another Congressional committee. The move came after an article based on the information appeared in yesterday's New York Times.

title: 'Profound Change of Policy'
description: Valery N. Soifer was a highly placed Soviet molecular biologist. In 1978 he applied to emigrate to Israel. He immediately lost his job, and for 10 years he lived the painful life of a refusenik. He finally got out this past March, and he is now a visiting professor at Ohio State.

title: Books of The Times; An Individual's Triumph Over Soviet State Power
description: Fear No Evil By Natan Sharansky Translated by Stefani Hoffman. Illustrated. 437 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Beyond Camp: Summer Fun for Youth
description: FOR parents whose children think camp is a four-letter word, or for people who are expecting young visitors, traditional summer activities may not always be practical or appealing.

title: New Frontier: Divorced but Friends
description: RELATIONS in families after divorce have come a long way since the mid-1970's, when the term ''joint custody'' was just being defined and when tension or outright hostility between former spouses was the norm. Now that many divorced couples are civil to each other - or at least try to be - comes the next brave frontier: should they, along with their new mates, become close friends?

title: Review/Theater; Memories of Vietnam
description: The most memorable images in Thomas Bird's one-man play ''Walking Point: A Vietnam Voyage,'' are his sketches of the Vietnamese people living in harmony with a landscape that the war left scarred but did not destroy: images of water buffalo, children in rice fields, laughing villagers and roadside barbershops.

title: Carp With Genes Altered Grow Faster
description: A gene that controls growth in rainbow trout has been introduced into common carp by scientists, creating a new line of fish that grows significantly faster than its natural relatives.

title: MOSCOW SUMMIT: Reporters Notebook; Veil on Personalities Is Drawn Back
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev was midway into his televised news conference today when the question came that must have drained the blood from the television censor's face.

title: Arbor Drugs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Pro Football Notebook; Free-Agency Battle Returning to Court
description: The National Football League Players Association and the National Football League will meet in another freewheeling bout over free agency on June 17 before Judge David Doty of United States District Court in Minneapolis. Doty will hear two hours of arguments and will likely take the case under advisement, issuing his decision in mid-July.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sports People column yesterday misidentified the company that provided a collection of baseball cards to the Baseball Alumni Team, a fund to aid destitute former players and umpires. It was Lever Brothers, not Procter & Gamble.

title: TV Notes
description: A Special on the Arts

title: Singapore Seeks to End Strain With U.S.
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today that he would apologize to the United States if it could demonstrate that an American diplomat who met with opposition figures here was not interfering in Singapore's internal affairs.

title: City Gas Co of Florida reports earnings for 12mo March 31
description: All share earnings are restated for a 3-for-1 stock split Aug. 17, 1987.

title: SOYBEANS CLOSE ABOVE $8 ON BIG LAST-MINUTE ORDER
description: The price of soybeans from last year's harvest yesterday closed above $8 a bushel for the first time since June 1984, lifted by a large order near the close.

title: Printronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Net loss and included a $5.1 million writedown of inventory and equipment, and a tax credit for current domestic losses carried back to prior years.

title: Personal Health
description: Clarissa was married to a man who was habitually having affairs.

title: Gradco Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $68,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $432,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary charges of $142,000 and $456,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Evoking Memories One Record at a Time
description: DO you long to hear Eddy Duchin leading his band in ''Coffee in the Morning, Kisses at Night''? Is ''The Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy'' more your style?

title: Slaying Suspect Dies in Shootout With Troopers
description: A man sought in the slaying of his former wife's lawyer was killed by state police officers yesterday in a pre-dawn shootout on a quiet upstate road, authorities said.

title: Russell DeYoung Is Dead at 79; Led Goodyear Tire and Rubber
description: Russell DeYoung, 79 years old, former chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, died Tuesday at his home in Naples, Fla. The apparent cause of death was heart failure.

title: NEW ORDERS AT FACTORIES SURGE 1.2%
description: Orders received by the nation's manufacturers surged in April for the second consecutive month, indicating that American factories will be busy in the months ahead.

title: Anderson Says He Will Retire As State Senator
description: Warren M. Anderson, who as majority leader has led the New York State Senate longer than any previous lawmaker, announced today that he would not seek re-election, drawing to a close a career that spanned the tenures of six governors and that put him at the center of state government 15 years.

title: Cypress Fund reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The latest second quarter had a net loss of $743,869, compared with net income of $395,953, or 4 cents a share, for year-ago period.

title: Bad Day at N.R.C.
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, whose efforts to approve easier emergency evacuation plans that would allow the start-up of nuclear power stations failed to save the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island, had an emergency evacuation of its own yesterday.

title: House Backs a Move for a Drug-Free Workplace
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved a measure that some legislators said could become a model for requiring Federal contractors to maintain a drug-free workplace.

title: Baseball Notebook; Psychologists View Behavior by Martin
description: What would prompt a 60-year-old man to throw dirt on somebody?

title: SUMMIT TALKS END
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev complained today that his fourth and probably final summit meeting with President Reagan was filled with ''missed opportunities'' and impeded by contradictions in American policy.

title: Lawyer Seeks Nomination By G.O.P.
description: Robert R. McMillan, a Long Island lawyer and Republican fund raiser, announced his candidacy for the Republican Senatorial nomination in New York yesterday. He criticized the Democratic incumbent, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, for ''a lack of performance'' and ''ignoring the problems that confront the average family in this state.''

title: HELLER FINANCIAL SETS NOTE OFFERING
description: Heller Financial Inc. priced a $100 million offering of 9 1/8 percent 3-year senior subordinated notes yesterday through a syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Sym-Tek Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: New York City Sales Still Soft
description: Retail sales in New York City in May continued in a weak pattern, with an average gain of 2.3 percent from May 1987, a spot-check of a number of leading department-store companies showed. When sales of the same companies' suburban branches throughout the metropolitan area were included, the results were even weaker, showing an average gain of three-tenths of 1 percent over the year-ago period.

title: Clark Consolidated Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said share earnings are adjusted for preferred dividends of $3 a share paid in March.

title: Lacana Mining Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special charge of $100,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $500,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $700,000 and $2,600,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Melvin Starr, 69, Head of a Firm That Created Signs on Times Sq.
description: Melvin Starr, the president of a company that has set Times Square ablaze with spectacular signs for almost a century, died Tuesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 69 years old.

title: End the Losing War on Drugs by Legalizing Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgery for Jockey
description: Richard Migliore, a jockey, underwent surgery yesterday to realign his cervical spine, which he dislocated in a spill at Belmont Park. ''The prognosis depends entirely on how heals,'' his wife, Carmella, said before the operation. ''The doctors said he was 100 percent fit and that that will help greatly.'' Migliore, who has shown no signs of paralysis, underwent surgery at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. Two other jockeys, Chris Antley and Julie Krone, were injured in the spill during the first race Monday. Antley's agent, Drew Mollica, said Antley suffered a severe concussion. But doctors found no serious neurological damage. Krone wasn't seriously injured. She is scheduled to ride in Friday's opening-day card at Monmouth Park.(AP)

title:
Seward Journal;
Alaska's Savage and Untamed Finally Get a Home Behind Bars
description: LEAD: Since territorial days, Alaska's dangerous and troublesome criminals have been shipped to Federal prisons in the lower 48 states.

title: Consolidated TVX Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $613,000 from the sale of the company's interest in Omni Natural Resources. c-Net loss The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Joint Document: 'Realistic Approach' to Reducing Nuclear Risk
description: Following are excerpts from the joint statement issued at the fourth summit meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe Mr. Reagan missed an important chance to take a step forward.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A17:1. ]

title: Therapeutic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $163,973 from a real estate lease termination. c-Net loss

title: 2 N.H.L. Coaches Hired
description: With the Stanley Cup playoffs completed less than a week ago, two National Hockey League teams began preparations for next season by filling coaching vacancies yesterday. The Philadelphia Flyers, who on May 11 dismissed Mike Keenan despite his 190-102-28 record over four seasons, named an assistant coach, Paul Holmgren, as his successor. Holmgren, 32 years old, became the seventh coach in the Flyers' 21-year history and the youngest active coach in the league. He was a popular right wing with the Flyers from 1975 to 1984, recording 138 goals, 171 assists and a franchise-record 1,600 minutes in penalties. He was an assistant to Keenan for the last three years.

title: Review/Jazz; Terumasa Hino, A Trumpeter From Japan
description: Terumasa Hino's first set Tuesday night at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street), where he'll be performing through the weekend, ended, aptly, with a ferocious onslaught from his two drummers, Frederick Waits and J. T. Lewis. The constant, all-enveloping din of the drummers defined the sound of the group led by Mr. Hino, one of Japan's best known jazz trumpeters, and featuring Kenny Garrett, a young alto saxophonist, and Dave Bargeron on tuba.

title: Kenji Fukunaga, Politician, 77
description: Kenji Fukunaga, a veteran politician of the governing party and former speaker of Japan's lower house, died of respiratory failure at a hospital Tuesday, a hospital official said. He was 77 years old.

title: Edna Boyne Campbell, Library Founder, 80
description: Edna Boyne Campbell, known to generations of Morningside Heights residents through her association with the Morningside Junior Library, died of cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80 years old.

title: Currents; 50 Women in Design Tell How They Got There
description: WHEN Zaha Hadid, an Iraqi-born architect who works in London, won a prestigious competition for the design of a sports club in Hong Kong in 1983, the promoters of the contest telephoned to tell Mr. Hadid the good news. They discovered that he was a she.

title: German's Red Square Plane Offered for Sale
description: Mathias Rust may still be in a Soviet prison cell, but the single-engine plane he put down next to Red Square in Moscow a year ago has basked in a bit of celebrity since the Russians let it out of custody six months ago.

title: 2 LARGE DEALS WITH SOVIET
