According to patent 4,747,185, granted to Mr. Thacker this week, electrical current is administered to an animal's skull by a hand-held tool. The equipment has been used on a test basis.

title: Reviews/Film; Multiple Murder As Healthy Fun For the Children
description: Rod Steiger is called Paw. Yvonne De Carlo is Maw. Try to imagine Grant Wood's wizened characters after they've binged on mashed potatoes and white bread for 40 years or so, and you'll find the only point of contact between the film ''American Gothic'' and the too-often-parodied painting. This cruel, painfully unfunny story is about Maw and Paw and their psychotic Bible-fearing family - two middle-aged sons and a middle-aged daughter, all three with the minds of children. They live with the daughter's mummified baby on an otherwise deserted island, so one can only guess at the inbreeding that has produced this crew.

title: Telephone & Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Reagan's appearance before a student audience in Moscow incompletely reported proposals by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to limit the terms of Soviet officials. His plan provides for a limit of two five-year terms, with the possibility of a third term by vote of three-fourths of the Communist Party Central Committee.

title: Accountant Accused In Narcotics Case
description: A 27-year-old New York accountant has been accused of operating a $10,000-a-week drug ring in Monmouth County and bribing an undercover police detective.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Celtics Miss Their Shots and the Finals
description: More than 100 games after training camp began last September, the Celtics' season came to an end tonight. Only in Boston, perhaps, would it be considered premature. The Celtics fell short of reaching the National Basketball Association final, depriving themselves of a chance to win a championship they feel is theirs by divine right.

title: Repligen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special charge of $17,261,000 which the company incurred in connection with its acquisition of all commercial rights to its AIDS vaccine project and rights to other technologies. c-Net loss

title: Logicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pre-tax provision for contract loss of $2.5 million and tax benefits of $600,000. c-Net loss

title: Biocraft Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kasler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Travelers Real Estate Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 5.

title: New Library President
description: S. Parker Gilbert, chairman of the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., the investment banking concern, was elected president of the board of the Pierpont Morgan Library on May 19, the library announced this week. Mr. Gilbert, who was formerly vice president of the board, is also a director of the New York Stock Exchange. He replaces Haliburton Fales 2d, who has served as the library's president for seven years.

title: Public Flirtation With Private Desire
description: There is an ancient adage, whispered these days, that goes: ''First marriage, to please one's parents; second marriage, to please oneself.''

title: Intelogic Trace Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,481,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $654,000.

title: Europe in New Japan Inquiry
description: The European Community said today that it had opened investigations into allegations of dumping by 17 Japanese makers of small hydraulic excavators and 7 makers of wheeled loaders, which are used in the building industry.

title: Dead Man's Purchase Of House Is Checked
description: Local, state and Federal officials are investigating a deal in which a house was purchased by a man - a month after he had been killed - from one of the pallbearers at the man's funeral.

title: From Umpires, a Get-Tough Call on Martin
description: In an unprecedented step, the American League baseball umpires vowed yesterday that they would no longer tolerate Billy Martin's dirt-kicking, dirt-throwing antics, promising to ''take strong measures'' against the Yankee manager ''to curb his temper.''

title: Billie Holiday Honored In Outdoor Jazz Concert
description: A free outdoor jazz concert in tribute to the singer Billie Holiday will be held on Sunday at 2 P.M. at 76th Road and Parsons Boulevard in the Parsons Gardens section of Queens. Miss Holiday, who died in 1959, was a resident of the area in the 1950's. Those appearing will be the trumpet player Buck Clayton and his band, the singer Keisha St. John and the Jazz Interaction All-Star Band.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6, 28 East-West tensions are receding as change occurs in the Soviet Union, President Reagan said in a report on his meetings in Moscow. Mr. Reagan urged Western allies to help Mikhail Gorbachev fulfill his plans. Page 1 Beijing has had little to say about the summit meeting 6 A shift in Moscow's U.N. policy will allow Soviet civil servants to join the United Nations on a full-time basis. The move could help meet American demands for changes in the organization and ease its financial crisis. 1 Andrei Sakharov spoke to journalists at the Soviet Foreign Ministry. Dr. Sakharov, who was exiled in 1980 for almost seven years, said his appearance reflected changes in the Soviet Union. 1 Moscow destroyed a launcher for a medium-range missile to show how it plans to comply with the treaty eliminating some medium- and shorter-range missiles. Western reporters were invited to witness the demonstration. 1 A century after Jack the Ripper murdered five prostitutes in London, his identity eludes police. Ripperologists are in an uproar over a television film that the producer says will solve the case. 1 A new attempt at Middle East peace was begun by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Arriving in Cairo, he called on Arabs and Israelis to lay aside prejudices and ''overblown dreams.'' 3 The Amal militia will be dissolved in all Lebanon except the south, and its members should go to southern Lebanon to fight Israel, said the leader of the Shiite militia, Nabih Berri. 3 Another Arab is killed on the West Bank 3 Open discussion of sex in China has been discouraged or prohibited until recently. But a newspaper in Shanghai published letters from workers who wrote about the desire for romance beyond rigid constraints. 4 Discussions of Mexico's foreign debt will be held in New York next week between President Miguel de la Madrid, U.S. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, officials said. 37 Beijing students protest death of a colleague 4 National 7-9, 34 Job growth slowed in May as the official unemployment rate increased one-tenth of a point to 5.5 percent, the Government reported. Wages posted their second straight sizable advance. 1 Man in the news: James D. Watkins, the former Chief of Naval Operations and now chairman of the President's AIDS commission, has combined pragmatism and compassion to give new life to the panel. 7 A counterterrorism investigation of opponents of Administration policies in Central America was too broad, according to an internal F.B.I report, which recommends stricter guidelines for anti-terrorism investigations. 9 Documents in the Iran-contra affair sought by the defendants disclose intelligence operations so sensitive that they are known only to the President and a few senior aides, a C.I.A. official asserted in court papers. 7 Federal anti-drug efforts have been hampered by a lack of military radar planes. Many of the surveillance planes have been grounded because of wing cracks. 34 The stock market closed with a gain as the Dow Jones industrial average increased 18.85 points more, to close at 2,071.30. The Dow gained 114.86 points for the week, a record weekly point gain. 37 Army sergeant found guilty of attempted espionage 7 Politics 8 Kitty Dukakis underwent surgery to remove two herniated disks that had been pressing against her spinal cord. Doctors for Mrs. Dukakis, the wife of the Democratic Presidential candidate, said the operation went well.

title: President Quits At Firestone
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that its president, Albert E. Suter, had resigned ''to pursue other business interests.''

title: Dycom Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the appointment of a dean at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism misstated the history of broadcast journalists in that post. Joan W. Konner is not the first; Elie

title: Schwab Sets Cuts
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation is temporarily cutting management salaries and encouraging employees to take time off as part of a plan to reduce operating costs by 10 percent because of a slowdown in the brokerage business. ''We're taking action to reduce personnel expenses from the top down, and at the same time, we are working to retain our valuable, highly trained staff,'' Charles R. Schwab, chairman, said in a statement. The San Francisco-based company, parent of the nation's largest discount brokerage, has about 2,300 employees in more than 110 offices nationwide.

title: 3 Hits Not Enough for Mets
description: The Mets ran out of hits, runs and late tricks last night, chiefly because Jamie Moyer of the Chicago Cubs threw zeros at them all evening in a tour de force of three-hit pitching.

title: Brian Roberts; Newspaper Editor, 81
description: Brian Roberts, a newspaper editor who was tried and acquited for championing press freedom over a Government report on the Nigerian civil war, died Thursday, his family said. He was 81 years old. The cause of death was not given. Mr. Roberts spent 37 years with the Telegraph newspapers in London and was the editor of The Sunday Telegraph from 1966 to 1976.

title: Reviews/Film; Two Lonely Lovebirds, Under False Pretenses
description: ''Perfect Match,'' which opened yesterday at the Cine 2, might be called ''The (Video) Shop Around the Corner.'' Set in contemporary Los Angeles, ''Perfect Match'' is an extremely distant relative of Ernst Lubitsch's 1940 comedy about two lonely people who meet under false pretenses and fall in love in spite of themselves.

title: Major Gold Merger Set for Canada
description: Shareholders of five Canadian gold companies approved a merger that will create the Corona Corporation, the fifth-largest gold producer in North America. The new company will have market capitalization of $2 billion (Canadian), or $1.62 billion (United States), and annual operating earnings of $200 million (Canadian) - $162 million (United States) - based on annual gold production of more than 300,000 ounces.

title: Under Heavy Fire, California Governor Drops Budget Plan
description: Gov. George Deukmejian today withdrew key portions of his $2.3 billion plan to balance the California budget, accusing the news media of misrepresenting his proposals as tax increases.

title: Burdines Layoffs
description: Burdines, a unit of Federated Department Stores Inc., the recently acquired subsidiary of the Campeau Corporation, said it had begun this week to lay off 320 people of its work force of 11,500. The company said the move was part of a larger strategy of streamlining and restructuring the company to be completed early next week. Burdines was not available for further comment.

title: Central Sprinkler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Advanced Telecommunicaions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Companies to Build Rocket That Can Be Fired From Airplane
description: Two aerospace companies formally announced plans yesterday to build a new type of rocket that would be launched from an airplane to put small satellites into orbit. The rocket was described as the first all-new unmanned launching craft to be produced in this country in two decades.

title: L.I. Dispute: Are 2 Pools 1 Too Many?
description: Joseph and Sarah Papandrea own an ocean-front house here with a million-dollar view and a short walk to the beach. The house also has a swimming pool, but the Papandreas want to build another behind their home - an indoor pool for winter.

title: RESUTLS PLUS
description: Golf Lopez Maintains Lead: Nancy Lopez overcame her second straight opening-hole bogey to shoot a two-under-par 70-138 yesterday and maintain a one-stroke lead over Laura Davies after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Jamie Farr Toledo Classic. Lopez bogeyed the par-4, 400-yard first hole but was flawless the rest of the way. (AP) Rookie Halfway Home: Jim Hallet, a rookie on the Professional Golf Association Tour, birdied four straight holes on the way to a six-under-par 65-133 yesterday that gave him a one-stroke lead over the defender, Tom Kite, and Morris Hatalsky after two rounds of the $800,000 Kemper Open at Potomac, Md. (AP) Cycling U.S. Racer Wins Stage: Andy Hampsten of the United States won the 12th stage of the Tour of Italy championship yesterday at Selvino, Italy, while Franco Chioccioli of Italy took over the pink jersey that signifies the overall leader. Hampsten is in fifth place over all.(AP)

title: TIMES AND GUILD NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON 6-YEAR LABOR PACT
description: The New York Times and the Newspaper Guild of New York reached a tentative agreement last night on a new six-year labor contract that would provide improved wages and benefits for 2,000 news, advertising, circulation and business employees.

title: U.S. Bonds Soar on Short-Covering
description: Prices of Treasury bonds soared as much as a full point yesterday as traders who had sold short large amounts of long-term issues rushed to buy out of their positions.

title: Pistons Knock Out Celtics to Reach Final Round
description: An era in the Boston Celtics' history ended tonight.

title: No Headline
description: For years, Mohawk Indians living on the Canadian side of the border with New York State have been profiting quietly from a trade known among its participants as ''buttlegging.'' That is the illicit sale to non-Indians of tax-free Canadian cigarettes that have been exported to the United States, then reimported duty-free into Canada across a section of the border straddled by Mohawk land.

title: Coke Executive Joins Law Firm
description: Francis T. Vincent Jr., the former head of Columbia Pictures Industries and former executive vice president of the Coca-Cola Company, has returned to the private practice of law as a member of Caplin & Drysdale, effective this week.

title: Ecology & Environment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mock Trial of Waldheim Brings HBO Under Fire
description: An HBO special on Sunday night - a mock trial of Kurt Waldheim, the President of Austria, on war crimes charges - has aroused concern among some officials familiar with the case.

title: Reviews/Music; A Tudor-Style Group
description: The English Consort, a Tudor-style group of viols that specializes in music of the 16th and early 17th centuries, is said to be looking for a new name - perhaps to avoid confusion with Trevor Pinnock's English Concert, an ensemble that plays music of more recent (18th century) vintage. In the meantime, the group offered an enjoyable evening of works by Gibbons, Byrd, Ford and other composers of the late Renaissance on Thursday at the Church of St. John the Evangelist.

title: Wilton Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $514,000. c-Includes tax credits of $303,000 and $1,248,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Gertrude Joy Grimm; Waves Officer, 83
description: Gertrude Joy Grimm, an assistant director of the Waves in World War II, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 83 years old.

title: Bishop Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BEIJING STUDENTS MARCH IN PROTEST
description: About 1,000 students from Beijing University marched to Tian An Men Square in the heart of the capital early today to protest the death of a fellow student in a brawl.

title: Investor Group Lifts Centel Stake
description: An investor group headed by Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier, and Metro Mobile CTS Inc.'s chairman, George Lindemann, said it owns about 5.6 percent of the Centel Corporation's outstanding shares, up from 5.5 percent. The group now owns 2,434,800 shares of Centel including call options on 55,000 shares, the group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: WHEATON COLLEGE TO OFFER REFUNDS
description: Wheaton College in Norton today settled a case with alumnae upset by the school's plans to admit men, offering donors the chance to take back as much as $16 million in contributions.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Radiation Leak Report Is Investigated as False
description: Emergency crews investigating a report Friday of a possible explosion and radiation leak at a Martin-Marietta research center near Catonsville said today that they could find no apparent problem.

title: Wilson Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Prior periods have been restated to reflect the adoption of the statement on income taxes issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Circus Circus Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,235,000 from an accounting change.

title: Jury's Racial Makeup Is Disputed
description: The prosecution in the second trial in the Howard Beach racial-attack case asserted yesterday that some defense lawyers were discriminating against blacks in selecting people for one of the two juries in the trial.

title: S-K-I Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
Umpires' Resolution
description: This is the resolution approved yesterday by the seven chiefs of the American League umpiring crews:

title:
Patents;
A Scanning Profiler For Fine Measurement
description: LEAD: A scanning profiler to provide high-resolution measurement of miniature surface structures in the sub-micron range was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation. Such tools can be used to verify etched lines in conductors and insulators, and measure film thickness and surface roughness.

title: U.S.-Mexican Talks on Debt Are Expected
description: President Miguel de la Madrid will meet next week with the United States Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to discuss Mexico's debt crisis and related economic problems, Mexican and foreign officials said today.

title: Agent Sues Agent
description: Norby Walters, the sports agent who on Thursday avoided criminal charges by agreeing to pay the University of Alabama $213,500 and promising not to deal with Southeastern Conference athletes, filed a lawsuit earlier Thursday against Norman Blass, the agent for Derrick McKey, now a forward for the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: ARIZONA STATE USES ELEMENT OF SURPRISE
description: Has adherence to accepted baseball courtesy become less important than winning a college baseball championship?

title: LTX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $810,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss The latest quarter and 9 months also included a pre-tax gain on the sale of land of $2,377,000 and a pre-tax loss from the provision for a reduction of leased facilities of $2,338,000.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Unemployment: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Ex-Insurance Agent in Jersey Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: A former staff manager at a branch of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Lakewood pleaded guilty today to stealing $54,000 from customer accounts and using the proceeds to buy a house, the authorities said.

title: Beijing Auction a Failure; Antiques Priced Too High
description: Beijing's first large-scale auction of antiques ended today with overpriced items going once, going twice and gone back to the warehouse.

title: Reagan in New Tack On Rights in Soviet
description: President Reagan tried again today to clarify a comment he made at the Moscow summit talks, during which he blamed bureaucratic inertia rather than official policy for human rights problems in the Soviet Union.

title: No Parole in Atlanta Deaths
description: Wayne Williams, convicted of two in a series of killings of young blacks here from 1979 to 1981, has been denied parole, state officials announced today. The parole review, required by state law, was the first for the 29-year-old free-lance photographer, who was convicted in February 1982 of two counts of murder in what had become known as the Atlanta child slayings. He is serving two life terms. The conviction is under appeal.

title: Pay Deliverers Robbed Again; A Guard Is Shot
description: A security guard was wounded and a payroll delivery van was robbed yesterday in Brooklyn, less than a month after gunmen wounded two of the delivery service's guards in a $300,000 robbery in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Special Invitation
description: In a move to promote golf in the Soviet Union, the Royal and Ancient Club of St. Andrews, Scotland, has invited a Soviet official to attend this year's British Open July 14-17.

title: French Open; Wilander, Leconte Gain Final
description: With quiet determination, Mats Wilander of Sweden has worked himself into his fifth French Open final, where he will be up against Henri Leconte of France and a stadium of patriotic supporters.

title: About New York; A Small World: The Wonders Of Entomology
description: One cool, breezy evening this week, people who care for flowers and insects and such things gathered at the American Museum of Natural History for a bug show. Except for a fat man who slept soundly midway down on the center aisle, it was an attentive, knowledgeable, appreciative crowd - New York naturalists, all.

title: Amal Disbands Militia Outside South
description: The leader of Lebanon's largest Shiite Moslem militia announced today that he was dissolving the paramilitary group in all of Lebanon except the south.

title: Normandy Oil & Gas Company Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-After a gain of $440,813 from the reduction of debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Helping Arts Thrive in the Suburbs
description: Suburbia and the arts have not always been the most natural or likely companions. At best, residents of affluent bedroom communities were little more than commuting audiences for the theaters and concert halls of New York and other big cities. But that was before so-called regional arts centers began to alter the cultural landscape of medium-size American cities and suburbs in the 1970's and 80's.

title: It's Baby-Selling, and It's Wrong
description: Is the hiring of a woman to bear a child for one who is infertile protected by some fundamental right to reproduce? Or is it a noxious form of commerce? The New York State Task Force on Life and the Law offers all states a clear, convincing answer: Such a practice is baby-selling, and it's wrong.

title: New Home Opening For Cinque Gallery
description: The Cinque Gallery, founded in 1969 by three prominent painters to display work by young and emerging artists, will open at its new location today, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street.

title: Reviews/Music; Convention of Pianists Celebrates Steinway
description: Like twin imperial powers, Steinway and Carnegie Hall have for decades bestrode the musical trench that is 57th Street, ruling over the fortunes of virtually every pianist who has hoped to own a principality in the concert world. It was entirely natural, therefore, that when the Steinway factory churned out the company's 500,000th instrument, Carnegie served as the locale for a celebration. The affair, which the piano manufacturer held for itself on Thursday evening, may well have been the longest set of encores ever staged.

title: PHH Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a charge of $21.9 million from a writedown of goodwill for the quarter and year; the year also included a restated first quarter to reflect a gain of $25 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income The company also charged to income certain restructuring costs related to its facilities management business in the latest periods.

title: Collins Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,827,000 and $2,078,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $141,000 for the quarter and $155,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $170,000 and $232,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $137,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results included discontinued operations for three of Collins' nine divisions.

title: Utility in Seabrook Write-Off Accord
description: The New England Electric System said yesterday that if the Seabrook nuclear plant did not operate it would take a write-off of $289 million on its investment, under a settlement negotiated with officials in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The cost to shareholders would be $196 million after taxes, the company said.

title: Rent-and-Own Plans: Handy but Costly
description: Once seen only in poor neighborhoods, stores that rent appliances, furniture, televisions, video-cassette recorders and stereo equipment with the prospect of ownership are springing up in suburban shopping centers and along center-city streets.

title: Vehicle Sales Rose by 10.6% in May
description: Another strong performance by domestic manufacturers pushed May sales of new cars and light trucks 10.6 percent above the level recorded in the same month last year.

title: Extend New York's Subways
description: LEAD: On my wall is a framed map of New York City, published by Fortune magazine in 1939, as part of a special issue on the city. Contrasting it with New York today, one sees there have been enormous changes. But one thing is almost unchanged: Just about every means of access we now have to Manhattan, by rail or road, was already built and on the map.

title: Sakharov, in New Forum, Still Dissents
description: Andrei D. Sakharov spoke out today for his Government's new strivings and against its old and continuing repressions, using the auditorium, microphones and translating services of the Soviet Foreign Ministry for words that not long ago would have been cause for criminal action.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about American political reaction to the Moscow summit meeting omitted most of a quotation from Representative Henry J. Hyde. After saying ''it was wrong'' for the President to have attributed human rights abuses in the Soviet Union to bureaucratic inertia, the Illinois Republican went on to say: ''But no matter how you look at it, a big human rights package was placed before the Soviet people. He stressed human rights to the point of irritation with the General Secretary. But he did remember he was the guest of the General Secretary. He's an awfully nice guy, and I guess he did not want to irritate Gorbachev any further.''

title: Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The company said net income per common share is reflective of a common stock offering in the second quarter fiscal 1988 as well as common stock equivalents in the form of stock options.

title: Too Strong a Lens
description: To the Editor:

title: Spartech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to give effect to the company's 5-percent stock dividend distributed in March 1988.

title: I.B.F. Approves 12-Round Fights
description: The International Boxing Federation voted today to shorten its world championship fights from 15 to 12 rounds, but said the decision would not affect the title bout between Michael Spinks and Mike Tyson.

title: American Stores Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Gia Cravotta Married To Lieut. R. C. Hinman
description: Josephine Gia Cravotta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Cravotta Jr. of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Second Lieut. Richard Carroll Hinman, U.S.A., the son of Sylvia Royce of Washington and John C. Hinman of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. E. Robert Geehan, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony in the Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Out, but for How Long?

title: Universal Security Instruents Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Former Islander Is Shot to Death
description: Brian Spencer, a former New York Islander who was acquitted of murder last year, died of a gunshot wound to the chest today, the police said.

title: Interpharm Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: INSIDE
description: Detroit Eliminates Celtics

title: PLANE'S PROBLEMS HINDER DRUG FIGHT
description: Federal efforts to intercept drug smugglers have been hampered in recent months by a lack of specialized military aircraft because of cracks in the wings, Government officials said today.

title: Dr. Michele Smith Married in Jersey
description: The marriage of Dr. Michele Smith, who graduated from the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston last month, to Adam R. Blackwood, an institutional equities salesman for Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. Frank McNulty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.

title: In Environmental Group's War, Trees Are Weapon of Choice
description: On one recent hot day, with reddish smog heavy in the Los Angeles Basin, a group of sixth graders from St. Paul the Apostle elementary school wandered amid a cool, green oasis on a ridge high in the Santa Monica Mountains between two valleys of urban sprawl.

title: NCH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Young Couple Held In Murder of Mother
description: A couple, angry because the girl's mother opposed their romance, murdered the woman in a frenzy, the police said yesterday.

title: Friedman Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Macrochem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
4 Die in Worst South Africa Bombing in a Year
description: A bomb hidden in a garbage can exploded on a busy street corner outside the city today, killing 3 black men and a white woman and injuring 19 other people. It was the worst toll in a South African bombing in more than a year.

title: Six Are Found Alive 60 Hours After Blast In W. German Mine
description: Six miners were found alive early this morning after being trapped for more than two days by an explosion in a coal shaft, Hesse State radio said.

title: Aircraft Experts Fault Old Inspection Methods
description: Aircraft experts say there is a strong need for more research on the inspection of corrosion and fatigue damage, which is believed to have caused an airliner to rip open in flight over Hawaii April 28.

title: Frankness Begins as Soviet and Central European Writers Meet
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Sparks From a Soviet Torch, A First Whack at Destroying Arms
description: A gusher of sparks bathed the military garage in an eerie glow today as an army welder slowly sliced through the thick steel beam. With a crack, the rear section of the launching vehicle for a Soviet SS-20 medium-range missile broke free from the behemoth chassis and was hoisted away.

title: Behind the Soviet Pullout From Afghanistan
description: LEAD: Where else on earth would one rather have been this week than in Moscow? The skies were clear, the weather balmy, the mood of the people summery and light, and conversation everywhere was buoyant with excitement at the events of these days and expectation of the future. The city was as packed as Bethlehem in the tax-gathering season, and you could sell a room at any inn for a ton of myrrh; fortunately, I was spared the competition for hotel rooms, having an apartment of my own in

title: Reviews/Film; Grown Men Re-live Cub Scout Days
description: The arrested-development movie craze may have reached some kind of extreme with ''The Wrong Guys,'' the story of five grown men who band together and re-live their Cub Scout days. Encouraged by Louie (Louie Anderson), whose mother was the group's original leader and whose house once boasted a display of different scouting knots mounted on the wall, the veterans of 1961's Den 7 reconvene for a wilderness adventure.

title:
Patents;
Drug Dispenser Sets Dosage and Timing
description: LEAD: A dispenser to administer one or more drugs in the correct dosage and at the proper time was patented this week. John Urquhart assigned patent 4,748,600 to the Aprex Corporation of Palo Alto, Calif.. Mr. Urquhart is the company's chief scientist.

title: Explosives Inquiry Widens
description: Federal authorities are investigating other suspects linked to a Japanese man arrested on explosives charges, according to court papers filed today in the case of the man, Yu Kikumura, 35 years old, whom authorities have identified as an associate of the Japanese Red Army. The Government said there was a continuing ''investigation into the criminal activities of the defendant and others,'' who were not named, after the arrest on the New Jersey Turnpike April 12.

title: Unemployment Rises to 5.5% As Wages Gain
description: Job growth slowed last month as unemployment inched upward and wages posted their second straight sizable advance, the Government said today.

title: 18.85 Gain Puts Dow At 2,071.30
description: LEAD: The stock market ended a strong week with a flourish yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 18.85 points more to close at 2,071.30.

title: Phonetel Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Where the Money Is: Wall St.'s Best-Paid People
description: Despite the perception that Wall Street is not the place it used to be for making money, one would never know that by looking at a soon-to-be-published list of the highest-paid people in the investment community. The estimated 1987 earnings of the top 100 people ranged from $2.4 million for Alan C. Greenberg, chairman of Bear, Stearns & Company, to more than $80 million for Paul Tudor Jones, an investment manager who first made the list only last year.

title: To the Raided, He's Icahn the Terror
description: Except possibly for T. Boone Pickens, who seems to have lost interest in attacking corporations, no single corporate raider these days comes close to Carl C. Icahn for an uncanny ability to terrorize corporate chieftains by the simple act of buying stock and, one way or another, emerging with a profit.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, Ariel Dorfman's article Thursday misstated his thesis. He did did not say Chileans cannot defeat Gen. August Pinochet in a still-unscheduled plebiscite without support from abroad. Rather, he urged prominent foreigners to visit Chile now as a possible deterrent to efforts to ''steal this election.''

title: Books of The Times; For Brutalized Misfits, the Perversities of Passion
description: Vanished By Mary McGarry Morris 246 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: Jazz; A Pair of Solo Pianists In Unlikely Apposition
description: For the last eight years Ralph Sutton and Jay McShann, who normally perform as solo pianists, have joined forces from time to time, billed provocatively as ''The Last of the Whorehouse Pianists'' and leading a quartet that includes Milt Hinton on bass and Gus Johnson on drums.

title: British Gas Bid
description: British Gas P.L.C. announced a takeover offer of $:370 million, or about $665 million, for Britain's third-largest independent oil explorer and producer, Acre Oil P.L.C. British Gas, which dominates domestic and industrial gas supply in Britain, said it already controlled 50.3 percent of Acre's issued share capital. The company offered 220 pence, or about $3.96, for each Acre share. British Gas said the takeover had been recommended by Acre's directors.

title: Mayoral Hopefuls Jostling for Position in 'Silly Season'
description: Political operatives are having a field day plotting, promoting and planning. Possible mayoral candidates are reveling in unexpected publicity. Newspapers and magazines are filled with speculation.

title: Runner's Surprising Road
description: Margaret Groos took one drink and changed her life.

title: Henry Mechutan; Furrier, 89
description: Henry Mechutan, the founder and president of the Mechutan Fur Company, died of a heart attack Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: D W I Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Millicom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter includes sales and services of the company's U.K. cellular telephone operation, Millicom Cellular (U.K.) Ltd., acquired in March 1987.

title: A Theater's 24-Year Road to a Tony
description: A theater company that gave its first performances from the back of a Studebaker station wagon in 1964 is now recognized as one of the top dozen regional theaters in the country.

title: Referee Is Appointed In Irving Bank Dispute
description: A special referee was appointed yesterday to evaluate a dispute between the Irving Bank Corportion and the Bank of New York Corporation about the outcome of last month's vote for Irving's board of directors.

title: Eye Tests for Glasses Help in the Early Discovery of Glaucoma
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Is Killed on the West Bank
description: A 20-year-old Arab was shot and killed in the Israeli-occupied West Bank today, and Palestinians said he was killed by a civilian, probably an Israeli settler.

title: Leveraged Buyout Of Lumex Studied
description: Cincinnati-based Surgical Appliance Industries, which holds a 9.3 percent stake in Lumex Inc., said today that it is considering a possible leveraged buyout of the company. Lumex manufactures heath-care and rehabilitation equipment from its headquarters in Bay Shore, L.I.

title: Oshap Technologies reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: All dollar figures are translated at an exchange rate of 32.90 Belgian francs to U.S. $1.00, the rate on Dec. 31, 1987. The company said the latest year reflects the April 1 acquisition of a controlling interest in Pegard Productics.

title: On Landmarking Chambers Farm
description: To the Editor:

title: English Rally Behind Rowntree
description: Not since Ivar the Boneless led the Viking invasion in 866 have the local residents put up such fierce resistance to foreign marauders.

title: 2 Die as Tower Falls
description: Using cutting torches, bulldozers and a bloodhound, workers today searched in wreckage for one of three men who were replacing structural braces on a 2,000-foot television tower when it collapsed on Thursday. Bodies of the other two men, employed by Structural System Technology Inc. of McLean, Va., were found earlier. The tower, which belonged to KTVO-TV in Kirksville, collapsed in calm weather.

title: At Pratt, a Celebration Of Community Service
description: When Brooklyn community groups needed technical assistance several years ago to design and win government approval for housing for poor, single mothers, they turned to Pratt Institute.

title: Old Shell Causes Bomb Scare
description: A war relic that a young tourist sent home on a flight from Denmark caused a bomb scare and partial evacuation today at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, the authorities said.

title: SI Handling Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Another Olmsted Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Travelers Realty Income Inestors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 4, 1988
description: Markets

title: Dukakis Counts on Dropouts' Delegates
description: The campaign of Michael S. Dukakis hopes to clinch the Democratic nomination next Tuesday by combining the endorsements of delegates whose candidates are no longer active with the votes the Massachusetts Governor expects to win that day in the last four primaries of 1988.

title: Yugo Airbags
description: Yugo of America said it would offer airbags as standard equipment on all of its 1990 models, following the introduction of seat belts and shoulder harnesses in the back seats of 1989 models. The bags, which inflate on impact to cushion a car's occupants, will be offered only on the driver's side.

title: Eli Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Classic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $115,000 and $390,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-After net of $6,000 for the quarter and a loss of $94,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations. The company said the loss for the third quarter was primarily the result of lower sales volume, a significant reduction in gross margins compared to the third quarter of fiscal 1987, and a provision of $1,055,000 for discontinuation of its heater manufacturing operations, and for consolidation of a number of manufacturing and warehouse facilities.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about the biography ''Picasso: Creator and Destroyer,'' by Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington, discussed the attention given the book and the possibility that its negative portrayal of the artist might affect collectors.

title: Cuomo Proposes 3-Point Program For Budget Gap
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would propose that a $900 million state budget gap be closed through a combination of spending cuts, hiring delays and loans from reserve funds. He said half the measures would require legislative approval.

title: I.B.M. Account Up for Bids In a Setback to Lord, Geller
description: In a stunning blow for the Lord, Geller, Federico & Einstein agency, I.B.M. announced yesterday that it would invite a small number of advertising agencies to bid for its United States advertising account.

title: Genovese Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 20
description: b-Includes a $487,000 gain for cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said year-ago net income and shares outstanding are adjusted to retroactively reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared on Sept. 8, 1987.

title: Smiley's 1-Hitter Ends Pirates' Slide
description: John Smiley pitched a one-hitter and Mike D'iaz, a pinch-hitter, drove in the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Montreal Expos, 2-1.

title: Directors Warn Writers About Independent Pacts
description: The Directors Guild of America has put the Writers Guild of America on notice that it is considering legal action against the independent television producers of ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Tonight'' and other series. Those producers signed a separate agreement with the striking writers last week. and are, in many cases, now in pre-production.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES SHIFT ON U.N. STAFF DEMANDED BY U.S.
description: The Soviet Union has announced a shift in its policy toward the United Nations that could help meet American demands for fundamental changes in the organization and ease its financial crisis, United Nations and Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Dollar General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Beazer in Pact On Koppers
description: The chairman of Beazer P.L.C., the British company that this week struck a deal to acquire the Koppers Company, signed a statement today that he would keep Koppers in Pittsburgh.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: James David Watkins; A Compassionate Pragmatist
description: Years ago a sailor could be court-martialed for contracting a venereal disease. It was the Navy's way of deterring sailors from becoming infected, but the fear of punishment prompted bluejackets to conceal VD and not seek treatment at sick call.

title: Sports of The Times; The Goose in His Old Nest
description: We remember him with the Yankees, for six years from 1978 through 1983, when Goose Gossage was possibly the most fearsome man in baseball.

title: Military Jury Finds Army Sergeant Guilty of Attempted Espionage
description: A military jury today found a decorated Army sergeant guilty of attempted espionage for passing unclassified documents to an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was posing as a Soviet spy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aloha Airlines Inc., Honolulu, a unit of Aloha Airgroup Inc., said it had purchased two Boeing 737-300 jets from Polaris Aircraft Leasing Co. for $60 million.

title: The Job Picture
Dart Drug Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $2.7 million on the sale of 11 leasehold interests.

title: CHINA SAYS LITTLE ABOUT THE SUMMIT
description: One day after President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended their fourth summit meeting, China still had little to say about it today, reporting the events while generally avoiding editorial comment.

title: Brazil Opposes U.S. Subsidy
description: A Brazilian farm industry group plans to seek an international trade ruling to halt United States export subsidies that it contends are hurting the country's economy.

title: Penn-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $20,000 gain on the disposal of oil and gas property. c-Net income and after a gain of $830,281 on the extinguishment of debt.

title: Cuomo Swats Reform Wing Of State Party
description: The Reform wing of the New York State Democratic Party, which began in the Adlai E. Stevenson era 30 years ago and grew so powerful that it could topple Democratic county leaders and veto Democratic statewide candidates, suffered a major setback yesterday at the hands of Governor Cuomo and the Democratic leadership.

title: Elan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in U.S. dollars. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year figures translated from Irish pounds at the rate of $1.612 an Irish pound, and the year-ago fourth quarter and year figures translated at the rate of $1.48 an Irish pound.

title: Refugees Deserve Better From Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Referee Is Appointed In Irving Bank Dispute
description: A special referee was appointed yesterday to evaluate a dispute between the Irving Bank Corporation and the Bank of New York Corporation about the outcome of last month's vote for Irving's board of directors.

title: Transmation Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Fiscal 1987 results included a gain of $106,500, or 6 cents a share, from a land sale.

title: Little Consortium of Big Banks Is Aiding Inwood
description: In many New York City neighborhoods, the completion of a new condominium is routine. But in the Inwood section of Manhattan, the sale of apartments in two renovated buildings now known as the Academy Twins represents a milestone.

title: Bridge; With International Team playoffs under their belts, Westerners look forward to Venice.
description: The West beat the East all down the line today in the International Team playoffs here. The United States representation in the world championships in October in Venice will be largely or entirely players from Texas, California and the state of Washington.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of a retired executive of the Witty Brothers clothing concern yesterday misspelled his name and that of a surviving brother. The executive was Fredric N. Witty; his brother is Ephraim.

title: Hearing on Jersey City Schools Opens
description: Jersey City opened its challenge today to a State Education Department plan to take control of its school system, with a Board of Education lawyer calling the proposed move ''misguided and counterproductive'' and arguing that school officials ''are working nights and weekends to bring about change.''

title: Greenman Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,182,000 for the latest quarter and $3,510,000 for the year-earlier period. Prior year was restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 96.

title: Pep Boys--Manny, Moe & Jack reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $4,688,000, or 8 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest first quarter's net from operations is after a one-time charge of $1.5 million, reflecting a reserve for the cost of consolidating administrative operations in the company's Los Angeles office.

title: Fred Halstead, Trotskyist Leader, Dies at 61
description: Fred W. Halstead, a longtime leader of the Socialist Workers Party and its candidate for President in 1968, died of liver cancer at his home in Los Angeles on Thursday. He was 61 years old.

title: Arts and Humanities Agencies Were Embattled
description: To the Editor:

title: The Unemployment Rates for May Rise in New York and New Jersey
description: The unemployment rate in New York and New Jersey rose slightly last month but remained well below the national rate of 5.5 percent, the Federal Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Colombia Inflation Slows
description: This country's inflation slowed to 1.73 percent in May, compared with 3.91 percent in April, and is running at an annual rate of 28.4 percent, the Government's statistics office said today. President Virgilio Barco Vargas has said that inflation control is one of the priorities of his economic policy. The Government is hoping to keep the inflation rate to 22 percent for the whole of 1988. The rate reached 25.04 percent for all of 1987.

title: Marquette Aide
description: Bo Ellis, the only Marquette University basketball player to play in the N.C.A.A. Final Four twice (1974 and 1977), was hired as assistant men's basketball coach at Marquette yesterday. Ellis, 33, will work under Bob Dukiet, the head coach, who said he expected the 6-foot-9-inch former forward to help in recruiting and working with ''the big guys.'' (AP)

title: KEY RATES
Stumbling Forward in Brazil
description: Brazil's President Jose Sarney won two major victories this week. His negotiators reached an agreement in principle with the International Monetary Fund on new economic support. And the Brazilian Congress said that he could remain in office through 1990. He now has breathing space to reverse a disastrous economic course. Outsiders - including American banks - can help him. But too much meddling could strengthen the very forces he must overcome.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For Martin to stay in the game, he's going to have to behave like an altar boy. He's going to have to fold his hands, shut his mouth and that's it.'' - Richie Phillips, lawyer for the American League umpires. [ 1:1. ]

title: Security Federal Savings & Loan Assn- Cleveland reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $564,000. The share earnings were not available; the company converted to stock ownership on Jan. 15.

title: Quaker State Sells Restaurant Chain
description: The Quaker State Corporation, a leading refiner of engine lubricants, signed a definitive agreement to sell its Western chain of 102 Arctic Circle restaurants to a Pittsburgh-based investment fund. Quaker State acquired the restaurants in 1985 in the purchase of Arctic Circle's chain of motor oil changing shops, which have been renamed Quaker State Minute Lube Inc.

title: Subway Token Clerk Burned During Attempted Robbery
description: A man threw an incendiary device into a token booth at a Brooklyn subway station last night, critically injuring the clerk he had tried to rob, the police said.

title: William Wilson; Author, 82
description: Willliam E. Wilson, an author and retired professor of English at Indiana University, died of cancer last Sunday in Bloomington Hospital in Indiana. He was 82 years old and lived in Bloomington.

title: Review/Ballet; Nuances and Innuendos Of 'Liebeslieder Walzer'
description: The New York City Ballet offered elegant and boisterous choreography by George Balanchine on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. The program's most elegant work was ''Liebeslieder Walzer,'' which received its first performance this season.

title: Novell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Summation Delayed In Cigarette Trial
description: Closing arguments were postponed in midstream yesterday in the four-month trial of three tobacco companies accused of causing the death of a cigarette smoker, Rose Cipollone, from lung cancer.

title: F.B.I. Reportedly Faults Its Inquiry on Foes of Latin America Policy
description: An internal report has found that while the Federal Bureau of Investigation acted properly by opening a counterterrorism investigation of opponents of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America, the investigation was too broad, Government officials said today.

title: National Lumber & Supply reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $250,000 from an accounting change.

title: Gallery for Len Tversky
description: A new gallery in honor of the artist Len Tversky is to be dedicated from 4 to 6 P.M. today at Art Awareness, an art center in Lexington, N.Y. Admission: free. Information: (518) 989-6433. To get there, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway north to Exit 19 in Kingston, Route 28 west and Route 42 north.

title: Data Disclosure In Contra Case Fought by U.S.
description: The classified documents being sought by the defendants in the Iran-contra affair disclose intelligence operations so sensitive that they are known only to the President and a few senior aides, an intelligence official said in court papers filed today.

title: Grande Chain Bans Sale of Cigarettes
description: Grande, a Puerto Rican supermarket chain, has banned the sale of cigarettes in its 26 stores, company executives said. The chain last year had a $300,000 profit on gross sales of $4 million in cigarettes, said Grande's president, Atilano Cordero.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 35.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2.5 million and $14,240,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included an accounting gain of $1.8 million. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $499,000 and $1,032,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Man Guilty in Hagaddah Case
description: A Long Island man has pleaded guilty to selling counterfeit copies of a 15th-century Passover Haggadah.

title: Dorsett Is Traded to Broncos
description: Tony Dorsett, the fourth leading career rusher in National Football League history was traded to the Denver Broncos for a 1989 draft choice, the Dallas Cowboys announced today.

title: Ruling Permits Polling Of Voters in Montana
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that Montana's ban on polling voters within 200 feet of voting places after they have cast ballots is ''seemingly a broadside attack upon significant, traditional and cherished First Amendment freedoms.''

title: Heat Wave in India Kills 450; Many Made Ill
description: A two-week heat wave, with temperatures soaring past 120 degrees in some areas, has killed more than 450 people and left hundreds of others ill across northern, western and central India, according to officials and news reports.

title: Car Jumps Curb and Kills Man in Chinatown
description: A man was killed early yesterday in lower Manhattan when he was struck by a car that jumped the curb as it dragged another man through the street, the police said.

title: COPING/With Buying a Grill become more sophisticated and expensive.
description: It's time again to enjoy the world's simplest and most ancient cooking method: grilling food over hot coals. As warmer weather sets in, so does the urge to cook outdoors. Take a look at last year's grill. If you want to replace it, there are many choices, because equipment is becoming more and more sophisticated.

title: 4 Vibraphonists
description: Vibration Industrial Park, four vibraphonists - Damon Choice, Khan Jamal, Eli Fountain and Wilson Moorman 3d - with Oscar Brown 3d on bass and Dennis Charles on drums, are to perform at 7 P.M. tomorrow at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $5.

title: Poison-Ivy Cream, Industrial Strength
description: Poison ivy and poison oak, the bane of gardeners and hikers in summer, might soon pose less of a threat. A cream called Multi Shield, developed originally to protect the skin of workers from industrial chemicals, has been found also to protect against the irritants in those plants.

title: N.J. Transit Dismisses 3 Workers After Crash
description: Error by the three-member crew of an N.J. Transit engine caused a crash last month with a passenger train in South Amboy that injured 37 people, officials said today.

title: Black to Lead Philadelphia Police
description: Deputy Police Commissioner, Willie L. Williams, a 24-year veteran of the department, was named the city's Police Commissioner today.

title: Shultz, in Cairo, Seeks New Peace Effort
description: Calling on Arabs and Israelis to lay aside their prejudices and ''overblown dreams,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here tonight for a new attempt to negotiate a comprehensive peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors.

title: Pacer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After expenses of $954,312 for the quarter and $992,132 for the year associated with the termination of a merger with Ticketmaster Corp. c-Net income Pacer said the charges in fiscal 1988 included $600,000 incurred by the company to be released from certain covenants prohibiting negotiations with other potential suitors.

title: BEI Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $39,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $962,174 and $1,549,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Rowing; Cornell Breaks Course Record
description: A Cornell crew that had not beaten anyone this season broke the course record at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta today to the astonishment of all.

title: Atom Smasher Supported
description: The House today approved budget legislation for the Department of Energy that covers an atom smasher project that could eventually cost $5.4 billion. The device, a superconducting supercollider, will use powerful magnets that conduct electricity without any resistance to throw atomic particles around an elaborate tunnel so that particle collisions can be observed to learn more about matter.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TENSION IS NOW RECEDING, REAGAN DECLARES
description: In a report on his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Reagan said today that longstanding tensions between East and West were receding steadily as the Soviet Union makes major changes in its internal policies and structure.

title: Hitachi Posts Gain in Profits
description: Hitachi Ltd. said yesterday that it had managed its first gain in profits and sales in three years in the fiscal year ended March 31, as profits rose 39 percent and revenues 3 percent.

title: Irish Music
description: Joe and Willy Kelly, two fiddlers, and Liam Murphy, a guitarist, are to perform Irish traditional music tonight at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Your Money; Theater Investor's High-Risk Role
description: For those who share Hamlet's sentiments that ''the play's the thing,'' and who have the wherewithal and the nerve for a high-risk investment, the theater offers dramatic possibilities.

title: John (3-0) Easily Stops the Orioles
description: Mike Ferraro, filling in as manager of the Yankees in place of the suspended Billy Martin, wanted more than anything for things to go simply tonight. So, he couldn't have asked for anything more than what the schedule provided, the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Coach's Magic Formula
description: Matt Guokas, hired on Wednesday as the head coach of the expansion Orlando Magic, which will not play a National Basketball Association game until the 1989-90 season, knows already what he wants. ''The most successful teams are the teams that are sound defensively, and that's what I would like to build here,'' Guokas said in a news conference Thursday. ''Tough, aggressive, feisty on defense.''

title: Excerpts From President's Address on U.S.-Soviet Relations
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address today to the Royal Institute of International Affairs at Guildhall:

title: M. D. Lynn Wed To Ms. Pomerantz
description: Andrea Gayle Pomerantz, a daughter of John J. Pomerantz of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and Harrison, N.Y., and Mrs. Sandford Furman of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Mitchell David Lynn, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerry H. Lynn of New York and Palm Beach. Rabbis Sheldon Zimmerman and Stanley M. Davids officiated at the Harrison home of the bride's father and stepmother, Laura H. Pomerantz.

title: PEN Issues Warning on Censorship
description: In a coming report on censorship commissioned by the American Center of PEN, the international organization of poets, essayists, editors and novelists sounds the alarm against what it says is an increasing number of First Amendment ''violations and other forms of censorship in the United States.''

title: Lela Schaus to Marry Thomas Philip
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Farmington, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Lela Renee Schaus to Thomas Winslow Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of Bedford, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Eileen P. Hart Is a Bride
description: Eileen Patricia Hart, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Hart of Bedford Village, N.Y., was married at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church there yesterday to Alvaro Freyre De Andrade, a son of Vivian Davis of Houston and the late Fernando Freyre De Andrade. The Rev. Thomas O'Hagan officiated. Mrs. Freyre and her husband are employed by Apple Computer in Cupertino, Calif., she as a product manager and he as a marketing analyst. They hold M.B.A. degrees from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
The Home-Building Pinch Hits Older Areas
description: LEAD: LAST month, David and Bronia Weisberger moved into a two-bedroom town house in a development in Hewlett called the Gables, leaving a five-bedroom house in nearby Woodsburgh that had become too large for them after their four children left home.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: COMPETING FOR THE YEN;
Japan's Money Helps Build America
description: LEAD: THESE uncertain economic times suggest it is time to take a new look at our view of Japan. Japan's emergence as a world economic power has created a strange dichotomy in American public policy. On the one hand, public pressure continues to mount on Congress and the President to take decisive steps to pry open the Japanese market for American goods and services.

title: Sacred Art Exhibition
description: Teachers and students from the School of Sacred Arts will exhibit their work from the spring semester, today from 1 to 5 P.M. at the school, 133 West Fourth Street. Members of the faculty will demonstrate Islamic calligraphy, Indian temple dancing and Sufi music. Tea will be served.

title: Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: I suggest that you pose this question to the president of the N.H.L., John Ziegler, if you can find him! BARBARA LEVI New York

title: Lost in Summit Noise
description: At any time but summit time, the string of novelties that came out of the Soviet Union last week would have resonated. First, as Ronald Reagan prepared to leave for Moscow, the Soviet legislature staged a tax revolt of sorts. A goodly portion of a body known primarily for its rubber stamp opposed a business tax that had earlier been put into effect without discussion.

title: Debra Weiss Has Wedding
description: Debra Anne Weiss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Weiss of New York, was married last evening to James Robert Huddleston, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ellis Wright Huddleston of Las Cruces and Ruidoso, N.M. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan.

title: HOW THE ASPIC FROM TOPEKA WON THE HEART OF ALICE B. TOKLAS
description: I suppose everybody makes lists of favorite books. Firmly entrenched on my reference list for modern literature and the arts - and, I suspect, on most everybody else's too - is ''The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas.'' With that book, in the summer of 1933, after decades of rejection and mostly coterie and vanity publication, Gertrude Stein could at last read herself in the pages of The Atlantic Monthly - in four successive issues. After Harcourt, Brace published the book in August, the Literary Guild distributed an edition of its own the following month. Gertrude Stein was no longer just a high priestess (to some) or a clown (to others). She was a writer who was read.

title: UMPIRES' RESOLUTION DOESN'T WORRY YANKEES
description: Billy Martin has left town, and thus left to his players the job of defending him and his rights as a manager.

title: Minimalist Circus Loaded With Maximum Punch
description: The Cirque du Soleil is not only a captivating entertainment, it also provides a cautionary lesson in a theatrical time when musicals are becoming more elaborate and more expensive. With Cirque du Soleil, the French-Canadian one-ring circus scheduled to conclude its brief run in Battery Park City next Sunday, less is, legitimately, more.

title:
ART;
Giving a Master Her Due
description: LEAD: THE spirited, vigorously expressive line in Mary Nimmo Moran's late 19th-century etchings is remarkably close to current art sensibility, which values the unlimited creativity possible when marks are loose, autonomous and free from the need to connect or to develop shapes.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: IF YOU are a regular visitor to state parks and forests, the Division of Parks and Forestry has a deal for you.

title: Putting Unwanted Food on Tables of the Hungry
description: When the Parker Meridien Hotel offered Helen Palit a two-ton chocolate Statue of Liberty left over from the centennial celebration, Ms. Palit knew exactly what to do.

title: DATA BANK: June 5, 1988
Welcome Back
description: IN 1907, THE PEAK YEAR, 1,004,756 immigrants were received at Ellis Island, alongside the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. Beginning in 1989, half again as many visitors are expected there annually, when the restoration of the premises is complete and the Ellis Island Immigration Museum opens to the public. The new museum, constructed within the same building that welcomed and processed the immigrants themselves, will be the third largest in New York, encompassing 100,000 square feet of exhibit space, two theaters, an oral history archive and a library for immigration studies.

title: Graf Shuts Out Zvereva to Gain French Open Title
description: Steffi Graf won the French Open so easily and so quickly today that in her speech to the crowd afterward she apologized.

title: Officer Wounded in Jamaica And Queens Man Is Arrested
description: A police officer was shot in the forearm yesterday, suffering a flesh wound, while following a suspect, and a man was arrested in the shooting minutes later, the police said.

title: 2 Developers Compete for Malls 10 Miles Apart
description: THE latest mall war in Connecticut is heating up in the Waterbury area with two developers planning projects 10 miles apart.

title: Bishop Fred Holloway Of Methodist Church
description: Bishop Fred G. Holloway, the first bishop of the West Virginia Area of the Methodist Church, died here Wednesday after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: In Defense Of Guerrero
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An All-Star Team With a Taste for Politics
description: SINCE 1984, they have been known as the Tuesday Team, part of a collection of advertising all-stars who helped keep Ronald Reagan in the White House. Now they are known as Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey. Individually, they are Thomas G. Messner, Barry T. Vettere, Ronald S.Berger and Walter A. Carey. Before they were summoned to the President's aid, the first three worked at Ally & Gargano; Mr. Carey came from Leber Katz Partners. Then Robert Schmetterer, formerly of HCM Advertising, signed on as the fifth partner and president.

title: TEXAS DEAL MAKER: Robert M. Bass; A Younger Brother Steps Out on His Own
description: FOR years, the standard thumbnail sketches of the Bass brothers, theirs to one of Texas's most famous oil fortunes, went like this:

title: Another Tate
description: HIS brother is a former world champion and Olympic gold medalist, and now Thomas Tate is beginning to look like a champion in the making. The 156-pounder, who is trained by his brother, Frank Tate, the former International Boxing Association middleweight champion, got a step closer to an Olympic berth of his own Friday night when he won a unanimous decision in the semifinals of the Western Olympic Boxing Trials in Houston. Tate, who defeated Timothy Hagans of the Navy, used his height and reach to score consistently with his left, although Hagans got his attention with some tough inside boxing in the first round. ''I shook it off,'' Tate said. ''My jab was perfect. There was no way I could lose.''

title: 'Bedroom Farce,' A Frothy Comedy
description: ALAN AYCKBOURN'S ''Bedroom Farce,'' at the Arena Players Repertory Theater, is exactly what its title describes. It is a farce, and all the action takes place in three bedrooms.

title: Splendors of the Baroque Age From Munich
description: With the arrival at the National Gallery of Art in Washington of ''Masterworks from Munich,'' a loan show of 62 Old Master paintings from the Alte Pinakothek, a persistent imbalance is partly righted. People go on and on about the Medicis in Florence, but it should be recognized that the role of the Wittelsbachs in Munich was quite as distinguished and lasted considerably longer.

title: How California Does It
description: With business development offices in Tokyo, London and, soon, Mexico City, California has been a leader at luring foreign investment. James R. Rinehart, director of the office of business development for the state, spoke to the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about what California does to attract foreign investment.

title: Castro Vows to Free Most Political Prisoners
description: Struggling to improve his human rights image, Fidel Castro has declared that he is ready to free all but 44 of the political prisoners in his jails, including many who have been there for more than 20 years.

title: The Real 'Emperor'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR BALLET THEATER: A BRIGHT SEASON, A NEW SPIRIT
description: American Ballet Theater closes its season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday with what is actually also an opening night: The First New York International Festival of the Arts launches its entire monthlong series with a dance event, a performance by Ballet Theater that features two new productions saved for the occasion. One is the company premiere of Antony Tudor's charming 1964 chamber ballet ''Fandango,'' and the other is a new work by Clark Tippet (a principal in the company) to music from a barbershop quartet and called ''S.P.E.B.S.Q.S.A. (Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America).''

title: Neglect Imperils Historic Sites
description: IT'S A magnificent ruin, resembling some antediluvian steamboat that came to rest atop Kittatinny Ridge.

title: Q&A
description: Seattle-Vancouver Question:We are planning a trip to the Pacific Northwest and would like information on travel between Seattle and Vancouver by boat. - P. N., Hoboken, N.J. Answer:Two ferry companies operate daily service between Seattle and Victoria on Vancouver Island. There are several ferry crossings a day between the island and the city of Vancouver on the mainland.

title: How America Voted: Early and Often, and Mostly by the Old Rules
description: THE long, long, long Presidential nominating season essentially ends this week - not with a bang, not with a whimper, perhaps with a sigh of relief. After the California, New Jersey, Montana and New Mexico primaries on Tuesday, the nation moves on to the nominating conventions and the fall campaign.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
What Our Ancestors Ate
description: LEAD: THERE ARE THESE LITTLE ROUND BLACK cookies - you know the ones: two flat hard chocolate biscuits separated by a creamy, sugary interior. You can part the halves and lick the cream. You can take little bites to prolong the ecstasy. Or, following one of my more usual methods, you can try to toss them down by the handful.

title: Returning From Taiwan, O'Rourke Talks of Trade
description: LIKE Marco Polo, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has returned from the Orient - in this case, Taiwan - with tales of treasure and the opportunity for trade. The treasure is in the form of a $19 billion trade imbalance that Taiwan is trying to redress; the trade could be with Westchester companies.

title: The Gender of Guys as a Burning Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: >Karen Methany Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert Moura and Bradie Methany, both of South Dartmouth, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Karen Simone Methany to Anthony Joseph Rafanelli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Rafanelli of Providence, R.I. Miss Methany is a travel consultant at International Travel Services in Portsmouth, R.I. Her fiance is a material and process section manager at the Raytheon Company, also in Portsmouth.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: IONA PREPARATORY SCHOOL;
The Class of '63 Shares Its Yesterdays
description: LEAD: WILLIAM PEP'E was wearing a picture of his former self the other night, a snapshot taped to his jacket pocket that showed a clean-cut crewcut fellow of 17 years or so. ''Pep,'' read the caption under the photo, which was taken 25 years ago. ''Bowling, dance committee, glee club. Fella with a red hot Corv - one of the pin topplers for the varsity bowling team; plans to pursue a career in real estate.

title: HIGH BRITE TAKES ROSEBEN
description: High Brite, owned by Joe Allen and trained by D. Wayne Lukas, nosed out Jazzing Around, owned and trained by Lukas, to win the $113,200 Roseben Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title:
GARDENING;
Rediscovering the Hearty Old Rose
description: LEAD: ROSE and marigold enthusiasts battled for years in Congress to determine which plant should be the national flower. Marigold supporters argued for the honor, saying the plant is native. Rose supporters argued that roses were universally loved. It was not too much of a surprise when the rose won.

title: Taxi Troubles
description: 'We need to make a wholesale revamping. The yellow-cab industry is not properly concerned that the riders like the ride or feel comfortable or secure.' - Gorman Gilbert, who resigned last month as chairman of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Sandra Kunhardt, A Writer, Marries
description: Sandra Kunhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Kunhardt Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married in Ossining, N.Y., yesterday to Francis X. Basile Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Basile of Pelham, N.Y. The Rev. Philip B. Kunhardt 3d, a brother of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's on-the-Hill Episcopal Church, of which he is rector. He was assisted by the Rev. Joseph Quigley, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Writers Are Busy in Nation's Capital
description: Two disheveled men sauntered by a little local bookstore one recent evening, stopped, and tapped on the window. ''What are you doing in there?'' they shouted to the hundred-odd people sipping white wine and leaning against the bookcases.

title: About Cars; A Prize Worthy of Pursuing
description: THESE days, whenever I get to feeling low, I remember a couple of guys named Cruz, both of them with truly bad luck.

title: Jeffrey Barr Wed To Lilian Chance
description: Lilian Carpenter Chance, a daughter of Lilian Streeter Lucas Chance of Malvern, Pa., and Dr. Britton Chance of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Jeffrey A. Barr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Barr of New York. Judge Edward S. Lawhorne of the Delaware County Common Pleas Court performed the ceremony at Troutbeck Farm, the home of the bride's mother.

title: Decision Nears On Grace Church
description: LEAD: THE property surrounding Grace Episcopal Church, a prime site considered by many to be the heart and soul of downtown White Plains, is the latest focus in the ongoing citywide debate about future development.

title: Headliners; In Court
description: Dr. Peter J. Sarosi, who two years ago helped arrange the adoption of a newborn boy by a New York City couple later charged with being murderously abusive parents, last week pleaded guilty to violating state adoption laws.

title: Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: No. As a recruited hockey fan originally from the South, I used to think of the words ''hockey'' and ''barbaric'' in the same sentence. After watching a few games, however, I began to appreciate the beauty of the game.

title: Love Is a Midlife Crisis
description: IN EARLY ADULTHOOD, you looked on a lover as a person to have babies with. Cut to 20 years or a divorce or two later: your lover, you suddenly realize, is the person you may die with.

title: POSTINGS: 145 Acres; A Big Park For Business
description: Cabot, Cabot & Forbes built its first business park - the first in the United States, its officials say - in 1947. The 200-acre office and warehouse complex on Route 128 in Needham, Mass., became home to five tire companies, several shoe companies and the American Can Company. Now, after developing 100 such complexes, the 91-year-old Boston firm owned by Marshall Field 5th and his family is about to begin a 145-acre business park in Hamilton Township, N.J.

title: Israeli Censorship Takes On Two Meanings
description: THE Israeli Army raised no objections recently when several Israeli newspapers printed an evocative photograph of a soldier confronting an angry crowd of Arabs. But military officials shut down a Palestinian newspaper for a month after it published the same photo a few days later.

title: Finding a Cure for Financial Inertia
description: ARE your finances making you feel guilty? Does every passing week leave you more determined to finally get your fiscal affairs under control . . . and more frustrated because you don't know how or where to start?

title: Combining Safety And Cycling
