description: The concept of rolling on two wheels through the Connecticut countryside as depicted on the front page on May 8 (''Company for the Long-Distance Rider'') is a promise of pleasurable, healthy fun. A 10-speed bike, a challenging course, and a group of compatible cyclists conjure up dreams of a perfect spring day.

title: Co-Author as Alive as Law
description: Charles A. Vanik retired from the House of Representatives in 1981 after 26 years representing the Cleveland suburbs. As chairman of the House trade subcommittee, Mr. Vanik, a Democrat, was co-author, with Senator Henry M. Jackson, of the 1974 legislation linking trade with the Soviet Union with emigration of Soviet Jews.

title: Ligachev Says Kremlin Is United on Changes
description: Yegor K. Ligachev, the No. 2 Soviet leader, broke his silence today on reports that he leads a conservative faction and said enemies are trying to divide a leadership united behind Mikhail S. Gorbachev's initiatives.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The house I am buying has kitchen cabinets covered with a pecan veneer, and I would like to paint them white. Is there a special treatment or special paint for these cabinets?

title: What's Doing In Dublin
description: ''Free drinks! . . .'' a departing happy customer announced, holding the door of Doheny & Nesbitt's pub for a bearded man about to enter. ''. . . for everyone but bearded chaps!'' Thus goes a typical welcome to this sweet, wounded city where a stranger is not considered so strange by the passing throngs of red-cheeked, tart-tongued Irish and even less so once safe inside the dim place on Lower Baggot Street and snug outside a pint of stout. The old pub's polished brass and mahogany is a temple, the Guinness a tonic, the sound of the Irish at play a feast. Himself, Tom Nesbitt, is behind the bar and the brave new world of pseudo-atmospherics in concocted places named Raffles or P. J. Blarney's or TGIF is checked at the door lest honest carousing be desecrated. And if you're missing the American sense of overpaying as proof of luxury, well, the pint costs $2.35, so overtaxed is this debt-ridden nation.

title: Top County Jobs: White, Male
description: LEAD: THE top jobs in county government remained disproportionately in the hands of white men despite the strong spoken support for affirmative action by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a recently compiled report shows.

title:
SUMMER READING;
IN MUDVILLE, HOPE SPRINGS ETERNAL: MIGHTY CASEY'S 100TH SEASON
description: LEAD: Somewhere the sun is shining and somewhere children shout, and somewhere someone is writing ''Casey at One Hundred.'' A century ago, on June 3, 1888, ''Casey at the Bat,'' by Ernest Lawrence Thayer, a 25-year-old Harvard graduate, was published in the pages of The San Francisco Examiner. I suppose it's the most popular poem in our country's history, if not exactly in its literature.

title: Fast Track Across the Ocean
description: The entry list for an upcoming ocean race from Plymouth, England, to Newport, R.I., reads like a who's who of solo yacht racing. It is a high-technology, bigger-is-better kind of event, in which competitors rely heavily on shoreside help.

title:
TELEVISION;
The Hill Streeters Today: New Beats, Few Beefs
description: LEAD: When Sgt. Phil Esterhaus would advise his fellow police officers to ''be careful out there,'' he was warning them about the dangers of the fictional city in which ''Hill Street Blues'' was set. But the late Michael Conrad, the actor who played Esterhaus, might well have been warning his colleagues of the career perils after a successful prime-time series ends.

title: Headliners; In the Race
description: People who remember ''keeping clean for Gene'' got a blast from the past last week as former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy announced his entry into the 1988 Presidential race. Mr. McCarthy, who ran as an anti-Vietnam War candidate in 1968 but lost the Democratic nomination to Hubert H. Humphrey, a fellow Minnesotan, will be running this time as the candidate of the Consumer Party.

title: Filipino Soldiers, Uneasily, Wage a War of Persuasion
description: When his soldiers walk into a neighborhood on their new mission of winning the people's hearts and minds, ''they begin from below zero,'' said Col. Jesus Ranjo. ''Because of past abuses, people believe, 'Oh, the soldiers are here for no good,' '' said the colonel, who is in charge of civic action for the Manila area.

title: Stage to Screen, via Scarborough
description: It is hard to imagine an odder cinematic alliance than that between Michael Winner and Alan Ayckbourn.

title: 'Haves' Should Have Less to Aid The 'Have-Nots'
description: MOST of us are involved in various activities in our lives that through the years lead us into different circles of friends, different situations and different priorities.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: THE 1950's REVISITED; Coming Soon: More Men than Women
description: AN important demographic trend is pointing to the resurgence of traditional family life with wide implications for the economy and business. The trend is the changing sex ratio among eligible males and females. Some of the immediate consequences of this change will be an increase in birth rates in the 1990's, and a resurgence of the conventional family by the year 2000 (father working, mother at home with the children) from today's 28 percent of all households, to the 1960's level of 44 percent.

title: MORE DRUG TREATMENT CENTERS ARE URGED
description: Government health experts have called for a major increase in treatment programs to serve hundreds of thousands of drug addicts in an effort to slow the AIDS epidemic.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's been a total change in the way people view special interests. This year the special interests are the monied interests, not labor.'' - Al Zack of the United Food and Commercial Workers. [ 26:1. ]

title: 2 Killed, 5 Wounded in Brooklyn Social Club Shooting
description: A gunman unleashed a barrage of fire at a dance crowded with high-school students in a Brooklyn social club early yesterday, killing two people, including a 16-year-old student, and wounding five others, the police said.

title: North Africa Yearning for Western Tourists
description: As the tourists of summer begin arriving in their shorts and sunglasses, governments of North Africa are increasingly depending on this vacation travel to underpin their frail economies.

title: Fostering Art for the Public's Sake
description: LEAD: FOR several years, it has been predicted that American corporations would be the new Medicis. Federal budgets for art are routinely cut, and works paid for with government money are often a source of dispute. On the other hand, art placed by private companies around their grounds and in their boardrooms has a cachet for the corporation and materially rewards the artist, but not many people get to look at it.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Patchogue
description: LEAD: A HUGE, century-old red-brick former lace mill on West Main Street in Patchogue symbolizes an industrial past from which the village is evolving.

title: Susan J. Reiss, a Lawyer, Weds Dr. Steven Baskin
description: Susan Jane Reiss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton Reiss of West Orange, N.J., and Dr. Steven Eric Baskin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Baskin of Dix Hills, L.I., were married last evening at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Barry Hewitt Green and Cantor Norman Sommers officiated.

title: Leigh Ann Hutchinson, a Physician, Marries Barry David Lites, a Lawyer
description: Dr. Leigh Ann Hutchinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Edward Hutchinson 3d of New York and Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church in New York to Barry David Lites, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm T. Lites of Woodmere, L.I., and Chincoteague, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eric Kolbell, a United Church of Christ minister; the Rev. Maria D. Lites, the bridegroom's aunt, who is an Evangelical-Baptist minister; and the Rev. Ernest Rudloff, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: To the LP At 40: Hail! (And Farewell?)
description: Forty years ago this month, on June 21, 1948, a press conference was convened at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to launch what in today's jargon would be called a ''new recording configuration.'' Columbia Records' ''Long-Playing Microgroove Record'' - LP, for short - promised up to 25 minutes of music on a 12-inch side, five or six times as much as one of the then-standard 78-rpm shellac disks. Not only would this allow extended musical works to be played with few or no interruptions; it also meant significant economies of cost per minute of music and of storage space. And, instead of gritty shellac, LP's were made of vinylite, nonbreakable and silent-surfaced (though easily scratched if not handled with care).

title:
SOUND AND RECORDINGS;
Carpenter's Sassy 'Skyscrapers' Ballet
description: LEAD: Although he studied under John Knowles Paine at Harvard, Bernhard Ziehn in Chicago and Edward Elgar in Rome, it was French Impressionism, along with jazz, that strongly influenced John Alden Carpenter, who was born in Park Ridge, Ill., in 1876 and divided his time between writing music and working for his father's shipping supply business in Chicago.

title: A New Haven Premiere for 'Elvis'
description: HE was called a rebel with a cause, and the cause encompassed shaking up music and rattling a nation. It has been said that his performing style presaged the generation gap and the sexual revolution. For sobriquets, ''The Pelvis'' may be the most instantly identifiable, but ''The King,'' be it of rock and roll or popular culture, is the most frequently used to denote Elvis Presley.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ABBEY THEATER PROGRAM The famed Abbey Theater of Dublin, founded in 1904 by William Butler Yeats, will bring its production of J. M. Synge's ''Playboy of the Western World'' to Stamford this week. It will be the group's first presentation of the play in America in several decades.

title: Dr. Susan Kellie Wed To Dr. James Harding
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Dr. Susan Margaret Kellie, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Kellie of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. James Sutherland Harding, the son of Dr. Donnan Bueter Harding Jr. of Toledo, Ohio, and Justyn Harding of Sylvania, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Sandler Married To Dr. S. K. Grinspoon
description: Winifred Ann Sandler, an associate in the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, and Dr. Steven Kyle Grinspoon, who is to begin a residency in internal medicine this month at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbi David H. Lincoln performed the ceremony.

title: BONILLA IS CLEAR EVIDENCE OF THRIFT'S GOOD VISION
description: For an 18-year-old kid from the Bronx, the trip to Denmark, Sweden and Finland is a long one, but Bobby Bonilla used it to travel even farther: to the major leagues.

title: DELAWARE INC.
description: ON JAN. 3, 1986, THE READERS OF THE ASIAN EDITION of The Wall Street Journal were treated to an arresting full-page advertisement. Topped by a smiling photograph of S. B. (for Shien Biau) Woo, the Lieutenant Governor of Delaware, who is also the state's highest-ranking elected Democrat, the highest-ranking Chinese-American official in the United States and a physicist, the ad posed two questions. ''Are you thinking of investing in the USA?'' it asked. ''WHY NOT DO AS THE AMERICANS DO!'' The wily Americans, Woo's text explained, incorporated their companies in the benign business climate of Delaware, established trusts there and founded Delaware banks and holding companies.

title: Making Sure The Rental Car Has a Baby Seat
description: ALL 50 states require the use of safety seats for young children in automobiles.

title: Bright Spot In a Downer
description: IT has been said that the hardest season for a promising major league pitcher is the second. In the first season, his stuff comes as a surprise to the batters, but in the second, they come to be familiar with his curve, fastball and changeup.

title: Wuorinen's Bleak View of the Future
description: Charles Wuorinen, who will be 50 years old on Thursday, is a second-generation 12-tone composer who perceives that his musical universe is being threatened by a burgeoning populism. ''I feel what I do is right,'' he said in a recent conversation. ''Pluralism has been carried much too far.'' Only five years ago Mr. Wuorinen felt no need to defend his path. Five of his compositions were receiving their New York premieres in one week at that time, and he remarked then that ''contrary to what many believe, this is not an age of transition. We are already in a new age which is going to be very much remembered, an age comparable to the Periclean period. We are Athens and we don't know it.''

title: Who Will Pay New York City's AIDS Costs?
description: FROM City Hall to Albany to Washington, there are emotional debates over proposed measures to stem the spread of AIDS: mandatory premarital testing, free condoms in schools or in prisons, free hypodermics for drug users so that they would no longer spread the disease by sharing contaminated needles. But political will is most stringently tested in deciding who will spend how much to prevent AIDS and to care for incurably ill members of two minority groups: homosexual men, who are now well organized to lobby for assistance, and intravenous drug users, who are not.

title: ON CAMPUS: THE BATTLE OF THE BOOKS
description: THE PHILOSOPHER GEORGE SANTAYANA was once asked which books young people should read. It didn't matter, he replied, as long as they read the same ones. Generations of Eng. lit. majors in American colleges followed his advice. You started with the Bible, moved briskly through Beowulf and Chaucer, Shakespeare and Milton, the 18th-century novel, the Romantics, a few big American books like ''The Scarlet Letter'' and ''Moby-Dick'' - and so on, masterpiece by masterpiece, century by century, until you'd read (or browsed through) the corpus.

title: Lots of Water, Lots of Growth
description: The article on Sanibel-Captiva was more than a bit interesting. My son has owned a condominium on Sanibel for 14 years. I have gone there each winter, and so I have seen it grow.

title: Florida: Following Tamiami Trail across the Everglades
description: Some motorists find driving across the Everglades in south Florida as boring as cutting through the unbroken wheat fields of Kansas. To the uneducated eye, the flat land and sawgrass marshes that reach to the horizon start looking the same after a few miles, broken only by hammocks of hardwood trees or narrow canals radiating across the landscape.

title: STREETSCAPES: Seaman-Drake Arch; Encrusted Relic of a Mid-19th-Century Inwood Estate
description: IT is one of the most unusual structures in upper Manhattan, a 35-foot-high, 20-foot-deep marble arch on the west side of Broadway at 215th Street. Built as the gateway to a hilltop estate in 1855, it is now surrounded by one- and two-story structures concealing most of its lower portion.

title: Miss Holmes Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Carole Christine Holmes to Sean Wallace McCarthy has been announced by Arlene Dahl Rosen of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Christian R. Holmes 3d of Houston, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick McCarthy of Boston and Christmas Cove, Me. A September wedding is planned.

title: County and Metro-North Await Report on New Rochelle Bridge
description: LEAD: BOTH the county and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad stepped back from a showdown over the fate of a New Rochelle bridge last Wednesday without either side conceding that it had blinked.

title: Lilco Management to Remain in Place
description: FOR weeks, as negotiators for New York State and the Long Island Lighting Company struggled to conclude their accord to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant and allow Lilco to remain an independent, investor-owned utility, one of the major stumbling blocks appeared to be questions over Lilco's management.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: WE IN the natural-history racket get lots of phone calls. In the spring, the lines overload with accounts of deranged (sic) cardinals trying to get into houses, mockingbirds that keep the hours of nightclub owners and woodpeckers that tap out reveille on drainpipes.

title: 28 Years of Memories For 'Dean' of Legislature
description: LEAD: AFTER 28 years, State Senator Michael L. Morano has many memories about the General Assembly.

title: Energy Squeeze Is Seen for Summer
description: THE $18 million conservation program of the Connecticut Light and Power Company is too late to avoid power shortages this summer, utility executives have said.

title: POSTINGS: 'Village' Festival; Saving the Waterfront
description: Gone is the Bayard Estate where Alexander Hamilton died after his duel with Aaron Burr. And gone is the Christopher Street pier from which Robert Fulton launched his first steamboat. But still standing are Pier 54 where the Titanic was expected to berth and the Jane Street Hotel where its survivors were tended.

title: THE ROAD TO CANTON
description: ONCE, CHINESE food in America meant chow mein, chop suey and moo shu pork. Later, it was the fiery Hunan and Sichuan cuisines. Now, the trend in

title: Q & A: David Gunn; Subways' Next Frontier: 'Quality of Life'
description: NEW YORK CITY'S subways have improved since David L. Gunn became president of the Transit Authority in 1984, the authority and its critics agree. But how much? And what are the prospects? At a recent discussion sponsored by Columbia University and the New York Historical Society, Mr. Gunn declared:

title: Coast Guard's Cuts Worry Boaters
description: FEDERAL officials and Long Island boaters fear that a $103 million shortfall in the Coast Guard's 1988 budget will endanger boating safety this summer.

title: COLORADO'S THRIVING CULTS
description: Fergus Bordewich's observation that a religious movement so closely identified with the counterculture of the 1960's has been appropriated by corporate businessmen and yuppies in Colorado may seem ironic, but it is hardly surprising, given the origins of the New Age movement in America (''Colorado's Thriving Cults,'' May 1).

title: CORRECTION
description: A story in the Arts and Leisure section of May 29 about Thomas Krens, the newly appointed director of the Guggenheim Museum, gave an incorrect title for an exhibition being organized by Mr. Krens. The title is ''Refigured Painting: The German Image, 1960-1988.''

title: British Classical Label to Bow Here
description: Virgin Records, a British entertainment company and mainstream pop record label that has spawned such stars as Boy George and Julian Lennon, has entered the classical music field, and its first offerings are scheduled to be released in this country in August.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 5, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis. 2 2 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) An author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 3 5 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.50.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago. 4 2 TENDER REBEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A Scottish heiress accepts the aid of a handsome rake in her search for a husband. 5 4 DIRK GENTLY'S HOLISTIC DETECTIVE AGENCY, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $4.50.) A private eye's trip through space and time. 6 6 FLIGHT OF THE OLD DOG, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $4.95.) Meeting Russia's challenge after it has mastered Star Wars technology. 7 * 13 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's. 8 5 THE SISTERS, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The competition between two sisters, a best- selling novelist and a renowned actress. 9 1 FIRST BORN, by Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $4.95.) The rivalry of sisters and cousins played out in the worlds of high fashion and politics. 10 5 WINTER HAWK, by Craig Thomas. (Avon, $4.95.) A Soviet plot to launch a Star Wars weapon on the eve of the signing of a disarmament treaty. 11 1 THE AWAKENING, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) A hot-blooded union organizer arouses the desires of the daughter of a California rancher. 12 1 TIMETRAP, by David Dvorkin. (Pocket, $3.95.) Captain Kirk of ''Star Trek'' stranded in a strange new empire 100 years in the future. 13 1 NEW ORLEANS LEGACY, by Alexandra Ripley. (Warner, $3.95.) A young woman's romantic adventures in antebellum New Orleans. 14 13 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A psychologist-detective solves a string of vicious murders. 15 1 THE INVADERS PLAN, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) The first volume in the ''Mission Earth'' science fiction saga. 16 * 27 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 2 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 2 5 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 3 241 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 4 3 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) The information that ''every American needs to know.'' 5 82 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 6 67 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 7 * 3 LIFE AND DEATH IN SHANGHAI, by Nien Cheng. (Penguin, $8.95.) China's Cultural Revolution as experienced by a wealthy woman. 8 19 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Avon, $4.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. 9 1 CALL ME ANNA, by Patty Duke and Kenneth Turan. (Bantam, $4.95.) The autobiography of the actress and show business personality. 10 * 5 INTIMATE PARTNERS, by Maggie Scarf. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Changing patterns in love and marriage. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 11 SOMETHING UNDER THE BED IS DROOLING, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) New ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 7 YOU CAN HEAL YOUR LIFE, by Louise L. Hay. (Hay House, $10.) A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 3 18 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 4 2 WOMEN MEN LOVE, WOMEN MEN LEAVE, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) How women can influence the course of their relationships with men. 5 * 54 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A Special Award For a Theater Man
description: When Broadway dispenses the last and most important of its annual awards tonight, the name of one winner is certain to baffle most of the nearly 2,000 spectators at the Minskoff Theater. But for several hundred insiders - and Broadway is as much an insider's domain as any Prohibition speakeasy - the uttering of the name Fred Golden will bring a smile to their collective countenance, a rare unanimity to an extended family that loves to feud.

title: POSTINGS: 800 for Glen Cove; Town Houses on a Creek
description: Three sites on both sides of Glen Cove Creek on Long Island will soon be occupied by 800 town houses, completing development along the creek and filling some of the last vacant land on Nassau County's north shore. The setting will make it possible for buyers of the town houses to live close to their boats.

title:
SOUND AND RECORDINGS;
Harnoncourt's Period 'Giulio Cesare'
description: LEAD: Record annotations are usually useful and instructive, but sometimes they can get on your nerves. Teldec, a fine German label, whose products are now distributed by Koch Import Service, provides a good case in point. There are, in fact, two cases, both involving the prolific and venturesome Nikolaus Harnoncourt.

title: FOCUS: Overbuilt Office Markets; Developers Redirecting Their Energies
description: IT is a measure of the overbuilding that has taken place in this country that Tishman Speyer Properties, one of New York's leading developers, has only one office building in the United States planned for this year: the NBC Tower, rising on the shores of Lake Michigan in Chicago.

title: Andre Agassi: Refreshing Reign
description: To the Sports Editor: rrFinally, the tennis youth of America has a decent role model: Andre Agassi. After what seemed an eternity of the superbrat scowl and the arrogant Jimbo Strut, it is refreshing to cheer for an American.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: More Cards Offer Coverage For Rental Cars

title: COLORADO'S THRIVING CULTS
description: I suggest that Mr. Bordewich shouldn't be so quick to condemn the voice of change. After all, what do physicists make of the discovery of molecules that anticipate one another's actions across the solar system (as reported in your Science pages earlier this year)? Perhaps science is fated to reaffirm what other cultures have known all along: that the cosmos is one. KRYSTIE KELLER New York, N.Y.

title: Andrew W. Clurman Wed to Claire Hebert
description: Claire Denise Hebert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer T. Hebert Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Andrew William Clurman, a son of Adele Bourne of Moorestown, N.J., and Rodney Hart Clurman of San Francisco. The Rev. J. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Macon, Ga.;
A New Blow Against Blight
description: LEAD: SINCE 1976 almost $250 million of public and private money has been spent to restore many of the turn-of-the-century buildings in downtown Macon. Now the renovation of 18 historic buildings is about to bring new life to a block just to the south in one of the city's most neglected areas.

title: Armenians Recall Republic at Parade
description: Affirming solidarity with their brethren in the Soviet Union and Turkey, about 3,000 Armenians marched up the Avenue of the Americas yesterday afternoon to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of the short-lived Republic of Armenia.

title: Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: About as much as a blistering slap shot that hits a goalie's protective cup. It doesn't do any permanent damage, it leaves you stunned and surprised, and you sure as hell don't ever want to see it happen again. ROBERT JAMES Clifton, N.J.

title: Death Row Legal Aid Mandated
description: A Federal appeals court has affirmed that prisoners have a right to legal counsel provided by the state for as long as they challenge their death sentences.

title: President Says Summit Has Nurtured Freedom
description: President Reagan said today that his visit to Moscow sowed ''seeds of freedom and greater trust,'' which he believes will take root and grow in ways yet unimagined.

title: TESTIFYING TO TORTURE
description: HE CAME INTO MY office in San Salvador reeking of the vinegar-tinged sweat of simple human fear. His eyes rolled to show their whites as he insisted that ''they'' were trying to kill him. He said his name was Florencio Caballero and he wanted to tell me of his work as an interrogator in a Honduran Army death squad, which he said had tortured and then murdered approximately 120 Hondurans and other Latin Americans. He had been trained in Texas by the Central Intelligence Agency, he told me. As a sergeant in the Honduran Army, he said, he had kidnapped and interrogated people, including an American priest, who were then murdered. ''Horrible things'' had been done to people in dark basements and hidden graveyards.

title: Michigan: Between the lake and the bay, the Leelanau Peninsula
description: The summit of the Sleeping Bear Sand Dunes stands some 450 feet above the cold, blue surface of Lake Michigan, a kind of Sahara of the north woods or, if you look at it another way, Michigan's steepest beach. From these ghostly sand mountains, flecked with wildflowers and bits of polished driftwood, the lake seems to go on forever.

title: U.S. Study of Soviet Performance in Afghan War Cites Poor Morale
description: The Soviet Army has performed poorly during its eight-and-a-half-year war in Afghanistan, largely because of low morale, according to a study of its combat effectiveness completed for the United States Army.

title:
INVESTING;
The Numbers That Move the Market
description: LEAD: INDIVIDUAL investors have every reason to be confused by the flood of financial statistics that pours out of Washington. The so-called market experts who try to glean information about the economy from Government reports are often wrong. And then the market tends to overreact to the erroneous forecasts.

title: TALKING: Noise; Soft Talk Can End Nuisances
description: SOMETIMES the problem is a nearby air-conditioner that rattles and rumbles all night long, or a dog left to bark for hours at a time. Then there are those lawn mowers or chain saws that zoom into action at the crack of dawn on Sunday.

title: Strong Stars
description: THE DARK PAST Starring William Holden and Lee J. Cobb (in photo), Nina Foch. Produced by Buddy Adler. Directed by Rudolph Mate. 1948. RCA-Columbia Pictures Home Video. 75 minutes. $69.95.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Stamford Shrugs Off Condo Deal's Collapse
description: LATE last month Stamford got the kind of wrenching news that many people trying to sell real estate are facing. The First Realty Company of Boston notified the Mayor that it was unable to finance the $14.8 million purchase of the Burdick School and must back out of its 1987 contract. Three hundred twenty-five condominiums were to be built on the three-acre site.

title: In Lebanon, a New Chance for the Old War
description: LEBANON is caught in a new cycle of violence that may accelerate as warring factions are further provoked by this summer's presidential election. If new fighting breaks out over the presidency, it is likely to pit most Moslem militias against Christian forces, the two groups who have been fighting sporadically for control of the nation in the civil war that began in 1975.

title:
IDEAS AND TRENDS;
What Technology Can Do for the Disabled
description: LEAD: WHEN Diane Bailey, a quadriplegic, wants her three teen-age daughters to stop watching television and help her in the kitchen, she speaks to a computer about the size of a cereal box. ''Alfred,'' she commands, ''TV off.'' ''Yes, master,'' it replies, and the television screen goes blank.

title: Getting a Play to Broadway (or Off)
description: TO PROVE that there is life after regional theater, two recent productions that were transferred, virtually intact, from New Jersey to Off Broadway stages offer strategies on how to keep a play going.

title: Missouri-Arkansas: Sampling the Ozarks over 100 twisting miles
description: From Springfield, Mo., to Eureka Springs, Ark., is a trip of 100 miles but a journey across more than 100 years of history.

title: Community Spirit Across Generations
description: THE day of Sept. 17, 1886, was cloudy and damp in Hartford. But wet grass in Bushnell Park did not stop thousands from pouring in for the dedication of the new Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch.

title: New Smoking Rules Weighed
description: LEAD: THE County Board of Legislators is discussing whether to make Westchester's smoking regulations more stringent - requiring, for example, that restaurants serving 50 or more patrons set aside 70 percent of their seating for nonsmokers.

title: Roger M. Machlis Is Wed To Hilary Rae Markowitz
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., Hilary Rae Markowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Markowitz of Greenlawn, L.I., was married last evening to Roger Mitchell Machlis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Machlis of Edison, N.J. Rabbi Barton Shallat officiated. The bride, a graduate of Brandeis University, is an advertising sales representative at Barron's in New York. The bridegroom, an associate in the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and the New York University School of Law.

title: Lakers Survive Another Scare
description: With Boston eliminated, the burning question before the Lakers' seventh-game showdown with Dallas was whether Los Angeles, the lone survivor of the old guard, could survive a desperate challenge from a fierce young rival.

title: Clinics Treat Pet Emergencies
description: AS the workday is coming to a close for most veterinarians, four clinics in the state open up to serve the emergency needs of animals. The clinics -in Danbury, Norwalk, Stratford and West Hartford - are open during the night and on weekends and holidays.

title: Is the Bull About to Run?
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 74.68 points on Tuesday and 32.89 points on Wednesday on heavy volume, and finished 114.86 points up over the previous week. To many analysts, these upswings hint at a future bull market as buyers come back into the stock market from the sidelines. To others it signals the beginning of a more limited summer rally. Are conditions ripe for a new bull market? Robert H. Stovall President, Stovall/21st Advisers Inc.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Italian Oasis in Pound Ridge
description: LEAD: THE county's real estate boom of the past few years has brought in its wake a flurry of restaurant openings, particularly in the north. Pound Ridge, however, seems to be one of the few towns immune to the surge of expansion, remaining conspicuous in its ability to get along on one restaurant that has served the area for the past 11 years: Di Nardo's.

title: Impeachment of Judges Is a Job for Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Mosquito Infestation Expected In June
description: NEW JERSEYANS are likely to be doing a lot of scratching this month. The heavy rainfall in May created excellent spawning conditions for the state's 61 varieties of mosquitoes and hampered efforts by mosquito-control officials to kill the larvae before they hatch.

title: For the Sushi and Sukiyaki Lover
description: THERE has been a flurry of Japanese restaurant openings in southwestern Connecticut, as enthusiasm for sushi and other Japanese dishes mounts. The newest restaurant is Fuji, housed in a one-story, creamy-tan stucco building (which has hosted more than its share of restaurants in the past), off exit 13 on Interstate 95 North in Darien.

title:
GARDENING;
Rediscovering the Hearty Old Rose
description: LEAD: ROSE and marigold enthusiasts battled for years in Congress to determine which plant should be the national flower. Marigold supporters argued for the honor, saying the plant is native. Rose supporters argued that roses were universally loved. It was not too much of a surprise when the rose won.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Lopez Leads by One Stroke: Nancy Lopez shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday in Toledo for a one-stroke lead over Laura Davies of Britain and a two-stroke edge over Betsy King after 54 holes of the Jamie Farr Toledo Classic. King, 32, shot a third-round 68 for a 54-hole total of seven-under 209. Lopez leads at 207, and Davies, who matched Lopez's 69 Saturday, is at 208.(AP) Halatsky Leads by Two: Morris Hatalsky, going for his first tournament triumph since 1983, shot a three-under-par 68 yesterday to take a two-stroke lead over three players after the third round of the $800,000 Kemper Open at Potomac, Md. Hatalsky, who missed the cut in each of his last three tournaments, finished with an 11-under-par 202 through 54 holes at the Tournament Players Club at Avenel. Craig Stadler, who shot a course-record 64, Mike Reid and John Mahaffey were two strokes off the pace.(AP) Lyle Increases His Lead: Sandy Lyle moved ahead in the $465,000 British Masters golf tournament yesterday at Woburn, England. He shot a third-round 68 to lead the field by four strokes. After three rounds, Lyle's total of 202 gave him a comfortable advantage over the British Open champion, Nick Faldo of Britain, whose third-round 67 gave him an aggregate of 206. In third place was Jose Maria Olazabal of Spain, who shot a 71 to fall six strokes off the lead.(AP) MARATHON Winner Leads by 34 Seconds: Suleiman Nyambui of Tanzania coasted to a 34-second victory over Jose da Silva of Brazil in the 10th Stockholm Marathon yesterday. Nyambui, who graduated from the University of Texas-El Paso last year, covered the 26-mile-385-yard race, held in chilly and wet weather, in 2 hours 14 minutes 26 seconds. It was well off Nyambui's personal best of 2:11:11, set when he won for the first time in a marathon at Berlin last year. But this hilly course is considered to be much more difficult. Grete Waitz of Norway took a big step toward a fourth Olympic start by easily winning the women's division. Waitz took the lead early in the women's field of 1,163 and never was challenged as she finished in an excellent time of 2:28:24. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD A Personal Best: Nnenna Lynch, a Hunter College High School junior, turned in her best time for the 800-meter run yesterday at Randalls Island in the Public Schools Athletic League's girls outdoor championships when she won the event in 2 minutes 12.2 seconds. The 16-year-old also won the 1,500-meter run in 4 minutes 43.2 seconds for a double victory. Lynch's times in both the 800 and 1,500 were meet records. Kyron Agard, a sophomore at Tilden, won the girls' 100-meter dash in 10.04 seconds and the 200-meter dash in 24.87. In the P.S.A.L. boys title meet, Greg St. Omar of Prosepct Heights, Brooklyn registered his fastest individual time for 800 meters when he won in 1 minute 53.7 seconds. Double winners in the boys' events included Ray Stilva of Tottenville who took the shot-put at 54 feet 5 1/4 inches and the discus throw at 162-2, and Clandale Brown of Bushwick who won the 100-meter dash in 10.94 seconds and the 200-meter dash in 22.34. Ramon Espinosa of Washington, after winning the 3,200-meter run in 9:24.1, lost his opportunity for a double victory when Dave Whitehouse, son of the Tottenville coach, passed him in the final 10 meters for the victory in the 1,500-meter run in 4:20.23. TENNIS Edberg Beats Curren in Final: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the world's No. 2 player, continued his warm-up for the Wimbledon tennis championships yesterday at Manchester, England, by beating Kevin Curren of the United States in the final of the Northern grass-court tournament. Edberg, a late addition to the draw after being knocked out of the French Open last week, won by 6-3, 6-4. In the women's singles final, Ronni Reis of the United States beat Hester Witvoet of the Netherlands, 6-7, 6-4, 6-2. (AP) Horace Mann Advances in 2 Divisions: Intermittent rain put a damper on the first day of competition for the Mayor's Cup Trophy at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow Park in Queens yesterday. But before things got too wet in the citywide secondary school tournament, Horace Mann defeated Junior High School 239, 5-0, in the mixed middle school division, while the school scored a 5-0 victory over Xaviar in the boys' high school division. No matches had been completed in the girls' high school division by the time a second rain storm of the day interrupted play just before 4 P.M. An earlier rain had stopped play for two hours. In the other middle school competion, St. Francis Prep defeated Intermediate School 78, 4-1; St. David's scored a 4-1 victory over Junior High 240; Junior High 43 beat Junior High 216, 4-1, and Junior High 180 won by default over Junior High 104. Junior High 145 and Waggoner Junior High drew byes to the second round. BOWLING Pair Holds Early Lead to Win: Joe Berardi and Dave Ferraro captured the $140,000 Professional Bowlers Association Showboat Doubles Classic yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev., beating Pete Weber and Brian Voss, 214-210, in the championship game. Berardi and Ferraro jumped out to an early lead and hung on for the win. Ferraro converted a relatively easy 2-5 spare in the final frame and followed that with a nine-count to shut out Weber and Voss before they could bowl their 10th frame.(AP)

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CREW RACES

title: Marie Silverman And Bob Marich, A Writer, Marry
description: Marie Saxon Silverman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Syd Silverman of White Plains, was married yesterday to Peter Robert Marich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vladislav Marich of Oak Park, Ill. Msgr. John J. Healy performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows in White Plains.

title: California Primary Testing Candidates' Fall Strategies
description: It was supposed to provide a rousing grand finale to the nominating season, as it has so often done in the past. But with the Presidential candidates in both parties all but chosen, Tuesday's California primary has turned out to be a trial heat for the fall election.

title: Rebecca Cox Wed To Wilfrid Wood
description: Rebecca Lee Cox, a daughter of Walter C. Cox of Lexington, Ky., and the late Mary Lee Engle Cox, was married yesterday to Wilfrid Kip Wood, the son of Wilfred P. Wood of Bernardsville, N.J., and the late Carol Tompane Wood. The Rev. Franklin Owen performed the ceremony at Calvary Baptist Church in Lexington.

title: Ex-Arizona Legislator Guilty
description: Former Representative Sam Steiger was placed on four years' probation and fined $5,480 on Friday for pressuring a parole board member on a personnel matter while working for Gov. Evan Mecham, who was later ousted from office. Judge Ronald Reinstein of the Maricopa County Superior Court also ordered him to perform 700 hours of community service work.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETS.
description: IT'S not that Sallie Slate is particularly status conscious; for goodness' sake, you'd have to be pretty far gone to even think of status in connection with garbage. No, it's just that Ms. Slate liked the looks of the brown and white striped bags from Henri Bendel - pretty and crisp, she thought - and she often dumped her garbage in them because they were just the right size to slide down the chute to the compactor.

title: SHULTZ, IN JORDAN, APPEALS TO KING ON MIDEAST PLAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew to Jordan today to make a fresh appeal to King Hussein to support the United States blueprint for a comprehensive peace in the Middle East. But American officials said the King's response was ambivalent.

title: The Thailand Touch in Chatham
description: LEAD: THAI cuisine is hot in both senses of the word: hot and spicy and, following hard on the heels of Sichuan and Cajun fare, rapidly gaining popularity in New Jersey.

title: READ AND RUN: A CRAM COURSE FOR THE PRESIDENCY
description: Between speeches and strategy sessions, the Presidential candidates might find time for useful summer reading. The Book Review asked a number of notable people for suggestions in their fields of expertise. Their recommendations follow. Scott Turow A practicing lawyer and the author of ''Presumed Innocent,'' a novel, and ''One L,'' a nonfiction account of his first year in law school.

title: Dorothy Oehmler Is a Bride
description: Dorothy Drew Oehmler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Oehmler of Huntington Bay, L.I., and Eugene Warren Williams, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Williams of Southfield, Mich., were married yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I., by Msgr. John Casey. The bride is an editorial assistant at New York Graphic Society Books, a division of Little Brown & Company. The bridegroom is a management consultant for Corporate Decisions in Boston.

title: Flying Four Flags: Patriotism or an Ad?
description: JAMES GRAYBILL says that he considers himself a patriot, and that putting up four flags outside his service station in Old Lyme was just showing the way he felt.

title: The French Rethink the Prospect of One Europe
description: ''THERE was a fear of Europe in this election - one could feel it,'' declared Prime Minister Michel Rocard at his first news conference last month. ''We will have to respond to that by making Europe reassuring.''

title: An Island of Sequestered Wildflowers
description: IN deeply wooded country here is a special place and a special person. The special place is a small island wildflower sanctuary within the 400-acre Teatown Lake Reservation, an environmental education center. The special person is Marjorie Swope, who, although in her early 80's, does not hesitate to don blue jeans and hat so she can plant and weed the wildflowers she dearly loves.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: It's not easy to cook with your feet up. But having nourished the imagination, some of the new cookbooks will inevitably whet the summertime appetite and inspire even the laziest of cooks.

title: Why We Search for R.F.K.
description: Why, after 20 years, are we recalling the memory of Robert F. Kennedy? Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected President four times and greatly loved, but we did not celebrate him in 1965. Why Robert Kennedy, who was cut down before he could reach the office?

title: Mixing Legal Studies And Municipal Service
description: It was final exam week recently at New York Law School, and Angelo J. Aponte, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, was just another student. So was Marilyn J. Flood, Executive Director of the city's Commission on the Status of Women, who used some of her vacation time to study for the tests.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE First Jersey National Bank will waive fees amounting to $50,000 and award 30-year fixed-rate mortgages at 9.25 percent to the purchasers of 38 affordable town houses in Jersey City.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Against, and Sometimes For, Interpretation

title: David L. Guyer Memorial
description: A memorial service for David L. Guyer, a former diplomat at the United Nations and later president of the Save the Children Federation, will be Friday at noon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. Mr. Guyer, a resident of Manhattan, died May 14 at age of 62 in Honolulu.

title: Huskies Finally Row to Title
description: Northeastern's eight-oared crew at long last won the Varsity Challenge Cup today at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on Onondaga Lake.

title: Washington: From sweltering valleys to Ice Age grandeur
description: Washington's North Cascades Highway: Alpine meadows, bursting with lupine and Indian paintbrush, or millennias-old glaciers, tinged blue in the sunlight, unpredictable, scary at one moment, sublime at the next. For about 100 miles, the motorist will pass through almost every type of terrain and climate known in the West. On the North Cascades Highway, the Ice Age lives not far from river valleys where summer temperatures average 90 degrees.

title:
SUMMER READING;
THE THINGS THEY BABBLED TO WILLIE
description: LEAD: BREAKING AND ENTERING By Joy Williams. 279 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries. Paper, $6.95.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Shopping Centers; After the Boom, Vacant Stores and Lagging Sales
description: NOW that developers have squeezed shopping centers onto almost every site that held even a little promise, competition for shoppers has grown too intense for projects flawed by poor location or management.

title: D. B. Wake Wed To Miss Phlipot
description: Constance Ann Phlipot and Douglas Bruce Wake, Foreign Service officers, were married yesterday at the American Foreign Service Club in Washington by Commissioner Morton Berg of Superior Court of the District of Columbia.

title:
GARDENING;
Including a Splash of White
description: LEAD: A GARDEN designed to be enjoyed in both daylight and moonlight, a white garden does not have to be the sole province of those blessed with acres of land and bushels of ready cash.

title: Trade Bill Doesn't Force Plant Buyer to Hire Seller's Employees
description: To the Editor:

title: UConn Pitcher Closer To a Baseball Dream
description: IT is something Charles Nagy has thought about since he first began to play baseball. He would play catch in the backyard with his older brother, Rich, and dream about being elsewhere. In his fantasies, Charles was never in the backyard. He was on the pitcher's mound in a major league ballpark.

title: One Million Expected At the Polls In Primaries
description: ABOUT a million voters, or 27 percent of those eligible, are expected to cast ballots Tuesday in the state's primary elections, according to Jane Burgio, the Secretary of State. The polls will be open from 7 A. M. to 8 P.M.

title: What Might Have Been
description: Is history the product of impersonal social and economic forces, or can individuals change its course? That old question comes to mind as we approach the anniversary of the death of Robert Kennedy.

title: Sheila A. Murray Wed To Felipe S. Prestamo
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., Sheila Ann Murray, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Murray of Neptune, N.J., was married yesterday to Felipe S. Prestamo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Felipe J. Prestamo of Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Fred C. Magnuson Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Church to Accept Zoning Conditions
description: LEAD: IN zoning matters, religious institutions often get their own way.But in Valley Stream, the

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Temple Gets Room to Grow
description: LEAD: A 4.8-ACRE parcel of land on Broad Street in North Philadelphia, for 50 years the site of a large car dealership, will now provide growing room for the adjacent main campus of Temple University.

title: Troubles Still Roil State Rent Agency
description: MORE than a year after legislators attacked New York State's rent regulation agency for gross inefficiencies and mismanagement, it still is plagued by many of the same problems and its new director says it could take two more years to straighten out the mess.

title: AFRICAN DISPUTES PIT ARAB VS. BLACK
description: The article in a recent issue of a West African magazine described the Libya of centuries past, but few black African readers failed to grasp its implied message about the Libya of today. Its headline: ''The First Slave Traders.''

title: Governments Struggle To Find Employees
description: LEAD: THE Bergen County Executive received a call from the representative of an out-of-state company that wanted to relocate to Bergen, but only if it could be guaranteed of finding 1,000 white-collar workers.

title:
;
A Second Thayer Honor
description: LEAD: For the second year in a row, a student from State University of New York at Purchase has won the Walter N. Thayer Fellowship in the Arts. Julie Sukman, an actress, won the $7,000 award, which is given to a graduating State University-system senior pursuing a career in the arts. Last year's winner was a dancer, Nikki

title: Let's Not Yet Give Up on American Science; On With Supercollider
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Bridgeport, Conn. $119,000 330 Bond Street 2-family house; 2 apartments with a total of 5 bedrooms and 2 baths, needs work, in-town location, 25- by 100-foot lot; taxes $1,400. Weston, Conn. $477,500 8 Old Kings Highway 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; pond views, c/a, 2.4 acres; taxes $4,710. Wilton, Conn. $353,500 17 Hanford Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; recently renovated, new bathrooms and kitchen, .5 acre; taxes $2,506. Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $350,000 201 Jackson Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, living room with fireplace, 2-car garage, .43 acre; taxes $5,062. Scarsdale, N.Y. $535,000 8 Autenreith Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 70-year-old frame farmhouse; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage, .32 acre; taxes $6,502. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $197,000 916 Parkway Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old brick ranch; fireplace, 1-car garage, walk to transportation and shopping, .25 acre; taxes $4,298. OTHER AREAS Glen Cove, L.I. $375,000 11 Marietta Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, c/a, cathedral ceilings, 2-car garage; estimated taxes $5,000. Selden, L.I. $152,500 5 Buick Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Alpha, N.J. $99,500 908 Park Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, dining room; taxes $1,100.

title: COMMUNING WITH NATURE
description: AS OPULENT AND often aggressive architect-designed homes have overcrowded the Hamptons in recent years, the image of the simple, modern beach house now seems as anachronistic as the acres of potato fields that once dominated the Long Island landscape. A few of these shacklike structures still exist, however, including the house shown on these pages. Tucked away on a small parcel of land off the main road, it has a kind of understated chic that is not only appropriate for life by the seashore but also reflects the impeccable taste of the owner, Lee Bailey, the designer and author.

title: Tainted Water Worries Boston
description: The city has shipped bottled water to half its elementary schools after state health officials found lead concentrations in drinking water exceeded Federal limits.

title: Ankle Monitor Gets A Home Tryout
description: WHEN Denise Keller arrived home one recent evening, she heard her husband, James, the assistant director of public affairs for the county, conducting a most peculiar telephone conversation. ''Alaska,'' he intoned solemnly. ''Tennessee. California.''

title: Judge Drops Out of Race For Prosecutor in Bronx
description: In a bizarre turn to an already fractious political race, the Bronx Democratic leader's handpicked candidate for District Attorney has decided not to run, leaving the splintered party searching for a challenger to oppose the interim prosecutor, Paul T. Gentile, in the September primary.

title: Daughters, Mothers And Abortion
description: A FRIEND recently asked me how I felt about abortion.

title: COLORADO'S THRIVING CULTS
description: I've been working for the last five years on an oral history of American beliefs and values. I've spent the last two years in Denver. It is true that Boulder has a high percentage of spiritual seekers, but Colorado as a whole is hardly a hotbed of New Age spirituality.

title: Headliners; On the Mound
description: It never occurred to Jim Abbott that baseball was a game only for people with two hands. Nor did the California Angels give much thought to Abbott's handicap: they drafted the University of Michigan pitcher in the first round last week. Abbott, who was born without a right hand, has a 94-mile-an-hour fastball and a 26-8 record at Michigan. Chatting with reporters after his selection was announced, Abbott said he grew up playing baseball and never thought of himself as handicapped. ''As I look back on it, it was a different situation and if I had any common sense, I probably would've stopped,'' he said. ''But growing up, playing with one hand never entered my mind as holding me back.'' This season, Abbott may play for his country instead of for California: he has been invited to try out for the United States Olympic team.

title: Book Review/Section 7
description: The Summer Reading issue.

title: Flavor of Puri
description: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed Claire Frankel's article on Puri (Travel, April 3). Having just come from a vacation there, I can testify that she has nicely captured some of the flavor of this very special place.

title: The Altoona Papers (cont.): Discovering Who Was Who
description: A tourist's postcard from Rome, described here May 8, has undergone the sort of textual analysis usually reserved for newly found verses ascribed to Shakespeare. It has been great fun, involving West Coast relatives of the addressee, East Coast friends of the relatives and a film buff in the Bronx.

title: Karen Donfried Weds Alan Untereiner
description: At the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., Karen Erika Donfried, the daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Karl P. Donfried of Amherst, Mass., was married yesterday to Alan Edward Untereiner, the son of Dr. Wayne W. Untereiner of Rancho California, Calif., and the late Ann Yeomans Abbot. The Rev. Paul Bosch and the bride's father, Lutheran ministers, performed the ceremony.

title: Lauren Jannucci Marries in Jersey
description: Lauren Elaine Jannucci, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Jannucci of Mendham and Normandy Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Robert Mulcahy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Mulcahy 3d of Mendham. Msgr. Kenneth E. Lasch performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. James in Basking Ridge, N.J. He was assisted by the Revs. Edward Kearns and George Moore.

title: The Waldheim Docu-Trial
description: Television history is often suspect history: trivialized and rewritten shamelessly to grab a mass audience. Hence the shudders many people felt on learning that Britain's Thames Television has joined with Home Box Office to put Kurt Waldheim before the bar on the box. The fears are unfounded. ''Waldheim: A Commission of Inquiry,'' to be shown tonight on cable TV, respects history and the rights of Mr. Waldheim.

title: GERMAN MINERS RESCUED AFTER NEARLY 3 DAYS TRAPPED IN AIR POCKET
description: Six miners were pulled alive from a mine shaft today, nearly three days after an explosion trapped them in a pocket of air deep underground. Rescuers, who had given up hope, said there may be more survivors and rescue efforts would intensify.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No More Mugs For John Singer Sargent, to make a living painting portraits was like being the host of a perpetual tea party. The story of how he gave it up in 1907 is told in ''John Singer Sargent: His Portrait'' by Stanley Olson (St. Martin's).

title: Broadway Classics And Classic Folk Artists
description: THE program for the original edition of ''Guys and Dolls'' and the road companies of ''Call Me Madam'' and ''Can-Can'' listed a promising ballerina named Conchita del Rivero. When she became a featured dancer in one of the ''Shoestring Revues,'' the name was changed and, as the saying goes, a star was born.

title: Tennessee-N. Carolina: Off the beaten path through the Great Smokies
description: The main route through the Great Smoky Mountains, Newfound Gap Road, twists and almost turns back on itself as it rises to reveal a series of views of forested slopes and bald areas of rock slides. But for the motorist who does not mind a bit of meandering, there are several roads off this two-lane, 45-mile highway that present the mountains in all their variety. Instead of using the main entrance, at Gatlingburg, Tenn., approach Great Smoky Mountains National Park from Route 321 and begin at the little-used entrance at Townsend, Tenn. Drive west on Little River Road, through cove hardwood forests, deeply shaded with yellow poplar, magnolia and oaks. Drive seven and a half miles to Cades Cove, a preserved early settlement where the canopy of trees gives way to open meadows dotted with log cabins, a church and mill. An 11-mile, one-way loop allows visitors to see a small slice of human history in the Smokies. The people have been there 100 years; the mountains, hundreds of millions of years.

title: Elizabeth Noone Marries a Physician
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ann Noone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Noone Jr. of Alexandria, Va., to Dr. Samuel Thompson Merrick, a son of Mrs. Charles N. Gregg Jr. of McLean, Va., and Dr. John V. Merrick 4th of Puyallup, Wash., took place yesterday at the summer home of the bridegroom's family in Matunuck, R.I. The Rev. Elizabeth M. Nestor, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Let's Not Yet Give Up on American Science; Forget NASA's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: When Medicine Has Only Miracles Left
description: ''HARVEY, the doctor told me I have leukemia,'' said my 44-year-old brother, Ted. I try to find a place to sit and digest the horrible news my brother is relating to me on the phone.

title: From SoHo to Caramoor
description: On Wooster Street

title: Part-Time Workers Are Ruled Eligible For Pension Benefits
description: Part-time employees of New York City, who until now have been excluded from municipal pension programs, are eligible for such benefits, the state's highest court ruled this week.

title: Dukakis, on Stump Again, Stresses the Family
description: Michael S. Dukakis returned to the campaign trail today, thanked his audience for their ''good wishes and prayers'' for his ailing wife, then sketched a Democratic vision of the needs of the family.

title: Reviews/Music; Mezzo-Soprano in Debut
description: By the time Hyunjoo Yun had completed the set of Mendelssohn songs that came midway through the first half of her debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening, the mezzo-soprano's considerable gifts had become apparent. Miss Yun, a Korean-born artist who received her doctorate in voice at the Manhattan School of Music, sings with ease and grace, bringing a surety of pitch and a steady, unforced approach to fluid melodic lines. Her voice is light and fresh-sounding, if not distinctively rich when pushed toward its lower end; but Miss Yun managed to deliver high notes in a forceful and never shrill fashion.

title: Ciao, New Jersey; Hello, Kentucky
description: WHEN my friends and business associates heard that I was moving from New Jersey to Murray, Ky., they sent me sympathy cards - lots of grim black borders and soothing words about time healing all wounds.

title: THE REGION: Anderson's Exit; Redefining The Republican
description: A MERE shadow of the power it once was, the New York State Republican Party lost one of its few remaining giants last week when Warren M. Anderson, the State Senate majority leader, announced that he had decided to retire in December.

title: Janet Lee Collins Wed To Roger Lyle Drumm
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., Janet Lee Collins, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman R. Collins of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Roger Lyle Drumm, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ray Drumm of Penn Yan, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony.

title: The New and the Rococo, by Trio Bell'Arte
description: Music of C. P. E. Bach, adventurous but well within the realm of rococo pleasantry, alternated with new scores that sought and found a similar musical realm at the Trio Bell'Arte concert Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall. The ensemble consists of Robert Stallman (flute), Bert Lucarelli (oboe) and Elaine Comparone (harpsichord), and the first new piece was a ''Spring Sonata'' for all three instruments by William Thomas McKinley.

title: DeLoach Equals Record in 100 Meters
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships ended today with the usual array of unusual developments for a meet this size, and Joe DeLoach of Houston still has difficulty believing what happened to him.

title: Street Fashion; With Grips, Snug Is a Cinch
description: EVER wonder how to take up the sag in the back of that oversize jacket? Or how to keep your T-shirt sleeves rolled up, your pants from falling down or your leg warmers from drooping? Obviously, there are many ways, but those who are fashion-conscious have been using little gizmos that serve all those functions, and a few others too. Called mini-grips or grippers, they consist of little elastic bands with metal grips on either end. They look like suspenders for extremely short people.

title: Nazis and History To the Editor
description: If Serge Schmemann's article [ ''Germans Argue Over a Museum That Will Offer a Probing Look at Their History,'' May 15 ] is any indication of what the world can expect from this venture, we should not get up our hopes. The article is filled with empty verbiage and euphemisms, much of it quotations from German publications: ''The museum should help . . . this country realize who they are as Germans and as Europeans, where they come from, where they stand and where they may be going.'' Whatever that means! The reader really has to search for allusions to genocide, death camps, torture. Rather one finds the whining relativism one has come to expect from exasperated West Germans. Predictably, they wish to remind the world that West Germany is not unique in having to deal with its past. What about the Russian gulag, America's Vietnam and France's occupation?

title: Proposition to Watch
description: Politicians often claim that voters oppose spending tax dollars to finance election campaigns. A voter-initiated referendum on Tuesday's California ballot offers an intriguing test.

title: When T-Shirts Just Won't Do
description: THEY were sleep clothes designed for women who have never worn traditional lingerie and are getting tired of oversize T-shirts, explained Carole Hochman, a lingerie designer. She was describing her Bordeaux collection of cotton knit styles, made in Israel, that double for sleeping and lounging. They are decorated with polka dots or lace and include loose tops, teddies, boxer shorts and robes. Everything is priced well under $100. The cotton knit group was the hit of Mrs. Hochman's recent showing of her extensive lingerie designs, which included traditional trousseau gowns as well luxurious printed silk robes from her Christian Dior collection. The cotton knits were the hands-down favorite of the professional audience, which included mature women as well as the young people for whom they were designed. ''There's a place for nontraditional lingerie,'' Mrs. Hochman said.

title: Ms. Tauber Is Married To John F. Mulholland
description: At the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains, Sharon Allison Tauber, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Tauber of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to John Frank Mulholland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Herbert Mulholland of Monroe, Conn. Rabbi Abraham Klausner and the Rev. Wayne Lavender, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: INSIDE
description: Missteps in Afghanistan

title: Correction
description: An article about alternative energy sources in The Week in Review on May 22 misstated the status of Federal income tax credits for investment in geothermal and solar power. The tax credits were extended at a reduced rate in 1985. They are scheduled to expire by the end of this year.

title: Foes Dig In on Gun Ban in Maryland
description: Opponents and proponents of laws to control the sale and manufacturer of pistols are engaged in a fight in Maryland whose outcome could have a major effect on firearms control elsewhere in the country.

title: Troubled Youth Learning to Put Lives Back Together
description: Franklin Academy, a private school for troubled teen-agers, is a study in contrasts. It is run by a rabbi out of a building that was built as a Catholic school for girls. The confessional is still on the second floor.

title: Delays Likely on Palisades Parkway
description: MOTORISTS will encounter intermittent lane closings on the Palisades Interstate Parkway until Dec. 16 while bridges on the parkway are being rehabilitated.

title: Another Arms Pact Is Within Reach
description: LEAD: Now that Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have completed ratification of the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces, they have an opportunity to achieve more together in the remaining seven months of the President's term than both countries have in the past seven years.

title: Rev. Clyde Taylor, 83; Led Evangelical Group
description: The Rev. Dr. Clyde W. Taylor, retired general director of the National Association of Evangelicals, died Friday of cancer at his home in Arnold, Md. He was 83 years old.

title: Kodak to Back Home Values at Chemical Site
description: Saying they wanted to ''do the right thing,'' Eastman Kodak Company officials acted this week to stabilize real-estate values in two communities shaken by reports of possible chemical contamination.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHAT WOULD A GUINEA PIG DO? Written and illustrated by Kate Duke. Unpaged. New York: E. P. Dutton.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Drop That Flower! Hands Up!

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Colonnades Question
description: LEAD: MAYOR Nicholas A. Wasicsko of Yonkers has consistently said he would prefer that his tenure be marked by tearing down a monument rather than erecting one. He may soon have his wish. Late last month, the Yonkers City Council voted unanimously to remove the Colonnades - a plaza of 17 concrete columns in two clusters rising 25 above Getty

title: Five Views on How to Do Things Differently
description: Remove the Privilege Of Being First

title: Boskin: Mainstream Conservative
description: MICHAEL J. BOSKIN, for Vice President Bush, and Lawrence H. Summers, for Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, have emerged as leading economists in the 1988 Presidential campaigns. If, as expected, Mr. Dukakis and Mr. Bush oppose each other this fall, one of these economists is likely to land a top job in the next Administration and to put his theories to work.

title: Dinah Minot Marries Grant Hubley, Actor
description: Dinah Curtis Minot, a daughter of George R. Minot of Manchester, Mass., and the late Helen R. Minot, was married in Manchester yesterday to Grant S. Hubley Jr., the son of Mrs. Hal C. B. Clagett Jr. of Upper Marlboro, Md., and the late Mr. Hubley. The Rev. James J. Harrington performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Union Support Spurs Housing
description: LEAD: THE largest of three below-market-rate housing developments built with labor union support is rising on 11 acres at the foot of Mission Hill.

title: Casting Aside All Cares: Fishing in Montana
description: JUST north of the hamlet of Wolf Creek, Mont., the Missouri River moves slowly. It oxbows on its course like a moving snake, winding its way alternately through steep-walled canyons and past open fields where sprinklers mounted on wheels arc water over lush fields of alfalfa, and small rainbows hover in the mist above each sprinkler head.

title: TALES OF A WAR HORSE
description: TRAVELLER By Richard Adams. 270 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: The Fight to Break the Squeeze of Time
description: TIME is shrinking. I don't know if someone is stealing it or if there's a conspiracy going on. Whether it's cooked up by our Government or another, on this planet or another, it's of cosmic proportions.

title: Michele Martin Is Married To Robert Noel Grossman
description: The Wren Chapel at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., was the setting for the wedding yesterday of Michele Ashton Martin, a meeting planner for Merrill Lynch & Company, and Robert Noel Grossman, a marketing analyst for Tennis magazine, both in New York. The Rev. David Blakely performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Fair Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL GRIDLOCK
description: I was flabbergasted at the solution offered by the experts and engineers to the problem of ''transportation hell'' (''National Gridlock,'' by James Gleick, May 8). Their answer is to outfit every car with its own radar system tied to a centralized computer! I can see it now: cars screeching and fuming down the side streets of Los Angeles, New York and San Francisco, each driver trying to beat the other guy to the office. The problem is that everyone will be using the same short cut.

title: DRESSED TO KILL
description: THE INVITATION READS ''BLACK TIE,'' and full regalia seems in order - from the requisite pleat-front shirt to the ribbed bow tie to the black evening jacket that properly tops the whole outfit.

title: DATA UPDATE: June 5, 1988
Bush's Campaign, Amid Frictions, Confers With New Faces and Old Allies
description: Vice President Bush's organization is reaching out for more Republican talent at a time when there is already confusion about who is in charge of a campaign that is starting to show friction and irritability.

title: Learning the Value of Money, Again
description: MONEY, everyone knows, just isn't what it used to be. Most of us remember, or remember hearing from our parents, how penny candy really used to cost a penny. Some can remember when Saturday movie matinees cost 50 cents and gas cost less than $1. But where, oh where, have those days gone?

title: Musical Therapy for the Terminally Ill
description: Curled under a floral blanket on a mattress in the middle of the living room, a woman lies dying of lung cancer. Beside her bed, a pair of musicians smile as they play ''A Lot of Living to Do'' on flute and piano.

title: Street Smarts for 18 Ducks
description: Why did the 18 ducks cross the busy street? They were trying to get to the other side, but 17 of them fell into a storm sewer.

title: Lisa M. Maguire and Donald Foley 2d Are Married
description: At St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., Lisa Marie Maguire, a daughter of Suzanne Maguire of Rye, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Edward J. Maguire Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Donald Robert Foley 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Foley of Jupiter, Fla. Msgr. John G. Woolsey performed the ceremony.

title: Lizabeth A. Davey to Wed Samuel Gilliland Jr. in July
description: Lizabeth Ann Davey, the publicity director in New York for the Little, Brown publishing company, and Samuel Alexander Gilliland Jr., a stockbroker at Oppenheimer & Company in New York, plan to be married July 30.

title: Candidates and Stars Bask in Mutual Spotlight
description: With cameras and flashbulbs poised, photographers lined the alley outside the stage door of the glitzy Palace nightclub at Hollywood and Vine, waiting for the star.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The house I am buying has kitchen cabinets covered with a pecan veneer, and I would like to paint them white. Is there a special treatment or special paint for these cabinets?

title: Stimulating Variety In Canadian Works
description: A PANORAMA of ceramics, glass and jewelry by 50 leading artists from across Canada is on view at the Lee Sclar Gallery, 14 South Street, through July 2.

title: Ukrainian Religious Celebrating for 1,000 Reasons
description: The ancient Byzantine ritual was solemn, the a cappella music was haunting, the sanctuary was awash with church dignitaries in green and gold and red and purple and blue robes.

title: Two Views Offered on Drunken Driving
description: In the wake of creating the nation's most stringent D.W.I. (Driving While Intoxicated) laws, New Jersey motorists were ''blessed'' with the Joint Underwriting Association.

title: Mixed Signals On the Economy
description: Unemployment rose in May. In its first increase since October, the unemployment rate reached 5.5 percent, up from April's 14-year low of 5.4 percent. The economy created 209,000 nonfarm jobs in May, nearly all of them in the service-producing sector. There were 536,000 fewer Americans at work than in April; in all, 115,909,000 Americans held jobs in May. Because gains in manufacturing employment were lower than expected, there was some indication that economic growth might be slowing, quieting fears that wages will rise and place upward pressure on the inflation rate. But the job figures also allayed recession fears.

title: Pregnant Women's Use Of VDT's Is Scrutinized
description: Women who used video display terminals for more than 20 hours each week in the first three months of pregnancy suffered almost twice as many miscarriages as women doing other types of office work, according to a new study.

title: Unions Less Sanguine
description: LEAD: IN SPITE of the promised influx of new jobs in Hudson County, labor still has its back to the wall, according to Edward Pulver, president of the Jersey City-based Central Labor Council, an organization of about 35 unions with 80,000 members. He said that business, with its ability to move its operations anywhere in the world where labor was cheap, had the upper hand.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Dewey Beach, Del.; Road Project Worries Resort
description: COMMERCIAL development has begun to pick up again in this coastal resort since a four-year moratorium on sewage hookups was lifted in December. Work has begun on three motels and construction is to begin on two more by the end of the year.

title: A Wave of Start-Ups on Madison Avenue
description: IN the shadow of advertising giants like the JWT Group, Young & Rubicam Inc. and the Ogilvy Group, there is a group of fledgling advertising agencies with far less familiar names. The first group bills billion of dollars and employs thousands of people; most of the second bunch have less than $30 million in billings and payrolls of no more than 19.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A 50th Anniversary Adds Some Respect to the Nickel
description: LEAD: THE Jefferson nickel is 50 years old this year. And the golden anniversary is going largely unnoticed.

title: The Real 'Emperor'
description: To the Editor:

title: Setback for Driver
description: HE made a remarkable comeback after a serious crash last fall, but Roberto Guerrero, the race driver who spent 17 days in a coma last September, has been a bit shaky since returning to the track in January, initially for training and later as a driver in all three of the Indy-car races held so far this season. He had two minor mishaps at Indidanapolis last month, and yesterday, while practicing for the Miller 200 on the one-mile oval at the Wisconsin State Fair Park in Milwaukee, Guerrero was involved in a one-car accident that left him unconscious for a brief period. The 29-year-old Guerrero, who was alert and talking by the time he was removed from his wrecked Lola, was taken to Milwaukee County General Hospital for observation.

title: Racewalking From the Neighborhood to the Grand Prix
description: LEAD: MARYANNE TORRELLAS of Clinton holds virtually every American women's racewalking record, indoors and outdoors, on the road and on the track. And she did not begin racewalking until 1983.

title: The Best 'Ring' Issued On Just 7 Compact Disks
description: A compact disk, as everyone knows, provides slightly more than twice the music contained on a single side of a long-playing, 12-inch black disk.
