Most CD's offer 40 to 65 minutes of music, depending on the generosity of the company. The upper limit is supposed to be about 75 minutes, although some disks have squeezed in a few extra minutes.

title: U.S. Intervention in Panama: For Now, Just Conversation
description: The implicit threat of United States military intervention to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from Panama, if other options prove futile, is not generally taken seriously here, though some Panamanians say they would like the United States to rid them of their military leader.

title: Rockefeller Fellows Program Seeks 5 to Study Urban Issues
description: The New York City Partnership is seeking candidates for its first David Rockefeller Fellows Program. The purpose of the program is to develop ''future generations of leaders'' who will serve in city government, in business or in local, nonprofit organizations.

title: Let's Not Yet Give Up on American Science
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Mall Trade-Offs Provide Housing Bonus
description: LEAD: THE continued growth of malls in the densely populated Hudson and Bergen Counties has meant not only more jobs, but more affordable housing as well.

title: Tippecanoe and Baseball, Too
description: ONE morning a few years ago, my wife and I were driving along State Route 20 in northern Ohio.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Barfly Starring Mickey Rourke, Faye Dunaway, Alice Krige, Jack Nance, J. C. Quinn, Frank Stallone, Sandy Martin, Roberta Bassin, Gloria LeRoy. Directed by Barbet Schroeder. 1987. Warner Home Video. 98 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: Prison Security: Deviled Eggs and Val D'Or
description: The table was covered with a pink tablecloth and set with bone china in the Val D'Or pattern. One hundred chicken breasts simmered in a golden pool of curry sauce, next to 100 servings of Hungarian noodles. As an appetizer, there were 100 fancy deviled eggs.

title: Doctors Polled on Life Support
description: Nearly 80 percent of American physicians favor withdrawing life support systems from ''hopelessly ill'' or irreversibly comatose patients if the patients or their families request it, according to a survey conducted by the American Medical Association.

title: Pamela J. Nott, a Lawyer, Marries Daniel Hirshfield
description: At Bethlehem Lutheran Church in Farmington Hills, Mich., Pamela J. Nott, an associate in the law firm of Gourvitz & Braun in Union, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel S. Hirshfield, the president of his own public-relations concern in Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Jonathan K. Bomgren performed the ceremony.

title: Oceanside Celebrates Past With a Gala
description: LEAD: MUCH has changed in Oceanside since the days when residents made their living farming and oyster planting and farmers grazed their cattle among open acres of sedge and soft hay, but as Doris Chwatsky sees it, much remains the same. The area still has ''a small-town feeling,'' she said, even though the population has multiplied.

title: NATIONAL GRIDLOCK
description: James Gleick's account of research dealing with traffic jams is fascinating and encouraging. It made me think of a chronic problem in New York City that nobody does anything about.

title: A Plug From Reagan, a New Test Ahead
description: STARTLING as it was to watch President Reagan stand before students at Moscow State University last week and deliver a heartfelt plea for freedom and democracy, the real revelation was the reaction of his Soviet listeners. What once would have been taken as a show of American chauvinism was, in this heady time the American President called ''Moscow spring,'' widely regarded as a sort of campaign speech for Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The house I am buying has kitchen cabinets covered with a pecan veneer, and I would like to paint them white. Is there a special treatment or special paint for these cabinets?

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $155,000 273 Second Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Coram $135,000 154 Pauls Path 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 10-year-old ranch; dining room, finished basement; taxes $2,500. Glen Cove $375,000 11 Marietta Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, c/a, cathedral ceilings, 2-car garage; estimated taxes $5,000. Selden $152,500 5 Buick Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Tanglewood Hills $133,000 9 Flair Way 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old attached town house; pool, clubhouse; taxes $2,300 annually, common charges $75 monthly. Westbury $259,000 15 Marlboro Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, den, finished basement; taxes $5,000. OTHER AREAS Weston, Conn. $477,500 8 Old Kings Highway 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; pond views, c/a, 2.4 acres; taxes $4,710. Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $350,000 201 Jackson Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, living room with fireplace, basement with family room, 2-car garage, .43 acre; taxes $5,062. Alpha, N.J. $99,500 908 Park Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, full basement, formal dining room; taxes $1,100.

title: Ecuador Crash Kills General
description: A small military plane that experts think might have been struck by lightning slammed into a Quito mountainside in a storm Friday evening, killing all 11 people aboard, including Ecuador's air force commander, officials said today. Among the dead was an Israeli military attache, Col. Shabtai Ben-Shoua. The air force commander, Gen. Angel Augusto Flores, was succeeded by Gen. Carlos Jaramillo Abarca, Ecuador's air force operations commander.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TO THE RIGHT, MARCH! Musket drills and battle demonstrations by the Bergen County Militia will be the martial highlight of an 18th-century Encampment and Craft Fair at the Dey Mansion Museum in Wayne Saturday and next Sunday.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dewey Beach, Del.; Road Project Worries Resort
description: COMMERCIAL development has begun to pick up again in this coastal resort since a four-year moratorium on sewage hookups was lifted in December. Work has begun on three motels and construction is to begin on two more by the end of the year.

title: Stacy H. Warth Is Married To Mark Carlson Sullivan
description: Stacy Hamilton Warth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stacy Warth of Whitemarsh, Pa., and Mark Carlson Sullivan, a son of William Henry Long Sullivan of Blue Bell, Pa., and the late Eugenia Morris Cheston, were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles Carter performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia.

title:
MUSIC;
New Head of Center Sees Need for Identity
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH only two weeks into his new position, and not officially the full-time executive director until Aug. 1, Paul Brown is convinced that the William Carlos Williams Center for the Performing Arts in Rutherford needs a clear sense of identity and a five-year plan for both the center and the not-yet-restored Rivoli

title: Two Viewpoints On Drunken Driving
description: Recent events at New Jersey colleges involving driving and drinking and drug abuse bring home the local effects of what is a national plague.

title: If America Is Serious About Aids; And Localities Must Fight for Drug Treatment
description: The AIDS epidemic finds fertile ground in New York and other cities where thousands of drug abusers, now denied treatment for their addiction, inject heroin and cocaine up to five times a day. They do so with contaminated syringes, which they share, thus accelerating the spread of the AIDS virus. The rise of AIDS among addicts underscores the Watkins Commission plea for Federal funds to provide treatment on demand to every addict.

title: Not-So-Instant Replay Of the 1987 Playoffs
description: THE process of selecting United States teams for competition in the World Team Olympiad concludes today in Memphis. Before final play-offs began Wednesday, it was certain, since women's teams as well as open teams were involved, that there would be more bidding and play than on a similar occasion a year ago. And it was just about as certain that there would be less drama.

title: How Healthy Is Billy Martin?
description: About a week before opening day, long before the American League umpire crew chiefs vowed to no longer tolerate Billy Martin's ''taproom behavior,'' George Steinbrenner was asked the question that he's had to cope with, off and on, for more than a decade: Will Billy Martin survive the season as the Yankees manager?

title: AIDS Plan: Treat the Addict
description: Government health experts are calling for a major increase in drug treatment centers to slow the spread of AIDS by addicts. Page 28.

title: Saying Goodbye to Cold Calls and Corporate Lunches
description: AFTER decades of doing what they were told at Doyle Dane Bernbach, Roy Grace and Diane Rothschild are not budging now that they have their own agency. They do not make cold calls, they do not take prospects to lunch and they do not accept every offer they get. When the head of a major financial services company started dictating copy and typography, for example, they quit the account. When they started two years ago, they said they would only accept 10 accounts. To date, their roster lists four; their billings are $30 million. ''We're a little ahead of the game,'' Mr. Grace said, adding he had predicted they would be billing $25 million by now.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Tracking Suspects; A New Breed Of Snoopier Computers
description: COMPUTERS that once tracked crime suspects by their Social Security numbers or their criminal records may be on the verge of learning to find them by the sound of their voices, the shape of their faces or even by their basic body chemistry.

title: When Summer Camp Built Character
description: SUMMER camps once provided escape from and counterpoint to modern society: a ritualized time out when individuals left their everyday social identities behind and came together in nature.

title: Mets Win On Homer in 13th
description: Ron Darling thought these days were behind him. Obviously, he was wrong.

title: Dr. Ellen R. Sher Is Married to Philip J. Voorhees
description: The marriage of Dr. Ellen Ruth Sher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Sher of Monmouth Beach, N.J., to Philip James Voorhees, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Voorhees of Brielle, N.J., took place last evening at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Irwin Fishbein performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles Dolan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: >Dr. Maria Mileno Weds
description: Dr. Maria Denise Mileno and Dr. Thomas Edward Sepe, both of whom graduated from Brown University and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx. Msgr. John J. Mescall officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Mileno of the Bronx. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Sepe Jr. of Cranston, R.I.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1987. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: TRIGGERMAN'S FRIEND
description: DADDY'S GIRL The Campbell Murder Case. A True Tale of Vengeance, Betrayal, and Texas Justice. By Clifford Irving. Illustrated. 516 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Molly F. Free Marries John Hall McClement
description: The marriage of Molly Forrest Free, a daughter of Marcella J. Free of New York and Water Mill, L.I., and F. William Free of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., to John Hall McClement took place yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Millbrook. The Rev. Brewster Beach performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. McClement of Andover, Mass., and Northport, Me.

title: Direction for County Youth Bureau Takes a Turn to the North
description: THE newly appointed Executive Director of the County's Youth Bureau, Dr. Antoinette Collarini, heads a division of the County Executive's office established 13 years ago to oversee the development of youth programs in Westchester. Its major responsibility has been to channel more than $2.5 million in state and private funds to community-based agencies, most in urban areas whose target groups are economically and educationally disadvantaged youth. Recently, the Youth Bureau has been engaged in a major effort to extend its reach to smaller, more suburban communities, particularly in the northern part of the county.

title: Paris Is Still for Movie Lovers
description: The other morning, on the segment of a television magazine show devoted to ''le tele-shopping,'' three incredibly cheerful hosts (two men and a woman) admired a block of clear plastic in which an orchid had been embedded and, which, when turned on, was both a lamp and a music box.

title: Urban Food Court
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Romance Romance': Hearts in the Hamptons
description: THE place is the Hamptons; the time is ''August of the current year.'' Sam and Monica, both in their 30's, have been platonic best friends and confidantes since high school; in fact, they're ''living proof that platonic relationships really work,'' as one of them says.

title:
GARDENING;
Rediscovering the Hearty Old Rose
description: LEAD: ROSE and marigold enthusiasts battled for years in Congress to determine which plant should be the national flower. Marigold supporters argued for the honor, saying the plant is native. Rose supporters argued that roses were universally loved. It was not too much of a surprise when the rose won.

title: Anne Emmons, an Art Administrator, And James Stephenson Mason Marry
description: At Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester, Mass., Anne Neal Emmons, a daughter of Diane Neal Emmons of Manchester and Robert Wales Emmons Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to James Stephenson Mason, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Mason of Parkersburg, W. Va., and Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Cynthia Briggs Kittredge performed the ceremony.

title: Elisabeth Shackelford Wed to Timothy R. Dodson
description: The marriage of Elisabeth Carroll Shackelford, a writer and dance-aerobics instructor, to Timothy Rees Dodson, a lawyer, took place yesterday in Atlanta at the home of Renee Shackelford, the bride's mother. The Rev. Roger Ard, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Women Rock Their Way
description: Old truisms die hard, but here's one that finally joined the dinosaurs and the dodos: Women can't rock like men. Sure they can; listen no further than Tina Turner, Joan Jett, Bonnie Raitt, Joan Armatrading, K. D. Lang, Annie Lennox of Eurythmics, Ann and Nancy Wilson of Heart. Now comes phase two -women who rock on their own terms. Among a slew of recent recordings by female singers, songwriters and band leaders (many of whom owe their signings to the popularity of Suzanne Vega's ''Luka''), some suggest that women are ready to shake up, or melt down, conventional rock songwriting. Like feminist artists who rediscovered quilts and samplers, female rockers are - self-consciously or not - reclaiming their own traditions and methods.

title: LORDING IT OVER ENGLAND
description: Israel Shenker's article on the House of Lords bears the headline ''Lording It Over England'' (May 8). Many of us Scots, even exiled ones, recall the Treaty of Union of 1707 with no great fondness; but the inescapable fact is that the House of Lords does indeed lord it over not just England, but Scotland, and indeed Wales and Northern Ireland.

title: Water Protection Area Is Key in Farm Fight
description: LEAD: A TEST of the influence of the State Legislature in protecting Long Island's ground water is unfolding in Huntington, where developers are pressing forward with plans for new housing on two farm parcels that the state designated last year as ground-water protection areas.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Alpha $99,500 908 Park Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, full basement, formal dining room; taxes $1,100. Byram Township $164,500 103 Lake Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; lakefront property, fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,690. Colts Neck $439,900 64 Beaver Dam Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; patio, screened sunroom, 2-car attached garage; taxes $4,000. Denville $500,000 11402 Copeland Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, new colonial; c/a, fireplace in living room, den, deck; taxes $7,200. Lawrence Township $421,500 15 Buckingham Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new colonial; fireplace, two-car attached garage, dining room; taxes $8,600. Stockholm $145,000 3 Fox Trail 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; family room, hardwood floors, 1-car garage, patio; taxes $2,119. OTHER AREAS Weston, Conn. $477,500 8 Old Kings Highway 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; pond views, c/a, 2.4 acres; taxes $4,710. Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $350,000 201 Jackson Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, living room with fireplace, 2-car garage, .43 acre; taxes $5,062. Selden, L.I. $152,500 5 Buick Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300.

title: Massachusetts City Is Given A Friend's Millions of Thanks
description: For the last few years Jacob Hiatt, an industrialist, has shared half of his personal income with Worcester residents - a total of $20 million - to improve education and the arts. He says he plans to donate another $20 million in the next few years ''because I love this city.''

title: Italian Cabinet Accepts NATO F-16's
description: The Italian Government today approved a NATO plan to transfer 72 American F-16 fighter-bombers from Spain to Italy in a move that military experts and officials described as a major enhancement of Italy's role within the Atlantic Alliance.

title: Broadway Breaks Out of Its Shell
description: Were one to evaluate the artistic health of the Broadway musical theater by sorting through the original-cast albums of this year's shows, the doomsaying that usually tolls at the end of each theater season would have to be muted.

title: Youths Who Set Fires Lack Help, Study Finds
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH officials acknowledge that the problem of fires set by juveniles is widespread, the state lacks not only a way to identify such juveniles, but also treatment programs to help them, according to a recently released report.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MINERS' WIVES' TALE Michael Wilding and Brooke Palance are the leading players in ''From Daylight to Boonville,'' opening Wednesday and playing through June 26 at the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls. This will be the third venture for Acorn Productions, a company founded in 1986 by Miss Palance and two actress friends, Pamela Moller and Jane Myers.

title: DAY CARE BECOMES A GROWING BURDEN
description: To the well-documented strains associated with day care, add another: as more women leave home for work and careers, fewer are available to take care of other people's children.

title: 10 Years Later, Voters in California Are Asked to Make Up for Lost Taxes
description: When Californians go to the polls Tuesday they will not only bring down the curtain on the Presidential primary season but also mark the 10th anniversary of the national revolt against taxes and spending they ignited with Proposition 13.

title: RISES AT DAWN, WRITES, THEN RETIRES
description: IN SEARCH OF J. D. SALINGER By Ian Hamilton. 222 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Rights Measure Disturbs Hopes for Soviet Trade
description: While President Reagan was holding out hope for increased Soviet-American trade at the Moscow summit meeting, Congress was weighing action that would make it more difficult for the Administration to reduce barriers to Soviet imports.

title: FIRING YOUR FATHER ISN'T EASY
description: MOONWALK By Michael Jackson. Illustrated. 283 pp. New York: Doubleday. $15.95.

title: THE WORLD: Toward a Political Deal; Having Little Choice, The Sandinistas and The Contras Talk On
description: AFTER two months of verbal sparring, Nicaragua's Government and rebels are getting down to basics. Last weekend they finally began to discuss possible changes in the structure of political power in Nicaragua. Nothing is certain, but there are some signs that a political deal may be within reach at their next meeting this week in Managua.

title: Navajo Eyes On Tourist Trade
description: IN IT'S struggle for economic independence, the 200,000-member Navajo Nation has for more than a decade stressed business and industrial development on its reservation, which stretches over three Western states. Last October, the tribe said it would add a new dimension: a world-class luxury resort hotel.

title: GARDENING
description: The year's surfeit of new garden books is frankly intimidating. But with so many publishers pandering to the dirty-fingernail crowd, it was inevitable that too many offerings would be slick packages geared to the quick sale, devoid of either sustenance or soul. So caveat emptor is the name of the garden book game, and serious browsing is essential for determining which authors know more about their subject than they do about getting their name (or photos) into print. THE OPINIONATED GARDENER: Random Offshoots From an Alpine Garden. By Geoffrey B. Charlesworth. Illustrated by Laura Louise Foster. 197 pp. (Godine, $16.95.) Geoffrey B. Charlesworth's essays are a glorious mix of sophisticated how-to information and dispassionate, occasionally hilarious observations that reveal the arrogance and insecurities of gardeners. The essays, originally intended as contributions to a rock garden society newsletter, are zesty and fast paced. They are also pure pleasure, even if nose-to-soil admiration of microscopic alpine plants is not your favorite garden posture. Organized in loosely related sections, these ''random offshoots'' range from witty musings keyed to the seasons (as in a spring welcoming of ''the swallows and the drabas, also . . . the U.P.S. man with the box of plants you forgot you ordered'') to philosophical ruminations on the gardener's predilection for proselytizing (''every time you give a lithops to an orchid grower . . . you are engaged in an effort to change the recipient's way of life''). It's hard to imagine a merrier way of confronting the likes of androsace or erysimum, especially when armed with such advice as ''if you want to identify plants expertly, you should spend a lot of time surreptitiously reading labels.'' The exquisite line drawings, sensitively rendered by the late Laura Louise Foster, seem the ideal counterpoint to Mr. Charlesworth's elegant prose. THE ANNUAL GARDEN. By Peter Loewer. Illustrated by the author. 242 pp. (Rodale, $19.95.) It's always fun to romp through another garden read with Peter Loewer, whose talent for breezy, informative prose is exceeded only by his ability to translate into winsome line drawings the object of his attention. There are signs of a renewed interest in annuals lurking just down the garden path, and Mr. Loewer's latest offering has arrived in the nick of time to save us from what he calls the ''triple threat of petunias, marigolds and zinnias.'' Here we are introduced (or reintroduced) to the charms of cuphea, cleome, love-in-a-mist, cosmos, schizanthus and over 350 versatile species, not all of which are true annuals, that Mr. Loewer finds praiseworthy as reliable sources of color for a single season. Basic growing techniques are provided - most notably, helpful words on working with seeds. Also included are 14 of Mr. Loewer's easy-to-follow plans for some dazzling and original combinations. TOPIARY: The Art of Clipping Trees and Ornamental Hedges. By A. M. Clevely. Illustrated. 128 pp. (Salem House, $29.95.) THE COMPLETE BOOK OF TOPIARY. By Barbara Gallup and Deborah Reich. Illustrated. 318 pp. (Workman, Paper, $10.95.) Ever since Roman slaves first indulged their masters' passion for plants clipped in fanciful forms, topiary's appeal has ebbed and flowed. Judging from flower show exhibits in recent years, we are presently in a flow phase, so it is fortunate that two fine books are now available to guide us. ''Topiary'' by A. M. Clevely has beautifully informative photographs and no-nonsense, equally informative prose. Mr. Clevely's years of clipping, tying, training and generally having his way with yews, junipers and other woody species are evident from his clear directives and detailed lists of suggested plants. Even those with an aversion to wielding shears themselves will enjoy his discourse on the history of this fascinating, occasionally controversial, garden art. ''The Complete Book of Topiary'' is more a craft manual than a classic garden tome, and thus ideal for those who appreciate step-by-step directives for converting their creeping fig or English ivy into a giraffe or spiral. Illustrated throughout with cheerful line drawings printed in green ink and historical snippets set in the margins, the book has a user-friendly exuberance that makes even the most complex topiary trick seem achievable. The ''complete'' in its title notwithstanding, this book's strength is its focus on tender species for indoor display; outdoors, the authors seem less secure. In a volume packed with so much information, though, it is unforgivable that the publisher has chosen to omit an index. PLANTS FOR PROBLEM PLACES. By Graham Rice. Illustrated. 184 pp. (Timber Press, $29.95.) You can give up your home and move to a better garden site, or turn your liabilities into assets. Graham Rice makes a case for the latter in this delightfully written, well-organized primer of 13 nasty garden problems - among them wind, waterlogged soils and shade. A concise analysis of each difficulty is followed by an assortment of mechanical methods (windbreaks and drains, for example) that can be used to alleviate the condition. Culling his vast horticultural store, Mr. Rice then lists a sampling of trees, shrubs, vines and perennials that may be used as problem solvers. In dry shade, for example, there's Oregon grape holly (Mahonia aquifolium), while Solomon's seal (polygonatum) appreciates damp shade. Mr. Rice's droll style itself should lighten the spirits of those disheartened by vexing gardens. THE ART OF THE KITCHEN GARDEN. By Ethne Clarke. Illustrated by Sharon Beeden. 168 pp. (Knopf, $24.95.) KITCHEN HERBS: The Art and Enjoyment of Growing Herbs and Cooking With Them. By Sal Gilbertie. Photographs by Joseph Kugielsky. Recipes by Frances Towner Giedt. 251 pp. (Bantam, $24.95.) Don't be fooled by the title of Ethne Clarke's book, which in no way belies the extent of her exhaustively researched look at the plants that Western man has grown for his table -fruit trees and flowers, vegetables and herbs. Although Ms. Clarke's focus is the period from the Middle Ages to the 18th century, she also liberally intersperses backward glances (as when we learn that the Roman naturalist Pliny ''noted nine types of lettuces . . . some of which had red-tinted leaves'') as well as glimpses of the present (references to the latest cultivars, like Burpee's recently introduced Purple Ruffles basil). There is truly something for everyone in this artfully organized, handsomely illustrated work, which provides advice on everything from training a fruit tree cordon to making potpourri and a 17th-century apple cream. Ms. Clarke has achieved a smooth blending of captivating historical details and solid gardening information. In ''Kitchen Herbs'' by Sal Gilbertie, an aspiring herbal cook can learn from a third-generation nurseryman. Abundant photographs make this book more colorful than Mr. Gilbertie's two previous works, and, as ever, his homespun conversational style makes it a pleasure to learn from him. Nearly three dozen culinary herbs come under scrutiny here, with growing hints and herbal lore informally blended with kitchen advice. One only wishes there were more. Roughly two-thirds of the book is devoted to carefully presented, original herbal recipes, which seem delectable indeed. THE NEW AMERICAN GARDEN. By Carole Ottesen. Illustrated. 148 pp. (Macmillan, $24.95.) THE AMERICAN WEEKEND GARDEN. By Patricia Thorpe. Illustrated. 285 pp. (Random House, $24.95.) American gardeners have turned to flag-waving - a reaction, understandably, not to discomforting trade relations but to the intimidating achievements of their British garden counterparts (that specter of Tories in the perennial patch). Prose with a particularly jingoistic ring may be found in ''The New American Garden'' by Carole Ottesen, whose ideas on an indigenous approach to landscape design are unequivocal. Ms. Ottesen does make a knowledgeable case for the use of native species, such as prairie grasses like Panicum virgatum, as well as planting styles with meadowlike massings that are neither demanding nor environmentally destructive. But her ''manifesto for today's gardener'' (as it's called on the jacket) does grind the patriotic ax a tad heavily. Also, the author's debt to her former employers - Oehme, van Sweden & Associates, who were early vocal advocates of this admittedly inspiring approach -should have been more fully disclosed in both her text and picture credits. In ''The American Weekend Garden,'' Patricia Thorpe takes a similar route, but tempers dogma with a friendlier sell. Just as in her first book, ''Everlastings,'' Ms. Thorpe's sensible ideas are presented in a spirited, flowing style, with first-hand admonitions on coping pragmatically with a tract that must maintain itself while the gardener is elsewhere. There is creative advice on the use of a wide range of sumptuous species, from old roses to woodland primulas and roadside Queen Anne's lace. And she is persuasive in reminding readers of the importance of acquiring a sense of the place they expect to enrich, as well as the time they expect to devote to it. GARDENING BY MAIL 2: A Source Book. By Barbara J. Barton. Unpaged. (Tusker Press/Publishers Group West, Paper, $16.) Giving the lie to the coffeetable book syndrome, one of the year's most useful publications is this unillustrated, uncolorful, unpretentious compendium (originally published in 1986 and now revised and updated), whose subtitle could have been ''Everything You Need to Know to Mail Order Any Garden Object You Could Conceivably Hanker For.'' Using her computer (and private press) in an enterprising manner, Barbara Barton has created the ultimate in reference guides by organizing America's multifarious mail-order services into their most accessible form. With humor and crisply worded data, and cross-references galore, Ms. Barton covers the garden field from acacia seeds to Zingiber (the magazine of the American Ginger Society), with every imaginable hose, hammock and humidifier in between. This is the one catalogue no armchair gardener can afford to be without.

title: Cyprus Leaders Plan Talks to End Partition
description: The leaders of the Greek and Turkish communities of Cyprus plan to meet in Geneva next month in a new United Nations-sponsored effort to end the 14-year-old division of their Mediterranean island, according to United Nations officials and diplomats.

title: 'Summer Evenings' Series Enters 'Lucky 13th''
description: FOR a dozen years now, the adventuresome series at Sarah Lawrence College modestly titled ''Summer Evenings'' has neatly bridged the concert gap between the closing of the regular spring season and the start of summer festivals.

title: A Feast Day Of Roast Corn Up in Michigan
description: MOST days, the folks who turn off U.S. Route 2 toward the tiny town of Cooks in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan live there or near there, or have family or friends who do. But one day a year, Cooks gets actual tourists, like my parents and me (they, from Florida, summering near Sault Ste. Marie, a couple of hours farther along; I, from New York City, visiting them after visiting my sister at Bark River, about an hour back). So on that day, a Sunday in August, the small green sign bearing only the town's name is covered up by a conspicuous hand-lettered poster for ''The Cooks Corn Roast, Sunday 12-8,'' with an arrow at the bottom pointing left.

title: Beth Hines and William Battison 3d Are Married
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Elizabeth-Ann Hines, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hines of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Quoque, L.I., was married yesterday to William James Battison 3d, the son of Shirley Battison of Bradenton, Fla., and the late Mr. Battison Jr. The Rev. Thomas J. Joyce performed the ceremony.

title: Broadway's Siren Song
description: To the Editor; Robert Brustein's piece [ ''The Siren Song of Broadway Is a Warning,'' May 22 ] indeed points to trends that disturb the founders of the resident theater movement. I refer to that part of his very provocative essay analyzing the risks assumed by nonprofit theaters transferring new plays to Broadway, particularly when they let the selection of a particular work be influenced by second-guessing commercial producers. From this to becoming a tryout house can be a small step.

title: Landfill Shortage Putting Pressure on Budgets
description: LEAD: A YEAR ago, the impending closing of landfills in East Brunswick and the Hackensack Meadowlands threatened to leave at least a half-dozen North Jersey counties with no place to take their garbage. That danger has passed, but at a price ranging from $65 to $137 a ton at the transfer stations set up to shift the waste to long-haul trucks for the journey to landfills in

title: Devils Played In Wrong Arena
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1987 Christmas issue. THE THANATOS SYNDROME, by Walker Percy. (Ivy/ Ballantine, $4.95.) In a metaphysical thriller, a psychiatrist's patients begin acting like computers. CULTURAL LITERACY: What Every American Needs to Know, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) The author adds to his list of indispensable data. MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK, by Saul Bellow. (Dell, $4.95.) Despite his vast learning, a world authority on lichens is a miserable failure at love. THE NAZI DOCTORS: Medical Killing and the Psychology of Genocide, by Robert Jay Lifton. (Basic, $12.95.) How medical euthanasia led to Nazi genocide. THAT NIGHT, by Alice McDermott. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) A novel of violence in suburbia. THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND: How Higher Education Has Failed Democracy and Impoverished the Souls of Today's Students, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Is creeping relativism eroding American society? PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A deputy prosecutor investigates the murder of his beautiful colleague. STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM: Wall Street, the Raiders, and the Battle for Disney, by John Taylor. (Ballantine, $9.95.) How the disciples of Roy Disney, Walt's brother, took financial revenge. A YELLOW RAFT IN BLUE WATER, by Michael Dorris. (Warner, $7.95.) The thrice-told tale of a Montana Indian family and its dying culture. LOOK HOMEWARD: A Life of Thomas Wolfe, by David Herbert Donald. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) The biography that won this year's Pulitzer Prize. A NIGHT AT THE MOVIES: Or, You Must Remember This, by Robert Coover. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) Absurd cinematic parodies by a master of strange fiction. A SPORT OF NATURE, by Nadine Gordimer. (Penguin, $7.95.) A powerful novel about a white South African woman who marries a black revolutionary. THE MAKING OF THE ATOMIC BOMB, by Richard Rhodes. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) This definitive history of the development of nuclear weapons won a National Book Award and a Pulitzer Prize. ANYWHERE BUT HERE, by Mona Simpson. (Vintage, $6.95.) Adele August flees a boring life in Wisconsin to make her daughter a star. WILLA CATHER: The Emerging Voice, by Sharon O'Brien. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) A biography of the author whose best-known novels include ''O Pioneers!'' and ''Death Comes for the Archbishop.'' BANDITS, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $4.95.) An ex-con, an ex-cop and an ex-nun become involved with contras, Sandinistas and a Miskito Indian. IRON & SILK, by Mark Salzman. (Vintage, $5.95.) A young author tells of two years spent teaching English to Chinese doctors in Hunan. PARADISE, by Donald Barthelme. (Penguin, $6.95.) In this novel, three homeless lingerie models move in with a 53-year-old architect. BEARING THE CROSS: Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, by David J. Garrow. (Vintage, $10.95.) ''The fundament of fact on which future King biographies must rest,'' our reviewer said. SAINTS AND STRANGERS, by Angela Carter. (King Penguin, $5.95.) The characters in these eight stories include Edgar Allan Poe, Lizzie Borden and Jeanne Duval, the alienated mistress of Charles Baudelaire. THE BLIND WATCHMAKER: Why the Evidence of Evolution Reveals a Universe Without Design, by Richard Dawkins. (Norton, $7.95.) To show that God is unnecessary, a biologist programmed a computer to demonstrate a crude but spectacular form of evolution. THE COUNTERLIFE, by Philip Roth. (Penguin, $4.95.) Literary twists are used in this novel to explore the relationship between life and art. MEN'S LIVES, by Peter Matthiessen. (Vintage, $7.95.) Our reviewer called this a ''magnificent and somber portrait'' of the fishermen of Long Island's South Fork. THE LOCKED ROOM: The New York Trilogy, Volume Three, by Paul Auster. (Penguin, $5.95.) The latest of Paul Auster's self-reflexive, metafictional whodunits. THE POLITICAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Houghton Mifflin, $10.95.) How children around the world develop political and moral consciousness. MRS. CALIBAN, by Rachel Ingalls. (Laurel/Dell, $6.95.) An unhappy California housewife has an affair with a 6-foot-7-inch amphibian humanoid named Larry. THE WISE MEN. Six Friends and the World They Made: Acheson, Bohlen, Harriman, Kennan, Lovett, McCloy, by Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) The interwoven life stories of six powerful men. INDIAN COUNTRY, by Philip Caputo. (Bantam, $4.95.) A Vietnam veteran finds life in Michigan's remote Upper Peninsula as frightening as in ''Indian Country'' - G.I. slang for an area under enemy control. THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Vintage, $10.95.) Australia's vast story told with style. ME AND DIMAGGIO: A Baseball Fan Goes in Search of His Gods, by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. (Dell, $3.95.) A New York Times critic contemplates the uneasy relationship between those who play baseball and those who write about it. STARING AT THE SUN, by Julian Barnes. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) According to our reviewer, this novel about a transcendent flight to the sun is ''a marvelous literary epiphany.''

title: Catherine Wick Weds Physician
description: The marriage of Catherine Lee Wick to Dr. Robert Michael McLean, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin B. McLean of Potomac, Md., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Wick of Watertown, Conn., the parents of the bride. The Rev. William Zito, minister of the First Congregational Church in Watertown, performed the ceremony.

title: Museum Revamping After Years of Conflict
description: LEAD: PLAGUED by bitter disputes with the Office of Cultural Development, the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, one of the prime cultural institutions on the Island, is preparing for a reorganization that signals a new direction for the museum.

title: World-Hopping Documentary Film Maker Hops the Subway
description: LEAD: JAMES LIPSCOMB stepped out of his Tarrytown home, approached a newly planted tree and gently touched its lacy branches. ''I study this birch every morning, and it's such a thrill; this is my first spring in Westchester in three years,'' he said.

title: A Technology Analyst's Bank
description: WHEN is a bank not really a bank? Maybe when a technology analyst recommends its stock. In view of how it earns most of its money, the State Street Boston Corporation is ''primarily a data-processing service company'' rather than a bank, said Gary J. Blauer, a vice president at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. ''How many banks can you name where the president comes from I.B.M. sales management?'' he said. Mr. Blauer recommends the stock of the corporation, which owns the almost-200-year-old State Street Bank and Trust, the fourth-largest bank in Massachusetts.

title: If America Is Serious About AIDS; Then Washington Must Fight Discrimination
description: The Government's reponse to the AIDS epidemic still lacks a critical element: a law barring discrimination against those who carry the virus. Without such protection, people will fear being tested lest careless disclosure cost them jobs and housing. This plain truth has long eluded some in the Administration and Congress. Maybe they will bend to the force of the message now argued by retired Admiral James Watkins, chairman of the President's Commission on AIDS.

title: Black Hawks Look
description: HE has the security of another year on his contract, but whether Bob Murdoch will be coaching the Chicago Black Hawks next season remains to be seen. The club's general manager, Bob Pulford, has told him he might be replaced by Mike Keenan, who was dismissed as coach of the Philadelphia Flyers. ''We could be criticized for not talking to Keenan,'' Pulford said. ''A coach of his record deserves consideration.'' The general manager said that Murdoch had not been pleased when he was told of the interest in Keenan.

title: Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: I really don't feel the postseason hurt the N.H.L. because the game still remains the most exciting of sports - such fantastic skating! - and my No. 1.

title: 2 Newark Children Die in Fire Set by Mother
description: A distraught mother killed two of her children by setting fire to their bedroom this afternoon, fire officials said. The woman died after the fire spread to the rest of the house.

title: Landscapes, Old and New
description: LANDSCAPES old and new: The first group, by the graphic artist Joseph Pennell (1857-1926), is on the third floor of the Newark Public Library, 5 Washington Street; the second, by six contemporaries, is at the Jersey City Museum (junction of Jersey Avenue and Montgomery Street).

title: Powered by Sun, Young Racers Look to Future
description: The tiny solar-powered racing car had just completed a test lap around the track and the driver, James Worden, needed some help from his pit crew. ''Can somebody get me out of here?'' Mr. Worden pleaded from behind the Plexiglas bubble that covered the cockpit.

title: Fake African Art and The Passion for Authenticity
description: To the Editor:

title: Laurie Caldwell Weds a Student
description: Laurie Jean Caldwell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Caldwell of Westport, Conn., and Peter Bevier Brandow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd E. Brandow Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Westport by the Rev. Philip T. Morrissey. Anne Elizabeth Naleid was the maid of honor, and Dr. Ari J. Namon was the best man.

title: When Will Lendl Get Citizenship?
description: To the Sports Editor: rrAs an avid tennis fan I would like to present my views on the article about Ivan Lendl (''Step by Step, Lendl Moves Out of the Shadows,'' The Times, May 15). Lendl moved into the sunlight four years ago, by becoming the world's No. 1 tennis player, and was then preparing ''step by step'' for his much desired American citizenship. He certainly felt the sunshine again last year when he won a tennis tournament in Stratton, Vt., and Vice President Bush publicly congratulated him via television and promised to speed action to help him gain United States citizenship. Lendl donated his complete winnings of $35,000, to the local tennis club in celebration and gratitude of the Vice President's promise. Eight months have passed and Lendl is still awaiting citizenship.

title: POSTINGS: Merchants' Mansions; Savannah in Essex
description: Matthew Buurma built his dream home; then he built another. Now he is selling both. Mr. Buurma, a developer, is offering his dreams for more than a million dollars each in North Caldwell, N.J. At the top of a ridge slicing through Essex County, he has built two adaptions of Savannah, Ga., mansions and is working on plans for a third. He has 14 more lots of three-quarters of an acre to an acre for the project, called Fox Hollow, but work is slow: three months to plan each home, 13 months to build. ''We're not production people,'' Mr. Buurma said.

title:
GARDENING;
Rediscovering the Hearty Old Rose
description: LEAD: ROSE and marigold enthusiasts battled for years in Congress to determine which plant should be the national flower. Marigold supporters argued for the honor, saying the plant is native. Rose supporters argued that roses were universally loved. It was not too much of a surprise when the rose won.

title: Present Development In View of the Past
description: I hasten to write in response to the article ''Designating Landmarks: Beware Hidden Agendas,'' (Opinion Page, May 15) by my colleague Karolyn Wrightson, for fear that she has offered an inside-out view of most historical societies' concerns for historic preservation and landmarking projects.

title: Update On the Hemline Hoopla
description: Last June, the debate was how short is chic. This magazine, for example, ran the pages shown above with the reactions from a few stylish women. A year later, the question is still hemlines, but now it is how much longer should they be. Or is it perhaps easier to skirt the whole issue with pants? Most of the women shown in last spring's pages have now settled for a length that hovers just above the knee, one that HG's editor in chief, Anna Wintour, still terms ''very modern.'' ''I was very daring in January and February,'' says Blaine Trump. ''Now just above the knee is what I like to wear best.'' As well as pants and, occasionally, her pre-1987 midcalf-length full or pleated skirts. But whatever the personal preference, the last year's short-skirt fad has brought about a good and sensible fashion climate - one in which a woman can choose the length of her own hemline and still be stylishly correct.

title: France's Rolling Pizza Palors
description: MY fascination with pizza trucks began several years ago at Christmas time, when near our home in Provence I spotted a small gray Citroen van for sale at a local gas station. For reasons even I don't understand, I began to dream of owning that truck - a battered, 25-year-old vehicle that had been customized into a mobile pizza stand, complete with wood-burning oven - and making the tour of markets up and down the Rhone valley.

title: COLORADO'S THRIVING CULTS
description: The meaning of the word ''cult'' needs clarification. Sociologists of religion have long sought to identify the distinctive characteristics of such organizational entities as churches, sects, movements, cults, denominations.

title: Vote Nears on Tower Planned for Brooklyn Heights
description: Four years ago, in a move that aroused immediate community opposition, the Jehovah's Witnesses proposed building a 35-story tower of offices and apartments in Brooklyn Heights, where the religious sect has its headquarters.

title: FOCUS: Overbuilding Developers; Redirecting Energies
description: IT is a measure of the overbuilding that has taken place in this country that Tishman Speyer Properties, one of New York's leading developers, has only one office building in the United States planned for this year: the NBC Tower, rising on the shores of Lake Michigan in Chicago.

title: Outdoors; Memories of a Master Guide
description: ALTHOUGH some misguided souls try to make them so, hunting and fishing are not competitive sports and, harmless bantering by companions aside, are degraded by serious attempts at score-keeping. But there is joy in the admiration of the often subjective, hard-to-measure qualities of competence and skill in your betters, or in the slow growth of personal ability.

title: Malaysian Jailing of 4 Hurts Women's Cause
description: They are an unlikely gang of four: two social workers and two church workers committed to the struggle for women's rights and social change in Malaysia.

title: The Lesser-Known But Sporty Dr. I
description: THE name started 14 years ago as a sly joke: Dr. I. Hardly the stuff of legends, as, say, his more famous client, Dr. J - Julius Erving, the eminent basketball player.

title: CARRIERS AND THE NAVY
description: Charles R. Morris's article ''Our Muscle-Bound Navy'' (April 24) is one of the most inaccurate and misleading pieces I have read about the Navy and the aircraft carrier.

title: Fast Forward for a Film Festival
description: LEAD: IN the high-powered world of film festivals, the Suffolk County Film and Video Competition is not exactly up there with Cannes. Not yet, at least.

title: 11th Great Hudson River Revival Sails In
description: LEAD: IN advance of the crowds that will greet the 11th Great Hudson River Revival this month at Westchester Community College, 1,500 volunteers have been working since last fall on the two-day festival. Some have been volunteering each year since the revival began and others started even earlier, with the first picnic more than 20 years ago, when the folk singer, Pete

title: Buying Binge
description: To the Editor:

title: Royals Revamping
description: HE has had a lot on his mind, but nobody can say that John Schuerholz can't chew the fat and dream up deals at the same time. Schuerholz, the general manager of the Kansas City Royals, spent most of the last week or so dealing. On May 28 he released Steve Balboni, the first baseman, clearing room for Bill Buckner. Then he turned to Omaha, calling up Gary Thurman to replace the disabled Bo Jackson, and Jeff Montgomery, a relief pitcher, to replace Scotti Madison, a utility man, who was sent to Omaha. Schuerholz rounded out the week by sending Bud Black, a left-handed relief pitcher, to Cleveland for Pat Tabler, who is expected to spell Buckner as designated hitter. Then he ruminated, but did not rest. Asked if he had any more personnel plans afoot, Schuerholz allowed that he had, and added, ''We're thinking about them even as we speak.''

title: Andrew Schildhaus, Orthopedics Chief, 73
description: Dr. Andrew Schildhaus, director of orthopedic surgery at Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center since 1968, died May 29 at Mary Fletcher Hospital in Burlington, Vt., where he had been moved after suffering a heart attack and lapsing into a coma in Boca Raton, Fla., on May 14. He was 73 years old and had moved to Boca Raton last winter.

title: The Business of Preparing a Banquet
description: THE traditional American business practice of meeting and eating reaches a peak in late spring, when dozens of luncheons, dinners and banquets are held each day at hotels in the county. The banquet industry is a big one, with hotels vying for the chance to play host at everything from charity benefits for 1,200 people to small corporate dinners for a select gathering of executives.

title: WLIV Challenged on Funds
description: LEAD: MONEY - how to raise it and how to justify spending it - is a crucial problem for Channel 21, Long Island's public television station, as it conducts its regular on-the-air fund drive.

title: Blood Bank Is Cleared in Colorado AIDS Case
description: A jury has cleared a blood bank of liability in the case of a woman who contracted AIDS through a tainted transfusion in 1983, before a screening test for the AIDS virus was developed.

title: The Rabbit in John Thompson's Race to the Olympics
description: GENE SMITH was out in Oregon, running a sneaker outlet, pursuing a profit as zealously as he used to pursue a basketball for John Thompson's Georgetown Hoyas. One day the phone rang. ''Beast, are you in shape?'' asked a familiar, deep voice.

title: Miss Nichols Has Wedding
description: Brooke Gardner Nichols, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Charles Nichols of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stuart Graydon Rogers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Graydon Rogers of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Gregory M. Schmidt performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church.

title: A Season for Eastern Sissy Playwrights
description: In the Hollywood lexicon of David Mamet's play ''Speed-the-Plow,'' film producers are ''whores,'' but even movie-industry whores must feel superior to someone. To Mr. Mamet's moguls, that someone - the lowest form of life known to diners at Spago - is the writer who rejects the formulas of screenwriting. ''Eastern sissy writers'' are the enemy because they stubbornly refuse to write the ''stories people need to see,'' choosing instead to create more elusive works about ''the half-life of society'' and other such bosh. Eastern sissy writers are not bankable. They are not filmable. And they are not whores.

title: Francesca Amato Marries
description: Francesca Amato, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francesco Amato of Hoboken, N.J., was married there yesterday to Neil P. Fitzpatrick, a son of Mrs. Cornelius Fitzpatrick of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Mr. Fitzpatrick. Msgr. Walter J. Niebrzydowski performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church. The bride is the manager of the Newspaper Guild of New York-New York Times Pension Fund. Mr. Fitzpatrick is the controller of Family Circle magazine.

title: A Tale of Fraud and Greed in Wedtech Testimony
description: A chief prosecution witness in the Wedtech racketeering case last week told a startling tale of the fraud, deceit and extortion that enabled executives of the once-obscure South Bronx military contractor to line their pockets with millions of dollars.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The Un-Greening Of Town Common

title: BEST SELLERS: June 5, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary New York. 2 2 13 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 3 3 7 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 4 4 7 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 5 5 31 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 6 6 4 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York society and one man's role in it. 7 8 3 FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) A Detroit police detective investigates a series of crimes with its roots in the 1960's. 8 7 12 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 9 10 12 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 10 * 9 5 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars. 11 11 16 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 12 13 2 SCORPIUS, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $12.95.) James Bond on the tortuous trail of a global czar of vice and terrorism. 13 15 3 PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION, by Isaac Asimov. (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95.) An overture to the five-volume science fiction saga about the Foundation empire. 14 1 CRIMSON JOY, by Robert B. Parker. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The private eye Spenser in pursuit of a serial lady-killer in Boston. 15 12 6 THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH, by Michael Chabon. (Morrow, $16.95.) An eye-opening summer for a young man just graduated from college. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 2 FOR THE RECORD, by Donald T. Regan. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $21.95.) The experiences of President Reagan's former Treasury Secretary and chief of staff. 2 2 7 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 3 5 MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the celebrated performer. 4 4 25 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 5 5 7 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 6 8 6 SPEAKING OUT, by Larry Speakes with Robert Pack. (Scribners, $19.95.) The recollections of President Reagan's former spokesman. 7 7 18 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 8 6 6 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 9 10 30 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 10 9 56 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 11 * 19 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 12 1 FREUD, by Peter Gay. (Norton, $25.) A reanalysis of the life and legacy of the pioneering psychoanalyst. 13 11 8 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 14 12 13 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 15 * 15 9 THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The Greek philosopher's life and death, with an unfavorable assessment of his ideas. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 48 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 9 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 140 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 31 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 4 9 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) HERB 'N' LORNA: A Love Story, by Eric Kraft. (Crown, $17.95.) A happy, expansive comic novel that covers four generations of cheerful errors in a family that makes and sells erotic jewelry. OSCAR & LUCINDA, by Peter Carey. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) Mr. Carey's third novel, racy with character and teeming with invention, concerns a man and a woman, both gamblers, who meet on a ship bound for Australia and live very strangely ever after. THE NEW CONFESSIONS, by William Boyd. (Morrow, $19.95.) This ambitious novel, Mr. Boyd's fourth, seeks to remake Rousseau and apply Heisenberg's uncertainty principle in the life of a British movie director foiled by a series of mischances. LIFE ON EARTH, by Sheila Ballantyne. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Fascination - or obsession - with death and dying characterizes this collection of short stories, most of them told in the voice of a high-strung, nameless female narrator. FLANAGAN'S VERSION: A Spectator's Guide to Science on the Eve of the 21st Century, by Dennis Flanagan. (Knopf, $18.95.) Not an introduction for novices but an engrossing and anecdote-filled ramble along the byways of modern science; the author was editor of Scientific American for 37 years. CURFEW, by Jose Donoso. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $18.95.) The exile's return is the subject of this political novel in which love story, fairy tale, thriller and comedy of manners combine; the author himself returned to Chile from Europe in 1980. MASTER OF THE RETURN, by Tova Reich. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Everybody - Jews, Christians, Moslems, atheists - is a fanatic in this comic novel about the dangers of trying to hasten the coming of the Messiah.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Steve Bentley  The Southern Cal swimmer gave up his use of cocaine and is now a gold-medal contender.; Swimmer Leaves Drugs And Poor Image in Wake
description: Steve Bentley was barely 18 years old, a college freshman living away from home for the first time. He was just another face in the crowd, and he wanted to be noticed. So he tried something different. Cocaine. It did little for his image or his classroom education. It decimated his bankroll and, for a while, his swimming career.

title: A Scotish Inn, Sturdy and Grand
description: IT is 5 P.M. in Scotland. From the sky above the hills of Morven to Loch Linnhe below, the world seems to have turned to silver. Sheep grazing on the green lawn that slopes from road to water look as though they are painted into the scenery. The thicket of bracken that fringes the road is graceful, even feathery.

title: Lori Patricof Weds
description: Lori Sue Patricof and Dr. Joel E. Kopelman were married last evening at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens, by Rabbi Joseph Potasnik. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Patricof of Rockville Centre, L.I. Dr. Kopelman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Kopelman of Randolph, N.J., is an oculoplastic surgeon at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmiry. He also and practices in Livingston and Ridgewood, N.J.

title: The Uncertainties of California's Big Sur
description: LEAD: BIG SUR has a longstanding habit of evading conventional boundaries. Even today, 446 years after the Portuguese mariner Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo first surveyed the coastline, it is not quite clear where Big Sur begins and ends. One current guidebook refers to Big Sur as a 65-mile stretch of coast; two others set the length at 80 miles.

title: YOU CAN NEVER BE TOO RICH OR TOO IDLE
description: THE WINDSOR STYLE By Suzy Menkes. Illustrated. 224 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Salem House. $34.95.

title: Billing $15 Million In Less Than a Year
description: FOR Robert Jeffrey, 34, and Gary Goldsmith, 33, opening their own agency was a way to pursue their high, not to say stratospheric, ideals. That, in turn, meant they had to be financially independent. They planned for two years, and opened in June, 1987 with one $1 million account, Knoll Furniture, but with no backers or partners.

title: KNOW THYSELF, FREE THYSELF
description: In the spring of 1973, a Soviet citizen named Anatoly Sharansky applied to his Government for an exit visa. His action set off a chain of circumstances at once absurd, tragic and inspiring, a moral drama on the Russian scale. Insisting on what he saw as his fundamental rights, Mr. Sharansky found the entire state power of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics arrayed against him, as though he were a one-man refutation of the dialectic. In March 1977, following years of police harassment and public contumely, he was arrested and charged with high treason, espionage and ''anti-Soviet activity,'' crimes for which untold numbers of Soviet citizens had been executed in the past and which still carry the death penalty today. Impresioned, he was subjected to the threats and cajolery of jailers acting on instructions from the highest authority. Following his conviction, he endured the physical and mental humiliations of the ''Gulag Archipelago'' for nin years.

title: THE REGION: 10 Years of Casinos; Why the Boardwalk Is Rich and Atlantic City is Poor
description: TEN years after the first of a dozen casino hotels opened in Atlantic City, it is clear that they have failed to be the ''unique tool of urban redevelopment'' the New Jersey Legislature envisioned. The casinos have made fortunes and have transformed the Boardwalk into a glittering strip of towers; they provide thousands of jobs and pay hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes. But much of Atlantic City is still blighted, with dilapidated housing, boarded-up businesses and unkempt vacant lots where buildings were razed for development that hasn't occurred.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: NANCY A. BEAUBAIRE;
'Gardening Is a Universal Language'
description: LEAD: NANCY A. BEAUBAIRE has had a wide variety of work experience in the field of horticulture.

title: Jackson Plans to Campaign Beyond the Primaries
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to continue campaigning even after the final Democratic Presidential primaries Tuesday and right up to the party's national convention in Atlanta next month.

title: Bad Goods
description: To the Editor:

title: Elegant Hotel Dining, at a Price
description: A FASHIONABLE restaurant has opened in the new Royce Carlin, the fortresslike hotel that towers over Melville's Route 110. In the lobby, a spirited piano bar, attractive patio restaurant (Watercolors) and a cascading waterfall and pool behind a glass wall dazzle guests.

title: Fair Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: Frederick Barthelme's Spilled Bean
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock-Transfer Fee Would End Profiteers' Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Sportsmanship Relegated to Past
description: To the Sports Editor: rrI am an amateur, in the best sense of the word, about horse racing. But if I know little or nothing about the so-called sport of kings, I do know something about sportsmanship. I know that to beat an opponent by unfair means is not sporting. The frank, even boastful admission by Forty Niner's trainer that he had in fact instructed his jockey ''to bump Winning Colors continuously in order to prevent the filly from winning'' the Preakness was an eye-opener to me.

title: California: The great wind farms of the Tehachapi Pass
description: Los Angeles may be fantasy enough, but for a truly otherworldly experience take the 115-mile drive to the Tehachapi Pass wind farms. The mountainous pass, which serves as a funnel through which powerful winds whip into the Mojave Desert below, is covered with huge windmills that generate electric power for Southern California.

title: Dealers Time Chinese Art Shows To Opening at Met
description: The Chinese antiquities exhibited in the new Charlotte C. and John C. Weber Galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have attracted throngs of collectors, historians and dealers to New York over the last two weeks. They came to view what the museum had acquired in recent years, during a period of intense archeological activity that brought an abundance of ancient works to the market. They also came to attend dealer exhibitions and auctions that were planned to coincide with the opening of the Met's new galleries.

title: Anything Goes
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Also Warms to New Climate in the East
description: LIKE President Ronald Reagan but with different methods and objectives, Pope John Paul II is taking a new look at old Communist foes with the hope of winning some concessions. Already this year the Vatican has broken a 15-year impasse with Czechoslovakia over the Pope's right to name new bishops there. Negotiations with the Polish Government have reached the point that full diplomatic relations with the Vatican may be re-established for the first time since the Communist takeover after World War II. And 3 of the 25 new cardinals the Pope named last Sunday were appointed to bolster the church's position in their Communist countries - Lithuania, Hungary and China.

title: Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: There were a number of bad moments in this year's playoffs. Nevertheless, we already knew that the N.H.L. is a league where spearing, confronting officials after the conclusion of a game, and other unsportsmanlike acts are commonplace - and go unpunished. But one good thing did emerge from this ''tainted'' postseason: How 'bout Those Devils! MATTHEW HILTZIK Teaneck, N.J.

title: Summitry Shows Up Misperceptions
description: The Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting came out all right, serving the basic purpose of moving Soviet-American relations onto a more regular footing. Mr. Gorbachev made that point, saying he was eager to continue with an early get-acquainted summit meeting with the next U.S. President, that is, without important new agreements to sign.

title: Tauna K. Vanderweghe, TV Producer, Married to Robert Kennish Mullarkey
description: Tauna Kay Vanderweghe and Robert Kennish Mullarkey were married yesterday at the Fordham University Chapel in the Bronx. The Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, Fordham's president, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien.

title: Expressway Goes on the Air
description: LEAD: THE Atlantic City Expressway might well have become known as Farley's Folly - it was the brainchild of the late State Senator Frank S. (Hap) Farley - if gambling casinos had not come to Atlantic City 12 years after it was opened.

title: Many Questions Arise as the Celtics Fall
description: Some people call it mystique, tradition or Celtic pride, alluding to the friendly Kelly-green ghosts that inhabit the Boston Garden and the gremlins that upset the best-laid plans of opposing teams. Others are less romantic, attributing the perennial success of the Celtics to Arnold (Red) Auerbach, the shrewd patriarch, who puffs on ever-present victory cigars, blowing smoke on the rest of the National Basketball Association even as he outwits it.

title: Mixing Cultures On the Assembly Line
description: TWO distinctly different car models are rolling off the assembly line at a gleaming new automobile plant here, about 15 miles south of Detroit. One bears the block letter badge of Mazda, the other the oval emblem of Ford.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CELEBRATING POETRY If you've got it, why not flaunt it? Exactly. So since Long Island can claim Walt Whitman as a native son, and his birthplace in Huntington Station as a national historic site and shrine, it figures that poetry has to play some role in the cultural life of the Island. It does, and today's the day for a Summer Celebration of Poetry. Part poetry reading and part period fair - weather permitting, all outdoors - the festivities, marking the 169th anniversary of Whitman's birth and the 150th year of The Long Islander, the newspaper he founded, begin at 1 P.M. and include an appearance by June Jordan, who will read from her poetry and award prizes to young poets; a mini-parade; 19th-century music provided by Jason Bergman, fiddler, and demonstrations of 19th-century crafts. All this takes place on the grounds of the Whitman Birthplace on Old Walt Whitman Road and is free. JUNE JUBILEE

title: A Zaire Commuter: 6 Miles on Foot
description: The sun pounds down mercilessly on the dirt road as Mutombo Kinaoudi trudges past Kintambo Cemetery, where the tropical vegetation swirls around and shrouds most of the simple stone markers.

title: RUSSIAN ORTHODOX TO MEET VATICAN ABOUT UKRAINIANS
description: On the eve of the celebration of 1,000 years of Christianity here, the Russian Orthodox Church has agreed to hold discussions with the Vatican on the status of the Ukrainian Catholics, the Soviet Union's largest underground church.

title: The St. Tropez Of the Atlantic Gets a Bridge
description: MANY French social luminaries migrate for their summer vacations not to the Cote d'Azur but to the minuscule sun-drenched Ile de Re off the Atlantic coast. Re basks surprisingly in a near Mediterranean climate, explaining its label as the St. Tropez of the Bay of Biscay. This blue sliver in the sea lies opposite La Rochelle, itself one of the loveliest cities in France and a little-known treasure for travelers 300 miles southwest of Paris.

title: The Newest Super Automatic
description: THE pace of automation has been so rapid in photography, sometimes it seems that the sky is the limit. I've jokingly predicted that the next logical development will be a camera that decides on its own what pictures to take. If this hypothetical camera sees a terrific landscape or a photogenic face, it will fire its own shutter, without any help from you or me.

title: Laura M. Fox Is Wed To Thomas Macken Jr.
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Laura Margaret Fox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Fox of Solvang, Calif., was married yesterday to Thomas Edmund Macken Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Macken of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Leo Gorman performed the ceremony.

title: A Rational Plan For Needy Cities
description: STATE residents can set a calendar by the annual outcry that occurs shortly before the deadline for the adoption of municipal budgets.

title: Orioles Rally in 14th With 3 Runs on Error
description: On a nearly interminable night filled with silliness and indignity, the Yankees, who had their bats confiscated and a couple of beers dumped on them, managed to cap it in suitably unbecoming fashion. They blew a two-run lead in the bottom of the 14th to lose to the Orioles, 7-6.

title: Review/Dance; Wryness By Self And Moore
description: A number of strange and wonderful worlds collide, though very gently, in ''Crankhouse,'' presented on Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. The work of Jim Self, the dancer and choreographer, and Frank Moore, the painter, ''Crankhouse'' is one of those rare collaborations in which the individual contributions are inseparable. The two have worked together for eight years. ''Crankhouse,'' performed for a last time this afternoon, is one of their few New York presentations. It is good to have them back.

title: A Golf Match Of 23 Years
description: THEY say golf requires patience and endurance. John Fenton and the Quaboag Country Club in Monson, Mass., appear to have both.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending May 21 MANHATTAN Upper East Side $576,000 50 East 72d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. prewar condo; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining room, fireplace; common charge $687, taxes $5,220 (Broker: Edward Lee Cave) Upper East Side $6.25 million 960 Fifth Avenue (77th Street) 4-bedroom, 5-bath, prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevators, 3 maid's rooms, dining room, library, breakfast room, Central Park view; maintenance $6,000, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Beatrice Ehrlich/Key Ventures Inc.) Upper East Side $270,000 120 East 81st Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, terrace; maintenance $969; 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Wallack Management) Upper West Side $220,000 176 West 87th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, roof deck; maintenance $410, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Upper West Side $1.7 million 317 West 92d Street 5-bedroom, 5-bath, 5-story, 7,800-sq.-ft. brick town house; dining room, large kitchen, 2 maids' rooms, 2 fireplaces, garden, 30- by 56-ft. lot; taxes $12,800 (Broker: Alpha Equities) West Village $162,000 299 West 12th Street 525-sq.-ft. prewar studio condo; 24-hr. doorman, separate kitchen and dressing area, fireplace; common charge $171, includes gas and electricity; taxes $840 (Broker: Bartlett Associates) BRONX Riverdale $350,000 3058 Independence Avenue 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, single-family, attached brick house; dining area, fireplace, large kitchen, family room, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $200 (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) Van Ness $140,000 1990 Cruger Avenue 2-family, detached, frame house; 3 bedrooms, 2 baths in primary unit; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in other; dining room, large kitchen in each; full basement, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $751 (Broker: Tryax Realty) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights $255,000 105 Montague Street (Hotel Montague) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op; dining area, roof deck; maintenance $589, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Montague Realty) Carroll Gardens $690,000 334 DeGraw Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-story, single-family brownstone; dining room, formal parlor, library, 2 fireplaces, south garden, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,000 (Broker: Renaissance Properties) QUEENS Forest Hills $110,000 71-36 110th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area; remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $389, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) Forest Hills Gardens $800,000 60 Exeter Street 6-bedroom, 5-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen with breakfast nook, fireplace, solarium, attached 2-car garage, 83- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $4,200 (Broker: Terrace Realty) STATEN ISLAND Port Richmond $162,000 39 Cortlandt Street 2-family, frame, Cape Cod; 2 bedrooms in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; full basement, 47- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,165 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty) Todt Hill $1.15 million 83 Westminster Court 6-bedroom, 4-bath, single-family, brick colonial; dining room, large kitchen, music room, study, playroom, den, 1-car attached garage, 1/4-acre lot; 100% tax-abated (Broker: Otto Vitale Real Estate)

title: LP Turntables Spin Ahead
description: When the compact disk was launched five years ago, its more avid advocates prophesied that by 1988 conventional LP turntables would be found only at the Smithsonian Institution. They are now eating their words.

title: Blue Jays Roar Past Red Sox, 10-2
description: Jim Clancy threw a shutout for seven and two-thirds innings and Kelly Gruber highlighted a seven-run ninth by hitting a three-run homer today as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Red Sox, 10-2, for their fifth straight victory.

title: Touch of the Artist Customizes Rooms
