description: LEAD: INTERIOR painters go beyond the decorator and add the touch of the artist. By stenciling and freeform and faux painting walls, floors, tiles and furniture, these artisans can transform entire rooms.

title: A CORRECTION
description: A Posting on May 22 on a North Hills, L.I., town-house project misidentified its initial developers. They were Eliot and Gerald Monter.

title: Monumental Longevity?
description: To the Sports Editor: rrI used to think that one last straw and I, too (''The Winfield Fiasco is the Last Straw,'' by James F. Clarity, The New York Times, May 8), would be gone from Yankee Stadium until Steinbrenner's ''temporary custody'' is over. Unfortunately, Steinbrenner has had control for over 10 years and he won't go away. I think that Steinbrenner is looking to take his place as part of the Yankee tradition (if results fail, then longevity will elect him). Will his ego fit on the standard monument in left-center field or will he shorten the fences again to get the needed acreage? RICHARD MARKMAN Bronx

title: The Month of June Brings on the Roses
description: HOUSE plants can be summered outdoors: begonias, gardenias, orchids and tropical foliage plants need shade, while geraniums, jades, cactuses and succulents can be placed in full sun. Hanging plants such as Swedish ivy, tradescantia and fuchsias can be fastened under limbs of shade trees. Last call to plant seed of lima beans, sweet corn and cucumbers; plant another half row of carrots and beets; pull up spent spinach plants and reseed these rows with chard or beets. Move tropical waterlilies to the garden pool, after it has been cleaned. June Bloom

title: The Work of Cezanne Before He Became Cezanne
description: ''Cezanne: The Early Years, 1859 - 1872'' at the Royal Academy of Arts here will surprise many of those for whom the Museum of Modern Art's 1977 exhibition ''Cezanne: The Late Work'' was a formative experience. What we see now is not the immediate prelude to those last years, with their controlled vision and mastery of pictorial structure, but a wholly different artist: Cezanne before he became the Cezanne who had such an impact on the painting of the early 20th century. The current show on the early years covers the wayward, provocative art of Cezanne's 20's, ending in 1872 when he went to work with Camille Pissarro at Pontoise and submitted himself to the discipline that led to the triumphs of his later years.

title: Belmont Drums Up Horse Promotion
description: LEAD: IN May of 1905, Belmont Race Track opened its gates for the first time. Forty thousand fans came to see Race King and Sysonby finish in a dead heat for first place.

title: Review/Film; Lust and Murder in Triangular 'Drifter'
description: ''The Drifter'' was shot, its press material says, ''in 17 days on a budget too low to mention.'' Here is a press release with more honesty than tact, and it is not encouraging. But there are worse things than competent formula films, and, as it turns out, many worse films around than ''The Drifter.'' This is an unapologetic B-movie in the mold of Roger Corman, who was its executive producer.

title: Scaring the Clients - Then Calming Them Down
description: LOWE TUCKER METCALF opened its doors with more than mere enthusiasm. It came with Frank Lowe, chairman of Lowe Howard-Spink & Bell P.L.C., London, which, in turn, is associated with the Interpublic Group of Companies, a holding company of advertising agencies with worldwide billings of $5.6 billion. So William W. Tucker and David Metcalf suffered no embarassing credit questions when they signed their lease for 15,000 square feet of space in Heron Towers at 70 East 55th Street.

title: At Stony Brook, a World of Stage
description: LEAD: WHEN is avant-garde theater not really avant-garde? This year when it is or isn't staged as part of the International Theater Festival at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: Technology Fair for the Disabled
description: LEAD: RICHARD M. MANLEY said he is ''no longer overwhelmed by the computer,'' at least not when it comes to such basic tasks as checking messages and writing memos. He added that he expected all that to change on Saturday.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a demonstration by an Israeli peace group referred incorrectly to a site on the West Bank and to its Mayor. The site, Ariel, is a Jewish settlement; its Mayor, Ron Nachman, is Jewish.

title: Henry James's Sussex Haunt
description: RISING above the surrounding marshes that reach to the English Channel two miles off, Rye is a compact pyramid of steep winding cobblestone lanes lined with brick and timbered red-roofed houses, many dating from the 15th century and often resting on foundations far older. Straddling the sandstone hilltop itself, ''like a stranded ark,'' as the local poet Patric Dickinson sees it, is the Norman church begun in the 12th century and dedicated to St. Mary the Virgin.

title: Privacy: A Definition Is Evolving Case by Case
description: OUTRAGED by lurid newspaper accounts of the wedding of a prominent Senator's daughter, two young Boston lawyers boldly penned an article in 1890 calling for a ''right to be let alone.''

title: In the Shade of Maples and Memories
description: THE three pieces of equipment arrived early, before 8 o'clock. One of the drivers knocked at the front door and asked us to move our car. The phone rang. Mary, our next-door neighbor, wanted to know what was going on and whether her driveway would be blocked.

title: 'I COME TO PLAY. I COME TO BEAT YOU. I COME TO KILL YOU'
description: THE GIANTS OF THE POLO GROUNDS The Glorious Times of Baseball's New York Giants. By Noel Hynd. Illustrated. 396 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95. SAY HEY The Autobiography of Willie Mays. By Willie Mays with Lou Sahadi. Illustrated. 286 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Texas: From San Antonio through the hill country
description: Driving in Texas has never been merely a matter of getting from one place to another. Instead, the endless stretches of road have always been a central part of the state's mythology - the truest way to plug into the diversity of terrain and the grandiose sense of scale that helps define the state.

title: Pace University
description: Thomas Sobol, New York State's Commissioner of Education and the president of the University of the State of New York, warned that ''the gaps are widening between minorities and whites'' during the commencement speech yesterday at Pace University. ''By the year 2000, one out of three people will be minority,'' Mr. Sobol told the 1,400 graduates, receiving bachelor's, master's and doctoral degress at the exercises held in Madison Square Garden. ''Either we embrace diversity or become a nation divided.'' During the ceremony, Pace's Alumni Federation honored the city's First Deputy Police Commissioner, Richard Condon, as Alumni of the Year.

title: Albany Notes; Budget Slows A Bid to Add 17 Judgeships
description: A plan to create 17 new judgeships in New York State has been stalled by budget problems and the politics of judicial selection.

title: Revaluation
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Burch Weds C. J. Zimmerman
description: The marriage of Emily Hunter Burch to Christopher John Zimmerman took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Headley Burch, in Gainesville, Ga. The Rev. Don Hubbard, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mary Ann Stanton of New York and Waccabuc, N.Y., and the late Harry Edward Zimmerman.

title: STRUGGLING BACK
description: IN A STREAM OF MULTICOLORED jerseys traveling 45 kilometers an hour through thousands of cheering Italians, the bicycle race storms toward the day's finish line, up the main street of Cassino. Just ahead is the last kilometer, marked by a red pennant to warn the riders. The Piazza XIV Febbraio passes in a blur on the right, the Piazza Labriola on the left. Now is the moment for each team to begin leading out its sprinter, guiding him toward the front while he drafts on a teammate's rear wheel, saving up to 25 percent of his energy. But the riders are too bunched on the narrow Via de Nicola to allow room for the pilot fish to assist the sprinters. Despite the 202 kilometers they have traveled in six hours, almost all the 177 riders in the six-day Tirreno-Adriatico remain together and it becomes a gang finish, every man for himself.

title: Colleges Join Business in Push for Jobs
description: LEAD: WHEN Karen Gregory, vice president for public relations at the National Westminster Bancorp N.J., put out the bank's 1986 annual report, she earned six credits toward a degree in English literature at Jersey City State College.

title: How Congress Came to Love the Canada Free-Trade Bill
description: FOR months this winter, people in the know were saying that the difficulties the Reagan Administration had last year in negotiating a free-trade agreement with Canada were going to be dwarfed by the obstacles it faced in Congress this year.

title: Summers: A Legacy of Liberalism
description: MICHAEL J. BOSKIN, for Vice President Bush, and Lawrence H. Summers, for Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, have emerged as leading economists in the 1988 Presidential campaigns. If, as expected, Mr. Dukakis and Mr. Bush oppose each other this fall, one of these economists is likely to land a top job in the next Administration and to put his theories to work.

title:
SUMMER READING;
TRAVEL
description: LEAD: This season's crop of travel books shows the genre cruising along with greater sophistication and widening popularity. The disturbing trend in the field, however, is that a fair amount of self-indulgent prattle is published under the rubric of travel literature as well, penned by authors who subscribe to the notion ''I travel, therefore I write.

title: Next Week; How Far Can a Manager Go During Arguments?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: ANOTHER SOJOURNER
description: LIVING BY THE WORD Selected Writings 1973-1987. By Alice Walker. 196 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: MOVE BY KHOMEINI RAISES QUESTIONS
description: The appointment last week of Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the speaker of Iran's Parliament, as commander of Iran's armed forces may indicate that Iran's leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, is no longer able or willing to carry out the task, according to Administration officials and experts on Iran.

title: Unions Make Major Gains In '88 Politics
description: Organized labor, through a combination of planning and good luck, is emerging from the Presidential primaries in a surprisingly strong position to influence the Democratic Party and its probable nominee.

title: Duarte Takes Up a Final Campaign
description: Before he left this week to be treated in the United States for cancer, President Jose Napoleon Duarte began a final effort to unify his ruling party and calm extremists in the army and opposition groups.

title: Subway Token Clerk Dies After Booth Was Set Afire
description: A subway token clerk who was engulfed in flames after a frustrated robber poured flammable liquid into her bulletproof booth and ignited it Friday night died yesterday.

title: CHEKHOV, TOLSTOY OR PROUST, PROUST, PROUST: WHOSE INFLUENCE IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: On a pleasant late spring day five years ago, I decided that my summer reading project would be short stories from around the world, with the idea of eventually compiling an anthology that would collect some of the best of them. As I read through the stories of the hundred or so authors I was considering for inclusion in the book (later published as ''The Art of the Tale''), I began to share my solitude with the voices of many of the masters of the genre, both in the stories at hand and in the echoes they evoked. And so it occurred to me to ask the contributors to the anthology if they might corroborate the identity of those other voices - that is, to list a few of the writers who had in some crucial way influenced their own work. The replies of some of the respondents (listed at right) are published here for the first time, but in the form of a quiz. The actual match-ups, which appear on page 57, provide a few surprises. The Influencers

title: Turning Glass Into Art - And Profits, Too
description: TUCKED away in this rocky and forested part of southern Sweden lies an area that local guidebooks call the Kingdom of Glass, where scores of glassmakers turn out products that are world renowned for their delicate craftsmanship.

title: Rebuilt Pistons Display Solidity
description: The date was June 12, 1984; the place, the Boston Garden.

title: Lazy Lester's Ambling Blues
description: When the blues singer and harmonica player Lazy Lester (Leslie Johnson) sings, his words flow into one another. Even at faster tempos, Mr. Lester, who performed at the Lone Star Cafe on Thursday night, makes his melodies amble along as if they were enjoying a summer day.

title: Pre-K Programs Have Content and Value
description: William H. Sanders Jr. [ ''Are Schools Just a Line in the Welfare Budget?,'' Opinion Page, May 8 ] questions many of the programs taught in New York State public schools. He knocks many of the programs that are currently part of our educational system, without any apparent knowledge of either the purpose or content of the programs.

title: Miss Ware Wed To Philip Caputo
description: Leslie Blanchard Ware, a senior editor at Audubon magazine in New York, and Philip Joseph Caputo, a writer, were married yesterday at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Robert MacLennan performed the Presbyterian service.

title: A MOCK TRIAL OF KURT WALDHEIM PROVES ELECTRIFYING
description: The cries of ''trail by television'' have already been sounded. But they are not persuasive in the case of ''Waldheim: A Commission of Inquiry,'' which can be seen tonight from 8 to 11:30 on the pay-cable service Home Box Office. This is an extraordinary project in several respects, not least because it so carefully avoids even a hint of the sensationalism or exploitation that can be found in so many other television excursions into nonfiction. This is not a docudrama, that often murky form given sometimes questionable shape by writers, directors and actors. No actors are heard here. There is no script. And ''Waldheim: A Commission of Inquiry,'' a co-production of HBO and Britain's Thames Television, is not a trial. Kurt Waldheim, a former Secretary General of the United Nations (1972-82) and now the President of Austria, did not participate in the project. For nine days in April, some 30 survivors of World War II met in a London television studio to testify before an international panel of five jurists. The subject was the already widely publicized allegations of war crimes against Mr. Waldheim. The panel -which included jurists from Great Britain, the United States, West Germany, Sweden and Canada - was being asked to decide, solely on the statements and documents presented, if ''there is enough evidence to warrant an answer by Dr. Kurt Waldheim to allegations that he wrongly participated in acts which were contrary to the international laws of war.'' In short, should he be brought to trial?

title: Stanford Surprises Fresno St.
description: At the start of the College World Series and near the end of an inconsistent season, the defending champions from Stanford have discovered a comfortable position. They are removed from the stress of a difficult Northeast regional tournament. But at the start of the 42d Series, they are not nearly close enough to the title game to be thinking about becoming the first repeat champions in 14 years.

title: Yes, There Are Summer Risotto Dishes
description: I USUALLY think of risotto as a cold-weather dish. The hearty, stick-to-the ribs nature of a plate of rice cooked so the texture retains a hint of resistance to the bite and the grains are bound with a creaminess that is not quite a sauce is delicious sustenance. It is not light summertime fare.

title: ME AND ANDY WARHOL
description: ANDY WARHOL SURE had a lot of stuff,'' my sister Jo says, swiveling her head like a radar scanner.

title: Boning Up
description: To the Editor: Methinks that Ruth Wolff doth protest too much about closely researching a journey beforehand (''Innocence Abroad,'' Travel, May 1). Is she perhaps trying to persuade herself that the things she's missed weren't worth seeing after all?

title: Correction
description: An article on May 22 about racial and religious crimes incorrectly described Temple Anshe Shalom in New Rochelle. It is an Orthodox congregation.

title: Wenzel's Route
description: AFTER seven years as the head coach at Jacksonville University, Bob Wenzel felt a bit out of place in his year as an assistant coach of the Nets. He sat quietly on the bench, rarely raising his voice and offering only occasional advice to the three men who coached the team during the season. Since taking over as head coach at Rutgers in April, Wenzel has felt right at home again. ''This feels right,'' he said the other day, acknowledging that he had had ''some problems'' with his subsidiary role at the Nets. ''Now I feel comfortable.'' One reason for his happier demeanor is that he is taking the team on a 10-game, 12-day overseas tour, which, under collegiate rules, allows him to hold an extra 10 days of practice.

title: Mean-Spirited Fun
description: THROW MOMMA FROM THE TRAIN Starring Danny DeVito, Billy Crystal, Anne Ramsey (in photo), Kim Greist, Kate Mulgrew, Branford Marsalis, Rob Reiner. Directed by Danny DeVito. 1987. Orion Home Video. 88 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG-13. Some rude language.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
New Surgery Center
description: LEAD: A new Ambulatory Surgery Center at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center will be formally dedicated at noon today and will be ''open for business'' Tuesday.

title: Pied Piper of Dance Inspires a Brat Pack
description: LEAD: FOR a select group of eight young dancers from Jersey City, the journey to Madison Square Garden is more than a PATH ride from Journal Square to 34th Street. Their route goes by way of Lincoln Center, where they dance their legs off every Saturday morning.

title: Reviews/Music; Exotic Influences in High-Tech Concert
description: Not so long ago, a concert-worthy synthesizer was a wall of erratic electronic modules tied to keyboards of limited capability. Today, electronic keyboards are immensely ''smarter,'' and with one or two of them linked to a computer and a couple of sequencers or other relatively compact devices, a composer interested in performing live electronic works has a great deal of power and variety at his fingertips.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The house I am buying has kitchen cabinets covered with a pecan veneer, and I would like to paint them white. Is there a special treatment or special paint for these cabinets?

title: THE NATION: Crafts Are 'Pivotal'; For the Skilled, It's a Seller's Market
description: AT a time when a shortage of low-paid service workers in fast-food restaurants and department stores has received widespread attention, economists and executives contend that there is a far more serious labor problem in the United States: the scarcity of skilled craftsmen.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Santa Barbara, Calif.;
Demand High For 207 Units
description: LEAD: OCCUPANCY will begin this month in the new condominiums of a large residential development called Rancho Arroyo, after 10 years of effort to get the project off the ground.

title: Truckers Upset by Plan on Exhausts
description: ATLHOUGH the state requires car emissions to be tested every year, trucks and buses have been exempt.

title: PHILIPPINE ARMY SEIZES THE MOMENT IN REBEL WAR
description: The Philippine colonel, relaxed in a red T-shirt, sat back in his chair and patted a stack of computer printouts, the trophies of a recent raid on an insurgent hideout in the heart of Manila.

title: LOOKING AT THE NEW YORK STATE OF BOXING
description: BOXING is the sport of the poor. It belongs on no one's priority list. One must look far and beyond to find a reasonable place for it in our society. Men and women in high places view it as an archaic activity dominated by asinine men of the wrong color and ethnic background who speak a foreign language and live within a subculture of our human family. In effect, the world of pugilism is acceptable only as a throwback to our basic animal instinct; a place, they think, where rational brain function is barely present.

title: Q and A
description: Bank Failure

title: Rediscovering Insley Landscapes
description: ALBERT INSLEY, whose paintings and drawings are on view at Nardin Fine Arts here, is another in a series of ''rediscoveries'' this season in Westchester. Insley (1842-1937), however, is not a brand new old painter.

title: Yale Law Students From Poor Backgrounds Unite
description: Eric Klopfer did not carry on the family tradition of becoming an auto mechanic. Instead, the first high-school graduate in his family earned a bachelor's degree from the University of Pittsburgh and a doctorate from Oxford University.

title: College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: How Great Towers Of the City's Past Proved to Be Passing Shadows On the Skyline
description: Will they ever decide to pull down the Empire State Building? Will there ever be a generation of New Yorkers that has never set eyes on the Metropolitan Museum or the Brooklyn Bridge? One day the Rockies will crumble - but not, surely, Rockefeller Center?

title: NATIONAL GRIDLOCK
description: What's needed, clearly, are dramatic incentives to move people out of cars and onto mass transit. In Paris, for example, commuters can buy weekly or monthly passes at a discount, and they can transfer between buses and the metro for free. Until this kind of innovation is brought to New York, I'm not sure the gridlock crisis can ever be untangled. MYRA ALPERSON New York, N.Y.

title: Kissing and Telling About Kiss-and-Tell
description: Because I once wrote a White House memoir of the Nixon era, and because I often issue diatribes or hosannas about books written by more recent White House aides, I am often asked: ''Where do you stand on >kiss and tell?''

title: '8-Week Wonders' Should Not Be Teachers
description: Over the last few years, Connecticut has spent tens of millions of dollars to increase teachers' salaries and to improve the quality of education. Teachers have been required to have additional professional training to help them continue to improve in their profession.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's the kind of day when anything you bought went up. Just don't overstay your welcome.'' - Norman J. Shapiro, manager of equity trading at New Japan Securities on the market's 74.68 gain.

title: Hawaii's Expressive Handmade Quilts
description: WHEN the missionary women of New England introduced quilt stitchery to the Sandwich Islands, an avenue was opened for Hawaiian creativity to turn the craft into a celebration of heart, head and hand. Durable, expressive Hawaiian quilts are a Pacific contribution to a traditional American art form, and in island homes they are as treasured as the family silver.

title: Lots of Water, Lots of Growth
description: Dan Dramer's piece, ''Tainted Water Supply: A Way Out'' [ Opinion Page, May 15 ] , concerning Sanibel Is land's reverse osmosis plant, leaves out an important factor: Once an island has an unlimited water supply, growth can also be unlimited.

title: Fresh Air Fund Operates Youth Camp
description: The first lesson James E. Elliott, a 15-year-old streetwise son of East Harlem, learned when he arrived at Camp Pioneer was that his night vision improved when he turned his flashlight off. Once his eyes adjusted to the darkness, he could see much more than a tiny light could illuminate.

title: Sidewalk Litter Law: A Psychic Toll
description: Standing in front of the neatly arranged hyacinth and cyclamen in his storefront display, George Karounos fumed at a New York City Sanitation Department enforcement agent. Nearby, paper cups and newspapers dotted the Greenwich Village sidewalk.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the causes of an N.J. Transit train crash incorrectly reported the results of drug and alcohol tests on the three crew members of one of the trains. Although operating errors by the three were blamed for the May 5 crash, the tests found no evidence of drugs or alcohol in the crew members from either train.

title: Reds Top Dodgers On O'Neill's Homer
description: Paul O'Neill hit a three-run homer with two out in the top of the ninth to break a 2-2 tie and give the Cincinnati Reds a 5-2 victory over the Dodgers today.

title: Producing Musicals On a Small Scale
description: DASHA EPSTEIN of Bedford Hills has had a number of big Broadway hits, all of them small scale. ''It doesn't have to be big to be good,'' said the co-producer of the mini-musical hit ''Ain't Misbehavin,' '' Hal Holbrook's famed one-man show, ''Mark Twain Tonight,'' the immensely successful two-character comedy ''Same Time, Next Year'' and the prize-winning three-character drama '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the boys,'' among others.

title: THE YEAR OF THE ASTERISK
description: SEASON OF GLORY The Amazing Saga of the 1961 New York Yankees. By Ralph Houk and Robert W. Creamer. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Industry, Government and Labor Try To Plan for Workers' Obsolescence
description: CASTER DAVIDSON, a 40-year-old former autoworker, is becoming adept at installing roof shingles, plumbing and other building maintenance tasks she has been learning in a storefront classroom in recent weeks. She hopes to be doing the same thing on real houses as summer starts.

title: 4 Bridge Teams Vie for Venice
description: Four top-ranked contract bridge teams clashed here today in final playoffs to determine which will represent the United States in the 1988 world championships in Venice in October.

title: A Teen Prodigy Cuts Deals on Tenements
description: ABE BETESH was wheeling from lane to lane headed uptown in his brand-new red sports car, talking real estate.

title:
ART;
Atheneum Program Spotlights a Home-Grown Artist
description: LEAD: MATRIX, the space at the Wadsworth Atheneum that brings the freshest and most controversial contemporary art to Hartford, has reached the plateau of its 100th exhibition. And for that milestone, the gallery's spotlight falls on a home-grown artist.

title: At This Festival, the Jugglers Are Behind the Scenes
description: One day last April, Tony Rudel, the bright and loquacious music impresario of the First New York International Festival of the Arts - which opens Saturday - suddenly found himself speechless. He had just received a letter from Leonard Bernstein's manager declaring that the maestro had decided that his contribution to the festival would be to lead the Chicago Symphony in three short works by Richard Strauss.

title: Davey Moore, 28, Is Dead in Accident; Held Boxing Title
description: Davey Moore, a former World Boxing Association junior-middleweight champion, was killed Friday when an unoccupied vehicle rolled down his driveway and ran over him as he tried to stop it, his trainer and the police said today. He was 28 years old.

title: Soldering: It's Not So Hard
description: SOLDERING is a method of using heat to join pieces of metal, especially sheet metal, plumbing and electrical wiring. Unlike welding, in which pieces being joined are heated until they melt and flow together, in soldering, additional metal - solder - is melted so it flows between the pieces and cements them.

title: Did the Postseason Hurt the N.H.L.?
description: If you take the position that good or bad publicity is better than no publicity at all, then doughnuts and blackouts kept the N.H.L. atop the sports headlines. However, if, like the author, you are a true fan of hockey, you'd realize that what transpired did nothing to enhance the sport.

title: In Lebanon, a New Chance for the Old War; The Leaders
description: Political and military leaders in Lebanon who are expected to have influence in choosing the country's next president: President Amin Gemayel . . . 46 . . . Maronite Christian . . . six-year term expires Sept. 23 . . . expected to take over leadership of the Christian Phalange Party founded by his father. Samir Geagea . . . 38 . . . Maronite Christian physician . . . commander of Christian Lebanese Forces militia, which can muster 20,000 fighters in East Beirut and other Christian areas. Elie Hobeika . . . 38 . . . Maronite Christian . . . heads a 600-man splinter faction of the Lebanese Forces in Syrian-controlled Bekaa region . . . foe of Dr. Geagea, who ousted him from main militia two years ago. Walid Jumblatt . . . 41. . . Druse leader, also heads Progressive Socialist Party and its militia of about 10,000, controlling the Shuf mountains southeast of Beirut. Nabih Berri . . . 48 . . . Moslem Shiite lawyer . . . leader of Amal, mainstream Shiite movement . . . Minister of Justice in present Government . . . announced Friday that militia, with 10,000 fighters, will operate only in southern Lebanon, abandoning the Beirut area, where it had fought with the other Shiite group, the Party of God. Mustafa Saad . . . 37 . . . Sunni Moslem . . . Soviet-educated agricultural engineer . . . leads People's Liberation Army of 2,000 in southern city of Sidon . . . blinded in 1985 when car bomb exploded outside his home. Ibrahim Koleilat . . . 41 . . . Sunni Moslem . . . leader of Al Murabitoun militia, once important Sunni force, which was virtually eliminated by other militias . . . lives in Libya. Hussein Musawi, Ibrahim Al Amin and Hussein Khalil . . . Shiite clerics heading Party of God with militia of 6,000 . . . direct links to Iran . . . have won important battles against Amal in recent fighting near Beirut.

title: COLORADO'S THRIVING CULTS
description: Fergus Bordewich was able to find critics aplenty to mouth the growing attack on the New Age movement but seemed reluctant to quote as generously from articulate proponents. The critics use scare terms such as ''Satanism, totalitarianism and irrationalism,'' and warn that an emphasis on the inner life will mean serious glitches in technological civilization. Wittingly or not, the tone of the article is chillingly like the right-wing propaganda attack on fundamentalist television most weekdays against the New Age movement.

title: Dating Again: The Good, Bad and Boring
description: MY king and I had five rambunctious children with robust appetites, two ''attack'' German shepherds named Brutus and Caesar, four promiscuous cats and a toilet that flushed around the clock.

title: The Past Is the Present Passion
description: FEW towns in Connecticut have such a preoccupation with the past as Lebanon, the hotbed of rebel activity in the state during the Revolutionary War.

title: Of John Kennedy And Suit Buttons
description: THE news item said a legislative commission assigned to choose a statue of John F. Kennedy for installation outside the Statehouse in Boston had run into a problem: Should the top button of the suit jacket worn by the 35th President be buttoned?

title: Correction
description: A map on May 15 with an article about Deer Isle, Me., omitted a geographic detail; there is a causeway connecting the isle with the village of Sunshine.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: Wyoming-Montana: Climbing 10,000 feet on the way to Yellowstone
description: As with most memorable travel discoveries, it was an accident of the kind that seems to happen all too rarely in these days of computerized family automobile trips planned to the last E-Z Off-On.

title: Late Starter Is the Earliest Finisher
description: Ingrid Kristiansen was training in her native Norway when she started thinking about the L'eggs Mini Marathon in New York.

title: Lauren Stewart Moores, Economist, Marries Blake Auchincloss, Architect
description: Lauren Stewart Moores, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Duer Moores Jr. of Convent Station, N.J., and Blake Leay Auchincloss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Auchincloss of New York and Claryville, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Robert Fitzpatrick performed the ceremony.

title: ART
description: Right now, we have major exhibition catalogues that in scope, thoroughness and quality of reproduction outrank all their predecessors. Should they also outrank the art books to which no great exhibition is attached? Yes, we might say, when we look at some current examples. ''Fragonard'' (not long ago at the Met), ''Gauguin'' (now at the National Gallery of Art in Washington), ''Degas'' (now at the new National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa and due at the Met in the fall), ''The Berggruen Klee Collection'' (now at the Met) and ''The Pulitzer Collection'' (now at the Fogg Art Gallery in Cambridge, Mass.) all came with catalogues that are at least the equal of, and sometimes far superior to, any trade book. New facts, new insights, new documentary material - all combine to overwhelm the opposition.

title: Frederick Barthelme's Spilled Bean
description: To the Editor:

title: Bergman Brings A Restive Hamlet To Brooklyn
description: Ingmar Bergman may have bowed out of cinema with his semi-autobiographical film ''Fanny and Alexander,'' but he is by no means out of the picture. The legendary Swedish film director makes his New York theater debut with his eccentric version of Shakespeare's ''Hamlet,'' Wednesday for a limited run through June 16 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Miss Cobun Wed To Gerard Fallon
description: Lynette Cobun, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Cobun Jr. of New Paltz, N.Y., was married at the Reformed Church there yesterday to Gerard Fallon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Fallon of Boston. The Rev. Howard Major 3d performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. William Shannon, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: U.S. Economy Seems to Gain Strength From Its Weakness
description: Since the stock market crash, many Americans have been fearful that an economic slowdown might soon follow.

title: AIDS Virus Found to Hide in Cells, Eluding Detection by Normal Tests
description: Scientists have discovered what they believe are unusual cases in which the AIDS virus remained hidden in one type of body cell, undetectable by commonly used screening methods.

title: Cathryn Jakobsen Wed to Composer
description: Cathryn Jakobson, a daughter of Mrs. Alan R. Denzer of Greenwich, Conn., and Peter Jakobson of New York and Elberon, N.J., was married last evening to Ronald Ramin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Ramin of New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Egyptian Tourism
description: To the Editor: My wife and I just returned from a T.W.A. tour of Egypt. The trip was truly memorable, due especially to our wonderful guide Aki, who made everything about ancient Egypt come alive, exceptionally good weather and, of course, such unforgettable sights as the temple of Ramses II at Abu Simbul, the temple of Karnak and the tombs at Luxor, the great Egyptian Museum in Cairo and the pyramids at Giza. These are surely among the greatest treasures of mankind and a fitting testimonial to the greatest artistic ancient civilization of all.

title: A Broad Piece of Legislation Addresses Worries About Health
description: THE first worker safety law concentrating on video display terminals is scheduled for signing this week in Suffolk County, on eastern Long Island. The law would affect thousands of workers in an estimated 300 to 400 businesses there. Because its supporters view the bill as a model for similar laws in other municipal, county and state governments, it might eventually affect 900,000 workers who use terminals in New York State, and an estimated 12 million nationwide. The Suffolk legislation has, in fact, become a focal point for the safety controversy involving video terminals.

title: An Addition That Leaves Well Enough Alone
description: No skyscraper, no football stadium, no shopping mall could possibly say as much about how our culture's attitudes toward architecture have evolved as the diminutive addition that has been proposed for the Jewish Museum on Fifth Avenue. The extraordinary thing about this addition is that when it is finished, no one is supposed to know that anything happened at all. or what the architect Kevin Roche has planned is not a modern building or one that in any way at all signals that it was built at the end of the 20th century. He has suggested, instead, that the museum simply extend northward the Warburg mansion, the French Gothic chateau that is its main building, literally copying C. P. H. Gilbert's design of 1908. This would stretch it as if Gilbert himself had been handed a larger building plot 80 years ago, turning the mansion into an expanded version of what it has always been.

title: Labor Woes Mar the View
description: VISITORS to state parks this summer will find dirtier picnic areas, unmown grass and some restricted swimming areas because of a shortage of workers that has steadily worsened over the past few years.

title: TIME HAS BEEN KIND TO THE NYMPHET: 'LOLITA' 30 YEARS LATER
description: ''Lolita is famous, not I,'' Nabokov said to one of the many interviewers who came to interrogate him after the succes de scandale of ''Lolita.'' And like so many Nabokovian utterances, it was both true and the mirror image of true. Lolita's fame made her creator both a ''brand-name'' author - to use that distressing contemporary locution -and an adjective.

title: State Dept. Sees Mixed Soviet Rights Record
description: The Soviet Union improved its human rights performance in the last six months, but its record remains seriously flawed, a State Department report to Congress says.

title: Pilots' Fatigue Termed Threat To Safe Flying
description: Fatigued by grueling schedules that have disrupted their biological clocks, airline pilots are frequently falling asleep in the cockpit in flight, particularly on long ocean crossings, according to pilots and aerospace scientists familiar with the problem.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Pomp and Other Circumstance
description: LEAD: GRADUATION weekend: the pomp, the ritual, the poignance of seeing your child clad in academic robe and mortarboard, shifting her tassel from right to left (a procedure costing about $40,000 a shift) - in a ceremony that is almost as long as her college career.

title: Review/Ballet; NEW MALE LEAD IN 'GAITE'
description: The new costumes Christian Lacroix designed for American Ballet Theater's revival of ''Gaite Parisienne'' continue to make balletgoers argue about whether they are colorful or merely garish. Yet Leonide Massine's comic ballet remains as bright as ever, and on Friday night it was great fun.

title: Why Subsidize Expensive Private Drug Care?
description: LEAD: Adm. James P. Watkins, the chairman of President Reagan's AIDS commission, estimates that ''treatment on demand'' for every intravenous-drug addict would cost the Government $15 billion over the next 10 years. Too much for our deficit-ridden Government to pay, even for an issue that voters feel strongly about?

title: Berkeley Journal; Who'll Sell Tofu Puffs After Co-ops Are Gone?
description: For 51 years, it was as if a loving relative was telling them to eat a good breakfast instead of that sugar-coated cereal, did not let them have hot dogs full of nitrites and made sure their grapes and lettuce were picked by the United Farm Workers' union.

title: Reviews/Dance; THE WHIMSY OF ACROBATICS ON POINT
description: Matthew Nash loves to send choreographic thoughts on whimsical flights of fancy. Many bright ideas flashed by Saturday night when his company, Matthew Nash Music and Dance, performed at the CSC Theater. But these ideas only occasionally cohered into satisfying wholes.

title: S. E. Coleman, Lawyer, Wed to Laura Berkman
description: At Rodef Shalom Temple in Pittsburgh, Laura Galman Berkman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Berkman of Pittsburgh, and Steven Earl Coleman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coleman of Canton, Mass., were married yesterday by Rabbi Walter Jacob.

title: Samuel L. Duboc And Marina Kalb Marry in Capital
description: The marriage of Margot Marina Kalb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kalb of Rockville, Md., to Samuel Livingston Duboc, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Duboc of Fox Chapel, Pa., took place yesterday at the Madison Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Andrew Baker performed the ceremony.

title: Despite Support, a Child Care Bill Fails to Emerge
description: The notion that the Federal Government should help working parents take care of their children has been embraced this year by politicians of every stripe. But the consensus needed to translate those campaign pronouncements into legislation has yet to emerge.

title: ROUT FOR AMERICANS
description: Two minutes into his bout today against the American fighter Ray Mercer, Zelko Mavroic, an amateur heavyweight from Yugoslavia, took a hard right-hand blow on his nose.

title: Ad Agencies' Obsession With Winning Awards
description: The One Show, the pinnacle of advertising awards ceremonies, takes place this Thursday night, with writers and art directors from more than 600 agencies vying for 45 ''Gold Pencils.'' Just as an Oscar can resurrect a struggling studio and bring fabulous fees to a star, a Gold Pencil can bring new clients to an ad agency and inflated salaries to the honored individual.

title: AN EXULTANT ZUBIN MEHTA OFFERS MAHLER IN MOSCOW
description: The final, tender strains of Mahler's Ninth Symphony faded, and Zubin Mehta, director of the New York Philharmonic, dropped his arms and turned to face the roaring applause of the audience at Tchaikovsky Hall.

title: Rising Aluminum Prices Spur Oversupply Fears
description: Economists and industry analysts have expressed concern that surging aluminum prices will encourage producing countries to increase their capacity further, which could lead to an oversupply in the future.

title: Dr. Ruth Gershen Is Wed to a Rabbi
description: Dr. Ruth Susan Gershen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin E. Gershen of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Rabbi Hillel David Gold, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Raphael Gold of Savannah, Ga. Rabbi Allan Blaine, an uncle of the bride, and the bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of Princeton.

title: Losses at Detroit Papers
description: Knight Ridder Inc.'s Detroit Free Press and the Gannett Company's Detroit News, which have applied to the Justice Department to operate jointly, have told their unions that they have lost $30 million in the last year. The newspapers, which are among the nation's 10 largest, told the unions that the losses are running more than $2.5 million a month. Robert Hall, Detroit Free Press executive vice president, said The Free Press losses accounted for about $18 million of the annual total of $30 million.

title: Israel Upholds Expulsion of Palestinian-American
description: The Israeli Supreme Court today upheld the Government's decision to expel Mubarak E. Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence.

title: Review/Theater; PUERTO RICAN TROUPE IN 'FIRST CLASS'
description: In Candido Tirado's ''First Class'' at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, two young men are forced to discover the truth about themselves. While their discovery sets one of them free, whether the truth is sufficient armor to get them through a deadly battle at the end we never find out.

title: Olmsted, Parks Guru, Had Eye for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Wichita State Rolls On
description: Wichita State remained undefeated here despite making four errors tonight, and Florida overcame an early five-run deficit to avoid being eliminated from the 42d College World Series.

title: Billy On the Bench
description: MAXIMUM RICHIE PHILLIPS, the self-appointed judge and jury in baseball and umpire relations, decided the other day that he was going to take care of Billy Martin all by himself.

title: Let a Third Party Decide About the Building That Was Too Tall; The Madras Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN ARTIST GETS MIXED REACTION IN BEIJING
description: Frederick J. Brown, a 43-year-old painter from SoHo in New York City, brought his bold, loudly colored canvases to Beijing this week, to the mystification and the delight of museumgoers.

title: BUSH RECALLS THE PLAY
description: For all that has happened to him over the last four decades, George Bush still vividly remembers The triple play that may have cost the Yale baseball team the national championship in 1948.

title: The Chance for Peace in Managua
description: When the Sandinistas and contras resume talks tomorrow, they may have the makings of a fair and viable bargain to end their seven-year war. A blend of circumstances helps widen the opening:

title: Price of Zinc Hits Record
description: Zinc prices raced to record dollar highs in London on Friday, with producers and consumers competing in the open market for scarce supplies as a possible strike loomed in the Yukon Territory in Canada.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Saudi Arabia posted a $2.56 billion trade surplus last year, up from a $360,000 surplus in 1986, the Finance Ministry said. The Saudis have mounted a major effort to diversify their oil-dependent economy, developing agricultural products for export as well as for domestic consumption. Exports totaled $22.56 billion last year, up from $19.24 billion in 1986, the ministry said. Imports were $20 billion, compared with $19.24 billion. The countries accounting for the largest share of imports were Japan, the United States, Britain, West Germany and Italy.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL SESSION OF GENERAL ASSEMBLY ON DISARMAMENT (COMMITTEE OF WHOLE) - 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council UNITED NATIONS CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M.

title: Stop U.N.-Bashing
description: The annual Administration report to Congress on voting practices at the United Nations has become a weapon in the hands of United Nations opponents. They use it to stir up anti-United Nations feeling in this country and to justify cuts in American contributions. Their efforts do not improve that organization, but they do diminish American influence.

title: Dr. Lipka Is the Bride Of Dr. Mark H. Weiner
description: Dr. Suzanne Beth Lipka, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Lipka of New York, and Dr. Mark H. Weiner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Weiner of Plantation, Fla., were married yesterday at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski officiated.

title: INSIDE
description: Nuns Gain on Dissent A religious order refused to dismiss two American members who publicly supported the right of Roman Catholics to oppose the church's ban on abortion. Page A14. A-Plant Draws Opposition Opponents of nuclear power believe they have a good chance to close the Rancho Seco plant near Sacramento, Calif. Page D1. Early Tuesday, Long Island Lighting

title: Hearing Begins Into Death of Naval Recruit
description: A Navy rescue instructor yelled, ''Get him!'' before a panic-stricken recruit was forced back into the swimming pool where he died, a classmate testified Saturday.

title: Bass Group Lifts Bid for Macmillan
description: In a surprise move, the Robert M. Bass Group has raised its bid for Macmillan Inc., in what is thought to be its most vigorous attempt at an unfriendly takeover.

title: Bush Steps Back on Offshore Oil
description: Vice President Bush shifted his position today on one of the state's most heated issues and declared that the Administration's proposal to permit offshore drilling in northern California should be deferred indefinitely.

title: Early-Bird Trading Plan
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange is considering ringing the opening bell for its foreign currency options trading at 3 A.M. to capture European business.

title: Red Sox, Umpires Ahead for Martin
description: The Yankees will play the Boston Red Sox for the first time tonight, and the game at Yankee Stadium will also be the first test of the umpires' declared intention to eject Billy Martin at the first and every opporunity.

title: Superiors Refuse to Dismiss Nuns in Abortion Ad Case
description: In an apparent victory for advocates of dissent within the Roman Catholic Church, an international order of nuns announced today that it had decided not to dismiss two American nuns who signed a newspaper advertisement supporting the right of Catholics to oppose the church's ban on abortion.

title: New York to Enforce New Law on Smoking
description: After a two-month grace period, New York City's anti-smoking law turns tough today when city health inspectors may begin issuing court citations to violators, rather than polite warnings.

title: Not All Trial Lawyers Oppose Tort Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: National League; Phils' Palmer Ends Cardinals' Streak
description: David Palmer allowed six hits in seven and two-thirds innings, hit a homer and a double and scored two runs as the Philadelphia Phillies beat St. Louis, 6-3, today, ending the Cardinals' five-game winning streak.

title: Reviews/Music; NEVADA CHAMBER GROUP
description: Beth Mehocic, composer in residence at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, formed the Las Vegas Music and Dance Ensemble mainly as a vehicle for her own chamber works. The group - Carol Urban, pianist; Walter Blanton, trumpeter; Richard Soule, flutist; and Debra Greschner, soprano, with the choreographer Carol Rae and the dancers Deborah Stone and Cathy Allen - performed five works by Ms. Mehocic and one by Mr. Blanton at its New York debut on Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall.

title: A Helping Hand
description: When their playing days are over, retirement is not always rosy for former major leaguers, especially those who ended their careers before the era of big contracts and comfortable pensions.

title: The Teams Played On
description: Mike Ferraro returned to his hotel, turned on the shower, filled the tub, and climbed in. He didn't move for the rest of the night. When Frank Robinson got home, he turned on the television, turned down the sound and tumbled onto his bed. He remembers looking at the clock at 3:30, although he is not exactly sure when he fell asleep.

title: Deal for 50% of Cinco Dias
description: The French business publisher Groupe Expansion S.A. is to team up with Dow Jones & Company and two French banks to acquire 50 percent of a concern that publishes the leading Spanish financial daily Cinco Dias.

title: For Fed-Up Speedsters, a Parking Lot Le Mans
description: Helen Wepman learned to drive when she was 10 years old in Brooklyn, and has always loved high speeds. But like other off-track speed merchants, Mrs. Wepman has been frustrated by city streets congealed with traffic and patrolled by fussy police officers.

title: A Prescription for Birth Defects
description: The Food and Drug Administration errs seriously in the way it is regulating Accutane, an acne cure that is also a highly potent cause of birth defects. The agency continues to focus on patients' behavior, not that of dermatologists who are overprescribing the drug. The result is avoidable cases of abortion and malformed children.

title: SAVINGS INSURANCE OF OVER $1 BILLION TO BE PAID BY U.S.
description: The Federal Government will pay more than $1 billion in insurance to depositors of one or more savings institutions that it will liquidate shortly, the head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday.

title: Guardians of Order on New York's Party Line
description: The intelligence from the New York Party Connection is that Carlton the Doorman, as he is called, has proposed marriage to a woman known as Leslie. Carlton popped the question over the telephone last week with six other people, including Blondie, a brunette from Long Island, listening in on the Party Connection, a 900-number party line service.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the reaction to a Supreme Court decision on gray market imports misstated the location of ABC International Traders. The company is in Los Angeles.

title: Europe-Japan Trade Gap
description: The European Community's trade deficit with Japan rose by 13 percent in dollar terms last year but shrank 4 percent in terms of European Currency Units, the European Community commission said today. Europe's trade deficit with Japan rose to $24.2 billion in 1987 from $21.4 billion the year before. But in terms of European Currency Units, known as E.C.U.'s, the gap narrowed to 20.9 billion from 21.8 billion.

title: House's Adviser on Drugs
description: The Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control was establisheed in 1976 and has been re-authorized by a voice vote of each Congress since.

title: For Gaiety, a New Lease on Pastrami
description: LEAD: Two years had passed since the Gaiety Delicatessen served strawberry shortcake to tourists with a Broadway ticket, struggling actresses looking for a break and agents on the make. But last Thursday the Gaiety, at 224 West 47th Street, reopened - raising expectations among stargazers who remember this

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Still Reach For Proper Respect
description: There was a mild celebration in the Lakers' dressing room following their 117-102 victory Saturday over the Dallas Mavericks. By the time the television cameras and the microphones were allowed inside, the Lakers assumed the posture of businessmen who had closed an important but routine deal.

title: Bridge
description: Four teams with world championship ambitions battled to the wire here today, with the two winners due to represent the United States in Venice in October.

title: This Educator Is No Star
description: LEAD: We have seen and heard the hyped media accounts about Joe Clark, the principal of the predominantly black and Hispanic Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J., whose unorthodox disciplinary measures have won him praise. But now that he is to be glorified in a Warner Brothers movie, his record should be carefully scrutinized.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 6, 1988: MONDAY Cincinnati Bell TUESDAY Alaska Air Group Phillips-Van Heusen Chyron Corp Pillsbury Co McDermott Intl Staley Continental WEDNESDAY Fort Howard Corp SNE Telecommunications Handleman Corp Wallace Computer HJ Heinz Witco Corp Nicor Inc Wm Wrigley Jr THURSDAY Centel Corp Trinity Industries Hancock Fabrics Universal Foods Illinois Power FRIDAY DeSoto Inc Helmerich & Payne

title: Market Place; Will Bank Stocks Continue to Rally?
description: DESPITE concerns about the economy and higher interest rates, financial stocks have been leading the market since the beginning of May. One index of money center banks, by Salomon Brothers, climbed 10 percent last month.

title: Truce a Relief to a Nicaraguan Town
description: For the first time since Dr. Marlon Amador became director of the public hospital here in 1985, he is not treating a single war victim.

title: Ethiopian Rebels' Claims
description: Guerrillas said today that they inflicted heavy casualties on Ethiopian Government forces in fighting in southern Tigre Province over the last two weeks. The Eritrean rebels' radio said two battalions were wiped out near Amba Alagi between May 25 and May 28. The radio said 320 troops were killed and 420 captured. It said that in fighting last week, 234 Ethiopian troops were killed or wounded and 30 captured.

title: Tax Watch; Repair of '86 Law Facing Obstacles
description: AFTER numerous delays, the House Ways and Means Committee hopes to begin work next week on a long-awaited bill to make ''technical corrections'' and other minor changes in the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: A Quake Jolts New Zealand
description: A strong earthquake set off landslides, shattered windows and caused power failures in the lower half of New Zealand's South Island on Saturday, officials said. There were no immediate reports of injuries. The quake measured 6.5 on the Richter scale, but damage was limited because it was centered on the sparsely populated area of Lake Te Anau, north of the town of Invercargill, officials said.

title: Wendy Klein Is Married
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., Wendy Klein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Klein of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to David Schmalholz, a son of June Whittaker of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein performed the ceremony. The bride is an administrative assistant at Manhattan Industries, a shirt manufacturer in New York. Mr. Schmalholz is the audience coordinator for Geraldo Rivera's syndicated talk show on NBC-TV.

title: Nuclear-Plant Vote Worries Utilities
description: Opponents of nuclear power think they have a good chance to close the troubled Rancho Seco nuclear plant near Sacramento, Calif., in a local referendum tomorrow.

title: Young Lawyer Opposing House Veteran in Jersey
description: A young lawyer is reaching out to the new immigrants in Hudson County in his bid to unseat a 10-year Congressional veteran in Tuesday's primary elections that will nominate candidates in the state's 14 Congressional districts.

title: New Atlantans Join In, And the City Has a Ball
description: It's only three years old and its benefactors are two new arrivals in town, but the Swan House Ball, a benefit for the Atlanta Historical Society, is already being called one of Atlanta's top social events.

title: SOTHEBY'S HAS AUCTION IN CHINA
description: Sotheby's auctioneers recorded nearly $500,000 in sales today at their first auction in China, and the organizers said the profits would go to renovate half a mile of the Great Wall.

title: FOR ADULTS ONLY
description: Like a lot of fathers before him, Terry Monroe rediscovered the joys of organized baseball when his 10-year old son started playing on a local team.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Plans An Office in Shanghai
description: Ogilvy & Mather is opening an office next Monday in Shanghai, which will be in addition to the one it has in Beijing. Ogilvy says it will be the first American agency in Shanghai. Alfred Ma, from the Hong Kong branch, will be the office manager.

title: Presidents Are Always Turning Into History; Carter in Retrospect
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Bulldog! Bulldog! It's Traditional Not to Fight!
description: When Calvin Trillin (Yale '57), the wry essayist and chronicler of crime and nourishment, was mulling an offer to star in a one-ham show next fall, his daughter, Abigail ('90), had reservations.

title: COMMENCEMENTS
description: John Jay College

title: His Clout Distracts Gooden
description: The National League's No. 1 hitting pitcher fell six outs short of pitching the Mets' first no-hitter yesterday, and it was his hitting that might have undermined his effort.

title: JACKSON RELATIVE HELD ON CHARGES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's half-brother, Noah Ryan Robinson, has been charged with arranging an attack on a witness to a killing, the police said today.

title: Chiat/Day Clarifies Nissan Arrangement
description: Jay Chiat, chairman of Chiat/Day, reported Friday that the reason his advertising agency was one of the three dropped from the competition for Nissan's proposed Infiniti automobile was that earlier in the week it had been named agency for the consolidated Nissan dealers' advertising associations. The billings total $80 million a year, he said.

title: Julia H. Mills and Andrew S. Levine Are Married
description: Julia Holbrook Mills and Andrew Seth Levine were married yesterday at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y., by Judge Anthony A. Scarpino Jr., the senior judge of City Court in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: NBC Tries a Quieter Way Of Breaking Into Cable TV
description: ROBERT C. WRIGHT, the president of NBC, went to Washington last week and complained about what a lousy business network television has become. He observed that there may not be enough advertising money in the marketplace to support two broadcast networks, much less three or four, and lamented, ''Network advertising revenues are about as flat as sales on the Ollie North doll.''

title: Track and Field; Hurdler Comes Back
description: As the memories of the 1984 Olympics faded, so did the presence of Roger Kingdom for the most part. He won the 110-meter hurdles race, stunning Greg Foster, the world champion at the time, but then seemed to fade into the landscape.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday U.S. Productivity First Quarter (rev.) Tuesday Consumer Credit April Wednesday None Tursday None Friday Producer Prices May

title: He Can Go Home Again
description: Most Washington authors are transients, often passing through the capital on a foreshortened political timetable, and they usually have their book parties in places with which they are not all that familiar. Not columnist Patrick J. Buchanan, the former Reagan White House aide and Nixon confidant, whose roots here run much deeper.

title: Tokyo Stocks Finish High
description: Stock prices climbed across the board here today, driving the Tokyo Stock Exchange's main barometer above 28,000 points for the first time as the United States dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen.

title: Horse Racing; Familiar Overture For the Favorites
description: The two favorites for the Belmont Stakes Saturday are coming up to the race just the way they did for the Preakness on May 21, which means that it is time for handicappers to throw up their arms in confusion once again.

title: Peak Performance
description: For one afternoon, the botched cutoff throws, the balls that skidded between infielder's legs and the rallies that never began or were snuffed out early, were forgotten by the East Orange (N.J.) High School baseball team, thanks to Anthony Roberts.

title: Tony Night On Broadway
description: ''Phantom of the Opera,'' a musical import from Britain, and ''M. Butterfly,'' by the American playwright David Henry Hwang, won the top Tony Awards last night. ''Phantom,'' with music by

title: J.C. SNEAD TO DEFEND WESTCHESTER TITLE
description: AFTER the fourth round of the recent Las Vegas Invitational pro-am, J. C. Snead stood at the corner of the practice range trying to convince a fairly good amateur golfer that he would improve measurably by keeping his hips away from his downswing. Half an hour later, Snead was on the other side of the range giving tips to Sandy Lyle, the Scot who had won the Masters three weeks earlier.

title: Let a Third Party Decide About the Building That Was Too Tall
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Is Said to Consider 3 as Hunter President
description: The trustees of the City University of New York are expected to choose the next president of Hunter College from a list of three candidates at the end of this month, City University officials say.

title: Primark President Adds Two More Top Posts
description: Joseph E. Kasputys, president of the Primark Corporation, has taken on the additional titles of chairman and chief executive, succeeding Robert W. Stewart, 63, who has retired.

title: The 'Moscow Spring'
description: Driver pulls up in front of the Intourist Hotel near Red Square, double-parks and blocks the entrance. Soviet policeman shouts at him that the car will be towed away. Driver shrugs, walks off. How, I ask, can this challenge to authority be tolerated? ''The threat had no credibility,'' my interpreter replied. ''That cop couldn't get a tow truck here in a week.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Uprooting me from my family, land, friends and culture is a disgrace. As a Palestinian, I never hated you. I don't hate you now. I will never hate you.

title: The Tony Winners
description: BEST PLAY: ''M. Butterfly'' (David Henry Hwang). BEST MUSICAL: ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' BEST BOOK OF A MUSICAL: James Lapine (''Into the Woods''). BEST ORIGINAL SCORE: Stephen Sondheim (''Into the Woods''). BEST REVIVAL: ''Anything Goes.'' LEADING ACTOR IN A PLAY: Ron Silver (''Speed-the-Plow''). LEADING ACTRESS IN A PLAY: Joan Allen (''Burn This''). LEADING ACTOR IN A MUSICAL: Michael Crawford (''The Phantom of the Opera''). LEADING ACTRESS IN A MUSICAL:

title: Toys That Kill
description: A popular race-car game for children is ''recommended for ages 3 and up.'' Prudent legislation sponsored by Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, would require the toy's label to say more: that it contains small parts on which a child might choke.

title: Catastrophic Coverage? Hardly.
description: LEAD: Congress is about to send to the President a measure that would impose the most far-reaching changes in Medicare's benefits since the program's enactment in 1965. But the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Plan of 1988, while adding some protection against the catastrophic costs of illness, delivers far less than its name implies.

title: Chubb Names Chief Executive
description: The Chubb Corporation has named Dean R. O'Hare chairman and chief executive to succeed Henry U. Harder, 63 years old, who is retiring. Mr. O'Hare, who is 45, joined

title: Arafat Guerrillas and Rivals Fight in Beirut Refugee Area
description: Guerrillas loyal to the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, fought Syrian-backed Palestinian dissidents with mortars and grenades in a Beirut refugee district today. Two people were reported killed and nine wounded.

title: Woman Circles Globe
description: A 34-year-old Australian woman became the first woman to sail round the world alone nonstop when she arrived here today after a 189-day voyage.

title: Julie Ridgely Married to Peter F. Miller
description: Julie Dillon Ripley Ridgely, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Dillon Ripley of Washington and Litchfield, Conn., and Peter Freeland Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Miller Jr. of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday at the United Church in Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. John S. Livingston, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Ronald S. James, a Presbyterian minister.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. will pay more than $1 billion in savings insurance to depositors of one or more institutions that it will soon liquidate. The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board declined to identify the institutions, but a California newspaper said they were the American Diversified Savings Bank and North American Savings and Loan, both in Costa Mesa. [ Page A1. ] Surging aluminum prices could encourage an increase in capacity, which could result in an oversupply of the metal, economists and industry analysts say. [ D2. ] The U.S. economy grew in May for the 22d consecutive month, according to a report by the nation's purchasing managers. [ D2. ] Investor skittishness is forcing companies that want capital to seek alternatives to new stock offerings. [ D1. ] The S.E.C. chairman, David S. Ruder, discussed his concerns and proposals in an interview. [ D4. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The Robert M. Bass Group raised its bid for Macmillan. The group, in an unusually vigorous takeover attempt, offered $2 billion in cash or a restructuring plan that it says is worth $5.65 a share more than a similar management offer. [ D1. ] Most of the staff has left Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, an influential trade publication. [ D1. ] Too many awards for advertising? Some agency executives think so. [ D10. ] Art magazines can spur a career and establish a gallery, as well as please a growing number of readers. [ D10. ] NBC's president hopes to move the company into new businesses, on the premise that network broadcasting's best days are past. Television. [ D10. ] COMPANIES Lawyers are watching a suit brought against Griffin B. Bell by a former E. F. Hutton branch manager who charged that the former Attorney General defamed him in a 1985 investigation. [ D1. ] Opponents of nuclear power think they have enough votes in a local referendum to close the troubled Rancho Seco nuclear plant near Sacramento, Calif. [ D1. ] Long Island Lighting will conduct a multimillion-dollar emergency drill for its Shoreham nuclear station, even though it plans to abandon the plant. [ B1. ] A much faster computer network will be introduced today by Scientific Computer Systems of California. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The Dominican Republic's industrial parks are attracting many U.S. businesses with their cheap labor. [ D8. ] The restructuring of the steel industry in West Germany could return it to long-term profitability, industry leaders say. [ D8. ] House Democrats want new sanctions against South Africa that would impose a sweeping trade embargo and ban virtually all American business investment in that country. [ A8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS U.S.-Japan differences are bread and butter to Ko-Yung Tung, who helps corporations make deals. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] A House committee will soon begin making corrections in the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Stocks in financial institutions have been leading the market, although there is little agreement among professionals about how long the rally will last. Market Place. [ D6. ] The recent rally in bond prices is unlikely to continue, many analysts think. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: And The Winner Is (Are)?
description: Somewhere out there are two tickets with the six numbers needed to win the biggest North American lottery jackpot, $51.2 million, a California lottery spokesman said today.

title: Santo Domingo's Labor-Cost Lure
description: New blacktop roads curve past carefully manicured lawns and low-rise, pastel-painted buildings that suggest a small university campus.

title: Reviews/Dance; 2 DEBUTS IN 'INFORMER'
description: ''The Informer,'' Agnes de Mille's recent ballet about Irish and British strife in the 1920's, featured two major debuts in American Ballet Theater's performance Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Reviews/Dance; IVORY COAST TROUPE COMES TO BROOKLYN
description: Danceafrica has grown up. Now in its 11th year, the popular festival, presented Saturday and Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, presented a company from Africa for the first time, as well as a newly streamlined show. While the results were varied, there is no question about the Guirivoires from the Ivory Coast.

title: Wave Your Arms for Fitness
description: AEROBIC dance instructors tell their students that to obtain a more thorough workout they should use their arms more, waving them higher in the air and more energetically. Anyone who follows that advice quickly discovers its wisdom.

title: Review/Rock; SNARLS OF AN UNDERDOG
description: Graham Parker has been a perennial rock underdog since he released his debut album in 1976. When he played Roseland on Friday night, he seemed to thrive on the role. In the 1970's, Mr. Parker suffered from bad timing and ineffectual marketing. He was an angry young songwriter just a little too early for punk-rock; then Elvis Costello, with a similar style, eclipsed Mr. Parker with more radical songs and attitudes. And Mr. Parker's best album, ''Squeezing Out Sparks'' (1979), somehow never reached the large audience it deserved. At the same time, Mr. Parker has been an extremely inconsistent songwriter, and his chosen style - a mixture of mid-1960's Bob Dylan, late-1960's soul and early-1970's reggae - demands first-rate lyrics that he hasn't always delivered.

title: Hiring Outlook Appears Strong
description: Hiring in the third quarter is expected to reach its highest level in a decade, driven by strong seasonal demand in the construction and service industries, according to a survey to be issued Monday.

title: Russians Want to Expedite an Angola Settlement
description: The Soviet Union is willing to play a more active role in ending the war in Angola, including offering its services as co-guarantor of a peace settlement and becoming a direct participant in negotiations ''if others want it,'' according to a senior Soviet official.

title: Goal of U.S. Oil Reserve
description: The Department of Energy expects to reach its goal of having 750 million barrels of oil in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve by the middle 1990's, according to the director of the reserve's operations and readiness division. Currently, 548 million barrels are stored in five salt domes in Texas and Louisiana, the director, Fred Hutchinson, said on Friday. ''Tankers are unloading 50,000 to 60,000 barrels per day,'' he said. The program, aimed at insuring the nation's oil supply in the event of a cutoff from overseas producers, began in 1977.

title: Wright Aide Assigned To Book, Paper Says
description: House Speaker Jim Wright assigned a staff member in 1984 to help him prepare a book that is at the center of Republican efforts to seek an ethics investigation of the Texas Democrat, according to a published report.

title: Appreciating Art, and Russians
description: The canvases were familiar enough: the lovely, warm scenes of Dutch domesticity that the Western eye knows well; the meticulously rendered opulence of satin and fur, the cold clarity of checkered-tile cathedral floors; and the swirling, Italianate biblical scenes, all reds and blues and grand proportions.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Tuesday with a front-page article about a bill to protect Medicare beneficiaries from large medical bills misstated a provision intended to help with patient care at home. The legislation would provide for 80 hours of care each year by someone from outside the household.

title: Chicago Board In Japan Pact
description: The Chicago Board of Trade announced Friday that it had signed an agreement with the Tokyo Stock Exchange to monitor trading activity in futures on the Tokyo Price Index.

title: More Bond Gains Called Unlikely
description: The recent strong rally in bond prices is unlikely to continue, most credit market analysts contend.

title: Shultz, in Warning to Israel, Says Occupation Is 'Dead-End Street'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz cautioned Israel today that the occupation of the West Bank and the frustration of Palestinian rights were ''a dead-end street,'' but he continued to fail to win any support for the American peace plan from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: BEST PLAY: 'BUTTERFLY'
description: ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's version of Gaston Leroux's tale of ghoul meets girl at the Paris Opera, won the Tony Award last night as best musical of the 1987-88 Broadway season. ''Phantom,'' which took home a total of seven awards, was the second import in a row from London's West End to get the prize - ''Les Miserables'' won last year.

title: TV Notes
description: Coloring Controversy ''Clark Gable walks into the room and there is Claudette Colbert behind the desk. He yells at her and storms out.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 In French parliamentary elections, President Mitterrand's Socialist Party did not poll as well as had been expected in the first round. But itcould win a majority in the runoff vote next week. Page A1

title: Giuliani Withheld Wedtech Evidence
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan last year withheld from the Justice Department evidence linking Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to the Wedtech scandal because Mr. Meese had not disqualified himself from the case, according to an assistant Federal prosecutor.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Building Bridges From Tokyo to New York
description: As they have every year for nearly two decades, the corporate elite of New York's Japanese community gathered last week for the Japan Society's annual dinner. And as they have nearly every year, the executives and dignitaries who filled the ballroom at the New York Hilton heard the keynote speaker deliver the same message. This time, it came from Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, who is the House majority leader.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Hatalsky Breaks the Ice: Morris Hatalsky made a 4-foot putt for par on the second extra hole yesterday to win a playoff with the defender, Tom Kite, and capture the $800,000 Kemper Open in Potomac, Md.

title: Pepsi Links Campaign To 'I Love New York'
description: Pepsi-Cola bottlers of upstate New York are tapping in on all the recognition built up by the ''I Love New York'' advertising and are even using some of the film that Wells, Rich, Greene took for its travel-promotion campaign.

title: Nina Adler Katzander Becomes Bride
description: Nina Adler Katzander, the daughter of Barbara Adler Katzander of New York and the late Howard L. Katzander of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday in the Beth-El Chapel at Temple Emanu-El in New York to Jason Curtis Gold, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald David Gold of Atlanta. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Mintz & Hoke Depicts Shift at Pratt & Whitney
description: Ten years ago, before the aircraft engine makers at General Electric and Rolls-Royce became so aggressive, their counterparts at Pratt & Whitney developed a haughty sole-supplier manner, some people say. Some customers even said it was easier trying to talk to a brick wall.

title: Amy R. Berman, a Lawyer, Weds Dr. Craig Alan Sukin
description: Amy Robin Berman, an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, and Dr. Craig Alan Sukin, who received an M.D. degree last month from Duke University, were married yesterday at Temple Emanuel-El in New York by Rabbi David M. Posner.

title: Jackson to Push for Plank On Voter Registration Rules
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson announced today that one of his key objectives at the Democratic National Convention would be winning the party's commitment to eliminate virtually all restrictions on procedures for registering to vote in the United States.

title: Study Supports New York's Needle Plan
description: Giving free needles to addicts has not increased drug abuse, studies in foreign cities show, and, surprisingly, some needle recipients even reduced their frequency of injection.

title: New Twists in Search for Capital
description: Wall Street's October crash and subsequent doldrums have not slammed the door on new stock offerings, but investor skittishness is forcing many companies that want new capital to consider alternatives.

title: Reviews/Music; MADCAP CABARET SONGS
description: Claiborne Cary has a Cheshire cat smile, tousled hair and a craggy chameleon voice that rises from a husky whisper to delicate piccolo-like pop-jazz flights.
