The ''Frontline'' documentary, on Channel 13 tonight at 10 P.M., reports that some 1.5 million Americans are infected with the AIDS virus, and the number is going up fast. By 1991, the program reports, the cost of caring for them will reach $8 billion to $10 billion a year, at least half of which will have to come from taxes.

title: A Grande Dame of Ballet Honored at 90
description: With cheers, a few tears and hundreds of flowers, Dame Ninette de Valois - dancer, choreographer, teacher and founder of Britain's Royal Ballet - was honored at a gala 90th-birthday celebration tonight at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden.

title: Senate Avoids Vote on Keeping Forces in Gulf
description: The Senate today blocked formal authorization of the continued presence of American military forces in the Persian Gulf under provisions of the 1973 War Powers Resolution.

title: Orion Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $66,000 for the quarter and $17,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $999,000 for the quarter and $1,212,000 for the year.

title: Despite Collapse of Stocks, Luxury Sales Bounce Back
description: Nearly eight months after the stock market collapse brought predictions of ruin for businesses devoted to luxury items, the demand for those goods around the country appears to be booming.

title: Paine Webber Officer Resigns to Start Firm
description: In 1983, John F. Perkowski, a senior investment banker at Paine Webber Inc., helped the Metromedia Company sell and lease back some of its office space and television studios.

title: Sandwich Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Fiscal 1987 per share earnings is not available because the company went public in July 1986. The year-ago fourth quarter and full year are after a pre-tax provision for loan losses of $300,000 and included a pre-tax gain of $1,458,000 from a distribution from the Massachusetts Co- operative Central Bank.

title: Delaware Senate Field Grows
description: Lieut. Gov. S.B. Woo officially announced today that would seek the Democratic nomination to run against Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Republican who is completing his third term in the Senate.

title: High Schools in West Bank Are Reopened by the Israelis
description: The Israeli Army reopened high schools today for 36,000 students in the West Bank and freed more than 100 Palestinian teen-agers from jail so they could attend classes.

title: Sanctuary Movement Gains a Court Hearing on Its Principles
description: Legal arguments that are the foundation of the movement to provide sanctuary to Central Americans will be the focus of a hearing here Tuesday on charges against a writer and a minister who arranged for two Salvadoran women to enter the United States illegally.

title: QED Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New York State Lottery Chooses DDB Needham
description: After a search that began in September, the New York State Lottery has selected DDB Needham New York, an Omnicom Group company, as its ad agency. It replaces McCaffrey & McCall, a Saatchi & Saatchi agency.

title: MEETING OF SHAMIR AND SHEVARDNADZE SET FOR THIS WEEK
description: In a demonstration of the shift in Moscow's Middle East policy, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will hold his first meeting with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel this week in New York, Israeli officials and Soviet diplomats said yesterday.

title: Leone Peters, 76, Dies; Real-Estate Chairman
description: Leone J. Peters, the former chairman and chief executive of Cushman & Wakefield, a real-estate concern in Manhattan, died of heart failure Saturday after open-heart surgery at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Airlines Improve On-Time Rates
description: The airlines had their best on-time performance and least number of consumer complaints to the Government in the latest aviation consumer statistics, the Transportation Department announced today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Seeing No Evil
description: The Rand Corporation, the Los Angeles-based research group known for its close ties to, and lucrative contracts with, a succession of Democratic and Republican administrations, has taken its a latest linguistic cue from the Reagan White House.

title: In South Korea, Anger at U.S. Spreads
description: Ever since American troops died defending this nation in the Korean War, Americans have basked in the gratitude of the Korean people. But now the image of a benevolent America is being called into question as a new wave of anti-Americanism moves off campus and into the mainstream.

title: United Buying Service International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Book of Kabbalah'
description: To the Editor:

title: Former President Ford Says Meese Should Offer to Quit
description: Former President Gerald M. Ford strongly suggested today that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d should offer his resignation to President Reagan.

title: Plan for Oil Drilling Off California Is Halted
description: Interior Secretary Donald Hodel today suspended plans to lease 1.1 million acres off the northern California coast for oil drilling.

title: Showscan Film Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sherman R. Krupp, Anthropology Professor, 61
description: Sherman R. Krupp, professor of anthropology and sociology at Queens College, died of heart failure Sunday at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Judge Orders Mother of Brawley Sent to Jail for Refusing to Testify
description: A judge today ordered Tawana Brawley's mother jailed for 30 days and fined $250 for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating her daughter's assertion that she was abducted and raped in a racially motivated assault last November.

title: Bass Files Suit to Block Breakup by Macmillan
description: The Robert M. Bass Group of Texas filed suit in a Delaware Chancery Court yesterday in an attempt to stop Macmillan Inc. from carrying out its proposed reorganization plan on Friday.

title: Smith & Wesson Seeking U.S. Job
description: Smith & Wesson, the gun manufacturer that three years ago lost a battle to produce the military's primary handgun, is again trying to win the Army's business in a new contract competition ordered by Congress.

title: It's Ron and Mikhail in a New Summit Mini-Series
description: LEAD: The network anchors have hardly settled back in their New York studios, and already the co-producers of the most successful miniseries in diplomatic history are planning their fifth summit meeting.

title: F.D.A. Approves Wart Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had approved the use of alpha interferon, a hormone-like protein, to treat genital warts.

title: Mini-Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Ohio Law Review Ordered
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered a lower court to re-examine its 1986 ruling that an Ohio law regulating corporate takeovers is unconstitutional.

title: Cuomo Imposes Hiring Halt and Plans Program Cuts
description: Two weeks after he announced that the state was facing a $900 million budget shortfall, Governor Cuomo today imposed a hiring freeze on all state agencies and proposed spending cuts that would eliminate about 600 jobs.

title: Judge in Iran-Contra Case Denies A Defense Request for Secret Files
description: The judge in the Iran-contra case rejected a request by defense lawyers today to review some of the most sensitive and highly classified intelligence documents in Government files.

title: High Court Won't Hear Case on Fed
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court's dismissal of a challenge to the composition of the Federal Reserve panel that has prime responsibility for setting the nation's monetary policy.

title: Jordan Limits Currency
description: Fighting to stem a run on the local currency, Jordan's central bank set compulsory rates today for the dinar against foreign currencies. The central bank quoted the dollar at 358 fils, compared with 350 fils on Sunday. Dealers said the housing bank, the first commercial bank to quote rates today, followed those set by the central bank, but money changers failed to abide by the official rates and were selling the dollar at around 375 fils. Jordan's official press organizations said Sunday that the central bank would start setting binding rates as one of several measures to regulate dealing.

title: James H. Gildea, Ex-Congressman, 97
description: James H. Gildea, a Democrat who represented Pennsylvania in the House of Representatives from 1935 to 1939, died of cardiac arrest Sunday. He was 97 years old.

title: Norway Enacts Trading Law
description: Norway's Parliament today approved a law under which violators of stock trading rules can be jailed for up to three years.

title: Baltimore Journal; Of White Marble Steps And Painted Screens
description: More than most cities, this is a city of distinct, close-knit neighborhoods, 237 by one count, and few are more distinct than those of southeast Baltimore.

title: Unocal Names Chief Executive
description: Fred L. Hartley, chairman and chief executive of the Unocal Corporation since 1960, will retire as chief executive and be succeeded by Richard J. Stegemeier, the company said today.

title: Matrix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains from the repurchase of long-term debt of $500,000 and $4,200,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $200,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Uprising Is the Agenda at Arab Summit
description: As Secretary of State George P. Shultz concludes another Middle East peace mission, Arab leaders are expected to give strong moral, political and financial support this week to the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Oxford First Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $250,000 for the latest first quarter and $164,000 for the year- ago period. The year-ago figures were restated.

title: Anti-Corrosion System Gaining
description: Engineers are applying a principle familiar to high school physics students to create giant ''backward batteries'' to fight corrosion of steel supporting bridges and highways.

title: Perpetual Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a credit of $197,000 from early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $307,000 and extraordinary gain of $2,135,000 for the 6 months. c-After a pre-tax charge of $6,354,000 for a one-time expense of FSLIC secondary reserve for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Farragut Mortgage reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Afghan Chief Rattles Saber at Pakistan
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said here today that he might ask the Soviet Union to delay the withdrawal of its troops from his country if Pakistan continued to allow the shipment of weapons to Afghan guerrillas.

title: Israeli-Selected Arab Mayor Is Stabbed
description: The Mayor of El Bireh, appointed by Israel in 1986, was stabbed and critically wounded today as he stepped out of his office.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Keys to Tennis Court
description: In a way, the Presidential campaign is also a contest for the key to the White House tennis court.

title: Review/Theater; A Return, After 28 Years
description: Arline Lanin, a pianist, made her New York debut in 1960, and has not played a recital here since then. She has been teaching nearby, however, at the Westminster Conservatory, in Princeton. On Sunday afternoon, she ended her long absence with an energetically played performance at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: WINE TALK
description: The first time I paid any at-tention to the pinot blanc grape was about 10 years ago. I was sitting in a steamy little restaurant in Epernay, in the Champagne region of France, with Edmond Maudiere, the wine maker for Moet et Chandon and the consulting wine maker for Domaine Chandon in California.

title: INSIDE
description: Lawyers for the Poor

title: PEACE IS NEARER IN MARTIN-UMPIRE WAR
description: Billy Martin, submitting to the request of Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, yesterday offered an apology to American League umpires for his dirt-kicking and dirt-throwing episode May 30 at Oakland, Calif. The apology was not returned, although the umpires backed down from a threat to eject Martin whenever he stepped onto the field to dispute a call.

title: Athens Says U.S. Seeks Arab in Attacks on 2 Jets
description: A Greek police official said today that the United States was demanding the extradition of a Palestinian in connection with two mid-flight bomb attacks on American passenger planes.

title: Economic Scene; Effects of a Lower Capital Gains Tax
description: FEW among Washington's movers and shakers spend their leisure hours contemplating the intricacies of multilinear regression analysis. But many do appreciate the value of arcane economic research that delivers an easily understood political message.

title: Shopper Is Slain Inside a Garage In Connecticut
description: A 61-year-old New Canaan woman was stabbed to death Monday night in a Bloomingdale's parking garage in what the police said was an apparent robbery as she returned to her car from shopping.

title: Sedalia Journal; Unlikely Cash Crop Of Weeds Flourishes
description: John Sneed's farm is either a weed Waikiki or a hay fever sufferer's Hades.

title: First Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank holding company said proceeds of its sale of stock during the second quarter of 1987 have been redeployed into the growth of operations instead of earnings assets, which accounts for the decrease in earnings per share during a period in which earnings increased.

title: Impressionist Spirit Blooms in the Park
description: LATTER-DAY Monets in the gardens at Giverny?

title: Edward S. Quade, 79; Was Rand Researcher
description: Edward Schaumberg Quade, who helped develop the problem-solving method of systems analysis, died after suffering a stroke, a Rand Corporation spokesman said. He was 79 years old.

title: Carlucci, in Seoul, Talks of North's Threat
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that North Korea posed as strong a threat as ever to the stability of the Korean Peninsula.

title: Charles Vanda Is Dead; Television Writer, 84
description: Charles Vanda, a writer, producer and former president of the Directors Guild, died Saturday. He was 84 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, is offering $200 million of 9 percent notes, due in 1993, at a price of 99.84 to yield 9.04 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Miami Hopes for Title Dashed
description: Miami's hope of becoming the fifth school to win a college football poll and a national baseball championship in one year came to a sudden and shocking end tonight.

title: Granite Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $363,390, which represents a dividend from Co-operative Central Bank's share insurance fund for both the quarter and year.

title: Trade Bill's Chances Grow Without Plant-Closing Item
description: Chances have improved for passage of a second, slimmed-down trade bill if the Senate, as expected, upholds President Reagan's veto of the original legislation, lawmakers and lobbyists said today. The Senate plans to vote Wednesday.

title: North American Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included an addition of $9,413,966 to loan reserves.

title: Dimensional Medicine reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home Loan Rates Rise
description: Interest rates on both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages rose in April, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: A Bracelet, an Odd Earring, Cracked Teacups
description: I came to live in the United States believing I was profoundly prepared. I had studied the works of Flannery O'Connor in Polish, and had learned English by reading J.D. Salinger's short stories. I had seen all of Woody Allen's movies, and could sing Duke Ellington's ''Take the 'A' Train.''

title: Universities Creating Second-Class Faculties
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Foreign Investment in U.S. Is Good for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: New York to Seek Loan to Bolster Cash Flow
description: For the first time in six years, New York State will have to borrow money from its own short-term investment pool because it does not have enough cash on hand to meet operating expenses, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said today.

title: GAF Sells Stake
description: The GAF Corporation said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had sold its 9.4 percent stake in CBI Industries for $59 million. Analysts had speculated that GAF, of Wayne, N.J., might seek control of CBI, an industrial gas supplier based in Oak Brook, Ill. Based upon the figures in the filing, GAF had a profit of more than $3 a share on its CBI investment of more than two million shares.

title: A Better Tribute To Interned Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Equion Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $161,000. c-Includes tax credits of $712,158 and $2,019,018 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: In Moscow, Tolerance Of Protests
description: In a move both Soviet officials and dissidents describe as a significant step toward greater freedom of political expression, the Moscow authorities have quietly adopted a more tolerant attitude toward unauthorized public demonstrations.

title: Adolph Mechner, Physician, 91
description: Dr. Adolph Mechner, a retired physician, died of pneumonia last Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cronkite Idea for Special Is Rejected by CBS
description: CBS, which is negotiating to keep a dissatisfied Walter Cronkite from leaving the network, has rejected his proposal to be the anchor for a prime-time special report this fall on the 25th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy. The project was Mr. Cronkite's first proposal in his effort to find a more meaningful role at CBS, according to people associated with the project.

title: Market Place; Aerospace Issues: Summit Cool-Off
description: THE improving relationship between Washington and Moscow has further dampened the prospects of military contractors, a stock group that was already out of favor.

title: Intech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $200,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Estimated Cost Of Pipeline Cut
description: Technological advances and an improved economic climate have helped cut the estimated cost of a proposed pipeline by $11.5 billion, according to American and Canadian pipeline executives.

title: Key Changes At Magazines
description: Nicholas H. Niles, who introduced Changing Times magazine to advertising (and vice versa) during his nine years as publisher, is now headed for American Express Publishing where he will be vice president and publisher of Food & Wine. Mr. Niles will be replaced by

title: Food, Prayer And Respite In the Barrios Of Manila
description: LEAD: TO a casual observer, a spacious, tranquil French restaurant might seem out of place amid the clutter and noise of Manila's industrial district. Here at Eau Vive (the name means ''living water''), not far from the Manila Gas Corporation and the Coca-Cola bottling plant, guests can sit beside a flower-filled grotto, listen to soft string music and enjoy duck a l'orange and fine wine.

title: Service Corp International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Murray Rejects 2d Electrolux Bid
description: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company rejected as inadequate a sweetened $52-a-share tender offer from Electrolux A.B. of Sweden valued at $197.1 million. Murray, based in Brentwood, Tenn., also took several steps to thwart the hostile offer by amending its anti-takeover plan. Murray said its board considered the Electrolux bid inadequate and ''not in the best interests of Murray or its shareholders.''

title: Shultz as Cassandra
description: For the last four days, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has roamed through the Middle East as a prophet of doom.

title: Coniston Discloses Macmillan Stake
description: Coniston Partners, the investment firm that recently lost a proxy fight with Gillette Inc., said yesterday that it holds a 4.9 percent stake in Macmillan Inc., the publishing company in the throes of a takeover battle.

title: Front-Runner Status Helps Bring Dukakis a Sweep of Jersey Vote
description: Michael S. Dukakis won virtually all of New Jersey in the Presidential primary yesterday, from the southern shore to the northern suburbs, and ceded only the heavily black urban areas to the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: A Diner Artist Goes to the Source for Inspiration
description: There is no free lunch at Uncle Bob's Diner. Indeed, there's no lunch at all: no eggs sunny side up, no french fries with gravy, no coffee. Jerry Berta's menu nourishes the souls of diner devotees.

title: Giant Food Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 21
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend issued June 3.

title: Gingrich Says He Used Aide To Help With His Own Book
description: The principal critic of Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, on ethical issues said today that he, too, used a member of his congressional staff to work on a book he was writing.

title: Merchants Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shortage of Rocket Fuel Creating New Crisis for U.S. Space Flights
description: The United States is facing another crisis in its space launching capacity because of an impending shortage of a critical ingredient for solid-fuel rockets, military and space agency officials said yesterday.

title: ingapore Journal; Where Conspiracies and Furtive Figures Bloom
description: Teo Eng Seng is being followed; or rather, he thinks he is being followed; or perhaps it is wisest simply to say he wouldn't be surprised if he were being followed.

title: Trial Begins in Slaying of Witness
description: In a case that raised fears about the security of witnesses, three men went on trial yesterday on charges of murdering a 61-year-old woman who had seen a shooting in front of the South Jamaica, Queens, car service where she was a dispatcher.

title: Books of The Times; People Who Talk but Don't Connect
description: Believe Them By Mary Robison 146 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: PCA International reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $47,000 for the latest first quarter and $89,000 for the year-ago period; the year-ago period also included a pre-tax gain of $212,618 from the sale of land.

title: Topics of The Times; No Pensions for Crooks
description: A former New York Supreme Court Justice, William Brennan, served 26 months in prison for accepting $50,000 in bribes to fix four criminal cases. He still gets a $41,236 annual pension from New York State.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Thanks to the back-to-basics thrust, we've brought up the students who were at the bottom. Now the challenge is to do something about the upper end of the academic scale.'' - Gregory Anrig, of the Educational Testing Service, on high school mathematics teaching. [ A1:2. ]

title: Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Drops 20.62
description: Stock prices retreated broadly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.62 points, to 2,054.59.

title: Bangladesh Parliament Votes To Make Islam State Religion
description: Parliament approved a constitutional amendment tonight that makes Islam the state religion of this south Asian nation. Opposition parties rejected the change and said they would resist it.

title: Renault to Return To Formula One
description: The French auto firm Renault said today that it would return to Formula One Grand Prix racing in 1989 as an engine manufacturer.

title: USX to Sell 2 Units
description: The USX Corporation has signed a letter of intent to sell its Carnegie Natural Gas Company and Apollo Gas Company units to Mast Resources Inc. of New York and the Carnegie Energy Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Carnegie and Apollo produce and distribute natural gas to about 7,500 residential, commercial and industrial customers in southwestern Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

title: Emerge Magazine Aims At Black Readers
description: From the time he was 12 years old, Wilmer Ames had wanted to be a writer. Moving from some very small towns, he made it big in the big city -a reporter first for Sports Illustrated and then for Time.

title: Boston U. Picks Dean For School Of Law
description: Colin S. Diver, a professor of administrative law whose experiences in this city's school busing crisis were chronicled in the book ''Common Ground,'' which won a Pulitzer Prize, has been named dean of the Boston University School of Law.

title: SALUTE TO THE POTATO
description: IT was just nine months ago that we last left Dave Bresnahan, who was packing his bags in Williamsport, Pa.

title: David Hart, 37, Dies; Played Baroque Flutes
description: David Hart, a flutist noted for his work with Baroque and earlier instruments, died May 25 from complications resulting from AIDS at his home in Fort Worth. He was 37 years old.

title: Emergency Space Shuttle Landing Simulated
description: Three astronauts made a tricky mock emergency landing today, ending a comprehensive rehearsal for the next launching of a space shuttle.

title: Skeptical Views on OPEC Meeting
description: As oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries prepare for their midyear meeting in Vienna on Saturday, many of the group's experts appear convinced that there is little likelihood of raising oil prices much.

title: Mahlon Apgar 3d, Real-Estate Broker, 85
description: Mahlon Apgar 3d, a real-estate broker who specialized in large-scale land acquisitions, died of cancer Monday at Mease Hospital-Dunedin in Clearwater, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Clearwater.

title: Bioplasty Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $84,841 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $58,593 from discontinued operations. d-Net income and after a loss of $141,602 from discontinued operations.

title: Review/Music; Classics From Longtime Blues Men
description: Two virtually unknown early New York rhythm-and-blues musicians, Larry Dale, a guitarist, and Bob Gaddy, a pianist, played at Under Acme on Saturday night. Backed by Killing Floor, a competent quartet of Larry Simon on guitar, Brian Jost on bass, Andrew Johnson on drums and George Boziwick on harmonica, Mr. Dale and Mr. Gaddy - aged 65 and 64, respectively - charged through a set of blues standards, turning Charles Brown's ''Drifting Blues'' into a deep blues lament and tearing up Jimmy Reed's ''Bright Lights, Big City.''

title: Coated Sales Faces Inquiry
description: Coated Sales Inc. disclosed today that its internal investigation had uncovered a $6 million overstatement on its most recent financial statement.

title: Corn Mill Deal Opposed
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced Monday that it was moving to require that the merger of two leading dry corn mills be rescinded. Illinois Cereal Mills Inc.'s acquisition of the Lincoln Grain Company from Elders Grain Inc. could substantially reduce competition in the production of dry corn products in the United States, the F.T.C. said. The commission said it had directed its staff to seek a Federal court injunction blocking the move or requiring it to be rescinded.

title: Help for a Soviet Journalist
description: Members of the American Newsletter Association voted today to assist a dissident Soviet journalist whose magazine was recently suppressed by the Soviet authorities.

title: Medical Technologists Need More Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Pity the Mugger
description: Jack Hood Vaughn, a 67-year-old former director of the Peace Corps who was also United States Ambassador to Panama and Colombia, recently left his hotel in midtown Manhattan after midnight to get a newspaper. As the slightly built, gray-haired man was returning, he was accosted by a mugger.

title: Lincoln Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rewarding Tuesday For J.W.T.
description: THE J. Walter Thompson Company had the kind of day yesterday that could make any agency forget its troubles.

title: Despite Tie to a Popular President, Bush Faces Dukakis as Underdog
description: Five months from today, the nation will elect a new President, and as things now stand Michael S. Dukakis is much the most likely victor, according to surveys taken by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Yanks' Victory Soothes Martin
description: Billy Martin walked up the steps of the dugout, headed swiftly toward the pitcher's mound and stopped when he met Charles Hudson. There were a few words exchanged, perhaps some encouragement, and then the Yankee manager turned back toward the bench. He touched the bill of his cap briefly to acknowledge the ovation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank named David Puth New York foreign exchange manager.

title: Prisoner Charges Poor Conditions Are U.S. 'Psychiatric Experiment'
description: One of seven women held in a special security unit of a Federal prison in Kentucky charged in court here today that conditions were deliberately made inhumane as part of a ''psychiatric experiment'' to control prisoners. Several of the prisoners in the unit have been linked by the authorities to terrorist groups.

title: Report Sees Countermoves By Soviets on Missile Shield
description: United States deployment of anti-missile defenses in orbit would prompt rapid countermeasures by the Soviet Union, spurring a race between the superpowers to exert military control over space, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment said today.

title: Food Notes
description: Cheeses With Less Fat

title: Sale at Tenneco Brings Several Bids
description: Tenneco Inc., the nation's 10th-largest oil company, said it had received several offers for its oil and gas operations since putting them up for sale last month. Analysts said the units could bring between $5 billion and $7 billion. A Tenneco spokesman declined to identify the bidders, except to say that an offer had been received from Gulf Financial Resources Inc., a Houston investment firm financed by European interests.

title: S.E.C. Said To Favor Drexel Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement staff told Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. last week that it had been authorized to charge the investment firm with securities violations regarding 18 deals, people with knowledge of the Federal investigation said last night.

title: Abuna Tekle Haimanot, 70, Ethiopian Orthodox Leader
description: The Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, Abuna Tekle Haimanot, has died at the age of 70, the Ethiopian press agency reported today.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE skirt steak goes by many names, including hanger steak, oyster steak and butcher steak. The last arose because butchers traditionally kept these sinewy yet exceptionally juicy and flavorful cuts for themselves.

title: Commercial Test Nears For Hidden AIDS Virus
description: With demand growing for a test that would find the AIDS virus even if it is hidden in the body from tests now commonly used, a biotechnology company says a new procedure that meets this need may be widely available within two months.

title: Salvadoran Leader Has Surgery; Outlook Is Grim
description: Surgeons removed a malignant tumor today from the stomach of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, but left his cancerous liver untouched. Medical experts said the move indicated that he had little chance of long-term survival.

title: Savoy Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The factors which contributed most significantly to the 1987 loss were losses incurred in connection with the company's discontinued operations aggregating $11,271,000; the interest expense on the 16 1/2 percent subordinated debentures of Robert Bruce Industries, Savoy's principal operating subsidiary, aggregating about $2,846,000, and the recording of about $6.2 million of one-time reserves related to a restructuring of Robert Bruce's remaining operation and other costs.

title: How to Succeed as 'Attila the Hun'
description: After receiving advice from Lee Iacocca, Donald Trump, T. Boone Pickens and many other captains of industry and high finance, business executives will soon be receiving management tips from Attila the Hun.

title: Wallace Computer Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Television; Topical Humor From Harry Shearer
description: Nearly two weeks ago, Harry Shearer did what was called an ''HBO Comedy Hour Live.'' Actually, several of the segments were taped, but that's part of the magic of television these days. Even bits and pieces of Sunday night's ''live'' Tony Awards were taped earlier. In any case, the Shearer special is being repeated on Home Box Office, and now the whole show is taped. The difference is hardly consequential. The show, directed by Paul Miller and produced by Kevin Bright, can be seen this evening at 10:30 on the pay-cable service.

title: Lenin Faulted on State Terror, And a Soviet Taboo Is Broken
description: A leading Soviet journalist, breaking a major remaining taboo of the glasnost era, has written that Lenin personally justified the systematic use of terror in managing the Soviet state.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CPI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Apple Buys Software Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had purchased Orion Network Systems Inc., a small company in Berkeley, Calif., that makes software allowing non-I.B.M. computers to communicate over networks with I.B.M. machines. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Royal Way With Wayward Animals
description: ''ALL my life I've been obsessed with suffering. Obsessed!'' Her Serene and declamatory

title: Baseball; INDIANS WIN ON HOMER IN 9TH
description: Cory Snyder hit a game-winning, two-run home run in the ninth inning tonight to give the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. Carmen Castillo, pinch-hitting, led off the ninth with an infield single against David Wells (3-3) and Snyder followed with his 12th home run.

title: HG Magazine Is Not What It Used to Be
description: Fashion watchers have dubbed it ''House & Garment.'' A Manhattan decorator calls it ''Hot Gossip.'' And people in interior design, fashion, advertising, architecture and publishing aren't sure what to make of HG, the Conde Nast magazine formerly known as House & Garden.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about Anne Henderson Pollard, a Federal prisoner, misstated the charges against her. She pleaded guilty to conspiracy to receive embezzled Government property and to being an accessory to the possession of military documents by her husband, Jonathan Pollard. She was never charged with espionage.

title: Reviews/Music; Vibraphones and Jazz Improvisations
description: The Vibration Industrial Park, a group of four vibraphonists - Damon Choice, Khan Jamal, Bryan Carrott and Wilson Moorman 3d - plus a rhythm section of Oscar Brown Jr. on bass and Dennis Charles on drums, began its debut performance at the Knitting Factory on Sunday night in canon. One ostinato followed another until all four vibraphonists created a golden, circular wall of sound. Out of the background emerged the soloists, one vibraphonist after another, and what had been a piece influenced by African music, using the vibraphones as percussion instruments, slowly changed into jazz.

title: North Korea Out In Table Tennis
description: North Korea has forfeited its spots in men's and women's table tennis at the Summer Olympics, the International Table Tennis Federation said today.

title: Life After Cavendish, or, Yes, We Have Plenty of Bananas
description: ABOUT 75 miles north of Los Angeles, in a tiny town called La Conchita just across the Ventura Freeway from the crashing waves of the Pacific Ocean, an inconspicuous sign announces the site of Richardson's Seaside Banana Gardens. If you look quickly as you travel down the freeway, you will see what looks like a jungle forest in the making.

title: Speaker Wright's Ghostly Ethics
description: At first blush, news that House Speaker Jim Wright relied on a staff member to help write a book adds little to an already compelling case for an Ethics Committee investigation of several charges. Even Newt Gingrich, the Speaker's severest House critic, hesitates to make an issue of ghostwriting courtesy of the taxpayers.

title: Innovations: A Hat, a Cart And a Watch
description: Not every innovation from the San Francisco Bay Area is a microchip or bioengineered protein.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The S.E.C. has authorized charges against Drexel Burnham Lambert for securities law violations, according to people with knowledge of the investigation. Ivan F. Boesky, who is now in jail after his conviction in an insider trading scheme, is said to have been involved in 14 of the 18 Drexel deals that concern the S.E.C. [ Page D1. ] Chances have improved for passage of a second trade bill if the Senate, as expected, upholds President Reagan's veto of the original legislation, lawmakers and lobbyists said. The second bill would eliminate for the provision requiring 60 days' notice of layoffs. [ D1. ] Americans are anxious about both the nation's economy and their own ability to achieve long-term financial goals, a survey for a financial planners' group showed. [ D5. ] Americans increased their installment borrowing in April. [ D2. ] Bank earnings are rebounding from their worst year since the Depression in every region except the Southwest. [ D9. ] The U.S. faces another crisis in its space-launching capability because of the shortage of a rocket-fuel ingredient. [ A1. ] COMPANIES A court set aside a contempt order against Eastern Airlines -an order that has prevented the airline from transferring its shuttle operation to Texas Air, its parent company. [ D1. ] Texaco plans to buy back nearly $1.7 billion of its stock before year's end. [ D1. ] Members of the divided Gucci family have sold almost 50 percent of the retailer to a Middle Eastern investment firm. [ D9. ] Coniston Partners holds a 4.9 percent stake in Macmillan, which is fending off a hostile bid from the Bass Group. [ D20. ] Kirk Kerkorian might sell parts of MGM/UA Communications and distribute the proceeds to shareholders. [ D20. ] McKesson agreed to sell its wine and spirits wholesale division to a new company. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL Oil prices appear unlikely to rise soon, many experts say. This conclusion comes as oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries prepare for their midyear meeting. [ D5. ] All of Antarctica will be opened to regulated development of its natural resources under a 33-nation pact. [ A1. ] MARKETS Stock prices retreated broadly and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.62 points, to 2,054.59. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed as traders awaited Government reports. [ D16. ] The dollar finished slightly lower. Gold prices also fell, dropping $2.90 an ounce, to $460, on New York's Comex. [ D18. ] Soybean and grain prices closed mixed. Still, the Commodity Research Bureau's index rose 0.79, to 260.31. [ D18. ] TECHNOLOGY Engineers are creating giant ''backward batteries'' to fight corrosion of steel supporting bridges and highways. [ D8. ] Not all innovations from the San Francisco Bay Area are microchips or bioengineered proteins. There are also hard hats. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The use of lower capital gains taxes as a way to channel cash into more productive investments has received a lift from a new Treasury study. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The improving relationship between Washington and Moscow has further depressed the stocks of military contractors, a market sector that was already out of favor. [ D10. ]

title: Old Dominion Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Co-operative Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,770,000 from a partial distribution from the share insurance fund of the Co-operative Central Bank for both the quarter and year, and gains on the sale of securities of $2,002,000 for the quarter and $2,998,000 for the year.

title: Boxing; Hearns Questions His Tactics
description: When he got to his room at the Las Vegas Hilton late Monday night, Thomas Hearns posed an anguished question.

title: CALIFORNIA AND JERSEY PUSH DUKAKIS OVER TOP AS DEMOCRATS' NOMINEE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts clinched the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday with sweeping victories over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the primaries of New Jersey, California, Montana and New Mexico.

title: An Unlikely Success in Scotch
description: This verdant glen in the Scottish Highlands, hard by the River Spey, is where the world's top-selling single-malt whisky, Glenfiddich, is produced. That gives tiny Dufftown a starring role in one of the most unlikely marketing success stories of the 1980's.

title: Five-Year Offering From Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $800 million of debentures, due on June 10, 1993, through various securities dealers.

title: Pope Shifts Brazilian Church to Right
description: Pope John Paul II is quietly using his authority to name new cardinals and bishops as a way of reasserting Vatican control over Brazil's powerful and outspoken Roman Catholic hierarchy, church experts here say.

title: Soybean and Grain Prices End Mixed in Profit Taking
description: Soybean and grain prices closed mixed yesterday as many speculators who had cleared large profits during the recent strong advance cashed in some of their gains.

title: Brooklyn Teen-Ager Arrested In Shooting of a 4-Year-Old
description: A teen-ager was charged last night in the shooting Monday of a 4-year-old boy caught in the middle of a drug-related gun battle in a Brooklyn housing project, the police said.

title: Suit Against Cigarette Makers Goes to Jersey Jury
description: The jury began deliberations today in a four-month trial of three tobacco companies accused of causing the lung-cancer death of a smoker by leading her to believe that their cigarettes would not harm her health.

title: On the Prowl in the Bronx For Authentic Tastes of Italy
description: MARCELLA HAZAN, the cookbook author and teacher, is an expert on Italian foods, and her experience has made her a sharp comparison shopper. In New York, where she sometimes holds classes, and in Venice and Bologna, where she runs her cooking schools, she prowls the markets for quality and value in fish, produce, cheeses, meats and groceries.

title: Koch Bid for Tax Rise Is Opposed
description: The New York City Board of Estimate joined the City Council yesterday in defying Mayor Koch's request for a $150 million increase in property taxes to balance the city's 1989 operating budget.

title: Kit Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Tug Strike: Blow to a Shrinking Business
description: Hank Goldhorn's wives all gave him the same ultimatum: ''It's me or your silly boat.'' Now in the process of separating from his fifth wife, Mr. Goldhorn says the women never stood a chance.

title: St. Louis Evaluates Its Pioneer Integration Plan
description: Five years ago, St. Louis pioneered a metropolitanwide school desegregation plan that tried to fuse the predominantly black and poor inner city with 16 mostly white and wealthy suburbs.

title: Israel Studying a 2d Rubber-Bullet Incident
description: The army said today that it was investigating reports that a 9-month-old Palestinian girl lost an eye in a clash between Israeli soldiers and demonstrators in the occupied Gaza Strip. The report came a week after another infant was shot in the eye with rubber bullets.

title: Paraguay Official Linked to Assault in U.S.
description: A Paraguayan official and six other men here for the General Assembly's special session on disarmament assaulted demonstrators who were protesting against Paraguay's military Government near the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Monday evening, officials at the United States Mission to the United Nations said today.

title: Orlando Arena Gets More Funds
description: City commissioners have approved another $9.7 million to complete an arena in time for their new professional basketball team, bringing the cost of the project to $99.4 million.

title: 57 Sirens Fail as Lilco Tests A Shoreham Evacuation Plan
description: Fifty-seven of the Long Island Lighting Company's 89 warning sirens failed to sound today as the utility began a drill of its emergency plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Errors by Chicago Air Controllers Prompt Inquiry by U.S. at O'Hare
description: Reacting to three errors in two days by air traffic controllers in Chicago, the National Transportation Safety Board decided yesterday to dispatch a special team to investigate the persistent problem.

title: If the Girl's Own Mother Won't Testify
description: Should Glenda Brawley go to jail for contempt of court? It's the wrong question. Her behavior is surely contemptuous, hostile to achieving justice in the case of her daughter, Tawana, who says she was the victim of racial attack last November in Dutchess County, New York.

title: In U.S., Vintage Era for Foreign Investors
description: WHAT do you like in California wines? How about a zinfandel from the Otsuka Pharmaceutical Company? Or a cabernet from the Minami Kyushi Coca-Cola Bottling Company? What about a nice Alexander Valley pinot noir from A. Rake of West Germany, or a rich chardonnay from those Thai wine specialists, Four Seas Investing?

title: Review/Theater; A Clash of Different Shades of Red
description: When Josip Sulka, the Soviet boss of a Communist-controlled island in the Caribbean, challenges Frederick Cassidy, an imprisoned Roman Catholic writer, to an ideology-to-ideology encounter - ''my faith against your faith'' - the audience at ''Resistance'' may reasonably expect a duel of mind and spirit, along the lines of Arthur Koestler or Graham Greene. But D. Keith Mano's play, now at the Judith Anderson Theater, does not deliver on the promise of its premise. As the three prison cells that dominate the stage are filled with Cassidy's son, wife, mistress and illegitimate daughter (along with a formidable mass murderer, unrelated to Cassidy or, indeed, to the plot), the work races this way and that as if attempting to evade the central conflict.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Pride and Peril
description: Soldiers and police officers wounded in gun battles are fond of keeping the bullets that struck them down as souvenirs of the scrapes with death. Institutions apparently experience the same urge.

title: A Wall Street Greeting For Unocal's New Chief
description: Richard J. Stegemeier has served as Wall Street's window into the Unocal Corporation ever since becoming president and chief operating officer of the nation's 12th-largest oil company in 1985.

title: Article 946788 -- No Title
description: With little more than a week remaining before Carl C. Icahn takes on Texaco Inc. in a proxy fight at its annual stockholders meeting, the company announced yesterday that it would spend nearly $1.7 billion, only part of it in cash, to buy back stock by year's end.

title: Bonneville Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said its share earnings for the latest year is in line with the change in the original projection of 85 cents made earlier in the year. It said the change in projection resulted from a decision to retain ownership in four projects originally to be sold for a one-time development fee.

title: First Central Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shoney's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 8
Bush and Dukakis Spar Over Issue Of Who Is the Better Conservative
description: In a preview of coming attractions, George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis appeared today at an ABC television forum and argued, in spirited back-to-back interviews, about who better embodies conservative principles.

title: For 2 Cousins, Breaking Bread Means Sharing Memories
description: SOME fathers leave their sons money. The fathers of Marvin Korman and Jess Korman left them a passion for bread.

title: Seymour Ellis, 71, a Retired Restaurateur
description: Seymour Ellis, a retired New York restaurateur, died of heart failure May 25 at his retirement home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 71 years old and had lived for many years in Stamford, Conn.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amfac Inc., San Francisco, which is involved in food, retail and hotel businesses, said its board had approved the previously announced sale of its Monterey Mushrooms division for about $30 million.

title: McKesson to Sell Liquor Division
description: The McKesson Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its McKesson Wine and Spirits wholesale division to a new company formed by the unit's management and Weiss, Peck & Greer, an investment firm in New York.

title: Testing Doesn't Make a Drug Program
description: To the Editor:

title: James W. Moore, 65, Education Dept. Aide
description: James W. Moore, who in the 1960's pioneered the College Work-Study and Guaranteed Student Loan programs at the United States Department of Education, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Lake Oswego, Ore. He was 65 years old.

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
For Houses of Worship, Long History as Havens
description: The tradition of turning to churches and synagogues for refuge in time of danger is as old as the Bible.

title: Mr. Duarte's Hardest Fight
description: Jose Napoleon Duarte, El Salvador's President, has fought hard against many tough opponents. Now he battles stomach cancer in a Washington hospital, yet another cruel uphill test. While it is too soon for a final assessment, it is a fit time to recall some real achievements.

title: Firstcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $245,000 for both the quarter and year. The latest year's earnings include those of Durham's (N.C.) First Federal Savings & Loan Association for the 6 months ended March 31.

title: Swedish Justice Chief Quits Over Inquiry on Palme Death
description: Justice Minister Anna-Greta Leijon resigned today over a secret investigation she authorized in the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme. The resignation averted a confidence vote that threatened to bring down the Government.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CONE'S STREAK STOPPED
description: In a dashing display of rabbit baseball, the St. Louis Cardinals stole six bases tonight, outran and outscored the Mets, 4-1, and ended David Cone's undefeated season and seven-game winning streak.

title: Girls' Participation in Sports Improves
description: Not long ago, girls were called tomboys if they played with boys or even played at what were considered boys' games.

title: Mother of Brawley To Seek Sanctuary, Family Advisers Say
description: Tawana Brawley's mother, defying a contempt citation as she had earlier resisted a subpoena, will seek sanctuary this morning in a church in New York City to avoid arrest for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating her daughter's case, the family's representatives said yesterday.

title: Pretoria Reports 7 Dead in Strike
description: With a three-day national protest strike by more than a million black workers in its second day, the South African Government said today that seven people had been killed in violence on the first day of the strike.

title: Sports People; Woodward Dismissed
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, in last place in the National League East, dismissed their personnel director, Woody Woodward, and the farm director, Jim Baumer, yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; First 'Giselle' From Ballet Theater
description: Amanda McKerrow, Ross Stretton, Cynthia Anderson and Clark Tippet were on the side of the angels Monday night when they filled the first ''Giselle'' of American Ballet Theater's season with fresh and fascinating fantasy.

title: Group Discloses Sun Electric Stake
description: S.O.Q. Partners, a partnership of American and British investors, said it owned a 6 percent stake in the Sun Electric Corporation and was seeking to meet with the company's management. D. Barry Davis, the chairman, president and chief executive of Sun Electric, quickly responded that the company was not interested in a transaction with S.O.Q.

title: SOME INDIA TROOPS LEAVING SRI LANKA
description: India began withdrawing a small contingent of its more than 50,000 troops from Sri Lanka today, declaring it was justified by recent gains in quelling the Tamil insurgency on the island.

title: Alfin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3,527,000 for the quarter and $5,949,000 for the 9 months.

title: 'Nurturing Network' Supports Middle-Class Unwed Mothers
description: Marjorie, a 26-year-old college student two courses short of her bachelor's degree, thought she had nowhere to go when she became pregnant a year ago. Her boyfriend initially was not supportive, she said. While her family tried to understand, Marjorie believed that her situation would damage the reputation of her father, a Presbyterian minister in a big Minnesota city.

title: AT ARAB SUMMIT, CALLS FOR UNITY
description: An Arab summit meeting opened tonight with a strong appeal for Arab unity and support for the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Top Colleges Turn to Waiting Lists
description: In marked contrast to last year, many selective colleges and universities are turning to their waiting lists to fill their entering freshman classes.

title: On Eve of Primary, Drilling Plan Is Delayed
description: In a political gesture to Vice President Bush on the eve of the California primary, the Interior Department said Monday night that it would temporarily suspend plans to lease 1.1 million acres off the Northern California coast for oil and gas exploration.

title: Washington Talk: Education Aid; Quest for Solutions to Defaults on Student Loans
description: First the Internal Revenue Service was ordered to withhold tax refunds from people who defaulted on federally guaranteed student loans. Then the Education Department got stern with the banks, ordering them to demonstrate ''due diligence'' in seeking repayment of student loans. Next, Congress passed a law allowing the Government to sell defaulted loans to collection agencies.

title: With Discipline, Not Dazzle, Dukakis Outlasts His Rivals
description: As he flew across the country Sunday night, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was pressed to reflect on the intensity of the moment, two days before the primaries that he expected to seal his hold on the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Bellow Papers Bring a Record at Auction
description: The notebooks, typescript and all papers relating to Saul Bellow's ''Mr. Sammler's Planet,'' were sold yesterday at Sotheby's for $66,000, a record at auction for a work by a living author. The archive of the novel, published in 1970, was the first manuscript material sold by Mr. Bellow.

title: Gucci Family, Split by Feud, Sells Large Stake in Retailer
description: Members of the Gucci family of Italy, split by bitter fights for control of their high-fashion retail empire, have sold nearly a 50 percent interest in Guccio Gucci S.p.A. to a Middle Eastern investment banking firm.

title: Yields at 5% to 6.85% Range On Ohio Highway Bonds
description: The debt market remains uncertain about the course of interest rates and many institutional and retail investors have been buying shorter- and medium-term bond issues, instead of issues with longer maturities.

title: Topics of The Times; Wrong Population Message
description: For the same strained reason, the U.S. Agency for International Development has again decided to withhold its contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. It contends that the fund supports coerced abortions in China.

title: First Team Sports reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said the prior year figures include the period from May 9, 1986, when the company was incorporated, through Feb. 28, 1987.

title: Sports People; Retirement Announced
description: Wayne Duke announced yesterday that he would retire as Big Ten commissioner at the end of next year after running the athletic conference since 1971. He plans to serve as a consultant to the Big Ten after leaving his post.

title: Kirkpatrick and Vance Joust
description: Two longtime ideological sparring partners, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick and Cyrus R. Vance, found themselves at opposite ends of a New York podium Monday night for a spirited dialogue on foreign policy - what it is and what it should be.

title: First Federal Savings of Aransas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the losses are after provisions for losses of $45,657,000 in the latest quarter and $47,617,000 for the 6 months, and $2,305,000 and $3,853,000 for the year- ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Central Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $2,849,000 from a one-time liquidating dividend from the Co-operative Central Bank share insurance fund. The bank coverted to stock form of ownership in October 1986.

title: MGM/UA Parts for Sale
description: Kirk Kerkorian, who controls the MGM/UA Communications Company, disclosed yesterday that he might sell parts of company and distribute the proceeds to shareholders.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Brian Bellows, a right wing who had 81 points with the Minnesota North Stars last season, signed a multiyear contract with the team. Terms were not disclosed. . . . Julius Erving, the former star of the Philadelphia 76ers who has garnered many awards for his work with young people, received another one last night. He was honored as the man of the year by the Catholic Big Brothers of New York at a dinner at Tavern-on-the-Green.(AP)

title: Review Set for Devils
description: When it convenes in Montreal for its annual meeting later this week, the National Hockey League plans to review the disobedience of both the New Jersey Devils and the referees and linesmen during the playoffs May 8. The Devils used a State Supreme Court injunction to defy a league-ordered suspension of Coach Jim Schoenfeld and the officials staged a one-game walkout in protest of the Devils' actions.

title: Big Law Firm To Help Poor In Civil Cases
description: In the largest program of its kind, a New York law firm announced yesterday that it would establish a $10 million fellowship program to place lawyers in legal-assistance organizations throughout the United States.

title: The Belmont; Granacus Is Long on Appeal
description: Kentuckians root for a horse raised in their bluegrass to win the Derby, and Baltimoreans find the Preakness sweeter when a Maryland-bred is the winner. There are no New York-breds in the Belmont Stakes Saturday, but perhaps Granacus should be adopted as the hometown horse. The colt has absolutely no local connections, but he is as much of a melting pot in throughbred racing as New York City is for the world.

title: Gamma Biologicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Car Bombing Kills 4 In Southern Beirut; 2 Syrians Wounded
description: A car bomb exploded today in the predominantly Shiite Moslem southern suburbs of Beirut, killing 4 people and wounding at least 20 more, including 2 Syrian soldiers.

title: A Good Idea Gone Sour: Savings Talent on Loan
description: When Federal regulators developed a plan three years ago to allow the most troubled savings and loan institutions to continue operating under executives borrowed from well-run institutions, everyone agreed it was a good idea.

title: KEY RATES
Sports People; Drug Arrest in Japan
description: Dick Davis, an infielder for the Kintetsu Buffaloes and a former major league player, was arrested yesterday on charges of violating Japanese drug laws.

title: Fred Freeman, Graphic Artist, Dies at 81
description: Fred Freeman, a graphic artist who designed and illustrated books on naval history, space exploration and other subjects, died Monday of a heart attack at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middlesex, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: U.S. Reported in Touch With Iran on Hostages
description: The United States, Britain and West Germany have initiated direct contacts with the Iranians in an effort to free foreign hostages in Lebanon, The Times of London reported today.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $1,271,000. Preferred dividend adjustments exceeded net income in the latest first quarter.

title: Lessons
description: The problem with teachers, a wise educator once observed, is that too many of them have one arrow in their quiver of techniques. They give a lesson and hope that the student gets it. If not, that is too bad. The teacher does not try to get the point across in a different way by shooting a second arrow.

title: Board Leader to Run Against Ohrenstein
description: The chairman of a community board in midtown Manhattan announced yesterday that he would challenge the renomination of Manfred Ohrenstein, a state Senator for 28 years and Senate Democratic leader for 14.

title: Bridge
description: Two strong teams battled down to the wire Saturday in the final of the prestigious Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, played at the Cavendish Club, 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Becker and Connors Advance: Back on the grass surface he thrives on, Boris Becker was back in the groove yesterday, serving and volleying his way to victory in the first round of the $385,000 Stella Artois championships at London's Queens Club. Becker took only 58 minutes to rout Charlton Eagle, 6-1, 6-3. Jimmy Connors, Becker's projected semifinal opponent, also thrived on being back on the grass in his first competitive match in seven weeks. The 35-year-old American, who withdrew from the French Open because of a foot injury, defeated a countryman, Mel Purcell, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Reis Posts Upset: Ronni Reis, a 22-year-old American just out of the University of Miami, came back to upset ninth-seeded Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union, 2-6, 7-6, 6-1, in the second round of the Dow ChemClassic women's tournament yesterday at Birmingham, England. In other matches in the grass-court Wimbledon tune-up tournament, fourth-seeded Zina Garrison beat a fellow American, Heather Ludloff, 6-1, 6-2, but Wendy White was upset by Dinky van Rensburg of South Africa, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3.(AP) Jaite Leads Advance: Martin Jaite and Alberto Mancini of Argentina, Juan Aguilera of Spain and Ulf Stenlund of Sweden qualified for the second round of the $99,000 Bologna tournament in Italy. They were among the players who completed first-round matches ahead of a rainstorm that stopped further action.(AP) Cycling Hampsten Keeps Overall Lead: Franco Vona of Italy beat eight other cyclists by four seconds, including the overall leader, Andrew Hampsten, to win the 16th stage of the Tour of Italy race, which crossed the border into the Austrian city of Innsbruck. The 26-year-old Hampsten, of Boulder, Colo., retained the pink jersey as the overall leader for the third straight day as he finished seventh in the stage. Hampsten, who can become the first American ever to win the ''Giro,'' held an advantage of 42 seconds over all on Eric Breukink of the Netherlands. Vona covered the 109-mile distance from Merano to Innsbruck in 5 hours 15 minutes 7 seconds, at an average speed of 21 miles an hour.(AP) New Zealander Wins: Graeme Miller of New Zealand scored his second consecutive stage victory, but Ivan Ivanov of the Soviet Union maintained his overall lead in the Milk Race in Sheffield, England. In the 64-mile stage from Barnsley, Miller finished 55 seconds ahead of Yvan Waddell of Canada. Ivanov stayed in front over all, 4 minutes ahead of Britain's Dave Rayner. (AP) Road Racing Schlett Is First: Stefan Schlett of West Germany won the Sri Chimnoy 1,300-mile race in Flushing Meadow Park. Schlett and Trishal Cherns of Vail, Colo., were the only runners in the original field of eight who finished the 18-day event. During that time, the runners attempted to complete an average of more than 72 miles per day. Schlett completed 1,172 miles, short of the record of 1,250 set last year by Marty Sprengelmeyer of Davenport, Iowa. Cherns finished with 1,051 miles. (AP) Golf Updegraff Leads: Dr. Ed Updegraff of Tucson, Ariz., playing through heavy winds, managed a one-over-par 73 yesterday for the low round of the day and the lead in one of seven age classifications in the first round of the 84th United States Seniors Golf Association tournament. The tournament, which involves 440 players and concludes today, is taking place at three sites: The Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y., the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, Conn., and the Blind Brook Club in Purchase, N.Y. Updegraff, who played at Apawamis, holds a two-shot edge over William Patton of Mimona Hills in the 65-69 age group. In the youngest group, 55-59, Eli Tullis of Seminole holds a one-stroke lead with a 75, and Fred Woodley of San Antonio is one shot ahead of the field in the 60-64 classification. William Zimmerman of Green Island, who shot 74 for the second low round of the day, stands atop the 70-74 group by three shots. Miller Fails: Johnny Miller, the 1973 champion when he shot a final round of 63, failed to reach this year's United States Open when he shot a 71-75-146 in the sectional qualifying at the Old Oaks Country Club and Century Country Club, both in Purchase, N.Y. A field of 114, including 12 amateurs, competed for 21 places for the Open, June 16-19 at The Country Club, Brookline, Mass. Ken Green of Molokai, Hawaii, was the top qualifier with a 66-69-135, one stroke better than Darrell Kestner (68-68) of Sunningdale Country Club, Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jim Hallett (67-69), South Yarmouth, Mass.

title: New Political Synthesis
description: President Francois Mitterrand stole a march on his vanquished opponents after his re-election to a second seven-year term last month. He had run on a promise of ''opening to the center'' and ''uniting France.'' But he won so handsomely that he used his power to dissolve the Assembly, where the conservatives had won a majority in 1986.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in very light trading yesterday.

title: MILLER STILL CHASING DREAM
description: There were no ropes along the fairways, no galleries, no news media waiting to follow Johnny Miller around the course at the Century Golf Club this morning. He was just one of 113 amateur and struggling professional players attempting to win one of 21 berths at a sectional qualifying tournament in advance of next week's United States Open in Brookline, Mass.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Ex-Unisys Executive To Head Intel Venture
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it and Siemens A.G. had formed an international computer systems company that will be headed by Joseph J. Kroger, former vice chairman of the Unisys Corporation.

title: Soviets Send Three Into Space
description: Two Soviet astronauts and a Bulgarian rocketed into space today, headed to a space station on the first manned flight of 1988.

title: Quinn to Get Yankee Job
description: The Yankees are expected to announce the realignment of their front office today by naming Bob Quinn as their general manager and defining the role of Lou Piniella, who resigned from the position nearly two weeks ago in a surprising announcement.

title: Consumer Debt Grew In April at Slower Rate
description: Americans increased their installment borrowing at a moderate annual rate of 7 percent in April as growth in consumer credit slowed from the first three months of the year.

title: A Woodsy 'Hamptons' In Corner of Connecticut
description: In the last few years, Connecticut's rural Northwest Corner has attracted so many weekenders that they now own, as second homes, half the houses in some towns and nearly a third in the region.

title: Sports People; Wicks Leaves Camp
description: Sue Wicks of Rutgers, the college player of the year in women's basketball, has left a United States Olympic team mini-camp for personal reasons, according to Rutgers officials.

title:
EDUCATION;
About Education
description: LEAD: Behind the pomp and circumstance of commencements, human responses and special footnotes speak to the moment in time.

title: About New York; 90 Subdued Years Of Funerals For the Famous
description: Quietly (and how!), Frank E. Campbell, ''The Funeral Chapel Inc.,'' the city's undertaker to the stars, is celebrating its 90th anniversary this year. It's a hushed affair. There will be, according to an official, ''no formal celebration, no formal acknowledgement'' outside the building at 81st and Madison - and not much within.

title: E.P.A. Tentatively Approves Testing Banned Pesticides in Homes
description: The Environmental Protection Agency quietly and tentatively approved a plan last month that would allow an Illinois chemical company to test two banned insecticides at 200 houses around the country, agency officials confirmed today.

title: Optimism Greets 4th Round of Contra Talks
description: Contra leaders arrived in Managua today and began a fourth round of peace talks that some politicians say could produce an accord with the Sandinista Government.

title: DENMARK AGREES ON NUCLEAR POLICY
description: Denmark and the United States have resolved their dispute about whether NATO ships armed with nuclear weapons can visit Danish ports, officials of both countries announced today.

title: NEWS SUMMARYQuotation of the Day
description: International A3-15

title: Bank Earnings Recover in U.S.
description: Earnings at the nation's commercial banks are rebounding from the worst year since the Depression in every region except the Southwest.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Pistons Top Lakers To Lead Series, 1-0
description: While it wouldn't be completely accurate to say that the Lakers were taking the Pistons lightly, the defending champions seemed for the last couple of days to be talking through the Pistons, as if they were some abstract obstacle between the Lakers and a second consecutive championship.

title: Long Island Faces a Financial Meltdown
description: The shortsighted decision to abandon the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island before it produced even a single watt of commercial power means that businesses and consumers will be stuck paying for much of the $5.3 billion facility for years to come.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Tribute to Mandela

title: First Columbia Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Layoffs at Foley's
description: Foley's Department Stores said it would lay off 5 percent of its work force, or about 800 employees. Foley's, which was acquired last month by the May Department Stores Company, said the layoffs would affect executives as well as hourly workers. ''It's an attempt to get our operating costs down,'' said Dan Hagan, a Foley's vice president. The chain has about 16,000 employees in 39 stores in Texas, Arizona, New Mexico and Oklahoma. May, based in St. Louis, bought Foley's and 18 Filene's stores from Federated Department Stores Inc. last month after the Campeau Corporation acquired the chain.

title: Court Rules For Eastern On Shuttle
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday set aside a contempt order against Eastern Airlines - an order that has prevented the airline from transferring its shuttle operation to its parent, the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Dallas Times Herald Sale
description: W. Dean Singleton, chief executive of Media News Holdings Inc., announced today that his company had agreed to sell The Dallas Times Herald to a new company led by the newspaper's publisher, John Buzzetta.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 12 headed ''Two Forks Journal'' misstated a provision of the Denver Water Department's budget for the proposed Two Forks Dam project. It has allowed about $48 million for environmental mitigation (not litigation), to deal with wildlife and recreation activities affected by the dam.

title: Citicorp Rates Down at Sale
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper fell yesterday for the first time in more than a month.

title: New York G.O.P. Picks Lawyer for Senate Race
description: Robert R. McMillan, a Republican fund-raiser and lawyer, was nominated yesterday for the United States Senate by the New York Republican Party.

title: As He Leaves, Anderson Appears to Be at Peace
description: Warren M. Anderson's law office seems not so much a place of business as a den of Republicanism. Reagan and Rockefeller and Dewey stare down from the walls, the inscriptions on their pictures beginning ''To Warren'' or ''To Andy.''

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,685,000 from an accounting change. The company said the latest first quarter sales includes new store sales and a decrease of 7 percent in comparable store sales.

title: People Found Anxious On Economy and Goals
description: Americans are anxious about both the nation's economy and their own ability to achieve long-term financial goals, a survey released yesterday by the International Association for Financial Planning showed.

title: Control Data in India
description: The Indian Government has signed an agreement with the Control Data Corporation for the company to manufacture its mainframe Cyber 930 computer in India, the United News of India reported this week. The pact was signed by K.P.P. Nambiar, secretary of the Electronics Ministry, during a recent visit to the United States.

title: COUNCILMAN WINS IN RODINO DISTRICT
description: Donald M. Payne, who twice challenged Peter W. Rodino in New Jersey's 10th Congressional District, became the retiring Congressman's heir apparent yesterday when he won the district's Democratic nomination.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the results for the latest quarter were adversely affected by a general slowdown in consumer spending, a highly promotional environment that affected sales and gross margin, and additional expenses connected with the acquisition of the Casey & Osh Stores.

title: Broadway Producers From Project To Commission Plays by Americans
description: David Henry Hwang. Christopher Durang. Marsha Norman. David Rabe. Wendy Wasserstein. Terrence McNally.

title: DEVELOPMENT SEEN FOR THE MINERALS OF ALL ANTARCTICA
description: Concluding 6 years of difficult negotiations, 33 nations have agreed to open all of Antarctica to regulated development of its oil and mineral resources, according to American participants in the talks.

title: Sports People; Spurs Dismiss Weiss
description: Bob Weiss was dismissed as coach of the San Antonio Spurs yesterday after two straight losing seasons.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Caught in Red Square
description: Toward the end of the Moscow summit meeting, Tony Dolan, the proudly conservative White House speechwriter, slipped out to Red Square for a final peek at the gilded onion towers of St. Basil's Cathedral.

title: Schools' Back-to-Basics Drive Found to Be Working in Math
description: The back-to-basics movement in education that began in the 1970's has succeeded in assuring that almost every American high school graduate can handle simple mathematics, new testing data released yesterday suggest.

title: Eating Well
description: LEAD: A POP quiz: What are Escherichia coli, staphylococcus and salmonella? No, not toga-clad characters in a ''Masterpiece Theater'' series. They are bacteria, and they might be uninvited guests at your next picnic or barbecue if you don't heed some simple rules of warm-weather food handling.

title: The Modern Helps a Brazilian Sister
description: When fire swept through the Museum of Modern Art here early one morning in July 1978, it destroyed not only 900 works of art but also one of the few centers of artistic and political expression that had managed to survive 14 years of rightist military rule in Brazil.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about charges against a writer and a minister involved in the illegal entry of two Salvadoran women into the United States misstated the role of the writer, Demetria Martinez. Ms. Martinez knew about the entry and wrote about it; she did not arrange the trip.

title: Ueberroth Refuses a 2d Term
description: Peter Ueberroth, whose future as the commmissioner of baseball has been uncertain after more than three and a half years in office, said yesterday that he would not accept a second five-year term when the first one expires Dec. 31, 1989.

title: Montclair Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Per share earnings for 1987 were not available because the company was not a stock institution during the comparable periods.

title: Trial Opens for 5 in Foster Home Fire
description: Five Queens residents heard a prosecutor describe them in court yesterday as arsonists who set fire to a neighboring house where the city planned to open a foster-care home for babies.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: MELVIN N. PORETZ of Merrick, L.I., was on a Madison Avenue bus not long ago when guess who he should see standing in the rear of the very same vehicle: Abe Beame, the former mayor. Mr. Poretz had just been talking about Mr. Beame at lunch at the N.Y.U. Club, but what surprised Mr. Poretz was that the man whose job was once described as the second most important elective office in the United States was now standing - standing! - on a bus in the city he had once led.

title: Earlier Black Bishop
description: To the Editor:

title: Once There Was Passion
