description: The 20th anniversary of Robert Kennedy's murder has set flocks of aging journalists to sentimentalizing about their pasts. Beware old men reminiscing about their lost youth, especially if they are journalists. The codger's normal wail for the passing of the good old days is insufficient to gratify the journalist's habit of turning inconsequential happenings into momentous events. An old journalist looking back on his youth is not content to sorrow for the passing of the good old days; he must lament the death of a golden age when giants strode across his ken, and men dreamed nobler dreams than are dreamed today and glory was still possible in the land.

title: Real Estate; Doubleday Leaseback Deal on L.I.
description: SINCE 1910 an 18-acre enclave on the main commercial strip in Garden City, L.I., has been home to Doubleday & Company. But within the next few months the publishing company's status at the Franklin Avenue office park, which looks more like an estate than a place of business, will change from owner to tenant.

title: A Pained Lucas Ponders Attacks on 'Willow'
description: The thick sweet scent of lilacs was everywhere on Skywalker Ranch, but it could not mask the sour taste that reviews of his new movie had left in George Lucas's mouth. ''When someone says you're 'The Great Regurgitator,' it's painful,'' Mr. Lucas said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Gucci Ads Set In Serial Form
description: Tomorrow, through an insert in Women's Wear Daily, the trade will get a preview of a love story that consumers won't begin to see until fall.

title: Nigeria Seeks Fare Cuts
description: Nigeria has ordered two airlines, Swissair and Lufthansa, to cancel immediately their increased fares on flights from Lagos, official and aviation sources said today. The Swiss and West German carriers last month raised fares by about 300 percent on some routes to compensate for the devaluation of Nigeria's currency.

title: Crack-Den j'Secretary' Tells How a Murder Was Planned
description: A 17-year-old girl testified yesterday that a group of young men discussed ways of murdering a taxi dispatcher who had appeared before a grand jury, and described how one man aimed a shotgun at the floor and pretended to shoot the woman.

title: Talking Deals; The Perot Thorn In G.M.'s Side
description: WHEN the General Motors Corporation got rid of H. Ross Perot in late 1986 by buying back his G.M. class E stock for more than $700 million, the company hoped it would be free of headaches brought on by the Dallas billionaire.

title: Review/Television; Lives of Women in Prison
description: One of Fox Broadcasting's more peculiar contributions to prime-time culture has been the series called ''Women in Prison,'' a sitcom crammed with lovably tough, wisecracking good-time gals who seemingly found life behind bars a bit of a hoot. The laugh track had a pronounced male heartiness, heavy on the ''har, har, har'' kind of guffaw peculiar to mud-wrestling matches. Some viewers found the incarceration antics hilarious in their unabashed vulgarity. Those same viewers might take a look at tonight's edition of ''Currents'' on Channel 13 at 8:30. With Marlene Sanders as host, the program examines ''Women Doing Time.''

title: Soybeans and Grain Plunge, Touching Off Other Declines
description: Futures prices of soybeans, bean products and most grains plunged yesterday, setting off broad and steep declines in precious metals and most other major commodities markets.

title: A Widening Range of Choices
description: Approximate effectiveness of these reversible methods of birth control is measured in pregnancies per 100 actual users per year. DEVICE: Intrauterine devices (Paragard Copper T380A, Progestasert) ACTION: Small plastic or metal devices placed in the uterus that somehow prevent fertilization or implantation; some contain copper, others release hormones. FAILURE RATES: 1-5 ADVANTAGES: Convenient, highly effective, need to be replaced infrequently. DISADVANTAGES: Can cause excess menstrual bleeding and pain; danger of perforation, infection and expulsion; not recommended for those who are childless, not monogamous, or who have had pelvic inflammatory disease; dangerous in pregnancy. DEVICE: Oral contraceptives ACTION: Hormones, either in combination or progestin only, that primarily prevent release of egg. FAILURE RATES: 1-10, depending on type ADVANTAGES: Convenient and highly effective; provide significant noncontraceptive health benefits, such as protection against ovarian and endometrial cancers. DISADVANTAGES: Pills must be taken regularly; possible minor side effects, which new formulations have reduced; not for women with cardiovascular risks, mostly those over 35 who smoke. DEVICE: Condom ACTION: Thin rubber sheath for penis that collects semen. FAILURE RATES: 3-15 ADVANTAGES: Easy to use, effective and inexpensive; protects against some sexually transmitted diseases. DISADVANTAGES: Requires male cooperation, may diminish spontaneity, may deteriorate on the shelf. DEVICE: Diaphragm ACTION: Soft rubber cup that covers entrance to uterus, prevents sperm from reaching egg and holds spermicide. FAILURE RATES: 4-25 ADVANTAGES: No dangerous side effects; reliable if used properly; provides some protection against sexually transmitted diseases and cervical cancer. DISADVANTAGES: Requires careful fitting; some in convenience associated with insertion and removal; may be dislodged during sex. DEVICE: Cervical cap ACTION: Miniature diaphragm that covers cervix closely, prevents sperm from reaching egg and holds spermicide. FAILURE RATES: Probably comparable to diaphragm. ADVANTAGES: No dangerous side effects; fairly effective; can remain in place longer than diaphragm. DISADVANTAGES: Problems with fitting and insertion; comes in limited number of sizes. DEVICE: Foams, creams, jellies, vaginal suppositories ACTION: Chemical spermicides inserted in vagina before intercourse that also prevent sperm from entering uterus. FAILURE RATES: 10-25 ADVANTAGES: Can be used by anyone who is not allergic; protect against some sexually transmitted diseases; no known side effects. DISADVANTAGES: Relatively unreliable, sometimes messy; must be used 5 to 10 minutes before each act of intercourse. DEVICE: Sponge ACTION: Acts as sperm barrier and releases spermicide. FAILURE RATES: 15-30 ADVANTAGES: Safe; easy to insert; provides some protection against sexually transmitted diseases; can be left in place for 24 hours; needs no fitting. DISADVANTAGES: Relatively unreliable; comes in only one size; some sensitivity and removal problems; cannot be used during menstruation. DEVICE: Implant (Norplant) Not available as birth control in U.S. ACTION: Capsules surgically implanted under skin that slowly release a hormone that blocks release of eggs. FAILURE RATES: 0.3 ADVANTAGES: Very safe, convenient and effective; very long-lasting (five years); may have non-reproductive health benefits like those of oral contraceptives. DISADVANTAGES: Irregular or absent periods; necessity of minor surgical procedure to insert and remove. DEVICE: Injectable contraceptive (Depo-Provera) Unavailable in U.S. ACTION: Injection every three-months of a hormone slowly released from the muscle that prevents ovulation. FAILURE RATES: 1 ADVANTAGES: Convenient and highly effective; no serious side effects other than occasional heavy menstrual bleeding. DISADVANTAGES: Animal studies suggest that it may cause cancer, though new studies of women are mostly encouraging. Sources: Population Crisis Committee, Alan Guttmacher Institute, American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

title: Racing Notebook; Horseless Carriages in Winner's Circle
description: Corporate sponsorship of racing reached a zenith of intrusiveness yesterday when five new automobiles were positioned at Belmont Park in honor of Saturday's featured race: the final leg of the Chrysler Triple Crown Challenge, better known as the Belmont Stakes.

title: At Ellis I., Tracking 17 Million Names
description: The estimated 100 million Americans whose relatives arrived in the United States at Ellis Island will be able to instantly trace their history at a new computerized geneological center planned for the restored immigration site.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a computer problem, the trading volume for Pacific Gas and Electric Company's stock is incorrect in today's New York Stock Exchange list, the N.Y.S.E. most-active list and the table of Dow Jones averages that shows the volume of component stocks. The actual number of Pacific

title: U.S. Support of Dollar Falls
description: The United States Government intervened in currency markets to buy a total of $818 million to support the dollar in the three months ended April 30, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Pan Am's Board Backs Asset Selloff
description: Adding pressure to get union concessions, the board of directors of Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had authorized management to sell some of the airline's assets if no agreements were reached.

title: 5 Workers at Texas Refinery Injured in Fire and Explosion
description: An explosion and fire injured five employees at a Chevron refinery plant today, the authorities said.

title: Nairobi Slum: Urbanization As a Cancer
description: The steady drift in Africa from rural areas to cities often ends in places like Mathare Valley, a sprawling slum of rock-bottom poverty where roads of mud and sewage appear to lead nowhere.

title: Fire Destroys 12 Stores On a Mt. Vernon Street
description: A general-alarm fire swept through a dozen stores on East Third Street in Mount Vernon last night, collapsing a wall and sending flames through the roof, officials said.

title: TCS Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Arnell Bickford Wins A Revlon Assignment
description: The Arnell Bickford agency has picked up an assignment from Revlon to promote a merchandising concept called The Nines (as in ''dressing to the nines'') that will involve department and specialty stores and a number of its brands.

title: Health: Birth Control; U.S. Experts Applaud Growth in Options For Contraception
description: Experts on birth control are buoyed by the introduction of two newly available contraceptives in the United States and by plans to seek Federal approval to market two more. They say that they hope this is a harbinger of a new era when Americans have available a wider array of contraceptive choices.

title: South Africa Mobilizes Reserves Over Angola
description: South Africa announced tonight that its armed forces had begun a limited mobilization of citizen reserves in response to a reported build-up of Cuban-backed Angolan troops north of the Angolan border with South-West Africa.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS DUKAKIS DISTORTS ECONOMIC PICTURE
description: Less than 24 hours after Michael S. Dukakis clinched the Democratic Presidential nomination, the Republicans turned their most powerful weapon against him yesterday when President Reagan assailed the Massachusetts Governor, charging that he distorted reality by painting economic conditions as unhealthy.

title: A Family Commitment: Auctions and Antiques
description: ON an outing to Manhattan for a Broadway show and a dinner with his editorial staff, which is also his family, R. Scudder Smith issued a warning. The first person to mention The Bee would have to get out of the car. He meant it, and no one - not his wife, Helen, nor their two children nor their spouses - breathed a story idea or a headline.

title: Review/Pop; Improvising With Parade As Paradigm
description: Joe Zawinul loves a parade: the way it's heard from afar, marches into view and finally wends its way down the road. As Weather Report's keyboardist and co-leader from 1971 to 1985 and now with the six-piece Zawinul Syndicate, he has often written pieces to that pattern. The beat, which might come from any continent, coalesces, struts or dances, then moves on; melodies appear in bits and pieces, then unfold to full-length tunes. That framework opens up jazz-rock for improvisation from top to bottom, and for most of Monday's late set at the Bottom Line, finishing a two-night stand, the Zawinul Syndicate's music was a swirl of exhilaration.

title: Irregulars in the Drug War
description: It took the crack dealers, operating from a rundown apartment, only a few weeks to destroy any sense of tranquillity on the block. The stream of customers - hollow stares and torn jeans, gold nameplates and hundred-dollar sneakers, three-piece suits and blow-dried hair - came from all over the city. Muggings and burglaries increased. Sirens interrupted sleep. Now and then, so did sounds of gunfire. But it was a less dramatic development that most infuriated the neighbors: With the crush of strange cars arriving at all hours, it had become impossible to find a parking place.

title: AIDS UNCERTAINTY VOICED IN REPORT
description: Seven years after the reporting of the first case of AIDS in the United States, it remains impossible to determine whether the virus that causes it is spreading significantly into the heterosexual population, according to a new assessment published in Nature, a leading British scientific journal.

title: Yields Rise In Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all up for the week ended yesterday. But analysts said that the modest rise in bank rates that began May 11, after an increase of half a percentage point in the prime lending rate, might be ending.

title: But Are They Leaders?
description: It's only nominal news that Michael Dukakis has won the Democratic nomination. Practically speaking, the Republican campaign ended in March and the Democratic outcome was sealed in April in New York. The news is not that the primaries are over but that the fall campaign has already begun.

title: Bridge
description: A partnership from the Philadelphia area headed the field of 84,000 pairs in the Worldwide Epson contest last Friday.

title: London House Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
McClain Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Contra Disarray Impedes Nicaragua Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: MITTERRAND, BREAKING SILENCE, ASKS VOTERS FOR SOLID MAJORITY
description: With the Socialists increasingly concerned about their prospects in Sunday's legislative elections, President Francois Mitterrand appealed today for a solid parliamentary majority to match his own triumphant re-election last month.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tyco Planning to Use Bozell Agency Again
description: A couple of months ago Tyco Industries, the toy company based in Mount Laurel, N.J., left its agency, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in Los Angeles, because it was just too far away since Tyco had become a year-round advertiser.

title: U.S. Judge Orders Separate Trials For 4 on Iran-Contra Conspiracy
description: The judge in the Iran-contra conspiracy case ruled today that Oliver L. North, John M. Poindexter and two co-defendants must be tried separately.

title: PALESTINIAN YOUTH DIES IN ISRAEL CARE
description: A 19-year-old Palestinian died in an Israeli hospital this morning, and his family asserted that soldiers had beaten him to death.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

United Tote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $207,862 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CSR Ltd., Sydney, Australia, a sugar and building materials group, said its purchase of Rinker Materials Corp. had put it into a position to grow in the United States.

title: Word From the Aegean: A Dukakis Groundswell
description: The main road through this island village, a 10-foot wide cement-and-dirt track formerly known as St. George's Street, has just been renamed Michael Dukakis Street. The signposts are written in both English and Greek.

title: The Vote Count in Tuesday's Primaries
Stunned by 3 Killings in 5 Days, Stamford Cites Growing Drug Crisis
description: For officials of this Fairfield County city, three murders in five days are a startling coincidence, underscoring a growing problem with drug trafficking at a time when the police force has been strengthened and drug arrests are up sharply.

title: Delegate Tally
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. DEMOCRATS

title: Gulf & Western Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The net income for both latest periods included a net gain of $4.8 million from the sale of the company's 30 percent interest in a video cassette duplication business. The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 2, 1988.

title: A Victor in Jersey's Primary: From Coach to Congress Race
description: More than anything else, it was his response to coaching a losing football team at South Side - now Shabazz - High School in the late 1950's that set Donald M. Payne on the path that could lead him to become New Jersey's first black Congressman.

title: Service for Photographer
description: A memorial service for David B. Eisendrath, an industrial photographer, lecturer and writer, will take place on Tuesday at 4 P.M. at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. Mr. Eisendrath died May 2 at the age of 73. Photographers and those in related businesses are expected to speak at the service, including George Tames, Burt Keppler, Martin Forscher, Ben Fernandez, Charles Reynolds, Harry Amdur, Yvonne Halsman and Norman C. Lipton. The service is open to the public.

title: SOVIET AIDE INVITES TREATY OBSERVERS
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze invited international representatives today to witness the destruction of Soviet intermediate-range missiles under the recently concluded treaty with the United States.

title: Sports of The Times; When Art and Life Collide in the World of Sports
description: THE absolute best thing on television for the past year has not been a sitcom or a news special or a talk show. The best thing on television has been a commercial for one of the beer companies.

title: A Wild Splash of Perennials, for Balance
description: I HAVE read a couple of articles about gardening lately, praising annuals by damning perennials, and I'm puzzled by the notion that it's a question of one versus the other. Such partisanship is perhaps understandable on the part of a local nursery that sells petunias and other annuals as bedding plants, but I don't see its value for a gardener.

title: Group to Buy Stake In 2d Spanish Bank
description: A consortium of Spanish and Kuwaiti investors that holds a stake in one leading Spanish bank said it was buying 2 percent of the bank's prospective merger partner, Banco Espanol de Credito. Cartera Central, a company set up by the Spanish building group Construcciones y Contratas S.A. and the Kuwait Investment Office, is already the largest shareholder in Banco Central, with a 13.1 percent stake.

title: Fellow Democrats Fight Cuomo's Cuts for Budget
description: Two days after Governor Cuomo proposed $400 million in spending cuts to help close the state's budget gap, legislators from his own party today attacked the cuts as too concentrated on social services.

title: Sara Lee to Bid For Pannill
description: In a new effort to expand its non-food operations, the Sara Lee Corporation late today announced moves aimed at gaining control of the Pannill Knitting Company, a sportswear manufacturer and distributor.

title: Dukakis Aims to End G.O.P. Presidential Grip on New Jersey
description: New Jersey, which no Democratic Presidential candidate has carried since 1964, has become a testing ground for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and his hopes of shepherding back the stray Democrats who helped send Ronald Reagan to the White House for eight years.

title: How Students Learn To Understand Death
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; BASF Assigns Job To Leo Burnett
description: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago has been given the domestic advertising assignment for BASF audio and video tapes, the advertising for which is already being done by Burnett abroad. Billings are not known.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL SESSION ON DISARMAMENT - COMMITTEE OF WHOLE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. WORKING GROUP DRAFTING CONVENTION PROTECTING MIGRANT WORKERS' RIGHTS - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Health; New Drug Therapies Are Being Tested to Help Smokers Quit
description: As evidence of the health hazards of smoking becomes indisputable and the social pressure to stop smoking increases, researchers are developing new drug therapies to help smokers, especially those who have tried many times but failed to quit the habit.

title: Ban This Missile From the Seas
description: The cruise missile, about 18 feet long and with a 104-inch wingspread, erupts from a torpedo tube of the attack submarine Los Angeles. It bursts from the sea 500 nautical miles from the coast and, skimming above the water at 550 miles per hour, reaches land in just under an hour.

title: Columbus Circle, in Balance
description: Boston Properties' new proposal for a building on Columbus Circle in New York City shows balance, grace and respect for the city around it. Those who continue to debate the project owe it the same courtesies.

title: Robert-Mark Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: Shakespeare in Park To Begin on June 24
description: The free Shakespeare in the Park series will begin on June 24 with performances of ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' starring Kevin Kline, Blythe Danner, Brian Murray, Jerry Stiller and Phoebe Cates. The production of ''Much Ado,'' which is being directed by Gerald Freedman and is being set in Sicily in the early 19th century, is the fourth in the festival's three-year undertaking to produce all 36 of Shakespeare's plays.

title: Washington Talk: Capitol Hill; Counterattacking G.O.P. Sees a Campaign Issue: Jim Wright
description: For months the Republicans have been suffering from what the Democrats call the ''sleaze factor'': the ethical problems of some of President Reagan's closest friends and aides, including Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. Now the Republicans think they have found the ideal target for a counterattack in Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Local groups, rebuffing the Kremlin and the leadership of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, have apparently chosen delegates to a key Soviet Communist Party meeting mostly from their own conservative ranks. Page A1

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for 6 percent stock dividend distributed in November 1987.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 11 about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York misstated the percentage of his 1986 election victory. In the final tally, the Senator, a Republican, received 56.9 percent of the votes. The record margin of victory for a Republican in a statewide election in New York was 57.4 percent won by Senator Jacob K. Javits in 1962.

title: Unico Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Confession Set In VW Fraud
description: A West German foreign exchange broker suspected of masterminding a currency swindle that cost Volkswagen A.G. $280 million will confess his involvement, a lawyer representing the broker said today.

title: Navajos to Build Plant for Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said the Navajo Indian tribe would build an electronics assembly plant for its weapon systems subsidiary near Farmington, N.M. The 30,000-square-foot factory will be constructed on tribal lands in a Navajo agricultural products industrial park and will be leased by General Dynamics for 15 years, the company said. Since 1967, General Dynamics has had a plant at Fort Defiance, Ariz., which is in the Navajo reservation.

title: After the Intifada
description: The Israelis have finally figured out a way to contain the Palestinian Intifada, or Uprising, in the disputed territories: arrests and detention; a few deportations; and mainly an economic squeeze that creates dissension among demonstrators.

title: The Firearms the Second Amendment Protects; Stop Police Dumdums
description: To the Editor:

title: Total Votes Cast In 37 Primaries
description: Unofficial vote count, with 99.4 percent of Democratic precincts reporting, and 99.9 percent reporting for Republicans. DEMOCRATS Dukakis 9,727,083 (42.5%) Jackson 6,707,199 (29.3%) Gore 3,135,523 (13.7%) Gephardt 1,315,027 (5.7%) Simon 1,079,473 (4.7%) Hart 405,467 (1.8%) Babbitt 87,497 (0.4%) Others 216,961 (0.9%) Uncomm. 228,688 (1.0%) REPUBLICANS Bush 8,124,979 (67.9%) Dole 2,306,244 (19.3%) Robertson 1,051,936 (8.8%) Kemp 323,833 (2.7%) Du Pont 49,855 (0.4%) Haig 26,818 (0.2%) Others 6,739 (0.1%) Uncomm. 69,719 (0.6%) Source: The Associated Press

title: Case and Gandalf
description: The data communications company Case Group P.L.C. repeated its rejection of a hostile takeover bid of $:58 million ($105.6 million United States) from Canada's Gandalf Technologies. Case said Gandalf's formal document relating to the offer, issued Tuesday, did nothing to change its initial view. Case said the offer significantly undervalued the company and the future of its business. It added that Gandalf had nothing meaningful to contribute to Case in terms of management, technology or business or financial position.

title: Isco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Handbags, Linings And Shoulder Straps
description: A WOMAN'S pocketbook is not something to be treated lightly. ''Women are very serious about their handbags,'' said Ronald Price. He ought to know: he has been in the handbag business for 30 years. He is also, with Donald Moore, a co-owner of Artbag Creations, a company that has been manufacturing, repairing and selling handbags since 1932.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The May Department Stores Company is offering $600 million of debt securities in a three-part financing through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Remembrances, Fans and Songs At a Memorial for George Rose
description: In words and music, with laughter and personal anecdotes, Broadway paid tribute to George Rose yesterday morning.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Victoria's Secret Goes To FCB/Leber Katz
description: Victoria's Secret, a chain of lingerie shops, has retained FCB/Leber Katz Partners to do its advertising as well as supplying brand development and marketing communications. The budget has not been set, but the client is promising ''multimillions.'' Dollars, that is.

title: Handleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
German Beer Tax Fight
description: West German brewers said today that they would fight proposals to bring beer taxes throughout the European Community into agreement because they would lead to higher prices in West Germany. ''We reject these proposals totally,'' Dieter Soltmann, president of the West German Brewers Association, said. He said that the West German beer tax faced an increase of 145 percent.

title: Golf; Ballesteros Chasing a Dream
description: Seve Ballesteros, who relinquished his PGA Tour membership three years ago because he refused to play the required minimum of 15 tournaments a year in the United States, said today he might return to a 15-event schedule in America next year.

title: Lawyers in Brawley Case Look Beyond Their Client
description: Editorials question their defiant posture in the Tawana Brawley case. Cartoons depict them as buffoons. Former allies in the civil rights struggle raise doubts publicly and privately about their competence and their motives. And professional disciplinary panels investigate their behavior.

title: Architects in All but Name, 13,000 Cram for Their Big Exam
description: ''NO death doors,'' Patrick S. Raspante told his class of nervous would-be architects. ''Don't design doors that open onto corridors and clobber the people who are walking by.''

title: Shopsmith Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $100,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: Violence Erupts in Korea Over March North
description: Thousands of protesters battled the riot police today, hurling firebombs and rocks, as the Government began deploying 60,000 policemen to stop students from marching to the border with North Korea.

title: Sale of Paper In Knoxville
description: A Hawaiian company has agreed to buy The Knoxville Journal, one of the city's two daily newspapers, The Journal said today.

title: The Firearms the Second Amendment Protects; A Seven-Day Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Sholomir, Stunt Man, 57
description: Jack Sholomir, a stunt man who appeared in more than 30 motion pictures, including three James Bond movies, died of a heart attack last Wednesday. He was 57 years old.

title: Borland International reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The year 1987 was restated for the retroactive adoption of FAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes and pooling of interest. Borland's stock is publicly traded on the unlisted securities market of the London Stock Exchange.

title: Deposits Rise At Saving Units
description: Net deposits at the 3,113 federally insured savings and loan associations increased in April by $1.2 billion, to $962.4 billion, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. It was the seventh consecutive monthly increase. Deposit growth slowed in

title: Ambrit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $299,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $413,000 from discontinued operations. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago period. Ambrit said the latest quarter included a pre-tax gain of about $7.1 million from the settlement of litigation with Kraft Inc.

title: Pepper Ploy: U.S. Combats Begonia Thief
description: A Federal law-enforcement official has devised a plan he hopes will foil the Begonia Bandit of Brooklyn. He intends to plant mainly hot green peppers and bush tomatoes outside the Federal Courthouse for the Eastern District of New York.

title: Treasury Issues Advance Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were up sharply in active trading yesterday as market participants took heart from a drop in commodity prices and comments about the dollar by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman.

title: Lemieux Named League M.V.P.
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins' Mario Lemieux ended Wayne Gretzky's eight-year reign as the National Hockey League's most valuable player when he was awarded the Hart Trophy tonight.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Portrait of the Voters on 2 Coasts
PARENT & CHILD
description: WITHIN a few weeks thousands of parents will receive a tear-stained letter or a telephone call from a small choked-up voice saying something like this: ''I'm miserable. Everyone at camp hates me. I want to come home!''

title: Buffalo Don's Artesian Wells reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Net loss

title: 48.36 Jump Puts Dow At 2,102.95
description: LEAD: Stock prices surged broadly in heavy trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,100, its highest point since April 13.

title: General Cinema Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,855,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $910,000 for the quarter and $1,896,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter and 6 months included the results of Neiman-Marcus Group on a consolidated basis. General Cinema owns 50 percent of Neiman-Marcus common and 100 percent of its 6 percent preferred stock.

title: 2d Youth Charged in Shooting Of Boy, 4, Caught in Crossfire
description: A second teen-ager was charged last night in the shooting Monday of a 4-year-old boy who was caught in the middle of a drug-related gun battle in a Brooklyn housing project, the police said.

title: TV Notes
description: Father-Son Story

title: New York City Schools Have a Few Success Stories to Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error in editing, an article yesterday about the growing popularity of Northwestern Connecticut as a weekend residence was omitted from pages B1 and B6 in some copies. The article is reprinted today on page B9.

title: Orbital Sciences Head Looks to Bright Future
description: David W. Thompson, president of the Orbital Sciences Corporation, says he has been interested in rockets since he was a youth and saw the Soviet Union's first Sputnik satellite in the night sky. Today, his company is perfecting a system to launch rockets from an airplane to put small satellites in orbit.

title: French Plan to Forgive Africa Debt
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that France would cancel one-third of the debt owed it by sub-Saharan countries and urged the industrial world to do the same.

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: AS anyone who has them can tell you, children have a certain strange contrary streak. Nowhere is this more evident than in their ability to put you on the spot when you least expect it and are not dressed for it. If you are having an hour of quiet and introspective time with your little boy, reading with him on the couch and discussing this and that - as will happen perhaps every eight or nine years - his most probing question is likely to be, ''But how come I can't have chocolate chip cookies for breakfast?''

title: VATICAN DELEGATION CARRIES LETTER FROM POPE TO GORBACHEV
description: A high-level delegation of Vatican officials flew to Moscow today for a major religious celebration, carrying a letter from Pope John Paul II to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Vatican officials said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: LDI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a non-recurring benefit of $1,450,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: 180 INMATES FREED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Nearly 200 inmates were released from crowded city prisons here today as a result of an order from Federal appellate court.

title: Russell Harty, Talk-Show Host, 54
description: Russell Harty, a writer and broadcaster who became one of Britain's top television talk-show hosts, died of liver failure caused by hepatitis on Wednesday, according to a statement from St. James University Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: House Passes Bill Limiting Commercials in Children's TV
description: The House of Representatives yesterday passed a bill that would limit the number of commercials in children's television programs and require broadcasters to provide educational and informational programming for children as a condition of license renewal.

title: HOUSE REJECTS BILL ON LONGTERM HOME HEALTH CARE
description: Capping an emotional election year debate, the House of Representatives today rejected a bill that would provide Federal funds for longterm home health care for 32 million Medicare beneficiaries, as well as disabled children.

title: Suzuki Defending Samurai Against Safety Complaints
description: A week after Consumer Reports magazine judged the Samurai utility vehicle ''not acceptable'' and urged that it be recalled, the Suzuki Motor Company is poised to strike back with its own test analyses and a new advertising campaign in support of its contention that its vehicle is safe.

title: U.S. to Urge Allies to Use East Bloc Loans as Lever
description: The United States is telling its NATO allies that they should not provide loans or other financial help to Eastern Europe unless countries there first make political changes to replace authoritarian rule with democracy.

title: Bank of New York Begins A New Offensive on Irving
description: Faced with legal fights that have delayed its hostile bid for the Irving Bank Corporation, the Bank of New York Company began a new offensive yesterday, writing letters to New York State's banking regulators and the Federal Reserve Board to urge that they deny the application of Banca Commerciale Italiana, which has the support of Irving's management.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Vice Presidency is not quite the top, but it's a long way from where I started.'' - The Rev. Jesse Jackson. [ B10:2. ]

title: Murray Says It Has Takeover Options
description: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company disclosed that it was holding talks with unidentified parties concerning possible alternatives to a $52-a-share offer from Sweden's A. B. Electrolux. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Murray Ohio said it ''is in the preliminary stages of negotiation'' concerning a combination or recapitalization.

title: 'Crocodile Dundee II' Top Film at Box Office
description: ''Crocodile Dundee II'' took in $12.72 million last weekend, more than 50 percent of its nearest competitor, to run away with the box-office sweepstakes as the No. 1 movie.

title: Thomas Nelson Publishers reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $734,450 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,207,222. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,195,778 and a gain of $216,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to May 16
Soviet Drama Troupe Cancels New York Visit
description: The first American appearance by the Maly Theater of Leningrad, which was to have been a major attraction of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, opening Saturday, has been canceled.

title: Northrop's Jet Sale Plan Is Questioned
description: The Northrop Corporation, which is already enduring scandals over its work on the MX missile and the Stealth bomber, is now being rocked by questions about its efforts to sell its ill-fated F-20 fighter plane to South Korea several years ago.

title: MDI Says Holders Block Takeover
description: MDI Mobile Data International Inc. accused its two largest shareholders of collaborating to thwart a takeover attempt by Motorola Inc.'s Canadian unit. MDI Mobile's president, Barclay Isherwood, said that Glenayre Electronics Ltd. of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Lincluden Management Ltd. of Oakville, Ontario, had a ''hidden agenda'' aimed at controlling MDI.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aequitron Medical Inc., Minneapolis, a maker of medical electronic equipment, said George A. Jackson, chairman, president and chief executive, plans to resign. He will remain chairman until a successor is named. He will then continue as a director.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: As more Americans turn to unorthodox remedies and preventive medicines, the Food and Drug Administration has begun an accelerated campaign against quackery, which the agency defines as ''the promotion of false or unproven products or therapies for profit.''

title: New York City Schools Have a Few Success Stories to Tell; What Makes a Magnet
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Expects Vote on Grants
description: Dick Schultz, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's executive director, said today he expected the Southeastern Conference, which recently decided to deny athletic scholarships to academic non-qualifiers, to put the issue to a national vote at the next N.C.A.A. convention, in January.

title: Britain's Maxwell Sets Deal For Educational Publisher
description: Two weeks after saying that ''unacceptably high'' prices for publishing companies had cooled his interest in deals in the United States, Robert Maxwell, the British publishing entrepreneur, announced yesterday that he would acquire Science Research Associates for around $150 million.

title: Murdoch TV Expansion
description: News International P.L.C., a unit of Rupert Murdoch's Australian-based News Corporation, today announced a substantial expansion of its European satellite television interests.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; For Services Rendered
description: As chief American negotiator of the new missile accord, Maynard W. Glitman spent countless hours dealing with the Russians in Geneva. Then he spent months in Washington trying to assure Senate approval of the pact.

title: Talks on Beef Might Resume
description: The United States and Japan will probably resume negotiations on beef and citrus trade next week in Tokyo, United States trade officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday, about a survey of girls' athletic participation, characterized a figure incorrectly in some editions in discussing girls 15 to 18 years old. The 75 percent figure referred to girls who said they do participate.

title: U.S. Rescinds Rights to Bid
description: The Defense Department took away the right to bid on military work from 284 contractors because of wrongdoing during the first half of the current fiscal year, according to a Pentagon report released today.

title: At the End of the Road, Yet Jackson Promises to Continue His Journey
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson refused today to concede the Democratic Presidential nomination to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, saying he would fight on to the convention to try to win party rules changes, platform positions and perhaps even the Vice Presidency.

title: Monsanto to Pay $1.5 Million in Poisoning Case
description: Monsanto has agreed to a $1.5 million settlement in a huge chemical poisoning case filed by more than 170 former plant workers, lawyers said today.

title: A Wilderness 45 Miles From Broadway
description: WITH aplogies to George M. Cohan, I have been fishing, hiking and hunting this spring in a little island of wilderness that may be a bit more than 45 minutes from Broadway, but is no more than 45 airline miles away.

title: Staley Head to Remain
description: Robert M. Powers will remain president of the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company under its new owner, Tate & Lyle P.L.C., the British sugar refiner that took control last month in a $1.49 billion deal. Mr. Powers joined Staley in 1958 as a research chemist and became president in 1980. Tate & Lyle also plans to move Staley's headquarters, now in Rolling Meadows, Ill., back to Decatur, where it was founded in the 1920's.

title: Report on Foreign Bank-Insider Ties Backed
description: The nation's top securities regulator agreed today with a Congressional report that warned of the growing use of foreign bank accounts to mask illegal insider trading.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Connors and Becker Advance: Jimmy Connors and Boris Becker, the third- and fourth-seeded players, struggled into the third round of the $385,000 Stella Artois championship at the Queen's Club in London yesterday. Becker, the Wimbledon champion in 1985 and 1986, came from a set down to overcome Scott Davis of the United States, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4.

title: Arizonan Says He Didn't Seek to Break Law in Mecham Loan
description: The developer who gave former Gov. Evan Mecham a $350,000 campaign loan testified today that, although he wanted it kept confidential, he never sought to violate campaign finance reporting requirements.

title: Boxng; Tyson-Spinks Goes Round and Round
description: A dispute arose today over how many rounds the June 27 heavyweight title fight between Mike Tyson and Michael Spinks should have - 12 or 15.

title: U.S. Denies Making Contact With Teheran Over Hostages
description: The United States denied today that it had opened new contacts with Iran about American hostages.

title: Sports People; Giants Trade Leonard
description: The San Francisco Giants yesterday traded the outfielder Jeffrey Leonard to the Milwaukee Brewers for Ernest Riles, an infielder..

title: Sports People; Bol Traded for Feitl
description: The Washington Bullets yesterday traded Manute Bol, their 7-foot-6-inch reserve center, to the Golden State Warriors for Dave Feitl, who is also a center, and a 1989 second-round draft choice.

title: Sports People; Chaney Considered
description: There is also an opening for a basketball coach in Houston since the Rockets dismissed Bill Fitch Monday. Five or six candidates have emerged, but the favorite seems to be Don Chaney, an assistant coach with the Atlanta Hawks. Ray Patterson, the Houston general manager, told The Houston Post yesterday that the Rockets have been in touch with the 41-year-old Chaney, who was a defensive standout as a guard with the Boston Celtics and who coached the Los Angeles Clippers for more than two seasons. (AP)

title: Olympics; Swimmer Tests an International Rule
description: West Germany is ready to name Jens-Peter Berndt, the swimmer who defected from East Germany to the United States in 1985, to its team for the Olympic Games in September in Seoul, South Korea. However, East Germany seems likely to protest, and the matter probably will be settled by the highest decision-making authority of the Olympic movement, the International Olympic Committee's executive board.

title: Israel Says Troops on Patrol Kill 3 Guerrillas in Lebanon
description: Israeli soldiers killed three guerrillas in southeastern Lebanon on Wednesday at the edge of the six-mile-deep security zone set up by Israel to prevent attacks on its northern border, the army said. It said no Israelis were wounded in the clash.

title: Weekenders Alter the Yankee Flavor Of a Woodsy Corner of Connecticut
description: In the last few years, Connecticut's rural Northwest Corner has attracted so many weekenders that they now own, as second homes, half the houses in some towns and nearly a third in the region.

title: Milk Program Assessed
description: More than $1 billion in Federal payments to farmers, aimed at reducing milk surpluses, merely caused a temporary leveling off of production, according to a report from the General Accounting Office. ''While the program contracted to remove almost 9 percent from annual milk production, nonparticipating dairy farmers continued to increase their production,'' the report by the Congressional investigative agency said. It said that in 1986, the first year of the dairy termination program, or whole-herd buyout as it is sometimes called, production actually increased by a fraction of 1 percent from the 1985 level.

title: Paris Opera Treasures at Cooper-Hewitt
description: LEAD: A glimpse of the opulent Paris Opera may be seen through Sept. 25 at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan. The exhibition, ''The Paris Opera on Stage: Designs, Costumes, Jewels,'' offers a rare look at hundreds of treasures from the opera house, its wardrobe and its museum.

title: Senate Upholds Veto; New Trade Bill Sought
description: The Senate today upheld President Reagan's veto of a sweeping trade bill, and Congressional leaders immediately began to work on new legislation that might be introduced in the House as early as next week.

title: 8 From Contaminated Town Lose Illness Suit
description: A jury has rejected contentions by eight former residents of a chemically contaminated town that dioxin in oil sprayed on the streets had made them ill.

title: Sports People; Reds Deal Rasmussen
description: The Cincinnati Reds traded the struggling left-handed starter, Dennis Rasmussen, to San Diego yesterday, just hours before he was supposed to start against the Padres.

title: Books of The Times; Smoking Case Is Closed but Testimony Continues
description: Merchants of Death The American Tobacco Industry By Larry C. White 240 pages. Beech Tree/William Morrow. $17.95.

title: CORNUCOPIA OF HERESIES BURSTS INTO SOVIET PRESS
description: Here are a few thoughts on how to make the Soviet Union more democratic: Curb the powers of the K.G.B. Abolish the system of internal passports. Create new political organizations to compete with the Communist Party. Publish the party's secret budget. Print transcripts of meetings of the ruling Politburo.

title: Raw Dead Rats
description: The C.I.A. trained Honduran soldiers in ways to make political suspects talk: Keep them naked in prison, give them raw dead animals to eat . . . Going beyond such ''psychological'' methods, the Hondurans tortured many to death. U.S. officials knew what was happening, but they mostly looked the other way.

title: Metro Matters; Racial Steering As Official Policy, Not as a Crime
description: Q. Do you know what the term ''phases,'' in the context of the New York City Housing Authority, means?

title: Local Leaders Rebuff Backers Of Gorbachev
description: Local Communist Party organizations across the Soviet Union, resisting the wishes of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, appear to have picked delegates to a key party meeting later this month mostly from their own orthodox leadership ranks.

title: Cyril Issac Magnin, 88, Ex-Head Of Store Chain and Patron of Arts
description: Cyril Issac Magnin, a former department store tycoon whose dedication to promoting this city and its performing arts earned him the title of ''Mr. San Francisco,'' died of cardiac failure here today after five weeks of hospitalization at the University of California Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived here.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hennessy Stays With Lord, Geller
description: YESTERDAY it was Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein's turn to get some much-needed good news. After a review, Hennessy Cognac, its first account assignment 20 years ago, has decided to keep its $8 million account at the agency.

title: Judge Orders Visas for Four
description: A judge has ordered the Government to grant visas to the Nicaraguan Interior Minister and three others barred from the country because of Communist affiliations. Judge Harold H. Greene of Federal District Court, ruling on Tuesday, said Interior Minister Tomas Borge, two Cuban officials and a former Italian senator should be admitted to accept speaking engagements. He reversed a finding that had been set aside by an appeals court. The American Civil Liberties Union argued that to bar someone, the State Department must determine that proposed activities in the visit pose a danger.

title: Iraq Demands Oil Quota Rise
description: Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, said today that Iraq would not back down from its demand for a petroleum output quota equal to Iran's.

title: Review/Music; How 'The Phantom' Plays in Tokyo
description: The world of Andrew Lloyd Webber's flossy but spectacular musicals has expanded from the West End and Broadway to far, far beyond. Productions of ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ''Evita,'' ''Cats,'' ''Starlight Express,'' ''The Phantom of the Opera'' and other hits by the British composer now circle the planet, appearing with startling frequency in Japan, Australia, Europe and South America as well as in many North American cities.

title: ARAB CHIEFS REBUFF P.L.O. ON UPRISING
description: Arab leaders rebuffed the Palestine Liberation Organization today by declining to extend substantial new financial aid to support the upheaval in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Friends at the Top
description: With friends in the right places, it's amazing what you can get done in Washington - or Moscow, as Kenneth M. Duberstein, President Reagan's deputy chief of staff, established last week when he asked his boss for a favor.

title: If He Can't Buy It, He'll Make It
description: THAT an object is one of a kind doesn't faze Paul Fuhrman. His custom fabricating plant in Allentown, Pa., reproduces nearly anything dating from as early as the turn of the century.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the rejection of a proposal by Walter Cronkite for a prime-time special on the 25th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy attributed the decision incorrectly in some editions.

title: Greenspan Sees Harm If Dollar Falls Further
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that a further decline in the dollar's value would not help improve the nation's trade deficit.

title: Two Juries Are Chosen In Howard Beach Trial
description: Jury selection was completed yesterday for the second trial in the Howard Beach racial-attack case, and opening arguments were scheduled for next Monday in State Supreme Court in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Beijing Sends Out Police to Thwart Student Protest
description: The authorities sent hundreds of policemen onto the streets of the capital today to thwart a threatened protest march by Beijing University students to the city center.

title: Supreme Equipment & Sysems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $161,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after a reversal of a tax credit of $95,000. d-After a tax credit of $336,000.

title: Cards' 3-Run 7th Topples Mets
description: Well, at least the St. Louis Cardinals didn't steal any bases tonight. But they did run and hit and peck away, they teased home three runs off Roger McDowell in the seventh inning and for the second straight time they beat the Mets, 5-2.

title: U.S. Agency Cuts Aid to New York Public Library
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities, reversing a 16-year partnership with the New York Public Library, has drastically reduced its financing in 1989 for the activities of the research libraries - the heart of the institution - and says it may continue to do so in the future.

title: Hijacked to Hartford
description: LEAD: At noon, the 9:30 A.M. Pan Am shuttle from New York's La Guardia Airport was still circling over Boston's fogged-in Logan Airport. Three times, the pilot had announced that he was going in for a landing. But nothing happened, except for a lot of seat belt-buckling - and more circling.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Group Offers 5 Premieres
description: The Catskill Chamber Players, a flexibly deployed ensemble from the Catskill Conservatory in Oneonta, N.Y., came to Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening with five works listed as New York premieres. Among them were two relics, Lou Harrison's Serenade in C (1949) and Henry Cowell's Trio for Flute, Violin and Harp (1962).

title: Thor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Groupe Laperriere et Vereault Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
Super Food Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 7
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shift by UPS
description: United Parcel Service, which uses Ammirati & Puris aas its agency in the United States and Canada, has consolidated all of its international advertising in McCann-Erickson, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The size of the budget was not disclosed.

title: Sports People; Jordan Unanimous Pick
description: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, the National Basketball Association's leader in scoring and steals, was the only unanimous choice to the league's all-star team announced yesterday. Three voters from each league city and 11 members of the national news media voted for Jordan, who garnered a maximum 160 votes. Boston's Larry Bird made the first team for the ninth consecutive year, with 159 votes. The other members were Charles Barkley of Philadelphia, forward; Akeem Olajuwon of Houston, center, and Magic Johnson of the Lakers, guard.(AP)

title: Woodwork Sets a Mood for Dining
description: RARE and interesting woodwork is a design trend at some popular restaurants, and the same inventive eye, that of the architect Adam Tihany, is behind each scheme. He uses wood as his primary building medium not only because of its versatility, but because of its warmth.

title: Valley Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings for the latest 9 months and both year-ago periods are not applicable; the company converted to a stock savings bank July 15, 1987.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN the surfaces of furniture and woodwork have suffered more damage than minor repairs can cure, or when so many layers of finish have been applied that another will not adhere, the only solution is to strip the existing finish entirely and apply a new one to the bared wood.

title: College World Series; Arizona State Wins In 10th to Stay Alive
description: Arizona State, needing a victory tonight to stay alive in the College World Series, rallied for two runs in the ninth inning and scored the winning run in the 10th for a 4-3 victory over Wichita State.

title: Paula L. Zajan, Professor, 59
description: Paula L. Zajan, a professor of early childhood education at Hostos Community College, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hungary Chief to Visit U.S.
description: The new Hungarian Communist Party leader, Karoly Grosz, will visit the United States next month, Deputy Secretary of State John Whitehead said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: TREATY LEADS SIGHTSEERS TO U.S. BASE
description: The United States Air Force put its nuclear weapons on public display today at its cruise missile base here.

title: U.S. IS INVESTIGATING ERRORS BY CHICAGO AIR CONTROLLERS
description: The Government yesterday began a broad investigation of errors by air traffic controllers in Chicago, two days after an incident in which the pilot of a corporate jet says he thinks he would have hit a United Airlines jet if he had not taken sharp evasive action.

title: Macmillan Rejects Bid Of $1.9 Billion by Bass
description: Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected the investor Robert M. Bass's offer to acquire the company for $73 a share in cash, or $1.9 billion.

title: Drexel Suit Prepared By S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has authorized the filing of charges of securities law violations against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and four of its employees, Frederick H. Joseph, the chief executive, told the firm's employees yesterday.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Tom Kelly, who led the Minnesota Twins to the World Series championship last season in his first full year as a major league manager, yesterday had his contract extended through 1989. . . . Ted Fiore, who has guided the St. Peter's basketball team to two straight 20-victory seasons, signed a new five-year contract to remain head coach. The contract will run through the 1992-1993 season.(AP)

title: New York Foster-Care Rules Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday rejected efforts by Catholic and Jewish foster-care agencies to block a New York City policy limiting the role of religion in the foster-care system.

title: 6 Die in Military Plane Crash
description: A military transport plane crashed and burned in a fireball today near the Greenville airport, killing the six Air National Guardsmen aboard, authorities and witnesses said.

title: Abuna Tekle Haimanot, Ethiopian Orthodox Leader, 70
description: The Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, Abuna Tekle Haimanot, has died at the age of 70, the Ethiopian press agency reported Tuesday.

title: Race to Rescue: Police-Fire Feud Dates From the 30's
description: In New York, as in almost no other city, the Police Department dominates the Fire Department in handling emergencies and rescues, among the most valorous municipal work there is. But politics and personalities had as much to do with creating the unusual division of duties as did logic, efficiency or skill.

title: Showhouse Showcase Opens n Philadelphia
description: DESIGNER show houses are becoming a warm-weather tradition in some cities and suburban communities these days. Most are held in old houses and are organized so that each designer has one room to decorate. In Philadelphia, however, a new designer show house has allowed participants to show off their work in an entire apartment.

title: In Seven Days, Designing a New Traditional Town
description: In the beginning, the rolling countryside here, about 18 miles northwest of the United States Capitol, did not contain Red Barn Econolodges, 12-screen Cineplex Odeons or seamless subdivisions with ''Village'' in their titles.

title: G.&W. Net Rises 1.1%
description: Gulf and Western Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 1.1 percent on a 13 percent increase in revenues.

title: U.S. Economic Warfare Brings Disaster to Panama
description: The extended American confrontation with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has produced an economic disaster in Panama causing structural damage that is likely to persist whether or not the general stays in power.

title: Baseball; Indians Closing In on Yanks
description: Cory Snyder hit his 13th home run and Domingo Ramos hit a two-run single tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-2, to sweep their three-game series and move a half-game from the first-place Yankees in the American League East.

title: Utility in Virginia Marketing Bonds
description: In the competitive bond market, the Virginia Electric and Power Company, a unit of Dominion Resources Inc., awarded a $150 million bond issue to a group of underwriters headed by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Usenco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Family Tree of AIDS Viruses Is Viewed as 37 to 80 Years Old
description: The origin of human AIDS viruses in their current forms could be as recent as 40 years ago, a group of scientists have concluded after a study that may have important implications for understanding the current epidemic and the development of vaccines against the deadly disease.

title: SOQ-Sun Electric
description: SOQ Partners L.P., an investment group based in Greenwich, Conn., has raised its stake in the Sun Electric Corporation to 7.7 percent from about 6 percent. SOQ, a group of American and British investors, said in a filing Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was interested in a friendly acquisition of the concern, which designs, manufactures and markets diagnostic and service equipment for the motor vehicle industry. Later that day, Sun, based in Crystal Lake, Ill., issued a statement that it was not for sale. Its shares rose $1.125 today, to $17, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Dome's Shareholders Approve Amoco Offer
description: Shareholders of Dome Petroleum Ltd. today resoundingly approved an offer of $5.5 billion (Canadian), or $4.5 billion (United States), from the Amoco Corporation's Canadian subsidiary, clearing the way for Canada's biggest takeover.

title: Review/Recital; A Soprano In Debussy And Barber
description: Dominique Labelle, who was presented Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall as winner of the Canadian Women's Club vocal contest, has a beautiful lyric soprano voice and a sympathy for song. On the evidence of her Rossini, Schumann, Barber and Debussy here, she is not yet a fully formed artist, but she is a singer to watch.

title: Volt Information Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a $5,355,000, or 79 cents a share, gain from an accounting change. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $3,165,000 from the early redemption of 12 3/4 percent subordinated debentures for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Auto Sales Estimate Up
description: The Commerce Department expects United States auto sales, including imports, to reach 10.5 million to 10.6 million units in 1988, up from its previous forecast of 10.3 million vehicles, a department official said today. Al Warner, director of the Office of Automotive Affairs, also said the department expects the Japanese share of the United States auto market to decline to 16.7 percent in 1991. In 1987, Japanese auto makers held 20.1 percent of the United States market.

title: Judge Approves Release of Facts In Beating Case
description: The disclosure of damaging evidence against Joel B. Steinberg at a bail hearing would not deprive him of a fair trial on charges that he murdered 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg, a New York judge ruled yesterday.

title: Koch Plans To Rebuild Rusted Bridge
description: The Williamsburg Bridge, once condemned to demolition and still partly closed as a public danger, will be kept open and rebuilt at a cost of $350 million, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Baseball Notebook; A Revolving Door In Phillies' Office
description: Less than five years ago, in October 1983, the Baltimore Orioles and the Philadelphia Phillies were in the World Series. Today, they are in last place.

title: Tons of Toys reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AUDI OFFERS CASH TO SETTLE LAWSUIT
description: Audi of America Inc., in an effort to settle a lawsuit charging that some Audis accelerate on their own, is proposing cash payments of up to $2,000 to any suing car owner who buys a new Audi over the next three years.

title: When Suburban Homes Were Built by the Book
description: INthe early teens and 20's, prospective suburban homeowners often selected a house straight from a builder's planning book. Homes in styles ranging from a simple bungalow to a mock Tudor could be ordered by mail from the books and received at the site in kit form.

title: Officer Defended in Drowning
description: A defense lawyer argued today that the drowning of a Navy recruit in training March 2 was an accident and suggested that Navy officers higher than his clients were to blame for poor supervision of the program.

title: Soviet Train Toll Rises to 80
description: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the death toll in a train explosion Saturday in the Volga River valley has risen to 80. The agency said initial results of an inquiry suggested recent high temperatures were to blame for the blast, adding human error did not appear to be a factor.

title: Manila Votes Land Distribution Compromise
description: The Philippine Congress enacted a land redistribution measure early today that strikes a compromise between the claims of landowners and the country's majority of landless farm workers.

title: Sports People; Spurs Courting Brown
description: After his team won the national collegiate basketball championship in April, Larry Brown of Kansas was able to resist the allure of a jump to U.C.L.A. But he may now be facing an even stronger temptation to abandon Lawrence, Kan., this one from the San Antonio Spurs, who dismissed Coach Bob Weiss Tuesday.

title: WIDE DISRUPTION IN SOUTH AFRICA STRIKE
description: As about one million black workers continued a protest strike for a third and final day, employers and trade unions agreed today to negotiate on a labor bill that seeks to curb union powers.

title: Ella Raines, a Star of Westerns And Dramas in the 40's, Dies at 67
description: Ella Raines, an actress who starred in film dramas, comedies and westerns during the 1940's, died of throat cancer May 30 in Los Angeles. She was 67 years old.

title: NICARAGUAN TALKS APPEAR TO FALTER
description: Peace talks between the Sandinista Government and contra leaders appeared to falter today, with each side accusing the other of bad faith.

title: Eli Mintz, Stage and Film Actor And Uncle David in 'Goldbergs'
description: Eli Mintz, an actor who played the ever-philosophizing Uncle David in the stage, movie and television versions of ''The Goldbergs,'' died of pneumonia yesterday at Point Pleasant Hospital in New Jersey. He was 83 years old and lived in Brick, N.J.

title: Chief Financial Officer Is Named by Salomon
description: Salomon Inc. named a chief financial officer yesterday and announced a stock repurchase program to help its share price.

title: INSIDE
description: Arabs Rebuff the P.L.O.

title: Court in Italy Rejects Trials For Officials of Vatican Bank
description: Italy's constitutional court ruled today that Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the former head of the Vatican Bank, and two other executives of the bank cannot be tried in the 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, Italy's biggest banking failure.

title: San Francisco Journal; Wheels of Fortitude Make the Grade
description: The big rig crested the Filbert Street hill and the driver gasped at the sheer drop before him.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers' Big Worry: Stopping Dantley
description: With so much attention focused on the National Basketball Association championship series, players become used to waves of reporters and repetitive questions. They even seem to tolerate questions that don't make much sense.

title: Rainy Russian Skies Clear in Farewell Concert
description: There was celestial activity to mark both the start and the end of the New York Philharmonic's farewell concert in the Soviet Union, a joint performance with the Soviet State Symphony Orchestra in Gorky Park.

title: Rada Electronic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said, pursuant to Israeli law, it recently changed its fiscal year to a Dec. 31 calendar year- end.

title: Rocket Bidders Are Expected
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration expects strong competition among prospective makers of the next generation of shuttle rockets despite a decision by Morton Thiokol Inc., the sole builder of current solid-fuel boosters, to pull out of the running, a spokesman said Tuesday.

title: Life in the 30's
description: The Life in the 30's column by Anna Quindlen on May 12 was about amniocentesis, a test that can determine the presence of some genetic defects in fetuses.

title: 'Freeway' Minister Focuses on the Family
description: The office rented by the author of ''Little House on the Freeway'' has been condemned by the Arizona Department of Transportation, to make way for a freeway.

title: ARCO, SCE Open Cogeneration Plant
description: ARCO and the SCE Corporation intend to dedicate the West Coast's largest cogeneration plant this week. The plant is capable of serving a city the size of Long Beach, Calif. The $300 million plant in Carson, Calif., represents the largest effort yet under a controversial nine-year-old state policy to stimulate new sources of electricity within California.

title: Calendar: Garden Evenings and Roses
description: Garden Evenings, Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street between York and First Avenues; 212-838-7044 and 212-838-6878.

title: Conflicting Votes on Election Funds Set Stage for Confusion in California
description: In an act of political will that had politicians and lawyers scratching their heads in confusion today, California voters on Tuesday approved two conflicting proposals on financing political campaigns.

title: Man Ordered Jailed in Inquiry Into Puerto Rican Nationalist Group
description: A 28-year-old Emergency Medical Service technician who is an advocate of independence for Puerto Rico was held in civil contempt and ordered jailed yesterday after he refused to appear before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that is investigating a Puerto Rican separatist group, the F.A.L.N.

title: SUPREME COURT IS EXPECTED TO GAIN WIDE FREEDOM IN SELECTING CASES
description: The Supreme Court will have nearly total freedom to decide which cases to review under a bill that has cleared Congress and that President Reagan is expected to sign.

title: Diary of an Architect on the Move
description: SOME architects seem to have all the fun. Take Peter Marino, for instance. His list of jobs shows one glamorous project after another.

title: Bomber Cost Said to Exceed Estimate
description: An assessment from a Congressional investigative agency puts the cost of the Air Force program to build a fleet of radar-evading nuclear bombers at $68.8 billion, almost $10 billion more than the Defense Department's latest estimate.

title: Echoes of the 1930's In a Manhattan Home
description: DESPITE relentless shifts in decorating tastes, there is occasionally an interior that stands unchanged, witness in its immutability to the taste of another time.

title: South Pole Shelter: Ugly but Charming
description: WHEN Renee Shields of Wapiti, Wyo., arrived at the scientific-research station here to work as a general field assistant, home turned out to be a 6-by-8-foot cubicle in a Jamesway, the Korean War version of a Quonset hut.

title: New Kodak Notes Will Yield 10.05%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is offering $300 million of 10 percent notes due in 2001 at a price of 99.641 to yield 10.05 percent. Underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: The Firearms the Second Amendment Protects
description: To the Editor:

title: Brawley Family Moves to Queens Church
description: The mother of Tawana Brawley entered a Queens church yesterday, prepared to resist any attempts to arrest her for refusing to appear before a grand jury.

title: Smith Closes Out Yanks; Henderson Injures Ankle
description: The toughest part, Lee Smith said of the transition from the Chicago Cubs to the Boston Red Sox, has been having so little an idea about how to pitch to the lineups he faces. Not having committed habits to memory, he is constantly worried about committing a mistake in the clutch. Consequently, he goes with what he knows: that his best pitch is his fastball.

title: East Germany Ready to Aid Jewish Victims of the Nazis
description: East Germany said today that it is prepared to give humanitarian aid to Jewish survivors of Nazi concentration camps and that talks are under way to work out the details.

title: Mondale Urges Primary Plan
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has urged Congress to order a system of regional Presidential primaries to replace what he called a hodgepodge that ''cries out for reform.''

title: Review/Jazz; Including The Listener In Creativity
description: Over the last 10 years or so, jazz has been flirting with implication as an esthetic tool. The World Saxophone Quartet, by using the precision sound of the reed section of an orchestra, implies an entire big band, letting an audience imagine a whole orchestra, rhythm section and all. A group without a bassist lets members of the audience fill in the bass lines with their imaginations. Partly, this is a result of routine: an audience knows the sound of a walking bass, and the actual thing can be obvious. By implying instead of stating, a composer can include the audience in the imaginative act.

title: Math Woes Also Trip The Tester
description: Those who have always dreaded the mathematical word problems in textbooks and aptitude tests can take some consolation from an announcement Tuesday by the Educational Testing Service.

title: New Plan Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $176,000 gain on the sale of securities and property. c-After gains on the sales of securities and property of $847,000 for the quarter and $2,558,000 for the 9 months.

title: Worlds of Wonder Has Survival Plan
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the troubled toy manufacturer, said its lenders had agreed in principle to a business plan that would allow it to continue operating through March 31. The company, based in Fremont, Calif., said the plan was subject to negotiation of a definitive agreement with a committee of its secured lenders and unsecured creditors, as well as approval by the bankruptcy court.

title: Market Place; Analysts' View Of Chip Industry
description: WITH most semiconductor stocks trading at post-crash highs and with the industry's leading indicator registering a slight drop yesterday, investors might be expected to move their money elsewhere. But chip stocks are among the most popular issues on the Street, and many analysts say there is life in the group yet.

title: C.F.T.C. Cites Refco Trades
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has accused Refco Inc., one of the world's largest trading firms, of 11 commodities law violations.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We use our unheated 70-year-old on weekends. Two years ago we painted the long hall and stairwell with a latex paint, and a month later extensive peeling began. We think this may be because the walls were still damp from winter. We scraped off some of the peeling paint, because we planned to repaint soon, but the peeling continues. What is the easiest way to cover this? A. The peeling is not due to dampness if you used latex paints; since these are water-thinned, they can be applied over damp surfaces. So it's likely that the peeling will continue until all the paint that is not bonding properly comes off.

title: Sports People; Collision With Whale
description: With more than 2,000 miles to go to the finish at Newport, R.I., the original field of 94 yachts that left Plymouth, England, on Sunday in the Single-Handed Transatlantic Yacht Race yesterday had been reduced to 86, including a Canadian frontrunner that was knocked out of the race after a collision with a whale.

title: Couple Wins $25 Million Suit
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan yesterday directed New York City and the Navistar International Corporation to pay $25 million in damages to the parents of two Brooklyn boys who were crushed to death by a truck while crossing Seventh Avenue with their mother in 1981.

title: Treasury Issues Post Small Drop
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes edged lower in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves defensively in advance of an inflation report scheduled to be released this morning.

title: LEON FALK, EXECUTIVE, DIES AT 86
description: Leon Falk Jr., an industrialist and philanthropist who also raised purebred cattle, died yesterday at Shadyside Hospital in Pittsburgh after a series of strokes. A lifelong resident of Pittsburgh, he was 86 years old.

title: The Media Business; NBC Cable Deal Is Off, But Lease Accord Is Set
description: The National Broadcasting Company will not buy Tempo Television after all, NBC executives said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Film; Detachment And Despair In Europe
description: ''Les Rendez-Vous d'Anna'' was shown as part of the 1979 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 27, 1979. The film, which is in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Stuarts Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $903,000, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of prior years' accounting changes. The year-ago first quarter's operating loss included a credit of $203,000, or 5 cents a share, from a change in inventory accounting methods. The year-ago results restated to reflect the accounting changes adopted Feb. 1, 1987.

title: Tax 'Credits' Don't Help the Poor Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur Blythe Quartet
description: Arthur Blythe, an alto saxophonist, will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Company News; Kuwait Won't Buy Larger B.P. Stake
