description: The Kuwait Investment Office has agreed not to increase its 22 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company pending a British Government inquiry into its holding, the Government said. In cases where the Government investigates share holdings, Britain routinely asks investors involved not to buy more stock.

title: Clayton Timbrell, 67, An Ex-U.N. Official
description: Clayton Carey Timbrell, a career civil servant with the United Nations and a retired Assistant Secretary General for General Services, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 67 years old and retired in 1984.

title: Review/Ballet; The Contrasts of 2 Casts In Versions of 'Giselle'
description: That ''Giselle'' remains one of the 19th-century's most satisfying ballets was clear from recent performances by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. On Wednesday night, Leslie Browne and Robert Hill gave promising, but uneven performances, as Giselle, the betrayed young peasant girl, and Albrecht, her duplicitous aristocratic lover. On Tuesday night, Marianna Tcherkassky and Kevin McKenzie were superb in those roles.

title: Reviews/Film; Whining Daddy And His 3 Sons Rob and Kidnap
description: The muse visits in many forms, but the desire to re-use a brothel set left over from ''Big Bad Mama II'' is not one of them. That was Roger Corman's inspiration for producing ''Daddy's Boys,'' a cheaply made film that proves you often get exactly what you pay for.

title: Monica Bergman, Art Historian, 40
description: Monica Bergman, an art historian, died of cancer Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cardozo Faces Lafayette
description: Although Benjamin Cardozo High School's baseball team went all the way to the Public Schools Athletic League championship game last year before losing to Tottenville and is back in the semifinals this year after beating McKee of Staten Island on Tuesday, the Judges are not penciling themselves into this year's championship game.

title: Eyesore or Landmark? The House Donahue Razed
description: To Phil Donahue, the talk-show host, the experimental, all-concrete house next door to his classic Tudor-style mansion here was a bit of an eyesore, an odd hybrid of Stonehenge and bomb shelter.

title: U.S. May Need Humanitarian Admissions Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Pan Am Says It Has Offers
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that its board had received several offers to buy various assets, but the airline company did not disclose the names of any of the interested parties. Pan Am, a unit of the Pan

title: Company News; Bid Is Said to Fail To Control Gucci
description: A Middle Eastern investment bank has failed to take control of the board of directors of the Italian fashion house Guccio Gucci S.p.A., sources close to Gucci said.

title: Cut in Mexico Oil Price
description: Mexico, the world's sixth-largest oil producer, last month trimmed the average price of its light Isthmus crude for United States clients, the Government oil monopoly said Wednesday night. Pemex said in a statement that it had charged United States customers an average of $15.78 for a 42-gallon barrel in May, down from the $16 of April. The average price of heavy Maya oil rose from $12.77 a barrel in April to $13.07 in May, the statement said. Prices for Japanese buyers were held steady in May at $15.30 a barrel for the light oil and $12.60 a barrel for the heavy brand.

title: Magna International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Bush Paints Rival as Elitist, With 'Harvard Yard' Views
description: Vice President Bush today mocked the foreign policy views of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis as ''born in Harvard Yard's boutique'' and labeled his rival's stance on crime as ''standard old-style 60's liberalism.''

title: Auctions
description: Wright Designs

title: Facing Up to State Budget Pain
description: Mis-estimates of the effects of Federal tax reform have left several states - notably California, Massachusetts and New York - surprised and embarrassed by revenue shortages. The budget damage, requiring painful remedies, poses a test of state house leadership.

title: Company News; Investors Disclose Talks on Scherer
description: Two New York-based investment firms that hold the equivalent of an 8.8 percent stake in the R. P. Scherer Corporation disclosed that they had held talks with a senior Scherer executive and other shareholders about a possible sale of the gelatin capsule manufacturer, based in Troy, Mich.

title: Pakistani Appoints Cabinet And Cancels Trip to the U.S.
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq swore in a new 18-member Cabinet today, 11 days after he disbanded the Government.

title: Guilty Plea In Hutton Case
description: A former broker for E. F. Hutton & Company has pleaded guilty to charges stemming from his role in a money-laundering scheme conducted at the firm's Providence office.

title: Pretoria Extends Emergency Rule for a Year
description: The South African Government tonight renewed a two-year-old nationwide state of emergency for another 12 months.

title: Bush Campaign Negotiating With Two for Top Press Posts
description: Vice President Bush is exploring a plan to shore up his campaign press operations by naming James Lake and Sheila Tate to senior positions, campaign officials said today.

title: Review/Theater; A 'Hamlet' Stamped With a Bergman Seal
description: When the Ghost appears on the battlements at Elsinore, he is so corporeal that he could be the figure of Death in ''The Seventh Seal.'' One almost expects him to sit down with Hamlet for a game of chess. Later, when Hamlet cavorts backstage with the traveling players - a scene filled with histrionic flair - one is reminded of the rich theatrical canvas of ''Fanny and Alexander.''

title: Company News; Giant Abandons Talks to Sell Unit
description: The Giant Group Ltd. said it has been unable to reach a definitive agreement over the proposed $110 million sale of its cement and waste-burning business and had ended month-long talks with the Environmental Treatment and Technologies Corporation of Findlay, Ohio.

title: College World Series; Stanford Defeats Fullerton State, 4-1
description: Lee Plemel scattered eight hits for his second victory in the College World Series tournament as Stanford, the defending champion, stayed alive with a 4-1 victory tonight over Fullerton State.

title: Assemblyman Engel to Challenge Biaggi's Renomination to House
description: Assemblyman Eliot L. Engel announced yesterday that he would challenge the renomination of Representative Mario Biaggi. He is the second Democrat to announce against Mr. Biaggi this week.

title: Sports of the Times; This Horse Has a Prayer
description: AT first they prayed only for the health of the horse named Risen Star, but lately the residents of an old-age home in New Orleans have been reassured there is nothing sacrilegious in rooting for the horse to finish first.

title: Washington Talk: The White House; Candidates Are Urged To Pick Science Aides
description: The nation's chief scientist may well be its President. More than any other person's policies, the President's policies set the country's scientific priorities and channel billions of dollars into research and development.

title: Sports People; Keenan Is Hired
description: Mike Keenan, dismissed as coach of the Philadelphia Flyers on May 11 despite a .638 winning percentage, the highest among active National Hockey League coaches, was signed by the Chicago Blackhawks yesterday.

title: Addicts in Portland, Ore., Will Get Free Hypodermic Needles
description: The nation's first authorized distribution of free hypodermic needles to drug addicts in hopes of preventing the spread of AIDS will begin next month in Portland, Ore., sponsors of the program announced here yesterday.

title: Company News; Motorola's Offer For MDI Advances
description: A takeover bid by Motorola Inc.'s Canadian unit for MDI Mobile Data International Inc., valued at $105 million (Canadian), or $86 million (United States), appeared likely to succeed after the main opposition to the offer was dropped. Glenayre Electronics Ltd., which had earlier opposed Motorola Canada Ltd.'s bid for being too low, said it plans to tender its 12 percent stake in MDI under the offer.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Saatchi Cuts Dual Titles, Promotes 3
description: THE strange situation of dual titles in the United States operations of British-based Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide will be all but eliminated with the promotions of Gary M. Susnjara, Edward L. Wax and Joseph P. Mack.

title: Project to Convert Atomic Waste Begins
description: The United States Department of Energy and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation have begun processing nuclear waste in a system they hope will be the model for stabilizing millions of gallons of highly toxic, highly radioactive waste in leaking, decaying tanks around the country.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus fell 21 percent, to $5.05 billion, in May for its 13th consecutive monthly drop from its level of a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: London Journal; In Tory Country, Someone to Watch Over TV
description: For most of his career, Sir William Rees-Mogg has been depicted as a bona fide member of that band of selfless Tory gentlemen who guide Britain's main institutions. It took Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her campaign to clean up television to give him a new public image as a threat to freedom.

title: Sports People; Guerrero Disabled
description: The Dodgers placed Pedro Guerrero on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, retroactive to June 5. The third baseman will enter Centinela Hospital Medical Center for three to five days, where he will be placed in traction and given medication for a pinched nerve in his neck, from which he is experiencing acute soreness.

title: Standard Commercial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $566,000 for the quarter and $1,470,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary gains of $158,000 for the quarter and $429,000 for the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The Group of Seven has a ''nonaggression pact'' for its summit meeting a week from Sunday. When President Reagan meets with the heads of America's leading trading partners, the talk will be of noncontentious issues, including the dollar's stability and the African debt crisis. The leaders are wary of rattling the financial markets or upsetting the economy during an American election campaign, so they plan to tiptoe around their differences over trade, agriculture, Latin American debt and U.S. deficits. [ Page A1. ] The O.E.C.D. warned of inflationary pressures in the U.S. but said the overall economic outlook for the industrial world appeared stronger than it seemed six months ago. [ D2. ] MARKETS Grain and soybean prices rebounded, partly because of fresh buying by speculators. Earlier in the week, many speculators had taken profits to take advantage of the strong price surge that began early this month. But crop conditions continue to deteriorate in key wheat-growing areas of the Grain Belt. [ D1. ] Trading large baskets of stocks may soon be easier. The Big Board is reviewing the possibility of creating a post where investors could buy or sell a portfolio of stocks in a single transaction. The Chicago Merc is considering the introduction of a system for trading large bundles of stock index futures contracts. Both could significantly increase the amount of program trading. [ D1. ] Stock prices were mixed in continued heavy trading as a late rally in blue-chip issues fizzled. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,093.35, down 9.60 points. [ D4. ] Prices of Treasuries edged lower in moderately active trading, as dealers positioned themselves defensively in advance of an inflation report scheduled to be released this morning. [ D10. ] The dollar lost ground against all major currencies in domestic trading. Gold rose $1 an ounce on the Comex, to $457.10. [ D12. ] THE ECONOMY The Government published adjusted foreign-trade figures that make it easier to discern economic trends. The seasonally adjusted figures showed the U.S. trade deficit had narrowed more slowly in the last year than earlier figures had indicated. [ D1. ] U.S. businesses plan to modernize and expand at the fastest rate in four years, according to a Government survey. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Suzuki challenged Consumers Union's suggestion that its Samurai utility vehicle is prone to roll over, presenting its own safety test results. Suzuki also pointed out that Consumers Union had changed its rollover test after the Samurai had passed the publisher's standard evasion test for vehicles. [ D1. ] Drexel Burnham Lambert will build a new headquarters in lower Manhattan. With an unnamed developer, Drexel will erect a building with 1.2 million to 1.5 million square feet of space. [ D1. ] NBC will not buy Tempo Television after all. Citing ''tax complications,'' NBC said it would instead lease time on Tempo's network to present its financial network. [ D16. ] Texas Air is studying ways to restructure Eastern Airlines, but it says it has no plans to sell the operation. [ D3. ] Desert Partners dropped its bid for USG, ending a nine-month battle for the nation's largest gypsum producer. [ D3. ] Hal Riney won three Gold Pencils at the One Show, as did the Martin Agency and Rice & Rice. [ D16. ] The publisher of The Dayton Daily News was dismissed for refusing to publish a classified ad from a homosexual group. [ C32. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Federal regulators remain upbeat about the savings industry, days after the $1.35 billion liquidation of two California savings and loan institutions. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Is the Gap bouncing back? Analysts are starting to reassess their negative opinions of the apparel chain. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Arab Declaration Falls Short of P.L.O. Demands
description: An Arab summit meeting ended today with a broad resolution supporting the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories and pledging ''all necessary help and assistance in all necessary forms'' to insure that the upheaval continues.

title: Roller Skating
description: The Wollman Skating Rink in Central Park is now open for roller skating. Weekend hours are 10 A.M. to 11 P.M. Fridays and Saturdays and 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. on Sundays. Admission is $5 ($2 for those under 12); skate rentals are $2 daily. The rink, reachable by the 60th Street entrance to the park, will remain open for roller skating until October, when ice skating resumes. Information: 517-4800.

title: Memorial for Patriarch
description: A special memorial service for Abuna Tekle Haimanot, Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, will be held Sunday at 10 A.M. at Holy Trinity Ethiopian Orthodox Church at 140 West 176th Street in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.

title: Russian Orthodoxy Tests Freedoms
description: Testing the new freedoms proferred by the Kremlin, the Russian Orthodox Church adopted new rules today, loosening some of the stringent bonds on its authority and activity.

title: Yanks' General Manager Fulfills Dream
description: John Quinn, who was general manager of the Boston Braves for 23 years, liked to work in the kitchen of the family's home in Newton, Mass. It was a place that could get warm in early June as rumors of deals grew hot and the phone lines burned through the night.

title: Bridge
description: Kerri Shuman, a member of the women's team that will represent the United States in the world championships in October, has had other matters on her mind lately.

title: Crown Books Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Company News; Group Suggests Allegheny Study
description: The New York investor Bennett S. Lebow has requested confidential financial information from Allegheny International Inc. to formulate a plan of restructuring the troubled appliance manufacturer, which is based in Pittsburgh.

title: Eve Orton, Editor, 72
description: Eve Orton, a former editor for Harper's Bazaar and a well-known figure in the fashion industry, was found dead of an overdose of sleeping pills in her Manhattan apartment on May 31, her son said. She was 72 years old and had been ill for more than two years.

title: Bush vs. Dukakis On Drugs
description: How Presidential candidates would combat drug abuse, more than any other issue, may determine the voters' choice. With the primaries over, the electorate can judge how the two candidates might deal with this problem if elected.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Bedeviled by a heel injury that prompted her withdrawal from the Italian Open last month and caused discomfort in a third-round loss in the French Open, Chris Evert withdrew from next week's Pilkington Glass women's grass-court championships at Eastbourne, England. Evert plans to play at Wimbledon, where she has won three singles titles. . . . Ian Woosnam of Wales, who won eight events worldwide last year, has withdrawn from next week's United States Open. Woosnam said he had suffered torn ligaments in his left wrist in an accident at his home.

title: Our Towns; How to Fake Nuclear Disaster The Lilco Way
description: For the last three days, at a cost of up to $2 million, 100 Federal officials have been busy evaluating 4,000 Long Island Lighting Company workers who pretended to be safely evacuating the Island after a make-believe nuclear accident at Shoreham, a power plant that in reality will probably never open. Lilco officials said it went great. Many others feel this is absurd. The state's two Senators, several Representatives, the Governor, untold numbers of state and county officials have said it is ridiculous to have a drill now, when a tentative deal has been made to scrap the plant and a final deal seems close. The Federal Emergency Management Agency, which ran the drill, pleaded to put it off. Shoreham is a half dozen years behind schedule; emergency officials thought they could wait a few more weeks. ''Oh, absolutely,'' said Bill McAda, a FEMA spokesman.

title: Meet Adjusted To Suit Slaney
description: Promoters of the June 25 Michelob Invitational track and field meet, acting on a request by Mary Decker Slaney, have dropped the women's mile from the program in favor of a 2,000-meter event.

title: Savings Bond Sales Fall
description: Sales of United States savings bonds dropped in May for the second consecutive month, falling nine-tenths of a percent, to $655 million. The Treasury Department said Wednesday that May sales were $6 million lower than in April and $51 million lower than in March. Before the two drops, however, sales had increased for eight consecutive months. May sales were also 8.8 percent higher those of last May. The current interest rate on savings bonds held five years or longer is 6.90 percent.

title: Income Gap in Britain
description: A British Government study issued today showed that Britain is increasingly divided along economic lines, with northerners poorer, less healthy and facing higher unemployment than their southern neighbors. According to the latest issue of Official Trends, nearly half a million people fled the north, Midlands and Wales in 1986 to settle in the wealthier south. The study shows that the gap between ''haves'' and ''haves not'' widened between 1980 and 1986, with the difference in weekly incomes in north and south doubling from $:40, to $:80 ($145).

title: Moscow Rejects Homeland for the Tatars
description: A high-level Soviet commission set up to review the rights of Crimean Tatars has rejected their demands for an autonomous homeland, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Review/Art; Artschwager's Knack For Hybrid Works
description: When it comes to prominence, Richard Artschwager has been a tortoise in a field of hares. While various Pop and Minimal artists, their labels secure, have sped past to fame, fortune and museum retrospectives -although not necessarily in that order - Mr. Artschwager has proceeded at his own pace, under his own banner. His New York retrospective, at the Whitney Museum of American Art, was held only this year, some 20 years after his debut at the Leo Castelli Gallery.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON FACULTY SHIFT
description: The chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst today asked the faculty government to investigate whether academic freedom was breached when a black faculty member was transferred out of the Afro-American studies department.

title: Newly Found Wall May Give Clue To Origin of Rome, Scientist Says
description: In a discovery that might require the rewriting of ancient Roman history, archeologists digging on a slope of the Palatine Hill last week unearthed what they believe is the defensive wall built when Rome was founded.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; White House Bulletin
description: The White House has begun publication of a monthly bulletin of economic news, confident that the trends in the waning days of the Reagan Administration will be rising and will perhaps overshadow such issues as Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's legal problems and the Iran-contra trials.

title: THOUSANDS BATTLE AS SEOUL BLOCKS MARCH TO NORTH
description: Fierce but sporadic battles erupted here this afternoon as riot policemen tried to block students from marching to the North Korean border for a meeting with North Korean students at Panmunjom.

title: Company News; Desert Partners Drops USG Bid
description: Desert Partners L.P. said today that it had dropped its bid for the USG Corporation, giving up a nine-month battle for the nation's largest gypsum producer. The partnership, led by the

title: Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $706,000 from discontinued operations.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; People
description: Mark Abrams, Paul Katzka, Peter le Comte and Darryl Lindberg have been elected senior vice presidents at DDB Needham Worldwide.

title: THE BIG RACE DRAWS A SMALL FIELD OF 6
description: Four colts, a filly and a gelding were the only 3-year-olds entered yesterday for the 120th running of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.

title: The Admiral on His Watch
description: At La Guardia Airport, a driver was holding up a sign with the name of a man coming off the Washington shuttle. I stopped short when I saw the name and felt a strong urge to wait for the driver's passenger, introduce myself and congratulate him on what he is doing for the country; so I did.

title: Trak Auto Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SLOWER GAINS IN DEFICIT SHOWN IN ADJUSTED DATA
description: As part of a move expected to calm currency and securities markets, the Government published adjusted foreign-trade figures today that make it easier to discern economic trends by allowing for quirks of the season and calendar.

title: Chrysler Forecast Of Vehicle Sales
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it expects to sell at least 2.25 million cars and trucks in 1988, up from 2 million vehicles sold in 1987. A Chrysler spokesman said the sales forecast is the first issued by the company for 1988. A spokesman, Tom Houston, said actual sales in 1988 may be higher than the estimate.

title: Where to Pick Your Own Strawberries
description: A week later than usual in many areas because of a cool wet May, the 1988 strawberry crop is now ready for picking in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut berry patches.

title: Barbershop Inspires a Ballet
description: The First New York International Festival of the Arts opens tomorrow night on a decidedly home-grown note: a performance by the American Ballet Theater. The world premiere that forms the program's centerpiece is a ballet drawn from the ingenuously American art of barbershop quartet singing. And ''S.P.E.B.S.Q.S.A.,'' the new ballet by Clark Tippet, summons a curiously American world of male bonding and homey patriotism.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Beber Silverstein Wins Sogrape Account
description: The New York office of Miami-based Beber Silverstein & Partners has become agency for Sogrape USA, a marketer of imported wines, whose best-known brand is Mateus Wines of Portugal. The account, billing about $3 million, was formerly at Rubin Reid Noto & Ehrenthal.

title: Telos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $89,000 from discontinued operations. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the quarter and $66,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter results reflected adjustments primarily related to the adoption by Telos of a policy which provides for increased amortization of replacement parts, which reduced net income by about $325,000 in the quarter. The prior year results were restated to reflect the acquisition by Telos in October 1987 of DMA Inc.

title: Pushing to Become First Brother
description: Twenty-seven years ago, Jonathan Bush auditioned for a Broadway show as a song-and-dance man. He failed and turned to a career in finance and now runs his own investment management firm.

title: Mary Martin Leads 'Cole' Salute
description: She was a self-described hayseed from Weatherford, Tex., who had never even heard the word striptease, let alone performed one.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day yesterday about the Pratt & Whitney Company misstated its corporate affiliation. It is a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, not Colt Industries.

title: NICARAGUAN TALKS SALVAGE THE TRUCE
description: The latest round of peace talks between the Sandinistas and contra guerrilla leaders ended today with mutual accusations, but also with an agreement not to resume fighting.

title: Review/Film; Composer's Discordant History
description: Paul Morrissey's ''Beethoven's Nephew,'' opening today at the Plaza, is something of a first: two different movies that unreel simultaneously on a single screen.

title: After Stormy Years, a Calm Dollar
description: For nearly six months, the dollar's value has hardly budged against other leading currencies - making this one of the longest periods of stability for the dollar since the early 1980's and one that many economists say is likely to last at least until Labor Day.

title: Debt
description: American Express Credit Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $1 billion shelf offering of debt securities and warrants to purchase debt securities.

title: BRIEFS
description: Alberta Energy Co., Edmonton, which is engaged in gas and oil production, said it would offer to buy the common shares, warrants, convertible debentures and convertible preferred shares of Chieftain Development Co. that it does not already own.

title: Hospital Interns' Long Hours To Be Reduced in New York
description: The long, often grueling hours of interns and residents in New York State hospitals will be substantially reduced next year under new regulations approved yesterday by a state health panel.

title: A Publisher Is Dismissed Over Ad Ban
description: The publisher of The Dayton Daily News was dismissed Wednesday for refusing to publish a classified advertisement from a homosexual organization, David E. Easterly, president of Cox Newspapers, the paper's parent company, said yesterday.

title: Name That Fossil
description: Collectors who have an unidentified item on their hands - be it fossil, insect, mineral or bone - can take it to the American Museum of Natural History tomorrow during Identification Day. Members of the museum staff will be on hand to help identify all natural objects, except gemstones. Hours are 1 to 4:30 P.M. in the Charles A. Dana Education Wing, on 77th Street just off Central Park West. Admission is by contribution: $3.50, or $1.50 for those under 12 years. Information: 769-5305.

title: Meritor Hires Banker As Chairman and Chief
description: The Meritor Financial Group, a troubled Philadelphia-based financial services company seeking to restore profitability, yesterday hired Roger S. Hillas, a leading Philadelphia banker, to be chairman and chief executive.

title: Sports People; Brown to Spurs?
description: Larry Brown, the coach of the Kansas Jayhawks, last season's national champions, has reportedly agreed in principle to become the next coach of the San Antonio Spurs, according to a story in The San Antonio Light.

title: AIDS Researchers Discover 2 Less Deadly Virus Strains
description: Researchers have isolated two variants of an African AIDS virus that are less deadly to immune system cells than are most AIDS viruses. Scientists hope the variants will offer clues to why most AIDS viruses are so able to cause disease.

title: The Media Business; Bid on Infinity Broadcasting
description: A management group has agreed to acquire the outstanding stock of the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, the largest publicly traded radio company in terms of the number of stations and revenues.

title: Army Kills a Palestinian as Strike Marks 6 Months of Uprising
description: The Palestinian uprising completed its sixth month today. By the standards of most other places it was a remarkable day, but here it seemed almost commonplace.

title: House Ethics Committee Weighs An Inquiry Into Wright's Finances
description: The House ethics committee met in closed session today to discuss whether to undertake a formal investigation of charges that Speaker Jim Wright's financial dealings may have violated House rules.

title: Police Slayings Are Up In Death Penalty States
description: To the Editor:

title: Testimony Attacked in Drug Case
description: Defense attorneys yesterday began an assault on the credibility and character of a key prosecution witness who had testified she heard three defendants and others discuss ways to kill a grand jury witness.

title: The Law; Expert Witness Is Unfazed by 'Dr. Death' Label
description: Last week was an eventful one for Dr. James P. Grigson. The Supreme Court ruled that he had infringed on a prisoner's constitutional rights. American Civil Liberties Union lawyers called him ''a menace.'' Officials of the American Psychiatric Association questioned his professional ethics. Newspapers around the country referred to him as ''Dr. Death'' and ''Dr. Doom.''

title: Dining Out Guide: Westchester
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Westchester Weekly section of The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Eastchester Fish Gourmet

title: Review/Film; A Tomlin-Midler Comedy of Errors
description: It begins when an addled nurse in a small West Virginia hospital mixes up two pairs of newborn identical twins, sending each set of parents home with a mismatched pair of baby girls. By chance, both families name their twins Sadie and Rose, who, in a casting inspiration, grow up to be played by Bette Midler and Lily Tomlin.

title: TCA Cable TV Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Raves and Reservations On Dukakis Drug Plan
description: The emergence of drugs as a major issue in the Presidential campaign has focused attention on what Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has tried to do about drug abuse in Massachusetts.

title: Books of The Times; Madness, Prophecy and a Lost Friend
description: Twilight By Elie Wiesel Translated by Marion Wiesel. 217 pages. Summit Books. $17.95.

title: Court to Rehear Challenge To Army's Homosexual Ban
description: The Federal appeals court here, which last February struck down the Army's ban on homosexuals, nullified that ruling today by agreeing to rehear the case.

title: TEST CHANGE DRAWS FIRE FROM SUZUKI
description: Presenting its own safety test results, the American Suzuki Motor Corporation yesterday challenged Consumers Union's suggestion that its Samurai utility vehicle is prone to roll over.

title: Seoul to Pay for More of U.S. Military Cost
description: South Korea agreed today to pay for more of its own defense and the United States agreed to deploy additional American forces during the Olympic Games to ward off terrorism.

title: Lawyer Says Connally Is Out of Bankruptcy
description: Former Gov. John B. Connally has emerged from bankruptcy less than a year after filing for protection from creditors to deal with $93 million in debts, his lawyer says.

title: Bok Assails Gaps in Pay In Vital Jobs
description: In a strongly worded speech, Derek C. Bok, the president of Harvard University, told graduates today that public servants and teachers in grade school must receive higher salaries or society will pay a steeper price.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Taking No Chances
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., the New York investment banking firm, is hedging its bets on the November election.

title: Review/Film; Documentary On Sex Change At the Age of 55
description: ''Call Me Madame'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 12. The film, which is in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Life on Columbus Ave. Predated Boutiques
description: To the Editor:

title: At The Movies
description: Consultant With Cleats

title: Agency Calls for Ethics Code
description: An independent Government agency urged President Reagan today to issue an executive order setting out ethical guidelines for private citizens who will work on the transition team for the new President after the November elections.

title: Jazz Messengers
description: Art Blakey, a drummer, is leading the Jazz Messengers tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Who Is Really Killing the American Musical?
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservative's Letter Assails Solicitor General
description: Amid complaints by some conservative legal advocates about Solicitor General Charles Fried, one such group has urged Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to dismiss him if he will not urge the Supreme Court to overrule a major civil rights precedent.

title: Company News; Labor Pact Spurs NWA Stock Gains
description: A gain of more than 10 percent in the common stock of NWA Inc. in the last week indicates that the carrier has regained its footing after its 1986 takeover of Republic Airlines, analysts said. NWA's stock rose 62.5 cents today to close at $44.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ISRAEL CHIEF MEETS SOVIET AIDE AT U.N.
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, met for nearly two hours today, and Mr. Shevardnadze said afterward that a long-planned visit by an Israeli consular team to the Soviet Union would take place next month.

title: TWITTY, ROBERTS SHARE LEAD
description: Howard Twitty believes that some golfers do well on certain courses time after time. The 6-foot-5-inch Twitty, who finished second in the 1979 Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic and has usually fared well here, backed up his contention today by taking a share of the lead in the first round.

title: Review/Film; A Boys' School Rebellion in Franco's Shadow
description: ''Hail Hazana!,'' made in Spain in 1978, when the memory of the Franco dictatorship was still fresh, may be taken as a parable of the country's political transformation. We are in a Roman Catholic boys' school, where each day begins with the neatly turned-out lads, in orderly columns, singing their anthem: ''Beloved School, Second Home.'' No graffiti mar the walls, and the head of the school maintains surveillance through binoculars from an upstairs window.

title: Seagram Co Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included after-tax dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of $43,366,000 for the latest first quarter and $39,506,000 for the year- ago period, and equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont of $85,020,000 and $41,786,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Black Health, A New Quarterly
description: A couple of former ad agency people, Bonnie White and Carlos Maynard, have joined forces as co-publishers to bring out a new quarterly called Black Health, 25,000 copies of which will be distributed without charge to the waiting rooms of health care professionals who have large numbers of black patients.

title: Drexel Analyst Takes Post at Paine Webber
description: Hercules A. Segalas, a well-known securities analyst in the consumer packaged goods industry, said yesterday that he was leaving Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for Paine Webber Inc.

title: The Media Business; RINEY WINS 3 AWARDS AT A LEADING AD SHOW
description: Fresh from being awarded the General Motors Saturn account two weeks ago, Hal Riney & Partners won a smaller but almost as sweet victory last night. It was honored with three ''Gold Pencils'' at the One Show, the annual awards presentation of the One Club for Art and Copy, the New York-based organization of advertising copywriters and art directors.

title: Henderson to Miss Week
description: Rickey Henderson, who suffered a sprained right ankle in the fourth inning of Wednesday night's 4-3 loss to the Boston Red Sox, left Yankee Stadium yesterday on crutches, burdened by the dispiriting news that he will likely be out of action until next week at the earliest.

title: ATHLETICS LOSE 5th STRAIGHT
description: Barry Bonds hit a two-out, two-run single that capped a three-run rally in the ninth inning tonight and the Pirates edged the Chicago Cubs, 4-3.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Blackstone Group, a financial advisory firm, and Blackstone Management Partners named James R. Birle a general partner.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 429 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.70 billion, to $267.28 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 118 institutional funds fell by $1.01 billion, to $70.61 billion. Assets of the 214 general purpose funds were down by $681.2 million, to $82.95 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds dropped by $5.9 million, to $113.73 billion, the Washington-based organization said.

title: North to Be First Tried In the Iran-Contra Case
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra conspiracy case announced today that he had selected Oliver L. North as the first of four defendants to stand trial.

title: Economic Scene; Paying for Failure Of Savings Units
description: WILL the Federal Home Loan Bank Board be able to raise enough cash to keep the savings and loan industry afloat? The liquidation this week of two relatively small California thrift institutions, at a cost of $1.35 billion, did not dampen the regulators' upbeat rhetoric. Bank board insiders still argue that, with a little luck, the net cost of closing or merging insolvent savings and loan associations can be kept to $25 billion. Such a sum could probably be financed with more borrowing against future deposit insurance premiums to be collected from viable savings units.

title: The Editorial Notebook; When Racism Goes to College
description: Commencement season is a time for celebration and reflection on higher education. Now, an ugly development darkens that reflection: increased racial conflict on too many campuses.

title: U.S. Seizes Fireworks At Ports on East Coast
description: Federal agents searching for illegal fireworks in East Coast ports have seized seven million spinners, cherry balls, Roman candles and other dangerous pyrotechnics imported from China, officials said Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are now learning that the Romans must be taken on their own terms as a complex society in an urban setting at a time when many historians considered them to be mere shepherds.'' - Russell T. Scott, a classicist at Bryn Mawr College. [ A8:3. ]

title: Golf; LANGER STILL BATTLING PAIN AND COURSE
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany has more reasons than most golfers to play well in Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic here this week.

title: Empire Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings for the year-ago period would have been 45 cents a share had Empire been a stock company with 11,602,047 shares outstanding.

title: HOSTILE BID IS WEIGHED BY ICAHN
description: Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that he might make a hostile takeover for Texaco Inc. if he wins a seat on the oil company's board and the directors still refuse to let shareholders vote on his takeover offer.

title: Wicks Ends Olympic Bid
description: Kay Yow, the coach of the United States women's Olympic basketball team, said yesterday that Sue Wicks, the Rutgers' all-American, would not return to seek a place on the team after walking out of mini-camp in Raleigh, N.C., earlier this week.

title: Chronicle of City's Neglect Of Williamsburg Bridge
description: For nearly two decades, engineers warned in a series of reports that the Williamsburg Bridge approaches were decaying. But New York City failed to act in time to prevent the bridge from being closed as a hazard, according to inspection documents, budget memos and interviews with state and city officials.

title: Dukakis in the Middle
description: A headline on the front page of The Los Angeles Times for May 26 proclaimed: ''Dukakis Not Ruling Out First Use.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: The ''Your Money'' column in Business Day last Saturday incorrectly described the source of financing for authors' royalties, theater rentals, and pay for actors and other workers.

title: California Utility's $100 Million Issue
description: The Southern California Gas Company, a unit of the Pacific Lighting Corporation, is offering $100 million in 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1998 at 99.203, to yield 9.50 percent, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Forum on South Bronx
description: ''The South Bronx Today: A Challenge to the Constitution'' is to be the subject of a forum at St. Ann's Church of Morrisania, 295 St. Ann's Avenue, at 140th Street in the Bronx, tomorrow afternoon at 2:30. Speakers will include Benno C. Schmidt Jr., president of Yale University; Gov. Kean of New Jersey; the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer; Bishop Paul Moore Jr.; Julius Chambers, director of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, and the columnist Tom Wicker. A buffet and theater presentation will follow. Admission is free, but a donation is suggested. A bus will make a round trip, at $7, leaving at 1:30 P.M. from St. James Church, on Madison Avenue and 71st Street. Information: 585-5632 or 585-6325.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Fred Frith and Friends

title: Book Notes
description: Power of TV No Myth

title: Company News; Texas Air to Consider Restructuring Eastern
description: The Texas Air Corporation's chairman, Frank Lorenzo, said yesterday that the company was studying ways to restructure its troubled Eastern Airlines subsidiary but had no plans to sell the operation.

title: Guard at Foster Home Recalls Crowd Intimidation
description: A private guard who was watching a Queens house that the city planned to use as a home for foster-care babies testified yesterday that she had been intimidated into leaving the scene by a crowd outside the house shortly before a fire was set in it.

title: O.E.C.D. Growth Outlook Brightens
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today of inflationary pressures in the United States but said the overall economic outlook for the industrial world appeared stronger than it seemed six months ago.

title: Sports People; Hall Is Recuperating
description: Joe B. Hall, former basketball coach at Kentucky, was reported in good condition yesterday after he underwent surgery to remove a malignant tumor from his colon.

title: 1,000 Youngsters to Evoke Coney Island With Dance
description: ''A Day in the Life of Coney Island,'' the weekend's third event in the First New York International Festival of the Arts, is a musical extravaganza created by Jacques d'Amboise, a former principal dancer of the New York City Ballet. A tribute to the Brooklyn beach and recreation area, it includes choreographic evocations of roller-coaster rides, sun bathing, shark attacks and life-saving rescues.

title: Wavetech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a loss of $21,410 for the quarter and net of $17,061 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $58,333 for the quarter and $102,590 for the 6 months. The results included the operations of Applied Environmental Technology Inc. from its acquisition on Sept. 28, 1987.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Reagan Aide Leaving
description: Thomas C. Griscom, who has been President Reagan's director of communications for 17 months, will be leaving his post soon and is likely to return to private industry in his hometown of Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: Review/Art; After Long Wait, a Look At the Luxurious Braque
description: Walking up Fifth Avenue toward the Guggenheim Museum, where a retrospective of paintings, drawings and sculptures by Georges Braque (1882-1963) can be seen through Sept. 11, this critic wondered how it was possible that 39 years have gone by since Braque last had a comprehensive museum show in New York. Coming out of the show, half a morning later, it seemed more than ever ridiculous.

title: Steps to Aid Big Trades Weighed
description: In two steps that could significantly increase the amount of program trading of the stock market, the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange are considering ways to make it easier to trade large baskets of stocks.

title: Official Offers to Testify in Brawley Case
description: A Dutchess County prosecutor whom Tawana Brawley's lawyers have called one of her attackers has asked a special state grand jury to subpoena his accusers as a condition for him to come forward and clear himself.

title: Suit by Four Blacks Charges Illegal Surveillance by Police
description: Four blacks active in community affairs sued the New York City Police Department yesterday for $100 million, charging that a so-called black desk in the department unlawfully harassed and spied on them and other blacks and on the black-owned radio station WLIB last year.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Get Even in Final
description: The Los Angeles Lakers still have their backs against the wall, but they gave themselves some breathing room tonight with a 108-96 victory over the Detroit Pistons to tie the National Basketball Association final series at one game each.

title: Where the Paintings Are on Exhibit
description: Paintings of the Hudson River School - by Thomas Cole, Asher B. Durand, Frederick Edwin Church, Jasper Cropsey, Albert Bierstadt and company - are not in short supply at institutions in and around New York City.

title: 7 ALLIED NATIONS TO AVOID DISCORD AT SUMMIT TALKS
description: Wary of rattling the financial markets or upsetting the economy during the American election campaign, officials of the leading industrial democracies say they plan to focus on several noncontentious issues at their annual economic summit conference.

title: Soviet Troupe Arrives Without a Job
description: Twenty-three members of the Maly Theater of Leningrad arrived in New York City from Toronto yesterday, frustrated that the production they expected to offer at the First New York International Festival of the Arts had been canceled.

title: CDI Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,639,000 for an accounting change. c-Includes a gain of $1,299,000 on the sale of land.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Job for Fuel Expert
description: In light of the current international surplus of natural gas and petroleum products, the Reagan Administration has been less than enthusiastic about promoting synthetic fuels. But there are countries that have few resources and therefore pursue development of synthetic fuels. One is East Germany.

title: METS HAMSTRUNG BY SERIES OF INJURIES
description: ''Where does it leave us?'' Dave Johnson asked, trying to assess the damage after three games in St. Louis. ''A little banged-up.''

title: Qaddafi Among the Arabs: Speaking the Unspeakable
description: He wore a white glove on his right hand to avoid soiling it by shaking hands with Arab traitors.

title: Rules in the Wright Case
description: Following is the text of the clauses in House rule XLIII that are cited in Representative Newt Gingrich's complaint against Speaker Jim Wright. Clause 3

title: A History of Corrosion at Points 15B-17B
description: Just west of Wythe Avenue in Brooklyn, high above the scattered tenement buildings and factories of the Brooklyn waterfront, is a 60-foot cross-section of the Williamsburg Bridge known on the engineering maps as panel points 15B through 17B.

title: A Decade of '20/20'
description: ABC's ''20/20'' is 10 years old this week and is celebrating with a birthday special tonight at 9. The two-hour retrospective offers representative clips from the series that became ABC's first regularly scheduled prime-time news hour. Although never coming close to the top-10 success and profits of CBS's ''60 Minutes,'' the ''20/20'' format has found a steady and respectable ratings niche for itself over the years. As students of memorable television disasters will attest, the show's survival could hardly have been predicted on the basis of its June 6, 1978, premiere.

title: Review/Film; Hitting the Highway
description: In an 80's twist on Jack Kerouac's myth of the open road, ''Candy Mountain'' presents the least self-reflective hero ever to hit the highway. Julius (Kevin O'Connor) is a sometime guitarist and a persistent con man, hired to track down a reclusive, brilliant guitar maker named Elmore Silk. The directors, Robert Frank and Rudy Wurlitzer (who also wrote the screenplay), set Julius traveling on the fringes of society, for the film asserts, in its lighthearted, unpretentious way, that the spirit of our times can be found in those margins. It turns out to be a sardonic spirit, embodied in Julius's mercenary quest for a guru who refuses to dispense wisdom.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Congressional action on two health bills carried an erroneous figure in some copies for the Senate vote on a measure providing Federal funds for Medicare patients with catastrophic illness. The vote was 86 to 11 in favor, not 87 to 11.

title: Restaurants
description: Manhattan Ocean Club

title: Ex-Manager of a Welfare Hotel Is to Be Jailed
description: The former manager of the Holland Hotel - one of the most troubled welfare hotels in New York City - will be jailed for contempt for violating an agreement reached last year to improve security at the hotel, a housing judge said yesterday.

title: Second Deadline Is Set for Lilco Pact
description: Governor Cuomo, unhappy with the pace of negotiations over the details of the state's agreement with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, today set a deadline of next Wednesday for his negotiators to finish the job.

title: Debt Meeting Is Canceled
description: The Mexican Government has abruptly canceled a meeting between President Miguel de la Madrid, Reagan Administration officials and private bankers, foreign officials in Mexico said yesterday.

title: Domingo in the Park
description: Placido Domingo, the Metropolitan Opera tenor, will give a free concert of love songs from musical comedies and operettas at 8 P.M. on July 11 on the Great Lawn of Central Park. The program will be the final event of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. Eugene Kohn will conduct the American Symphony Orchestra. There will be cameo appearances by the singers Rosario Andvade, Gloria Estefan and Linda Ronstadt. The rain date is July 12, but Miss Ronstadt will not be able to appear on that day.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY BRIDGE AS ART GALLERY

title: Market Place; Can the Gap Be On the Rebound?
description: CAN the Gap Inc., one of the most spectacular stars in American apparel retailing but with one of the most depressed stocks in the wake of Oct. 19, be bouncing back?

title: Festival Events
description: For a recorded complete list of events, the number in New York is (212) 587-1111; from outside New York State, (800) 782-4369. Tickets are available from the individual theaters. AMERICAN BALLET THEATER, Saturday, 8 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; 362-6000. ''A CABARET FOR COLE,'' Sunday, 7:30 P.M., Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street; 840-2824. NATIONAL DANCE INSTITUTE, ''A Day in the Life of Coney Island,'' first preview, Sunday, 8 P.M., Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden. Box office, 563-8130; Teletron, 947-5850. BECKETT'S ''I'LL GO ON,'' Previews, Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center; 239-6200.

title: Ira L. Tilzer, Tax Lawyer, 74
description: Ira L. Tilzer, a tax lawyer and a former regional counsel to the criminal tax division of the Internal Revenue Service, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island. He was 74 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: About Real Estate; Historic Archive Building Restored for Rental Use
description: The building is historic: it was finished in 1899 and is a recognized landmark. It is enormous: it is the largest structure in Greenwich Village, with red brick walls that are three feet thick at the base. And it is tall: from its 11th-floor penthouses, New Jersey's Watchung Mountains and the Palisades may be seen on a clear day.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: Shortly after he joined Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler a decade ago, Richard D. Parsons appeared on behalf of Nelson A. Rockefeller at a meeting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. On hand when he arrived were two museum lawyers, Herbert Brownell and Ashton Hawkins, and some of their assistants. Mr. Parsons took his seat, only to notice that everyone's eyes remained fixed on the door.

title: Mountain Medical Equipment Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Note Offering Set By Unit of Xerox
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation, is offering $100 million in three-year notes through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: British Telecommunication PLC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt (ADR) and each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. All results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated at an exchange rate of $1.89 to the pound, the rate prevailing on March 31, 1988.

title: New York Must Keep Insurance-Rate Restraints
description: To the Editor:

title: The Time to Finish Start: Now
description: Conventional wisdom now holds that it's too difficult to resolve the remaining issues in the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks before the Reagan Administration ends. But just because the issues are complicated doesn't mean a treaty is beyond reach. The ultimate prize is well worth the strain: an agreement that cuts long-range nuclear forces nearly in half.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Sharp Electronics Plans Systemwide Campaign
description: Sharp Electronics, the Japanese company whose unit sales of many office products top the industry, is prepared to mount a $12 million umbrella advertising campaign that for the first time will unite its business systems divisions.

title: Key West Journal; Isle Basks in Success, But the Fun Is Fading
description: Just about everything in Key West is booming these days, but ''Margaritaville,'' the name the singer Jimmy Buffett gave this island, is kind of wasting away.

title: Chock Full O' Nuts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an unrealized gain in equity investments of $372,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter, and an unrealized loss on equity investments of $2,974,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes gains, net of tax, on sale of 50 percent interest in real estate of $1,935,000, or 29 cents a share, for the three months, and $1.9 million, or 30 cents a share, for the 9 months. Both 1988 and 1987 includes results of Greenwich Mills Company from Dec. 30, 1986, date of acquisition. Share earnings gives effect to 3 percent stock dividend to stockholders of record on July 8, 1988.

title: Dow Falls 9.60 as Rally in Blue Chips Fades
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday in continued heavy trading as a late rally in blue-chip issues fizzled. The Dow Jones industrial average, which struggled all day, finally closed at 2,093.35, down 9.60 points.

title: Overachieving at Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: International Container Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Drexel Burnham to Move To New Headquarters in '93
description: A year and a half after it abandoned plans to move into 7 World Trade Center, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that in 1993 it would move to a new world headquarters building to be built on West Street, just north of the Vista International Hotel in lower Manhattan.

title: Video Executive Indicted for Aid To a Hart Drive
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a videotape entrepreneur today for making more than $200,000 in illegal contributions to Gary Hart's 1984 Presidential campaign and later to the 1986 campaigns of several candidates for the Senate and the House.

title: Beijing Warns Americans of Terrorist Threat
description: China has warned the United States Embassy here that terrorists from another country may be planning attacks on Americans living in the Chinese capital, the embassy said today.

title: Yes, Mr. Buckley, There's an Indian Lit.
description: LEAD: It was one of those rare conversations on TV, the kind that makes you long for the day when the medium is no longer obsessed with ratings. William F. Buckley Jr. and the philosopher Mortimer Adler sparred on ''Firing Line'' over the state of higher education in America. As you would expect, William Bennett, Allan Bloom, the new Stanford course, elitism, sexism and the problems of cultural relativism fig-ured in the rich dialogue.

title: 46th Street 'Restaurant Row' Starts Guardian Angel Patrol
description: A group of proprietors on Restaurant Row in New York City, distressed over a decline in business that they blame on a surge in the crack trade and inadequate police protection, has recruited the Guardian Angels to patrol their neighborhood.

title: The Media Business; Paper Tested In Washington
description: The Washington Times, a daily morning newspaper, has begun test-marketing the capital's first afternoon newspaper in seven years.

title: Review/Film; 2 Buddies, A Murder And Love
description: Sean Connery is a fine actor under any circumstances, but he doesn't do much acting in ''The Presidio,'' which opens today at Loews 84th Street and other theaters. What he does is to recite his lines while staring over Mark Harmon's shoulder. For his part, Mr. Harmon does much the same thing, staring past Mr. Connery to deliver the other half of the leading men's back-and-forth banter in a style that the director Peter Hyams obviously intends as gutsy and crisp. There's a blowhard side to this tough stuff, too, since in one scene Mr. Connery fends off a large barroom bully using nothing but his thumb.

title: Campeau Sets Sale of Unit
description: The Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 22 Filene's Basement stores to an investment group led by the discount chain's management and three investment bankers. The price was not disclosed.

title: Ultimate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
National Hardgoods Distribuors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: KEY RATES
RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Bubka Vaults Record: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his world record in the pole vault yesterday, clearing 19 feet 10 1/4 inches in an International Amateur Athletic Federation Grand Prix meet in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia. Bubka's leap surpassed the mark of 19-9 1/4 he set last June 23 at Prague. He cleared the record height on his first attempt, the CTK news agency said. (AP) Tennis Cash and Connors Upset: Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, was upset in the third round of the $385,000 Stella Artois championship by a fellow Australian, Darren Cahill, 7-6, 6-4. The tournament also lost Jimmy Connors, the No. 3 seed, who lost, 6-4, 7-6, to Guy Forget of France. Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the No. 2 seed, rallied to defeat Johan Kriek, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2. Boris Becker, Wimbledon champion in 1985 and 1986, also won, stopping Bill Scanlon, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Shriver Gains: Top-seeded Pam Shriver of the United States began her quest for a fifth consecutive title in the Dow Classic tournament in Telford, England, with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over Elizabeth Smylie of Australia. Matches were moved indoors after rain made the grass courts at Edgbaston in Birmingham slippery. Second-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany and third-seeded Lori McNeil of the United States also won. Kohde-Kilsch defeated Elizabeth Minter of Australia, 6-0, 6-2, and McNeil downed Ann Henricksson of the United States, 7-6, 6-4. (AP) Cycling Hampsten Widens Lead: Andrew Hampsten won the 18th stage of the Tour of Italy to widen his overall lead and move to the brink of becoming the first American to capture the prestigious race. Hampsten won the 18-kilometer, uphill, against-the-clock leg from Levico Terme to Valico del Vetriolo in 43 minutes 37 seconds. Second and third places went to Italy's Roberto Visentini and Flavio Giupponi, who trailed by 32 and 40 seconds, respectively. Switzerland's Urs Zimmerman was fourth, 52 seconds back, and Hampsten's main challenger, Eric Breukink of the Netherlands, finished 1:04 back. Hampsten, who went into the stage with a 42-second lead over Breukink, widened the advantage to 2:05 with only three legs left. (AP) Golf Gowan Leads: Caroline Gowan sank a 95-yard shot for an eagle and chipped in to save par on the way to a 5-under-par 67 and the first-round lead at the LPGA Tour's Rochester International. Danielle Ammaccapane and Sherri Steinhauer were tied for second at 68, one shot back. Gowan, of Greenville, S.C., had the eagle, five birdies and two bogeys on the 6,182-yard Locust Hill Country Club course. (AP) Goalby Ahead by 1: Bob Goalby overcame a slow start to shoot a 66 and take a one-stroke lead over Bob Charles after the opening round of the Senior Tournament Players Championship in Ponte Vedre Beach, Fla. Goalby climbed the leaderboard with four birdies and an eagle after he matched par for the first seven holes on the 6,646-yard T.P.C. Valley Course at Sawgrass Country Club. His 6-under-par total is a personal-best since a 1982 back injury that forced him off the Senior PGA Tour for six months. (AP)

title: Jacob M. Miller, Lawyer, 79
description: Jacob M. Miller, a retired lawyer and health planning consultant, died of cancer Tuesday at the Community Hospice at Camelot in Sun City, Ariz. He was 79 years old and lived in Sun City.

title: BUSINESSES SEE '88 RISE IN OUTLAYS
description: Enjoying a boom in export sales, the nation's businesses plan to modernize and expand at the fastest rate in four years, according to a Government survey.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $1,205,516, or 27 cents a share. c-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $143,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Review/Film; 'They're He-eere!' Again
description: ''Poltergeist III'' is made much ghostlier by the death last February of its 12-year-old star, Heather O'Rourke, than by anything that happens on the screen. The setting this time is an impersonally modern high-rise building complex in Chicago, where little Carol Anne (Miss O'Rourke) has been packed off to live with her Uncle Bruce (Tom Skerritt) and Aunt Patricia (Nancy Allen). Carol Anne, who cried out the famous ''They're he-eere!'' that earned the first ''Poltergeist'' its place in history, is still being hotly pursued by whatever it is that blamed her family for building houses on a favorite graveyard.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Brassy Bernhard

title: INSIDE
description: Walsh to Try North First

title: Sports People; Islanders Sign Juniors
description: The Islanders have signed three junior-hockey league prospects, Rob Dimaio, Dean Chynoweth and Kerry Clark.

title: The Law; Once Again, 'Billy Budd' Is Standing Trial
description: It is a story of innocence and evil, of crime and punishment, of rationality and insanity, of motives tainted and pure. In short, material that lawyers thrive on, and since it was published posthumously in 1924, ''Billy Budd, Sailor'' has gripped the collective imagination of the bar.

title: V.A. Halts Bonus Payments To Appeals Board Members
description: Facing Congressional criticism and a court challenge, the Veterans Administration said today that it had discontinued a system of bonus payments to members of an appeals board that rules on veterans' claims for benefits.

title: Officials Urge a Wide Military Role in Drug Fight
description: Several state and local officials, including Mayor Koch of New York, urged Congress today to take whatever legislative and budget steps were necessary to assure a significant role for the military in efforts to halt the smuggling of drugs into the United States.

title: The Legacy of the Hudson River School
description: In 1825, Thomas Cole went to the Catskill Mountains to paint their rugged cliffs and streams. It was the birth of the Hudson River School of painting, which flourished until the turn of the 20th century and which has now come back into vogue.

title: Health-Care Expertise Benefiting Head of IC
description: Karl D. Bays, the chairman and chief executive of IC Industries, has begun applying his health-care expertise to the $4 billion consumer goods and services company's search for acquisitions.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Release of Ex-Prisoners By Hanoi Is Discussed
description: The Vietnamese Foreign Minister said today that Vietnam and the United States had begun discussions on the fate of tens of thousands of former Vietnamese political prisoners and their families.

title: Company News; SLM Action Sports Buys Coleco Units
description: Coleco Industries has sold its swimming pool and snow goods divisions to SLM Action Sports Inc. of Morrisville, N.C., for an undisclosed price. The deal included a 315,000-square-foot factory in Mayfield, N.Y.

title: Home of U.S. Ambassador In Peru Is Hit by Mortar Fire
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked the United States Ambassador's residence with mortar fire today, damaging the roof but causing no injuries, officials said.

title: Edward Kramer, 75, Ex-Union Officer, Dies
description: Edward Kramer, a former vice president and general manager of the Eastern region of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died Wednesday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital of injuries sustained in an automobile accident and what was apparently a stroke. He was 75 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Boy Dies and a 2d Is Injured When a Stolen Auto Crashes
description: A 15-year-old boy who was driving a stolen auto was killed last night when the car hit a telephone pole at the corner of 56th Road and Laurel Hill Boulevard near Calvary Cemetery in Woodside, Queens, the police said.

title: Futures/Options; Soybean And Grain Prices Rise
description: Grain and soybean prices rebounded yesterday, despite the scattered showers that fell across sections of the still-parched Midwest in recent days.

title: Look! See! A Children's Book Show
description: Quick! Who wrote ''Mary Poppins''? ''Winnie-the-Pooh''? ''Can a Pig Fly?''?

title: Soccer Alert: The British (Fans) Are Coming!
description: With the European national soccer championships beginning Friday in Dusseldorf, the residents of West Germany and battalions of police are girding for the least-welcome tourists from Britain: English soccer hooligans.

title: Company News; Unions May Back Sale of Rowntree
description: Britain's three leading trade unions have conditionally agreed to support a foreign takeover of the British candy company Rowntree P.L.C. In a joint statement the unions said they preferred that Rowntree remain British but they would back a friendly takeover if jobs were not threatened. The unions - the Transport and General Workers; the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers; and the General, Municipal and Boilermakers Union - are now seeking a meeting with Rowntree executives to discuss their position.

title: On Stage
description: Producers Playing Mother

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Council Maps $214 Million In Budget Cuts
description: The New York City Council, having spurned Mayor Koch's request for a $150 million tax increase to balance his budget, has now drafted a list of $214 million in possible spending cuts that would eliminate most of Mr. Koch's new programs for the coming fiscal year.

title: American Healthcare Management reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Diner's Journal
description: Brazil 2000

title: Jackson Says He Is Best Choice for Vice President
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson described himself today as the Democratic Party's best choice for Vice President but said that the selection of a running mate was ''only one item on a long list of concerns'' that he wants to discuss with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Western Union Suit
description: A former top executive of the Western Union Corporation set up a network of ''double agents'' to establish a rival to the troubled telecommunications company and used his position to steal Latin American business from it, Western Union contends.

title: CANADA PACT MAY LOSE URANIUM AID
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they would probably drop a controversial proposal for uranium subsidies from the Canadian free trade agreement.

title: COMPANY NEWS: BRIEFS
description: Arkansas Best Corp., Fort Smith, Ark., a freight transportation company, rejected Razorback Acquisition Corp.'s revised tender offer of $23 a share.

title: TEXACO PAPERS UNSEALED
description: Texaco Inc.'s second-largest shareholder, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, considered selling its stake several times, and Carl C. Icahn, the oil company's biggest shareholder, once tried to bring in the Canadian investor Marc Belzberg to buy the investment firm's holdings, according to court papers unsealed today.

title: Unfamiliar Golfers Swing to the Top
description: He has not won since he joined the PGA Tour in 1980, and he has never finished better than 83d on the money list. He missed the cut in six of his last seven tournaments. And in the one event in which he made the cut, he finished tied for 47th.

title: Ex-Banker Is Convicted
description: The former chairman of a Connecticut savings bank was convicted in a Federal District Court in New Haven yesterday of insider trading and wire and mail fraud.

title: Gentile Accuses Rival of Hurting An Investigation
description: The Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, said yesterday that a political opponent who asserted he had been followed by detectives from Mr. Gentile's office knew that the detectives were staking out organized-crime figures.

title: At 35/ an Hour, How're Ya Gonna Keep'em Down on the Dairy Farm?
description: The bank was not foreclosing and their crops had not failed, but Ken and Teresa Sayward's farm equipment and dairy herd were up for auction. After 16 years the Saywards were giving up farming, the vocation of Mr. Sayward's father and of his father before him.

title: Paul R. Reynolds, Literary Agent For Many Top Writers, Dies at 83
description: Paul R. Reynolds, a literary agent whose career spanned more than half a century, died yesterday in Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: A Pillow to Discourage Sleepers From Snoring
description: Peter Sandler, founder of Thera-P-Cushion Inc. in Markham, Ontario, has patented an anti-snoring pillow. ''It has a success rate of 82 percent,'' said Mr. Sandler, who is wrapping up more than a year of market testing.

title: Chrysler Planning Layoffs in Kenosha
description: A four-week layoff for 1,200 production workers for the Chrysler Corporation in Kenosha will start Aug. 1 because of a shortage of steel and other materials. Doug Nicoll, Chrysler's public relations manager for manufacturing, said the shortage had resulted from a switch in plans for building Dodge Omnis and Plymouth Horizons in Kenosha. Chrysler had announced in January it would halt such production in mid-July, putting 5,500 employees out of work.

title: A BOULEVARD TRIES TO RECAPTURE MAJESTY
description: Along the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, an era of aspiration can be discerned in the names inscribed on apartment buildings: the Majestic Court, the Royal Terrace, the Augusta Arms, the Grand-View.

title: TV Again Put Spotlight on the News Business in 'Inside Story'; Where Editorials Began
description: To the Editor:

title: Guitar Duo
description: Pasquale Bianculli and Harris Becker, a guitar duo, are to play music by Bach, Carulli, Sor and Rovics at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street, at 4 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $15. Information: 595-0862.

title: Jungle Out There
description: There is a heavy infestation of obnoxious and unpleasant people in television commercials this season. Since advertising people know more about us than we know about ourselves, it probably means we have changed in some important way recently.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Favorite Stocks chart in Business Day yesterday, with the article about the stock market, included outdated prices. Instead of Wednesday's closing prices, it should have used Thursday's, which did appear in the stock market tables.

title: White House to Ask Approval For Sale of F-18's to Kuwait
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to sell F-18 warplanes, the most sophisticated American fighter-bombers, to Kuwait and will seek Congressional approval, the White House said today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Norway Reaches Pact With Israel to Inspect Nuclear Chemical
description: Norway and Israel have resolved their differences over a Norwegian shipment of heavy water, a chemical that can be used in making nuclear weapons, Norwegian officials said today.

title: Cheever's Widow Wins One Round in Book Suit
description: A Federal judge on Thursday upheld the right of Mary W. Cheever, the widow of John Cheever, to bring suit to prevent a Chicago publishing house from printing ''The Uncollected Short Stories of John Cheever'' in September.

title: Lincoln Center Sale
description: The New York Public Library at Lincoln Center will hold a sale called ''Mostly Music'' outdoors at Lincoln Center plaza from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. today. Items include vocal and miniature scores, chamber and piano music, records, sheet music and books. The proceeds of event, sponsored by Library Supporters, will benefit the library. Information: 870-1613.

title: U.S. Panel's Chief Urges Better Image for Nurses
description: LEAD: The head of a Federal commission studying the nursing shortage said yesterday that the image of nurses as second-class citizens must be changed to help solve the problem.

title: Peer Review for Speaker Wright
description: The House Ethics Committee had little choice but to start a preliminary investigation into charges of misconduct against Speaker Jim Wright. That's not because all six charges are weighty - some are stale and discredited. But few of them can be disposed of without gathering records and testimony, including testimony from the Speaker himself. All of them would best be handled under the direction of an outside counsel who's not subordinate to the most powerful member of the House.

title: Seattle Integration Plan Aims to Cut Busing
description: School board officials say that the number of students bused for desegregation here will be cut in half by 1989 under a system that emphasizes integration within certain neighborhoods rather than in individual schools.

title: Jung Knew the Dangers of Pact With the Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: Airliner Sales To East Seen
description: European and United States aircraft groups are likely to get the go-ahead within the next few weeks for substantial sales of their high-technology airliners to East bloc countries, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Reviews/Music; Precision Saxophone
description: The alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe opened his first set on Wednesday night at the Village Vanguard (Seventh Avenue South near 11th Street), where he'll be performing through Sunday, with Thelonious Monk's pensive ballad, ''Ruby, My Dear.'' Accompanied only by his pianist, John Hicks, Mr. Blythe exhibited how precise he's become with nuance: he gave each note its own vibrato and texture until the entire melody seemed to quiver in the air. Leaving broad, open spaces of silence between notes, he read the melody as it should be read, like an intimate conversation between friends.

title: Slayer of Five Boys Is Executed in Utah By Injection of Drugs
description: A former Eagle Scout who sought his own execution for the sex-related murders of five boys was put to death today by injection.

title: Struggle and Hope in the New South
description: Spence + Lila By Bobbie Ann Mason Illustrations by LaNelle Mason. 176 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Roll-Call in Senate On Death Penalty
description: Following is the 65-29 roll-call vote by which the Senate approved legislation today permitting the death penalty for drug dealers convicted of murder Voting yes were 27 Democrats and 38 Republicans. Voting no were 23 Democrats and 6 Republicans. xxx denotes senators not voting.

title: Reviews/Music; Anne Francine Spoofs Herself In Cabaret Act
description: Anne Francine, the veteran actress who plays Mrs. Evangeline Harcourt in the Lincoln Center revival of ''Anything Goes,'' imbues her role of a starchy dowager with a welcome glint of antic merriment. And in her late-night cabaret act, which plays through next Saturday at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street), that glint becomes a beam of comic light. Miss Francine spoofs her own background as a Philadelphia debutante who still likes to kick up her heels.

title: With a Deal at Hand, Positions Hardened
description: The failure to conclude a peace agreement to end the conflict in Nicaragua came after rebel leaders hardened their position in response to mixed political signals from the Sandinista Government.
