title: Sculptures That Frolic in the Wind
description: A circus came to town last week -a troupe of 10 acrobatic pieces of kinetic sculpture called ''Windcircus.'' The delicately balanced, finely engineered metal sculpture, which has been traveling around the world in a standard shipping container, was assembled in the Austin J. Tobin Plaza of the World Trade Center, where the works will spin, dip and rise in the updrafts of the Twin Towers through July 15. The sculpture, created by Susumu Shingu of Japan, left Kobe, Japan, in March 1987; Manhattan is the first stop of its cross-country American tour.

title: New Device To Block TV Commercials
description: ALBERT P. NOVAK'S quest to kill television commercials continues. Five years ago, the inventor in Goldens Bridge, N.Y., patented a device that lets a viewer electronically mark any undesirable commercial as it crosses the screen. If the ad comes across again, the device automatically blocks it out.

title: Blood and Money in Salvador
description: LEAD: On Feb. 26, Salvadoran Army troops seized Felix Antonio Rivera, 25 years old, and Mario Cruz Rivera, 16, from the small village of Tepemechin, in the northeastern department of Morazan. After forcing them to run barefoot through a burning field, the soldiers tortured and killed them within earshot of a farmer, who described hearing their cries of agony followed by shots.

title: Glenda Brawley Moves To a Brooklyn Church
description: Glenda Brawley, who took refuge in a Queens church Wednesday to avoid arrest by Dutchess County authorities, moved to a Brooklyn church yesterday.

title: DUKAKIS RESTATES POSITION ON ISRAEL
description: Michael S. Dukakis restated today his support for moving the American Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, despite sharp criticism of the position from Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Company News; Texaco Weighs Plan to Alter Board
description: Texaco Inc. is considering a new process for nominating outside directors that would put representatives of institutional investors on its board.

title: Bush Traces How Yale Differs From Harvard
description: The Yale man was asked how he could make fun of the Harvard man for having a ''boutique'' foreign policy born at an Ivy League school.

title: Your Money; Investment Fraud Can Be Avoided
description: WHEN clients of Roberto C. Polo sued the suave, internationally known financier, contending that he had diverted some $130 million for his own use, other investors had reason to pause.

title: Fix the Bridge? Get a Second Opinion
description: On the advice of a panel of engineers he set up last August, Mayor Koch wants to repair the main span and cables of the Williamsburg Bridge and replace its approach roads and walkways. Before New York and Washington pour millions into a huge and possibly short-lived repair job, taxpayers, motorists and subway riders are entitled to the opinion of Federal bridge and highway engineers.

title: Nynex Reaches Deal For AGS Computers
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the professional services and software products businesses of AGS Computers Inc. Under the agreement, shareholders of AGS will receive $21 in cash plus a share of Microamerica Inc., an AGS subsidiary, for each share of AGS common stock.

title: E. G. Higdon, Ex-Maytag Chairman, 79
description: E. G. Higdon, retired chairman and chief executive of the Maytag Company, died of complications of Parkinson's disease Tuesday at his home in Wilsonille, Ore. He was 79 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Company News report in Business Day on Thursday about the Pannill Knitting Company misstated details of the Sara Lee Corporation's offer in some editions. Sara Lee is seeking 50 percent of Pannill's stock, not a full takeover. In addition, the status of the Adams-Millis Corporation was misstated. The company is being acquired by its chairman, James H. Millis Sr., and his family for $77 million, surpassing bids by Sara Lee and other parties.

title: Company News; McKesson Adding Drug Wholesaler
description: The McKesson Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Northwestern Drug Company, a privately held independent drug wholesaler based in Auburn, Wash., about 20 miles south of Seattle. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

title: South Africa Widens Curbs on Press
description: The South African Government disclosed details today of a new emergency decree tightening the clamp on the reporting of anti-apartheid protests.

title: Public Seen as More Informed About Children With AIDS
description: AIDS education is paying off, with more than two-thirds of adults who were recently surveyed saying that children with AIDS should be allowed to attend school with other children, the American Medical Association said today.

title: Jung Knew the Dangers of Pact With the Nazis; Self-Incrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: For Heirs of the Persecuted, Power
description: After Prime Minister Michel Rocard announced his first Cabinet last month, some took it as a sign of the priority he gave to higher learning that his Education Minister, Lionel Jospin, was ranked first in terms of protocol. But then others recalled that when Mr. Rocard had been a leader of a Protestant youth group, Mr. Jospin had been a member of his troop.

title: Pravda Reports Further Strikes By Armenians
description: Armenian strikes have paralyzed most industries in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region for nearly three weeks, creating food shortages and rising tension, Pravda reported today.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Hana Mandlikova of Australia, the top-seeded player in the Scottish Grasscourt championships in Edinburgh, withdrew yesterday because of a stomach virus and said she would probably also skip the Wimbledon tuneup at Eastbourne, England, next week. . . . The Atlanta Braves placed the catcher-first baseman Ted Simmons on the 15-day disabled list and signed a veteran third baseman, Jim Morrison.

title: 11-Year-Old Develops A Brush for Chain Saws
description: The Patent Office recognized a young inventor this week, awarding patent 4,748,745 to Richard G. Woodbridge, 11 years old, of Princeton, N.J., for his design of a brush to clear excess sawdust from chain saw cuts. ''When you cut a log, the sawdust builds up and makes the chain saw jam,'' he explained. ''I thought, why not put on one of those brushes you see on snow scrapers?''

title: Ban on Japanese Fishing Left Standing by Justices
description: The Supreme Court has left standing an injunction barring Japanese fleets from salmon fishing with nine-mile-long nets in an area off the Alaska coast.

title: Europeans Are Safer Drivers Than We Are
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Should Continue to Elect Its Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore May Endorse Dukakis Next Week
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., the only former Democratic Presidential candidate who has not made a formal endorsement, may give Gov. Michael S. Dukakis his support next week, a Gore aide said today.

title: IT'S BACK TO HIS AND HERS
description: It's June, and with wedding bells ringing again, can joint ownership be far behind?

title: ROBERTS TAKES ONE-SHOT LEAD
description: Loren Roberts, Bill Buttner, Brandel Chamblee and Steve Elkington have a total of 50 PGA Tour starts this year and only 24 finishes. Collectively, they have missed the cut 26 times.

title: BONDS FOLLOW SWINGS IN COMMODITY PRICES
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities posting small gains and the intermediate sector unchanged to slightly lower. Treasury bill rates were essentially unchanged.

title: Dow Gains 8.36 but Remains Below 2,110
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved modestly higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 8.36 points to close at 2,101.71.

title: Wedtech Witness Admits Issuing Bad Checks
description: A former president of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday that he knowingly wrote checks for many thousands of dollars with insufficient funds in his account, even after agreeing to cooperate with the Government in the case.

title: Review/Piano; Fast and Forceful Fugue
description: Within the first few bars of his Tuesday evening piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall, Amiram Rigai made it clear that he had an ironclad technique, and an interpretive will to match. His opening work, Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue, was taken with extraordinary speed and forcefulness, and whatever one's ideas about Bach performance may be, it was hard not to be fascinated by his transformation of the fantasy into torrents of cascading phrases, and his rendering of the fugue as a thundering, cathartic drama.

title: Sports People; Speculation on Chaney
description: Don Chaney, an assistant coach with the Atlanta Hawks who was the coach of the Los Angeles Clippers for more than two seasons, seems likely to be named to replace Bill Fitch as coach of the Houston Rockets, according to reports in two Houston newspapers.

title: PUTTING SUZUKI SAMURAI TO THE TEST
description: ''We chose utility vehicles because we haven't done them in four years, and we had been getting a lot of letters from readers requesting tests,'' said Dr. R. David Pittle, the technical director of Consumer Reports. The testing of sport-utility vehicles followed customary procedures, according to executives at the magazine.

title: Company News; Dean Witter Revamping Unit
description: Dean Witter Financial Services Inc. said that it was restructuring its taxable fixed-income unit in an effort to improve the management of the unit's various divisions.

title: Beech-Nut Court Delay
description: The sentencing of Niels L. Hoyvald, former president and chief executive of the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation, and John F. Lavery, a former vice president of the company, has been put off until Thursday by Judge Thomas C. Platt in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. The two men were convicted in February of violating Federal law by intentionally distributing an inferior product while representing it as pure apple juice intended for babies. Their sentencing had been set for yesterday.

title: Delicate Shaping Begins On Democrats' Platform
description: A small group of Democrats began trying to write a party platform today, faced with the quadrennial problem of producing a document so general that all elements of the party can accept it but specific enough to distinguish Democratic views from those of Republicans.

title: Constantine Generales, Doctor, 79
description: Dr. Constantine D. J. Generales, a medical internist and a specialist in biomedical research and space medicine, died of heart disease Thursday at Doctors Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Israel Philharmonic Honors Bernstein
description: Leonard Bernstein has accepted a scroll naming him laureate conductor of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Reagan Assails Senate on Treaty Condition
description: In a statement to the Senate, President Reagan today assailed a condition on how treaties are to be interpreted that the Senate attached to the new missile accord. But Senate Democratics said that they had won the battle and that the President's objections were ''irrelevant.''

title: Subway Service Will Resume Over the Williamsburg Bridge
description: The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would resume subway service over the Williamsburg Bridge beginning at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Arms Official to Visit Central America
description: Under pressure from conservatives in Congress to seek additional contra aid after the collapse of Nicaraguan peace talks, the White House chose instead today to send a senior negotiator to Central America.

title: About New York; Calling for Peace The World Over, By Area Code
description: ''Hello.''

title: Herman Crook, 89, Harmonica Player, Of Grand Ole Opry
description: Herman Crook, a harmonica player who was the oldest member of the Grand Ole Opry, died today of a heart attack at Park View Medical Center. He was 89 years old.

title: RETURN OF EX-FINANCIAL CORP. CHEIF
description: You can't keep Charles W. Knapp down.

title: Sharansky to Speak On His Book and Life
description: Natan Sharansky will be at the 92d Street Y at 8 P.M. tomorrow to discuss his book, ''Fear No Evil,'' his life and his thoughts about human rights and the future of Soviet Jews.

title: From the Perspective of the Playpen
description: Carol Clements offered an evening of breezy entertainment on Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Ms. Clements's eager, puckering little face is amusing, and she sees life through a cheerfully jaundiced haze. But like the proverbial Chinese dinner, the program's three pieces were light to the point of insubstantiality.

title: MACMILLAN REVAMPING IS BLOCKED
description: A Delaware Chancery Court judge yesterday temporarily blocked a planned restructuring by Macmillan Inc. as it was about to begin.

title: Curb on 'No-Load' Funds Planned
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a controversial rule change that would significantly limit the fees that ''no-load,'' or no-charge, mutual funds are allowed to pass on to their shareholders.

title: Israel Seizes Palestinian in Attack on Arab Mayor
description: The Israeli security police have arrested a Palestinian and demolished his home in a West Bank refugee district, saying he confessed to attacking an Israeli-appointed Arab mayor on Tuesday, the army said today.

title: Review/Jazz; Spirit of Basie in a New Band
description: The recent debut of the Gene Harris All Star Big Band on a Concord Jazz Album called ''Tribute to Count Basie'' was particularly notable because it evoked the swinging spirit of the Basie band rather than attempting to duplicate the Basie arrangements.

title: Marchers for Reunification Are Halted by South Korea
description: A march to the border by South Korean students for a meeting with their North Korean counterparts failed today when tens of thousands of riot policemen blocked their path.

title: 'Comedy of Errors'
description: A production of Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors'' this weekend in Prospect Park in Brooklyn will open a free series of outdoor Shakespeare by the Kings County Shakespeare Company. The performances are today and tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. at the Vale of Cashmere Lawn, reachable by the Grand Army Plaza entrance to the park. The production will be presented at other locations in the park and at the nearby Botanic Garden through July 10. A second production, ''The Winter's Tale,'' is planned in August. Information: (718) 596-9685.

title: Business Digest: Saturday, June 11, 1988
description: The Economy

title: EXPOS FORCE DARLING TO RETIRE EARLY
description: For a change, the Mets didn't hit any baseballs off the roof of Olympic Stadium tonight.

title: NEW YORK FINDS MORE CASH TO NARROW GAP IN REVENUE
description: Mayor Koch's budget director said yesterday that there was nearly enough money left unspent by New York City agencies in the fiscal year that ends June 30 to meet an unexpectedly large shortfall in tax revenue.

title: Review/Dance; A Touch of the New In Works From the Past
description: Several sets of unusual ballet debuts took place Wednesday. In the evening, Jerome Robbins's ''Fancy Free'' by the New York City Ballet saw a new and amusingly matched trio of sailors marked by a striking disparity in height. And in the afternoon, Julio Bocca, with two hours' notice, stepped in as Albrecht in American Ballet Theater's ''Giselle.''

title: Home Burglar Alarms That Are Only for Show
description: Home burglar alarms often cost $2,000 installed. Michael Krasik of Seattle has patented a fake alarm called Scarecrow that costs considerably less.

title: HOW CONSUMERS UNION PUTS TEETH INTO 'LET THE SELLER BEWARE'
description: When Consumers Union announced 10 days ago that the Suzuki Samurai sport-utility vehicle had failed its track test, the whole country paused to listen.

title: Quake Hits Parts of California
description: An earthquake jolted a large area of cental and Southern California today, temporarily closing a vital aqueduct and catapulting rocks onto Interstate 5.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a faculty dispute at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst misidentified the chancellor. He is Joseph D. Duffey.

title: Hepatitis Test Urged in All Pregnancies
description: Federal health officials have recommended that all pregnant women be tested for type B hepatitis and that newborns of infected women be vaccinated.

title: Company News; Sunbeam Interest
description: The investment bank Rothschild Inc. said that an unnamed client might be interested in buying the Sunbeam subsidiary of Allegheny International Inc. New York-based Rothschild made the statement in a routine filing in United States Bankruptcy Court about possible conflicts of interest. Lawyers representing unsecured creditors of Allegheny International, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, want to hire Rothschild to advise them on the Pittsburgh consumer products company. Allegheny is locked in a proxy fight with a group of dissident shareholders, led by the investment firm Spear, Leeds and Kellogg.

title: Terror at the Theater
description: John David Earnest's ''Tales of Terror and Murder,'' a musical theater piece set to a text by Mervin Goldstein and Alice B. Toklas, is to have its world premiere at 8 P.M. tomorrow at the Advent Lutheran Church, Broadway at 93d Street. Also on the program are Thomas Turner's ''There Will Come Soft Rains,'' Robert Starer's ''Mystic Trumpeter,'' and a group of bandstand standards by Sousa, Youmans and others. The performers are Judith Otten, soprano; Frank Hosticka, trumpeter, and William Vaughn Jones, pianist. Tickets are $10. Information: 787-0517.

title: From Squalor to Showcase: How a Group of Tenants Won Out
description: A decade ago the Cochran Gardens public housing development here was a squalid den for narcotics dealers. There were bullet holes in the walls and pools of urine in the hallways. The tenants, most of them welfare recipients, were virtual prisoners of the 12-building complex, and the city wanted to tear it down.

title: Chemical Fire Pollutes Loire
description: The Government cut off drinking water to 200,000 people after cancer-causing pollutants from a chemical fire flowed into the Loire River, the authorities said today. An explosion and fire Wednesday night at the Protex factory in Auzouer-en-Touraine, 15 miles northeast of Tours, injured one person and sent phenol and metallic pollutants into the Brenne, a tributary of the Loire. Protex produces synthetic carpets and other floor coverings.

title: Help for the High Court
description: Quietly, almost surreptitiously, Congress has passed a historic little bill that gives the Supreme Court nearly total power to hear only those cases it deems important. It's a valuable change even though most Americans may not directly feel its impact. Its most immediate benefit may be a moratorium on more drastic proposals to deal with the Court's caseload.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Bonn Trade Surplus Cut
description: West Germany announced today that its current account and trade data for March were better than expected.

title: God and Man in Moscow
description: An extraordinary gathering of world religious leaders assembled in atheist Moscow this week to celebrate a true millennium - the 1,000th anniversary of the Russian Orthodox Church. Participants included Cardinal O'Connor of New York, the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Vatican's Secretary of State and the Rev. Billy Graham.

title: Thanks to Me, Dukakis Made It
description: Could Michael S. Dukakis have won the Democratic nomination without my help?

title: BRIDGE
description: At the end of a long hard-fought match, most players can cite a deal that gives them a warm euphoric glow when they think about it.

title: Guardian Angels Are Praised For Cleaner Restaurant Row
description: There was a noticeable absence of crack smokers, panhandlers and transvestites yesterday along Restaurant Row, the stretch of 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where the red-bereted Guardian Angels have been on a round-the-clock patrol since Wednesday.

title: Defense Rests in Ex-Arizona Governor's Trial
description: The defense in the criminal trial of former Gov. Evan Mecham rested today without calling to the stand either Mr. Mecham or his brother Willard, who is a co-defendant.

title: A Cappella Choir
description: The Western Wind, an a cappella chamber choir, is to offer a program called ''The Western Wind Songbook: A Cabaret'' at 9:30 tonight at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The program, which is to include music by Perotin, Monteverdi, Gershwin, Kern and Glass, as well as barbershop quartet music and folk songs, is to be staged by Paul Lazarus. Tickets are $12 to $15. Information: 362-8719.

title: Apple's Chief Takes Time Off
description: Apple Computer Inc. said this week that John Sculley, its chairman and chief executive, would take a six-week paid sabbatical as well as three weeks' vacation at the end of the month.

title: Judge Dismisses Currency Count Against Senator
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a charge that State Senator Andrew Jenkins of Queens attempted to violate currency laws last year by accepting $150,000 from an undercover agent posing as a financier in a scheme to launder the money in Zaire.

title: INJURED YANKEES FALL TO ORIOLES
description: Rickey Henderson's ankle was buried in bandages, Don Mattingly's midsection was cinched with gauze, and Willie Randolph's leg and wrist were taped. As for the rest of the Yankees, they spent last night wrapped around Mike Boddicker's finger.

title: Company News; Lucky Set to Sell 38 Arizona Stores
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had agreed to sell its 38 supermarkets in Arizona to an affiliate of ABCO Markets for an undisclosed amount. The purchase will make ABCO, which is based in Phoneix, one of the three largest supermarket operators in the state, with 75 stores. ABCO is controlled by Odyssey Partners, a New York private investment group.

title: Company News; Digital Raises Computer Price
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, reacting to rising chip costs, lifted prices today on most of its computers and memory expansion products, a move that could spark a round of price rises by computer makers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 30 about a teen-ager with AIDS incorrectly described a service that helps runaways in Times Square. The service, Streetwork, is a project of the Victim Services Agency, a nonprofit organization.

title: Company News; Payless Studies Takeover Offer
description: Senior officials at Payless Cashways Inc. are exploring a leveraged buyout of the building materials retailer, the company says. But Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier, who is leading an investor group considering a takeover of Payless, said he planned to ask the company to share information so his group could consider a competing offer. Payless made the announcement in response to rumors that management was considering a buyout at $30 a share.

title: Token Clerks To Get Patrol To Bar Raids
description: The elevated subway station in Brooklyn was quiet and almost empty early yesterday when a man poured a flammable liquid into James Madden's token booth and threw in flaming matches in a horrifying replay of a similar token-booth attack that fatally burned a clerk a week ago.

title: Lawyer Sentenced in Robbery Case
description: A Long Island lawyer who was convicted of identifying three clients so they could be robbed by an organized-crime ring was sentenced yesterday to seven years in Federal prison.

title: Orange Crop Rise Seen
description: The nation's orange harvest for the 1987-88 crop year is estimated at 201 million boxes, 1 percent above last month's forecast and 10 percent over the level of a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

title: Ibuprofen to Be Used In Remedies for Colds
description: A New York City physician, Dr. Abraham Sunshine, and two partners have received seven patents to use the pain reliever ibuprofen in cough and cold remedies.

title: Strike Negotiations Resume After Nightlong Session
description: Striking writers and producers, after meeting through the night, resumed bargaining today, but declined to say whether they were nearing a settlement of the 14-week-old strike.

title: NATO BACKS LEVEL OF ARMS SPENDING
description: Members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today on the need to keep up the level of military spending even as they welcomed the relaxation of tensions between Washington and Moscow.

title: Companero Paul, of Harvard Law
description: As the search for peace in Nicaragua has intensified, Paul S. Reichler, an American lawyer who advises the Sandinista Government, has emerged as a key political figure here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Stalin's methods are dead today as far as the system of personal dictatorship and mass repressions. But they are still very much alive as the anti-democratic norm. The pale little Stalins are living among us.'' - Nikolai P. Popov, Soviet historian. [ 6:6. ]

title: Indoor Breezes
description: Many kinds of fans can provide indoor breezes in warm weather, as a pleasant alternative to air-conditioners. Floor fans are enclosed in box-shaped containers or in circular grilles. Either kind can be set on a table or a shelf, or mounted on a wall. Most circular fans can be set to oscillate, moving the breeze around a room. Standing fans on adjustable poles up to 60 inches high usually deliver the most powerful breeze. Window fans, made to be set in an open window, are often reversible and can exhaust inside air or bring fresh air from outside. Ceiling fans, which can be both decorative and functional, deliver a constant breeze. Almost all fans have several speeds. Small children should be kept away from fans and their controls. TYPE PRICE FEATURES Floor $20-70 Easy to move round Standing $35-100 Powerful; can cool open adjacent rooms Window Portable: $39-90 Best used with another Permanent: $200 open window for cross and up ventilation Ceiling $90 and up Quiet; require installation

title: STANFORD IN FINAL WITH ARIZONA STATE
description: With a nine-run sixth inning and a 23-hit attack, top-ranked Arizona State beat No. 4 Wichita State, 19-1, tonight and eliminated the Shockers from the College World Series.

title: Review/Books; Lifting a Bamboo Curtain in the U.S.
description: The New Chinatown By Peter Kwong 198 pages. Hill & Wang/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Washington vs. Cardoza
description: George Washington High School of Manhattan unleashed a 15-hit attack against Tottenville of Staten Island yesterday to win a Public Schools Athletic League semifinal, 11-3, at St. John's University field.

title: Sports People; Royal Request
description: Steffi Graf, who as the world's No. 1 female tennis player is often considered something of a monarch, held court with Diana, Princess of Wales, yesterday at the Vanderbilt Racquets Club in London, where a plaque was unveiled marking the opening of the European office of the Women's International Tennis Association.

title: In U.S.S.R., a Painful Prying At Roots of Stalin's Tyranny
description: Having arrived at an official consensus that Stalin was a tyrant, the Soviet Union has now begun grappling in public with the most painful question of its history: What made Stalin possible?

title: Man Opens Fire in a Midtown Disco, Wounding 9
description: A gunman opened fire on a crowded dance floor at a midtown discotheque early yesterday, slightly wounding nine people as scores of panicked customers fled into the street.

title: Suffolk Executive Vetoes a Bill For Workers at Video Terminals
description: The Suffolk County Executive today vetoed legislation that would have been the first in the nation to regulate the use of video-display terminals in the work place, saying it would economically isolate the county and cost it thousands of jobs.

title: Fire-Resistant Process For Blends of Fabric
description: Many consumers recall the controversy in the 1970's over Tris, a flame-retardant chemical used in textiles. The Consumer Product Safety Commission had ordered manufacturers of children's sleepwear to treat their products with it. But later, the Environmental Protection Agency linked Tris with cancer and banned the chemical.

title: Pre-employment Drug Tests Blocked by California Court
description: A lower court in California has issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting the publisher Matthew Bender & Company from requiring job applicants to submit to urine testing that can detect drug use.

title: Sports People; A Round in China
description: In another international match featuring an unusual pairing, Zhao Ziyang, chief of the Chinese Communist Party, attempted to match shots during nine holes of golf yesterday with Larry Nelson, the American who won the Professional Golfers Association Championship last year. The match was played at China's largest course, the Changping Golf Club, near a section of the Great Wall, in connection with today's Beijing International Friendship Tournament. The tournament will feature 55 amateur and professional golfers from eight nations at the year-old course, one of only five in China.

title: Colorado Governor Unsure On Value of Dam Proposal
description: Gov. Roy Romer recommended today that a construction permit be issued for a 550-foot dam on the South Platte River 25 miles southwest of here, but he said the dam should be built only as a last resort.

title: KEY RATES
Elizabeth Duggan, Dancer, 56
description: Elizabeth Duggan, a Broadway dancer, died Tuesday of cancer. She was 56 years old. Mrs. Duggan began her career at age 17 after studying at the Professional Children's School in New York City. Her Broadway credits included ''Brigadoon,'' ''Flahooley,'' ''Month of Sundays'' and ''New Faces of '52.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer West Germany Ties Italy: West Germany and Italy played to a 1-1 draw yesterday in the opening match of the European Championships in Dusseldorf, West Germany. After a scoreless first half, Roberto Donadoni of Italy set up the first goal in the 52d minute by stealing the ball from Matthias Herget, a sweeper, near the penalty area and feeding Roberto Mancini, who scored. Four minutes later Walter Zenga, the Italian goalkeeper, was called for taking too many steps with the ball before kicking it back into play. An English referee, Keith Hackett, awarded the West Germans an indirect free kick 6 feet inside the Italian penalty area and Andreas Brehme beat Zenga with a drive just inside the right post.(AP) Golf Gowan Maintains Lead: Caroline Gowan, playing in the first group off the tee, struggled to an even-par 72 yesterday but maintained a one-shot lead after the second round of the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Rochester International tournament. Gowan, who shot a 67 Thursday, finished with a 36-hole score of five-under-par 139. Rookie Danielle Ammaccapane, who had an opening-round 68, held the lead for six holes before bogeys on the 16th and 17th holes dropped her to 72 and into second place at 140.(AP) Britain-Ireland in Lead: Linda Bayman celebrated her 40th birthday yesterday by helping the Britain-Ireland team take a 6-3 lead over the United States in the Curtis Cup women's amateur matches at Royal St. Georges in England. The Britain-Ireland team needs only 3 1/2 points from the final nine matches today to retain the Cup it won in the last competition in 1986. Bayman did not have to stray far from her home, which backs out onto the par-75, 6,059-yard course, to beat Americans Tracy Kerdyk and Kathleen Scrivner, 2 and 1, with her partner Julie Wade in the opening foursomes.(AP) Tennis Edberg and Becker Advance: Stefan Edberg of Sweden and Boris Becker of West Germany moved into the semifinals of the $385,000 Stella Artois Championships yesterday in London. Edberg outlasted Christo van Rensburg of South Africa, 7-5, 5-7, 6-4. Becker, the defending champion, defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany, 7-5, 6-2. Joining them in the final four were Guy Forget of France and Darren Cahill of Australia. Forget downed Brod Dyke of Australia, 7-6, 6-4, clinching the victory on his fifth match point. Cahill, who is unseeded, upset Kevin Curren of the United States, 7-5, 7-6.(AP) Shriver Advances in Dow Classic: Top-seeded Pam Shriver had trouble warming up, but had no problems advancing yesterday into the quarterfinals of the Dow Classic in Birmingham, England, with a 6-3, 7-5 victory over Dinky van Rensburg of South Africa. All of the other top-seeded players won.(AP) Hlasek and Lundgren in Final: Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and Peter Lundgren of Sweden advanced yesterday to the men's final in the Bank of Scotland Grass-Court Championships in Edinburgh, Scotland. Hlasek beat Piet Norval of South Africa, 6-2, 7-5. Lundgren downed Stefan Kruger of South Africa, 7-6, 6-3. In the women's division, Wendy Turnbull of Australia defeated Sun Yan of China, 6-1, 6-1, and Gigi Fernandez of Puerto Rico beat Amy Van Buuren of the Netherlands, 7-5, 6-2. (AP) Cycling Italian Wins Stage: Stefano Giuliani of Italy edged Urs Zimmerman of Switzerland and won the 19th stage of the Tour of Italy race yesterday, and Andy Hampsten of the United States held the overall lead. Giuliani broke past Zimmerman in a final sprint to capture the 233-kilometer stage from Borgo Valsugana to Arta Terma in 6 hours 40 minutes 49 seconds. Zimmerman moved past Erik Breukink of The Netherlands into second place in the overall standings, 1 minute 55 seconds behind Hampsten with two stages remaining.(AP) Yachting Frenchman on Record Pace: Phillippe Poupon of France held the lead and was setting a record pace yesterday past the halfway point of the Single-Handed Trans-Atlantic race. Sailing the 60-foot trimaran Fleury Michon, Poupon was 60 miles ahead of the fleet as he passed the 1,500-mile mark on the sixth day of the race. Barring disasters, he should reach Newport, R.I., by the end of next week, beating his record of 16 days 11 hours 55 minutes set in 1984. (AP)

title: SOVIETS' EUROPEAN TRADE BID
description: The European Community announced today that the Soviet Union and East Germany had expressed a desire for the quick establishment of diplomatic and commercial relations.

title: THE MAGIC OF JOHNSON
description: THE best center in the National Basketball Association plays guard for the Los Angeles Lakers, the best forward plays guard for the Lakers, and, needless to say, the best guard in the N.B.A. plays guard for the Lakers. Maybe the best coach does, too. And team physician and ball boy and usher and popcorn vendor and whatever else it is with which Earvin (Magic) Johnson decides to occupy his time.

title: RISEN STAR SIZZLES IN FINAL WORKOUT
description: Risen Star's bumpy Triple Crown preparations took a last strange turn yesterday morning when the colt blazed three furlongs in 33 3/5 seconds in his final tuneup for the 120th Belmont Stakes today at Belmont Park.

title: Senate Supports Death Penalty In Drug Killings
description: The Senate, opening a new front in the election-year war on drugs, today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would permit Federal courts to impose the death penalty for certain drug-related killings, particularly in the deaths of law-enforcement officials.

title: L.I. Youth Sentenced In Death of Girlfriend
description: A judge sentenced Joseph Porto to up to four years in prison today for the 1986 strangulation of his girlfriend and said he would have given him a longer sentence if he could have.

title: PRITZKER FAMILY TO SELL ITS 64% BRANIFF STAKE
description: The Pritzker family of Chicago said today that it would sell its 64 percent stake in Braniff Inc. for about $100 million to an investor group formed by the Paine Webber Group.

title: Sports People; Into the Hall
description: Jimmy Ray Smith said he wished the College Football Hall of Fame could have inducted more people than the 17 former players and coaches it honored last night. ''So many other guys have been forgotten over the years,'' said Smith, who was inducted. ''They should be here.''

title: Blow Away the Foul-Air Lobby
description: LEAD: The latest plan to control acid rain, proposed earlier this month by Governor Cuomo of New York and Gov.

title: Review/Music; Forays Out of Bluegrass
description: At a time when a growing segment of American pop offers an abrasive aural reflection of urban strife, the clean-cut harmonies of bluegrass music present a comfortingly bucolic vision of community order. The New Grass Revival, a Nashville-based quartet that appeared at the Bottom Line on Thursday, is one of the most proficient groups to use bluegrass instrumentation as a base from which to venture into other areas including blues, gospel and jazz. But their stylistic forays are cautious, as they subsume outside genres into a bluegrass format.

title: Boston Mayor Acts Against Article
description: An uproar has arisen over an article in the June issue of Golf Digest's New England edition that parodies the Irish and their role at the 94-year-old Country Club in nearby Brookline, site of next week's United States Open.

title: Rowing; Olympic Trials Back in Action
description: The semifinal selection races for this year's Olympic rowing team were contested this evening after two days of postponements.

title: Reviews/Dance; Sleepwalking en Pointe Through 'Sonnambula'
description: ''La Sonnambula'' is a passionate ballet by George Balanchine, set to soaring, melodic music by Vittorio Rieti after themes from three operas by Vincenzo Bellini. It received a comparatively unimpassioned though effective performance by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday evening at the New York State Theater.

title: Weird Tales From an Offbeat Childhood
description: If an author's bent is to write fiction about the grotesque, it's useful to grow up on the grounds of Broadmoor Lunatic Asylum, west of London, where some of the most dangerous criminals in England are kept. This is especially true if the future author's father serves as the superintendent there and, at the family dinner table, relates case histories of the patients, like the one about the man who chopped off his mother's head and put it in an oven to bake.

title: Presbyterians Face Off Over Atom Arms Stand
description: A five-year effort in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) to adopt a statement declaring nuclear deterrence immoral and charting a plan of antiwar action has met resistance at the denomination's annual General Assembly here.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: COPING: WITH CHOOSING A SUNSCREEN
description: Sun protection can add up to more than just healthier skin. Sunscreens to last a family of four through summer weekends can easily cost $1,000 or more.

title: Text of Panel's Resolution Backing Inquiry on Wright
description: Following is the text of the House ethics committee's resolution, released today, approving a preliminary inquiry into the Speaker's conduct:

title: Consumer's World; Plastic Helps the Blooms
description: The arrival of the strawberry season is good news for gardeners: those little plastic strawberry baskets make excellent plant shelters to protect seedlings or transplanted perennials from sun and wind.

title: PRODUCER PRICES, LED BY FOOD COSTS, UP FOR 3D MONTH
description: Prices at the producer level rose in May for the third straight month, offering another sign that inflation this year may reach its highest level since 1981.

title: INSIDE
description: Speaking for the Consumer

title: STEINBERG IS PORTRAYED AS AN ADDICT
description: Joel Steinberg, the lawyer accused of beating to death the 6-year-old girl he illegally adopted, was portrayed in court documents released yesterday as a violent cocaine addict who conspired to manufacture a pharmaceutical form of the drug and who would blackmail clients for it.

title: Boy, Shot in Stomach, Dies After Seeking Help in a Store
description: A 13-year-old Bronx boy who had been shot once in the stomach died last night, the police said, after making his way to a candy store to ask for help.

title: Jung Knew the Dangers of Pact With the Nazis; Childish Denials
description: To the Editor:

title: BBC to Mute Apartheid at a Concert
description: The BBC will try to separate music from politics Saturday when it televises a daylong protest concert by rock stars to 60 nations on the 24th anniversary of Nelson Mandela's imprisonment in South Africa. In the United States, Fox Television will carry the concert starting at 5 P.M.

title: E.P.A. to Allow Limited Use Of a Herbicide It Suspended
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would permit temporary and limited use of a herbicide that has been found to cause birth defects and sterility in males. The agency said it had concluded that the benefits of the herbicide, dinoseb, outweighed the risks.

title: TV Again Put Spotlight on the News Business in 'Inside Story'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6 Protest strikes by Armenians in the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region of the Soviet Union have paralyzed most industries for nearly three weeks and created food shortages, Pravda reported. Page 1 A study of the origins of Stalinism has begun in the Soviet Union. It is a painful process that questions the legitimacy of Communism and the possibility of making it more democratic. 1 Roman and Ukrainian Catholics met in private in Moscow. Two senior Vatican representatives attending millenial celebrations of the Russian Orthodox Church met leaders of the underground Ukrainian church. 6 The level of NATO military spending must be maintained even as tensions relax between Moscow and Washington because changes in Soviet policies have not curbed military growth, members of the organization agreed. 6 News analysis: A peace agreement in Nicaragua was not concluded because rebel leaders hardened their positions in responce to mixed political signals from the Sandinista Government. They agreed to continue observing a cease-fire. 1 Companeros Paul, of Harvard Law 5 A U.S. mission to Central America will be undertaken by Max M. Kampleman, the State Department counselor, to assess conditions in the region after the collapse of peace talks in Nicaragua, the White House said. 5 South Korean police blocked students as they tried to march to the border for a meeting with North Korean students. In Seoul, several thousand students clashed with riot police. 3 The influence of French Protestants, France's most successful minority, has grown with the return to power of the Socialists. Prime Minister Michel Rochard and five of his Cabinet ministers are Protestants. 4 An Islamic regime in Afghanistan would fuel a resurgence of Islamic fundamentalism that would destabilize the region, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India said at the United Nations. 4 South African curbs on reporting of anti-apartheid protests were tightened. The measure requires most local news agencies to register with the Government, but exempts major foreign news agencies. 3 U.S. bars Panamanians who support Noriega 3 Palestinian seized in stabbing of mayor 4 Norway and Israel reach accord on inspecting heavy water 4 National 8-11, 32, 54 Charges against Speaker Jim Wright will be investigated by the House ethics committee, which voted unanimously to conduct the inquiry into Mr. Wright's financial dealings. 1 Producer prices rose again in May, the Government reported. The increase of five-tenths of 1 percent was the third straight monthly rise and was another sign of an extended period of gradually rising inflation, economists said. 1 Death for some drug-related killings was approved overwhelmingly by the Senate. The death penalty would not be mandatory under the legislation, and a unanimous jury vote would be required to impose it. 1 A temporary ban on drug tests was imposed by a California court, which ruled that Matthew Bender & Co. cannot require job applicants at its Oakland office to submit to urine tests as a condition of employment. 39 Limited use of a herbicide, dinoseb, which was found to cause birth defects and sterility in males, will be permited on a temporary basis by the E.P.A. because it said the benefits outweigh the risks. 8 Tenants running a housing project in St. Louis have transformed it from a squalid den for drug dealers into a showcase of ingenuity. They are members of a tenant management movement spreading rapidly across the country. 8 Seattle will cut back school busing for desegregation and will reduce the number of students bused by half under a program, to be in place by 1989, that emphasizes integration within certain neighborhoods. 32 A Presbyterian Church paper opposing nuclear deterrence has met resistance from delegates at the denomination's annual general assembly. The proposed policy has been intensely scrutinized. 8 Slayer of five boys is executed in Utah 8 U.S. ban on Japanese fishing is left standing 9 U.S. nursing panel chief outlines recruting strategy 9 Politics 10 A Senate subcommittee was used by its Democratic chairman to benefit Michael Dukakis's Presidential campaign by criticizing Vice President Bush, the ranking Republican Senator on the panel charged. 10 Jesse Jackson described himself as the Democratic Party's best choice for Vice President, but said that the selection of a running mate was only one of many points he wants to discuss with Michael Dukakis. 10 Regional 33-36 A bill on video terminals was vetoed by the Suffolk County Executive, who said regulation of the terminals in the work place would economically isolate the county and cost it thousands of jobs. 1 Fire attacks on subway token booths have prompted the transit police to form a task force. Three incidents similar to one in which a token booth clerk was burned to death have occurred in the last two days. 33 Joel Steinberg was a cocaine addict who blackmailed people into giving the drug to him, prosecutors told a judge in arguing against bail for the lawyer, who is accused of beating to death the six-year-old girl he illegally adopted. 33 Disturbances in Perth Amboy, N.J., followed the funeral Thursday of a Mexican man shot by an off-duty police officer. Hispanic residents met with city officials after a night of rock and bottle throwing. 33 A lawyer who betrayed three clients by identifying them so they could be robbed by an organized-crime ring was sentenced to seven years in Federal prison. A jury convicted the lawyer, William Klan, of Northport, N.Y., in March. 35 Farmers, pressed by long hours and low pay, sell equipment 34 Gentile and challenger exchange charges 34 Legislator cleared of currency-violation charge 35

title: 2 Vatican Officials Meet With Members of Underground Ukrainian Church
description: Two senior Vatican churchmen attending millennial celebrations of the Russian Orthodox Church held a private meeting today with representatives of the underground Ukrainian Catholic Church.

title: Irwin Winston, at 77; Founded Ad Company
description: Irwin Winston, the founder of what became the nation's leading transportation advertising company, Winston Network Inc., died of degenerative heart failure Thursday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 77 years old and lived in Hollywood, Fla.

title: Company News; Upjohn-Japan Link
description: The Upjohn Company said it had completed construction of a $100 million scientific center in Japan that will expand its research and development efforts. The pharmaceutical company said its Tsukuba Research Laboratories would initially house about 100 scientists and staff to conduct pre-clinical and clinical studies and to develop new therapeutic agents. By 1995 the staff is expected to reach about 400 employees. Research will focus on discovery of treatments for cardiovascular disease, central nervous system disorders and immune disorders, it said.

title: Horse Racing; Goodbye Halo Wins Goose
description: Goodbye Halo, the Kentucky Oaks winner and the only filly ever to beat Winning Colors, held off Make Change and Aptostar to win the $237,200 Mother Goose Stakes for 3-year-old fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Missing Woman's Body Found in Hudson River
description: The body of a Manhattan gemologist was found floating in the Hudson River yesterday, more than four months after the gemologist disappeared while carrying diamonds valued at $500,000, the police said.

title: U.S. Bars Supporters of Noriega
description: President Reagan said today that Panamanian citizens who carry out the policies of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Government, except for diplomats on official business, will be barred indefinitely from entering the United States.

title: PISTONS HAVE COSMIC BLUES
description: Perhaps it's bad karma, or perhaps the Pistons, as the blues song goes, were simply born under a bad sign.

title: AIDS Brings Composer's Inspiration
description: ''You know the flurry of activity that surrounds the death of composers? It's begun already,'' Louis Weingarden said the other day across enormous sheets of score paper in the Manhattan apartment he says his landlord would like him to vacate.

title: Company News; Cadillac Ends '88 Allante Output
description: The General Motors Corporation's Cadillac division has decided to end production of the slow-selling Allante luxury car for the 1988 model year. A spokesman for Cadillac said that production of the car, which sells for $56,533, would end Monday. He said production would resume in late August with 1989-model cars. About 70 workers are affected by the two-and-a-half-month shutdown.

title: 71,188 SEE TIGERS TRIM INDIANS
description: Jeff Robinson earned his sixth consecutive victory and Alan Trammell broke a seventh-inning tie with a home run as the Detroit Tigers edged the Cleveland Indians, 2-1, tonight before 71,188, the major league's largest crowd in nearly two years.

title: Gandhi Faults Islamic Rule for Kabul
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India has declared that if the Moslem guerrillas took power in Afghanistan they would fuel a resurgence of Islamic fundamentalism that would destabilize the region.

title: Company News; Stake Increased In R.P. Scherer
description: Two New York investment firms have increased their combined holding in the R. P. Scherer Corporation to 10.1 percent from 8.8 percent.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE VOTES TO CONDUCT INQUIRY ON WRIGHT
description: The House ethics committee announced today that it had voted unanimously to conduct a preliminary inquiry into six allegations regarding the conduct of the Speaker, Jim Wright.

title: Divided by Politics and the 38th Parallel
description: The border that South Korean students tried to march to yesterday before they were driven back by riot police has defined political life in this divided peninsula for more than four decades.

title: Company News; Farmers-B.A.T. Proxy Contest
description: A final count was released this week of voting by shareholders of Farmers Group Inc. on a resolution backing B.A.T Industries P.L.C. $4.3 billion takeover bid, but it failed to settle the week-old dispute over who won the proxy contest.

title: Senate Panel's Top Republican Says Chairman Politicized Drug Inquiry
description: The senior Republican on a Senate subcomittee said today that the panel's chairman, a Democrat, had used an inquiry into international narcotics trafficking to benefit the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: Violence Erupts After a Slaying by Police
description: A night of rock and bottle throwing followed a funeral here Thursday for a Mexican man who was shot by an off-duty police officer, and relations were tense today as Hispanic residents and officials met in an effort to calm the situation.

title: Prison Sentences Don't Stop Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Graduates on Increase
description: LEAD: IF THE rest of the students who are expected to receive high school diplomas this month are like his own graduates at Cherry Hill High School East, says the principal, Anthony R. Cost, ''then we are continuing to see more academically serious groups of pupils.''

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: What Albert Vorspan's valiant record confirms is that true religious commitment transcends even the most precious real estate. Dear as Israel may be to Jews everywhere, its value to us is as the locus of the ideals of humaneness, justice and law which identify our faith. IRVING LEOS Bayside, Queens

title: WESTCHESTER GUIIDE
description: JAM SESSIONS Amateur and professional jazz musicians are invited to sit in on jam sessions held on the second Tuesday of each month in Elmsford by Jazz Resources Inc. The nonprofit society was formed about a year ago by a group of doctors and scientists who were seeking an outlet for their musical talents.

title: ANOTHER CHALLENGE TO ROME BY LIBERAL CATHOLICS IN U.S.
description: FEW words in the religious lexicon have changed as much in 25 years as the word nuns. Once covered from head to toe with habits, and obedient to their superiors at every command, most active nuns now make decisions about their own lives and dress as they please. They choose their jobs, decide where to live and elect their leaders. Habits are rare.

title: AT THE BAR
description: I REMEMBER GRABBING A PASTRAMI SANDWICH, an ice-cold beer and a giant dill pickle on the fly at a bar called Clancy's. For a time, this was the only kind of bar that served meals. At pricier or more stylish restaurants, the bar was simply a place to wait - for your dinner partner or your reservation.

title: POSTINGS: Where Hessians Fought; Carriage Houses
description: The first large development in Fort Montgomery, N.Y., will be the product of a 19th-century architect's designs, Swedish prefabrication techniques and the work of a developer with an interest in Hudson River Valley history. The $14 million residential-and-retail complex on Route 9W near West Point is the project of John Dodson, a Vietnam veteran, Harvard M.B.A. and 1968 graduate of the United States Military Academy.

title: STARTING LATE, FINISHING FIRST
description: This essay is excerpted from a talk given at a memorial service for Joseph P. Lash at the Celeste Bartos Forum of the New York Public Library in October 1987.

title: Barbara Bellantoni Weds
description: Barbara Jean Bellantoni, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Bellantoni of Monroe Township, N.J., was married yesterday to James Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Evans of Washington Township, N.J. The Rev. James F. X. McManus performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Immaculate Conception Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J. The bride is a personnel representative for Lytel Inc., a manufacturer of fiber optics and electronics in Branchburg, N.J. Mr. Evans is an account executive with the Evans Food Service Companies in Moonachie, N.J.

title: Advice About Ticks
description: Following are suggestions on how to avoid being bitten by ticks and, if bitten, the measures to take:

title: YANKS AT OXFORD
description: THE TORMENTING OF LAFAYETTE JACKSON By Andrew Rosenheim. 194 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: Albert Vorspan has given the American public - and the American Congress - license to presume that the support and security of Israel is no longer the No. 1 item on the agenda of American Jewry. We are appalled that he would risk so much that is of importance to the relationship between Israel and the United States.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
Nightclub Zone Causes Debate
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to establish a zone in which nightclubs could stay open until dawn has touched off a debate in the Franklin Square neighborhood.

title: EVEN BUSINESSMEN GET THE BLUES
description: SILENT RETREATS By Philip F. Deaver. 229 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $15.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Lilies for a Single Day or a Whole Season
description: LEAD: IT would be difficult to fault the claim that the day lily is the most popular and widely used perennial. Ranging in height from less than 18 inches to four feet, these garden favorites can provide color from May until frost.

title: Kathleen M. O'Keefe Weds S. J. McCarthy
description: The marriage of Kathleen Mary O'Keefe to Stephen John McCarthy took place yesterday at St. Mary's of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Deal, N.J. The Rev. Hugh Cleary performed the ceremony.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: A manager has the right and responsibility to question calls concerning rules and apparent poor judgment. He does not have the privilege to degrade the officials and defile the integrity of the sport. In the Billy Martin incident, I would have liked to see just how far the team of umpires could have catapulted Martin over the centerfield fence. MARTIN J. LANNIGAN Brooklyn

title: Stepfamilies Group Providing Support
description: LEAD: AMONG them, they know all the old stories about wicked stepmothers, the pain of separation as their children juggled life between two families, the difficulty of disciplining a child not one's own and the financial and custody arrangements that strain a marriage.

title: A Vigorous New Conductor Faces a Tired Orchestra
description: NO ONE NEEDS TO TELL Yuri Temirkanov he has his work cut out for him. When appointed in early April as the new chief conductor of the once formidable Leningrad Philharmonic, he inherited an orchestra in trouble. Like dowdy Leningrad's pastel palaces, shabbier with each passing winter, the Philharmonic has been showing its age, sliding into perfunctory performances of a narrow repertory, fading along with Evgeny Mravinsky, its leader for nearly 50 - that's right, 50 - years. Chief conductor (at least in theory) until the very end, Mravinsky died in January, just shy of his 85th birthday.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Pound Ridge Oak
description: LEAD: IF Lisl Steiner Monchek has her way, part of the once-mighty Pound Ridge Oak will live on in the form of a bench placed at one of the town's gathering spots, such as its newly renovated Conant Hall, site of many community activities.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: As a survivor of the Holocaust who is sensitive to the issue of the good German who did not want to know about Auschwitz, I am pleased to see that Albert Vorspan refuses to follow that example. The time has come to speak up. When, 40 years ago, we proclaimed ''Never again,'' we did not mean that the end of oppression and inhumanity would be for Jews alone, but universal.

title: Former U.S. Aide Sentenced
description: A Federal district judge has sentenced a former Defense Department quality-control official to three months in prison for accepting about $3,000 in payoffs from a New Jersey clothing manufacturer. On Wednesday Judge Marvin Katz ordered the former official, Herbert D. Headley, 60 years old, of Voorhees, N.J., to report to prison July 8. Mr. Headley pleaded guilty to accepting monthly payments from George Chinnici, the president of Dale Fashions, Inc., of Vineland, N.J. from December 1984 through early 1987.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Debate Stirs Over Slogan

title: Ellen Jewett Weds Richard Kauffman
description: The marriage of Ellen Jewett, a daughter of Constance C. Jewett and Dr. Frank S. Jewett, both of New York, to Richard L. Kauffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond H. Kauffman of Encino, Calif., took place yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Justice Edward J. Greenfield of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: Albert Vorspan should seek out his American-Arab counterparts and persuade them to speak out against Arab terrorism and intransigence. One of them might even follow Rabbi Schindler's lead and write to the Palestinian leaders (do they dare approach Yasir Arafat?) and pressure them to come to the bargaining table. Let American Jew and American Arab join forces to pressure both sides and really try to solve the problems. SAMUEL GOLDMAN Carbondale, Ill.

title: Sports People; Boxing Coach Out
description: KEN Adams was removed as the United States Olympic boxing coach yesterday on grounds he assaulted a United States Amateur Boxing Federation official last month.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Grand Central Terminal; Air Rights in Search of a Place to Alight
description: FOR anyone interested in landmark preservation, this month should be celebrated as a landmark itself. It was 10 years ago, in June 1978, that the United States Supreme Court rendered the 6-to-3 decision that upheld New York City's landmarks laws against the challenge of the Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: Judge Finds for Aliens on Absences From U.S.
description: Maria de Jesus Gonzalez crossed over into Mexico to buy groceries, Ignacio Andrade to see a friend, Sofia Baez Huerta to visit her mother on Mother's Day.

title: WARNING SOUNDED ON U.S. HOSTAGES
description: As it looks ahead to the Presidential campaign, the White House has been warned that Iran is ''not above exploiting'' the nine Americans captive in Lebanon.

title: WAITING TO HEAR THE COURT'S NINTH VOICE
description: A YEAR ago, the surprise retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. handed President Reagan what seemed his best opportunity to transform the Supreme Court, perhaps even to enshrine much of his social agenda in the law of the land.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: It is the dream of every child in Little League to stand behind the plate and hit the high sizzling ball far out to the stadium limits. He sees his heroes do this on TV daily. This same child also sees the uncalled for and obnoxious behavior of many suburban Little League coaches. Why should they watch such behavior on TV and have it doubly reinforced? B. T. DAVIDSON Westport, Conn

title: TWO WOMEN BIGGER THAN BABE RUTH
description: THE GODDESS AND THE AMERICAN GIRL The Story of Suzanne Lenglen and Helen Wills. By Larry Engelmann. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $21.95.

title: Some Considerations On New Ethics Law
description: The County Board of Legislators should either improve the new Ethics Law [ ''Proposed Ethics Code Provokes Dispute,'' May 8 ] that it is considering or turn it down.

title: EIGHT LIVES
description: TWELVE YEARS LATER I could remember little about John Yarch, only his eyes and the gawky way he threw dirt clods at the hill. He was 9 when I met him in 1976 at the St. Francis Home for Boys in Detroit, a delicate, blond, shy child with piercing, very blue eyes that looked as though they had no bottom to them. The hill was a mound of dirt in back of St. Francis, and when we went for a walk around the grounds we would spend half an hour practicing our aim against it, seeing how hard we could throw and watching the dust rise. John threw like a girl, the other boys said.

title: Boltanski's Haunting Fragments of Despair
description: IN LAST SUMMER'S DOCUMENTA 8 exhibition, the international art extravaganza that takes over Kassel, West Germany, every five years, one of the most memorable experiences was to be had in the claustrophobic installation piece by the French conceptual artist Christian Boltanski. Isolated in a small room off a staircase at the back of the Friederichicianum, Boltanski's ''Archive'' consisted of hundreds of black-and-white photographs of children and adolescents. Minimally framed, blurred by the process of being rephotographed, this mixture of official school portraits and casual snapshots was hung floor to ceiling on the room's walls. Photographs also covered both sides of three steel-mesh screens that, positioned parallel to each other, divided the tiny space into narrow, dead-end corridors.

title: A Strong Cause, but a Weak Play
description: OUT OF an honorable mission has come a disheartening play. On Oct. 14 and 15, 1984, the Nuclear Weapons Freeze Campaign sponsored more than 100 staged readings of William Gibson's two-character pacifistic work, ''Handy Dandy.''

title: Molestation of Child by Priest Stirring Furor and Anguish in Seattle Church
description: In a painful acknowledgment of a problem in the Roman Catholic Church, worshipers throughout half the state of Washington have been informed by their Archbishop recently that one of their priests had sexually molested children.

title: Bruce Springsteen Has a Grown-Up Way With a Song
description: AS SOMEONE WHO HAS FOLlowed the career of Bruce Springsteen with interest and ambition - oh, to heck with sober critical moderation: with loving enthusiasm - for some 15 years, I took great satisfaction in his ''Tunnel of Love'' indoor-arena tour that ended recently with five shows at Madison Square Garden. For me, it amounted to a fascinating deepening of his concerns, from anthemic rocker to angry social commentator to, now, a grown-up if troubled composer whose songs can stand comparison with the finest art songs of the past.

title: We Need Global Regulations for Stocks
description: WE have enough of post-mortems on the Oct. 19 stock market collapse. But despite all the reports and Congressional hearings, one major aspect of stock market supervision has gone unstudied and unattended - the regulation of stocks that are issued and traded across national borders. This is a very dangerous omission.

title: Miss Outerbridge Weds in Bermuda
description: Elizabeth Whipple Outerbridge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yeaton Duval Outerbridge of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Jamestown, R.I., was married yesterday to Robert Stout McMenamin, the son of Ann Stout McMenamin of Philadelphia and the late John F. McMenamin. The Rev. Roy W. Greenland performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda.

title: Crews Repair Quake Damage
description: Crews worked around the clock today to repair earthquake damage at a pumping plant that shut down the California Aqueduct and its supply of water to the southern half of the state, officials said. The damage to circuit breakers at the A. D. Edmonston Pumping Plant, which pumps water over the Tehachapi Mountains northwest of Los Angeles, was the most significant damage from Friday's quake. There was no water shortage because of sufficient supplies in storage lakes, according to a dispatcher from the state Department of Water Resources, Harry Said in Sacramento.

title: Taxi Rules Sought to Bar 'Banditos'
description: LEAD: ''VERY strange-looking animals'' is the way the Brookhaven Town Public Safety Commissioner, Thomas Liguori, describes many of the taxicabs in his town.

title: Attacks on Philadelphia Homosexuals Studied
description: Nearly half of Philadelphia's homosexual men and one-fifth of the city's lesbians suffered violent crimes in a year because of their sexual orientation, a study by the Philadelphia Lesbian and Gay Task Force has reported.

title: Two Victims Establish A New Support Group
description: LEAD: LAST June, Vicki Korman began to have difficulty swallowing.

title: Developers Buoyed By High Court Ruling
description: LEAD: WHILE many homeowners protest a new crop of commercial construction in their neighborhoods, developers are reaping the benefits of recent United States Supreme Court decisions that have strengthened their right to build and weakened local government's power to stop them.

title: Trinity Offers Bells and Chamber Recitals
description: INDOOR chamber music concerts and outdoor carillon concerts are annually performed at Trinity College in Hartford, and the cycles are about to begin again.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: I commend Albert Vorspan for his article. Why is the Jewish leadership afraid to say that Israel today is facing extremism, injustice and intolerance?

title: Tatine Schwab Weds on L.I.
description: The marriage of Katharine Lambard Schwab, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Caspar Schwab of Oyster Bay, L.I., to Adam Overton Kimmick, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Donald W. Kimmick of Mahwah, N.J., took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: On Adding Some Floral Height
description: FINISH transplanting salvia, ageratum, impatiens, lobelia, geraniums, begonias, marigolds, zinnias and other summer flowers into window boxes and borders; water in well to settle roots. Prune leucothoe, pieris, azaleas, rhododendrons and other broadleaved evergreens that have bloomed; also remove faded flowers to prevent seed pod formation. Spray rosebushes again to protect plants from black spot, a fungus disease. Weed and mulch borders, vegetable gardens and shrubs. Cut off faded lilacs to prevent seed pods from forming. Do not cut down daffodil leaves until ripe, but if the tulips have turned brown, cut stalks to the ground level. Spikes

title: Court Says Prison Guards Immune From Suits Over Discipline
description: Prison guards in New York State have special legal immunity from being sued for the disciplinary actions they take against inmates, a widely divided state Court of Appeals decided today.

title: POSTINGS: Reuters' Dishes; Pigeons No More
description: A research-and-development complex that Reuters Holdings PLC is building in Hauppauge, L.I., lies just off the Northern State Parkway, but a huge, manmade crater hides its major link to the outside world. There, four satellite dishes will be increased to six by the information service that began business in 1850 by linking French and German telegraph lines with carrier pigeons.

title: Legislature ExpectedTo Act on Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: A BILL enabling the state's Department of Health to establish a statewide Lyme disease program is expected to be introduced in the Legislature early this summer.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: Managers should be allowed not more than two minutes to make their protest in a sane manner, and they should be automatically out of the game if they exceed that time or act in an undignified way. Baseball games are long enough without these senseless delays. They should realize that whatever they do, the umpire cannot change his call, but managers can play under protest if they feel it changed the complexion of the game. FRANK J. LANDERS Rockaway Point, Queens

title:
INVESTING;
Jewelry and Receivables, Too
description: LEAD: LIKE just about everything else, jewelry stocks lost a lot of their luster in October's market crash. But the sector has made quite a comeback, mainly because American consumers, who were expected to cut back on discretionary spending, have flocked to buy silver and gold jewelry, diamonds, emeralds, opals, pearls, sapphires - in fact, just about anything that glitters.

title: 'Handy Dandy' at Belfry: A Pacifist Mission
description: OUT of an honorable mission has come a disheartening play. On Oct. 14 and 15, 1984, the Nuclear Weapons Freeze Campaign sponsored more than 100 staged readings of William Gibson's two-character pacifistic work, ''Handy Dandy.''

title: A Corporate Approach To Drama Behind Bars
description: JOHN BERGMAN'S latest fund-raising technique is about as unusual as they come: He suggests that corporations can benefit by supporting plays for prisoners. Eight years ago, Mr. Bergman founded the Geese Theater Company in Spofford, N.H. The company produces plays on the premise that theater within prisons can be a valuable teaching and therapeutic tool. Since then, Geese's nine professional actors and actresses have performed in 350 institutions in 36 states.

title: Vegetating
description: BOTANISTS ARE THRILLED, though, understandably, not overanxious. The first reference work to list and describe all the higher plant life of the United States and Canada ought to be completed shortly after the millennium. Projected at 12 volumes, Flora of North America is to be published by Oxford University Press in New York, a tome at a time, beginning in 1990. ''There are literally millions of North American specimens,'' says Nancy R. Morin, the project's convening editor, who is principally responsible for the mammoth information harvest. ''There's a lot already written in scientific journals. And there are some nice field guides and regional books. But we need to have a single source for foresters, agronomists, chemists, people interested in land management or studying plant morphology.''

title: DATA UPDATE: June 12, 1988
Virginia G.O.P. Chooses Black
description: Maurice Dawkins, a black businessman and former Democrat, won the Republican nomination today to run for a Senate seat against former Gov. Charles S. Robb. Mr. Dawkins, 67 years old, is the first black to run for the United States Senate from Virginia since Reconstruction.

title: PARIS POINTS THE WAY
description: These days, trends, fads and ideas spring up anywhere and everywhere. Yet we still expect the great creators of Paris to at least validate - if not initiate - the newest style swings. They have done this for the fall season, and in so doing have earned themselves some whacks and pans from the media. The hemline issue, which was anticipated to become a bombshell of some sort, ended up a gentle fizzle. Some skirts continued way above the knee, most hovered around the knee and only a few dipped well below it.

title: NOTHING GOES RIGHT FOR LEFTIES
description: The Mets zigged and zagged tonight and even started eight left-handed hitters in a strategic brainstorm aimed at breaking their slump. But it didn't work, not even with Dwight Gooden pitching.

title: Headliners; Insensitive?
description: Phil Donahue, the talk show host, wanted more space for his family, and saw no reason to let the vacant house next door stand in his way. So he bought the unusual all-concrete house and 7.2 surrounding acres recently and had the house demolished last week. But many in Westport, Conn., agreed with the town's architectural historian, who said the house was ''the best design in Westport.''

title: Glenn Ratcliffe Weds Susan H. Resanovich
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chatham, N.J., Susan Helene Resanovich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milan Resanovich of Chatham Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Glenn Hall Ratcliffe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyndon Hanes Ratcliffe of Bristol, Conn. The Rev. John Branson performed the ceremony.

title: Marie J. Vogliano Marries Thomas Andrew Goodman
description: Marie Jean Vogliano, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Vogliano of New York and Eatons Neck, L.I., and Thomas Andrew Goodman, a son of Betty S. Goodman of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Reynold S. Goodman of Stuart, Fla., were married yesterday at Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. William J. Sweeney performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MUSIC WAS NOT ENOUGH. By Bob Wilber with Derek Webster. (Oxford University, $24.95.) It has never been easy to be a jazz musician. The saxophonist Bob Wilber, most recently in the public eye for his Grammy-winning score for Francis Coppola's film ''The Cotton Club,'' puts a new twist on the difficulties in this autobiography. Mr. Wilber grew up in Scarsdale, N.Y., during the 1940's. After school and on weekends he went into Manhattan to hear - and often play with - his heroes, older jazzmen from the 20's and 30's. He showed talent early and became apprenticed to the great New Orleans soprano saxophonist and clarinetist Sidney Bechet. As a young, white follower of New Orleans jazz and swing during the musical upheavals of the 40's that produced modern jazz, Mr. Wilber was something of a throwback, and he found himself as often as not working on the fringes of the jazz world. Musical skill proved to be less elusive than a unique style; Mr. Wilber has spent most of the rest of his career trying to come to terms with the daunting example set by the musicians he idolized. He is candid about the insecurities that have dogged his life. Jazz fans will enjoy the amusing, if somewhat superficial, sketches of Bechet, Eddie Condon, Benny Goodman and others, and the pungent anecdotes of life on the road with various bands. But Mr. Wilber himself never really comes into focus. The book's tone falls somewhere between a confession and a memoir, lacking the intensity and searching honesty necessary to drive the former, and the irony and perspective needed to leaven the latter.

title:
FOCUS: Philadelphia;
Wrangling On Re-use For Prison
description: LEAD: THE adaptive re-use of historic institutional buildings has been successfully achieved in many instances over the last 10 years in former school buildings, hospitals, textile mills and other institutional buildings.

title: PLAYERS MAY SEEK TO MAKE CALLS ON UMPIRE'S PERFORMANCE
description: A WEEK ago, the umpires, dissatisfied with the penalty accorded Billy Martin following his dirt-throwing tantrum, said they would scrutinize Martin's behavior and eject him from games should he argue their calls. Now the umpires themselves may be scrutinized by a group that is dissatisfied with their behavior: the players.

title: CRIMINAL PURSUITS
description: THE SMALL TRAIN from Domodossola, an Italian border town, snakes among the granite mountains of Switzerland's Ticino region. This is where Patricia Highsmith lives, in a village of 250 inhabitants, above the stark Maggia valley. She is on time to meet me at the crossroads of the local station. ''Watch out!'' she calls, a traffic warning. But no car is in sight, just her yellow Volkswagen.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Dartmouth, Mass.;
Building Boom On the Shore
description: LEAD: AN increasing demand for office and light industrial space in southeastern Massachusetts is creating a surge in development in this shore town of about 26,000 people.

title: Military Math
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-19 Political power among Afghan rebels is shifting from the rival exile parties based in Pakistan to guerrilla commanders operating inside Afghanistan. The partial withdrawal of Soviet troops has speeded the shift. Page 1 A school for Afghan girls in exile in Pakistan, offers them one of the few opportunities for higher education. The school's founder worries about the role of women in an Islamic Afghan state. 14 The effect of Chernobyl on Europe has not been as great as many on the Continent feared. But the disaster at the power plant in the Ukraine that sent radioactive plumes across the Continent has left a mark. 1 Air traffic across the North Atlantic will reach record levels this summer, increasing strains on the air traffic control system and delays in takeoff and landing in Europe and North America. 1 France's Socialists are fearful that they may not win an absolute majority in parliamentary elections. Party officials consider only 250 of 577 National Assembly seats ''sure,'' 39 short of an absolute majority. 3 A political dispute in Slovenia has erupted between the leadership of the communist party and the Yugoslav military. There have been charges of counterrevolution or a military coup. 17 News analysis: Arab leaders hardened their stand on terms for Middle East peace talks.
