The summit meeting of Arab heads of state also indicated the depth of anti-American sentiment among even moderates. 5 Economic change in Marxist Angola has been more painful than in other African countries that are moving toward free markets. The Soviet-style political elite has resisted changes in the Soviet-style economy. 15 The coming of the monsoons in India is crucial this year. Indians hope the rains will bring relief from the drought and heat. The rains are also important for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's political future. 10 Sttudents raid South Korean Government offices 3 Italian bishops assail plan to accept U.S. jets 4 Iran might use Lebanon hostage issue in U.S. election campaign 6 Shortage of rockets will hurt ''Star Wars,'' study says 9 Punjab disbands Sikh extremists 11 South African rebel commander: erudition and ruthlessness 16 National 22-32, 42-46 A Federal study to rate doctors who treat Medicare patients on the quality of their care is planned. The results of the study, which will list the names of the more than 300,000 doctors involved, will be made public. 1 A book by House Speaker Jim Wright is at the center of the ethical storm that now surrounds him. Longtime supporters of the Democratic leader backed the book to benefit him financially. 1 Federal scientists are growing coca, the plant from which cocaine is derived, in a Government building near Washington as part of an intensive effort to find an effective way to eradicate the crop abroad. 1 A priest who molested children was identified by name as a pedophile in a statement by Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen. Roman Catholic priests in half of the state of Washington read the statement at a Mass in May. 24 The strike by the Writers Guild has hit businesses that serve the entertainment industry. Typists, restauranteurs, caterers, drycleaners and many other tradespeople have felt the effects of the 14-week strike. 24 Illegal aliens may sue employers under Federal law if they are not paid the minimum wage or fairly compensated for overtime, in spite of changes in immigration law, a Federal appeals court in Atlanta ruled. 22 A new gorilla exhibit at Zoo Atlanta that tries to emulate the primates' natural habitat opens this weekend. The $4.5 million exhibit covers 1.5 acres of forested hillocks separated by hidden moats. 24 Neighbors help a black family 43 Mainers find moorings scarce 43 Politics 26-28 The intercessions of James Baker in the Presidential candidacy of George Bush have been influential. At least three of Mr. Bush's senior advisers were appointed on the Treasury Secretary's recommendation. 1 Michael Dukakis warned reporters that he was the only reliable source about whom he would pick as a running mate. But plenty of Democrats and members of Mr. Dukakis's campaign staff are willing to discuss the subject. 26 Jackson greeted in Chicago as a winner 26 Regional 33-39, 47-50 Labor shortages in New York and the region have gripped employers. Companies are competing for skilled and unskilled employees, in some cases offering salaries for entry-level jobs above the minimum wage. 34 A businessman shot and killed a gang member Thursday. The police charged Raymond David Tse with second-degree homicide. His lawyer said the victim had been slain as he tried to extort money from Mr. Tse at gunpoint. 34 Delays in a housing plan for Yonkers were removed by a Federal judge, who allowed the condemnation of private property needed for building sites. The judge also refused to allow city officials to abandon the plan. 35 A suit against 3 cigarette companies, charging them with causing the lung cancer that killed a woman, has been pursued by her husband and a tenacious lawyer. The case is now before a Federal jury in Newark. 36 Albany is building a civic center downtown 48 North Country residents angry at mistrial in chief's murder 50 Hoboken and Port Authority agree on piers 50

title: Raise Oil and Gas Prices Now
description: WE need to pay greater attention to the strategic value of America's oil and gas resources. Energy users must conserve. Producers, transporters, distributors and regulators must run more efficient industries. And owners must exert more responsibility to be sure domestic resources are managed better. Greater respect for the value of American oil and gas will enhance our political security and economic well-being and prevent future crises.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington;
Nightclub Zone Causes Debate
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to establish a zone in which nightclubs could stay open until dawn has touched off a debate in the Franklin Square neighborhood.

title: G. K. Bernhard Wed To Alice E. Mulligan
description: Alice E. Mulligan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Mulligan of Saddle River, N.J., and G. Kenneth Bernhard, a son of George K. Bernhard of Columbus, Ohio, and Mildred Bernhard of Eastchester, N.Y., were married yesterday at their home in Westport, Conn. Judge Burton Jacobson of State Superior Court in Connecticut performed the ceremony.

title: Chernobyl and the Europeans: Radiation and Doubts Linger
description: The clouds of Chernobyl have long passed, but two years later the shadows still linger over Western Europe.

title: A Little Imagination
description: AT every World Team Olympiad since the series began in 1960 the United States has been strongly represented in the Open Series. But the Americans have never managed to win: The title has gone to Italy three times, to France twice, and to Brazil and Poland once each.

title: Lauri Ann Livesey and James M. Sanduski Marry
description: Lauri Ann Livesey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Livesey of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Michael Sanduski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Albert Sanduski of Omaha. Msgr. Robert J. Skelly performed the ceremony at St. John and St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Napoleon's Cheese Vexes Zoning Panel
description: FROM the looks of the battle ground - a four-acre farm with hardscrabble fields, an old battered silo and a crumbling cow barn - it might appear that the Great Cheese War of Sherman has been fought, finished and forgotten.

title: Bert Greene, Cookbook Author, Dies at 65
description: Bert Greene, a cookbook author and food columnist, died of a heart attack Friday at New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan and Amagansett, L.I.

title: Diana Jean Leaf to Marry B. L. Kessler in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Leaf Jr. of Scarsdale and Canada Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Diana Jean Leaf to Bruce Lloyd Kessler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert E. Kessler of Millburn, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: STATELY ROOMS
description: PICTURE THE GREAT STATE ROOMS ON ocean liners like the Normandie or the Queen Mary,'' says Ira Howard Levy, senior vice president of corporate marketing and design for Estee Lauder. ''That's what I had in mind when I gutted my apartment.'' Interiors that resembled wonderful Noel Coward sets - rooms with big comfortable pieces of furniture or those crafted from great woods, as well as intriguing objects decorating the walls - were what Levy loosely used for reference when he planned the renovation of this 1939 apartment. Even the windows were treated in a nautical fashion -stripped of their moldings and decorated only with mirrored reveals to capture the profiles of neighboring buildings. In choosing the color scheme, Levy also had highly visual images. ''It's meant to look like a black-and-white movie with a few sepia tones thrown in,'' he says. This monochromatic palette was far from a historical allusion. Since Levy spends his days totally immersed in color, his quest for neutrality was an understandable relief. It was also very specific. Indeed, he admits the parchment tone of the walls came from a specific shade of makeup.

title: Arab Parley: Hard Stance; Anti-U.S. Inflamed by Uprising
description: The summit meeting of Arab heads of state this week has significantly hardened the common Arab stand on terms for Middle East peace talks. It has also shown the depth of anti-American sentiment taking root, among even the most moderate of Arab leaders, because of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: User-Friendly Video Stores
description: A few weeks ago the new owner of a VCR entered a video rental store for the first time. What she was looking for was Cagney . . . Garbo . . . the collected Hitchcock . . . ''The Untouchables'' . . . and flicks she wouldn't want to be seen waiting on a movie line for. What she found was the small-town library of her childhood. The same warmth. The same chattiness. The same willingness to share. Let her just lay a finger on ''The Big Easy'' and three strangers would tell her if she was making the right move. Let her reach for the remake of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' and three more would tell her to stick to the original. Let her choose, finally, ''F/X'' and a voice from over her shoulder would say, ''I liked that one.''

title: Why Do We Keep Old Keys? For the Memories They Unlock
description: A FEW weeks ago, I received a phone call at 8 A.M. I was already late for work, and the last thing I needed to hear was, ''Sir, we need to get into the basement of your other house to turn off the gas to replace an outside main.''

title: Rolling! Action! Cut! An Extra Is Born
description: THEY served us day-old mushroom pizza, filled our glasses with make-believe beer, and told us: ''Move your lips, but don't make a sound.'' Yet I wasn't complaining, because I playing my first role in a movie.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: How fortunate that we were permitted an insight into the struggles and doubts of a leader of the American Jewish community. How unfortunate that the Jews on the receiving end of rocks, slingshot-propelled missiles, fire bombs, occasional grenades, et al. are not afforded a parallel opportunity to present their feelings and thoughts. Your readers should know that there is another story and other diary entries. YISRAEL MEDAD Shiloh, Israeli-occupied West Bank

title: Revaluation
description: To the Editor:

title: Kim Michele Marks Weds C. D. Fiertz
description: At the Union Chapel on Shelter Island, L.I., Kim Michele Marks, a daughter of Edwin D. Marks of Sea Cliff, L.I., and Shelter Island, and Mrs. Robert S. Wien of Bayville, L.I., was married yesterday to Carey Daniels Fiertz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden L. Fiertz of New York, Geneva and South Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Christine B. Rannie Grimbol, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Rags and Riches Beyond Paris
description: THE moment long awaited by a passionate shopper of antiques and bric-a-brac had arrived! There on the cluttered stand in the peanut-sized flea market in Provins, a village about 70 miles southeast of Paris, gleamed an ornate wine bottle opener from the 1920's.

title: Ortega Says U.S. Is to Blame For Collapse of Contra Talks
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra blamed the Reagan Administration today for the breakdown of peace talks with the contras but said his Government was prepared to resume negotiations.

title: Miss D'Arc Weds Andrew S. Corwin
description: Pamela Stephanie D'Arc, a daughter of Stephanie Scourby D'Arc and Dr. Victor D'Arc, both of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew S. Corwin, the son of Marcia R. Corwin of New York and the late Raymond A. Corwin. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TREE BY LEAF By Cynthia Voigt. 192 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. (Ages 9 to 13)

title: Christie Lynn Parker Wed To Harry J. Steinbreder 3d
description: Christie Lynn Parker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Moore Parker of Brantingham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Harry John Steinbreder 3d, the son of Mrs. Steinbreder Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mr. Steinbreder. The Rev. Jerry Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of Easton, Conn.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: Albert Vorspan's breast-beating reveals that too many Jews will support the Jewish state only so long as it is comfortable to do so. He says that he ''suffers under the shame and stress of pictures of Israeli brutality televised nightly.'' He convinces me that he hasn't the backbone to stand up for the Jewish state in the face of adversity.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN VENICE
description: Venice has been proclaimed dead or dying more often and more eloquently than perhaps any other place on earth but the city defies its obituaries.

title: Democrats Wrestle With Plank on Tax Issue
description: The issue of raising taxes, the most fundamental policy difference between Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, was left unresolved today by Democrats working here on a first draft of their party's platform.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Naming the Courthouse
description: LEAD: After 14 years, it appears that the Westchester County Courthouse in White Plains will have an official name.

title: MURDOCH'S GLOBAL POWER PLAY
description: A FIERY-RED LOTUS ROARS OUT OF THE DRIVEWAY OF THE Bel-Air Hotel in Los Angeles. Knees tucked under the dashboard, Rupert Murdoch guns the low-slung two-seater through the twisting turns on Stone Canyon Road - simultaneously shifting, steering and tracking down his subordinates on the car telephone. At precisely 8 o'clock on this balmy January morning, the Lotus rolls through the gates of 20th Century-Fox, Murdoch's television and motion picture studio.

title: Provence
description: To the Editor: In his story on Provence revisited (Travel, March 20), Nicholas Delbanco regrets, with good reason, the closing of the restaurant Le Nid d'Aigle in Gourdon. We were there in July 1965 and had always hoped to return. Now we are left with only memories. How could anyone have abandoned so spectacular a site? GUY HENLE Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ROCK STAR. By Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Jackie Collins has made a name for herself as an entertainingly malicious chronicler of the rich and famous. But in her new novel, she leaves her usual international haunts to take on the seamy underside of rock-and-roll, following the lives of three musicians as they work their tortuous way up the ladder to stardom. The result is a curiously flat story that has about as much punch as the lyrics of a bubblegum pop song. Like Ms. Collins's other novels (most recently ''Hollywood Husbands'' and ''Lucky''), ''Rock Star'' is stuffed with sex scandals, drugs, mobsters and stretch limos. Ms. Collins tries to prove she has done her research by gamely dropping names like Eric Clapton, Sam Cooke and the Sex Pistols, but she is clearly not as comfortable or as confident exposing the music business as she is taking on the movie industry. Written in a singsong style that's less bold than that of her previous novels, Ms. Collins's narrative is self-conscious and detached. In fact, you almost get the feeling she was afraid to, as they used to say, get down. Even her trademark steamy sex scenes seem rather prim and restrained, and the rock stars themselves (a legendary English singer and guitar player; a black soul superstar who is a former men's-room attendant; a beautiful, lovelorn mulatto blues singer) have all the dimension of the celebrity cutouts that tourists are photographed with on street corners. They have no sex appeal and no passion for anything, including their own music.

title: An Island Rediscovers Its Role as the Little Hollywood Of the Caribbean
description: OVER IN THE NORTH coast town of Port Antonio, where Errol Flynn used to hang out, MGM/UA was shooting a thriller starring the Oscar nominee Denzel Washington.

title: Fighting AIDS With Bleach
description: PRODDED by Federal statistics indicating that Washington was fifth among American cities afflicted with AIDS, the District of Columbia said in February that it would begin giving drug addicts vials of bleach to clean their hypodermic needles.

title: NEW YORK FINDS IT'S HARD TO DO BUSINESS ABOVE THE FRAY
description: IT was born of necessity, devised by a beleaguered Mayor Koch.

title: On Following the Wrong Path
description: FRANK Marshall, United States champion from 1909 to 1936, once remarked of his erstwhile opponent, the Franco-Polish luminary David Janowski, ''He follows the wrong path with more determination than any man I ever met.''

title: WHY JAPAN CLOBBERED US (Cont.)
description: TRADING PLACES How We Allowed Japan to Take the Lead. By Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr. 365 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Rap Enters the Album Age and the Mainstream
description: RAP MUSIC, WHICH HAS BEEN around for 10 years now, has finally become a genre defined by the album. The release of three exceptional recordings in the last month or so - Run-D.M.C.'s ''Tougher Than Leather'' (Profile 1265; all three formats), Boogie Down Production's ''By All Means Necessary'' (Jive/ RCA 1097; all three formats) and Jazzy Jeff and Fresh Prince's ''He's the DJ, I'm the Rapper'' (Jive/RCA 10911; all three formats) - signals a change.

title:
THE NATION;
SAN GABRIEL'S WAR ON APARTMENT ENCROACHMENT
description: LEAD: Children play on concrete driveways, the only open space available to them except for the street. Apartment buildings fill their lots, allowing no room for lawns or open space. New structures go up alongside only slightly older ones. It is side only slightly older ones. It is often hard to find a place to park on residential streets, a problem that was unheard of a decade ago in this 4.4-square-mile city 10 miles north From a community of about 15,000 in 1940, San Gabriel grew gradually to a population of 29,000 in 1980.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Winston-Salem, N.C.;
Housing Market Moving Upscale
description: LEAD: THE housing market in this central North Carolina city of 140,000 appears to be holding steady despite a series of corporate departures over the last few years. Employment gains, and the experience of at least one major builder, suggest that, if anything, demand for higher-priced housing has risen.

title: SINGAPORE
description: ''CHOP,'' SAID THE CHINESE BUSINESSMAN SITTING next to me in the train in Singapore, ''chop, chop, chop!'' His right arm, fingers stretched, crashed down on his armrest. ''When the Japanese were here, there was discipline. We were afraid. If you were bad, they cut your head off.'' He illustrated his point with another crashing chop. ''Now, no more discipline. Many bad people in Singapore.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Roadwork Slows Airport Traffic In Minneapolis

title: Special Today; Business World/Magazine Part 2
description: * Murdoch and his power plays.

title: BIAGGI'S LAWYERS TO FOCUS ON MEESE
description: The White House and its role in assisting the Wedtech Corporation are likely to be the focus as the defense in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi begins presenting its case as early as this week.

title: R. A. Ungar Wed To Miss Doherty
description: Eileen Patricia Doherty, an associate dean at St. John's University, and Robert Arthur Ungar, a lawyer with the New York City Department of Investigation, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Lourdes Chapel at St. John's by the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, the university's president.

title: Ms. Neiman Engaged To James Stern Zisson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Noah Neiman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Anita Neiman, to James Stern Zisson, a son of Miles M. Zisson of Boca Raton, Fla., Purchase, N.Y., and New York and the late Norma Stern Zisson. The couple plan to marry in October.

title: Peter Bartlett Married To Colleen A. Sullivan
description: Colleen Ann Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Bryne Sullivan of Scituate, Mass., and Peter Spaulding Bartlett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bartlett of South Kent, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Michael's Chapel in South Kent. The Rev. Richard Schell, the headmaster of the Kent School and an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Roch Ciandella, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SHADOW BY THE DOOR. By Gerardo di Masso. Translated by Richard Jacques. (Curbstone Press/Talman, Paper, $6.95.) The action of this novella, which won Spain's Cafe Iruna Prize in 1982, takes place in Argentina, although the country is scarcely alluded to. At times the kinds of censorship a writer must elude are internal as well as external ones; thus a degree of geographic ambiguity can allow a certain freedom to a man like Gerardo di Masso, who suffered under Argentina's repressive military dictatorship.

title: U.S. Secretly Grows Coca to Find Way to Destroy Cocaine's Source
description: Federal agricultural scientists are secretly growing coca, the plant from which cocaine is derived, in a Government complex near here as part of an intensive effort to find an effective means of eradicating the crop abroad.

title: Catching Speeders The Easy Way
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz., catches traffic speeders in a flash.

title: At Croton Point, Problems Persist
description: THE 600 acres of Croton Point once formed one of the largest tidal marshes on the Hudson River. After 50 years as the site of an active county dump, however, the area is judged by environmentalists to be a health hazard. A Federal judge last month called the landfill, which was closed in 1986, an environmental time bomb.

title: Gorillas: A New View at Atlanta Zoo
description: A unique environment opened here today with 1.5 acres of rolling, forested hillocks and hidden moats set aside for 14 gorillas, and humans confined to narrow enclosed walkways and a series of small platforms.

title: Miss Schallman Married in Ohio
description: Patricia Lynn Schallman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Schallman of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married at her parents' home last evening to Matthew Robert Glass, a son of Mrs. Bernard Garrett of New York and St. Moritz, Switzerland, and Herbert I. Glass of Lakewood, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel Jeremy Silver performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
Lilies for a Single Day or a Whole Season
description: LEAD: IT would be difficult to fault the claim that the day lily is the most popular and widely used perennial. Ranging in height from less than 18 inches to four feet, these garden favorites can provide color from May until frost.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Several years ago I had an underground lawn sprinkling system installed at considerable expense. I didn't realize that I would have an expense twice a year of starting the system up each spring, then shutting it down (draining it) in the fall. Is it possible for me to do this work myself?

title: TALKING: New Houses; Negotiating On Extra Features
description: AMONG the more appealing features of new construction is the chance to customize or add - a fireplace here, a skylight there, a door shifted three feet to accommodate grandma's couch. Builders call them options or extras.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: Albert Vorspan writes as the quintessential Jewish community ''professional.'' In his world, liberalism is placed over Judaism.

title: Next Week; Who's the Most Exciting Tennis Player?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: CORRECTION
description: Picture captions last Sunday about the wildflowers at Teatown Lake Reservation misidentified the flowers. The top picture, of a winding path, showed irises and ferns; the smaller picture showed a shooting star flower.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GIVE THEM STONES. By Mary Beckett. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $14.95.) As Martha Murtagh works alone in her small Belfast bakery, she listens to Mozart and Tchaikovsky on a portable record player, one of her few remaining pleasures. When British soldiers spitefully break the machine, she observes: ''All my lovely escape world disappeared but nobody else had any escape so why should I? Some women were on tranquillisers and they'd come in for their bread hardly able to make the words come out of their mouths, or count their money or decide what they needed.'' Like Martha Murtagh, Mary Beckett is a wife and mother and a Roman Catholic raised in Belfast, although the 62-year-old writer has lived for many years in Dublin. Despite the book's setting, don't expect it to provide sensationalism or political intrigue. Instead, this short, thoughtful first novel is almost homey in tone as it considers the mundane ways that Northern Ireland's violence affects its ordinary citizens. Ms. Beckett skims through Martha Murtagh's life from the ''backstreets and boglands'' of her girlhood to a loveless marriage made ''because I could see no other future for me,'' all the way up to her ultimate dilemma: whether or not to countenance the atrocities committed by the I.R.A. American readers may find the choppy cadences of the novel's prose a bit difficult to get used to; they may also feel that Ms. Beckett doesn't entirely solve the problem of describing a constricted life without letting her narrative become monotonous. But in Martha Murtagh, whose qualities are skillfully balanced between the average and the exceptional, she conceives a character that rings tellingly true. ''Give Them Stones'' provides a subtle perspective on a stormy situation; it's a view of a troubled country that's well worth noting.

title: String Orchestra Reaches 35th Year
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago, Harry Alshin, then a music teacher at Hastings High School, had an idea for an extracurricular, all-school orchestera. ''It was such a necessity,'' he said recently, emphasizing the word ''necessity.'' ''We had so many excellent, talented musicians in the individual school bands, and all that was fine, but I felt they needed something more.''

description: Katherine Lee Ridder's engagement to Peter Morgan Pennoyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pennoyer of New York and Katonah, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. P. Anthony Ridder of Miami.

title: A Taste of Paraguay
description: Those who dare to demonstrate peacefully against Paraguay's dictator, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, risk attacks by thugs. Those who violently molest anti-Stroessner demonstrators risk nothing at all. Last week, General Stroessner brought a nasty taste of Paraguay to the streets of New York.

title:
ART;
Pinhole Pictures: Back to Basics
description: LEAD: WITH all the complicated photographic equipment on the market, it's easy to forget that the optical principles behind picture-taking are simple. The basic premise was understood centuries before technology enabled photographers to preserve images on film. The medium is light and the camera is merely a device for capturing its effects on a surface.

title: Out of the House: A Mother's Art
description: Natica Nast Warburg completed more than 200 drawings and sketches and painted close to 200 oils and watercolors before she died last year at the age of 82, but she did not sign her works and rarely gave them titles. ''She was not interested in public recognition; she just painted because she loved her work,'' said her daughter, Jeremy Warburg-Russo of Brookville.

On one side of the river are ranks of neat frame houses. On the other side is the sprawling International Paper Company mill. At night, the lights of the mill cast an eerie orange light on the steam billowing skyward; at all hours, a sulfurous stench from the mill hangs over the town.

Perhaps, if Israeli soldiers and political leaders and Palestinian activists had been writing the type of diary kept by Albert Vorspan, each would be closer to recognition of the other. SHLOIME PEREL Montreal

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MODERN PAINTERS. By John Ruskin. Edited by David Barrie. (Knopf, $45.) Although the five volumes of ''Modern Painters'' are ostensibly a treatise on art, they chronicle John Ruskin's progress from young evangelistic esthete to wearied socialistic philosopher. In gorgeous, vivid, unhurried prose, Ruskin composed an ambitious, far-ranging essay that constitutes one of the great literary works on painting. It has now been republished in a one-volume, 656-page edition abridged by David Barrie, a British diplomat. Roughly half the work has been cut; gone are many digressions and repetitions. This welcome version, with an informative introduction by the editor, provides enough to acquaint the general reader with the once influential, now neglected critic and philosopher. Ruskin brought a consuming passion for art to ''Modern Painters,'' whose early pages especially are charged with the zeal of a young, overconfident thinker. The first volume was published in 1843 and met with mixed reviews. Years later, Ruskin himself looked back rather disdainfully on the pretension and puritanism that characterized it. By the time he wrote the darkly colored yet still deeply religious final volume in 1860, he had become both more tolerant of sensuality in painting and less confident of the social value of art criticism. His admiration for Turner's paintings, which had originally inspired ''Modern Painters,'' never waned, and at the close of the work he mused on what Turner might have produced had the artist been nurtured by the admiration that was his due: ''Soft as Correggio's, solemn as Titian's, the enchanted colour would have glowed, imperishable and pure; and the subtle thoughts risen into loftiest teaching, helpful for centuries to come.''

title: Prospects; Who Will Follow France?

But Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has consistently argued against debt forgiveness. Will the United States and the other summit nations follow the French plan? Shafiqul Islam Senior fellow, Council on Foreign Relations, and visiting fellow, Institute for International Economics.

Canadian stock exchanges began outperforming the United States markets early in 1987. And when the crash came in October, the Toronto Stock Exchange suffered a milder plunge than its New York counterpart. So far this year, Toronto has rebounded with more vigor than New York.

Oliver North and Albert Hakim, were granted immunity in exchange for their testimony. That immunity now jeopardizes criminal prosecutions of the three, along with a fourth alleged conspirator, Maj. Gen. Richard Secord, who testified without immunity.

description: Hanya: Portrait of a Pioneer: The Story of Dancer/Choreographer Hanya Holm. Produced by Marilyn Cristofori and directed by Nancy Mason Hauswer. Princeton Book Company. 58 minutes. $49.95. Available in VHS format only.

It will devour more than 40 percent of the cash on hand at the Government's deposit insurance fund, whose paper losses already total almost $14 billion, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: Wine Roads In Germany
description: IT wasn't until the 19th century that poets began to laud the Eifel, a stretch of countryside embraced by the Rhine and Mosel Rivers and marked at its corners by Aachen, Cologne and Trier. The poets praised the austere beauty of its uplands and of the dark, glittering crater lakes, the narrow, winding valleys cut deep into the forest-covered plateaus, and the clusters of timber-frame houses. But for most Germans the Eifel remained a shadowy enclave behind the Rhine. Even today despite its convenient location, less than an hour's drive from any of the three cities, and within easy reach of Dusseldorf and Frankfurt, the Eifel has yet to be discovered by the vacationing crowds.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Llama Lovers IRIS CHRIST answered the door with a gracious smile and a llama on a leash. ''All my llamas have been in the house,'' said the granddaughter of William K. Vanderbilt Jr. as she and 6-month-old Pillow Talk, the cuddliest 150-pound, four-foot-high llama you'll ever see, led the way into the foyer.

description: The Roman Catholic Church is emerging as an unexpected source of protest against plans by NATO to transfer 72 American F-16 fighter-bombers from Spain to Italy.

title: Dillon's Abortion Stand: Dictates of Conscience
description: By publicly opposing abortion and refusing to prosecute opponents of abortion [ ''Dillon's Abortion Stand Roils Party,'' May 15 ] , instead requesting a special prosecutor in these cases, Denis E. Dillon is not breaking the law, but following the dictates of his conscience.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Biblical Theme For a New Medal
description: LEAD: THE parable of the prodigal son, one of the most familiar stories from the Bible, is the subject of an appealing new bronze medal. It is the latest in the series issued by the Society of Medalists.

title: 3 'ANGELS' ARE STABBED IN FIGHT MANHATTAN
description: A patrol leader of the Guardian Angels was critically injured and two patrol members were wounded last night in a fight with knife-wielding assailants near the Restaurant Row block where proprietors have invited the group to help deter street crime.

title: Lending an Ear To the Strains Of Bel Canto
description: THE ROSSINI REVIVAL IS, ON the whole, one of opera's success stories these days. Our ''Bohemes'' and ''Traviatas'' may be going downhill, ''Aida'' may be near extinction, but our ''Cenerentolas'' have demonstrably improved over the last three decades, and it has become possible to attempt all sorts of worthwhile works long forgotten or deemed unsingable.

title: A Summertime Flowering of Music
description: LEAD: LESS than a decade ago, summer brought with it large gaps in the state's musical life. Now, not only are New Jersey artists and musical organizations finding their vacation time diminishing, but the list of distinguished guest artists also continues to increase.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MY MOTHER'S SIN: And Other Stories. By Georgios Vizyenos. Translated by William F. Wyatt Jr. (University Press of New England, Cloth, $20; Paper, $10.95.) This collection of six stories will introduce readers to the neglected work of a 19th-century writer who has been credited with establishing literary realism in Greek fiction. Georgios Vizyenos (1849-1896) was born in a Thracian village that today is part of the European province of Turkey. Despite his humble origins, he earned two doctorates and traveled widely. His first short story - the title piece of this collection and his best-known work - was published in 1883 and probes, over a 28-year period, a peasant woman's heart-wrenching attempt to atone for the accidental death of her only daughter. Like this story, each of the six tales in ''My Mother's Sin'' offers a telling portrait of rural life. Each is told by an involved narrator and each proposes something of a mystery or paradox, starting immediately with the title itself. (What indeed were ''The Consequences of the Old Story''? What happened on a ship ''Between Peiraeus and Naples''?) The tour de force of the collection, ''Moscov-Selim,'' is a tale of an aging Turkish soldier whose service in the sultan's wars has cost him everything except his faith and dignity - a sympathetic portrait of a historic adversary that is virtually unheard-of for a Greek writer of any era. In all, William F. Wyatt Jr.'s able translation of Vizyenos's seamless blending of ritual, folklore, earthy humor, striking descriptions and unexpected irony makes for a significant contribution to world literature.

title: Baseball; Tigers Barge Into 2d Place
description: Jack Morris beat Cleveland for the seventh consecutive time and Gary Pettis had three hits and drove in two runs today as Detroit topped the Indians, 11-3.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
The Fiercest Continent
description: LEAD: Antarctica is the home of superlatives: it is the coldest, windiest, highest, driest and most desolate landmass on the planet. Ever since the Romans speculated about Terra Australis Incognita, map readers' eyes have looked to southern seas and wondered what lay beyond. In Edwin Mickleburgh's BEYOND THE FROZEN SEA: Visions of Antarctica (St.

title: Handicapped Given 'Respite Weekends'
description: Measured in numbers, a trip from Harlem to Pelham, N.Y., is not very long, 20 minutes by train, about 15 miles across the Bronx. To a handicapped girl unable to leave the city, though, Pelham is as far away as its trees and gardens are foreign.

title: Albany Builds a $55 Million Complex Downtown
description: A $55 million civic center is rising here, changing the face of the capital.

title: Mary D. McGrath Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Denise McGrath and George Daniel Donovan Jr. were married yesterday at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Chappaqua, N.Y., by the Rev. Richard J. Craig.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''There are Senators who won't want to go home without a trade bill. They may see after a while the slim likelihood of getting a second bill and be happy to get the chance to vote on this bill.'' - Robert C. Byrd, Senate majority leader, after Senate vote on trade bill

title: Three Years Of Fighting Town Hall About Town Hall
description: STARTING in 1799 and until three years ago, the official doings of the people of Salisbury, from marriage licenses to fishing permits, were recorded in the Town Hall. Come August, the townspeople will begin accustoming themselves to a new one.

title: Beach Restrictions Eased
description: THIS tiny borough in northern Ocean County must further open its beaches to the public this week under the terms of a settlement with the state's Department of the Public Advocate.

title: 'WE DON'T NEED THE PEOPLE'
description: AFGHANISTAN The Great Game Revisited. Edited by Rosanne Klass. Maps. 519 pp. New York: Freedom House. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $19.95. ''A NATION IS DYING'' Afghanistan Under the Soviets 1979-87. By Jeri Laber and Barnett R. Rubin. Illustrated. 179 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $26.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: Eleanor King Retrospective: Vintage Works, New Life
description: ONE OF THIS SPRING'S UNEXpected choreographic pleasures was the Eleanor King retrospective presented recently at St. Mark's Church under the auspices of Annabelle Gamson/Dance Solos. Consisting of solos created by Ms. King between 1935 and '63, the program was a pleasure to watch because of its choreographic craftsmanship. What made that pleasure unexpected was the fact that, although references to Ms. King occur in many books on modern dance, until this concert her works were largely unknown to most of today's dance audience. The retrospective brought old dances to new life. Ms. King, who is 82 years old, studied in New York with two modern-dance pioneers, Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman. She joined their company at its founding in 1928 and remained with it until 1935. She also started presenting programs of her own choreography during the 30's. She established a company in Seattle in 1943 and from 1951 to '71 taught at the University of Arkansas. She now lives in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: NICARAGUA HAS PEACE BUT NO UNDERSTANDING
description: THE breakdown of peace talks between the Sandinista Government and contra guerrillas last week came as negotiators approached the central question of the Nicaraguan conflict: What is democracy?

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: JUST PLAIN FOLK

title: Let the Market, Not Politicians, Set Prices
description: Julian L. Simon, professor of business administration at the University of Maryland, has studied energy and raw materials markets through history. His conclusion is that supplies can be assured only if the markets are left alone. Professor Simon, co-editor of ''The Resourceful Earth,'' spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about energy prices and policy.

title:
GARDENING;
Honoring Their Landscape Value
description: LEAD: THERE are at least 300,000 species of vascular plants and untold numbers of varieties (cultivars). Many are of exceptional ornamental value, yet most homeowners know only a few: azaleas, English ivy and, perhaps, Japanese maples. And marigolds.

title: A New County Attorney Prepares to Lead Law Department
description: THE appointment of a 39-year-old litigator to head the County Law Department comes at a time when critics of the department are complaining that it has been poorly managed and has followed questionable legal practices.

title: Karin Anne Keitel Marries David Branch Nuckols
description: At the Capitol Hill Presbyterian Church in Washington, Karin Anne Keitel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Glenn H. Keitel of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to David Branch Nuckols, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray Norwood Nuckols Jr. of Glen Allen, Va. The Rev. Thomas Starnes performed the ceremony.

title: Ferrer Goes His Own Way (Sometimes) in Bronx
description: The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, appeared to be setting up an independent political base when he parted company with the Bronx Democratic leadership on at least three major issues in the last nine months.

title: PUNJABIS DISBAND SECRET MILITANTS
description: The Punjab Government has disbanded and disarmed a group of Sikh extremists that it had financed and armed for several months to attack and confront other militants, a top security official said today.

title: Rowing; Harvard Takes Title for 2d Year in Row
description: The Cincinnati regatta became a battle of Boston today, with Harvard holding off Northeastern University's closing charge to win the national collegiate rowing championship for the second consecutive year.

title: UMPIRES AND MANAGERS: CALL ON PRIDE, NOT PREJUDICE
description: BILLY don't throw that dirt. Pete don't push Pallone. Oh, well.

title: Performances Custom Tailored for Company Needs
description: WHEN the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's managers in Seattle wanted to do something for the community, they paid for an actress to perform with the city's Repertory Theater. Dale Soules used her five-month residency to give 80 one-woman shows, dubbed ''Informances.'' These shows combined acting and audience participation; they were intended to entertain and to gather tales of family histories from the audience. With information gleaned from these performances, Ms. Soules will fashion an oral history of the city to be presented at Seattle's centennial next year. Among the actors will be many of the elderly that came to her performances.

title: IMPRESSIVE RESULTS FROM STATE CHAMPS
description: Nnenna Lynch of Hunter College High School in Manhattan ran the fastest girls' 1,500-meter run in the country this year today at the New York State high school outdoor track and field championships.

title: Today's Alter Has a Smaller Ego
description: THE GROWN MAN WHO'S ACTU-ally a teen-ager, the housewife who revisits the senior prom, the white college student who pretends to be black and the high-powered executive who'd rather be making baby food have something in common. Like a surprising number of characters in recent film comedies, they share the same underlying secret, one that can be summed up this way: I'm not really me.

title: THE WORLD: Dear Comrade Editor; Pleas for Freedom and a Fuller Accounting
description: THERE is an old joke that has recently enjoyed a revival in Moscow. A Soviet dog is telling a friend how life under Mikhail S. Gorbachev differs from the old days.

title: Nouvelle American in Mystic
description: THERE is a new reason for a trip to Mystic: the Mooring, a first-rate restaurant in the Mystic Hilton. Following the trend of many of the big hotel chains, the restaurant is small, stylish and upscale in both food and prices, and features a limited menu of nouvelle American dishes.

title: The Nation; State Acid Rain Accord Puts New Pressure on Washington
description: A PEACE plan to end the long war between the states over acid rain emerged last week, not from Washington, but from the Governors of two states that have led the opposing camps in the acid rain debate, New York and Ohio.

title: Kelly Mehiel Is Married
description: At the Greek Orthodox Church of the Archangels in Stamford, Conn., Kelly Elizabeth Mehiel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Mehiel of Armonk, N.Y., and James Bitzonis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aristotle Bitzonis of Stamford, were married yesterday by the Rev. George Poulos. The bride is working in her father's campaign for Democratic Representative in the 20th Congressional District in Westchester County. The bridegroom is a second-year student the Bridgeport University School of Law.

title: The Plan and Reaction to It
description: Here is a summary of the American peace plan for the Middle East and the positions of the parties involved. U.S. Plan

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Laurel Highlands, Pa.;
Ski Resorts Widen Appeal
description: LEAD: THE two largest second-home communities in this five-county area of southwestern Pennsylvania, originally conceived mainly as seasonal ski resorts, are now seeking to attract buyers from distant urban areas for year-round use.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE HAPPY HOT DOGS
description: DEALERS AND DREAMERS A New Look at the New Deal. By Joseph P. Lash. Illustrated. 510 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95.

title: Outdoors; Fly Rods Catch On To Northern Pike
description: AS a traveler moves north in Canada, where the trees get progressively smaller and the fish get bigger, vagrant thoughts may arise about the ways in which some fishermen think.

title: Court Panel Says Illegal Aliens May Sue Over Pay
description: A Federal appeals court here has ruled that illegal aliens who are not paid minimum wage or fairly compensated for overtime may sue employers under Federal labor laws in spite of recent changes in immigration law that prohibit employers from hiring aliens who enter this country illegally.

title: Ethiopia Opens Doors to American Art
description: American art is on display in a public cultural center here for the first time since Ethiopia became an ally of the Soviet Union 11 years ago.

title: The New Russian Enigma
description: At its annual meeting, the New York-based Institute for East-West Security Studies took an afternoon off a heavy schedule of speeches to remind us where we are.

title: Lilco Tries To Justify Evacuation Exercise
description: EVEN as the Long Island Lighting Company tested its emergency plans for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, a Federal appeals court here heard a challenge to the rule that served as the underpinning of the exercise.

title: YUGOSLAV REGION LOOKS AT LOYALTY
description: Slovenia, whose political culture resembles more the ways of its neighbors Italy and Austria than the rest of Yugoslavia, has long been a thorn in the flesh of Yugoslav Communist orthodoxy. It has now added to its innovations the novelty of a Communist leadership facing suspicion from its generals that it is not Communist enough.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: An article in The Business World of March 27, ''How Magnates Pick Partners,'' reported on a business relationship between Michael R. Milken of Drexel Burnham Lambert and Saul Steinberg, chairman of Reliance Group Holdings.

description: To the Editor:

title: Students Raid Korea Government Office
description: Students hurling firebombs stormed a Government building that houses the Prime Minister's office and fought with police officers today, one day after security forces blocked a march to the North Korean border by students seeking reunification.

title: Theater Pins Hopes On Stock Approach
description: ''THIS is the summer of 'Let's make a deal,' '' said John Hodge, the co-producer of the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport.

title: Show Business as a Business Tool
description: SLOWLY but steadily, corporate America is heeding the call of Henry James to ''Dramatize it, dramatize it.'' Theater, it seems, is becoming a tool of business. The tradition of corporate giving to the arts is well established. But corporate involvement is taking a new twist as businesses use actors and plays as part of their in-house educational efforts and to help with marketing and sales.

title: ON AND OFF TRACK, KING OVERCOMES HURDLES
description: THE symbols of her busy life stand in full view at opposite corners of the living room. Over here, a tall cabinet, filled with trophies. Over there, a squat plastic bin, brimming with teddy bears. At once, they envelop those in between and inform the unknowing that Judi Brown King has been eminently successful at many more endeavors than running over hurdles.

title: Where to Watch the Blue and the Gray
description: THE tide began to turn for the Union 125 years ago. The Battle of Gettysburg, the siege of Vicksburg and many other important battles made 1863 a decisive year, though the war would continue to rage until 1865.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: I am the daughter of Russian Polish Jews who survived the Holocaust, although the rest of my father's family died in the camps. In 1965 and 1966, I lived on a border kibbutz in Israel, at the foot of the Golan Heights, which then belonged to Syria. I worked in the banana fields on the border and on the kibbutz's fishing boat, which was occasionally shot at by Syrians from their position at the crest of the heights. In June 1966, two weeks after I left the kibbutz for Paris, the war broke out that led to Israel's occupation of the heights as well as the West Bank, Gaza, Sinai and Jerusalem. At the time, I was elated, though soon after, when the seizure of land became a goal of permanent occupation, I began to have my doubts. I remembered very clearly that Arabs within the country, as well as non-Ashkenazi Jews, were treated -to put it kindly - as second-class citizens. When I spent Christmas in Nazareth at the home of an Arab family (it was impossible to find a room in town), I listened to their distress about being virtual prisoners in the land of their birth, required to carry passes in order to move around the country. I listened to Jewish comments about Arabs: heard the racism and was shocked by it. And I felt, while I lived there, that my concern about these attitudes was in some way unacceptable. That was part of the reason I decided to leave.

title: Youths Flee School in Mississippi In Wake of Allegations of Abuse
description: Children fled a boarding school Friday before the authorities investigating allegations of abuse could take them into state custody, but state police officers and social workers rounded up most of them today.

title: Joseph Shields Jr. And Miss Flowers Marry in Georgia
description: Maury de Graffenried Flowers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Flowers Jr. of Thomasville, Ga., was married at All Saints' Episcopal Church there yesterday to Joseph Vincent Shields Jr., a son of the late Mr. Shields and the late Elizabeth Larus Shields of New York, Old Westbury, L.I., and Richmond. The Rev. James W. Law performed the ceremony.

title:
DINING OUT;
Mexican Fare Off the Saw Mill
description: LEAD: LONG situated on the Saw Mill River Parkway, Cantina couldn't be handier. From its bosky outdoor dining terraces and bar, one looks upon a pretty lake busy with wildlife. Indoors, a fireplace makes a cozy focal point on winter evenings, and banks of greenery soften the attractive contemporary dining spaces of wood and stone.

title: OVERCOMING THE VAPORS
description: NOT THAT SORT OF GIRL By Mary Wesley. 279 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Dr. Christina B. Casals-Ariet Is to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jordi Casals-Ariet of New York and Port Jefferson, L.I., have annnounced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Christina Brock Casals-Ariet, to David Mason Little 3d, a son of Mrs. Little Jr., of West Hartford, Conn., and Chocoura, N.H., and the late Dr. Little. The wedding is to be in August.

title: College World Series; Stanford Takes Title Again
description: Stanford had lost to Arizona State in five of six games during the regular season, and no team had ever won the College World Series with 23 losses.

title: Bonnie Hilton and Douglas M. Green Are Married
description: At Oheka, the Otto Kahn estate in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Bonnie Rose Hilton, a daughter of Edwina Marks of Copiague Harbor, L.I., and Lee J. Hilton of New York, was married last evening to Douglas Mitchell Green, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Green of Palo Alto, Calif. Rabbi Robert A. Rabb performed the ceremony.

title: Ellen Solowey Weds R. Stuart Swanson
description: Ellen Carol Solowey, a teacher of American government at the St. John's College High School in Washington and a freelance Russian translator, was married yesterday to R. Stuart Swanson, a vice consul and the third secretary at the United States Consulate in Lahore, Pakistan. Judge Milton Pollack of the Federal District Court in New York officiated at the Harmonie Club.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Several years ago I had an underground lawn sprinkling system installed at considerable expense. I didn't realize that I would have an expense twice a year of starting the system up each spring, then shutting it down (draining it) in the fall. Is it possible for me to do this work myself?

description: To the Editor:

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Fatal Attraction Starring Glenn Close, Michael Douglas, Anne Archer, Ellen Hamilton Latzen, Stuart Pankin, Ellen Foley, Fred Gwynne. Directed by Adrian Lyne. 1987. Paramount Home Video. 119 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: AN M.B.A. RUNS THE GANTLET
description: A FEW WEEKS AFTER BLACK Monday, I was sitting in James B. Rogers's class in securities analysis at the Columbia Business School when a television crew arrived to tape the session. Rogers is a noted investor who looks for fundamental values and supply and demand shifts. One of the topics that day was chicken farming. When consumer demand for chickens grows, he told us, prices rise and farmers rush to breed more chickens, producing an oversupply. Prices drop, creating a cycle of shrinking profits for the farmers.

title: In Pursuit of Splashy Ceramics
description: CLARICE CLIFF'S BOLD-ly graphic Art Deco ceramics, which Queen Mary once described as awful, are pursued these days by thousands of collectors on both sides of the Atlantic. A 1970's revival of interest in the British designer's pre-World War II vases, platters, pitchers and tea sets sparked a boom in sales that continues unabated. Now Louis K. Meisel, a SoHo art dealer who is a major collector of Cliff's painterly pottery, is presenting the largest and most comprehensive exhibition of her work ever held in this country. The show, opening Tuesday, will remain through July at Meisel/Primavera, Mr. Meisel's design gallery, at 133 Prince Street.

title: Sports People; No Complaints
description: WHEN a sports franchise is sold, there is always a certain amount of apprehension among the team's players and their agents while they wait to find out whether the new owner is a tightwad or a spendthrift.

title: Fast-Lane Kids
description: AN 11-YEAR-OLD GIRL ARRIVES home from school, anxiously clutching her report card. Alone in the house, she waits until early evening for her mother, an investment banker in Manhattan who routinely puts in 12-hour workdays. Her father, a corporate lawyer, is away on a business trip. When her mother walks in the door, the girl draws a deep breath and blurts out a well-rehearsed speech: ''I got a C in math, but I've got everything under control. We're going to hire a tutor to bring up my grade. Don't worry, Mom, I'm going to Harvard.'' The 11-year-old has found a means of coping with her low grade, but her parents' high academic expectations weigh heavy on her mind. And she is not alone. Throughout the country, the offspring of superachieving couples are experiencing similar ups and downs. They are members of the first generation to be raised by fathers and mothers who work in prestigious, high-powered careers - and to experience the pain, as well as the privileges, that accompany growing up in that fast lane.

title: Neighbors Come to Aid Of Blacks Hit by Vandals
description: Last Wednesday Michele and Charles Berkley parked their new car in the driveway of their new house and at 5:30 the next morning, Mrs. Berkley said, ''I opened the door and stepped into a nightmare.''

title: Plan to Move Post Office Upsets a Vermont Town
description: The two-story, wooden building across the brook from the four corners here began life in 1900 as James Logan's cobbler shop. Mr. Logan was small: He had the brass door latches set low to accommodate him. They were raised only a few years ago.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: THE BUSINESS FORUM on health care inflation (May 8) prompted an unusually strong response from readers. The two articles expressed the views of Willam B. Schwartz, M. D., of Tufts University (''Cutting Costs Means Painful Choices'') and Robert H. Blank, director of biosocial research at Northern Illinois University (''To Pare Expenses, Ration Services''). title: AN ARTFUL PLOY
description: HERMES SILK NECKTIES have survived the market crash as Wall Street status symbols, firmly knotted around the necks of investment bankers, bond traders and other highfliers.

title: Two Sculpture Shows: One in Small Scale, the Other Large
description: OWEN MORREL'S sculpture is large and site-specific -one of his major efforts, ''Omega,'' is cantilevered over the Niagara River, at Lewiston, N.Y. But the gallery where the artist is now showing, Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing in Ossining, is small and prospective visitors should be prepared to extrapolate from a model about three feet tall, a handful of drawings and a slide display.

title: The Church Rejected Priestesses
description: To the Editor:

title: RUNAWAY WIFE LIVES!
description: THE ASSIGNMENT Or, On the Observing of the Observer of the Observers. By Friedrich Durrenmatt. Translated by Joel Agee. 129 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95.

title: The Birth And Death Of a Legend
description: THE CENTENARY OF THE DEATH OF VALEN-tin Alkan passed recently without arousing much notice hereabouts. That struck me as surprising. The eccentric French composer and piano virtuoso whose admirers included Liszt, Schumann, Chopin and Busoni is one of those fascinating fringe figures whose modest fame a cult might be expected to keep alive. Alkan, who died under perplexing circumstances on March 29, 1888, enjoyed a surge of attention in the 1960's when pianists and Romantic Revivalists such as Raymond Lewenthal and Michel Ponti took him up. More recently, Ronald Smith has been carrying on the missionary work: one of his recordings, of 25 short pieces, has even made it into the CD catalogue.

title: Why O'Neill's Ghosts Haunt Us Still
description: HOW SHOULD WE BE RE-membering Eugene O'Neill today - with reverence, respect or simply a big, exhausted shrug? Are we to regard him as a genuinely great dramatist? Or as a figure of historical interest, important because he brought weight to the puny American theater of the early 20th century? Or was he, could he have been, a blustering windbag whose pretensions should now be deflated by a few well-aimed critical thrusts and jabs? There's no better time for confronting the somewhat extreme questions O'Neill inescapably raises than his centenary year - and, indeed, this particular week of his centenary year.

title: Q and A
description: A Property-Tax Error

title: Heather S. McLeod Weds James Greacen, a Geologist
description: Heather Standish McLeod, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Anderson McLeod of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Robertson Greacen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Greacen of Avon, Conn. The Rev. David S. Hoag performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Medley of Performers at 11th Revival
description: FOR 20 years now, the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater has been plying the river, taking its ballads and ecological lessons to thousands of people in dozens of shoreline communities. For 10 of those years, it has spent the summer solstice weekend moored at Croton Point, a visible symbol of hope and pride during the two-day song, dance and crafts festival officially known as the Great Hudson River Revival.

title: ROCKET STUDY SEES 'STAR WARS' DELAY
description: The first deployment of ''Star Wars'' antimissile defenses in space cannot occur before 1998 at the earliest because of a lack of heavy-duty rockets to put weapons into orbit, a Congressional staff study published today says.

title: German Mine Search Ends
description: Search teams have found the body of the last man missing after an explosion in a coal mine, bringing the number of confirmed dead to 51, officials said today. The body was found late Friday, according to a spokesman for Preussen Elektra, the company that owns the mine. On June 1, a methane gas explosion ripped through the Stolzenbach mine in Borken, about 70 miles northeast of Frankfurt. Fifty-seven miners were trapped.

title: Ms. Williams Wed To R. C. Howard
description: The chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jennifer Ann Williams and Robert Cameron Howard. The Rev. James Patrick Michael Walsh performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: Having the right to fight a bad call is a rule book guarantee that's quickly losing ground in baseball. The rarity of a reversed decision by umpires is indicative of their self-perceived infallibility. With a few exceptions, a call contested by a manager is usually verified by instant replay and yet because of false pride or a brotherhood amongst the umpires a changed call becomes as rare as a kosher stadium hot dog. Is a manager supposed to sit back and let a bad call decide the outcome of a close game? I suggest Billy wait for a rainy day at the stadium before he decides to kick and throw dirt on an impudent umpire. JOHN HALBERIAN New York

title:
ABOUT MEN;
Does Father Always Know Best?
description: LEAD: I BLEW IT AGAIN AT dinner the other night. I'd come home late and tired at the end of the week, but that's no excuse. Eliza - my youngest, 9 years old - had wanted us all to sit tight while she served the ice cream. Daniel and Sarah whined in unison. Both adolescents, they had no patience for a younger sister who wanted to call the shots for once.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SoHo
description: THAT chic and gritty district of Manhattan known as SoHo should post a warning at its borders: Only rich artists need apply. For what was once a refuge for painters seeking cheap space to work on huge canvases has been bid up like the prices of Warhol knickknacks at a Sotheby's auction.

title: New Entry, Familiar Formula
description: CAFE TESTAROSSA is creating a scene in Syosset. It's a now-familiar formula on Long Island: dramatic, neon-highlighted decor; young, hip waiters; casual, lighthearted food, and a spiffy, sporty clientele to match.

title: Needed: Foster Homes For the Elderly
description: We read with interest your recent article on the difficulty of finding foster homes for the increasing numbers of children in need of foster placement [ ''Need for Foster Parents Rises as Their Numbers Dwindle,'' May 22 ] . Here in Westchester County, there is another population also in need of foster homes.

title: Headliners; In Pain
description: Lawyers and relatives of Anne Henderson Pollard say the effect of prison life on her may be far worse than her five-year sentence would imply.

title: What They're Wearing: Hats
description: FOR SO MANY YEARS NOW, hats have been an archaic accessory. Few stylish women wore them. But at last, the hat seems to be returning to its rightful place as a genuine piece of chic. These photographs, taken at a recent luncheon in the Conservatory Garden of Manhattan's Central Park and at the Winterthur Point-to-Point in Winterthur, Del., prove the point. At the luncheon, particularly, any number of women who a year ago would not have considered donning a hat showed up becomingly shaded by straw brims with flower trims.

description: The Air Force has accused a large contractor of defaulting on an electronics contract handled by a Long Island subsidiary and said it was canceling the order and would demand repayment of $39 million in payments.

The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 9 12 2 FREUD, by Peter Gay. (Norton, $25.) A reanalysis of the life and legacy of Sigmund Freud. 10 2 TELL IT TO THE KING, by Larry King with Peter Occhiogrosso. (Putnam, $16.95.) Anecdotes about celebrities by the radio and TV talk show host. 11 11 20 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 12 13 9 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 13 1 SHOW TIME, by Pat Riley. (Warner, $17.95.) The coach of the Los Angeles Lakers reviews last year's championship season. 14 14 14 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 10 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 141 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.)
