The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Arab Envoy Assails Dukakis On Stance on U.S. Embassy
description: Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League's ambassador to the United States today sharply criticized Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's position that the United States should move its Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, saying that such a view was ''deeply wounding'' to Arab and Moslem peoples throughout the world and insensitive to their spiritual, historical and national attachment to the city.

title: Scene 14 of Writers Guild Strike: Tough Times in Hollywood
description: When times are good in the television and movie business, Barbara's Place in West Hollywood hums 24 hours a day. That is where the scripts for ''Jake and the Fat Man,'' ''Perry Mason'' and many other productions are typed, duplicated and rushed to the studios.

title: Dukakis Leads a Party Fed Up With Discord
description: DEMOCRATS have always been charmed by the definition of their party offered by Will Rogers:

title: Displaced Elderly Find Home in a Dorm
description: LEAD: AFTER a fire forced them from their residence last month, 46 elderly Hamden residents went back to college. Ranging in age from 62 to 90, the residents were the guests of Quinnipiac College in Hamden, which put them up in a women's dormitory that had been vacated for the summer.

title:
DINING OUT;
Eclectic Chinese in East Brunswick
description: LEAD: BACK IN January, Chau Wu and her husband, Eric, opened Chau's 18 in East Brunswick. In that short time, the couple already has had to add extra dining space to accommodate patrons who have become regular customers.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINIONSay, Can You See If My Flag's There?
description: WHEN I bought my property on the beach in a small town in Long Island, I never gave much thought to the flagpole, replete with an American flag thereon. It was only after I moved into my house that I realized it presented problems.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Corporate Conference Centers; Inviting Outside Users to Help Ease Operating Costs
description: LATER this month Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting giant, will begin marketing a product more typical to an innkeeper: a 145-acre center with guest rooms, dining halls, athletic facilities and classrooms for up to 1,500 people.

title: Boaters in Maine Find Moorings a Scarce Item
description: When John Coffin started working as a lobsterman 23 years ago, he put out 500 traps and rarely saw another boat in this Casco Bay harbor north of Portland. Now he sets 1,500 traps to get the same haul and worries constantly that he's going to run into one of hundreds of pleasure boaters. Mr. Coffin is not alone. Many Maine harbors have waiting lists for docking spaces of up to 10 years. Freeport residents cannot get a permit for a mooring for at least three years and nonresidents can forget it for a decade.

title: A Puzzle: Why Didn't Uncle William Give Me the Shoehorn?
description: MY mother's bachelor Uncle William was a formidable old gentleman, tall with a waxed gray mustache, piercing blue eyes, and a stern, unsmiling mouth. Each summer of my childhood, we would vacation at Narragansett Pier where Uncle William owned several Victorian mansions overlooking the sea.

title: A Countess's Creation
description: IT stands high on the top of a windswept hill, a symbol of pride, an affirmation of style and power; but, unlike just about every other great house in England, Hardwick Hall was built to glorify a woman. For the past 400 years, the carved stone initials and coronet of its creator, proudly cresting on the towers of the house in Derbyshire, have proclaimed to the world that, her royal namesake excepted, Elizabeth, Countess of Shrewsbury, was the most important woman in England.

title: Virginia McAleer Marries
description: Virginia Marie McAleer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McAleer of Port Washington, L.I., and Thomas T. Poleman 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Poleman Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., were married yesterday at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington by the Rev. Joseph Coschignano. The bride, a graduate of Cornell University, is the public relations manager at the National Marine Manufacturers Association in New York. The bridegroom, also a Cornell graduate, is a disk jockey and a programming assistant at radio stations WKCI-FM and WAVZ-AM in New Haven.

title: Utility-Built Lake Begins Filling Up
description: ONE of New Jersey's largest recreation areas -larger than both nearby Spruce Run Recreation Area and the newly dedicated and highly publicized Monksville Reservoir Recreation Area -has just been opened, unofficially, to the public.

title: YONKERS TAKEOVER OF SITES APPROVED
description: A Federal judge last week cleared the way for a long-delayed housing desegregation plan in Yonkers by allowing the condemnation of private property for building sites and by refusing to let elected officials abandon a housing plan the city adopted in January.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
An Urban Center Rises in the Suburbs
description: LEAD: OVER the last two decades, people have steadily moved from crowded central cities to the developing suburbs, often at the expense of convenience. Most suburban communities have been sprawling car-oriented places with residential subdivisions and shopping malls, but no downtown core.

title: Jill B. Jeffery Has Wedding
description: Jill Burr Jeffery, a daughter of Mrs. Carleton Jeffery of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Jeffery, was married yesterday to Mark Edward Garvin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Everett Garvin of Groton, Mass. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: Albert Vorspan talks of the moral need to speak out, but the question is complicated. Should not morality consider the comfort one's comments provide to those who would continue the war against Israel and who see the main battleground as right here in the United States? Should not morality take into account that Israel is situated not in the Middle West, with its democratic political culture, but in the Middle East, where authoritarianism, extremism and terrorism too often win out and threaten Israel? ABRAHAM H. FOXMAN National Director, Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith New York, N.Y.

title: Verbal Witchcraft Produces Magical Responses Out Front
description: UNLESS I AM SORELY MISTAK- en, we can begin to be grateful for a blessing that's overtaking us. The current theater, making the most of words as it always must, is in the process of recognizing words as something more than little units of information. It is venturing to use them as magic again.

title: THE MASTER AND HIS MISTRESSES
description: LEAD: PICASSO Creator and Destroyer. By Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington. Illustrated. 558 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: From the Comics to The Stage
description: WHAT happens when a wayward computer promotes Beetle Bailey, the perennial private and quintessential goldbricker, to the rank of corporal? Can the status of a three-star general be far behind?

title: Air Travel '88: Vexing Season For Atlantic Routes Foreseen
description: Air traffic across the North Atlantic will jump to record levels this summer, increasing strains on air control systems and aggravating flight delays in Europe and North America, industry officials say.

title: THE GUIDE
description: ROYAL PROSE AND VERSE ''The Hollow Crown,'' first perfomed in London in 1961 by the Royal Shakespeare Company, will be performed at 7:30 P.M. today in the First Church of Christ in Cornwall.

title: Ash Ship Heads for Africa
description: A ship that has been unable to unload its 10,000 tons of incinerator ash for 20 months is headed for West Africa, where public anger is rising at industrial nations' trying to dump wastes.

title: A DESIGNER FISH RAISES FEARS FOR NATURE AS WE KNOW IT
description: WITH the speed of a bass striking a fly, the development of genetically altered fish has raised a new round of concerns about biotechnology.

title: U.S Steps Up Drive On Illegal Aliens
description: THE Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service has made what a high-ranking official calls ''the most important I.N.S. bust ever in New Jersey.''

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY'S CASH COW
description: ON THE CREST OF A HILL IN Altura, Minn., where the air is so clear the eye can fasten easily on the emerald ridges of Sugar Loaf Bluff miles to the west and the Mississippi River valley to the east, the century's third wave of farm technology has arrived in the form of a glass vial in John Kurtz's milking barn.

title: Philadelphia's Master Plan Rests on Its Streets
description: THERE IS A NEW PLAN FOR THE center of this city, and it manages to learn both from Philadelphia's own history and from the halting and often failed efforts of other major American cities to control and guide their growth. Perhaps there should be no surprise that Philadelphia has done it right: from the standpoint of urban planning, after all, Philadelphia has long been one of the luckiest cities in the United States.

title: RHODEN PITCHES IN: A DESIGNATED HITTER
description: Rick Rhoden spent the early afternoon yesterday trying on protective helmets and looking for a bat that felt right. The search, marked by laughter and a little nervousness, was necessary because Rhoden arrived at Yankee Stadium to find himself in the batting order. And as the designated hitter, no less.

title: OWLS, MONKEYS AND SPIDERS IN SPACE
description: THE SISTERS New and Selected Poems. By Josephine Jacobsen. 132 pp. Columbia, S.C.: The Bench Press. Cloth, $18. Paper, $9. IN OTHER WORDS New Poems. By May Swenson. 128 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. AN OREGON MESSAGE. By William Stafford. 143 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: End Bias on Hiring From State Schools
description: The May 15 Long Island Interview with Donald Blinken, chairman of the board of trustees of the State University of New York, was a welcome boost for public higher education.

title: Charting the Scope of Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: THE potentially debilitating effects of Lyme disease, which prompted the state earlier this year to provide more financing for research, are of greatest concern in Westchester and Suffolk Counties, where more than 90 percent of the reported cases in New York have occurred.

title: The Season Grows Longer In Saratoga
description: HERE'S what it's like to take a mineral bath at the Saratoga Spa. An attendant ushers you into a spacious chamber done in austere Depression-vintage decor. The floor is covered with tiny black and white tiles. There is a plain single bed and a rattan chair. Sydney Greenstreet would not look out of place sitting there in a wrinkled white suit. A 60-gallon tub, roughly twice the size of the average home model, is filled with greenish spring water heated to 98 degrees. The attendant discreetly withdraws.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: SEWAGE is a major source of coastal pollution, and all of it does not come from outfall pipes. Among the less-controllable sources of human waste are boats with heads - toilets - whichmust have some way to get rid of their sewage.

title: Garbage: Planning for 1990
description: LEAD: WHAT are the 13 towns and 2 cities on Long Island doing to prepare for the state-mandated closing of their landfills?

title: Strategies for the End of an Era
description: FOR American business, the Reagan era had its own distinctive marks: regulation was out, mergers were in and Federal officials were passive in enforcing the thousands of Government rules that executives often see as nettlesome. But with Mr. Reagan's remaining term reduced to seven months, some of the most astute of corporate America's advisers are saying that executives must resist the temptation to dwell on the good old days and begin to plan for the future.

title: CENTURY CLUB AIDE LOOKING AT FIRST PGA CHECK
description: Seven club professionals from the metropolitan area qualified for the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, but only Rick Meskell survived the cut.

title: Robert Anderson: The Drama of Being a Dramatist
description: THE TRIUMPHS AND THE BUR-dens of the American theater in the last quarter of a century come together in the career of Robert Anderson, one of this country's few internationally recognized modern playwrights. Mr. Anderson continues to write steadily, but there is a certain poignancy about the fact that a major dramatist, with a series of hit plays behind him, now has to wait to get his new works considered promptly, or to see them staged in a large or small New York theater, or even to get a one-time reading by busy actors to fire up interest in a production. All this may sound depressing, but it is the theater that is depressed - by the usual financial problems - not the playwright. Mr. Anderson remains cheerful about his still-active theatrical life. This is where he is now:

title: Review/Music; Australian Pianist In Debut
description: Rosemary Tuck, a pianist from Sydney who made her local debut Friday at Weill Recital Hall under the sponsorship of the American Australian Bicentennial Foundation, is a sensitive musician whose first concern seems always to be the character of the composition at hand, but whose technique is not consistently enough developed to bring her ideas securely into sound.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: RIVER FESTIVAL

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FRIENDS, RUSSIANS, AND COUNTRYMEN. By Hampton Howard. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The United States intelligence agents who are portrayed in ''Friends, Russians, and Countrymen'' are too eccentric, too literate and too wisecracking actually to work for the American Government, but this is the only unpersuasive element in an otherwise colorful and fast-moving thriller. ''Soviet equity'' - that is, a spy - has been found in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, working out of New York University's Courant Institute of Mathematics. But rather than capture him, the C.I.A. inititates an operation to feed him disinformation. Ed Stuarti, a flamboyant 70-year-old intelligence veteran who played a bit part in Mr. Howard's previous novel, ''War Toys,'' runs this baroque con game from his West 13th Street safe house. Among the members of his cast are Tom Matthews, an anguished, burned-out agent; Harold-Who-Does-the-Disgusting-Things, a contract worker who, for reasons of national security, was once flown to Vienna to throw up on a mailman; and scores of F.B.I. agents dressed as Hasidim and basketball players so as to look plausibly New Yorkish. A modern spy, Stuarti is fully aware of the statutory prohibition against conducting C.I.A. operations in Greenwich Village, and he employs as much forethought duping Congressional oversight committees as he does the Russians. Hampton Howard writes convincing, jargon-rich spy dialogue, as well as archly elliptical descriptions. The novel concludes with a surprising revelation about the target of Stuarti's deception, a plot twist that may give pause to readers concerned about C.I.A. involvement in political affairs.

title:
DANCE;
'L'Histoire' to Open Rutgers Festival
description: LEAD: IN COMPOSING ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' in 1917, Stravinsky scored it for a small ensemble so the dance-theater piece could be taken on the road as an inexpensive moneymaker.

title: The Mark of El Supremo
description: I CAN STILL SEE MY FATHER, THE MER-chant, standing in front of his ladies' ready-to-wear store in Atlantic City. Or playing pinochle with his buddies on Saturday evenings in the 1930's. Or sitting beside me at the Waltz Dream Arena watching the fights. Always with a cigar in his mouth. The merest whiff of cigar smoke brings him back to me.

title: Washington Bridge Work Continues
description: LATE-NIGHT work on the upper level of the George Washington Bridge and the expressway lanes on both the upper and lower levels on the New York City side is continuing.

title: A New Breed of Corporate Skipper
description: IN THE OCEAN OFF MIAMI, FIVE 50-FOOT SAILBOATS WERE AP-proaching an inflated orange cone - the first windward mark of the triangular race course at the Miami 50's Yacht Racing World Championship last March. The boats were almost bumper to bumper, a sight that sent warning tingles up the spine. It wasn't their speed, about six knots, but their momentum, their inability to change direction quickly, and the fact that they have no brakes. Worse, three of the boats, including Royal Blue and Nitissima, were not positioned to pass the mark on the required side.

title: Suit Contends Japanese Sold Defective Printers
description: A SUIT filed in Federal District Court in Philadelphia in behalf of at least 5,000 buyers of a popular laser printer for computers and word processors says that the Japanese manufacturers and a New Jersey-based distributor engaged in a nationwide conspiracy to make and sell defective printers.

title: STREET SMARTS
description: One broiling August day in 1977, seated at my kitchen table in Brooklyn with a childhood friend, Connie Best, I had a million-dollar idea: We would go into business, producing a beverage that contained only natural, plant-derived ingredients. I was only 21 years old, but this wasn't my first venture. Since graduating from high school at the age of 16, I had been on my own -even starting a construction company and a grocery store, both in Maine.

title: Elizabeth Perdue, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Seaver Perdue, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Perdue of Sands Point, L.I., to Jeffrey Morris Strauss, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Meyer B. Strauss of Kenmore, N.Y., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Maurice A. Fetty, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz performed the ceremony.

title: THE NEW CALIFORNIAN DREAM: CLOSING THE DOOR
description: IT has been many years since the Americans who headed to Southern California have found an unspoiled promised land of orange and avocado groves, fan palms and the comfortable life. They learned to struggle instead with smog and the freeway culture but persisted in a vigorous entrepreneurial ethic that unrelenting growth was an unalloyed good. But today even the most hard-bitten Southern Californians say that the place has begun to reach its limits, becoming a vast basin of clogged roads, overburdened sewers, and high rises that are turning low-density suburbs into cities.

title: A Speedway Reckless as It Is Small
description: EVERY Sunday, dozens of cars pull onto the Newington Athletic Field and circle the hottest spot in town - a 700-foot dirt race track for radio-controlled miniature cars.

title: Garbage Options Reviewed
description: LEAD: COUNTY officials are assessing the implications of a new report that says Westchester may need a second solid-waste resource-recovery plant or an additional burner at its existing Charles Point plant in Peekskill unless it can recycle 32 percent of its garbage over the next seven years.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: POUND AS WUZ: Essays and Lectures on Ezra Pound. By James Laughlin. (Graywolf, Cloth, $17; Paper, $9.50.) Few people today knew Ezra Pound in his prime, but James Laughlin, the poet's friend and publisher (as founder of New Directions), convincingly brings Pound and his work to life in this collection of essays and lectures.

title:
WINE;
Bargains to Take Along on a Picnic
description: LEAD: LIGHT, uncomplicated wines offer consumers an elegant alternative to beer or coolers as accompaniment to picnic and barbecue fare. And local retail outlets are now stocking a large variety of these products, many of which are excellent bargains.

title: On Getting The 'Red' Out
description: MY pictures from the festivities of Memorial Day weekend are back, and I'm sorry to report that they, like so many color prints today, are afflicted with the dreaded disease known as red eye. Red eye, as you probably already know, is one of the major frustrations of snapshot-style photography.

title: NO LIFE OF RILEY WITHOUT JOHNSON
description: In the final chapter of his book, ''Showtime,'' Pat Riley, the Los Angeles Lakers' coach, made an observation about Magic Johnson that perhaps gets closer to the heart of things than all of the praise he's heaped on his point guard.

title: Cast Glitters in 'Getting the Gold'
description: LONG ISLAND STAGE, the Island's premier resident professional theater, has had a rough financial season, and for a while it seemed that this outstanding theater would have to close for lack of money. Luckily, this blow to the arts on Long Island was averted, at least for this year. The company's season is now ending with the current production of P. J. Barry's ''Getting the Gold.''

title: NOTED WIHT PLEASURE
description: No Smoking or Kissing Setting the scene, stirring the reader's curiosity, is the beginning of fiction. Gert Hofmann does this in a droll way in ''Arno,'' one of the stories in ''Balzac's Horse: And Other Stories'' (Fromm).

title: Swimsuit Like Dad's
description: A WAVE of nostalgia is sweeping over the men's swim-wear scene.

title: STUMBLING TO CANAAN
description: THE MIRACLE HATER By Shulamith Hareven. Translated by Hillel Halkin. 96 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Paper, $8.95.

title: ELECTION JITTERS OVER AN ANEMIC BUDGET
description: AFTER Governor Cuomo told the Legislature last week that $400 million had to be cut from state spending, there was some talk in the State Capitol about dashed plans for summer vacations. But beyond that, state leaders were concerned about how the renewed budget debate would affect the fall, when all 211 state legislators face elections, and the winter, when Mr. Cuomo must present next year's budget.

title: Handicapping Dukakis's Pick
description: Michael S. Dukakis's attempt to stifle comment on his choice for a Vice-Presidential nominee has not thwarted speculation on who is among the long shots and who deserves closer scrutiny. Page 26.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: A LOT of the good old days weren't all that good, and it doesn't much matter whether the days we're thinking of were a half-century or a half-decade ago. The fact is that a lot of them were upsetting, irritating, depressing and just plain horrible, and that they are remembered with a rosy glow only because memory is fortunately selective.

title: Roast Chicken, a Summer Favorite
description: ROAST CHICKEN is one of the most useful dishes for weekend entertaining in the summer. Not only is it easy to cook and good both hot and cold, it can be taken on picnics. Chicken is adaptable to all sorts of flavorings and is particularly good with summer vegetables such as eggplant, zucchini, tomatoes and corn -and, of course, fresh herbs such as tarragon, basil and thyme.

title: The Comfort and Dash of Culottes
description: WHILE short skirts drift aimlessly in a sea of raging ambivalence, another above-the-knee garment is bobbing along very nicely, thank you. Culottes, that cross between skirts and shorts, have adapted smoothly to a range of warmer-weather uses.

title: Jackson Returns to Chicago And Is Greeted as a Winner
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson came home today, a winner in the eyes of those who stood by him regardless of the campaign results.

title: Overprotecting Underdogs
description: Even the timetable is zany. It starts by sending everyone to the ice of Iowa in January. It ends, this year, in airless August, in New Orleans. And that's not half of what's wrong with the way America nominates Presidential candidates.

title: Beside Spring Lies Life's Dark Promise
description: A FRIEND called this morning, and while I looked out my window at a robin poking through the leaves for worms, I listened as she told me about her 12-year-old daughter, stricken suddenly with cancer. Her voice revealed a panic inside her carefully chosen words. I kept my voice calm and my eye on the robin. When I hung up the phone I was glad the robin was still there. I watched as she foraged through the dead leaves, turning them up and tossing them high in the air. And I realized that while I have a great respect and love of nature, I have not made peace with its dark side.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: U.S. PLANS TO RATE DOCTORS TREATING MEDICARE PATIENTS
description: The Federal Government is planning a study that will rate the more than 300,000 physicians who treat Medicare patients on the quality of their patient care, a top Administration health official said.

title: Marcos Loyalists Said to Fail to Free Soldiers
description: Former soldiers loyal to the deposed President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, ransacked a military armory today but failed to free soldiers jailed for involvement in coup attempts, the military said.

title: REDS RALLY PAST GIANTS WITH 6 RUNS IN EIGHTH INNING
description: A throwing error by Matt Williams, the shortstop, scored the go-ahead run in a six-run eighth-inning rally as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the San Francisco Giants, 7-2, today.

title: New Rules Sour Lollipops in Conversions
description: THE rooftop lollipop development, which is a fairly recent confection from New York cooperative apartment converters, may not survive a new set of disclosure guidelines from the Attorney General's office, real estate operators are saying.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: Contemptible swine that they have become, umpires bring out the worst in people. Billy's behavior calls for real punishment, but it is the fans who are getting the punishment ever since the umpires enthroned themselves as demigods.

title: Repairing Asphalt Roofing Shingles
description: ASPHALT shingles, the most widely used roofing material in the United States, ordinarily last 15 to 25 years before needing replacement. Roofs with asphalt shingles should be inspected annually for wear if they are 10 or more years old. Leaks and damage to individual shingles must be repaired immediately.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Dreyfus Statue Placed In Tuileries Gardens
description: A statue of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus, the Jewish soldier who was tried as a spy and later exonerated in a scandal that split France at the turn of the century, has been placed in the Tuileries Gardens here.

title: Wright in His Own Words
description: ''Reflections of a Public Man'' is described in a publisher's note as ''not a partisan book nor a plea for any particular legislation,'' but ''a collection of random thoughts and observations,'' like these:

title: Verbatim:; Children and TV
description: 'The political climate is changing and there's beginning to be some responsibility now. It would be against motherhood and apple pie to go against this thing right now.' - Frank Orme, President of the National Association for Better Broadcasting commenting on the House passage of a bill that would limit commercials on children's television shows and require educational programming.

title: Producer Prices Rise Once Again
description: Producer prices advanced in May for the third straight month. Driven higher by the cost of food, the producer price index for finished goods climbed five-tenths of 1 percent last month, only one-tenth of a percentage point higher than the rate at which it rose in April. Energy prices, which had surged in April, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May, largely because of a 3.8 percent drop in natural gas prices. The May rise was interpreted as another sign that inflation this year is expected to reach its highest level since 1981.

title: No Shades of Gray
description: AN UNENDING, Manichaean East-West death struggle'' was not something that Senator Albert Gore Jr. believed in, wrote Hendrik Hertzberg in The New Republic.

title: South African Rebel Commander: A Portrait in Erudition and Ruthlessness
description: With his tailored clothes and suave manners, Martin Thembisile Hani looks more like a prospering business executive than the chief of staff of Umkhonto we Sizwe, the military wing of the African National Congress.

title: A 'Bulldog' Battles Tobacco Industry
description: Before his wife died in 1984, Antonio Cipollone promised her that - no matter how long it took - he would pursue a lawsuit charging three cigarette companies with causing her lung cancer.

title: Behind the Scenes Of Quaker Movie
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Mt. Kilimanjaro Question:I am interested in visiting Tanzania and in climbing Mount Kilimanjaro. Could you provide information on the climb and travel packages? - H. H. F., Lenox, Mass. Answer:A glimpse at a package available from KLR International, one of the tour companies offering trips to East Africa, gives an indication of how this climb can be accomplished. The package begins in Arusha, the base for many Tanzanian safaris. Trekkers - who should be in good shape - are taken from there by bus to Marangu, a small town about 75 miles away on the lower range of the Kilimanjaro Forest. Here, at 5,200 feet (the mountain is 19,565 high) they stay at the Kibo Hotel, a country house-style lodge.

title: POSTINGS: Windsor Terrace Condos; A Mews Near the Park
description: The Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn has at least one advantage over its more upscale neighbor Park Slope - both border Prospect Park, but Windsor Terrace borders its lake. And a 55-unit condominium being built at 1115 Prospect Avenue in Windsor Terrace is within sight of the lake's recently discovered swan breeding ground. Called Prospect Park Mews, the new residence makes the most of its location; developers are even using a rendering of a swan with her three ugly ducklings in advertisments.

title:
GARDENING;
Lilies for a Single Day or a Whole Season

title: Estrellita Labella Wed to Physician
description: The Riverside Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Estrellita Labella, a daughter of Eugenio Labella of Cebu City, the Philippines, and the late Estrella Colina Labella, to Dr. Peteris E. Dzenis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Visvaldis Dzenis of Bloomfield, N.J. The Rev. Erik Kolbel performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Iranian Official Denies Khomeini Is Terminally Ill
description: A senior Iranian official here has denied a recent report that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini is terminally ill.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: REVOLUTION FROM ABROAD: The Soviet Conquest of Poland's Western Ukraine and Western Belorussia. By Jan T. Gross. (Princeton University, $25.) The Soviet occupation during World War II of eastern Poland (an area now in the Soviet Union) is much less familiar to us than the German occupation of the western part, but not for reasons of insignificance.

title: Big, Small, Indoors and Out
description: Special Hospital Benefit

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PIT BULL. By Scott Ely. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) Famous dull dogs abound in literature, but even the cur in ''A Dog of Flanders'' is full of surprises compared to Alligator, the pit bull of Scott Ely's second novel. Imagine a canine Rambo with a foul smell, and you've got him. Alligator may be ''dead game'' - the sporting term for a dog who'll fight to the death - but he's also dead boring. Even so, he doesn't deserve what happens to him by the end of this book. Neither do we. Nor, maybe, does Mr. Ely, who started with some promising ingredients: a father and son bitterly divided over the loss of their family farm and how to get it back, a whole Mississippi town (from woman mayor to preacher to black school principal) involved in a scheme to recoup everyone's fortunes by raising a monster marijuana crop, and a blonde in emerald earrings, hooking her way through nursing school, who decides she'd rather be a herpetologist. The main trouble is that none of these characters is real enough to care about, one way or the other. The son wishes the father violently dead on page 7 and frequently thereafter, but by the end of the first scene it's quite clear that nothing can ever come of their sullen strife beyond tepid reconciliation. Mr. Ely's prose is laconic to the point of shorthand, and when a character gets off a halfway good line it's repeated, parrotlike, every time the character reappears. Pavlovian symbolism abounds: whenever the son's shrapnel scars itch, for example, the reader is supposed to be conditioned to think, ''Ah, yes, Viet-Vet Syndrome.''

title: WEST 46th STREET: THE CRACK SUBCULTURE; ANGELS FIGHT THE ADDICTS ON NEW YORK'S RESTAURANT ROW
description: THE rrxhred berets set up their skirmishing post on Restaurant Row shortly before midnight. They chatted with a uniformed cop, adjusted their T-shirts with the Guardian Angel logos, made sure the walkie-talkies on their belts were squawking. The last customers straggling out of Orso's and Joe Allen's, looking down West 46th Street for taxicabs, gave bemused glances at the Guardians and the policeman, who soon moved along on his beat on the dark edge of the Times Square area in Hell's Kitchen.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The new government will be Islamic. We want an Islamic regime under the law of the Koran. There will be some educated people who know about this. They will serve Islam.'' - Lalmohammed, an Afghan guerrilla commander. [ 1:6. ]

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Hartsdale, N.Y. $290,000 9 Sherbrooke 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; fireplace, patio, finished basement, 2-car garage, 0.3 acre; taxes $4,919. New Rochelle, N.Y. $337,500 27 Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; powder room, eat-in kitchen, den, full basement, 2-car garage; 0.2 acre; taxes $5,011. Scarsdale, N.Y. $545,000 3 Sylvan Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 28-year-old brick/frame split level; eat-in kitchen, den, playroom, alarm system, 2-car garage, 0.28 acre; taxes $7,995. Ridgefield, Conn. $365,000 55 Hayes Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; totally renovated, new roof and furnace, 1.3 acres; taxes $2,412. Stamford, Conn. $528,000 Stone Hill Drive 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 40-year-old colonial; heated pool, screened porch with flagstone floor, 2.7 acres; taxes $4,390. Stratford, Conn. $248,500 300 Arrowhead Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old center-hall colonial; cul de sac, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,344. OTHER AREAS Madison, N.J. $649,000 32 Park Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old colonial; deck, c/a, garage, family room; taxes $5,934. Maplewood, N.J. $224,000 10 Lee Court 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old, 2-family colonial; 2-car attached garage, recently remodeled interior; taxes $3,817. Selden, L.I. $110,500 24 Peconic Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $960.

title: Julie Westcott Is Wed To David Allen Lahar
description: The marriage of Julie Westcott, a daughter of Dr. Jack Lawrence Westcott of New Haven and Judith Duvall Westcott of Farmington, Conn., to David Allen Lahar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond T. Lahar of Pomona, Calif., took place yesterday. The Rev. Joan Williams performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ, Congregational in Farmington.

title: ANOTHER TWIST IN THE PERPLEXING BRAWLEY CASE
description: IN the tortuous six months of the Tawana Brawley mystery, rarely has there been a week longer on event and shorter on meaningful development.

title:
GARDENING;
Lilies for a Single Day or a Whole Season
description: LEAD: IT would be difficult to fault the claim that the day lily is the most popular and widely used perennial. Ranging in height from less than 18 inches to four feet, these garden favorites can provide color from May until frost.

title: Airport Buses
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Getting to the Airport'' (Practical Traveler, March 13), my wife and I recently investigated the suggested 7B SamTrans bus from San Francisco airport into town but learned that it would leave us two longish blocks to the BART station (with luggage).

title: Mapping a Strategy for Retirement
description: A NEW YORK CITY couple in their 50's, who own a home and have finished paying for their three children's college educations, want to retire at age 65. They got in touch with Claire S. Longden, a financial planner with Butcher & Singer Inc., in New York, because ''we just didn't know, with the amount of money we had, and the number of years until retirement, what was the best course to take,'' the husband said.

title: POSTINGS: Looking Backward; West Side Walkabout
description: An amble back in time from the 1966 Metropolitan Opera House to the 1877 American Museum of Natural History is being offered this afternoon by the New York Historical Society. It is sponsoring a walking tour of the Upper West Side that will give those who take it an understanding of how this big slice of Manhattan developed into one of New York's most diverse and attractive neighborhoods.

title: Laurie Bruckner to Marry Jason C. Bastis in October
description: Laurie Anne Bruckner and Jason Christopher Bastis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christos G. Bastis of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., plan to marry in October, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Bruckner of New York and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla., have announced.

title: 'Commissar' Makes a Delayed Debut
description: IN SAN FRANCISCO IN 1968 AT WHAT WAS supposed to be the first American screening of ''Commissar,'' its director, Alexander Askoldov, told a rapt audience how, a year earlier in Moscow, unbeknown to him, his wife had to steal film cans containing his movie and hide them in a linen closet to save it from destruction by the authorities. As the film maker spoke - intense, visibly moved -there was a sense of deja vu. One was reminded of Nadezhda Mandelstam in Moscow telling in 1962 how in the 30's she had concealed the poems of her husband, Osip Mandelstam, in the saucepan from which she was then serving soup. Like the preservation of Mandelstam's poetry, that of Mr. Askoldov's film was a gift to Russian culture by a heroic wife. ''Commissar'' is a black-and-white movie in the great tradition of the early Soviet cinema, blending its constructivist legacy with a modern sensibility. The film deals honestly and compassionately with the fate of Jews in the Soviet Union and, by extension, in the modern world.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Listening to the Patient
description: LEAD: IN A CIRCLE OF light, we sit as witnesses: Gregor Samsa has been changed into a giant beetle.

title: Farmers Adapt to Keep Their Land
description: THE rural community of the East End has put on a new face: where once potato farmers wove dirt into neat rows for spring planting, greenhouses and nursery farms and vineyards have sprouted in the fields.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: As we've seen, he can go too far. Billy Martin's actions are a result of frustration; bad umpiring goes on uncorrected, umps seem to be exempt from scrutiny and performance reviews. If incompetent umpires were ''sent down'' to the minors like incompetent players, Billy and others like him could be convinced to limit their actions to noncontact (dirt or otherwise) forms of discussion. Dirt-throwing, bumping, kicking, spitting, etc. should be automatic 30-day suspensions. JEFFREY G. MARINER New Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Disarmament Rally Is Biggest Since 1982
description: A march, rally and program of music and speeches advocating nuclear disarmament drew more than 60,000 people to the United Nations and Central Park yesterday in what the police said was New York City's largest political demonstration since 1982.

title: Deficit Warning in Hartford
description: Despite earlier predictions of a modest budget surplus, the Governor's budget chief now concedes that the state could end the fiscal year with a deficit and is warning state agency heads to be prepared for spending cuts next year. The official, Anthony V. Milano, sent a letter to the state's commissioners and agency heads this week telling them their share of next year's $6.3 billion budget could be in jeopardy if revenues fall short. Mr. Milano would not estimate the size of the possible deficit. The next fiscal year begins July 1.

title: Europe Inc.
description: To the Editor:

title: Eroding Empire
description: To the Editor:

title: Westfield Potter Lauded
description: ALBERT GREEN, a potter from Westfield, will be among 16 artists inducted into the College of Fellows of the American Crafts Council in San Diego, Calif., tomorrow night at a meeting of the council's trustees in the San Diego Museum of Art.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Oakland, Calif.;
Strong Anchor For a Revival
description: LEAD: REDEVELOPMENT of 15 downtown blocks here has been a difficult process that began almost 20 years ago. But a milestone has been reached with the agreement of American President Companies Ltd., one of Oakland's largest employers, to be the major tenant for the final office building in a downtown business park known as City

title: IN ALPHABET CITY
description: TUCKED AWAY IN AN OFFICE building in New York's garment district, the video display screens are glowing brightly at 3 A.M. with a green-and-black crazy-quilt design. This is the headquarters of Spectrum, the nation's largest multilanguage type house, and the words on the screen are in the Cyrillic alphabet.

title: Sweet Success
description: ON THE WALLS OF HIS home in Bristol, Vt., David Folino displays a collection of 19th-century prints and photographs: bushy-bearded New Englanders, horses yoked to a sledge, sugar maples flanked with wooden buckets, deep snow on the ground.

title: Moscow Police Thwart Rally by Opposition Group
description: Moscow policemen broke up a demonstration by members of an opposition political group today, dragging off a dozen protesters who refused to disperse.

title: At a Crossroads On School Aid
description: THE recent dispute in Albany over state aid to schools tied up budget negotiations and contributed to the three-week delay in adopting a spending plan for the new state fiscal year. The budget was held up by lawmakers from Long Island who were concerned about how the latest aid formula distributes money among the state's 700-plus local school districts.

title: Plan to Save Farmlands Supported by Agriculture
description: LEAD: THE state's agricultural community has united behind a new farmland-preservation proposal that, its supporters say, would protect at least three-quarters of the remaining farmland in New Jersey without hurting farmers economically.

title: Senior Pro Golfers Set for L.I. Tournament
description: LEAD: BEFORE last year's inaugural Northville Invitational, the golf tournament's organizers were not sure there would be another one. Now, in promoting this year's event, they are only sure there will not be another one like it.

title: UNMOURNED LOSSES, UNSETTLED CLAIMS
description: CAPOTE A Biography. By Gerald Clarke. Illustrated. 632 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Female Sleuths
description: To the Editor:

title: Joanne Blodgett And M. L. Root Exchange Vows
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan, Joanne Washington Blodgett, an associate in corporate finance services at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Luxenberg Root, a marketing representative at Ogden Martin, a resource-recovery company in Fairfield, N.J. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony.

title: Where the Workers Are the Owners
description: The man behind the meat counter at the Heritage Supermarket or the woman at the cash register are not just employees; they are among 17 people who have staked their savings on the store and share responsibility for running it.

title: Lisa Mirabile Married To Giles Andrew Birch
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Sharon, Conn., Lisa Grimes Mirabile and Giles Andrew Birch, who both graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University with the class of '85, were married yesterday by the Rev. Gilbert Larsen. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Charles Samuel Mirabile Jr. of Sharon and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Birch of Dover, Mass.

title: Franco's Specter Haunts Police Trial in Spain
description: The traditions from this country's decades of dictatorship and the changes under 13 years of democracy are clashing at a corruption trial of seven policemen here.

title: Dispelling the Myth of the Redhead
description: IT never bothered my father to be called Red. His gold-streaked auburn hair gave him an identity that being an orphan had not. Besides, Red was a macho nickname for a man who was known as Pauly by family and friends.

title: Debra Borzon Marries
description: Debra Ann Borzon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond M. Borzon of Lindenhurst, L.I., was married in New York last evening to James Evan Kaplove, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay L. Kaplove of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated at the Beekman Tower Hotel. The bride is a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology. The bridegroom is a senior vice president and the treasurer of the Burson-Marsteller public relations agency in New York.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: A must for visitors to Mexico City is the Ballet Folklorico. But beware. During a recent trip to Mexico my wife and I discovered that there are two ballet companies: the Ballet Folklorico de Mexico and the Ballet Folklorico Nacional de Mexico.

title: Volunteer Effort Aids Lighthouse
description: LEAD: WHEN a building falls into disrepair, there are usually two choices: tear it down or repair it. But when the building belongs to the Government, when it houses a light that mariners need for guidance, and when it has historical value, things are not that simple.

title: Behind Jim Wright's Book, His Friends
description: At the center of an ethical storm surrounding House Speaker Jim Wright is a modest-sized book written by the Democratic leader and bought in bulk by longtime supporters to benefit him financially.

title: Judo Competitor Wins Sot for Seoul Olympics
description: LEAD: WHEN Eve Aronoff Trivella was 6 years old, she suffered a viral infection that left her legs paralyzed for a year. She stayed home, did her school work in bed and watched a lot of television. One day, she saw an ad for judo classes and ''liked the look'' of the sport.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: Israel's behavior has hardly been a source of pride to the Jews, but Albert Vorspan's platitudes about ''social justice'' do not provide an answer to the problem. If the idea of an international conference is too provocative for Shamir, then give him other, very specific options as part of the American Jewish statement - ideas expressed with clarity and candor and solicited from all of Judaism, particularly from the Reform group of which Mr. Vorspan is so vocally a leader. Mr. Vorspan does well in expressing his personal anguish, but he, like others, offers criticism but no original thinking in solid take-it-to-the-bank ideas. BRENDA R. TANGER Newton Centre, Mass.

title: Is Unix's Time Finally at Hand?
description: FOR years the ritual was the same. Supporters of the Unix operating system would proclaim that their time had come - that widespread acceptance of Unix was at hand. But 12 months later, Unix would remain right where it had been, firmly entrenched in the academic and scientific computing centers and largely ignored by businesses. With all its strengths, its supporters would say, all Unix lacked was momentum, a bandwagon effect that would drive it through the business world.

title: Pluto Atmosphere Reported Observed for the First Time
description: Scientists flying over the southern Pacific Ocean directly observed the atmosphere of Pluto for the first time, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has announced.

title: NOW YOU CAN KISS THE OFFICE GOODBYE
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN the drive to the office offered the members of the limousine class a moment to pause and ponder the challenges of the day ahead. The advent of the cellular telephone, which has become indispensable to car-borne executives, banished contemplation. Now technology has raised the curtain on the final act: the automobile as office.

title: Iran's Gunboats Hit 2 Ships in Persian Gulf
description: Iranian gunboats attacked a West German freighter and a British-owned supertanker today in the Persian Gulf. One crewman died and two were wounded in the attacks.

title: Baseball; Buhner Sparks Yankees
description: When Doug Sisk emerged from the Baltimore bullpen with runners on first and second and one out in the fifth inning yesterday, Jay Buhner, the rookie outfielder for the Yankees, quickly glanced at the scouting report on opposing pitchers that hangs in the team's dugout. Unsatisfied with this preparation, Buhner consulted several of his veteran teammates.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: I deeply resent the unfair and unfounded accusations against me contained in Albert Vorspan's article ''Soul-Searching'' (May 8). His outrageous charge that I put ''a kosher stamp on everything - shootings, deportations, excessive force,'' is belied by the series of unequivocal public statements I issued in the name of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. The metaphor in itself is offensive.

title: Horse Opera
description: THE MAN FROM LARAMIE Starring James Stewart, Donald Crisp, Alex Nicol, Arthur Kennedy. Directed by Anthony Mann. Distributed by RCA-Columbia. 104 minutes. $69.95.

title: Holocaust Lessons: Learning From the Past
description: Allow me to respond to a May 15 letter to the Long Island editor, ''Holocaust: Repetition Dulls the Horror.'' Rena G. Kunis, who wrote the letter, objects to my sharing my Holocaust experiences with the students in schools.

title: Man Held in '80 Death Of Teen-Age L.I. Girl
description: A Suffolk County man was arrested Friday in an eight-year-old murder case after he made statements about his guilt to police detectives who were conducting a routine review of the unsolved crime.

title: Pitching The Big Trip
description: ON A JANUARY NIGHT IN ST. PAUL, Will Steger slipped away from the table before dessert. In a nearby room, he studied a map by the light of a hissing, crackling fire. With Greenland laid out like a tablecloth before him, Steger slowly traced possible routes across the polar circle.

title: The Demise Of Idealism: Community College
description: THE community college system has a complex history whose roots can be traced from the Protestant revolution. The Protestants emphasized everyman's need to read and interpret the word of God; consequently, common schools and public education flourished during the reign of Henry VIII, and it is no accident that the famous publisher, William Caxton, introduced movable type into England at about that time.

title: DATA BANK: June 12, 1988
THE BRONX BOSS'S WORD IS ONLY A SUGGESTION
description: THE Bronx Democratic organization was once a national symbol of an all-powerful political apparatus. Its bosses, Ed Flynn and his successor, Charlie Buckley, could pick up a telephone and order an entire legislative delegation to vote one way. They could single-handedly pick legislators and judges and meet behind closed doors with party leaders to make or unmake statewide and citywide candidates. Who needed messy primaries? Ed Flynn had entree to the Franklin Roosevelt White House, and Charlie Buckley to the Kennedy White House.

title: In Philadelphia, a Look at the Creative Process
description: If Joseph Conrad had written ''Lord Jim'' on a word processor, no one would have known that he was a demon rewriter. On one page alone, in Chapter XIV of his manuscript, he crossed out a dozen words. In almost every sentence, he substituted new phrases, shortened his sentences and simplified his prose.

title: SAVAGES AND SIOUX
description: DALVA By Jim Harrison. 324 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton/ Seymour Lawrence. $18.95.

title: In Pakistan, Democracy Remains Distant
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAKING ALL THE RULES
description: OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY IN Columbus may be the most traditional of campuses in the most American of cities. But just off its tree-lined oval, not far from the U-shaped stadium and the meandering Olentangy River, a new building is going up that, when completed next spring, will be one of the most unsettling structures in the United States.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article on May 8 about leasing fashion showrooms misidentified the brokers who negotiated the deal between Mary McFadden and the owners of 240 West 35th Street. They were Sidney Winoker and Alan Sinovsky of Winoker Realty Company.

title: Socialists Jittery Over French Voting
description: Uncertainty surrounds the outcome of parliamentary elections in France on Sunday, with President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists fearful that they might fall short of a majority in the National Assembly.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MANAGER GO IN ARGUMENTS?
description: Why the big fuss? Being banished to the locker room is like being told to go to your room at home. Fines and suspensions are the ''adult'' substitute punishments. Kicking dirt or playing with it has its own interpretations, so obvious.

title: The Greats Play the Great Outdoors
description: IT may not be unusual over the next several weeks to hear the shrill descant of crickets augment a Bartok quartet. Or a frog to croak bass in Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture'' or seagulls to harmonize with sackbuts.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Becker to Face Edberg: Boris Becker and Stefan Edberg, two of the big favorites for Wimbledon, reached the final of the Grand Slam tournament's main warm-up event yesterday, the Stella Artois Championships at Queens Club in London. Becker, seeded fourth, ended the hopes of Darren Cahill of Australia, 6-2, 6-4. Edberg, seeded No. 1, beat 13th-seeded Guy Forget of France, 7-6, 6-1, in the other semifinal.(AP) Shriver Reaches Final: Pam Shriver of the United States moved into the final of the Dow Classic yesterday in Birmingham, England. In raw conditions that she described as ''horrible, the worst ever,'' the top-seeded player and four-time defending champion reached today's final with a 6-1, 4-6, 6-3 victory over third-seeded Lori McNeil. Shriver will face second-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, who defeated another American, No. 4 Zina Garrison, 6-2, 6-4 on the grass courts of the Edgsbaton Priory club.(AP) A Surprising Winner: Gigi Fernandez, a last-minute recruit for the event, defeated Wendy Turnbull of Australia, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to capture the women's title in the Bank of Scotland tournament in Edinburgh. A first-round loser at a grass-court tournament in Birmingham, England, on Tuesday, Fernandez started play in Edinburgh on Wednesday and was helped to the final when top-seeded Hana Mandlikova withdrew because of a stomach virus.(AP) Smith Defeats Nastase: Stan Smith, a former Wimbledon champion, defeated Ilie Nastase yesterday to advance to the final of the $135,000 MONY Tournament of Legends at the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I. Smith, who beat Nastase for the Wimbledon title in 1972, used a strong drop-volley game in winning the over-35 match, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2. Smith will face Bob Lutz in the final today.(AP) Golf Three-Way Tie for First: Lauri Peterson had six straight birdies en route to a seven-under-par 65 yesterday and moved into a three-way tie at 212 with Nancy Lopez and Caroline Gowan for the third-round lead of the Rochester International at Pittsford, N.Y. Lopez, the tour's leading money-winner, had a consistent round of 71, with one bogey and two birdies. (AP) Barber Overtakes Player: Miller Barber fired a 68 and came from four shots back yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Gary Player and Al Geiberger after three rounds of the Senior Tournament Players Championship at Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Barber will take a 54-hole total of 7-under-par 209 into today's final round. Player, the defending champion, and Geiberger had rounds of 67 and 68, respectively.(AP) Britain and Ireland Retain Cup: Susan Shapcott, at 18 the youngest player on the team, led Britain and Ireland to an 11-7 victory over the United States yesterday in the Curtis Cup women's amateur matches. The victory, at Sandwich, England, enabled the home team to retain the cup it won two years ago in Prairie Dunes, Kan. It was the first time the Americans had lost two straight tournaments in the 56 years of the event.(AP) Soccer Eagles Lose to Bolts: The New Jersey Eagles of the American Soccer League were shut out on the road last night, 2-0, by the Boston Bolts (4-6). After a scoreless first half, the Bolts' Andy Bing connected at 60 minutes 1 second. Boston put the game away 17 minutes later, when David Kulick beat the Eagles' goalie, Greg Kenney. John Ramos, the Bolts' goaltender, saved all 10 shots he faced. Despite the loss, the Eagles (9-2) remained in first place in the league's Northern Division. Returning home to Paterson, N.J., they will face the Fort Lauderdale Strikers at 5 P.M. today. Spain Wins: Spain edged Denmark, 3-2, yesterday in a Group 1 match of the European championships in Hanover, West Germany. In Group 2, England will play Ireland in Stuttgart today, and the Soviet Union will meet the Netherlands in Cologne. (AP) Cycling Hampsten Leads in Italy: Andrew Hampsten of the United States held on to the lead going into the last leg of the Tour of Italy after Alessio Di Basco of Italy won a stage yesterday. Di Basco pedaled the 132 miles from the thermal springs area of Arta Terme to Lido Di Jesolo, a beach resort near Venice, in a total time of 5 hours 51 minutes 33 seconds. Hampsten kept the leader's pink jersey with an edge of 1 minute 49 seconds over Urs Zimmerman of Switzerland.(AP) Auto Racing Dueling for the Lead at Le Mans: Jaguars and Porsches exchanged the lead as their battle continued into the night at the Le Mans 24-hour race in France. After eight hours, the Porsche 962 of Bob Wollek of France, Vern Schuppan of Australia and Sarel Van der Merwe of South Africa led with 133 laps, averaging almost 140 m.p.h. on the 8.41-mile circuit. The Jaguar of Andy Wallace, Jan Lammers and John Dumfries was second, about three minutes behind. (AP) Track and Field World Record in Long Jump: Galina Chistyakova of the Soviet Union set a world record in the women's long jump yesterday, soaring 24 feet 8 1/4 inches to break the record by nearly 3 inches, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. Chistyakova was competing in a meet at Kirov Stadium in Leningrad. Jackie Joyner-Kersee of the United States and Heike Drechsler of East Germany shared the old record of 24-5 1/2.(AP) Dog Show Setter Is Tops: An English setter, Champion Foxtract's the Invincible One, owned by Dorothy Berry, Robert and Ann Elston and Richard Fox, was named best of 2,351 dogs yesterday at the 56th Greenwich Kennel Club Show, on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase. It was the fifth top award for the 3-year-old, who was handled by Mark Threlfall. College Basketball Victory for Rutgers: Miles Dixon had 17 points and Emory Ward added 15 as Rutgers defeated Poligono-Tolcar, 94-64, yesterday in Toledo to open its nine-game tour of Spain. The victory was Bob Wenzel's first as the Rutgers coach. He replaced Craig Littlepage. The Scarlet Knights trailed, 28-25, with seven minutes remaining in the first half, but went on an 18-7 run for a 43-35 halftime lead.(AP)

title: A Lesson in Life At the Grocery
description: DESPERATE for a place to park, I leave my car outside the supermarket and rush over to the station. There has been a big fuss lately about commuters using the supermarket parking lot but, I rationalize, I'm not a commuter and I won't be long.

title: India Awaits the Monsoon, a Welcome Cloud
description: For days now, Indians have been tracking the progress of a huge saturated mass of air moving from south to north, as if its coming offers hope for relief, prosperity and even political stability.

title: Tearooms to the Manner Born
description: LEAD: MANY are the reasons for visiting the venerable country houses preserved by Britain's National Trust. There are the ancient facades, encrusted with the patina of centuries of continuous habitation; the enveloping parks, studded with manicured oaks, and the long galleries lined with portraits of ancestors in ruff collars.

title: North Wanted to Use Waite, Book Charges
description: Oliver L. North wanted to use the Church of England's special envoy, Terry Waite, to lure Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to his compound in Tripoli to increase the chances that the Libyan leader would be killed in a 1986 American air raid, according to excerpts of a book being published in U.S. News & World Report.

title: Carousel's Supporters Still Wait for a Ride
description: LEAD: THE merry-go-round in Lighthouse Point Park in New Haven does not work. It didn't work last summer, either. It did work in 1985 and 1986, but that is not good enough for Raymond Lavenway, who has spent eight years volunteering his time to get the carousel restored.

title: 'The Best Situation Is a Glass Cage'
description: HENRY B. FREYE is an allergist with offices in Mystic and Waterford. He is a former president of the New England Society of Allergy and the Rhode Island Society of Allergy.

title: Review/Dance; Rod Rodgers Company at 20 Years
description: Rod Rodgers has a calm yet impassioned way with dance and its rendering of the world about it. And that was much in evidence in ''El . . . Encounter,'' a recent work presented by the Rod Rodgers Dance Company on Friday at Theater of the Riverside Church, in a program celebrating the company's 20th anniversary.

title: An Afghan Exile, Her School and Hopes for Future
description: ''No one has been brave enough to help the women,'' Tajwar Kakar said. ''No one has even tried. This is not Afghan culture. This is not how I was raised to behave in my country.''

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $625,000 20 Tern Court 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; c/a, pool with cabana, tennis court, 1.5 acres, 2-car garage; taxes $6,800. Selden $110,500 24 Peconic Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $960. Tanglewood Hills $135,000 106 Sequoia Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; family room, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Westbury $300,000 32 Glenwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; center hall, dining room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $6,400. Williston Park $177,000 220 Broad Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; basement, attic, 1-car garage; taxes $1,600. OTHER AREAS New Rochelle, N.Y. $337,500 27 Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; powder room, eat-in kitchen, den, full basement, 2-car garage, 0.2 acre; taxes $5,011. Stratford, Conn. $248,500 300 Arrowhead Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; center-hall entrance, on cul de sac, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,344. Plainsboro, N.J. $273,000 6 Chandler Court 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; family room, c/a, 2-car attached garage; taxes $3,623.

title: Scouting the Vice-Presidential Field
description: Michael S. Dukakis this week ordered reporters covering his campaign not to pay any attention to ''highly placed advisers and well-placed sources'' in writing about whom he would pick as his running mate. Mr. Dukakis said that he and only he was a good source on that subject.

title: AT 34, DORSETT IS STILL ELUSIVE
description: HIS dad used to call him Turtle, and his college friends called him Hawk. That suited Tony Dorsett fine, though then and now he prefers this description: ''Tough, tough, tough. Man, I was always the toughest.'' Yet Tony Dorsett is afraid to sleep in the dark. ''I've always been a person afraid of the dark,'' Dorsett said sheepishly. ''I was taught that when you have complete darkness, that's when spirits walk. In our house when I was growing up, all the doors were always cracked a little bit at night so you could get light into the room. You come in my house now and you're gonna see light everywhere. Even now when I sleep, I leave the bathroom light on and leave the door cracked. And I'm not ashamed to tell you.''

title: Summer Homework Angers Parents
description: WHAT seemed like a simple requirement from the principal of the Branford Intermediate School - that students in grades five through eight read two books during summer vacation and then be tested on them when they return to school in the fall - is angering some parents.

title: Cheryl Jane Vieser Marries Donald Street Kleckner Jr.
description: Cheryl Jane Vieser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Vieser of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Donald Street Kleckner Jr., the son of Mrs. Kleckner of Chatham, N.J., and the late Mr. Kleckner. The Rev. Charles Barber, assisted by the Rev. David Evans, performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Walpole, N.H.

title: Miss Jurgensen and Tonio Palmer Wed
description: Anne Barbara Jurgensen, the daughter of Hans Peter Jurgensen of Dusseldorf, West Germany, and the late Heilke Jurgensen, was married yesterday to Anthony George Walter Palmer, the son of Walter de Kay Palmer of Tyringham, Mass., and New York and Elizabeth Gatterburg Palmer of New York.

title: A Chinatown Businessman Is Charged in a Slaying
description: A prominent Chinatown businessman shot and killed an apparently armed street-gang member with a barrage of 19 bullets Thursday night in a confrontation at the businessman's office, the police reported.

title: Bronx to Get a Big Town-House Complex
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on the largest low-rise residential development ever undertaken in the Bronx - a complex of 1,183 town houses along the East River in the Clasons Point section. It will rise in phases over several years, giving the borough, for the first time in decades, a new community for middle-income homeowners.

title: Unilateral Disaster
description: Everyone knows that the Reagan Administration's policy in Panama has been a humiliating failure. Announced as a sure way to blow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega out of Panama, it entrenched him and made the United States look ridiculous.

title: HOW TO READ A BOOK
description: This talk was delivered at the opening of the first book fair in Turin, Italy, on May 18.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: STOPPARD AT SETON HALL Tom Stoppard, the British playwright, will read from and discuss his works Tuesday evening in the Bishop Dougherty Student Center at Seton Hall University in South Orange. The program starts at 8 P.M.

title: Mailbox; A Baseball Can Be Lethal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Teaching Doctors Through Medical Make-Believe
description: MARGARET AND JOSEPH MCGOVERN try to see that art imitates life. That is no easy task when the life involved uses the highly specialized language of medicine. Yet their compelling theater has won good reviews from some tough critics - doctors.

title: Giuseppe Saragat Is Dead at 89; President of Italy From '64 to '71
description: Giuseppe Saragat, President of Italy from 1964 to 1971 and an strong opponent of Facism and Communism, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Rome. He was 89 years old.

title: Cash In, Cash Out
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE PRESIDENT IS COMING TO LUNCH. By Nan and Ivan Lyons. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Nan and Ivan Lyons have once again concocted a racy book that sizzles with gourmet delights. As in their first novel, ''Someone Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe,'' the center of the action is a fashionable restaurant - in this case a Manhattan watering hole called Libby's, known as ''the kingdom of glitz.

title: Ms. Ruttenberg and Randall J. Pattee, Lawyers in Minneapolis, Are Married
description: At the Washington Cathedral, Valerie Honore Ruttenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Charles B. Ruttenberg of Washington, and Randall James Pattee, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Pattee of Dubuque, Iowa, were married yesterday by Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington.

title: Sports People; Second Thoughts
description: THERE'S nothing like reaching a milestone to provide a lift to one of life's weary travelers. That seems to be the case with Doug Moe, the coach of the Denver Nuggets. Until recently, Moe, who will turn 50 in September, had let it be known that he planned to retire when his contract expires in 1990.

title: Can Science Play as Well in Peoria as in Boston?
description: LEAD: NOT SINCE THE PRODUCERS OF ''Cosmos'' built a facsimile of the library of Alexandria for Carl Sagan to browse in and a huge starship panel to fly by has public television been so ambitious in presenting the workaday world of science and its visions.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Several years ago I had an underground lawn sprinkling system installed at considerable expense. I didn't realize that I would have an expense twice a year of starting the system up each spring, then shutting it down (draining it) in the fall. Is it possible for me to do this work myself?

title: AT THE CENTER OF THE 60's
description: REUNION A Memoir. By Tom Hayden. Illustrated. 539 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: DEBTS ON THE RISE - WHAT, ME WORRY?
description: MY BROTHER BUYS GOLD.

title: TV's Film Editors Giveth As Well as Taketh
description: AS FAR AS TELEVISION IS CON- cerned, the movies have again become something of a ''magic box.'' Sometimes you see what you think you're going to see. Frequently you don't. That old black-and-white classic, for instance, may suddenly pop up on your home screen in soupy colors just this side of gray. But this is the least of a movie buff's problems, easily solved by turning down the color button on the TV set.

title: Soviet Pianist to Make State Debut
description: LEAD: THE Soviet emigre pianist Vladimir Feltsman will make his New Jersey debut next weekend, opening the Waterloo Festival Orchestra's 13th season with Beethoven's Third Piano Concerto. Gerard Schwarz will conduct.

title: Practical Traveler; Safeguarding Your Home
description: Those old lists about how to prepare to load the kids into the Norman Rockwell flivver for vacation always began with the homey entry: ''Stop milk deliveries.''

title: Residential Resales

Wonica)

title: An Endangered Species: The Fairfield Bowling Alley
description: DICK MOLLO recalls how, about a quarter-century ago, there were more than a half-dozen bowling establishments in Stamford, and all of them were thriving. For the last five years, though, Stamford, despite its growth, has had only one place to bowl - Bowlarama, in the Glenbrook section.

title: By Train From Rome To Zurich
description: THE rapido from Rome to Milan was late again, as that premier train of the Italian State Railways often is, and there were only a few minutes left to catch the 1 P.M. express to Zurich. Lugging a heavy suitcase and a carry-on, I jogged from platform 12 to platform 5 under the grimy steel-and-glass roof of Milan Central Station and found a long row of empty coaches. One small sign, alas, read (in Italian only): ''This section does not leave.'' An ultimate spurt was required to reach the Zurich train, which was sitting farther out on track 5, in the open.

title: Reviews/Music; Program of Americana By Concordia Ensemble
description: Concordia is a chamber orchestra with a special brief for concert works that draw on elements of popular music, particularly jazz. The orchestra dabbles in the standard literature, too - it offered the Beethoven Seventh earlier this season, and its prospectus for next year includes symphonies of Beethoven and Mendelssohn. But to close the orchestra's fourth season, Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, its founder and conductor, Marin Alsop, kept the focus firmly on the group's specialty.

title: Fanelli Contests Dismissal by O'Rourke
description: WHEN County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke announced he had dismissed Marino J. Fanelli, the county's suspended Director of Probation, he said that ''no charges are necessary,'' because it had been discovered that Mr. Fanelli had never taken an oath of office.

title: Music at Festival Brings Romantics Into Focus
description: LEAD: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY'S second SummerFest will examine Romantic music through concerts, lectures and panel discussions.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 12, 1988
description: Weeks This on Week List Fiction 1 8 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 3 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 3 3 TENDER REBEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A Scottish heiress accepts the aid of a handsome rake in her search for a husband. 4 6 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.50.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago. 5 2 TIMETRAP, by David Dvorkin. (Pocket, $3.95.) Captain Kirk of ''Star Trek'' stranded in a strange new empire 100 years in the future. 6 2 THE AWAKENING, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) A hot-blooded union organizer arouses the desires of the daughter of a California rancher. 7 14 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 8 2 FIRST BORN, by Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $4.95.) The rivalry of sisters and cousins, played out in the worlds of high fashion and politics. 9 5 DIRK GENTLY'S HOLISTIC DETECTIVE AGENCY, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $4.50.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Correspondent's Choice; In Provence's Luberon Range
description: FOR several days of meandering it had seemed that the best views of Luberon mountain range in Provence were from the cemeteries. A gesture of Christian kindness for those six feet under, but even more so for those who come to remember the dead. At Menerbes, a village stretched like a ship bow-to-stern across a cliff, it was at the graveyard that one could take in the royal sweep of the valley below and, beyond, the ridge brushed with snow. The same was true in Saignon, another postcard-pretty village clinging to its rocky perch, where it was good to stop for a cafe noir by the gurgling fountain in the little square. The secret of Saignon is the cemetery behind its fat Romanesque church: a window out of the cramped streets onto the long valley and the mountains.

title: GREEN LEADS WESTCHESTER CLASSIC BY 1 SHOT By GORDON S. WHITE Jr.
description: Ken Green, who said he wants to win the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic more than the British or United States Opens, was in a better position than anyone to do just that as he took a one-shot lead into the final round of the event, played 30 miles from his home in Danbury, Conn.

title: In Madison, Shape and Color
description: IN Sewell Sillman's show at the Madison Gallery, nothing is what it seems to be. What look like prints turn out to be watercolors; the shapes in them that appear to be flat chevrons are in reality rhomboids, A-frames and other geometric figures modeled and suspended in space as if they were origami.

title: A Doctor And His Images
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN may be proud of being born in the U.S.A., but Dr. Ronald David Weiss of Fair Lawn says the Garden State is just as fine a birthplace to boast about.

title: Martha Clarke's Thorny Garden
description: IT'S 1:30 IN THE MORNING IN THIS historic, genteel quintessence of the South, and the only people visible at the downtown crossroads of Broad and Meeting Streets are Northerners. The intersection is known as the Four Corners of Law, for the four laws represented by the city, county, Federal and church buildings that occupy it. But for this moment there is also a fifth law: Martha Clarke.

title: A Sculptor Caught Up in His Materials
description: THE EARLIEST SCULPTURE IN ''William Tucker: The American Decade, 1978-1988,'' at the Storm King Art Center, is called ''Justice.'' It dates from 1978 and is about 12 feet tall. It is abstract and architectural. It consists of wood beams built into an L-shaped structure, with an additional beam projecting diagonally upwards from the juncture where the two sections of the L intersect. The diagonal is like a lever. There is a sense that pulling it would mean execution. If the sculpture is about justice, that justice is pitiless and final.

title: Achievers Seek Advanced Diploma
description: LEAD: BY now, most Long Island high school seniors have completed their major examinations, but 15 seniors from three Long Island high schools have gone one step further by taking the International Baccalaureate, exams they hope will result in an I.B. diploma.

title: Doctor Calling It Quits To Run Coin Laundry
description: An anesthesiologist says he is quitting his practice to run a self-service laundry and dry-cleaning business because the wash carries a lot less liability than medicine.

title: Lamp by Frank Lloyd Wright Sells for $704,000, a Record
description: A stained-glass lamp designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, probably made in 1908 for the Frederick C. Robie House in Chicago, was sold yesterday at Christie's for $704,000, a record at auction for any work by a 20th-century designer.

title: McDonald's Tries Paris, Again
description: SIX years ago, McDonald's here was a model of everything the company tries not to be. In one Paris McDonald's, raw french fries were stored next to trash bags on the basement floor. To enter the McDonald's near the Gare St. Lazare, customers had to pass through the arcade of a porno movie theater. At a McDonald's on the Champs-Elysees, not only was the company's name misspelled out front, but the frying oil was the color of crankcase oil and open cans of insect spray stood atop boxes of Big Mac sauce.

title: Deirdre Connolly, Medical Student, Weds a Biologist
description: The marriage of Deirdre Connolly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Connolly of Locust Valley, L.I., to Olaf Sporns, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl L. Sporns of Kiel, West Germany, took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I. The Rev. John McCann performed the ceremony.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Critics Question Mitchel Field's Success
description: LEAD: TEN years ago, with its economy in trouble, Nassau County initiated nationwide efforts to attract commercial and industrial development to the 1,265-acre former Mitchel Field air base.

title: Plan for Commission On Shore Is Evolving
