description: THE ocean pollution that fouled New Jersey's beaches last summer, and inspired passage of a number of ocean-protection bills this year, may also result in the creation of a new agency with broad powers to regulate development along the shoreline.

title: Some Vestiges of the Last Emperor
description: THE last vestige of ''The Last Emperor'' may be two sets of stamps issued by Manchukuo. Two decades after Hsuan Tung, through his regent, abdicated as the last emperor of China, a Japanese-controlled regime in effect created Manchukuo out of Chinese Manchuria and installed him as emperor there.

title: Exploring Chateaus Of the Meuse Valley
description: IN Belgium, the Meuse is a river of two faces. The stretch from the French border passes Dinant with its ancient citadel perched like an aerie overlooking the town. Then it flows on to Namur, through some of the most beautiful countryside in Belgium. Here the riverbanks are lined with summer villas, chateaus, inns, outdoor cafes and towering cliffs. Pleasure craft, some towing water-skiers and excursion boats, ply the water along with heavy-duty barges and other commercial craft. Fishermen along the banks and in rowboats haul in trout, pike, carp, bream, eel and tiny fresh-water lobsters called ecrivisses.

title: Freeport Fights Group-Home Law
description: LEAD: THE Padavan law was intended to get mental health patients out of institutions and into group homes. It calls for an even distribution of homes, forbidding overconcentration in any community. Now, Freeport, faced with a fifth such hostel, is challenging the law itself and its application.

title: Sports People; Friendship Deepens
description: IT was at the MCI Heritage Classic in April that golf fans got a glimpse of the softer side of Greg Norman.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE PEPSICO SCULPTURE GARDENS;
Painting a Picture With Plants
description: LEAD: THE azaleas have been blooming at the Donald M. Kendall Sculpture Gardens at the Pepsico headquarters here, but don't look for a bright mass of magenta. There is cream, champagne, pale yellow and peach - but not a hint of the purplish pink that Francois Goffinet finds, frankly, a bit plebeian.

title: Recasting Sullivan & Cromwell
description: LEAD: SEVEN SENIOR OFFICERS OF THE Bank of New York Company and Morgan Stanley & Company were waiting tensely in a windowless conference room at 48 Wall Street, the bank's headquarters, in the late afternoon of Feb. 25 when H. Rodgin Cohen joined their vigil. Cohen, a 44-year-old partner in the venerable law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, the bank's longtime legal counsel, had learned that the Federal Reserve Board had met the previous morning in Washington to consider whether the bank could go forward with its hostile bid to acquire the Irving Bank

title: 'Godspell' Speaks to a New Generation
description: LEAD: THE JOINT WAS CERTAINLY jumping during a recent rehearsal of ''Godspell,'' a revival of the 1970's musical opening tonight at the Lambs Theater. ''Jumping, tumbling, dancing - this show is nonstop action,'' said Anne Marie Bobby, one of a breathless troupe of 10. Don Scardino, director of this vaudevillian journey through the Gospel of St.

title: OWEN, HENRICH SAY CASEY THREW A CURVE
description: Nearly half a century later, they were together again, two old actors reliving their roles in one of baseball's most theatrical scenes.

title:
INVESTING;
Is the Summer Rally Merely Folklore?
description: LEAD: THE stock market rally was in full swing last week as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 30 points to close just above 2,100; the broader market soared as well. Since Memorial Day, the Dow has gained more than 140 points.

title: Personal Ensign Now 8 for 8
description: Risen Star's Belmont Stakes victory overshadowed an outstanding performance 50 minutes earlier by Personal Ensign in the Hempstead Handicap, one of three other stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Airplane Returns to Kennedy After Birds Fly Into an Engine
description: Several birds flew into the engine of a Pan Am jumbo jet yesterday morning, forcing the pilot to turn off the engine and return to Kennedy International Airport on three engines, a Pan Am spokeswoman said.

title: The World: Mideast Mission; Shultz Tries Again, But Peace Seems As Elusive - And Complex - As Ever
description: AS Secretary of State George P. Shultz raced around the Middle East last week, trying again to gain support from Israel and its Arab neighbors for the United States peace plan for the region, a White House spokesman was asked about chances for success.

title: Pro Hockey; Slim Pickings for Local Clubs
description: The National Hockey League conducted a sedate entry draft this afternoon. There were no surprise trades and no infusion of prime talent for any of the three metropolitan area clubs, none of whom selected in the top 10.

title: Old Idea Aids New Housing: The Incentive of Ownership
description: LEAD: JACKIE GARDNER of Norwich is spending much of her time thinking about arranging furniture and picking out paint and wallpaper. For the first time in years, Ms. Gardner, who is 56 years old, will have comfortable housing she and her husband, Arthur, can afford.

title: Fighting the Civil War Anew
description: THE American Civil War, called the War of Northern Aggression by my grandmothers, continues to fascinate us. No other war, not even the Revolutionary War, has fired the public imagination as has the War Between the States.

title: Rebecca J. Idzik Wed To Harry T. Bahr 3d
description: Rebecca Joan Idzik, a daughter of Ann Beckner Idzik of Rye and Daniel R. Idzik of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Harry Theodore Bahr 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bahr Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Henry Hobbs performed the ceremony at the Rye (N.Y.) Methodist Church.

title: Cabaret Producer Basks in a New Spotlight
description: THE smoky, black-lacquered room was filled with talk of show business. Chic waitresses slipped between crowded cafe tables where customers discussed auditions, scripts and backers. A well-known actor and his entourage sat along a wall, and several agents were scattered about.

title: Douglas Butler, A Bank Official, Weds Ms. Moore
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Daphne d'Aubigny Moore, the daughter of Kathleen Roe Moore and John C. Moore, both of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas Andrew Butler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Butler of Orange, Calif. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Eli Sagan, Freud and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Pvt. Beetle Bailey, Breaking Into Song
description: WHAT happens when a wayward computer promotes Beetle Bailey, the perennial private and quintessential goldbricker, to the rank of corporal? Can the status of a three-star general be far behind?

title: Presbyterians Urge Israel to End Occupation
description: A committee of the 200th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) adopted a resolution today calling on Israel to end its 20-year occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: ROCKIN' COLT ROLLS TO VICTORY
description: Was it Ronnie Lamarque's serenading of Risen Star before the Belmont Stakes yesterday that brought the colt to the winner's circle?

title: Neighbors Seek to End Skeet Shooting at Club
description: FOR more than 40 years, skeet shooting has been a recognized sport at the Creek Club in Lattingtown. But neighbors, bothered by noise and worried about safety, are trying to put a stop to it.

title: The Testing Story That Came to the Screen as 'Stand and Deliver'
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Suspected Drug Dealers Found Shot Dead
description: Three suspected drug dealers were found shot to death Friday night in an apartment they were sharing in Hamilton Heights, the police reported yesterday.

title: Samuel Montgomery Marries Lindy Judge
description: The marriage of Eileen Mariea Judge, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Judge of Lowell, Mass., to Samuel Bishop Montgomery, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery Jr. of New York, took place yesterday in Boston. The Rev. Brian McMahon performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Marsh Chapel at Boston University.

title: AFGHANS IN EXILE LOSING INFLUENCE TO REBELS IN FIELD
description: As the Afghan insurgents stand on the brink of a military victory against the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul, political power is shifting from the seven rival guerrilla parties based here to the commanders operating inside Afghanistan.

title: SOUL-SEARCHING
description: What is it that Albert Vorspan and others like him fear? Is it that the image of Israeli soldiers defending themselves and their homeland threatens the security of Jews living in America? Indeed, if Jews abroad are cast as villains, Jews here become more vulnerable. The ''shtetl mentality'' is still part of the American Jew's psyche, timid and fearful of repercussions. RABBI AVRAHAM WEISS Hebrew Institute of Riverdale The Bronx

title: Lyme Disease: New Approaches
description: LEAD: THE potentially debilitating effects of Lyme disease, which prompted the state to provide more funds for research earlier this year, have given impetus to new efforts to deal with the troubling illness.

title: KOREAN STUDENTS WANT ONE HOMELAND AND NO AMERICANS
description: ONCE again, South Korea's students have taken to the streets. But this time, rather than pressing for internal democratic change as they did last year, the students are forging a potent link between anti-Americanism and the desire to reunite South Korea with North Korea. Throughout the week, demonstrators, who called for the removal of American troops from South Korea, fought with riot policemen. On Friday, the police blocked a planned meeting with North Korean students at the border village of Panmunjom.

title: Sports of the Times; No Regrets from Lukas
description: UP ahead there was only open space and a fast track and fresh Long Island sunshine, with no other horses to bump or tangle or impede.

title: Massachusetts
description: To the Editor: The item about ferry service (Travel Advisory, April 3) does a disservice to potential visitors to the islands of Massachusetts off Cape Cod.

title: A Once Vital, Cohesive Community Is Slowly, but Not Inevitably, Dying
description: THREE steps up a stoop to the door, a brick front and three windows looking out on the street. Inside, four or more rooms; outside, a backyard for plants, socializing and enjoying the breeze. A typical Camden row house. According to experts, these small and inexpensive individual dwellings once counted among the best ordinary urban housing in America. Yet, they have been neglected and abandoned; a third have been demolished and those remaining are threatened.

title: At Home With the Elizabethans
description: TO find a path less traveled in England is like asking for a country inn along the New Jersey Turnpike, but for the persevering explorer, there are pockets of the country with historical houses and glamorous gardens that are not on every tour-bus route and that have not been written about a thousand times before. Take the county of Northamptonshire, for instance, regarded by many as merely a way station en route from London to Scotland; or Lincolnshire, a rural outback on the way to nowhere, whose only claim to fame in many people's minds is the color green it apparently inspired. Yet there are surprises in both these often-ignored counties, including some little known treasures of architecture and design. Among them are Doddington Hall, an Elizabethan mansion, and Deene Park, a manor house that has been owned by the same family for over four centuries.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STAR MOTHERS: The Moms Behind the Celebrities. By Georgia Holt and Phyllis Quinn with Sue Russell. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Think of this book as a very thick supermarket tabloid, chock-full of stories about dozens of stars and their mothers. Unfortunately, any tidbits of information you pick up while waiting in the checkout line will be a lot juicier and definitely more current.

title: Sports People; Team of Bidders
description: TWO of the investors involved in the scramble to buy the Baltimore Orioles have joined forces. According to The Baltimore Sun, Jerold Hoffberger, the club's former owner, who has been pursuing the team for four months, has teamed up with Ronald Dowdy, a Florida real-estate developer who announced his interest last week.(AP)

title: Audio Geared for Summertime
description: WHAT ABOUT A LITtle summer music? That's the altogether agreeable question faced by lucky listeners heading for their country homes now that the kids are out of school. Lugging along one's regular stereo gear is probably impractical. Very likely the speakers are too big to stash in the car, and besides, unplugging and reassembling all those components just for the summer is daunting. A better solution is to set up a second system for that second home.

title: Headliners; In Protest
description: For some alumni who attended the 30th reunion of Yale University's class of 1958 last week, a few things around campus had changed for the worse.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FLYING JAKE Written and illustrated by Lane Smith. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $14.95. (Ages 2 and up)

title: Books of The Times; Re-examining the New Deal and Its Architects
description: Dealers and Dreamers A New Look at the New Deal By Joseph P. Lash Illustrated. 510 pages. Doubleday. $24.95.

title: GANDHI FOES FACE TEST OF STRENGTH
description: India's fractious political opposition has been struggling to unite before a major test of strength Thursday that could determine who leads the fight against Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in the next general election.

title: Pinochet Looking to Extend Tenure
description: Facing a strong electoral challenge to his 15-year presidency, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is said by supporters to have begun searching for a strategy to assure that he remains in power after a coming plebiscite.

title: Corrections
description: The headline on a brief article in some copies of the Sports section yesterday about the Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks fight was incorrect. Bill Cayton, Tyson's manager, wants the bout to be 12 rounds, not 15.

title: Aranyaprathet Journal; For Innocents Scathed by War, a Sort of Self-Help
description: For several thousand Cambodian refugees and poor Thai villagers struggling to survive along a border pockmarked by war, the unending battle for Cambodia has exacted a particularly heavy price. Wounded in battle, blown up by land mines, struck down by epidemic diseases or born with birth defects, they have become a handicapped minority in a small world already full of suffering and death.

title: Executive Says He Was Asked for Navy Yard Lease Bribe
description: The head of a ship-repair company says that he was solicited for a bribe of up to $70,000 in March to obtain a lease at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and that he was told the payoff would go to the counsel for the agency that runs the Navy Yard.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Report

title: Cable TV Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $68,000.

title: Byron Allen, Agriculture Official
description: Byron G. Allen, a former Assistant Secretary of Agriculture and a key figure in the merger of the Democratic and Farmer-Labor parties in Minnesota, died Friday at the age of 86.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Up
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose slightly in May as new entries to the labor force quickly snapped up the new jobs created by the country's strong economy, the Government's statistical agency reported Friday. The unemployment rate rose to 7.8 percent, from 7.7 percent in April, with the number of unemployed totaling 1,042,000. Figures are adjusted for seasonal variations. Statistics Canada said that 68,000 new jobs were created in the month but that there was a matching increase in the labor force.

title: Soccer; Acosta Finds His Dreams Close to Home
description: Jorge Acosta still looks like a man who dreamed about the impossible and woke to find it on his doorstep. Two months after the New Jersey Eagles played their first game, Acosta still glows with disbelief.

title: Wright Expects No Fallout From Inquiry
description: House Speaker Jim Wright, expressing confidence that he will be cleared of charges of conflict of interests related to his financial dealings, said today that he did not expect a House inquiry to affect his chairmanship of the Democratic National Convention next month.

title: Los Angeles Police Allowed To Try Hollow-Point Bullets
description: Police here have won permission to use hollow-point bullets on a one-year trial basis, outraging critics who say the bullets inflict far more serious wounds than conventional ammunition.

title: Even if Israel Budges, Then What?
description: Polls now suggest that Israelis, who will vote this fall, favor the hard-line Likud bloc and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, adamant foes of any trade of land for peace. But whatever the outcome, the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza has fundamentally affected attitudes, even in Mr. Shamir's bloc. The assumption has been that the occupied territories might be pacified indefinitely without doing violence to Israel's principles. After six months of rebellion, and with more now promised by last week's Arab summit meeting, the election will test that assumption.

title: N.H.L. Board to Hear Devils' Appeal
description: As the National Hockey League's Board of Governors convened today for its annual session of policy-making, league administrators braced themselves for a stormy finale Monday, when they will hear an appeal by the New Jersey Devils over the fine levied against the club and the suspension and fining of its coach during the playoffs.

title: Walter Gladwin, 85, Former Bronx Judge And Assemblyman
description: Walter H. Gladwin, the first black Assemblyman in the Bronx, died of a heart attack yesterday in Arden Hill Hospital in Goshen, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Highland Mills, N.Y.

title: Dolby's Stylistic Stew
description: Thomas Dolby wants his listeners to know that his current hit, ''Airhead,'' a snide put-down of a chesty, long-legged girl who's ''not an intellectual giant,'' doesn't sum up his view of women. At the Ritz on Friday, Mr. Dolby and his band, the Lost Toy People, were in the middle of ''Airhead'' when the percussionist and singer, Laura Creamer, trussed Mr. Dolby in his tailcoat and grabbed the microphone for a double-time rap. After she declared ''This is one airhead you don't control,'' she picked up a pair of hedge clippers and threatened to deprive Mr. Dolby of his manhood. Three male band members pacified her and insisted, ''The man's tongue is in his cheek,'' and freed Mr. Dolby for his last lines: ''It was men made her that way/It was us made her that way.'' But Ms. Creamer had the last, dismissive word.

title: Bridge
description: Competition between teams representing different clubs is common in Europe but rare on this side of the Atlantic. One of these rarities is the Cavendish Challenge Cup in Manhattan, contested last Thursday by 16 social and commercial clubs. The winners were Merrill Lynch, ahead of the host Cavendish Club and the Knickerbocker Club.

title: Safecard Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Summer Skiing: Mornging Adventures in the Alps
description: SNOW may have melted off the mountains in the Northern Hemisphere, but glaciers never die. In fact, they hold enough snow for skiing 12 months of the year, right through the summer. In the Alps, a number of ski resorts have installed lifts and developed skiing terrain on glaciers for winter use and these are often kept open through the summer. A few resorts on this continent have done so as well.

title: First Provident Group reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Argentine Jet Crashes; 22 Are Presumed Dead
description: A DC-9 jetliner with 22 people on board crashed in heavy fog today while trying to land at an airport in northeastern Argentina, officials said. All those on board were presumed dead.

title: New Goals for a Stronger Chrysler
description: Judging by the Chrysler Corporation's low stock price, the financial community is taking a dark view of the company's prospects. But judging by the strong sales of Jeeps, mini-vans and cars that have enabled Chrysler to increase its market share, consumers like what they see.

title: OUTLOOK ON AIDS IS TERMED BLEAK
description: The fourth international AIDS meeting opened here today with a prediction from its chairman that the picture to develop will be even bleaker than expected.

title: Meret Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 24
description: b-After a $1,559,942 loss from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $37,908 and $74,854 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a $334,461 gain from extraordinary items.

title: Three Quakes Hit California
description: A sharp earthquake jolted a wide region of Northern California tonight, but authorities said there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.

title: Inside Israeli Politics
description: The conflict within Israel about turning over land to Arabs who may never be satisfied is expressed in the kind of balancing-act politics that only a Mother of Parliaments could love.

title: American League; Tigers Complete Sweep of Indians
description: Luis Salazar's two-run homer capped a five-run outburst in the first two innings and the Detroit Tigers held on to beat the Cleveland Indians, 5-4, today for a sweep of their four-game series.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; 2 Angels Lead Broadway's Cast of Cash
description: When last we left Karen Goodwin and Elizabeth Williams, they had the aura of prosperous angels. It was a year ago, and they were standing in front of the Broadway Theater, where their investment in the musical ''Les Miserables'' was starting to earn them and their partners a hefty return.

title: Business and the Law; Young Lawyers' Salaries Stabilize
description: SALARIES for young associates at leading law firms are not expected to increase as dramatically as they have in the past two years - a casualty, in part, of the stock market crash and retrenchment on Wall Street.

title: Harvey Group Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $164,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $144,000. The company said the 1987 first quarter included a gain of $213,000 from the settlement of certain pension obligations relating to the company's terminated defined benefit plans.

title: Entertainment Marketing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a $501,925 gain from the extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss of $859,557 from discontinued operations.

title: International Capital Equipent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Emilie Bakal, Lawyer, Weds Eric Sternbach
description: The marriage of Emilie Bakal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bakal of New York, to Eric Sternbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Sternbach of Great Neck and Westhampton Beach, L.I., took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Rabbi Robert F. Widom officiated. The bride, an associate at the New York law firm of Reich & Reich, graduated cum ladue from the University of Pennsylvania and received a J.D. degree from Boston University. Her father is an author and journalist and president of Carl Bakal Associates, public-relations consultants in New York. Her mother, Shirley Bakal, a former concert pianist, is the assistant to the managing director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

title: Gertrude Soule, 93, of Shakers
description: Gertrude Soule, a Shaker leader whose storytelling helped visitors understand a rapidly disappearing religious community, has died at 93, leaving only two Shaker women in their 90's in the state.

title: Increased Use of Automobiles Is Called a Worldwide Threat
description: Severe traffic congestion and automobile-related health problems will continue to build internationally unless the use of cars is curtailed, according to a study by the Worldwatch Institute, a United Nations-sponsored group.

title: Panel to Take Up Liability Bill
description: Consumer groups and manufacturers are deeply divided over a bill that would replace state product liability laws with a Federal standard to be considered this week by the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Colombia's national airline, Avianca, has suspended freight flights to the United States after paying $3.4 million in fines for cocaine smuggled among fresh flowers, newspapers reported on Sunday. In addition, Florida's state treasury is levying a fine equivalent to 20 percent of the street value of the cocaine impounded, or nearly $2 million, one paper said. Avianca officials were not available for comment this weekend. Avianca carries a daily average of 13,000 boxes of flowers to the United States and brings back to Colombia up to 90 tons of merchandise.

title: Violent Clash in Bangladesh
description: The police clashed today with demonstrators protesting a constitutional amendment that made Islam the state religion. The authorities said 50 people suffered minor injuries. The demonstrations coincided with a one-day strike called to protest the new law, passed Tuesday by Parliament and signed into law by President H. M. Ershad.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Tony Lazzeri, the old-time Yankee second baseman, was never elected to the Hall of Fame. Since few of the players enshrined were voted in for their fielding ability, how do Lazzeri's batting statistics compare with those of the second basemen who are in the Hall of Fame? There are nine second basemen with plaques at Cooperstown, and in descending order of batting averages they are: Rogers Hornsby, who played from 1915-31; Nap Lajoie (1896-1916), Eddie Collins (1906-30), Charlie Gerhinger (1924-42), Frankie Frisch (1919-37), Jackie Robinson (1947-56), Billy Herman (1931-47), Bobby Doerr (1937-51) and Johnny Evers (1902-17).

title: International Yogurt Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jetronic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brown Group Inc., St. Louis, a consumer products company with operations in footwear and specialty retailing, elected Harry E. Rich executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Repast, for the Future
description: The menu was written in English and Cyrillic. But the conversation and the toasts were in English with a few Russian phrases thrown in as a group of 20 Soviet women who make their homes in the capital joined 40 Washington women for lunch at Nora's restaurant.

title: Survival Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Meryl Sali Justin, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Meryl Sali Justin, an associate in the New York law firm of Schoeman, Marsh, Updike & Welt, and Michael Chertoff, the first assistant United States Attorney for New Jersey, were married yesterday at the Oakside in Bloomfield, N.J. Dr. Gershon B. Chertoff, the rabbi of Temple B'nai Israel in Elizabeth, N.J., and the father of the bridegroom, officiated. He was assisted by the bridegroom's uncle, Rabbi Mordechai Chertoff.

title: Tolleson Lifts Yankees Over Orioles, 6-5
description: Willie Randolph, who could be losing his season, sat in the dugout yesterday and watched Wayne Tolleson recover his. The sight couldn't allay all of Randolph's personal anxiety, but he admitted it was reassuring to see Tolleson calm many of the concerns of his teammates.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perhaps we have won tonight a victory against our hereditary enemy - division.'' - Valery Giscard d'Estaing, former President of France. [ A9:3. ]

title: U.S. Cyclist Captures Tour of Italy
description: ''You can't lose a bicycle race,'' Andy Hampsten insists. ''One person can win it but there aren't 150 losers.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Neo-Nazi Activity Is Arising Among U.S. Youth
description: LEAD: A neo-Nazi political movement that has produced racially motivated crimes in Britain has begun to show up among teen-agers in the United States, alarming law-enforcement authorities and civil rights groups.

title: New York Begins Citing Smoking Law Violators
description: Larry Perry hardly stirred from the sizzle of his grill when a man with a plastic briefcase and a New York City health inspector's badge walked into his near-empty diner.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 2 Health-Care Accounts Won by Mullen Agency
description: The Mullen ad agency in Wenham, Mass., is going on a health kick: it has won the accounts of the Tufts Associated Health Plan and Medivision.

title: Blazes Ravage Israel's Forests; Arabs Blamed
description: Thousands of acres of Israel's scarce forest and natural woodlands were set afire over the weekend and the Police Minister, Haim Bar-Lev, and other officials blamed Palestinian arsonists for the destruction.

title: Cortronic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Olympic Notebook; Ben Johnson to Keep a Secret
description: Last week, he was tucked away in Padua, Italy. This week, he could be anywhere.

title: U.S. Open Could Signal Shift in Balance of Power
description: THE eight-column headline across the front page of Sports Section of The New York Times on Sunday, Sept. 21, 1913, read: ''Great British golfers defeated by Massachusetts boy in National Open tourney.''

title: Joan Morse Pritchard Wed to Edward Clark
description: Joan Morse Pritchard, the director of music and the pastoral assistant at the Elmwood Community Church in West Hartford, Conn., and Edward Ethan Clark, the director of music at the First Church of Christ, Congregational, in Farmington, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. James Simpson performed the ceremony at the Farmington church.

title: Dawkins Trails Despite Gains, A Poll Indicates
description: Former Brig. Gen. Pete Dawkins, the New Jersey Republican candidate for the United States Senate, increased his name recognition with a $1 million advertising campaign earlier this year but still trails the incumbent Democrat, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, by 17 points, according to a Star-Ledger/ Eagleton poll of voters released yesterday.

title: Mets Collapse in 11, Lose Fifth Straight
description: To Davey Johnson, it was ''a shame.'' To Howard Johnson, it was ''terrible.'' To Keith Hernandez, it was ''the worst.'' And to Andres Galarraga of the Montreal Expos, who made it all those things for the Mets, it was ''unbelievable.''

title: Silk Greenhouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Abiomed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Amy L. Feldman Wed To Dr. Andrew Green
description: Amy Louise Feldman, a daughter of Mrs. Elliot A. Feldman of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Mr. Feldman, and Dr. Andrew Green, a son of Alvin Green and Dr. Miriam Green of Great Neck, L.I., were married yesterday at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi David Feldman performed the ceremony.

title: Hale Systems reports earnings for Year to March 31
Dukakis Backers Agree Platform Will Call South Africa 'Terrorist'
description: Backers of the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis yielded today to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's demand that South Africa be branded a ''terrorist state'' in the Democratic Party's platform.

title: Louis L'Amour, Writer, Is Dead; Famed Chronicler of West Was 80
description: Louis L'Amour, who turned out novel after best-selling novel about plain-speaking, straight-shooting heroes of the old West, died Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80 years old.

title: MAJORITY ELUDES FRENCH SOCIALISTS IN NEW PARLIAMENT
description: The Socialist Party of President Francois Mitterrand today fell short of a majority of seats in the National Assembly, but a rightist coalition also failed to retain its legislative control.

title: A Soviet Joint Venture Is Special to Coin Dealer
description: Eugene V. Czaplinsky has tried teaching, acting, screenwriting and even running an Indian restaurant. Now he is applying his artistic bent, as well as drawing on his Russian heritage, in an unusual joint venture with the Soviet Union.

title: Tucker Drilling Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mexico's Economic Plan, 6 Months Old, Slows Inflation
description: Last December inflation in Mexico reached a then record monthly high of 14.8 percent, capping a year that saw the consumer price index rise 160 percent, the largest amount in Mexican history. Last month, however, inflation dipped to less than 2 percent, the lowest monthly figure in nearly seven years.

title: Proler International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Adena K. Berkowitz Is Married to Zev J. Brenner
description: Adena Karen Berkowitz, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. William Berkowitz of New York, and Zev Joseph Brenner, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Paul Brenner of Brooklyn, were married last evening at the Sheraton Centre in New York by the bride's father, who is the national president of the American Jewish Heritage Committee in New York.

title: S. A. Wolff Wed To Gail E. Loflin
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., Gail English Loflin, a daughter of John J. Loflin of Rye and the late Bonnie Loflin, was married yesterday to Steven Alexander Wolff, the son of Joan M. Wolff of Port Chester, N.Y., and Joel C. Wolff of New York. The Rev. Sharon H. C. Clayton and Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony.

title: Horse Racing; Risen Star's Feat Is Hard to Figure
description: The mile-and-a-half distance of the Belmont Stakes often makes it a tough race to predict. The 120th running Saturday, which Risen Star won by an astounding 14 3/4 lengths while running the second fastest time in the history of the race, shows that making sense of it afterward can be equally tough.

title: Warner Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $500,000 gain from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.

title: Army Plan to Mail Warfare Toxins Draws Protest
description: An Army plan to ship biological warfare substances through the mail and by courier services has ignited protests and is bringing to public attention the fact that infectious agents like these are already routinely shipped.

title: Galaxy Cheese reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Solution to Stock Volatility Lies in Dividends
description: To the Editor:

title: Vander Meer Went Fishin'
description: THE phone call last week to Johnny Vander Meer's home in Tampa, Fla., didn't fall on deaf ears, it just didn't fall on Johnny's ears.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Janet M. Galchick has been appointed senior vice president of Young & Rubicam New York.

title: A Sailing Course Especially for Women
description: THEIRS is a family affair, but with a national focus. Four women, cousins between the ages of 23 and 30, recently started a recreational sailing program for women in the United States. Boating in New York Harbor is one of their first priorities.

title: Report on Meese Inquiry: 'Unflattering' Conclusions
description: Even though an independent prosecutor's report is not expected to accuse Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d of criminal wrongdoing, Justice Department officials say it will almost certainly provide strong evidence that Mr. Meese was insensitive to the appearance of impropriety.

title: Cribb on Hold
description: As the Reagan Presidency winds down, aides increasingly turn their attention to personal concerns and their own futures, but there is at least one exception.

title: Auto Racing; Familiar Faces at the Finish
description: As the field of 26 Formula One cars lined up here today for the Canadian Grand Prix, a man who raced at Le Mans for the first time nearly 50 years ago offered a lament. ''It's all a business now,'' said Rob Walker, an Englishman who operated his own grand prix team in the 1950's and 1960's. ''It hasn't really been a sport in years.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Broadcasting Museum Planning a Y.&R. Show
description: Although advertising has always been part of the collection of the Museum of Broadcasting, it has always taken a back seat to programming during the museum's 11 years.

title: Odetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National League; Scott Just Misses His 2d No-Hitter
description: Mike Scott came within one out of pitching the second no-hitter of his career as the Houston Astros defeated the Atlanta Braves today, 5-0.

title: OPEC Said To Be Near Price War
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is sliding toward a new price war during the next few months, as its 13 members find themselves locked into irreconcilable differences.

title: INSIDE
description: Louis L'Amour Is Dead The novelist, who chronicled the American frontier in more than 100 books, died of cancer in Los Angeles.

title: North Hills Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,680.

title: Soccer; England Loses; Fans Riot
description: Mounted West German riot police, backed by dogs, broke up fighting between fans today following the match between England and Ireland in the European Championships.

title: In China, Nucleus of Eugene O'Neill Admirers Stages Festival
description: The brooding face of Eugene O'Neill stared out from the window of the Yaxipai motorcycle dealership on Zhongshan Road. Farther on, his face appeared on the rough brick wall of a herbal medicine shop.

title: Treasury Financings Are Limited to Bills
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Newmark & Lewis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter results were restated to reflect certain year-end adjustments.

title: Nancy Carey Becomes Bride Of Alan Goldberg, Executive
description: Nancy Elizabeth Carey, a daughter of Hugh L. Carey, the former Governor of New York, and the late Helen Owen Carey, and Alan Paul Goldberg were married yesterday at the Gideon Putnam Hotel in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Judge Vito J. Titone of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Goldberg of Swampscott, Mass.

title: Moynihan Seeking to Stand System on Its Head
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, an expert on issues involving families since he was in the Nixon Administration, wants to stand the American welfare system on its head. Why? Because he is distraught by current conditions.

title: Metro Matters; Bloody Steps Take a Liberator On to a Museum
description: Fred W. Friendly read a letter aloud the other day, a letter he wrote to his mother in 1945. He has recited it to his family every year since, but said he never before fully shared it with outsiders.

title: Icahn-Gulf Talks Called Inconclusive
description: Discussions between Carl C. Icahn and Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. about a $4.1 billion investment by the oil and gas company were brief and have ended, according to people close to the company.

title: Market Place; Initial Offerings Are Back in Favor
description: INITIAL public offerings, which withered after the Oct. 19 stock market crash, appear to be making a comeback, with several recent new issues being well received by investors.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 12, 1988: MONDAY First Interstate Bancorp Interco Inc Rockefeller Ctr Propts TUESDAY Amer Stores Brunswick Corp Chesapeake Corp First Boston Inc Fleetwood Enterprises Oklahoma G&E Premier Industrial Toro Co Wyle Laboratories WEDNESDAY Carolina P&L Collins Foods DCNY Corp Dow Jones & Co Fairchild Indus Franklin Resources National Service Indus Northwestern Steel & Wire Rochester G&E Ryland Group Inc United Jersey Banks THURSDAY Air Products & Chemicals AT&T Ames Dept Stores Engelhard Corp Ennis Business Forms General Signal Corp Insilco Corp MGI Properties National Fuel Gas NYNEX Corp Triton Energy Vestaur Securites FRIDAY General Cinema Illinois Tool Works Payless Cashways Southeast Banking United Cable Television

title: Tennis; Becker Beats Edberg in Final
description: Boris Becker got a large confidence boost for Wimbledon today as he outdueled Stefan Edberg, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3, to win the $385,000 Stella Artois grass championship at Queens Club.

title: Optek Technology reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After tax credits of $62,360 for the quarter and $94,645 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $111,806 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 6 months.

title: Drug War Is Priority, Dukakis Says
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis appeared before the nation's mayors here today and promised to step up the war on drugs and move it ''to the top of our foreign policy agenda.''

title: The Good News About Nursing Homes
description: To health economists, nursing home costs are like the San Andreas fault: a disaster waiting to happen. That's why newly enacted revisions in Medicare, Federal health insurance for the elderly, stop short of a commitment to pay nursing home bills. Yet a persuasive new report by two analysts at the Brookings Institution suggests that the fears are overstated. Decent care for all the aged could be affordable if Americans of all ages share the responsibility.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Unhealthy Infallibility of Science
description: Some strangled sounds have been emerging recently from the community of academic scientists. They're the noise of errors that no one wants to correct. Scientific leaders, loath to address the causes of poor quality in research, have not seriously begun to develop efficient methods for correcting erroneous claims.

title: Brief Calm Is Predicted for Bonds
description: The conditions that have enabled long-term interest rates to stabilize at around 9 percent should remain in place for the next few weeks, credit market analysts said, but the calm will be fairly brief.

title: 2 Boys Killed in Fire While Mother Is Out
description: Two boys were killed yesterday afternoon in a fire at their home in Queens Village after their mother left the house to get a babysitter for them, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Salthouse Agency Puts Norton in Its Name
description: Salthouse-Torre-Ferrante is changing its name to Salthouse-Torre-Norton, which is nice for Michael Norton, 40 years old, the executive vice president. The change reflects the fact that Frank Ferrante left a while back to start his own firm.

title: Outdoors: Tracking Trophy Trout
description: IN the first week of June five windburned, weary but dedicated anglers spent hour after hour hopping precariously from boulder to boulder along the banks of the first three brawling rapids of the Broadback River in Northern Quebec in pursuit of one of fishing's grails: big trophy brook trout weighing 5 pounds or more.

title: Surge in Steel Exports Is Expected
description: Several American steelmakers, anticipating continued weakness in the dollar and a tightening supply of steel, are taking steps to increase their exports to the highest levels in years.

title: With the Economic Summit, Toronto Hopes Visitors Savor Its Melting Pot
description: When a rusty freighter carrying 174 Indian Sikhs nudged illicitly into a rocky Nova Scotia cove last summer, one of the Sikh immigrants waded ashore, attache case in hand, and asked the first resident he met for help in summoning a taxi to Toronto, more than 1,000 miles away by road.

title: Richardson Assails Meese
description: Elliot L. Richardson, Attorney General in the Nixon Administration, sharply criticized Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d yesterday in a graduation address, calling him ''an anti-role model.'' .

title: Tisch Tries to Pacify CBS Affiliates
description: CBS Inc. executives, faced with mounting dissatisfaction among the network's 200 affiliates, tried today to convince local station owners and managers that they have a plan to lift CBS out of third place in the network ratings.

title: Synbiotics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $41,000 for the quarter and included a tax credit of $103,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Included a tax credit of $2,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Umpqua Journal; New Holy War in This Chosen Land
description: Deep inside the green tunnel of the Umpqua River Valley, on a hillside where the Coast Indians buried their dead, a 36-year-old former New Yorker is growing vegetables and clearing ground for a man he calls Master.

title: Hickok Electrical Instrument Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $145,000 and $160,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $134,800 for the quarter and $70,900 for the 6 months.

title: BLACK REPUBLICAN PICKED IN VIRGINIA
description: Maurice Dawkins, a black businessman and former Democrat, won the Republican nomination Saturdayto run for a Senate seat against former Gov. Charles S. Robb. Mr. Dawkins, 67 years old, is the first black to run for the United States Senate from Virginia since Reconstruction.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Taunton Assignment For Lintas: Vos Direct
description: Taunton Press of Newton, a 13-year-old publisher whose magazine titles include a quartet of sophisticated how-to books, has assigned its direct marketing needs - formerly done in-house - to Lintas: Vos Direct, which ultimately is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Brooklinew: Tough at the Turn
description: The par-71 course at The Country Club offers its strongest challenge after the turn, on the 10th through 13th holes. All are tough tough par 4's ranging from 433 to 453 yards. The Pairings and Starting Times

title: Groups Charge U.S. Surveillance Infringed on Rights of Policy Foes
description: A report by two prominent civil liberties groups has charged that a two-year inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation ''infringed on constitutionally protected rights'' of opponents of the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: 202 Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Manhattan Prosecutor Is Pressing Plan for Evictions of Drug Dealers
description: The Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday that he would move to have suspected drug dealers or users evicted from apartments in which law-enforcement agents found evidence of illegal drugs.

title: Central Bankers Warn Of Further Instability
description: The world's central bankers said today that the recent stability of the financial markets ''should not be taken for granted'' because of the huge trade imbalances.

title: Ballesteros First After 4-Way Tie
description: Seve Ballesteros, who lost on the first hole of a playoff at the Westchester Classic last year, returned to the scene of that defeat and beat Greg Norman, David Frost and Ken Green with a birdie 3 on the first extra hole today.

title: Hagler Retires From Ring
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the former middleweight champion, announced his retirement from boxing today, saying he didn't want to wait around for a rematch with Sugar Ray Leonard.

title: Reviews/Television; Series Explore Family Relationships
description: Relationships sweet, relationships sour: take your pick. On the comforting side of the ledger, there's ''Blue Skies,'' a limited-run series getting under way on CBS at 8 this evening. It was made in America. Then, drenched in British gloom, there's the three-part mini-series ''What If It's Raining?,'' beginning tonight at 11 on Channel 13.

title: Kewaunee Scientific Equipment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $175,000 and $331,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Westerbeke Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Commonwealth Savings & Loan Assn Fla reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary charge of $235,000. The company said the loss for the latest year and fourth quarter are from provisions for losses on its loan and real estate-owned portfolios, including additions to general loss reserves.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL SESSION ON DISARMAMENT - COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE - 6 and 7 P.M. COMMITTEE ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 3 P.M.

title: Why We Were in Vietnam Remains a Closed Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; From St. Louis Opera Theater, Some Rarities
description: In the unpredictable marketplace that is opera, most of this country's investors stick for safety to the repertory's blue chips. But here, the Opera Theater of St. Louis proves each year that a mixed portfolio can yield inspiring returns.

title: An 'Angel' Is Stabbed In Street Fight
description: On the third day of a patrol of Restaurant Row by the Guardian Angels, a teen-age member of the group was gravely wounded Saturday night when he was stabbed in a wild street fight with another group of men.

title: Blue Humor and Songs
description: Millie Jackson is the kind of performer who lets no emotion remain unexpressed. The pop-soul singer, who is famous for larding her vocal performances with X-rated dialogue, is understandably bitter about her comparative lack of success with Whitney Houston and Michael Jackson. And in the first of two shows at Roseland on Friday evening, she scolded the audience for buying Whitney Houston records and not hers and went on to offer the kind of wickedly funny impersonations of her younger colleagues that one might expect from Eddie Murphy.

title: Josep Tarradellas, 89, a Leader In the Fight for Catalan Autonomy
description: Josep Tarradellas, who helped keep the idea of Catalan autonomy alive during 38 years of self-imposed exile from Spain after the civil war, died of a chronic lung ailment on Friday in Barcelona, Spain. He was 89 years old.

title: Floating Point Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the latest quarter included $3.5 million in restructuring expenses.

title: Why We Were in Vietnam Remains a Closed Book; Johnson and the War
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Slaying, an Effort to Unite 2 Worlds
description: In the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Rockaway Avenue is the dividing line between what Alfred Becton calls ''two different worlds, two blocks apart.''

title: Perth Amboy Left Staggered By Its Rioting
description: This has always been a quiet city, within spitting distance of New York City but imbued with an air of suburban calm that shows in the tidy storefronts and well-kept homes that line romantically named streets like Catalpa Avenue and Wisteria Place.

title: Bush Signals a Greater Emphasis On Helping Minority Businesses
description: Signaling that a Bush administration would try to be more sensitive to the concerns of blacks and other minorities than the Reagan Administration has been, Vice President Bush said today that he strongly supports ''increased minority business development efforts by the Federal Government.''

title: 1,400 Seized in Gang Sweep
description: An anti-gang police task force arrested nearly 1,400 people over the weekend and seized several weapons and small quantities of drugs. The police sweep was conducted Friday and Saturday nights throughout the city. Officials said the officers impounded several automobiles and gathered information on suspected and known gang members.

title: Head of Video Chain Expects Consolidation
description: For H. Wayne Huizenga, the key to success is consolidation, and he is now applying that formula in the video rental industry with his fast-growing Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation.

title: Moscow Is Said to Lag in Afghan Pullout
description: Soviet troops, hampered by renewed attacks from Afghan guerrillas, have fallen somewhat behind in their informal timetable for pulling out of Afghanistan, Pakistani and American officials said today.

title: Europe's Plan On Farm Aid
description: The European Community proposed Friday that major farm-producing nations freeze their agricultural support programs, which have distorted world markets and created hostility between trading partners.

title: Cholesterol Phobia
description: LEAD: We are in an era of cholesterol phobia. Man or woman, fat or thin, young or old - everyone is concerned about cholesterol.

title: At 85, Sam Goody Longs For a New Business
description: Sam Goody, the once-upon-a-time music man, wants to play it again, but to a different tune.

title: Amity Shlaes Married to Seth Lipsky
description: Amity Shlaes and Seth Lipsky, editors for the Wall Street Journal/Europe in Brussels, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Karl K. and Marianne Sandstrom Lipsky, in New Marlboro, Mass. Rabbi Harold I. Salzmann performed the ceremony.

title: A Wine Magazine That Aged Well
description: Americans may not be the most sophisticated wine consumers, but they should be the most informed. By most tallies the United States has five or six million serious wine drinkers. Catering to them are at least 30 publications for wine consumers and 75 for the trade. In addition, at least 200 of the country's 1,000 or so wineries publish wine letters. Never, it could be said, have so many written so much for so few.

title: TV Notes
description: Plans for 'West 57th'

title: Savings Unit Suit Reported
description: The current officers of Sunbelt Savings Association have sued their predecessors, charging that fraud, negligence and wasting of assets resulted in the institution's having a $1.6 billion negative net worth, The Dallas Morning News and The Dallas Times Herald reported Saturday.

title: Greece Will Try Palestinian Sought by U.S.
description: A Palestinian wanted by the United States as a suspect in two mid-flight bombings on American passenger planes is to be tried in Greece on charges of traveling with a forged passport, a senior official of the Greek Ministry of Public Order said today.

title: Leon Belasco, Actor, 85
description: Leon Belasco, a Russian immigrant who parlayed his comedic talents and foreign accents into a career as a charactor actor spanning four decades, died June 1. He was 85 years old.

title: Icahn Sought Partner for Texaco Bid
description: Carl C. Icahn testified today that he had been negotiating with Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. for that company to invest $4.1 billion in his proposed takeover of Texaco Inc.

title: New Tax Credit Is Stimulus to Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Opera in Hamburg: A Look at Bessie Smith
description: Once one gets through describing ''Cosmopolitan Greetings,'' an eccentric yet bighearted and affecting avant-garde mixed-media whoozie-whatzit that opened here Saturday night, will continue through the month and eventually wind up as part of the 1989 Next Wave Festival in Brooklyn, one has pretty much reviewed it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 France's Socialists fell short of a majority of seats in the National Assembly, but a rightist coalition lost control of the lower house. Prime Minister Michel Rocard said he would remain at the head of a minority Cabinet. Page A1

title: Monumental Direction
description: Representatives Claude Pepper, 87 years old, a Florida Democrat, and Jimmy Hayes, 41, a freshman Louisiana Democrat, were chatting on a street corner near the Capitol when a Boy Scout troop walked by. The scout leader asked for directions to the ''Jefferson Monument.'' Mr. Pepper told the leader to walk two blocks, turn left at the Library of Congress, walk a few yards, turn again and ''you'll be where you ought to be.''

title: Morgan's Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $402,000 for both the quarter and year. The extraordinary gain reflects termination of the company's pension plan on Nov. 10, 1987.

title: Review/Theater; Children Awaiting the Pied Piper
description: In the world of ''Godspell,'' Stephen Schwartz and John-Michael Tebelak's phenomenally successful folk musical based on the Gospel according to St. Matthew, we are all troubled children adrift in the circusy playground of life, waiting for a spiritual pied piper to lead us to God. When Jesus arrives, with a heart painted on His forehead, clown makeup dripping from His eyes, and a Superman logo across His chest, He is an innocent, sweet-natured hippie who does light magic tricks and knows how to conduct a game of charades. He teaches His flock by having them illustrate New Testament parables in rituals that combine children's games, acting exercises and group therapy.

title: He's Not Flashy But He Wins
description: WHEN Hale Irwin walked off the Muirfield Village Golf Club course two weeks ago and boldly declared that Curtis Strange was the number one player in the world at that moment, some questioned the veteran golfer's opinion.

title: Jackson Share of Votes By Whites Triples in '88
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson garnered three times as many white votes in the 1988 primaries as he did four years ago, but he remained heavily dependent on the ballots of blacks, who provided him with two-thirds of his 6.6 million votes this year.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Interval Training Redefines Fitness
description: FOR years, the Holy Grail of fitness has been the short workout. At its easiest, becoming fit and staying fit is hard work and can even involve mild pain. Finding the necessary time for exercise is frequently the most difficult problem to overcome.

title: Comstock Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Richton International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued businesses of $2,515,000 for the quarter and $2,692,000 for the year.

title: Corrections
description: An answer for the Saturday News Quiz referred incorrectly to macro-phages, a type of immune system cell that can be infected with the AIDS virus. In some patients, macrophages carried the virus without prompting the production of antibodies. This suggests that some people declared free of the virus with commonly used antibody tests may actually be carrying the virus. Those tests are not intended to detect macrophages, which can be examined by other means.

title: Cost of Protecting Witness
description: Protecting a Federal witness costs an average of $118,200 a year, and conducting a state or Federal wiretap $35,000, the Justice Department says in a report on crime and justice that was based on information from 1980 to 1986. The study by the Bureau of Justice Statistics was released Thursday.

title: Concept of a Central Bank Gains Support in Europe
description: When France's former Finance Minister, Edouard Balladur, started pushing the idea of a European central bank six months ago, most government officials and economists said such a far-reaching proposal would go nowhere, mainly because of anticipated West German opposition.

title: JW Mays Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $424,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months included income from a lease termination of $493,884. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary charge of $974,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months included a gain of $4,307,180 from the sale of a leasehold and an extraordinary credit of $905,000.

title: Big Is Beautiful
description: LEAD: Recently, I attended a screening of a superb new film, ''Big,'' starring Tom Hanks. The subject of ''Big'' (a teen-age boy trapped in the body of a man) has been the subject of a plethora of new films this summer - a phenomenon that one can only wonder at unless, of course, one is me. People like me - single, New York City career women - can only wonder why all films are not on this subject (boys in men's bodies).

title: Reporter's Notebook; Faith Meets State in Moscow at the Millennium
description: The pageantry of the Eastern church filled the newly restored ramparts of Moscow's oldest monastery today as prelates, priests and more than 10,000 believers celebrated the millennium of the Russian faith in an open-air divine liturgy.

title: Denmark Fantasies And Ballet
description: The Royal Danish Ballet, which opens a weeklong engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow, has changed since it last performed in New York, in 1982.

title: Lise Susan Rubenfeld Weds A. K. Oelbaum
description: Lise Susan Rubenfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Rubenfeld of Port Washington, L.I., was married at the Lyndhurst estate in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday to Andrew Kenneth Oelbaum, the son of Sylvia Levy of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Harold Oelbaum of Bedford N.Y. Rabbi Donna Berman officiated.

title: Green Blames Himself For Loss
description: The thumping noise heard around Danbury, Conn., tonight was probably Ken Green's head banging against a wall as he blamed himself for losing the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic this afternoon.

title: Standard Logic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a loss of $1,902 for the quarter and a gain of $5,432 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a gain of $72,857 for the quarter and a loss of $52,190 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Pricor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
City Accuses M.T.A. Of '87 Overcharges
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority overcharged New York City nearly $3.3 million for maintenance of commuter rail stations last year, according to an audit by the City Comptroller.

title: Fred Meyer Inc reports earnings for 16wks to May 21
Results Plus
description: Golf Rookie From Taiwan Wins: Mei-Chi Cheng, a rookie from Taiwan, sank a 7-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole yesterday to defeat Nancy Lopez and win the $300,000 Rochester International in Pittsford, N.Y. Cheng, Lopez and Patty Sheehan finished the 72-hole tournament at one-under-par 287, the only players to record sub-par totals. It was the first tournament victory for Cheng, who entered the tournament 30th on the earnings list with $41,102 and took home $45,000.(AP) Casper Prevails by 2: Billy Casper became the seventh player to earn $1 million on the Senior PGA Tour when he posted a bogey-free 67 to win the Senior Tournament Players Championship in Pontre Vedra, Fla., yesterday. Casper shot 278 and finished two strokes ahead of Al Geiberger. The victory was the second of the season for Casper, 57, who has won $1,026,434 since joining the Senior Tour in 1981. (AP) Auto Racing Jaguar Team Wins: Jan Lammers of the Netherlands and two Britons, Andy Wallace and Johnny Dumfries, drove a Jaguar to victory in the Le Mans 24 Hours yesterday, the first time a Jaguar has won since 1957. Porsche has dominated the endurance race for almost two decades. With thousands of British fans cheering it on, the Jaguar XJR-9 won a furious battle with a Porsche 962 driven by the West Germans Hans Stuck and Klaus Ludwig and the Briton Derek Bell. In an unusually close race, the Jaguar covered 394 laps on the 8.41-mile circuit, averaging 137.77 m.p.h. and finished less than a lap ahead of the Porsche. The Jaguar covered a total of 3,314.35 miles.(AP) Wallace Takes Nascar Race: Rusty Wallace won the Budweiser 400 at Riverside, Calif., yesterday. Dale Earnhardt, contending for the lead with seven laps to go, was knocked down three places by a penalty. Terry Labonte finished second. (AP) Road Racing Swiss Runner Wins: Rainer Schenkel, 23 years old, of Lucerne, Switzerland, who turned in a time of 1 hour 12 minutes 19 seconds, won the New Rochelle Half Marathon. Ellyn Block of Ardsley, N.Y., was the women's gold medalist in 1:22.15. Horse Racing 13-1 Shot First: Cutlass Reality, a 13-1 shot, beat three millonaires yesterday as the 1987 Horse of the Year, Ferdinand, finished fourth and last in the $315,200 Californian at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif. Cutlass Reality, a 6-year-old, beat Gulch by 2 3/4 lengths, with Judge Angelucci third. (AP)

title: Punitive Damages: Muzzled Press?
description: A quarter century after the United States Supreme Court handed the press a libel triumph in New York Times v. Sullivan, the press is reeling from a series of costly libel awards. The latest is a $3.05 million judgment the high court let stand last month against CBS. Paradoxically, the seeds of the present threat to the First Amendment were sown in that earlier victory, which established that public figures must prove actual malice and reckless disregard of the truth to win a libel claim.

title: Charles Chasin Is Married To Elisabeth Leslie Schiff
description: Elisabeth Leslie Schiff, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Schiff of Neponsit, Queens, was married yesterday to Charles Chasin, a son of Lillian Chasin of Brooklyn and the late Sol Chasin. Rabbis Joseph I. Weiss and Paul H. Katz officiated at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Pop Music's Homage to Mandela
description: ''Freedomfest - Nelson Mandela's 70th Birthday Celebration,'' an all-day rock concert held Saturday at Wembley Stadium outside of London with a sold-out audience of 72,000 people, was a sorry mixture of good intentions, political censorship and show business. Six hours of it was broadcast all over the world, and its potential audience was in the billions; the show's producers estimated that they would earn nearly a $1 million, much of which was to be given away to charities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Seekers of Hispanic Markets Find a Helpful Tool: English
description: A decade ago, the nation's Hispanic population was largely ignored by the media and advertisers.

title: Restaurant Management Services reports earnings for Qtr to May 8
description: b-After a $426,302 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior periods.

title: Jackson, Backing Off, Says He Won't 'Push' Dukakis
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he did not want to push Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for the Vice Presidency, backing off from remarks that he had made in several interviews, that he had earned an offer of the job.

title: Moscow Political Clubs Issue Call for Expanded Freedoms
description: An alliance of independent Moscow political clubs, in their first concerted bid to influence Soviet policy, today adopted an ambitious platform of political changes to be offered at a national Communist Party conference later this month.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Della Femina Agency Gets A New Aura
description: IT came as no surprise Friday when Jerry Della Femina announced that Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which has already absorbed HBM/Creamer into its New York operation, is now doing the same with the Boston, Pittsburgh and Chicago operations.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Going Once, Twice. . .Unsold The yachts sat begging at their docks like pure breds at an animal shelter. Of the 75 boats for sale at Guernsey's auction over the weekend at the Museum of Yachting in Newport, R.I., fewer than 20 were sold.

title: Guardian Angel Is Stabbed
description: Three days after the Guardian Angels began patrolling a block of Manhattan restaurants, a member of the group was stabbed. Page B1.

title: Royalties From Photocopying Grow
description: More than 400 American publishers recently received a total of $1 million from an unusual source - users of photocopied material. And that royalty payment, through the Copyright Clearance Center, an organization established a decade ago by authors and publishers, appears to be only the beginning.

title: Festival Review/Dance; Tudor's 'Fandango' Graces Opening Night
description: Fortune favors the bold but the First New York International Festival of the Arts played it safe at its opening night. The entire and mammoth series of monthlong activities was inaugurated Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House with a gala performance by a known quantity, American Ballet Theater.

title: Johnson Does It All as Lakers Gain Edge
description: Magic Johnson left Michigan State University as a 19-year-old sophomore to join the Los Angeles Lakers and give the National Basketball Association something it had never seen: a 6-foot-9-inch playmaker.

title: In 'South Africa Now,' Daily Life Under Apartheid
description: A three-day strike by more than half of South Africa's black labor force concluded last Wednesday, leaving at least 10 people dead in the wake of violence and widespread disruptions, according to that country's Government. The news broadcasts on ABC, CBS and NBC that evening carried no reports on the strike's conclusion, however, something many journalists saw as further evidence that the South African Government's restrictions on press coveragd, particularly television coverage, have had the desired effect.

title: Rules on Video Display Terminals Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Bike Shoe Fits Into The Pedal
description: The Tour de France, France's premier bicycle race, spawned a new kind of pedal system in 1985 that soon became standard gear for serious racers.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,423,000 for the quarter and $1,414,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a book written by House Speaker Jim Wright incorrectly described the House ethics committee's investigation of him. The committee is exploring whether campaign funds were used to pay for publication of the book, ''Reflections of a Public Man,'' and whether government resources were used to complete work on the book. The amount of royalties received by Mr. Wright is not a subject of the investigation.

title: At Blair House, a New Beginning
description: There were important matters of state being attended to today at Blair House, the President's newly restored guest house. Chief among them were reviving the peonies and keeping the tasseled pillows fluffed.

title: Helping Victims of Violence Heal Their Psychic Wounds
description: Seven months after a knife-wielding man brutalized Deborah Whitley in her Manhattan apartment, her terror has lost its edge. She has learned self-defense and shaken her dread of strangers. The nightmare that once regularly awakened her, screaming, has departed.

title: Marcia Stein Weds
description: Marcia Lynne Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Stein of Hillside, N.J., and Gary Mitchell DuBoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley DuBoff of Rockaway, N.J., were married yesterday at the Summit Hotel in Summit, N.J., by Rabbi Abraham I. Zigelman. The bride, a graduate of the University of Hartford, is a marketing sales planner at The New York Times. The bridegroom, a graduate of the University of Bridgeport, is a certified public accountant with Ernst & Whinney in New York.

title: Cruises Find a Demand for Fantasy
description: When the stock market crashed last October, lots of Americans canceled their winter vacations to Caribbean islands. The Bahamas, Jamaica and Antigua were among the hardest hit. But the companies that operate the cruise ships that ply the Caribbean's warm blue waters say they barely felt a ripple.

title: Keep Government Out Of Surrogacy Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: On Racing;
description: Suppose for a moment that Louie Roussel 3d, Risen Star's trainer and co-owner, had done last Saturday what he threatens to do nearly every time he enters the colt in a major race. Suppose that Roussel, instead of sending out Risen Star to a 14 3/4-length victory in the Belmont Stakes, had scratched the colt from the race.

title: Study of 18 Men With AIDS Virus Finds Delay in Antibody Production
description: A NEW study of 18 men carrying the AIDS virus found that some were infected more than a year before their bodies produced antibodies in response to the invading virus. Two carried the virus for at least three years before they began producing antibodies.

title: 6 SOUTH AFRICANS ARE DENIED RETRIAL
description: Six South African blacks facing execution were refused a retrial today, three months after they won a reprieve under international pressure.

title: A FLIGHT BRIDGES GULF OF 40 YEARS
description: A plane carrying 80 Americans landed today in this remote Siberian city after a short flight aimed at bridging 40 years of wariness and distrust between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: PATTERNS
description: Making One's Mark

title: Hawker Siddeley To Buy Von Weise
description: Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the Von Weise Gear Company of St. Clair, Mo., for $:13 million ($23.5 million) in cash. Von Weise, a subsidiary of American Technical Industries, is among the leading United States makers of fractional horsepower gear motors and gear reducers, and it supplies medical, dental, food processing and ice-making equipment.

title: Sharansky, Breathing Free, Finds Idolatry Is Suffocating
description: Natan Sharansky, after nine years in Soviet prisons and labor camps, insisted to an audience of 900 people Sunday night that there was no special quality of heroism that separated him from them. But skeptical, like all New Yorkers, they refused to believe him, bathing him in the sort of adulation he likens to a more insidious prison.

title: Behind the Kitsch, the Flag
description: Two years ago, during all the hoopla surrounding her 100th birthday, Americans discovered an amazing thing about the Statue of Liberty. No matter how often she is photographed, no matter how many people put on those funny green foam diadems or give away those shoddy imitation-bronze paperweights, the Lady can't be cheapened. Neither, and for much the same reason, can the American flag.

title: Ballesteros Seeks Confidence Boost
description: Seve Ballesteros of Spain said today that one reason he hasn't won much this year was because of the confidence he lost when he was first man out of the three-man playoff in the 1987 Masters.

title: Careers; Middle-Level Glut Seen in Accounting
description: ACCOUNTING, that Rock of Gibraltar career, has developed what one job expert calls ''a problem area'' - the same problem confronting older middle managers in some other professions.

title: Over Protests, Israel Expels Palestinian-American
description: Mubarak Awad, the Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence, was deported from Israel today after an eight-month fight with the Government to remain in East Jerusalem, where he was born.

title: Police Dilemma on Restaurant Row
description: On Restaurant Row, as on hundreds of other blocks around the New York City, successes in the struggle against drugs have come to seem so rare and the scourge so relentless that citizens are increasingly turning to private patrols to supplement or supplant a criminal justice system that seems unable to cope.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''This is only the beginning. We will proceed with additional cases now.'' - Marc Z. Edell, a lawyer for Antonio Cipollone. [ A1:6. ]

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Sent Luis Quinones, shortstop, to Nashville of the American Association. Sent Tracy Jones, outfielder, to Chattanooga of the Southern League. METS (NL) - Placed Keith Hernandez, first baseman, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to June 7. Called up Keith Miller, infielder, from Tidewater. BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Named Don Chaney as head coach. SAN ANTONIO (NBA) - Named Larry Brown as head coach. FOOTBALL CINCINNATI (AFC) - Signed Elbert Woods, running back. MINNESOTA VIKINGS (NFC) -Named Jerry Brown as assistant offensive coach. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Acquired Eugene Marve, linebacker, from the Buffalo Bills for a 1989 undisclosed draft choice. Waived Carl Senegal, offensive tackle. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Signed Joe Caravello, tight end, to a one-year contract, and Jamie Morris, running back, and Carl Mims, defensive backs, to a series of one-year contracts. HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Traded Mark Hardy, defenseman, to the Minnesota North Stars for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Tennis Notebook; Wilander and Graf in Step to Win Slam
description: Because this has been one of the more competitive tennis seasons of the Open era, the last thing one would anticipate is someone winning the grand slam.

title: Quantronix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The loss in fiscal 1988 reflected a patent litigation settlement of about $640,000 and a loss of about $137,000 on disposal of marketable securities. Fiscal 1987 included a non-recurring gain of $815,000.

title: A Little Craft Still Searches For an End To Solar System
description: FOUR billion miles away, farther than any man-made object has ever traveled, Pioneer 10 has yet to find and cross the outer boundary of the solar system. Each day its instruments extend the known dimensions of the Sun's sphere of influence, with no end in sight.

title: League Upholds Devils' Punishment
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors voted today to uphold the one-game suspension of Coach Jim Schoenfeld and $11,000 in fines levied against the New Jersey Devils and their coach as punishment for Schoenfeld's verbal abuse of a referee after a playoff game.

title: New Jersey Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Outdoes British Empire in Troops Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is it that most celestial objects rotate or revolve counterclockwise?

title: Review/Music; From India, the Sounds of the Sarod
description: The sarod, a plucked, fretless lute, emerged in the 19th century as a modification of the rabab, an Afghan folk instrument. Its inventor is said to have been Ghulam Bandegi Khan Bangash, a rabab player who sought to give his instrument's sound greater projection and more fully sustained tones by changing from gut strings to metal strings, and attaching a metal resonating chest to the fingerboard. His innovations made it possible for players of the new instrument to move from the rustic heritage of the rabab to the more refined classical style.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,423,000 for the quarter and $1,414,000 for the 6 months. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova in Form: Martina Navratilova, who will go to Wimbledon seeking a record ninth women's singles title, made a successful start yesterday in her grass-court preparation as she beat Alexia Dechaume of France, 6-0, 6-2, in the first round of the Pilkington Glass championship in Eastbourne, England.
