C., Bulls, but the film involves no person, team or chewing tobacco with the Bull Durham name, so the title is slightly puzzling. It would be unsporting to mention this if there weren't many other misfires of a similar nature: dialogue that strains to be colorful, indiscriminately piled-on pop songs, plot developments that aren't followed through on, and minor aspects of motivation that are never known.

title: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Review/City Ballet; Devouring Female Of Species
description: The New York City Ballet offered much pleasure Sunday afternoon and evening at the New York State Theater.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson Assumes A Historic Stance
description: When Mike Tyson knocked out Larry Holmes in January, his body language at the end of the fight was that of a conqueror: he stood across the ring, arms akimbo, staring at the fallen Holmes with a look that appeared to say, ''Well, that takes care of that.''

title: 2 Die in Explosion in Wales
description: Two people were killed and a building was destroyed today in an explosion at a nitroglycerine plant in Wales. Several more were injured in the blast, which could be heard 20 miles from this small village in the Welsh northwest. It blew apart one building and damaged two others. The victims were process workers at the Imperial Chemical Industries plant who monitored the mixing of ingredients for nitroglycerine.

title: Cuomo Rebukes Brawley Family For Not Talking
description: Governor Cuomo, in his most forceful statement thus far on the Tawana Brawley case, yesterday condemned the family and its advisers for defying a special grand jury investigation, saying that ''our law has been mocked and trifled with.''

title: Europeans Urge U.S. to Pay Past U.N. Dues
description: Western European countries have mounted a new diplomatic initiative to persuade the United States to pay some of the hundreds of millions of dollars it owes the United Nations in back dues, European diplomats say.

title: Quantel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $551,000 and $313,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $31,000 for the quarter and after a tax provision of $689,000 for the year.

title: Review/Theater; The Stars Align for 'Long Day's Journey'
description: When people see a ghost, they are anticipating death, and that is unmistakably what Jason Robards feels as the thick fog of despair rolls into the Tyrone household for keeps in Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title: US Health Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $4 million from an accounting change.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Roots and Politics
description: With Michael S. Dukakis nearing the formality of his Democratic Presidential nomination, the appeal of having roots in Greece is apparently spreading.

title: Presbyterians Adopt Position On Obedience in Nuclear Age
description: Presbyterians overwhelmingly adopted a major statement on Christian responsibilities in a nuclear age today after lengthy revisions to mollify members who feared the church was embracing civil disobedience.

title: How the System Works at a G.M. Plant
description: If historical plaques are awarded to factories that pioneered in the deployment of the communications standards known as the Manufacturing Automation Protocol, or MAP, the General Motors' truck and bus plant in Pontiac, Mich., is sure to get one of the first.

title: Three Officials Quit Paperback
description: Paperback Software International said today that three top officers had left the company in a reorganization that would also reduce the day-to-day operating responsibilities of Adam Osborne, the prominent computer entrepreneur who founded the company.

title: Vanguard Technologies International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Senate Approves New Statue Of Nurse for War Memorial
description: The Senate today approved a bill authorizing a bronze statue of an Army nurse at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial to honor the women who were part of America's longest war.

title: Turkish Leader Offers Steps Of Conciliation for Greeks
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal of Turkey announced a series of small conciliatory measures toward Greece today as he held a second day of talks here with Greek leaders.

title: False Economy to Cut School Dental Program
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Blunt' Deputy Will Succeed Baker
description: As an avid ice hockey fan, Kenneth M. Duberstein watches the flashing sticks, flying pucks and bone-crushing action of the Washington Capitals from his seat as a season ticket holder at Capital Centre.

title: The Drive to Speed Automation
description: The world's leading industrial companies and engineering bodies came to a Baltimore convention center last week to spend a few days making something no one needed - 4,000 desktop holders for business cards and pens.

title: INSIDE
description: After the Smoking Suit

title: North American National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $43,000 for the quarter and $684,757 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $34,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $1,087,218 for the year.

title: Judge Overturns Landmark Status of Town House on Upper West Side
description: The landmark status of a town house on the Upper West Side of Manhattan called ''the Castle'' has been overturned by a state judge on the ground that the designation vote improperly included a member of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission who had effectively resigned.

title: Coated Sales Study Grows
description: Coated Sales Inc., a specialty textile maker in Laurence Harbor, N.J., announced today that an internal company investigation had uncovered inaccurate statements in its financial reports in ''substantial excess'' of the $6 million that it disclosed last week.

title: Norway Oil Output Off
description: Because of summer maintenance work on some North Sea platforms, Norwegian oil production showed a slight drop in May after four months of record output, oil companies said today. Norway, Western Europe's biggest oil producer after Britain, pumped 1.13 million barrels of oil a day, according to a survey of oil concerns operating here.

title: Peters, J M Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Big Money for Poverty Law
description: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the huge New York law firm, announced recently that it would create a $10 million endowment to provide public legal services. The endowment will support up to 25 lawyers to work in poverty and public interest law offices across the country.

title: Mitterrand Says Minority Cabinet Can Govern 881
description: President Francois Mitterrand sought to reassure France tonight that a new minority Socialist cabinet headed by Prime Minister Michel Rocard would guarantee stability and a decisive attack on the nation's problems.

title: Election-Year Advice
description: Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush have yet to name their running mates, but a panel assembled by the Twentieth Century Fund has already drafted suggestions for the person who will come to be only ''a heartbeat away'' from the Presidency.

title: When Parents Dine Out, Children Now Go Along
description: LEAD: BEFORE they had children, Anne and Joel Beerman went out to dinner a lot. ''A lot,'' emphasized Mr. Beerman, a lawyer here. ''We went to inexpensive seafood restaurants, ethnic restaurants and to, I don't know what you call them, New Wave or whatever, with salads and fancy sandwiches.''

title: S.E.C. Backs Bid to Restore Confidence in O-T-C Market
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a series of proposals by the National Association of Securities Dealers aimed at restoring public confidence in a stock trading system that was nearly paralyzed by customer orders during the October stock market crash.

title: New York State Marketing Bonds
description: The State of New York entered the debt market yesterday with a $111 million issue of general obligation bonds won in competitive bidding by an underwriting group led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: WINE TALK
description: LAWRENCE STONE had come home a winner. In Paris he had been chosen Best International Sommelier in competition with wine stewards from 10 other countries. Now, still bleary from travel and tension, he relaxed in a New York restaurant, sharing his expertise in a conversation that ranged from wine chemistry to the economics of the Bordeaux market to the merits of sparkling wine from Oregon.

title: Bridge
description: Beginners make bunches of defensive errors, and these slowly decrease as they improve.

title: Turks in Moscow Deal
description: The Turkish company Enka Construction Inc. has received two multimillion-dollar building contracts in Moscow, a Turkish Embassy spokesman said today. Enka has signed contracts to build a 1,000-bed hotel and a shopping center in Moscow with Soyuzvneshstroyimport, the Soviet organization dealing with foreign construction deals, he said. The spokesman said he could not give the exact value of the two contracts, but said they could help pay for Turkey's imports of Soviet natural gas.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Bush's Chess Game

title: American Building Mainteance Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Theater doesn't exist at the moment. It's bad everywhere.'' - Eugene Ionesco. [ C21:1. ]

title: Suspect in Bombing Is Released, Angering Both Britain and Ireland
description: The Irish and British Governments were angry, confused and critical today over the latest failure of their efforts to establish workable extradition procedures for terrorism suspects.

title: 50-Off Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $32,000 for the latest quarter and $9,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Economic Scene; User-Friendly Technical Fixes
description: WITH prices stable, the trade deficit improving and the Reagan boom perking into its sixth year, the performance of the American economy is confounding the doomsayers. Well, not quite all the doomsayers. Productivity growth, the most important measure of the economy's ability to sustain prosperity in the long run, has been drifting south for two decades. Unless the trend is soon reversed, it will be felt in stagnating incomes and increasingly bitter divisions over Government priorities.

title: 'Fences' Closing Sunday
description: ''Fences,'' the drama by August Wilson that won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the 46th Street Theater. The play, directed by Lloyd Richards and now starring Billy Dee Williams, will have run for 526 regular performances and 11 previews.

title: Nureyev in 'Orpheus' As City Ballet Guest
description: Rudolf Nureyev is to dance the title role in George Balanchine's ''Orpheus'' in two guest appearances this month with the New York City Ballet, the company has announced.

title: Fed Chief Against Rise in Index-Future Margins
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned Congress today that large institutional investors might take their business to Japanese and European markets if margins on stock index futures were raised and other new regulations were imposed on markets in the United States.

title: Modern Jazz Software Is Canceled by Lotus
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled development of Modern Jazz, an integrated software program intended for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh personal computer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amerace Corp., Hackettstown, N.J., a maker of electrical cable, connectors and component devices, named its chief executive, Joseph J. Incandela, to the additional post of chairman. He is succeeding Thomas Shepherd, who will continue as a director and chairman of the the executive committee.

title: 2 Juries in 1 Court in North-Poindexter Trial Barred
description: The judge in the Iran-contra conspiracy case today rejected the independent prosecutor's suggestion that two former White House aides, Oliver L. North and John M. Poindexter, be tried in the same courtroom before two juries.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Christmas Spectacular At World Trade Center
description: For the Christmas season, Comart Associates, the World Trade Center's marketing and promotion agency, is arranging a visual spectacular at the main crossroads in the concourse below the center.

title: Brown Gets Welcome
description: With Mayor Henry Cisneros as the head cheerleader, about 500 people turned out in San Antonio yesterday to welcome Larry Brown, the new Spurs coach. Brown promptly apologized for his previous putdown of the city. Brown, whose Carolina and Denver teams of the old American Basketball Association played the Spurs in the mid-1970's, had angered San Antonio fans back then by saying the only thing good in San Antonio was the guacamole. ''I apologize about the things I said about San Antonio a long time ago,'' said Brown. ''I really didn't mean it. I will eat the guacamole salad.'' (AP)

title: It's Too Late to Ask Where Spring Went
description: Spring was canceled this year, and Richard Belchive blames the phenomenon for ruining in short and merciless order his old front porch, his old favorite suit and a new romance. The constant rain of three weeks back, he will tell you, caused it all, finally undoing the foundation of the porch of his house on Staten Island and the inside stitching on his 1962 Brooks Brothers jacket. And it forced him and his friend Leanne to stay inside ''day after day after day, until we got sick of each other.''

title: Stormy History Of Endowment
description: The National Endowment for Democracy is a quasi-governmental organization created at the Reagan Administration's initiative in 1983 to promote democratic institutions around the world.

title: Miller Seeks Shift of Funds To Cut Deficit
description: In a move that could herald a breakthrough in the debate over how to solve the state's fiscal problems, the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, today proposed that up to $500 million in surplus funds from state authorities be used to help close New York's budget gap.

title: Strike Ends in Armenia as Unrest Slows
description: Armenians ended a strike in the Armenian capital of Yerevan today as two Soviet republics moved toward a legal stalemate.

title: Vistas Widen for U.S.-Soviet Student Exchange
description: The agreement in principle that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have reached to expand the American-Soviet student exchange program has spurred a rush of planning in Washington and intensified similar efforts by private exchange groups.

title: Suffolk Legislature Overrides Veto of a Video Terminal Bill
description: The Suffolk County Legislature today overrode a veto by the County Executive and enacted the nation's first law regulating the use of video-display terminals in the workplace.

title: Meese Orders I.R.A. Fugitive In New York to Go to Britain
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today ordered an Irish Republican Army fugitive deported to Britain, where he is wanted for the killing of a British soldier, on the ground that he entered the United States illegally.

title: About New York; For Volunteers, Walking a Dog Is Never a Chore
description: The alliteratively named Peter Paris, a young man who moved to town a year ago from Indiana and immediately missed having a dog, dropped into the Humane Society of New York Monday on his lunch hour and picked a pet to walk. He chose Pywaket, a mix of German shepherd and collie, by the looks of her, affixed a leash, got some newspaper, signed her out in the log book, and left by the front door, past a sign that says: ''Volunteer! Walk a dog! Dogs, up for adoption, need walks and fresh air. Contact Sarah: 752-4842.''

title: Gold and Silver Treasures Bring $2.5 Million at Auction
description: Gold and silver treasures, salvaged from two 17th-century Spanish galleons, were auctioned last night for a total of $2.58 million at Christie's.

title: U.S. Urges Israel to Rescind Settler Shoot-on-Sight Policy
description: The United States urged the Israeli authorities today against giving Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip the right to shoot Palestinian demonstrators carrying firebombs.

title: Jackson Hails Platform Work
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that a meeting to draft the Democratic platform was a ''step in the right direction'' toward resolving differences between him and Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Core Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Four Deaths Linked to Gas From Heater
description: Investigators said yesterday that a Bronx woman and her three children died of accidental carbon-monoxide poisoning Monday in their basement apartment and that the cause was apparently a clogged flue from a water heater.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Gilbert, Whitney Gets Dancookie Account
description: Gilbert, Whitney & Johns of Whippany, N.J., has been appointed agency for Dancookie Brands Inc., a recently formed consortium of the leading Danish bakers who have been shipping round tins of cookies to the United States since the end of World War II.

title: Bergen Brunswig Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $510,000 and $124,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a gain of $1,999,000 from the disposition of discontinued operations. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $678,000 for the quarter and $1,599,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 37 percent stock dividend paid June 1.

title: Review/Television; Father-Son Conflicts
description: Aging children and elderly parents are at the core of Robert Anderson's play ''I Never Sang for My Father,'' first produced on Broadway 20 years ago. As the United States grows older, demographically speaking, the play is more touching and pertinent than ever. A new television version, adapted from a stage production done at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles, can be seen this evening at 9 o'clock on Channel 13. It was taped at KCET-TV, and is an ''American Playhouse'' presentation.

title: Festival Review/Dance; Vibrant Frenetics From Frankfurt, a la Forsythe
description: A dance company for a young new audience arrived last night in the shape of the Frankfurt Ballet, a troupe from West Germany very much under the direction of its American choreographer, William Forsythe.

title: Communication Cable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Latvians Said to Demonstrate To Mark Deportations of 40's
description: Thousands of people demonstrated in Soviet Latvia today to mark the anniversary of mass deportations from the Baltic republic under Stalin, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Verdict Expected to Focus Attention on Early Tobacco Ads
description: A New Jersey jury's verdict that the Liggett Group was liable for a smoker's death because its advertising promoted tobacco's healthfulness will serve notice to all tobacco companies that they are responsible for their early advertising claims, according to several experts on tobacco marketing. Many of these ads use statements about health, comfort and vitality to sell cigarettes.

title: Information Solutions Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company attributed the latest quarter loss to recently discontinued or reorganized operations within the company and certain, one-time extraordinary items recorded in the first quarter as a result of the restructuring. The company said the extraordinary items included severance and vacation pay for laid-off workers, but did not give the amount of the items.

title: School Countdown
description: A cold and rainy Northeastern spring kept young minds focused on the classroom longer than usual this year, a grateful teacher notes. But the pull of summer has finally won. High school seniors come to school (if at all) these days for the friendships they're about to relinquish, not for the academics. Their college acceptances are safely in hand.

title: Western Publishing Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Wicks Speaks
description: Sue Wicks, the women's college basketball player of the year, commented for the first time on leaving the Olympic mini-camp but declined to say why she made the decision.

title: Koreans Protest Near DMZ
description: Students shouting anti-American slogans protested today at the edge of the demilitarized zone dividing North and South Korea and called for reunification of the peninsula.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Texaco Says Icahn Broke Stock Law
description: Lawyers for Texaco Inc. said today that the financier Carl C. Icahn had violated Federal securities laws by forming, without public disclosure, a group with the Canadian investor Marc D. Belzberg to acquire Texaco stock.

title: 3.2% Stake In Texaco Is Traded
description: A 7.7-million-share block of Texaco Inc.'s stock was traded yesterday, prompting speculation among Wall Street professionals that Carl C. Icahn's chances of winning a proxy fight against the company had significantly improved.

title: The Arts Festival; Eugene Ionesco in Defense of the Absurd
description: Eugene Ionesco was listing his compatriots in the Theater of the Absurd: Beckett, Genet, Adamov, Shakespeare. . . .

title: I.B.M. to Offer PC Trade-Ins
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has told its dealers that it will soon introduce a trade-in program to accelerate sales of its PS/2 line of personal computers.

title: Council, Disputing Koch, Rejects Plan With $150 Million Tax Rise
description: The New York City Council, maintaining its opposition to a $150 million tax increase to balance the Mayor's proposed budget, rejected a $25.2 billion spending plan yesterday and demanded that Mr. Koch resubmit a budget that does not require a tax increase.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shandwick Announces Two More Acquisitions
description: Less than two weeks after making an acquisition in Atlanta, Britain's Shandwick P.L.C., the world's largest independent public relations company, has announced two more acquisitions. In the United States it's Rubenstein, Wolfson & Company and in West Germany it's Kommunikations Marketing in Bonn.

title: Murdock to Offer Plan for Allegheny
description: The Los Angeles investor David H. Murdock disclosed that he would ''begin formulating a plan of reorganization'' for Allegheny International Inc. Allegheny's management and a dissident shareholder group led by the New York brokerage Spear Leeds & Kellogg had already said they were working on restructuring proposals.

title: Contras Ask U.S. For More Arms; Passage Dubious
description: Leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels said today that they needed more weapons and ammunition from the United States to strengthen their position in negotiations with the Sandinista Government.

title: Men and Boys on Restaurant Row
description: The array of better bistros on ''Restaurant Row,'' the block of 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, captures the best of Manhattan after dark: elegant menus, trays of sumptuous desserts, fresh flowers on every table. The sidewalks outside offer another kind of night life: prostitution, drug dealing, gatherings of homeless mental cases.

title: Back in Style
description: Some bills are like od clothes: Save them long enough and they come back into style.

title: Home Loan Banks Offer 4 Bond Issues
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks priced a four-part bond sale totaling $3.32 billion yesterday.

title: The Newly Uncivil British
description: Britons are not notoriously neat. Each day, I pick up cigarette packets, bits of plastic foam and computer printouts - the artifacts of our times - from my front door.

title: Minnesota's Yields Range Up to 7.45%
description: Minnesota is offering $200 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: F.B.I. in Surprise Search Of Pentagon and Suppliers
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation made surprise searches at the Pentagon today in what law-enforcement officials said was a major bribery investigation aimed at procurement officials of the Defense Department.

title: Dry Spell Is Called a Threat to Farms
description: Farms across the middle of the country must have rain soon or a fierce drought that is scorching fields could become a national disaster, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng told lawmakers today.

title: Coffin Nails
description: The $400,000 that a Federal jury awarded Antonio Cipollone in the lung-cancer death of his wife is a drop in the bucket to the Liggett Group. In 1985 the tobacco industry's earnings were a record $3.45 billion. The award is a fraction even of the $2 million that the suit cost Mr. Cipollone's law firm. But this verdict, the first ever to hold a tobacco company liable for injuries to a smoker, may yet become another, historic nail in tobacco's coffin.

title: Stock Rise For Gartner
description: The price of the common stock of the Gartner Group continued to climb yesterday, a day after the high-tech marketing research firm announced it was having discussions that could lead to its acquisition. The stock, traded over-the-counter, closed yesterday at $17, up 75 cents a share. On Monday it had gained $2.75 a share.

title: Water Crisis Takes Its Toll
description: About 200,000 restaurants in drought-plagued Southern California will replace the customary glass of water given to customers with a picture of a water glass. The cards will give details of the water shortage and add, ''If you would like a glass of water, just ask.'' The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California paid for the cards, and the California Restaurant Association will begin distributing them next week.

title: Raise for Congress Is Rejected
description: The House voted today to exempt members of Congress and other top Government officials from a 4 percent Federal pay increase it approved to take effect next January.

title: Market Place; Banks Expecting Add-On Business
description: COMMERCIAL bankers realize the securities markets are not an easily worked gold mine.

title: For Dinner, a First Course in Myths
description: CONSIDER this simple meal: Corn on the cob with butter and salt, chicken with rice, lettuce tossed with olive oil and lemon, and ice cream. What could be more ordinary? More prosaic? More boring? But its very ordinariness made it fascinating to Dr. Margaret Visser, a classicist whose interest in the meanings of everyday foods resulted in ''Much Depends on Dinner,'' a book about the myth and history of that one meal's ingredients. The book, a best seller in Canada, was published in the United States this year by Grove Press and is now going into its second printing.

title: Andujar Fined
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, the National League president, has fined a Houston Astros pitcher, Joaquin Andujar, $500 for throwing at batters and ''walking menacingly toward home plate,'' Andujar's agent said yesterday. Giamatti, in a letter to Andujar, warned that if the league felt that Andujar was throwing at batters again, he would be given ''a significant fine and suspension,'' the agent, Randy Hendricks, reported. According to the agent, Andujar was fined $200 for coming close to hitting Tony Pena of the St. Louis Cardinals on May 21 and was fined $100 for then approaching the plate in a menacing manner. He was fined $200 more for hitting Andre Dawson of the Chicago Cubs on May 28. The Major League Baseball Players Association filed an appeal of the fines yesterday. Giamatti will hear the appeal on June 30 or July 1, when the Astros are in New York. Giamatti was not in New York yesterday and was not available for comment, a league spokeswoman said.

title: Books of The Times; Mortality and Fidelity in Marriage
description: Silver By Hilma Wolitzer 324 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Split Israeli Election From Peace Referendum; Plan for Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Breed of Rhine Wines
description: A NEW breed of dry West German wines is entering the American market. Fruity and sophisticated, made to marry well with food, these wines have been created to cater to the American preference for round, well-defined premium whites. If they whet the public's appetite, the tide of Rhine wines may rise again in the United States.

title: Albert Holland Jr., 69, F.D.A. Medical Chief
description: Dr. Albert H. Holland Jr., former medical director of the Food and Drug Administration, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: Pumped-Up Pistons Tie Series, 2-2
description: It has been a strange championship series. There have been no in betweens. The finalists, the Los Angeles Lakers and the Detroit Pistons, have been either good or bad, as the victory margins of 12, 12, 13 and 25 points indicate.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Baltimore Orioles signed the veteran outfielder Ken Landreaux to a minor league contract. Landreaux, who hit .203 in 155 games with Los Angeles last year, will report to Class AAA Rochester of the International League. . . . Eugene Marve, a starting linebacker for most of his six seasons with the Buffalo Bills, has been traded to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in return for an undisclosed pick in the 1989.(AP)

title: The Ivy Hayseed
description: George Bush ought to be as electable as the next man in this year of the indifferent electorate, but it does him no good to pretend he isn't George Bush. Whenever he tries it, he looks silly and embarrasses people who want to see him look good.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: After NBO Stores' Sale, Founder Has 3d Career
description: Two significant events occurred recently at NBO Stores Inc., one of the area's largest men's clothing discounters.

title: Bush Says He'd Increase U.S. Aid for Education
description: Vice President Bush said today that he would support additional Federal spending to improve the quality of schools serving disadvantaged students, a proposal as significant for its symbolism as for its substance.

title: The New Show Off Broadway: 46th Street
description: The photographers outnumbered the drug dealers Monday night along Restaurant Row, the block of West 46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues that has become the temporary touchstone for New York City's agonized struggle with crack.

title: Soviets On, After All
description: The 23 members of the Maly Theater of Leningrad who checked into the Marriott Marquis Hotel almost a week ago will be appearing on the New York stage after all.

title: Split Israeli Election From Peace Referendum
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrected 'Ulysses' Sparks Scholarly Attack
description: Two years ago publishers in the United States and Britain issued a new edition of James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' one of the most celebrated novels in the English language. The team of German scholars who produced that edition claimed it corrected some 5,000 omissions, transpositions and other errors included in previous editions. Scholars and critics hailed it as a landmark of textual scholarship. Earlier editions of ''Ulysses'' eventually disappeared from most of the nation's bookstores and classrooms.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Injures Hand
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, who has starred in goal for the Rangers for the last four years, may be sidelined for the first half of the coming season after suffering nerve damage to his left wrist in what he described as a freakish accident at his home in Rye, N.Y., on Sunday night.

title: U.S. Sees Little Gain for Iran in Offensive in Iraq
description: Administration officials said today that Iranian troops did not appear to have made substantial territorial gains in a new counteroffensive in southern Iraq.

title: Citicorp Selling Notes at 9.031%
description: Citicorp is offering $250 million of 9 percent notes due in 1993 at 99.875 to yield 9.031 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Education; Lessons
description: The bright side of last week's report called ''The Mathematics Report Card - Are We Measuring Up?'' is that American schoolchildren as a group are now somewhat less ''dismal'' at math than they used to be, at least on easy questions.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the psychologist Erik H. Erikson incorrectly described the origin of the word caritas. It is a Latin word for charity.

title: Greenspan Finds Exports Causing No Inflation Yet
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said last night that he did not see inflationary pressures building so far in the nation's export manufacturing sector.

title: Uncertainty Takes a Toll On Salvador
description: Faced with continuing war and political uncertainty heightened by the illness of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, Salvadorans seem to be viewing the future with more anxiety than usual.

title: Witness Recalls Wedtech Effort In Washington
description: A former president of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday that an associate of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had lobbied two Presidential advisers to gain more business for the Bronx defense contractor.

title: Clearing the Streets: Rulings on Loitering
description: The controversy over patrols by the Guardian Angels on West 46th Street has raised questions about when a citizen or a police officer can confront someone who is loitering and appears to be acting suspiciously.

title: Education; New Formulas Tighten Purse Strings on Aid
description: Now that they have sent out their acceptance letters, colleges and universities are putting together financial aid packages for the 1988-89 academic year. For thousands of students this year, the news will not be good.

title: Lucien Cardin Is Dead; Canadian Aide Was 69
description: Lucien Cardin, whose statements on the handling of Canadian security cases touched off a political storm in 1966 while he was Justice Minister in the Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, died of cancer Monday. He was 69 years old and had been a tax court judge since 1983.

title: Solo Record Pace Intact
description: Light winds have slowed the pace of the French solo sailor, Philippe Poupon, but he could arrive here as early as Wednesday and cut six days from his 16 1/2-day record for racing single-handed across the Atlantic from east to west, set in 1984. He would also easily break the 13 1/2-day record for east-west crossings by any type of sailboat, crewed or single-handed.

title: A Time for Letting Go Grips a Teaching Staff
description: This is a bittersweet time of the year for the teachers of River Dell Junior High School as it is for teachers everywhere.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone & Belding Now in Norway's Top 5
description: A warm glow of pride has spread throughout the work force of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, a worldwide advertising force. No longer will people look down their noses at them for having the 15th-largest agency in Norway. Now, as the result of a merger, those well-known initials FCB will rank among the top five. It is a heady feeling.

title: Precautionary Measures
description: Government officials said today that concern over the potential for violence at the Seoul Olympics had resulted in plans for the evacuation of Australian athletes and spectators.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday of Samuel Barber's ''Vanessa'' by the Opera Theater of St. Louis misidentified the set designer. He was Kevin Rupnik.

title: Giuliani Faults Gentile On Use of F.B.I. Reports
description: United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani lashed out yesterday at the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, for what he said was the use of confidential investigative information for political purposes and ''pandering'' to the Bronx Democratic leadership.

title: Columnist, Backer Of Curbs on Guns, Shoots a Trespasser
description: The syndicated columnist Carl T. Rowan, who has written frequently of the need for stricter gun control, shot and slightly wounded a young man who took a predawn swim in the Rowan backyard pool early today.

title: Dumplings and a Smile: New Soviet Restaurants Find an Eager Public
description: THE setting was a simple cafe with handpainted medieval scenes on arched walls. On the table, a golden-skinned roasted chicken, surrounded by homemade pasta and garnished with sprigs of coriander and juicy tomato slices, was accompanied by a bowl of creamy sauce.

title: Reaching for the Stars In Luxury Fur Design
description: WHITE mink cascades down to the floor. A chinchilla coat in pure white is fit for a bride. A fox jacket dyed green, blue or wine slips over a sheared mink coat dyed exactly the same shade for a double helping of fur. A soft cloud of Russian lynx draws appreciative oh's and ah's from sophisticated retailers as they try to guess how much the long coat would cost. (The answer: $300,000) These are some of the high spots of the second round of fall fashion openings in the fur market. The openings last week included the first fur collection in a decade by Arnold Scaasi, the New York designer of made-to-order clothes; a tour de force by James Galanos, who makes expensive ready-to-wear, and the epitome of high-fashion shapes by Karl Lagerfeld for Revillon.

title: Conable Urges Aid by U.S.
description: Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, saying the United States faced reduced influence in the international lending agency, called upon Congress today to approve the American share of a general capital increase.

title: Soviet Rebel Without a Job
description: President Reagan's reception for Soviet dissenters, early in the Moscow summit conference, seemed to signal a new if grudging Soviet tolerance. Officials groused about American tactlessness. But they didn't block the President's meeting with human rights campaigners, former prisoners of conscience and critics of the Soviet state.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $404,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $910,000, or 38 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Moe Denies He's Departing
description: Doug Moe, coach of the Denver Nuggets, says a newspaper story over the weekend quoting him as saying he might leave the team when his present contract expires was out of context and ''out of whack.''

title: Servo Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The latest second quarter net loss included after-tax expenses of $205,000 related to the proposed merger offer.

title: The Pop Life
description: Prine at Carnegie

title: Swedish Prices Spurt
description: Swedish inflation last month reached its highest level since 1985, threatening an otherwise strong economy, Swedish economists said today. Government figures showed that prices rose at an annual rate of 6.7 percent in May. A price freeze introduced at the beginning of 1987 and lifted last July partly accounts for the recent high year-to-year rates.

title: China Presses Curbs on Spending
description: China has called for controls on consumer spending after recent rumors of price increases led to panic buying of items from toilet paper to clothing.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT CUT BACK IN APRIL TO 32-MONTH LOW
description: In a report that was far better than expected for the second straight month, the Government said today that the nation's trade deficit shrank 15.5 percent in April, to the lowest monthly point in more than two and a half years.

title: Clabir Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Wright Names Others Who Bought His Book
description: House Speaker Jim Wright today listed more people and a company who bought bulk quantities of his book, including a Washington lobbyist, a Boston insurance company and a fellow Congressman.

title: From Political Guerrilla to Republican Folk Hero
description: In the past, Republican colleagues called him arrogant, even hypocritical. They accused Newt Gingrich of being irrelevant to the legislative process, of trying to turn the House of Representatives into a pillow-fighting fraternity and, sometimes, of simply being a pain in the neck. Not lately.

title: EATING WELL
description: FOOD is an indispensable part of most summer outings, but what you take along will be determined by the mode of transportation. If a car trunk is at your disposal, there are almost no limits; when it is foot power or pedal power that gets you from point A to point B, there are limits. Add taste and good health considerations to the equation, and you're talking about advance planning, especially since the chances of finding healthful snacks at a tiny country store are almost nil.

title: Xeta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; College Students' TV Viewing on Low End
description: Although 75 percent of college students have TV sets for their own use, and 40 percent have VCR's as well, they average only 9.3 hours of viewing a week, putting them in the lowest viewer quintile, according to College Track, a New York research firm that has recently completed in-person interviews with 1,200 full-time students on 30 campuses.

title: Talks Over Convoy Reach Dead End
description: A week after arriving at the Mexican border with 30 tons of food and supplies destined for Nicaragua, a ragtag convoy of veterans and peace advocates has reached an apparent dead end in a dispute with Federal officials over the trade embargo on Nicaragua.

title: Southern Baptists Again Elect Conservative Leader
description: For the 10th time in a decade, the Southern Baptist Convention, the largest Protestant group in the nation, today elected a conservative president.

title: Ford-VW Venture
description: The head of the Ford Motor Company's international automotive operations said he did not expect its South American venture with Volkswagen A.G. to post a profit in 1988 because of skyrocketing inflation. Ford began the venture with Volkswagen, dubbed Autolatina, in 1987. Ford holds a 49 percent stake in the concern, the largest single company in South America. Last year, Autolatina posted a loss of $216 million, but the venture surprised analysts by posting a $25 million profit in the first quarter of 1988. But Allan D. Gilmour, a Ford executive vice president, said that Ford does not expect the venture to show a profit for 1988 as a whole.

title: WNET Will Announce New Fall Schedule Today
description: WNET plans to announce a new fall program schedule today, one that will include the first nightly local public-affairs program at the station in 13 years, according to staff members at the station.

title: Bill Giving Orthodox Jews Sole Power on Citizenship Fails in Israel
description: The Israeli Parliament defeated two bills today that would have given Orthodox Jewish authorities exclusive power to decide who is Jewish under the Law of Return.

title: Split Israeli Election From Peace Referendum; West Bank Rally
description: To the Editor:

title: Divided OPEC Puts Off Output and Price Moves
description: In a decision that brought neither surprise nor relief, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to extend its current production and pricing accord until the group meets here again on Nov. 21.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Minneapolis-St. Paul
description: LEAD: NEXT month signals the start of farmers' market mania in the Twin Cities. Through July and August, the peak season, 8,000 to 10,000 shoppers will flock to the cities' downtown open-air markets every weekend. Seven satellite markets in other neighborhoods operate on different days during the week.

title: Dense-Pac Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Included a tax credit of $96,000. c-Net loss and included pre-tax expenses of $22,220 from the closing of a Puerto Rican manufacturing facility and a $42,250 financing fee.

title: Dukakis Seeks to Assure Allies on Support for NATO
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whose views on foreign policy are unfamiliar to many foreigners, sought today to assure Western allies and those involved in American foreign policy about his commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Burns Harbor Journal; Out of Mothballs, Back on the Lakes
description: His hands grimy with grease and his coveralls drenched with sweat, the burly sailor bent over a plate of beef and potatoes and spoke of the joy of fatigue.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Norman Black has been appointed executive vice president of Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising, a unit of Marketing Corporation of America.

title: U. of Michigan Selects New President
description: After an extensive nationwide search, the University of Michigan has chosen as its new president James J. Duderstadt, who is now the school's provost and vice president for academic affairs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New England Monthly Is Bustling
description: THERE'S a lot of activity inside the old brick brass works on the Mill River in Haydenville, Mass., and it is being felt thoughout New England and beyond.

title: Ousted Palestinian-American Says Shamir 'Made Me a Hero'
description: Mubarak Awad, the Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolent opposition to the Israeli occupation, said yesterday that in deporting him, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir ''has made me a hero.''

title: Wausau Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an asset writeoff that reduced net by $795,000, or 16 cents a share, and a gain on the sale of a product line of $229,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Payless Cashways Inc reports earnings for 13wks to May 28
description: b-After an after-tax gain of $2,413,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in cost components of inventories.

title: Rogers Studies Cable-TV Bids
description: At least nine prospective buyers have submitted proposals of up to $1.4 billion to acquire five cable television stations in the United States from Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto, a Rogers executive said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday, about Dave Winfield of the Yankees making a diving catch, misidentified the player at rear. It was Bobby Meacham.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Opposition Aide Quits, Widening British Rift
description: The Labor Party defense spokesman, Denzil Davies, resigned today with a harsh attack on the party leader, Neil Kinnock, that deepened party divisions.

title: Bond Prices Jump After Trade Report
description: Bond prices soared and yields plummeted yesterday in response to a steep decline in the nation's trade deficit for April.

title: Sports of The Times; Do the Jets Need a Dictator?
description: THE frustrated followers of the New York Jets will be bemused to learn that the stewardship of their team has been passed from a man who once worked as a journalist to a man who once worked in the field of mental health.

title: Anguished, Yet Loving, AIDS Lesson
description: When the Honda Nighthawk motorcycle is parked outside his nursery school, 3-year-old Matt Moore can hardly wait to go inside.

title: Chamber Music Society Selects Artistic Director
description: Fred Sherry, a cellist and conductor, is to become artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in next June. Mr. Sherry, who is also the society's music administrator, will succeed Charles Wadsworth, who is resigning and who has been director since the society's inception in 1969.

title: Drug Inquiry Was Quashed, House Report Charges
description: Federal officials quashed an inquiry into drug trafficking at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California just three days before the investigation reached the laboratory's most sensitive areas, and then they misled House investigators, a Congressional report charges.

title: Pope Meets the Dalai Lama
description: Pope John Paul II received the Dalai Lama today in a private audience at the Vatican for talks on religious values and world peace. The leader of the world's Roman Catholics met the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism for about 20 minutes, Vatican officials reported. The Dalai Lama later left Rome for France.

title: Text of Letter From Cuomo
description: Following is the text of the letter from Governor Cuomo to Attorney General Robert Abrams:

title: Costly Faux Pas for Paris Bourse
description: The French Bourse's hopes of becoming one of the world's major stock markets took an embarrassing step backward today when the president of the French Stockbrokers Association resigned after a disclosure that the group lost $86 million because of mismanaged investments.

title: From the 'Evil Empire'
description: Although President Reagan has declared an end to Soviet-bashing and talk of the ''evil empire,'' the word apparently did not reach the United States Customs Service, which recently held up delivery here of 500 posters of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Lenin.

title: John W. Yengo Sr., 72, Ex-Judge in Jersey City
description: John W. Yengo Sr., a former controversial Municipal Court judge in Jersey City, died of Stevens-Johnson syndrome, a rare allergic reaction, Saturday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: More Science Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Development Is Tracked in Babies Born With the Virus
description: Forty percent of infants born with the AIDS virus develop the disease or a related illness within 10 months, researchers said today.

title: Inhaled Drug Is Found of Benefit Against Pneumonia in AIDS Cases
description: Early studies showing benefit from an inhaled drug to combat a form of pneumonia that often kills AIDS patients and discoveries of new genes in the AIDS virus were among the reports on the second day of the fourth international conference on AIDS here.

title: Early-June Vehicle Sales Fell
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks declined 4.1 percent in early June from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Dome Petroleum Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, said it would not consider a proposal by Cantario Petroleum to top Amoco Canada's takeover offer because it was conditional and Dome had questions about the financing.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: WHEN Southerners say they take their barbecue seriously, they don't mean pouring a bottled sauce over burgers quickly charred on a grill. They mean meat, usually pork, slow-cooked according to recipes that vary from state to state, city to city, cook to cook.

title: Osicom Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflect an increase in shares outstanding. This rise was because of an initial public offering June 3, 1987.

title: Canada-Egypt Accord
description: Canadian officials said the Canadian Wheat Board, which is responsible for wheat exports, signed an agreement with Egypt last week to reschedule payments due since January 1987.

title: Fresh Sweet Peas: A Small but Worthy Passion
description: LEAD: SUGAR SNAPS, snow peas, garden peas and petits pois. The vegetable lover need never grow bored when the sweet peas of spring are in season. Start out gobbling them raw, and slowly move to the simplest of preparations: lightly steamed and barely glazed with butter.

title: Results Plus
description: Soccer West Germany Tops Denmark: In the European championships, Jurgen Klinsmann scored in the ninth minute and Olaf Thon scored with three minutes left yesterday to lead West Germany past Denmark, 2-0, in Gelsenkirchen, West Germany. In the day's second game, in Frankfurt, Gianluca Vialli scored in the 74th minute to give Italy a 1-0 victory over Spain. Italy and West Germany have 3 points each in the tournament; Spain has 2 points and Denmark has been eliminated. On Friday, West Germany will play Spain and Italy will play Denmark. Klinsmann scored after Soeren Lerby attempted to head the ball back to his goalkeeper, Peter Schmeichel, but it was instead captured by the forward Rudi Voller, whose shot from close range was blocked by Schmeichel. Klinsmann, a 23-year-old striker from Stuttgart who led the West German league with 19 goals last season, put in the rebound. Thon, left alone by Danish defenders at the center of the penalty area, easily headed in a corner kick from Pierre Littbarski. In the second game, the 23-year-old Vialli took a ball on the left and shot a low, left-foot shot into the far corner of the goal.

title: Festival Review/Theater; Journey to Martyrdom
description: Poland's Gardzienice Theater Association is a grass roots company, drawing its inspiration from folklore and folk songs gathered during the troupe's journeys through Eastern Europe. As the artistic director, Wlodzimierz Staniewski, explained to the audience before Gardzienice began its first New York performance on Monday, the group considers itself to be an expeditionary force, unifying high and low culture. Theatergoers become participants in that ceremonial search.

title: Friedman Loses Federal Appeal Of Conviction
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, lost a court battle yesterday to overturn his conviction in a major corruption case focusing on the New York City Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Dartmouth, Mass.
description: FOR 100 years, Allen's Neck, a small Quaker community in southern Massachusetts, has held a fund-raising clambake on the third Thursday of August. Now the clambake, or a reasonable facsimile, is going to the nation's capital as part of the 22d Smithsonian Festival of American Folklife. The sold-out Massachusetts event is scheduled for Aug. 19; the Washington reconstruction will be from 11 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on June 26 on the Mall.

title: San Francisco
description: SOME will come for the first peach of summer, others for the long-awaited sweet white corn. At the Tasting of Summer Produce on Sunday, local farmers and growers will display their succulent wares among the terraced gardens of the Oakland Museum, 100 Oak Street in Oakland, Calif. They will offer generous samples of everything from white nectarines, Brandywine raspberries and edible flowers to Romance itself (a romaine lettuce).

title: Two Rulings Go Against Raiders
description: The Los Angeles Raiders suffered two legal setbacks today when judges reversed part of the verdict in the club's suit against the National Football League and dismissed a claim that the team had filed against the city's Coliseum Commission.

title: Robert W. Gilmore Is Dead at 67; Active in Rights and Peace Groups
description: Robert Wallace Gilmore, an organizer of peace and civil rights groups and the founder of an agency devoted to improving education worldwide, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Miami. He was 67 years old and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease. He also maintained a home in Manhattan.

title: To Fight AIDS, Indian Urges Ban on Sex With Foreigners
description: A top Indian health official has offered an unusual suggestion to prevent the spread of AIDS in India: he has urged the Government to ban sex between Indians and foreign visitors, enforceable by fines and prison terms.

title: Stocks Soar in Heavy Day; Dow Up 25.07
description: Stock prices rose in heavy trading yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest close since the October market collapse.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Security Council MEETING ON RENEWAL OF MANDATE OF FORCE IN CYPRUS - 10:30 A.M.

title: Worthington Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
G.& W. Unit Sets $200 Million Offer
description: The Associates Corporation of North America, a unit of Gulf and Western Inc., is offering $200 million of 8 5/8 percent senior notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.647, to yield 8.73 percent, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the closing of the play ''Fences'' misstated the date, which was supplied by the show's press representative.

title: Jewelmasters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest first quarter loss includes a gain of $106,000 from an accounting change.

title: Frances Sergeant Childs, Professor, 87
description: Dr. Frances Sergeant Childs, professor emeritus of history at Brooklyn College and a member of the founding faculty of the college in 1930, died Saturday at the Interchurch Residence in Bridgeport, Conn., where she lived. She was 87 years old.

title: Why Paterson School Principal Has Admirers
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Appeal of 'Beautiful Writing'
description: LEAD: When Judith Barbour was in fifth grade, she was given the tedious assignment of cutting block let-ters out of graph paper for a class project. She remembers thinking, ''I never want to have anything to do with letters again.''

title: Reagan Endorses Inquiry on Wright
description: President Reagan today called for the appointment of an outside investigator to look into the charges of ethics violations against House Speaker Jim Wright.

title: Heldor Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $964,000 after-tax gain from an insurance claim.

title: YANKEES' SLIPS; METS 6, CARDINALS 4
description: Darryl Strawberry launched two more of those screaming home runs into the sky over Shea Stadium last night, and the St. Louis Cardinals got the message.

title: Johnny Farrell, Hall of Fame Golfer, 87
description: Johnny Farrell, a member of the Professional Golfers' Association Hall of Fame and the club professional at Baltusrol in Springfield, N.J., for 40 years, died of a stroke at his home here Tuesday. He was 87 years old.

title: Demand for Power Surges to a Record In 96 degrees Temperature
description: With a temperature of 96 tying the record set 97 years ago, New Yorkers used more electricity yesterday than on any other June day in the history of Consolidated Edison.

title: Maoist Rebels Slay A U.S. Agronomist And Peru Colleague
description: Maoist rebels shot and killed an American agronomist and a Peruvian colleague after dragging them from their pickup truck on an isolated road, Government officials said today.

title: EUROPEANS LAUNCH IMPROVED ROCKET
description: Western Europe introduced a new generation of powerful and versatile rockets yesterday with the successful flight of the Ariane 4, a craft that is expected to be a workhorse of commercial and scientific launchings for the next decade.

title: CARLUCCI PLAN ON DRUG TESTING
description: The Secretary of Defense outlined plans to expand the Pentagon's drug testing rules to companies doing business with the military. Page A16.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I GREW up ragging my parents pretty mercilessly about one thing or another, including cigarette smoking. I was 14 years old when manufacturers were obliged to put warnings on cigarette packages, so all my adult life I have known that smoking is bad for you. I smoked for about a year once, when I was looking to be 19 going on 27, but my friends said I looked like a fish; I quit. Now I dislike the habit, although I am not a fanatic; I don't have any little signs in my house that say ''Thank you for not smoking,'' and if someone asks for an ashtray, I will produce an old cereal bowl. Slowly.

title: Uranium Industry Loses In High Court on Imports
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously rejected arguments made by the domestic uranium industry that the Government is required to protect it by restricting the enrichment of foreign uranium for use in commercial reactors in the United States.

title: Court Backs Man's Refusal To Allow Amputation of Leg
description: A nursing home resident with gangrene has the right to refuse a leg amputation that could save his life, a county judge says.

title: Senate Leader Offers Proposal On State Deficit
description: Although he continued to deny the existence of a state budget gap, the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, today nevertheless proposed a plan to make up a shortfall of almost $900 million ''if one occurs.''

title: A Celebration of Bloomsday: 'Ulysses' Marathon Begins
description: Exactly 84 years ago today, Stephen Dedalus and Leopold Bloom wandered for nearly 800 pages through the streets of Dublin in James Joyce's ''Ulysses.'' Devotees of Joyce and his 1922 masterpiece may celebrate in the seventh annual ''Bloomsday on Broadway'' marathon at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, today from 8 A.M. until 1 A.M. on Friday.

title: Key Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $107,000 for the quarter and $173,000 for the 6 months.

title: TV Notes
description: Culling 'Not News'

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ackerley Communications Inc., Seattle, which has interests in advertising and broadcasting and owns the Seattle Supersonics basketball team, named Donald E. Carter president. In addition, Barry Ackerley will become chairman and chief executive.

title: New Iberia Journal; Tanks Are Tombstones Of Ruined Fuel Policy
description: Against a landscape of green and brown, the blue and white tanks of the Agrifuels Refining Company plant rise unnaturally from a sugar cane field here, ghostly monuments to a state energy policy in ruins.

title: Varo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included $600,000, or 14 cents a share, from a change in accounting methods, a litigation settlement of $512,000, but offset by $192,000 in legal expenses--all items are for the quarter and year.

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE is a universally recognized remedy for clothes-closet clutter: close the door! This solution is simple, quick and effective, and thus wildly popular. But what happens when the inevitable occurs and the door no longer closes?

title: Righetti's Elbow Tender
description: Dave Righetti acknowledged today that he is experiencing tenderness in his pitching elbow, a condition that will likely cause the Yankees to call on their left-handed reliever less frequently than Manager Billy Martin would like.

title: The Arts Festival; Jose Quintero and O'Neill Resonate
description: Jose Quintero sat in a chair at the Neil Simon Theater with what looked like a silver microphone in his hand. He took a sip of water from a paper cup, touched the microphonelike object to his throat and began to speak.

title: Mcorp Sees Profit Despite Problems
description: Mcorp, the second-largest banking group in Texas, should post a second-quarter profit on the proceeds of asset sales, its chairman, Gene H. Bishop, said, but the troubled bank faces a long road to recovery. Mcorp, which lost $58.2 million in the first quarter, completed the sale of its Mtech Corporation subsidiary to the Electronics Data Systems Corporation unit of the General Motors Corporation for $281 million in late April.

title: Numerex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Toy Guns: Do They Fan Aggression?
description: ARMED with toy guns, children have played war games for years. And parents and psychologists continue to debate whether playing with war toys encourages violent behavior among youngsters, or inures them to the horrors of death and war.

title: Soviets Bar Family's Emigration
description: For the last two weeks, the Ziman family had begun to believe that their 11-year wait to emigrate from the Soviet Union was near an end.

title: KEY RATES
Bond Prices Slip in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury issues slipped slightly in light trading yesterday after rising sharply in the previous session.

title: Willie Velasquez, 44, Hispanic Leader, Dies
description: Willie Velasquez, a leader of the movement to increase political power among Hispanic Americans, died early today of cancer. He was 44 years old.

title: Deficit in Current Account Widens
description: The deficit in the current account, the broadest measure of United States foreign trade, widened in the first three months of the year, to $39.75 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Military procurement officials may have accepted payoffs from contractors and their consultants in exchange for confidential information on Government contracts. The investigation into possible Pentagon bribes is focusing on the actions of officials in all four military services and on some of the biggest contractors, as well as on former Defense Department officials who became private consultants. [ Page A1. ] An F.B.I. document links McDonnell Douglas and several of its senior executives, as well as a former Navy official, to a bribery scheme. [ D6. ] House Democrats agreed to consider a trade bill that does not include the layoff-notification provision that prompted a Presidential veto. The measure requiring that workers be warned of plant closings or layoffs will become part of other legislation. [ D1. ] The Senate asked the President to consult with U.S. allies about the effect of bank loans to the Soviet Union. [ D7. ] The nation's current-account deficit widened in the first quarter, to $39.75 billion. The figure included the first deficit in investment earnings in 30 years. [ D22. ] Industrial production grew a moderate 0.4 percent in May. [ D7. ] Retail sales edged up a scant 0.1 percent last month. [ D7. ] The Government does not have to restrict uranium imports to help domestic producers, the Supreme Court ruled. [ D2. ] The Administration urged changes in cable television rules to encourage competition. A Commerce Department report warned that large companies may be gaining too much control. [ D22. ] The Senate acted to prevent savings and loan companies from switching from the F.S.L.I.C. to the healthier F.D.I.C. [ D5. ] Concern about the health effects of video display terminals has erupted anew after years of quiescence. [ A1. ] Marc Belzberg and a family company illegally concealed purchases of Ashland Oil stock, a Federal judge ruled. [ D18. ] COMPANIES Bank of New York raised its bid for Irving Bank, offering an additional $5 in cash and about $3 in stock. [ D1. ] Texaco managers and Carl C. Icahn scrambled to win support as the company's annual meeting, and a heated proxy fight, draws near. [ D1. ] The College Retirement Equities Fund said it will vote nearly 3.5 million shares in Mr. Icahn's favor. [ D4. ] Centerre agreed to be acquired by Boatmen's Bancshares for stock worth about $467 million. [ D4. ] Allied Stores plans to sell the Ann Taylor chain, reversing its previous stance. [ D8. ] Federal Express begins its delivery service in Japan today, despite failing to resolve disputes with the Government. [ D20. ] MARKETS Soybean and grain prices rose their daily limits in Chicago as concern grew over hot, dry weather in the Farm Belt. [ D1. ] A committee of pension fund executives will meet today at the Big Board, with the discussions expected to center on trading strategies that have been blamed for market volatility. [ D1. ] Stock prices moved higher again, with the Dow Jones industrials rising 6.93 points, to 2,131.40. [ D8. ] Bond prices held steady after Tuesday's steep jump. [ D18. ] The dollar was mixed as currency traders began to mark time until next week's economic summit meeting. Gold rose $1.30 on the Comex, closing at $451.90. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Macmillan's restructuring plan is a sweetheart deal for company managers, the Robert M. Bass Group contends. Investors appear to agree with the would-be acquirer. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Some analysts say Dow Chemical's stock may be undervalued, pointing to a new balance in the company's products and the countries where it operates. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: After 3 Deaths, Realistic Toys Are Under Fire
description: LAST February San Francisco police officers killed a 13-year-old retarded boy after mistaking his cap gun for a real weapon. In December the Memphis police killed a 16-year-old boy whose pellet pistol looked like a .45-caliber handgun. And last spring, a sheriff's deputy shot and killed a 19-year-old man playing with a toy gun in San Bernadino County in California.

title: Texaco and Icahn Make Final Pitches
description: Texaco's management and Carl C. Icahn, its challenger, hit the hustings yesterday in last-minute efforts to round up proxy votes in advance of the company's annual meeting tomorrow in Tulsa, Okla.

title: NICARAGUA LIFTING WAGE-PRICE RULES
description: In a major policy shift, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has lifted wage and price controls and imposed limits on credit and imports in an attempt to revive Nicaragua's war-battered economy.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: AFTER a tough day at work, Linda Richter came home to find a messy kitchen. She turned angrily to one of her three teen-age children. ''All of a sudden I heard my mother's words come out of my mouth,'' Ms. Richter said later. ''I was saying some of the things that, when I was a child, I swore I'd never say to my own kids.''

title: Working Mother Is Now Norm, Study Shows
description: For the first time, more than half of new mothers are remaining in the job market, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Industrial Output Up 0.4% in May
description: A boom in the manufacture of business equipment and a pickup at automobile plants helped lift the nation's industrial production by a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in May.

title: Boris N. Naumov, Computer Scientist, 61
description: Boris N. Naumov, a leading figure in Soviet computer science who sought joint ventures with American companies, died Saturday, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. He was 61 years old.

title: Armenian Legislature Bakcs Calls For Annexing Disputed Territory
description: After four months of protests, strikes and ethnic violence, the Armenian legislature today sided with demonstrators demanding annexation of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region.

title: May Retail Sales Rose 0.1%, Quieting Inflation Worries
description: Retail sales grew a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department said today in a report that may help ease fears of higher inflation.

title: Dukakis Takes the Fore In the Land of Kennedy
description: Once upon a time, only one Democrat from Massachusetts was supposed to aspire to the Presidency, and his name was always Kennedy.

title: Aiding Contras: White House Weighs New Fight
description: The Reagan Administration, with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in the lead, seems to be gearing up for an effort to obtain more aid for the Nicaraguan guerrillas. President Reagan and

title: Topics of The Times; Mississippi Lacks Respect
description: At Samuel Bice Johnson's 1982 murder trial in Mississippi, the prosecutor persuaded a jury to vote for the death penalty. He cited Mr. Johnson's 1963 assault conviction in Rochester, N.Y., as an aggravating circumstance. Subsequently, however, New York's highest court erased that old conviction, agreeing that Mr. Johnson had a valid basis for appeal but had not been told about his appeal rights. But in a slap at New York justice, Mississippi's Supreme Court upheld the death sentence anyway.

title: Irving Bid Is Raised $8 a Share
description: The Bank of New York Company increased its bid for the Irving Bank Corporation yesterday, offering an additional $5 in cash and about $3 more in stock. Irving's board, which had previously rejected Bank of New York in favor of an offer from Banca Commerciale Italiana, will consider the new offer at its regularly scheduled meeting on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Open; Heat Is On as Tough Field Gathers
description: The unexpectedly hot weather this week may be the most critical factor in the 88th United States Open golf championship, which begins Thursday at The Country Club.

title: Talking Deals; Macmillan's Plan To Thwart Bass
description: TO fend off a hostile takeover bid from the Robert M. Bass Group, Macmillan Inc.'s management has proposed a restructuring plan that would split the publisher into two companies: a book publisher and an information company.

title: YANKEES' SLIPS; RED SOX 8, YANKEES 3
description: Jay Buhner backpedaled quickly in center field, his attention fixed on the fly ball that Mike Greenwell had lifted into the night. Buhner settled easily under the ball, guided it into the pocket of his glove and then stood there helplessly as someone in the bleachers doused him with a cup of warm beer.

title: Palestinian Firebomber Shot Dead As Israel Says Attacks Continue
description: Israeli soldiers came under attack by Arabs with firebombs in three incidents today. In one of the attacks, near Bethlehem, troops shot and killed a 21-year-old Palestinian, the army said.

title: WHO'S HUSTLING WHOM? A PAUL NEWMAN COURT DRAMA
description: The scene could have been cribbed from the script of any courthouse comedy: Paul Newman sits cooly in the witness stand. He bristles slightly at an attorney's question. He turns to the judge for help.

title: Video Terminals and Health: A Reawakening of Concern
description: After years of relative quiet, the possible health effects of video display terminals have again become a public issue, fueled by a new scientific study and a new law on Long Island. These appear against an unsettled scentific backdrop in which some dangers are discounted but others are still open to question.

title: Review/Dance; Playing With Space Under a Bridge
description: The Station House Opera, a performance group from London, was founded eight years ago by three visual artists. The company's preoccupation with the space and physical materials as a theatrical matrix was much in evidence in ''Piranesi in New York,'' which opened Tuesday at the Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage. Part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, the conceptualist work is being presented by Creative Time as part of its Big Ideas for Big Spaces, a five-week summer festival that aims at an imaginative use of the 50-foot-high brick vaults in the anchorage.

title: Presbyterians Adopt Statement on Nuclear Stance
description: Presbyterians overwhelmingly adopted a major statement on Christian responsibilities in a nuclear age Tuesday after considerable revision to mollify members who feared the church was embracing civil disobedience.

title: Howard Baker's Selfless Service
description: Sixteen months ago, in the tumultuous aftermath of the Iran-contra affair, Howard Baker abandoned his own Presidential ambitions to help President Reagan as White House chief of staff. Now he leaves that hot seat, after giving his President, party and country a model of selflessness.

title: Corrections
description: The Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect address for Jan Wallman's Restaurant Cabaret. It is at 49 West 44th Street, not on West 20th Street.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Society Explores the 20th Century
description: The chamber-music wing of the First New York International Festival of the Arts flapped into action at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening with a concert devoted to works composed in the first 20 years of this century. The program, one of four in which the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will take a bird's-eye view of more than eight decades of 20th-century music, was introduced by Charles Wadsworth in the hyperventilating, purposely corny style that the society's regular patrons know so well and evidently appreciate. Mr. Wadsworth, who retires at the end of the coming season after 20 years as the society's artistic director and cheerleader, also introduced his successor-in-waiting, the cellist Fred Sherry, who took a bow from the audience.

title: Alleco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
description: b-Includes a loss of $509,000 for the quarter and income of $31,391,000 for the year both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary charge of $89,000 for early retirement of debt for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $3,109,000 on the termination of a pension plan for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,779,000 and $43,289,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary charge of $2,482,000 for restructuring of debt.

title: House to Omit Plant Notice In Trade Bill
description: In a concession to President Reagan, House Democrats agreed today to take up a version of landmark trade legislation without a contested provision that would require companies to give 60 days' notice of factory closings and major layoffs.

title: National Service Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Review/Music; Rockabilly Blues and Tales
description: Over the last decade, devotees of 50's rockabilly have looked to Rodney Crowell, a Houston-born singer, songwriter and producer, as the most likely candidate to lead a rockabilly revival that might integrate country music into the pop-rock mainstream.

title: GORBACHEV AND THE CHURCH
description: The Soviet leader's new tolerance for the church is another front in his effort to change Soviet society. News analysis, page A12.

title: LABOR DISPUTE BACK IN COURT
description: The issue of free agency in the National Football League returns to court on Friday after months of contention. The dispute arose after the contracts of 340 players expired in February in the absence of a collective bargaining agreement.

title: Few Gains Seen as Greek-Turkish Talks End
description: The Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey ended three days of tense talks today without resolving any of the complex historical differences between them.

title: Bids Reported For Zenith Unit
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation has invited bids for its troubled consumer electronics division, according to officials of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

title: Review/Concert; Juilliard String Quartet
description: As the elder statesmen of the blossoming American chamber music world, the Juilliard String Quartet kicked off the quartet series of the First New York International Festival of the Arts with a Tuesday evening concert at the 92d Street Y. The program, in keeping with the festival's 20th-century mandate, includes two abstruse essays - Gunther Schuller's First Quartet (1957) and Milton Babbitt's Fourth Quartet (1970) - and a fond backward glance, Leos Janacek's Second Quartet (1928).

title: Psssst! A Bath Oil as Bug Spray
description: I KNOW the incongruous when I see it, and I saw it at a roadside fruit and vegetable stand near my house on the Friday before Memorial Day.
