On a shelf right above the Vidalia onions and the local asparagus, there were a couple of dozen bottles of bath oil, Avon Skin-So-Soft, to be specific.

title: Topics of The Times; From Russia With Apologies
description: The Soviet Government's persistent unwillingness to admit error and apologize has needlessly roiled Moscow's relations with the West. It's a welcome surprise, therefore, three years after Soviet soldiers in East Germany killed a U.S. Army officer, to hear the Soviet Defense Minister expressing regrets.

title: Baseball Notebook; WHO'S ON FIRST? HARD TO SAY
description: Whitey Herzog, thinking ahead to his third engagement in six years as manager of the National League All-Star team, was speculating on his starting lineup and stopped when he got to first base.

title: Yields Show Little Change
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were unchanged to slightly higher for the week ended yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: If bridge is allowed to boom in the Soviet Union, as it has in China, the development will be warmly welcomed in Estonia.

title: Budget Fight Past Deadline Is Predicted
description: The New York City Council yesterday pledged to continue its confrontation with Mayor Koch over his proposed $25.2 billion budget, despite a deadline of midnight tonight. The Council leadership also challenged the Mayor's revenue projections, saying that, given the surprising strength of the national economy, they are too low.

title: Panel of Pension Managers To Hold Talks at Big Board
description: A new committee comprising the executives of some of the nation's largest corporate and state pension funds will meet today at the New York Stock Exchange, with discussions likely to center on the capital requirements of specialists, trading liquidity, coordination of margin and clearing between the stock and futures markets in Chicago.

title: 'Al Jolson' In the Philippines
description: LEAD: ''We must slay the father image,''

title: Review/Music; A Choir Sings Haydn
description: JoAnn Rice and her Florilegium Chamber Choir put together a typically lively if slightly eccentric program Tuesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall. The eccentricities involved a normal amount of music presented without intermission; Haydn tacked onto the end of an otherwise all-20th-century and mostly contemporary program, and two works that didn't use the chorus at all.

title: Panatech Research & Develpment Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a gain on disposal of discontinued segments of $235,600 and a loss from operations of discontinued segments of $191,700. c-Net loss and after a loss from operations of discontinued segments of $255,200. The previous year's results are restated.

title: Investors Delaying On Proxy
description: With the biggest proxy fight in Wall Street history about to be decided, the College Retirement Equities Fund, representing nearly 4,000 colleges, universities and other educational institutions, said yesterday that it would vote its nearly 3.5 million shares of Texaco Inc. stock to give the financier Carl C. Icahn a seat on the Texaco board.

title: Windbags of Change
description: The British press is knocked out by the ''New Russian Revolution,'' end of the cold war, winds of change - oh, what a lovely peace.

title: Books of The Times; Conquering the Financial World With Junk Bonds
description: The Predators' Ball The Junk-Bond Raiders and the Man Who Staked Them By Connie Bruck 385 pages. The American Lawyer/Simon & Schuster. $19.95

title: Ford Sets Closing Of Plant in Ohio
description: The Ford Motor Company, confirming a decision it had announced in 1986, said it would close its forging plant in Canton, Ohio, in December. The plant makes forged parts, called spindles, that are used in the front suspension of such rear-drive cars as the Ford Mustang and the Lincoln Town Car. These cars are gradually being displaced by front-drive models, the suspensions of which use many parts that are cast rather than forged.

title: Sharing (Which?) NATO Burdens
description: Whither NATO? The very question sounds like a parody of portentous concern over the defense of Western Europe. Yet suddenly, parody becomes profundity, because of two sea changes affecting the alliance.

title: Investors Disclose Stake in Pennwalt
description: Centaur Partners, a partnership of three New York investors, has acquired 6.5 percent of the Pennwalt Corporation and said that it might seek control of the Philadelphia-based pharmaceutical and chemical company. Centaur said it would seek a meeting with Pennwalt's management ''to discuss ways to maximize value for all shareholders in a friendly transaction.''

title: Gray-Market Battle Is Far From Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Gencorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1 million and $2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After net from discontinued operations of $212 million for the quarter and $218 million for the 6 months. The company said share earnings in 1987 have been adjusted for the 3-for-1 stock split.

title: DEAL TO SELL SHOREHAM PLANT FOR $1 IS APPROVED BY LILCO
description: The directors of the Long Island Lighting Company today unanimously approved an accord between the utility and New York State that calls for Lilco to sell its Shoreham nuclear power station to New York for $1.

title: Results Plus; Tennis
description: Victory in 43 Minutes: Martina Navratilova routed Raffaella Reggi of Italy, 6-0, 6-2, in just 43 minutes yesterday to reach the quarterfinals of the Pilkington Glass championships in Eastbourne, England.

title: Steel and Fiberglass Open New Doors
description: When houses were built of stone, mortar and timbers, picking a front door was a simple matter. In most cases, the only choice was a slab of wood, which could be embellished as its owner saw fit.

title: Soviets Recognizing Their Drug Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Rice Output Rise Seen
description: The world's output of rice is headed up, led by sharply expanded planting in the United States, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. American production is expected to increase by 23 percent this year from 1987.

title: Allstate to Sell Parts of Subsidiary
description: The Allstate Insurance Company said it would sell portions of the group life and health operations of its subsidiary, the Allstate Life Insurance Company. Allstate, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company, would sell its corporate accounts and group brokerage operations. The operations had $923 million in combined revenues, or about 6 percent of Allstate Insurance's $15.6 billion in total sales last year.

title: Paul O'Neil, 79, Dies; Writer With Time Inc.
description: Paul E. O'Neil, a writer and reporter with Time Inc. for more than 40 years, died Sunday at the United Hospital of Port Chester, N.Y., after complications arose from surgery for the removal of a brain tumor. He was 79 years old.

title: Mail Boxes Etc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 20 percent stock dividend which was declared Tuesday for stockholders of record June 15.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Lakers Promising To Be Aggressive
description: In Magic Johnson's huge Tudor home in Bel Air, Calif., there is an Isiah Thomas Room that is reserved for the Detroit Pistons' playmaker.

title: Federal Express Japan Plan
description: Although the Federal Express Corporation has failed to end a dispute with the Japanese Government over restrictions on its proposed express package-delivery business, the company plans to begin the service anyway with a flight to Tokyo today.

title: Groundwater Technology Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Sports People; Knepper Speaks
description: Bob Knepper, the Houston Astros' pitcher who was criticized earlier this year when he said women should not umpire men's games, called the National Organization of Women ''a bunch of lesbians'' in an article in the June 20 issue of Sports Illustrated. According to an article in the magazine, Knepper shrugged off the Houston NOW chapter's decision to vote him ''Neanderthal of the Year'' after he said women shouldn't be umpires. ''NOW is such a blowhard organization,'' Knepper said. ''They are a bunch of lesbians. Their focus has nothing to do with women's rights. It has everything to do with women wanting to be men.'' When asked about the article, Knepper told The Houston Post: ''That is probably what I said, but I was joking at the time and I didn't mean it to be taken seriously. I don't know any of the people in the organization, so I really couldn't tell you what kind of people they are.'' During spring training this year, Knepper made his comments about female umpires after Pam Postema was the home-plate umpire in a game he pitched. He said he didn't think God meant for women to be umpires because women shouldn't have authority over men.(AP)

title: Haiti's President Rejects Military Order
description: In the first major confrontation between Haiti's four-month-old civilian Government and the powerful army, President Leslie F. Manigat today rejected a decision by the military commander to reassign several high-ranking officers.

title: Polish Communists Realign the Party Leadership
description: The Polish Communist Party reorganized the leadership at the end of a two-day party meeting Tuesday, naming the head of the central bank and the Foreign Minister to senior party posts.

title: Smaller Gain For Ads in '88 Is Predicted
description: ROBERT J. COEN, McCann-Erickson's seer of the marketplace, yesterday revised downward his prediction for total advertising in the United States in 1988.

title: Gorbachev and the Church: Behind New Tolerance
description: Summoning a rousing crescendo, the male choir filled the soaring vaults of St. Vladimir's Cathedral with the special hymn of the Russian Orthodox millennium:

title: Trade Figure Off in Canada
description: Canada's trade surplus was reduced in April by a sharp decline in exports, particularly to the United States, the Government reported today.

title: U.S. Inquiry Begun on Ford Vans
description: Federal regulators have opened an investigation into reports of fuel spurting in 1984-87 Ford E150 Econoline vans, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: IKEA Sues a Competitor Over Design of Its Stores
description: IKEA, the Swedish retailer of home furnishings, maintains that imitation is not the sincerest form of flattery, but grounds for a lawsuit.

title: Black Congressmen Exhort Dukakis to Choose Jackson
description: Black Democrats in Congress today sent a strong message to Michael S. Dukakis today urging him to name the Rev. Jesse Jackson as his running mate.

title: Sports People; New Leaders
description: Will Clark of the San Francisco Giants and Gary Carter of the Mets moved into first place in voting for the National League All-Star team, according to figures released yesterday. Clark leads Hernandez with 404,614 votes to 397,904. At catcher, Carter leads Tony Pena of the St. Louis Cardinals 312,459 to 296,786.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; He's Ready
description: Seen around town: a sort of ultimate bumper sticker - also marketed as red, white and blue T-shirt -that reads: He's Tan, Rested and Ready

title: Taking the Chaos Out of Home Libraries
description: IS your library a disaster? Has your reading group just chosen Edith Wharton's ''Age of Innocence'' and you can't find your college copy? Are you planning a trip to Britain this summer and can't find your travel guide? Then Kurt Thometz, who organizes and catalogues home libraries, is your man.

title: Aid Convoy Is Turned Back at Border
description: A convoy of food and medical supplies destined for Nicaragua was turned away from the border with Mexico today, a week after it arrived here, and most of the group headed for Washington instead to press their case.

title: Riot Police Patrol Soccer Site
description: English, Dutch and West German soccer fans skirmished today after a European Championship match as hundreds of riot police patrolled the city.

title: Bronx Health Center Seeks Reorganization
description: The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Health Center, a South Bronx agency that is one of the largest community health centers in the nation, filed for reorganization yesterday.

title: American Hoist & Derrick Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,570,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $18,000 and $2,187,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Robert B. Stewart, College Executive, 92
description: Robert B. Stewart, a retired Purdue University executive who also coordinated veterans' benefits for the Government, died Friday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: Product Liability Bill Backed
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved a product liability bill that consumer advocates maintain constitutes an assault on the legal rights of victims of hazardous goods.

title: AEL Industries Inc reports earnings for 13wks to May 27
Dalai Lama Approves Chinese Role in Tibet
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan Buddhist leader, said today that he recognized China's right to handle Tibet's foreign affairs and maintain troops on Tibetan soil.

title:
Market Place;
Is Dow Chemical Recession-Proof?
description: LEAD: THE Dow Chemical Company is earning more than ever from a business that is more evenly balanced than ever. So some analysts contend that despite a rise of about $6 in the last two weeks, its stock is undervalued. Dow's shares closed at $89.875 yesterday, off 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ex-Astronaut to Lead Small Laser Company
description: Frank Borman, the one-time astronaut and former chairman of Eastern Airlines, yesterday was given the task of charting the future direction of a tiny company that expects to be awash in cash from royalties on laser patents.

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $1,022,000 for the latest quarter and $784,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Review/Theater; Of Baseball, the Infinite and Various Kinds of Curves
description: Quincy Long gives a goofy spin to the first inning of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '88. His ''Something About Baseball'' is a sort of shaggy dog story, except that the dog is invisible, so for all we know it is hairless.

title: AIDES SAY BAKER FELT TASK FINISHED
description: The decision by Howard H. Baker Jr. to leave as White House chief of staff reflects his belief that President Reagan's major initiatives have been completed and that the Administration's final seven months will be largely a caretaker operation, Mr. Baker's friends and associates said today.

title: ATI Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
GREEN ISSUES FIRST REPORT ON SCHOOLS
description: In an eagerly awaited report on his first 100 days as New York City's Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green yesterday set goals for the troubled school system, sounding many of the themes he has already raised.

title: A Welcome Festival
description: The First New York Festival of the Arts is off and running, singing, dancing, acting and rolling film as energetically as its founder, Martin Segal, envisioned 11 years ago. For a whole month through July 11, the performing arts of the 20th century will be on view in 60 places around the city. Some 4,000 artists from 32 nations are participating in 350 events.

title: Canada Is Holding a Suspect In Spying on U.S. Navy Base
description: A Canadian arrested last week on espionage charges was involved in an attempt to spy on a United States Navy installation in Newfoundland that monitors the movements of Soviet nuclear submarines, according to Canadian officials involved in the arrest.

title: Pursuing Landlocked Salmon
description: THE landlocked salmon is an Apollo among fish.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M.

title: Metro Matters; Going Global: New York Fights To Stay on Top
description: Manhattan, by one economist's count, has more word processors than Western Europe. Yet the New York region's role in the emerging global economy may depend as much on its ability to deal collectively with common problems as on the surge in information and other services it exports.

title: Spread of AIDS Virus Found Slowing Among Drug Users in 3 Cities
description: The spread of the AIDS virus has slowed among intravenous drug users in three cities, including New York, according to a report here today at the fourth international conference on AIDS.

title: Sports People; Barkley Safe
description: Charles Barkley can expect to be back in Philadelphia with the 76ers next season Harold Katz, the team owner, said yesterday.

title: Inflation Rises in France
description: Inflation in France rose between two-tenths and three-tenths of a percent in May, compared with the previous month, according to provisional figures released today by the National Statistics Institute. Since January, prices have risen 1.4 percent. In the last 12 months, they have risen 2.5 percent to 2.6 percent. In April, inflation was five-tenths of a percent and in March it was three-tenths of a percent, the institute said.

title: Health: Personal Health
description: As summer approaches and the sun shines brightly on barely clothed bodies, the toll that sunlight has taken on unprotected skin through the years becomes more obvious. The fine wrinkles on your face, the liverlike patches on your arms and legs, perhaps even some rough, scaly spots on your nose or hands are all signs of ''photoaging,'' the damage done by repeated exposure to ultraviolet radiation.

title: Dismissal of Gay C.I.A. Worker Is Subject to Review, Court Holds
description: Rejecting the Reagan Administration's view, the Supreme Court ruled today that courts may review the constitutionality of the Central Intelligence Agency's dismissal of employees.

title: Allegheny Calls Talk Welcome
description: Officers of Allegheny International Inc. said yesterday that any interest in the company by Victor Kiam, the chairman of Remington Products Inc., reflected positively on their efforts to submit a reorganization plan in their Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding.

title: PENTAGON INQUIRY HEARS OF PAYOFFS FROM CONTRACTORS
description: A major Federal investigation of bribery at the Pentagon centers on allegations that Defense Department procurement officials accepted payoffs from military contractors and their consultants in exchange for confidential information on Government contracts, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Stenciling Goes 3-D
description: TROMPE l'oeil is not solely the province of artists. With the stencils of Vladimir Rozenshtein, above, people who barely know how to open a bucket of paint can design faux plaster moldings on bare walls.

title: Birdfinder Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Ballet; The Danes in a Joyous Fairy Tale
description: Superlatives come easily and honestly in talking about August Bournonville's ''Napoli.'' This may well be the most exuberant ballet ever choreographed, the sunniest work in the repertory.

title: Devoted To Design In London
description: IN 1981 Sir Terence Conran, the retailer, designer and author, created the Conran Foundation, an educational charity that, in turn, ran the Boilerhouse Project, a series of design shows at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London from 1981 to 1986.

title: The Do's and Don't's Of Agency Acquisitions
description: Mergers and acquisitions must be among the favorite topics of conversation for agency executives.

title: Yachting; Record Set for Trans-Atlantic Crossing
description: Philippe Poupon spends his life racing high-tech multihull yachts that look more like floating trampolines than boats. But even he couldn't have predicted the outcome of the Carlsberg Single-Handed Trans-Atlantic Race.

title: American Ballet Theater Is to Perform in Paris
description: American Ballet Theater is to perform at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in Paris in October. The two-week engagement marks the company's first European season in 11 years. Ballet Theater is to perform from Oct. 18 to 23 as part of the Festival International de Danse de Paris, which is sponsored by the city government of Paris.

title: In a Small Southern Town, a Church And Child Welfare Officials Do Battle
description: For the last week a red brick courthouse in this southeastern Mississippi town has been the scene of a dramatic confrontation between state welfare officials and a home for troubled children.

title: Alice May Hall, 96, Longtime Puppeteer
description: Alice May Hall, a noted puppeteer during a career spanning more than 70 years, died Monday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 96 years old, and had given her final performances just last weekend.

title: Mexican Seeks Right to Take Sides
description: As a Roman Catholic priest, Domingo Arteaga Castaneda has grudgingly learned to live with provisions of the Mexican Constitution prohibiting him from voting or holding public office. But when he saw the country's new electoral code, he decided the Government had gone too far.

title: Wiley, John & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Writedowns and additional charges for on-going reorganization in fiscal 1988, largely associated with the company's training operation, Wilson Learning Group, reduced results by $2.9 million. In fiscal 1987 a restructuring charge had reduced earnings by $5.4 million, and there had been a one-time after- tax gain of $1.1 million from the sale of land.

title: Schwartz Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $154,814, or 9 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle. All share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective June 4, 1987. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the change in the company's method of determining inventory cost.

title: Health: Medical Technology; Test Device Raises Hope of Keeping Organs Alive Longer for Transplant
description: A team of California scientists has invented a device that may pave the way for vastly extending the time that human hearts, livers, kidneys and other transplantable organs can be kept alive once they are removed from human donors.

title: Guild Ratifies a 6-Year Pact With The Times, 652 to 118
description: Members of the New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York ratified a six-year contract with the newspaper yesterday by a vote of 652 to 118.

title: Columnist Feels Justified in Shooting Youth
description: Carl T. Rowan writes in his syndicated column for Thursday that as long as society is ''awash in guns and drugs,'' he feels justified in using a gun to protect his home and family.

title: Zia Decrees the Islamic Code Is Supreme Law of Pakistan
description: The President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, decreed today that the Islamic legal code, known as sharia, would be the supreme law in Pakistan.

title: General Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Rio Journal; When the Bourgeois Dream, It's of Headier Days
description: Carmelene Pereira took her three children out of private school after fees doubled between January and April, while Maura Cardoso started ordering her clothes from a seamstress when boutique prices rocketed out of reach.

title: 10 States Join Liability Suits
description: Leading United States insurers conspired to stop providing some kinds of liability coverage, touching off a nationwide insurance crisis, 10 states have charged in lawsuits that echo earlier suits.

title: LIVE AT THE SANCTUARY: THE PHIL DONAHUE SHOW
description: Even for the ''Donahue'' show, which has considered topics as sensational as voodoo and women who kill their babies, it was a noteworthy spectacle: Phil Donahue in a black church in the heart of Bedford-Stuyvesant, a bused-in studio audience in tow, arguing about the case of Tawana Brawley.

title: Vials on Two Beaches In Jersey Tied to AIDS
description: Five vials with congealed human blood were among the waste picked up from beaches June 3 and 4, and two samples contained the HIV antibody, a sign of exposure to the AIDS virus, the State Health Department has said.

title: Francis M. Greene Jr., Investment Executive, 54
description: Francis Martin Greene Jr., an investment adviser, died Sunday in an automobile accident near East Johnsburg, N.Y. He was 54 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Pentagon Favors Drug Testing in Military Plants
description: Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci said today that he planned to require private companies doing business with the Pentagon to insure that their employees do not use illegal drugs, in some cases by testing civilian employees.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Canadian Edge
description: As Canadian and American lawmakers weigh approval of an agreement to wipe out trade barriers between the two countries over 10 years, American companies apparently are less prepared than their Canadian counterparts to take advantage of any new business opportunities.

title: Allied Stores, in a Reversal, Will Sell Ann Taylor Chain
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, which with the Federated Department Stores Company is owned by the Campeau Corporation, said yesterday that it intended to sell the Ann Taylor fashion specialty stores.

title: 'Angels' Detain Suspect for Arrest by Police
description: Continuing their patrols in midtown Manhattan, the Guardian Angels yesterday detained a man they said was a drug dealer and held him for arrest by the police.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Democracy means you have the freedom to do unwise things as well as wise things.'' - Abba Eban, passed over by the Labor Party for candidacy to the Israeli Parliament. [ A11:1. ]

title: James Stewart's New Role: Lobbyist
description: Almost 50 years ago, James Stewart, as the idealistic hero of ''Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' came to the capital to battle corruption. Today Mr. Stewart came to Washington to perform a real-life role, that of a lobbyist for the protection of classic American movies against those who would color them, re-edit them or even superimpose new faces on old actors.

title: U.S. Charges Ex-School Official In Jersey City Corruption Inquiry
description: A former director of school maintenance in Jersey City was indicted today on extortion and income-tax evasion charges as part of a Federal inquiry into corruption in that city's school system.

title: Murray Ohio Filing On Electrolux Bid
description: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company said it would like to investigate a sweetened bid by the Swedish consumer products giant A. B. Electrolux, although it cautioned that its board ''has not decided that the company should be sold.'' Murray Ohio has already rejected a sweetened $52-a-share offer, or about $197 million, from Electrolux.

title: Solid Lead in Heptathlon
description: Despite a painful knee injury, Jane Frederick of Santa Barbara, Calif., took an impressive lead in the heptathlon today as the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships began.

title: Jay Jacobs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ex-Prosecutor Is Sentenced on Tax Charges
description: A former Federal prosecutor was ordered yesterday to perform 300 hours of community service for failing to file income-tax returns for three years.

title: Hach Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Regine Kronacker Stix, Physician, 92
description: Dr. Regine Kronacker Stix, a physician and former chief of secondary-school health services in New York City, died of a heart attack Monday at Brookside House on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. She was 92 years old and lived in Chilmark on the island.

title: France and Iran Restoring Diplomatic Ties Today
description: After 11 months of confrontation, hostility and secret negotiations, France and Iran announced today that they would re-establish diplomatic relations on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday describing the origins of the partition of Korea gave an incorrect figure for American military strength in Korea in some copies. There are about 40,000 American military personnel there.

title: Sports People; Seeking Solution
description: Bill Cayton, manager of Mike Tyson, and Bob Lee, president of the International Boxing Federation, made no progress yesterday in a meeting aimed at resolving their differences on the length of Tyson's June 27 heavyweight title bout against Michael Spinks. Cayton wants the fight to be 12 rounds; Lee wants it to be 15. Both sides agreed to meet again on Monday in New York. Yesterday's meeting was held at the I.B.F. offices in Newark.

title: Reviews/Music; A Star of Be-bop Saxophone
description: Jackie McLean, the legendary be-bop alto saxophonist, came to the Studio Museum in Harlem on Friday night and gave a perfect performance. Mr. McLean, now the chairman of the African-American music department at Hartt School of Music in Hartford, rarely plays in New York. This is a shame, not only because he is playing as well as at any time in his career, but also because his acrid, romantic tone is a reminder that the jazz process demands an individual sound.

title: Gypsy-Cabby Is Fatally Shot In Apparent Robbery in Bronx
description: A gypsy-cab driver was shot and killed in the Bronx early yesterday in what was apparently a robbery, the police said.

title: U.S. Official Denies Cover-Up Of Drug Inquiry at Arms Lab
description: Federal officials ended an investigation into suspected drug trafficking at a nuclear weapon laboratory ''because it had run for eight months and was apparently not uncovering new productive leads,'' an Under Secretary of Energy testified today.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Centerre Merger Set With Boatmen's Bank
description: LEAD: Less than two months after agreeing to merge with another St. Louis bank holding company, Centerre Bancorporation Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by Boatmen's Bancshares Inc., also of St. Louis, for stock worth about $467 million, or $60 a share.

title: Budget Woes Challenging Image of an Able Dukakis
description: Growing state budget problems are raising questions about Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's campaign assertions of managerial prowess and are forcing him to consider how to raise money in ways that will not be viewed as tax increases.

title: Recycling Means Trash at Home, at Work, at the Lunch Counter
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncertainty Rewarded
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Is Charged In Fatal Attack In Connecticut
description: A 29-year-old man being held in a Westchester County jail in an unrelated burglary was charged today with the murder of a New Canaan woman in the Bloomingdale's parking garage here on June 6, the police said.

title: Head of Texas College Ousted
description: The president of Southwest Texas State University has been discharged amid charges of financial extravagance despite the support from faculty, students, parents and local residents.

title: WTD Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Senate Urges Talks on Loans
description: The Senate, in a nonbinding resolution, called on President Reagan today to consult other leaders at the Toronto economic summit talks on the impact on Western security of bank loans to the Soviet Union.

title: Lowrance Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Net income

title: Vertex Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax benefit reversal of $25,400. c-Net income and after a gain of $150,865 on the termination of a retirement plan and a tax benefit of $65,000.

title: Garbage In, Garbage Out
description: ''A Marked Bias Against Israel,'' the headline said. It was on a column last month by Jeane Kirkpatrick, the former U.S. delegate to the United Nations.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday on the resignation of Howard H. Baker Jr. as White House chief of staff misstated his status in the Senate's Watergate hearings in some copies. He was the ranking Republican minority member.

title: F.B.I. Links McDonnell to Bribe Plan
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and at least one former senior official of the Navy have been linked to a scheme to bribe Pentagon officials involved in contracts, according to a detailed written statement by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Baseball; Tigers' Robinson Stops Orioles, 1-0
description: Jeff Robinson pitched a five-hitter to win his seventh consecutive game tonight, and Dave Bergman hit a sacrifice fly to lead the Detroit Tigers past the Baltimore Orioles, 1-0.

title: Braniff Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest quarter include the operating figures of Braniff's newly acquired Florida Express Inc. unit for the period from April 20 through April 30, 1988.

title: U.S. Report Endorses More Cable Competition
description: The nation's cable television industry is increasingly being controlled by a few large companies, the Reagan Administration said today in a report recommending that Government regulations be relaxed to foster competition.

title: Stock Continue Climb as Dow Gains 6.93
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 6.93 points, closing at 2,131.40.

title: Jailhouse Rockers
description: MOST people buy rustic hickory furniture from stores. A few commission it from craftsmen. In Indiana you can also buy hickory-and-rattan chairs, beds and old-fashioned swings at a prison, the Indiana State Farm in Putnamville, 40 miles southwest of Indianapolis.

title: Wedtech Tried For Bush's Aid, Official Testifies
description: Wedtech Corporation executives contributed $200,000 to Ronald Reagan's 1984 Presidential campaign and met Vice President Bush in hopes of obtaining assistance in winning a Navy contract, a former Wedtech official has testified.

title: Cimco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes $344,000 due to a change in the method of accounting for deferred income taxes which retroactively increased first quarter earnings.

title: Satellite's Launching A First for Entrepreneur
description: An international telecommunications satellite was successfully launched yesterday for the Pan American Satellite Corporation, based in Greenwich, Conn., but Rene Anselmo, the company's chairman, was not in French Guiana to see the event in person.

title: New Pieces, New Looks For the Office
description: The gold leaf on the Louis XIV walls seemed to shimmy to the vibrations of the Peter Duchin orchestra Monday night, as the backbone of America's office furniture industry gathered in the ballroom of the Hilton Hotel to fete the 20th anniversary of Neocon, the industry's annual spring market.

title: A Prison Barge on Hudson: 'Folly' or 'Ideal'
description: Greenwich Village residents - and the politicians who represent them - are up in arms over New York City's plans to move its prison barge to a Hudson River pier at the edge of their neighborhood.

title: Sports People; Charitable Gesture
description: Larry Bird, a fierce rival of Magic Johnson on the basketball court, said yesterday he wants to carry that competition into the world of philanthropy. The two will be playing on the same team, however, in the Larry Bird Pro All-Star Scholarship Classic, a June 26 game in Indianapolis to benefit disadvantaged students who want to attend Indiana colleges.

title: Events: A Nature Walk, Crafts and Memorabilia
description: By the Seashore, City of New York Parks and Recreation Department; 212-548-7070.

title: Energy Spending Bill Passes
description: The Senate today passed its0first major spending bill for the 1989 fiscal year, an $18.05 billion energy and water development package that includes money to study a huge atom-smasher project.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Korean Slowdown Seen
description: South Korea's economic growth rate in the second quarter is expected to fall to 9 percent from 15.6 percent a year earlier, mainly because of labor disputes over wages, the Economic Planning Board said today. The projected rate would be the lowest in three years. The figure for the January-March quarter was 15.1 percent. The board said that industrial production, which rose 20.9 percent in the first quarter, would rise only 10 percent in the second quarter.

title: Weimar's Bold and Colorful Ceramics
description: Spray guns and stencils dramatically transformed mass-produced cake platters, tea sets and chocolate pots in Germany 60 years ago. The moderately priced Art Deco tableware that resulted - boldly striped and rainbow hued - was all the rage throughout Central Europe. Its popularity is easily understood after a visit to the exhibition ''Ceramics of the Weimar Republic, 1919-1933'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue and 91st Street.

title: Let's Invest in the Prevention of Heart Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene Technique Used to Correct Liver Defect
description: Scientists have corrected a serious genetic defect in liver cells in a laboratory experiment they described as an important first step toward a form of human gene therapy.

title: Beauty Contestant Denounces the 'Indignities'
description: A beauty contestant who pulled a protest banner from her bra in the middle of the Miss California pageant Monday says she plotted the disruption for a year and a half.

title: Museums as Architectual Showpieces
description: ASK an architect what he would most like to design, and the probable answer is a museum. ''Everything else being equal, a museum is the one large institutional client that you expect to be most sympathetic to the idea of architecture as art,'' said Steven Izenour, a partner in the Venturi, Rauch & Scott Brown architectural firm in Philadelphia.

title: REBEL ARCHBISHOP THREATENS SCHISM
description: Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre announced today that he would consecrate four bishops on June 30 without papal authority. The action threatens the first formal split in the Roman Catholic Church in 118 years.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Stores Co., Salt Lake City, said it expected its earnings for the rest of 1988 to decline because of its $2.5 billion purchase of Lucky Stores Inc., Dublin, Calif.

title: ABRAMS CONSIDERS A POSSIBLE HOAX IN BRAWLEY CASE
description: Saying he was now investigating the possibility of a hoax by Tawana Brawley's advisers, Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, announced yesterday that he had subpoenaed a former associate of the advisers who had publicly called the family's story a fabrication.

title: Court Reaffirms Interrogation Limits
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that once an arrested suspect says he wants to talk to a lawyer before answering questions, the police may not question him even about an unrelated crime.

title: Tennis Anytime? Maybe Not
description: Machines that serve up tennis balls would be relegated to the status of lawn mowers and bulldozers under a noise ordinance tentatively approved in this community, which once tried to make it illegal for men to run topless.

title: INSIDE
description: Bomb at Ulster Race Kills 5

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; World Bank Raise
description: Although Congress has not ratified a big increase in the resources of the World Bank, the rise in financing for the organization that lends money to third-world nations has taken effect because nations with more than 75 percent of the voting shares have assented.

title: Review/Television; Lawyers, Guns and Money in Miami
description: Clinton is a wiry little guy with a permanent 5 o'clock shadow. If there were a contest for the nation's hairiest torso, Clinton would just possibly beat out Robin Williams. He's a smuggler by trade, making frequent trips to Mexico. No, not drugs. Clinton deals in exotic birds. Nadine is a call girl. She has a son who is about to reach his first birthday. Raised in Florida, she was Miss Frost-Proof 1979 and had ambitions to become a singer. She meets Clinton when he finds her purse in his brother's house in Jacksonville. The brother has been murdered, and Clinton has stumbled across a gang of vicious Latinos looking for an audio cassette. Giving Nadine a lift in his dumpy, gas-guzzling Cadillac, Clinton heads for Miami.

title: Judge Rules Capasso Violated Court Order
description: Carl A. Capasso, the imprisoned companion of Bess Myerson. was found in contempt of court yesterday for allowing her to remove items from his wife's Westhampton Beach house.

title: Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Fit for Dignitaries, Blair House Reopens Its Stately Doors
description: Abraham Lincoln was a frequent visitor, Harry and Bess Truman lived there twice, and an array of emperors, kings, queens and heads of state have stayed awhile. Without a doubt, Blair House is the country's most exclusive guest house.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Georgetown University is offering $80 million of taxable exchangeable bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The financing marks the first time the university has entered the public debt market and the first such offering of exchangeable bonds.

title: Blast at Race in Ulster Kills 6 British Soldiers
description: A bomb exploded in a crowd gathered for the end of a foot race tonight, killing six British soldiers and wounding at least 10 civilians, the police said.

title: Credithrift Notes
description: The Credithrift Financial Corporation, a unit of the American General Corporation, is offering $300 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.961, to yield 8.64 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes are priced to yield 66-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity and are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Oppenheimer Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Endowment Chairman Addresses Library Cuts
description: Lynne V. Cheney, chairman of the National Endowment of the Humanities in Washington, took the Government's case to the New York Public Library yesterday, not long after the agency indicated that it would cut the library's funds substantially in 1989.

title: AS HOME FOR BABIES BURNED, A CELEBRATION
description: A key prosecution witness testified yesterday that shortly after a house planned for foster-care babies in Queens was set on fire, three neighbors on trial in the case drank liquor across the street from the house and that one raised her glass in a toast as the house burned.

title: Giuliani Pressuring Cuomo for the Ouster Of Bronx Prosecutor
description: United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday called on Governor Cuomo to remove Bronx District Attorney Paul T. Gentile from office, and the Governor responded with a broad hint that Mr. Gentile should step aside.

title: Judge Rules Belzbergs Hid Ashland Stake
description: A Federal judge ruled today that Marc Belzberg, of the wealthy Belzberg family of Canada, deliberately concealed purchases of Ashland Oil stock.

title: Sports People; Treated Unfairly
description: Joaquin Andujar of the Houston Astros said yesterday that baseball officials singled him out unfairly for throwing inside and he renewed his threat to retire rather than pitch tomorrow night.

title: Faster Computers: Race Is On
description: The race to create ever-faster computers has spawned almost two dozen small high-tech companies that are exploiting breakthroughs in software programming and hardware design to create radically different computers.

title: Grain Prices Surging on Drought News
description: As hot, dry weather continued to bake much of the nation's prime farmland, soybean and grain traders in Chicago bid up prices by the daily permissible limits, leaving huge pools of unsatisfied buy orders at the close.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: HONG KONG TO BAR NEW BOAT PEOPLE
description: Hong Kong announced today that newly arriving Vietnamese boat people who could not prove they fled religious or political persecution would be incarcerated as illegal aliens until they could be returned to Vietnam.

title: Savings Rule Is Extended
description: The Senate today extended a rule preventing healthy savings and loan institutions from leaving their deposit insurance system in favor of the much stronger system that insures commercial banks.

title: Pico Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: EBAN WITHDRAWS IN PARLIAMENT RACE
description: The veteran Israeli politician Abba Eban dropped out of parliamentary elections tonight after the Labor Party failed to elect him among its top 20 candidates.

title: Review/Theater; Tadeusz Kantor's Intimations of God and Death
description: Those of us who are hard pressed to remember our dreams can only wonder at Tadeusz Kantor's gift for making his own dreams into art. Mr. Kantor, the Polish director of Cracow's Cricot 2 Theater Company, dreams big: In his subconscious, the conventional memories of a village childhood - early intimations of God, sex and death - intermingle with the specters of a Holocaustal history. How does one put a canvas of that size and idiosyncratic tilt on stage? Mr. Kantor, as much artist and choreographer as playwright and director, boils it all down to a ragtag troupe of wandering actors, a few poor wood and metal props and some churning snatches of music culled equally from tango palaces, Chopin and the death camps.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The sliding glass door to my patio is made of double-pane insulating glass. Moisture seems to have got between the panes, clouding the view. Short of replacing the whole door, can I remedy this?

title: Judge Retains 400 Charges For the Trial of Ohrenstein
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday refused to dismiss nearly 400 counts of a grand larceny and fraud indictment that charged the State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, and other Senate officials with using public money to pay full-time campaign workers who performed no tasks for the Legislature.

title: Review/Books; U.S. Sanitizing of Nazis To Help Space Program
description: Blowback America's Recruitment of Nazis and Its Effects on the Cold War. By Christopher Simpson Illustrated. 398 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. 19.95.

title: Remove Old Wood Finish Carefully
description: LEAD: AS messy and time-consuming as the job is, there's nothing difficult in removing old finish from furniture. But upholstery complicates the task.

title: Falcon Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Words From a 'Veteran'
description: To The Home Section:

title: Israeli Inflation Shrinks
description: Israel said today that its rate of inflation was 1.2 percent in May, down from 2.7 percent in April. The May increase brings the rate of inflation for the last 12 months to 16.9 percent. The Central Bureau of Statistics said the increase was mainly caused by food prices.

title: Durfee Leaves Solow, Who Joins Biederman
description: James Durfee and Martin Solow, both former agency heads, came together in 1981 to found Durfee & Solow Advertising. Now Mr. Durfee is going his own way, and his partner is moving the agency in with Biederman & Company.

title: Washingtion Talk: Volunteer Organizations; Yes, the Peace Corps Is Alive and Full of Vigor
description: ''The Peace Corps, is it still around?'' people ask Loret Miller Ruppe, who has been its leader since 1981, longer than anyone else.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Out of the Lobby
description: In a city obsessed with image and nuance, political events have a way of changing even the language. Take the word ''lobbyist.'' One of that breed, Morris Amitay, the pro-Israeli lobbyist and former executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, said in remarks to a meeting of B'nai B'rith International on Tuesday that the bad publicity associated with such lobbyists as Michael K. Deaver and Lynn Nofziger had prompted him to pick a new name for his calling.

title: ONE ATHLETE WHO GOT AWAY
description: DARNELL DICKERSON said yes, he knew about the difficulty some coaches had in fielding Little League teams on the east side of Detroit because some kids make so much money selling crack and cocaine on the streets - as much as $200 a day - that they don't have time for baseball.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about the Bryant Park restoration plan described action taken by the New York City Art Commission incompletely.

title: METRO BOWL TO CHRIST THE KING
description: Whenever Ken Marchisella, the baseball coach at Christ the King High School, needs a big victory he knows he can usually count on somebody named Joe. Yesterday it was Joe Colombo, his senior left fielder, who had two key hits and a game-saving catch as the Catholic school champions beat Benjamin Cardozo, the public school champions, 4-2, in the Metro Bowl at Yankee Stadium.

title: Soviet Conductor Quits Philharmonic Concert
description: Gennady Rozhdestvensky, the Soviet conductor who was scheduled to lead the New York Philharmonic in a special concert tonight at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, has withdrawn, the orchestra has announced. His wife, Viktoriya Postnikova, who was to have been the piano soloist for the concert, has also withdrawn.

title: Diversified Foods reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Soybean Prices Go Still Higher
description: Soybean and corn prices soared further yesterday as one of the worst dry spells of the century continued to shrivel crops and create bottlenecks on the Mississippi River, the major transport artery for most of the nation's oilseeds and feed grains.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Security Council Meets at 11:30 A.M. on pending execution by South Africa of ''Sharpeville Six''

title: Southern Baptists Condemn Homosexuality as 'Depraved'
description: Delegates to the Southern Baptist Convention today condemned homosexuality as ''a manifestation of a depraved nature'' and ''a perversion of divine standards.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The grass just never turned green out here.'' - Arthur Buen, a 59-year-old rancher from Nashua, Mont. [ A15:4. ]

title: Harry E. Mattin, 92, Chemist and Executive
description: Harry E. Mattin, a chemist, businessman and philanthropist, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 92 years old.

title: GENTILE SEEKS MEESE INQUIRY INTO DISPUTE
description: Trying to take the dispute over his Bronx Democratic primary to Washington, District Attorney Paul T. Gentile yesterday called for the Justice Department to investigate the handling by prosecutors and news organizations of confidential Federal files on his opponent, Philip F. Foglia.

title: Curb Is Added to Bill on Arts Spending
description: The House Appropriations Committee took the unusual step of including a spending limitation in the bill it approved by voice vote today to appropriate $169 million for the National Endowment for the Arts and $153.7 million for the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Sports People; 2 Views of Mack Lobell
description: The owner and driver of Mack Lobell, the 1987 harness racing horse of the year, differ sharply in outlook on their prospects for the $100,000 mile-and-an-eighth Statue of Liberty trot tomorrow night at the Meadowlands.

title: The Arts Festival; The Shock of the New: East Village World's Fair
description: GRASS-ROOTS culture. That's the term Mark Russell, the director of Performance Space 122, the flourishing seedbed of experimental performance art at First Avenue and Ninth Street, uses to describe the variety of work that can be seen at the East Village World's Fair during the next three weeks.

title: Pension Panel Silent on Talks
description: Members of the Pension and Financial Managers Advisory Committee, an advisory panel to the New York Stock Exchange, met for most of the day yesterday but declined to disclose details of the discussions.

title: A Dry Decade at a Glance
description: Except for 1982, this has been a dry decade in much of America. 1980 - Hot and dry summer weather, with rainfall between 25 percent and 50 percent of normal across much of the nation. Heat wave blamed for as many as 1,200 deaths and crop and livestock damage estimated at $20 billion. 1981 - Drought retained grip on much of the nation. Rains in some farm areas in May; abnormally dry weather in northern Great Plains, Southeast and Middle Atlantic states. 1982 - No extensive areas of drought as cool Canadian air helped produce active rain fronts most of the summer. 1983 - Searing heat in July and August, with severe drought east of the Rockies, similar to 1980 but centered slightly farther north, in the western corn belt states. Corn and soybean crops severely damaged. Dryness extended to the Middle-Atlantic States. Less than one-quarter of normal rainfall in parts of Texas, Kansas, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Missouri, Iowa and Illinois. 1984 - More than $1 billion in wheat crops damaged in Montana and North Dakota when rainfall was only one-third of normal in the first half of the year. Many brush fires. Persistent dryness damaged crops and grasslands in central Texas. 1985 - Dry conditions led to serious brush and forest fires in California, the northern Rockies and Northern Plains. 1986 - The Southeast sweltered under dry conditions that began the previous autumn. Virginia, the Carolinas, Georgia, Alabama and Tennessee suffer a drought described as the worst in more than a century; less than one-quarter the normal rain in some areas. Some relief from August rains for soybean crops, but it was too late for hay and corn. Regional damage estimates topped $1 billion. 1987 - Forest fires scorched more than two million acres in Idaho, Washington, Oregon and California. Water shortages in Spokane and some other communities. Hot, dry conditions in July and August also contributed to drought conditions in the Southeast, reducing crop yields sharply. After heavy rains in September, excessively dry conditions returned to the Southeast in October and November, particularly in West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amfac Inc., San Francisco, a distributor of electrical and industrial supplies, said it would sell to Oxoco Inc. the plumbing, pipe valve and fitting, heating, ventilating and air-conditioning segments of its Amfac Supply division for about $56 million.

title: Merc-Comex Talks Snagged
description: In a new twist in merger talks between New York's two largest futures exchanges, directors of the New York Mercantile Exchange decided late Wednesday to bypass a comprehensive merger plan and to make a more limited proposal to the Commodity Exchange.

title: Lilco Chairman And Governor Sign Agreement
description: Governor Cuomo today signed the agreement between his negotiators and the Long Island Lighting Company to abandon the utility's $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power station.

title: Sports People; Kriek and Curren Fined
description: Johan Kriek and Kevin Curren of the United States were fined $900 each yesterday for racquet abuse and using profanity during defeats at a grass-court tournament in West Kirby, England.

title: PENTAGON INQUIRY IS SAID TO INCLUDE 3 CONGRESS OFFICES
description: The offices of at least three members of the House of Representatives, including one from New York, have been placed under investigation as part of a Federal bribery inquiry involving Pentagon aides and some of the nation's largest military contractors, a Justice Department official and other legal sources familiar with the inquiry said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY CHILD'S PLAY

title: DISCUS THROWERS FALL SHORT ON YOUTH
description: Mac Wilkins, the 1976 Olympic champion, is unhappy with the state of American discus-throwing. Part of it seems to be that at age 37, he has a solid chance to make the United States Olympic team, which means young talent, or talent of any age, is lacking.

title: Pakistani Women Take Lead In Drive Against Islamization
description: A judicial panel of Islamic scholars heard arguments last week about Pakistani laws that accord the legal testimony of women half the weight of the testimony of men.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Thompson Gets Work For Naugles/Del Taco
description: J. Walter Thompson, Los Angeles, part of Britain's WPP Group, has been named the agency for the Naugles/Del Taco chain of Mexican-food restaurants, which is expected to spend $8 million to $10 million on advertising.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 429 money market mutual funds decreased by $2.45 billion, to $264.80 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 118 institutional funds decreased by $450.3 million, to $70.16 billion. The assets of the 214 general purpose funds were down by $1.636 billion, to $81.31 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds fell by $371.5 million, to $113.33 billion, the Washington-based organization said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Soviet errors and misjudgments led to the Kremlin's 1979 military intervention in Afghanistan, according to people familiar with a secret document issued by the Soviet Communist Party leadership. Page A1

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; All About Jackson
description: Elizabeth L. Colton, who was Jesse Jackson's press secretary from January to April, has just landed a six-digit contract with Doubleday for a book she is writing, ''Behind the Jackson Campaign - The Man, The Power and The Myth.''

title: Untangling One Consultant's Web of Industry and Pentagon Contacts
description: Like many in the defense business, Melvyn R. Paisley, the consultant and former senior Navy official at the center of a Federal investigation of bribery and fraud in military contracting, has relied on a web of personal and professional contacts in moving between industry and the Pentagon.

title: Article Links Congressman to Racketeering
description: Representative Pat Swindall of Georgia pursued an $850,000 loan after being told that it might be financed with drug money that he would be helping to launder, a published report said today.

title: The Arts Festival; Central Park Stage Series Opens Today
description: One of New York's newest summertime traditions, the Summerstage performing-arts series, begins its third season at the Central Park Band Shell tonight. The festival will include 39 free outdoor concerts and other performances, primarily on Friday nights and Saturday and Sunday afternoons, and will continue through Sept. 4.

title: Phillips Petroleum
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company adopted a new employee benefit plan that is expected to increase employee ownership of the company and to improve the company's financing. The new leveraged employee stock ownership plan will begin July 1. The plan will borrow about $250 million, with a guarantee from Phillips, to buy shares of common stock from the company, a Phillips spokesman, Dan Harrison, said. The proceeds from the sale of the stock will be used to retire existing company debt, Mr. Harrison said.

title: Cineplex Odeon Stake Is Raised
description: The Canadian billionaire Charles R. Bronfman reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had increased his stake in the Cineplex Odeon Corporation to 11.83 percent from 8.72 percent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Units to Merge
description: Two more of Saatchi & Saatchi's operations have agreed to merge. The West Coast office of AC&R/DHB & Bess is merging with Cochrane Chase, Livingston, to form AC&R/ CCL. Lynn Livingston will be president and chief operating officer of the $100 million operation. Saatchi & Saatchi is a publicly held British holding company.

title: Market Place; A Difficult Day For SmithKline
description: THE SmithKline Beckman Corporation surprised shareholders with bad news yesterday, and many of them promptly began selling.

title: Shultz Says the U.S. Might Move 2 Bases From the Philippines
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned today that the United States might have to find other sites for its strategic air and naval bases in the Philippines if Filipino officials and politicians set what he termed unacceptable conditions on the American presence there.

title: Cananea Journal; For Sale: Symbol of Nationalism; Inquire Within
description: Eighty-two years ago this month, a violent strike here helped ignite the Mexican revolution. Now this small mining town is again making history and generating a passionate debate about Mexico's economic and political course.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on May 27 about the graduation at the City University of New York Law School at Queens College incompletely described the origin of the Communist anthem, the ''Internationale.'' The words were written in 1871 by the revolutionary Eugene Pottier, but the music was not written until 1888, when Pierre Degeyter adapted Pottier's poem.

title: GATT Oilseed Inquiry
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed today to investigate American charges that government aid to European producers of oilseeds and similar animal feed violates international trade rules. A panel of experts will see if the 12-nation European Community's subsidies are illegally cutting into United States soybean exports to Western Europe.

title: New Law on Hazardous Materials Will Protect New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Tyler Journal; Hippies Find a Way in a Texas Court
description: The Rainbow Family, a group of thousands of self-described hippies, plans to camp in the forests of East Texas over the July Fourth weekend and worship nature. The United States Forest Service does not like that idea, saying that in past years the group's gatherings have threatened public safety, causing a national outbreak of dysentery last year.

title: SMALL-TOWN FEELING IN WORLD CUP RACE
description: On Sunday, the residents of Manayunk will greet about 100 of the best professional cyclists in the world by throwing water in their faces.

title: Nova to Buy Polysar After 5-Month Quest
description: The Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation, the large Toronto-based petrochemical company, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Nova Corporation of Alberta for a package of cash and stock the company estimated to be worth $20.50 (Canadian) a share, or a total of $1.91 billion.

title: ESTONIANS REALIGN PARTY LEADERSHIP
description: The Estonian Communist Party leader was removed from his post today after two months of rising Estonian nationalism, including calls for economic and political autonomy.

title: Player Makes Obvious Choice
description: Gary Player of South Africa had two choices about where to play golf this week and he picked the obvious.

title: Boston Plan Attacks Bias in Housing
description: After months of negotiation, city and Federal officials here have agreed on a plan to end racial discrimination in Boston's system for selecting tenants for public housing.

title: Review/Film; 'A World Apart,' About South Africa
description: The title ''A World Apart,'' refers to several things, including the insulated world of South Africa's white minority for whom each commonplace gesture of daily life becomes an act of overbearing political significance, an affirmation of the minority's own God-given (and Government-decreed) superiority. White South Africans don't ignore the members of the black majority, yet somehow they don't see them.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday about calligraphers gave an incorrect telephone number for Barry Craig Morentz. It is 212-477-0198. A picture caption on the front page of the section also misidentified Mr. Morentz's script. It is Gothicized Italic.

title: Rental Agencies Would Pay For Car Damage Under Plan
description: Insurance commissioners from 50 states are expected to endorse legislation requiring that car-rental companies, rather than consumers, be responsible for paying for repairs to damaged rental cars.

title: 1 Dead, 18 Hurt in Pileup
description: One driver was killed and 18 people were injured early this morning when nine vehicles piled up in a series of accidents on Interstate 10 north of here. The vehicles, five of which were 18-wheel tractor-trailer rigs, crashed after dense smoke from a nearby woods fire had reduced visibility on the highway. Ten of the 18 injured were hospitalized.

title: Dow Plunges By 37.16 in Broad Selloff
description: LEAD: Stock prices retreated sharply yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 37.16 points to close at 2,094.24.

title: Minister Out on Bail
description: The Rev. Herman Fountain, the Baptist minister who runs a children's home that the state ordered shut down, was released on $40,000 bail Wednesday on charges of assaulting a police officer. The state shut down the Bethel Home for Children, operated by Mr. Fountain's independent Baptist group, on June 10 when a judge ruled its residents had been subjected to ''physical abuse, medical neglect and detention amounting to imprisonment.''

title: Violence Breaks Out at 2 Brooklyn Schools
description: Violence erupted at two Brooklyn schools yesterday, as fighting between groups of students leaving for the summer escalated into rioting and two girls were shot.

title: 12 Years After Soweto, Pain Goes On
description: On June 16, 1976, Poppie Zama Buthelezi, then a 17-year-old schoolgirl, joined thousands of other schoolchildren to protest apartheid in education.

title: LAKERS' BREAKS JAMMED
description: In their grueling playoff series with the Utah Jazz and the Dallas Mavericks, the Los Angeles Lakers avoided elimination by using their fastbreak. Now, the defending National Basketball Association champions seem to have hit a brick wall.

title: LACROSSE A BIG HIT IN QUEENS
description: For the past six years, it has been easy to find the best lacrosse team in the Public Schools Athletic League. Take the Grand Central Parkway to the Parsons Boulevard exit in Queens, make a right on 168th Street and go a block to Jamaica High School.

title: The Law; Justices Resolve an Unusual Capital Case
description: The United States Supreme Court settled a conflict this week between the highest courts of Mississippi and New York, in an unusual case that exposed the raw edges of the regional debate over capital punishment.

title: Diner's Journal; Vacation Schedules
description: These restaurants are closing for summer vacation:

title: Get the Garble Out of the Loudspeakers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Combination in London
description: In London, the recently formed alliance of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, a giant in the United States, and Publicis Communications, a huge French company, will create a new entity by merging FCB/ London with Mallett McCormick, one of two Publicis agencies in that city. The result will be Foote, Cone & Belding/ MM. Tony Dalton, formerly of BSB Dorland, will be the chairman and chief executive. McCormick Publicis, another London agency owned by the French, will be unaffected.

title: Newsstands Are No Menace
description: Given the crack epidemic, the homeless and the decay of bridges, New York City officials have enough to do without trying to exterminate newsstands. Yet six city agencies spend precious time and energy on a misguided attempt to do just that.

title: Why Israel Deported Awad
description: LEAD: Mubarak Awad, we are told, is an ''advocate of peace'' - comparable, some have argued, to such legendary practitioners of nonviolence as Mohandas K. Gandhi and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In reality, Mr. Awad, a United States citizen, is wholly a different figure. The legal and political reasons for his deportation from

title: BEWARE! SCHMIDT'S OVERDUE
description: Gary Carter, who is 34 years old and hit his last home run on May 16, considered the arrival tonight of Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies, who is 38 and hit his last home run on May 20. And Carter decided that Schmidt was in a slump, not a decline, and must be approached by the Mets this weekend with extreme caution.

title: Congress Aid Request Due Soon, Contra Says
description: The Reagan Administration told Nicaraguan rebel leaders today that it would soon ask Congress to provide the contra guerrillas with additional aid, the chief contra peace negotiator said.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Can Stop Fueling Southern African Fires; Railways No Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: NO EARLY MENTAL ILLS TIED TO AIDS, RESEARCH FINDS
description: People infected with the AIDS virus show no sign of mental problems until they develop physical symptoms associated with the deadly disease, a new study shows.

title: Tax Breaks Expanded for New York City Housing
description: The New York City Council yesterday approved an expansion of the city's tax-abatement and tax-exemption program for housing renovations.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Church's President Partial to Long Hours
description: LEAD: After working for food and restaurant companies in Detroit, Chicago, New York, Lexington, Ky., and Raleigh, N.C., in his 32-year career, Ernest E. Renaud will move to San Antonio as the new president of Church's Fried Chicken Inc.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ad Council Picks Chief
description: The board of the Advertising Council, the advertising industry's major volunteer endeavor, has elected Walter E. Mattson, president of The New York Times Company, as chairman. Founded during World War

title: Zoo's Animals Prepare To Meet Their Public
description: The Central Park Zoo has been closed for so long that children under 5 don't know it.

title: Writers Guild Says No To Producers' Offer in Strike
description: Striking Hollywood writers planned to meet producers this afternoon for what the producers described as ''the purpose of concluding negotiations'' to end a strike that has lasted 15 weeks and forced the networks to postpone the start of the television season this fall.

title: A Not-So-Lit'rary Bloomsday
description: The erudition has mercifully eased and Buck Mulligan is free to strut through the classic opening paragraph as himself again, stately and plump, the way James Joyce created him, so free of footnotes and full of life.

title: Music and History at Waterloo Village
description: WALKING amid the impeccably restored Colonial and Victorian homes, inns and mills, or listening to music on a summer evening against a backdrop of forests, streams and mountains, it is hard to understand why state tourism brochures say Waterloo Village is ''New Jersey's best-kept secret.'' This restored village - or ''living history museum,'' as Waterloo's founders, Percival Leach and Louis Gualandi, describe it - is metropolitan New York's answer to both Colonial Williamsburg and Tanglewood.

title: ESPOSITO AND 2 OTHERS INDICTED ON BRIBERY CHARGES
description: Meade H. Esposito, the 81-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury along with his daughter and a business associate.

title: Ferraro's Son Sentenced to 4 Months in Jail for Selling Cocaine
description: A Vermont District Court judge today sentenced John A. Zaccaro Jr. to four months in prison for selling cocaine to an undercover police officer in 1986.

title: The Law: At the Bar
description: Ten years ago, when Richard Posner and William Landes, professors at the University of Chicago Law School, joined by a second-year student, Andrew Rosenfield, founded Lexecon Inc., it was something of a lark.

title: Drought Brings a Specter of Major Price Increases
description: The driest spring in half a century has brought declarations of emergency in the Middle West, the South and the Great Plains and has raised what Department of Agriculture economists see as a prospect of the most dramatic rises in commodity prices since the 1970's.

title: AWAITING GOLF'S NEW HERO
description: IT'S as if this United States Open were a golf seance. As if everybody under the big leafy trees at The Country Club were waiting for Francis Ouimet to step out of the television screens in the old yellow-and-white wooden clubhouse or jump down from any of the black-and-white photographs of him on the dark wooden walls under the ceiling fans in the men's locker room.

title: U.S. Faulted in Hiring of a Belgian Nazi Criminal
description: United States intelligence authorities in Europe employed a Belgian Nazi war criminal for 10 years after World War II without properly checking his identity, even after he repeatedly gave different names, a Government report asserted yesterday.

title: Texaco in Deal With the Saudis
description: Saudi Arabia has signed a letter of intent to buy a 50 percent interest in Texaco Inc.'s refining and marketing system in 23 Eastern and Gulf Coast states for $1.28 billion.

title: Chinese Jails Still Hold Prisoners of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: France Makes Cohabitation a Habit
description: France voted four times in the last seven weeks and each round packed a surprise. Party and individual fortunes zoomed and plummeted, extremism surged and faded, until at last the pieces collected around the center. Now President Francois Mitterrand must pick them up and move toward the new moderate majority he promises without the Socialist majority he hoped for.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Sabatini Upset: Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami upset Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, 6-2, 7-5, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of a key Wimbledon warm-up event. The 16-year-old Fernandez will face top-seeded Martina Navratilova in the Pilkington Glass Championships in Eastbourne, England. In another quarterfinal match, 17-year-old Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, the finalist at the French Open earlier this month, beat Caterina Lindqvist of Sweden, 6-4, 0-6, 6-2. She will play Pascale Paradis of France. Navratilova defeated Larissa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 6-4; Paradis eliminated Anne Minter of Australia, 6-4, 6-3.(AP) Krishnan Gains: Third-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India, seventh-seeded Christian Saceanu of West Germany and two unseeded Americans, Derrick Rostagno and Mark Dickson, advanced to the semifinals of the Bristol Trophy grass-court tournament in England yesterday. Krishnan, aiming for his second Nabisco Grand Prix tournament victory of the year, beat fourth-seeded Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-3, 6-4. Krishnan will meet Dickson, who beat Stephen Shaw of Britain, 6-1, 7-5. Rostagno advanced with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over 14th-seeded Eduardo Masso of Argentina. He will face Saceanu, who beat Matt Anger of the United States, 6-3, 7-6.(AP) McEnroe in Semifinals: John McEnroe continued preparing yesterday for a Wimbledon return, coming back from a set down to beat Peter Lundgren of Sweden, 4-6, 6-4, 6-2. McEnroe advanced to the semifinals of the Wirral International tournament in West Kirby, England. McEnroe was one of three Americans to claim semifinal berths. David Pate beat Kevin Curren, 7-6, 7-6, and Leif Shiras defeated Jim Pugh 6-4, 6-3, in a pair of matches involving United States players. Christo van Rensburg, a native South African who lives in Great Neck, N.Y., took the last semifinal spot, upsetting Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-1.(AP) Boxing Davis Wins Again: Unbeaten Aaron Davis of the Bronx won his 17th fight last night when Tyrone Moore retired in his corner before the ninth round of a scheduled 10-round welterweight bout in Felt Forum. Davis, a 1986 New York Gold Glove champion, knocked Moore down once in the sixth round and twice in the seventh round. In an earlier bout, Renaldo Snipes stopped Terry Armstrong at 2:55 of the eighth round of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight match. Snipes drove Armstrong into the ropes with a powerful right and knocked him down with another right. Armstrong rose by the count of 9, but Referee Charley Norkus stopped the fight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Product News Reports Introductions
description: Because the New Product News under the new ownership of Gorman Publishing has changed the way it reports introductions, it doesn't make sense to compare monthly 1988 reports with those of previous years. However, the May declined dramatically from April, although last year May was up from April. The May 1988 figure was 883 compared with April's 1,071.

title: THE DETAILS OF THE AGREEMENT
description: New York State officials today released documents detailing the state's agreement with the Long Island Lighting Company about closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant. The agreement provides for the following:

title: Our Towns; Youthful Legions Arm to Wage Summer's Battles
description: According to concerned psychologists, the leading causes of nervous breakdowns are the death of a loved one, value-added taxes and outfitting your child for overnight camp.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Japan Calls For New Chip Talks
description: Japanese electronics companies today moved to reopen talks with American semiconductor companies over the issue of access to the Japanese market, but the two sides still remained divided over a fundamental issue.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * A.B. Electrolux, a maker of vacuum cleaners and related products, to Kobs & Draft Advertising for direct marketing.

title: Bank Fraud Guilty Plea
description: Edwin L. Cox Jr., the son of a Dallas business leader and a former operator of farming, cattle and energy ventures, said today that he would plead guilty to Federal fraud charges involving an $80 million loan from a forerunner of the First Republicbank Corporation.

title: HOUSING POLICE OFFICER KILLED IN CHASE
description: A housing police officer was killed and his partner injured yesterday when their patrol car hit an ambulance, slammed into a lamppost and burst into flames during a high-speed chase of a stolen police car in the Bronx.

title: Notes and Bonds Tumble in Price
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply in fairly active trading yesterday, as traders here and abroad took profits from the big rally early in the week.

title: Campus Bigotry Incidents Show an Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Cultural Institutions; Smithsonian Recognizes Influence Beyond White
description: For most of its 142 years, the Smithsonian Institution was oriented toward the presentation of white American history and culture.
