How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 7 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: In the Inn Tradition, Big and Bold
description: LA GAZELLE, big, bold and bright, sparkles on Southold's Main Road with its antebellum white-columned exterior and charming plant-filled interior illuminated with festive tiny lights. Despite the French name, French posters and main line French menu offerings, the restaurant is only minimally French. Rather, its countenance is early American, a throwback to its former incarnation as the Southold Inn.

title:
GARDENING;
Weighing the Benefits of Modern Tools
description: LEAD: OVER the years, the technology of the garden has advanced from spades and shovels to rototillers, with a lot in between. These modern tools and products are often a mixed blessing.

title: Wiping Out Spandau Prison
description: FOR more than 20 years, it was a prison with but one prisoner. It became a virtual shrine in West Berlin before which neo-Nazis vented a ritual rage.

title: Stonewalling In Ulster
description: THE STALKER AFFAIR By John Stalker. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: FOCUS: Affordability; H.U.D. Aid Without A Subsidy
description: WHEN Rich Boyden came up with the idea of constructing 81 homes in this fast-growing suburb 25 miles north of Seattle and selling them for 20 percent below market price, few people thought his project would work as planned, let alone become a national model.

title: Complaints Aside, Deer are a Joy
description: YEARS ago a neighbor newly arrived from the city threw up her hands and wailed to me: ''First the mice, then the hornets and now the gypsy moths! What next?'' Alas, she is no longer a country denizen, but if she were, she would know the answer: deer.

title: Pearl Primus Rejoices in the Black Tradition
description: ''MY CAREER HAS BEEN A quest, a search for roots,'' Pearl Primus, the black dance pioneer, has written. It is not a statement of belief one would necessarily find among others in the dance world. The special contribution that black choreographers and dancers have made to modern dance receives both honor and scrutiny this week at the American Dance Festival in a program entitled ''The Black Tradition in American Modern Dance.'' The three-year project aims at reviving ''lost'' or little-performed works and recording them on videotape, while also fostering scholarship through seminars and the publication of a collection of essays.

title: From Fresh Air Fund, a Father Figure
description: Father's Day is one of the most important days of the year for Kelvin Cooks, who met the man he calls his surrogate father 21 years ago through the Fresh Air Fund.

title: THE REGION: Vallone Vs. Koch on Taxes; City Council Power Play Puts Budget Game Into Overtime
description: IF only the budget negotiations that consumed City Hall last week had been merely about money, a new spending plan might have been approved by the deadline on Thursday. But as Peter F. Vallone, the majority leader of the City Council, framed the debate at midweek, what was at stake was respect. This would be the year the Council would stand up to the Mayor, or at least on its own 70 feet.

title: A Call for Change In Nursing Education
description: The article ''Nurse, Heal Thyself'' [ Opinion Page, May 22 ] cries out for comment. As a practicing nurse (hospital-based), I whole-heartedly support the deductive brilliance of Joan Swirsky.

title: 'Daylight and Boonville' Explores Arid Terrain
description: ''WE wait; that's what we do,'' says Lorette, with resignation. She's the eldest of three coal miner's wives, living in a trailer court, somewhere in southern Indiana, where they ''haven't seen a single blade of grass.''

title: Bronx Leader Plans To Appoint 3 Panels To Map New Growth
description: In an effort to end what he termed ''the hodge-podge method'' of municipal planning, the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said last week that he planned to appoint a number of task forces to draw up development strategies for the borough.

title: Torquemada and Friends
description: INQUISITION By Edward Peters. Illustrated. 362 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: Clara Pierre Has Wedding
description: Clara Pierre, an adjunct assistant professor of journalism at New York University, and David Kenny Reeves, the director of development at the Hastings Center in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., were married yesterday at their home in Princeton, N.J. Judge Russell W. Annich Jr. of Municipal Court in Princeton Borough officiated.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONE HALF OF THE SKY: Stories From Contemporary Women Writers of China. Translated by R. A. Roberts and Angela Knox. (Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) Modern Chinese literature, unlike Chinese food, is rarely served to the American public and perhaps on that account this book should be welcomed. The stories in ''One Half of the Sky'' date from the 1920's to the 70's, with some interesting developments from the 80's not included, so the ''contemporary'' in its subtitle, ''Stories From Contemporary Women Writers of China,'' is a little misleading. These works were originally part of a Chinese selection of women's fiction published in Canton, from which R. A. Roberts and Angela Knox, the Australian and English translators, made their own selections. They range from Bing Xin's ''Loneliness,'' a 1922 cameo of a little boy's sad universe, to ''Sketches From the 'Cattle Shed,' '' a 1979 recollection of the horrors of solitary confinement by China's most famous woman writer, Ding Ling. Frances Wood, a British sinologist, provides an introduction, and there are also brief biographies of each writer that seem to have been lifted straight from the Chinese original. Unfortunately, the translations feature a decidedly British phrasing, thus increasing the distance that already exists between American readers and Chinese writers. In addition, although these occasionally moving stories provide a window into the Chinese world, most of them suffer from sentimentality and the political ''new-speak'' that is endemic to so much modern Chinese fiction. Often puzzling to the uninitiated, they could have been made much less so if the introduction and biographies had been more elaborate - and, most important, if notes had been provided.

title: Earthy Ceramics In Sardinian Style
description: AT the Hotel Cala di Volpe on the Costa Smeralda, or Emerald Coast, in Sardinia, no two bathrooms have the same tiles. The most famous is the Harlequin bathroom in the Presidential suite with floor and walls gaily checkered like a carnival costume.

title: St. Luke's: Playing Where The Action
description: ''THE THREADS OF DIRECTION have been clear from the very beginning,'' says Michael Feldman, founder and artistic director of the St. Luke's Ensemble. ''We wanted to be able to play everything across the board, to have musicians with as wide a stylistic background as possible so that we could perform chamber music, opera, dance and orchestral music.''

title: Students Open Windows to Heaven
description: The 1,000th year of Christianity in the Soviet Union was marked last week with elaborate religious services in Moscow, Kiev and Leningrad. But one of the more intimate commemorations took place in a Greenwich Village basement where a handful of people were painting the most venerated of Russian religious symbols, an icon.

title: In Spain, Enthusiasm for Common Market Cools
description: Spain's success or failure in the European Economic Community depends, to a large extent, on Natividad Perez Somarilla and Aurelio Lopez Mencia and the other people of Cantabria Province.

title: The Barron: 2 Ways to Paint in Fresno
description: MAX DOERNER said that painting in fresco ''required the whole man.''

title: Correction
description: An introductory note to an excerpt from Edith Wharton's letters May 1 misidentified a play by Victor Hugo. Wharton quoted a line from Hugo's ''Ruy Blas,'' not ''Gil Blas,'' which is a tale by Alain-Rene Lesage.

title: Nature Preserved By the Gifts Of 2 Women
description: TWO Connecticut women have given away what they greatly love, to preserve it for the future.

title: E. Stacy Creamer, A Writer, Is Wed
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Ambler, Pa., E. Stacy Creamer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Shane Creamer of Blue Bell, Pa., was married yesterday to C. Roger Finney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement Seymour Finney of Victoria, British Columbia. The Rev. Pascal A. Monteleone performed the ceremony.

title: On Language; Inside Baseball
description: IT IS ONE OF THOSE underappreciated, 'inside baseball' moments that ratify politics as the Ultimate Game. . . .'' So begins a Michael Kramer column in U.S. News & World Report. ''Jack Germond produces a self-described 'inside baseball' syndicated political column,'' writes William Prochnau in The Washington Post, ''with his partner, Jules Witcover.'' A couple of years ago, Tom Oliphant of The Boston Globe said that the columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak had been ''marvelous on the inside baseball of the Democratic Party.''

title:
MUSIC;
Opera Audition Finalists in Concert
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey State Opera will present the four finalists in its annual Scholarship Auditions in a concert tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: Dukakis Praises 'America's Party'
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis weighed in today on the Harvard-Yale debate initiated by his rival, Vice President Bush.

title: Miss Chaney Has Wedding
description: Diana Louise Chaney and Andrew Klausner were married yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York by Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: Remorse Over a 'Drinking Binge'
description: A 30-YEAR-OLD Hunterdon County mother of two says she will never stop thinking about what her 6-year-old son could have become had she not gone on a ''drinking binge'' when she was three weeks' pregnant.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: New Airport This Fall For Palm Beach

title: No-Lead Gasoline
description: To the Editor: An addendum to the letter from Barrie Fahey (Travel, May 8) on car rentals in Europe: We rented a B.M.W. (325ix sedan) in Zurich and went to France. To get unleaded gas we had to drive to the nearest freeway a fourth of a tank away. The cost to fill up (about 15 gallons at about $4.25 a gallon) was $65! ELIZABETH C. MORRILL Beverly Farms, Mass.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Robert Price;
Public Utility Agency Chairman Pursues Continued Savings
description: LEAD: LIKE many others in the county, Robert Price turns off the lights in his Croton home to cut his energy costs.

title: Jamaican Emigres Bring Thrift Clubs to New York
description: When Monica Foster arrived in Brooklyn from Jamaica in 1968, she started saving to buy a home, but she did not open a bank account. Like many Caribbean immigrants, she joined a partnership, or savings club, run by her family and friends, ''throwing a hand'' of $100 a week.

title: West Point Honor Code Faces Study After Expulsion Furor
description: The West Point honor-code system, which has governed the conduct of generations of cadets at the United States Military Academy, will be reviewed by a panel of outside experts for the first time in more than a decade, military officials said yesterday.

title: Film Makers, Their Subsidies Cut, Find That Sex Is Good Box Office In Poland
description: THE BOX OFFICE SMASH in Poland this year, with the suggestive title ''Cupid's Bow,'' is a long film about war and sex and a decadent society dancing a jig on the edge of history's volcano in Cracow, in what was then Galicia in the Austro-Hungarian Empire, during the bitter days of World War I. It is the story of a young married woman, Maria, a daughter of Cracow's gilded upper class, who turns to a lecherous professor and a strapping teen-ager, among others, for sexual escape from the loneliness and encroaching penury that follows her young husband's departure for the front.

title: Why Columbus Circle Should Go Back to Square One
description: IF ANY PROJECT HAS SERVED AS A rallying point for sentiment against large-scale development in New York today, it is the vast tower proposed for the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle. The original plan for the coliseum site, designed by Moshe Safdie and made public in 1985, was attacked more vehemently, perhaps, than any project since the tower that a developer wanted to put atop Grand Central Terminal in 1968.

title: Mothers With Babies - and Jobs; A Transforming Change, in One Generation
description: Among women who had a child in the year preceding the June 1987 survey, 51 percent were in the labor force . . . as compared with 31 percent in June 1976.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on June 5 about black African attitudes toward the war in Chad gave an incorrect definition of the Arabic word iswid. It means black and is commonly used in referring to black people, not to slaves.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Overboard Starring Goldie Hawn, Kurt Russell, Edward Herrmann, Katherine Helmond, Roddy McDowall, Michael Hagerty. Directed by Garry Marshall. 1987. CBS-Fox Video. 112 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG. Some vulgar language.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Suffolk Clusters Preserve Its Golf Courses
description: LEAD: WHILE Nassau County has lost a number of golf courses to developers, most of those in Suffolk County that were made available for development have been preserved by clustering housing along the fairways. This lets the builder charge more for his house, but it also saves a recreational amenity for the community.

title: New Gate Systems at Rail Crossings
description: FOR years, motorists using the Metro-North grade crossing on New Canaan Avenue in Norwalk have had to worry as much about the rising and setting sun affecting their vision as the Danbury Branch trains traveling at 65 miles an hour.

title: Susan Pamela Adler and Allen Funk Are Married
description: The marriage of Susan Pamela Adler, the daughter of Sheila Adler of Pomona, N.Y., and the late Leonard J. Adler, to Allen Barlow Funk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Deane Funk of Santa Monica and Bishop, Calif., took place last evening at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated.

title: Gail Sarner to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Sarner of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Robin Sarner, to James M. Citrin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Citrin of Kings Point, L.I. The couple plan to marry Aug. 14.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; A Resort Blossoms in a Neglected Area
description: AFTER decades of neglect, a 60-year-old inn on 12 wooded acres hidden in the Norwich hills where the Prince of Wales, George Bernard Shaw and Charles Laughton often stayed in the 30's was restored in 1984 and has now been expanded into a luxurious resort, just a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Manhattan.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am interested in buying a house that has asbestos shingles on the outside. I fear that rain might cause leaching of the asbestos into the ground or make it airborne. Is there a health hazard with asbestos siding? A. I don't believe so, not as long as the shingles are on the outside and you are not cutting, sanding or otherwise abrading or breaking up the shingles. Asbestos is only a hazard when the fibers become airborne, and this does not seem a likely problem with exterior shingles. Q. My 45-year-old vacation home in the mountains is made of wood logs that have been treated every few years with creosote. However, creosote has been banned in this state. What preservative can I use over this? A. Any of the currently available wood preservatives can be used over the creosote after it has weathered for several years, but the dark color imparted by creosote will show through on the new coating. Q. How can I remove adhesive tape residue left when the tape was peeled off glossy Formica furniture without scratching the shiny surface on this furniture? A. The adhesive can be wiped off with a solvent such as lighter fluid or rubber cement thinner (sold in art supply stores). Saturate a piece of toweling with this and rub vigorously until the sticky residue comes off, then rub again with a dry cloth.

title: For $45, People Can Own Bits of Hartford Renewal
description: FOR $45, people can own a piece of Hartford, a personalized brick, and they can inscribe almost anything on it.

title: Nightmare in Vienna
description: LEAD: Mozart's Last Year. By H. C. Robbins Landon. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Schirmer Books/Macmillan. $19.95.

title: Imported Exports
description: To the Editor:

title: They're Easy to Grow
description: USE half-rate water-soluble fertilizer on container gardens planted in window boxes, tubs, planters and pots. Pull up and store string trellis for pea vines and seed the empty rows with snap beans or chard. Thin beets to one-half inch apart and use the thinnings in salads. Remove faded flowers promptly from geraniums and petunias to prolong their bloom season. Highly Recommended

title: Courses: Something for Everyone
description: WEAVING, anyone? Or casting? Those and a variety of other courses are available at art schools and centers throughout the state this summer.

title: POLAND'S LEADERS ARE LEFT TO TILT AT AN ECONOMY THAT WON'T BUDGE
description: Poland's Communist leadership is struggling desperately to restart a stalled economic recovery program and to halt the sharp inflation that has led to a wave of worker protests.

title: She Was The Other Ireland
description: NORA The Real Life of Molly Bloom. By Brenda Maddox. Illustrated. 472 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.

title: Federal Funds Advance for Nematode Control
description: DESPITE a move by the Reagan Administration to eliminate the Federal program that controls the golden nematode, a small, yellowish worm that feeds on potatoes, moves are under way in Congress to restore money for the program, which farmers say is vital to preventing crop infestation.

title: Cycling in Philadelphia Special to The New York Times
description: Nearly 100 professional cyclists will compete Sunday in the fourth annual CoreStates United States Professional Cycling Championship. The 156-mile race, which has been given world cup status this year, is the only such competition outside Europe.

title: Royals Making Hay As Their Pitchers Shine
description: THE direction of two pennant races might have been decided in the past two weeks. The St. Louis Cardinals played the Mets six times in 10 days and lost two games in the National League East standing. The Kansas City Royals played the Oakland Athletics six times in 11 days and gained seven games in the American League West standing.

title: At College Reunion, 60's Nonconformity Lives On
description: James McGalliard is not where he expected to be today. In the heady, radical atmosphere of his undergraduate days at Goddard College 20 years ago, he thought he would become a minister. Instead, he is a computer specialist, working for the Federal Government in Washington.

title: Don't Write Off Junk Bonds
description: ''JUNK BONDS'' - is there an empirical basis for the nasty-name-calling about the high-yield financing that raised more than $150 billion for growth companies over the past decade? Can investment-grade companies that issue ''non-junk bonds'' still be considered ''quality'' if they lay off workers and lose markets to foreign competitors? Does it really make any sense to consider non-investment grade companies as the ''junk'' of Corporate America?

title: Trying to Salvage Walden Pond
description: WALDEN POND in 1845: a pristine woodland that Henry David Thoreau retreated to for two years to escape the world of streets and crowds. In a pine cabin, he lived there outside of Concord, Mass., hiking, fishing, pondering life and writing.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN STOCKHOLM
description: Stockholmers feel they've earned their summers. After a harsh winter, when the sun skids across the horizon before retiring as early as 2 P.M., Swedes like to soak up any glorious sunlight with unabashed enthusiasm. Absenteeism from work rises notoriously on sunny days. Children romp at the Grona Lund amusement park. Ice cream vendors are at every corner and Kungstradgarden, the King's Garden at the city's center, comes alive with people and events.

title: GOOD SPORTS
description: FORGET BAGGY SWEATSHIRTS, SHAPELESS SWIMSUITS and anything in locker-room gray. Sports clothes have shed their fuddy-duddy image.

title: Elizabeth B. Hufstader Married to John Balay
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., Elizabeth Bryan Hufstader and John Michael Balay, graduates of Yale University, were married yesterday by the Rev. William W. Eddy. Mrs. Balay, a daughter of Peter Hufstader of Providence, R.I., and Mrs. Walter E. Steele of Edgartown, is a merchandise coordinator at Polo Ralph Lauren for Boys in Charlottesville, Va. She graduated from the Concord Academy. Her father is the assistant headmaster of the Wheeler School in Providence. Her mother, Margaret Steele, is the office manager at Harborside Realty in Edgartown.

title: Baseball; American League; Clemens Fires Sixth Shutout
description: After absorbing the worst pounding of his career in his previous start, Boston's Roger Clemens was eager to redeem himself.

title: Errol Train Weds John C. Giordano 3d
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md., Errol Cuthbert Train, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Train of Washington, was married yesterday to John Carl Giordano 3d, a son of Mr. Giordano Jr. of Middletown, N.J., and the late Mary Kay Wertheim Meyer. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

title: Out of the Closets And Into Action
description: THIS month marks the start of the high season for photography. Besides the June brides and high school graduates, there are cookouts, weekend trips and vacations that need to be immortalized. The solstice is nigh upon us as well, marking the year's longest day. For early risers and those not glued to evening baseball games, some of the most beautiful light imaginable can be had for no extra charge.

title: Pressures Building for a Rate Rise
description: The rally that pushed long-term interest rates to their lowest levels since early May is over, most credit market analysts contend, and pressures are building here and abroad that are likely to send rates modestly higher in coming weeks.

title: Airline, Citing Smoking, Bumps Abbie Hoffman
description: Abbie Hoffman said today he was ordered off a Continental Airlines plane at O'Hare International Airport here after a flight attendant unjustly accused him of smoking marijuana in the lavatory.

title: Robert S. Yellowtail Sr., Tribal Official, 98
description: Robert Summers Yellowtail Sr., a patriarch of the Crow Indian Tribe, died Saturday at his home. He was 98 years old.

title: Weinberger Says Bribery Inquiry May Show Reforms Are Necessary
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, former Secretary of Defense, said today he was disturbed by reports of widespread bribery among Pentagon officials, acknowledging that the Defense Department may not have been sufficiently vigilant against fraud during his years at the Pentagon.

title: James Houghton, 45, Medical Researcher
description: Capt. James O. Houghton, commanding officer of the Naval Aerospace Medical Research Laboratory, died in an automobile accident Thursday, the police said. He was 45 years old.

Information: (914) 476-5151 or (914) 428-0760. Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge Run. Central Park, 7 P.M. 3.5-mile race for more than 10,000 runners from 600 area companies. title: YANKS ROUTED, 11-3, BUT CLING TO LEAD
description: They are still in first place, but their hold seems more tenuous than ever. The Yankees struggled again today under a hot and heavy sun, their pitching and their hitting gone sour and their road trip growing more miserable by the day.

title: Metro Matters; Rosenberg Case: Family's Struggle At Reconciliation
description: Somewhere in New York City, perhaps in the modest house where he and his wife live pseudonymously, David Greenglass must have paused a moment yesterday to ponder the day, precisely 35 years ago, when his sister and brother-in-law died in the electric chair, largely as a result of his testimony.

title: Mars Graphic Services reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Sports World Specials; Peaceful Punches
description: Boxing and meditation, some might point out, have enjoyed a long and compatible relationship. A boxer lowers his guard, walks into an opponent's right hook and meditates for 10 seconds before being escorted from the ring.

title: Community Colleges Emerge As Centers for Job Training
description: The nation's community and junior colleges, sometimes dismissed as the poor relations of higher education, are carving a new role for themselves delivering customized job training and technical education to manufacturers and businesses in their towns.

title: Ellen Saideman Weds Professor
description: The marriage of Ellen Marjorie Saideman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben H. description: The Nashville Symphony Association filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection late last week after almost five months of struggling with its musicians to solve money problems. The 85-member orchestra shut down Feb. 3 because of financial trouble.

title: The Other Brawley Case
description: Bent on indicting American justice as racist, Tawana Brawley's advisers long ago forsook her interests for their own. If in fact the black teen-ager was kidnapped and sexually abused last November in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., her advisers, counseling non-cooperation with a special prosecutor, have induced her to forfeit her rights as a victim in order to put her on the national stage.

title: AT PLAY IN THE WORLDS OF WORD
description: As he amply demonstrated in ''On the Verge,'' Eric Overmyer is a playwright with a linguistic limberness to rival that of Tom Stoppard. Punster and anagrammarian, he is infatuated with language and with word games. His new play, ''In Perpetuity Throughout the Universe,'' opening last night at the Hudson Guild Theater, is filled with the author's verbal felicity and intelligence, but, in contrast to ''On the Verge,'' it has no inner momentum. It is less a play than a thesaurus. Though there are enough ideas and funny lines for a dozen comedies, it adds up to less than one. ''In Perpetuity'' is a literary exercise that might be more alive in the reading than in performance.

title: Auto Racing; Senna and Prost Finish 1-2 in Detroit
description: Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost ran away from the rest of the field at the Detroit Grand Prix today, continuing the McLaren team's utter domination of Formula One racing this year.

title: ASSIMILATING IMMIGRANTS AND KEEPING TRADITIONS
description: ''Green Card'' is at its most effective when instead of trying to score points, it concentrates on the anomalies of America's reception and rejection of the newest Americans. Using movement and music, enormous slides and striking stage design, the writer and director JoAnne Akalaitis finds humor, sadness and perplexity in the ways that immigrants, particularly from Southeast Asia and Central America, have been changing the United States even as they seek to adapt to it. We get sharp glimpses of cultures in collision and embrace. (Everybody seems to be a fan of ''The Incredible Hulk.'') The two hours at the Joyce Theater begin on a note of nonstartling irony with a reading of Emma Lazarus's Statue of Liberty verses by a young black woman wrapped in an American flag; it is immediately followed by a Lenny Bruce monologue (frenetically delivered by Jesse Borrego), made up almost entirely of the epithets that have been directed at minorities through the years. Get it? Then, suddenly and more engagingly, the ethnically assorted cast is caught up in a disco number, all races shaking away to the same made-in-America beat.

description: FOR more than a week, the conversation among surf fishermen at the general store had been devoted to speculation about when the pond would be opened to the ocean.

description: Andre Dawson hit a home run, triple and double and drove in three runs today as the Chicago Cubs beat the Montreal Expos, 9-3, to sweep the three-game series.

title: Palestinians' Uprising Finds A New Phase in Firebombing
description: The hands of the Palestinian taxi driver, Shakir Hamid, were covered with brown paint. An hour earlier he had driven into town with a fare, when Israeli soldiers stopped his cab and made him get out.

title: Council Elections in Poland Draw Lowest Voter Turnout
description: Local and province council elections on Sunday drew the lowest turnout in Poland's postwar history. Opposition groups had denounced the balloting as a farce and urged Poles not to vote.

title: Cycling; Italian Wins CoreStates Race
description: Roberto Gaggioli, a 25-year-old cyclist from Vinci, Italy, won the fourth annual CoreStates United States Pro Cycling Championship today. Riding for the Pepsi Fanini team, which is based in Philadelphia, he was the first foreigner to win the race, which is now in the 13-race world cup series.

title: Ticket to Dilemma; Move to Make Jackson Running Mate Is Testing Democrats' Political Skills
description: The movement to put the Rev. Jesse Jackson on the Democratic ticket as Vice President, while gaining no encouragement from the man who will make the choice, has developed a complex political life of its own that neither Mr. Jackson nor anyone else fully seems to control.

title: Disconnecting the Illegal Caller
description: The nation's three largest long-distance telephone companies and the Federal Government have successfully stepped up their campaigns against the use of stolen telephone credit-card and access numbers. They are reporting an increased number of arrests and a significant reduction in illegal calls, which have been costing the companies hundreds of millions of dollars a year.

title: Ex-Rep. Gladys N. Spellman Dies After Being in Coma for 8 Years
description: Former Representative Gladys Noon Spellman died early today in a nursing home in suburban Maryland after being in a coma for nearly eight years. She was 70 years old. Mrs. Spellman, a Democrat, was running for her fourth term in the House when her heart stopped beating temporarily on Oct. 31, 1980, while she was judging a Halloween costume contest at a shopping mall.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * West German companies are expected to increase their capital investments in 1988 by about 3 percent in real terms, the ecomomic research institute IFO said. It said a poll of 3,150 companies, conducted in March and April, showed that their investments in fixed assets and equipment grew in 1987 to 72 billion marks, or about $41 billion, a real increase of about 4 percent over 1986. However, the 1987 increase was well below double-digit growth seen in some previous years.

title: PIERRE BOULEZ CONDUCTS A HISTORY LESSON
description: Listening to Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic play Luciano Berio's ''Sinfonia'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night sent one's thoughts in curious directions. This listener's alighted on a little piano sonata in G - a tiny exercise in innocent high spirits written by Beethoven in the midst of abject personal despair. Beethoven seemed to be saying that music exists in a life above (or at least to the side) of the quotidian -that the experience of the day may provide the unfiltered raw materials, but not the end product, in an art operating outside the temporal world.

Results Plus
description: Field Hockey U.S. Wins Tournament: Marcia Pankratz scored two goals and Megan Donnelly added another as the United States captured the U.S.A. Field Hockey Classic yesterday in Ewing, N.J., by playing to a 3-3 tie with the Soviet Union. The tie, coupled with the United States' victories over Argentina and Scotland earlier in the four-team tournament, gave the Americans 5 points. The Soviet Union, which defeated Scotland and tied Argentina, finished with 4 points. Argentina, which defeated Scotland by 3-1 yesterday, was third with 3 points. The Scots had three losses.(AP) Soccer Eagles Edge Bolts: The New Jersey Eagles of the American Soccer League beat the Boston Bolts, 3-2, yesterday at Hinchliffe Stadium in Paterson, N.J. With the score 2-2 and four minutes left, Maicol Antelo beat John Ramos, the Bolts' goalie, on a free kick for his second goal of the evening. Greg Kenney saved 11 shots for New Jersey (11-2); Ramos stopped 8 for Boston (4-7). The Eagles have a three-game lead in the Northern Division. Boating Powerboat Breaks Record: An 11,640-horsepower offshore powerboat broke the Miami-to-New York record yesterday with 13 minutes to spare. The offshore trip aboard the 110-foot Gentry Eagle took 19 hours 17 minutes 27 seconds for the 1,093-mile voyage. The boat is owned by Tom Gentry, an offshore powerboat champion from Honolulu. The previous record of 19 hours 31 minutes was set in 1985 in a 46-foot powerboat. Basketball U.S. Routs Finland: Steve Kerr of Arizona scored 17 points, including three 3-pointers, as the United States Selects crushed Finland, 117-63, in the Pohjola Cup final yesterday in Kotka, Finland. The Selects finished the round-robin tournament with a 3-0 record. Earlier, Britain edged the Netherlands, 70-66, to finish second with a 2-1 record. The Netherlands was third at 1-2; Finland did not win in three games.(AP) 6 Teams Qualify: The Soviet Union, Yugoslavia, China, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Australia have qualified to play in the women's Olympic tournament in Seoul in September. The Soviet Union topped Czechoslovakia, 83-49, to remain the sole undefeated team in the qualifier, finishing the round-robin competition with a 7-0 won-lost record and 14 points. The Soviet squad led, 33-23, at halftime. In other matches yesterday, Yugoslavia defeated Australia 68-58, China beat Poland, 90-74, and Italy downed Bulgaria, 79-77.(AP)

description: BETWEEN an industry like retailing that loves self-promotion and a Wall Street that has learned to be cautious, even the most glowing example of success can have a difficult time finding recognition.

title: NICARAGUAN SEEKS NEW CONTRA TALKS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra called today for new peace talks with United States-backed rebels but warned that approval of fresh American military funds for the rebels would be ''totally unacceptable.''

title: New Effort By Carbide On Bhopal
description: Frustrated by its failure to negotiate a settlement with the Indian Government, the Union Carbide Corporation has begun talks with lawyers for individual victims of the Bhopal gas disaster, seeking an out-of-court solution to the prolonged litigation, company representatives said today.

title: Two-Hit Shutout Disappoints Cone
description: The line drive dropped into shallow center field and as one the 46,773 fans collapsed back into their seats. In the sudden silence, David Cone stood to the right of the pitching mound, his heart sinking faster than any slider he'd thrown all afternoon, his lifelong dream broken off as abruptly as any curveball he might imagine or one day perfect.

title: Missing Heavy Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Regulatory Guidelines Were Culprit in Shoreham Closing
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Corp. Reassurances
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board last week provided reassurances to securities dealers holding certain futures and options contracts with the American Savings and Loan Association, the nation's largest savings institution.

title: Sikhs Blamed in Bombing At Shop in Punjab; 15 Die
description: Fifteen people were killed and 25 wounded today when a bomb planted by Sikh extremists exploded in a crowd of people watching television outside an electronics shop, the police said.

title: American League; Blue Jays Slip Past Tigers
description: Jesse Barfield drove in four runs today, including three on his second homer in two games, as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Detroit Tigers, 6-4, to earn a split of the four-game series.

title: A COMEDIAN'S SALUTE TO JEWISH ANGST
description: Going on 40, Richard Lewis is a boyish looking comedian who dresses entirely in black, wondering darkly if someone might think he's a member of some crazed cult called ''Jews for Satan.'' Since the heydays of Shelly Berman and Lenny Bruce, no comedian has specialized so aggressively, and hilariously, in the phenomenon of Jewish-American angst. Mr. Lewis paces the stage frantically like some overwound Groucho Marx doll. He clutches his hair. He apologizes for using a cliche. He uses notes to remind himself where he is in the act. He can't stop talking. Appropriately enough, his new Home Box Office special, ''The 'I'm Exhausted' Concert,'' opens with a nervous breakdown.

title: Riverbend International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Advanced Medical Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings are less than 1 cent a share in each period. Comparative results from the prior year or quarter are not shown since the company was incorporated on Sept. 24, 1986 and significant operations did not commence until late March 1987.

title: Griffin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest first quarter includes a charge of $636,100 for hardware and material costs on two slow-selling products, a charge of $164,200 from an accounting change and a charge of $1,052,100 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Nuclear Regulatory Guidelines Were Culprit in Shoreham Closing; Get Another Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah L. Kramm Marries Gary Baiz
description: Deborah L. Kramm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hartzell M. Kramm of Peoria, Ill., and Gary Baiz, the son of Blanche Baiz of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Curacao and the late Egon D. Baiz, were married yesterday. The Rev. Jeffery Steenson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Winnebago Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Third World: Stronger, Bolder
description: LEAD: The decline of the superpowers' influence in the world will come about not because their economies, strained by huge defense budgets, are pulling them down, as some experts have suggested. Rather, regardless of how much the the United States and Soviet Union spend on defense, they are finding they are less welcome in the third world than they once were, that they must contend with better-armed opponents and that they face greater domestic political costs by such intervention.

title: Long Wait for Senior Victory
description: Don Bies, who hadn't won a PGA Tour event in 13 years, played today as if finishing first were old hat.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Mess in the Bronx
description: Even by the tawdry standards of Bronx politics, the campaign for Bronx District Attorney last week sank to an unacceptable low as the candidacy of Paul Gentile bogged down in a barrage of charges and countercharges. Governor Cuomo, who created this mess with his mistaken appointment of Mr. Gentile as interim D.A., now owes the Bronx another candidate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ads Appear on the Back Of Cash Register Tapes
description: Blank space, as everyone knows, is a violation of the advertising code. It must be filled with commercial messages so minds can be swayed and money can be made.

title: Israel Seeks to Control Destination of Emigres
description: The Cabinet said today that it would try to force Soviet Jews emigrating with Israeli visas to travel directly to Israel instead of settling elsewhere.

title: A Different Drug Test
description: Members of Congress often have a tough time getting their colleagues to pay attention to other points of view. So Representative Fortney H. (Pete) Stark, who objects to what he calls the ''bipartisan hysteria surrounding the drug crisis,'' came up with an original way to convey his view on the issue: a drug test.

title: Eric Waha, Journalist, 63
description: Eric Waha, a former Vienna bureau chief for The Associated Press, was killed in a car crash today about 12 miles from Vienna. He was 63 years old.

title: Scott Corwin Marries Ann Walden, Student
description: Ann Elizabeth Walden and Scott Laurence Corwin were married yesterday at the American Boychoir School in Princeton, N.J., by Rabbi Z. David Levy.

title: A WRITER IS AUTHOR AT LAST
description: A quotation from Flaubert, so appropriate it seems eerie, is taped to the paperclip holder on Mary McGarry Morris's desk. ''Be regular and orderly in your life,'' it reads, ''so that you may be violent and original in your work.''

title: 2 Boys Drown On Scout Trip To S.I. Camp
description: A 10-year-old Cub Scout from Brooklyn on his first camping trip was found drowned yesterday in a Staten Island lake, and a 9-year-old Cub Scout from the same pack, who was pulled unconscious from the lake on Saturday, died last night.

title: Mexicans Crowd a Last Opening to U.S.
description: They begin lining up at dawn, crowding into the tunnel here that leads to Mexico's border with the United States and clutching the application forms, notarized letters and check stubs they hope will gain them legal entry to California.

title: Phyllis Fine Weds
description: The marriage of Phyllis Sara Fine, the daughter of Frieda Fine Davis of Union, N.J., and the late Irving Fine, to Leslie Neil Luchter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Luchter of Oceanside, L.I., took place yesterday at the Leeds Pond Preserve in Manhasset, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is the associate cruise editor of Travel Agent magazine and Mr. Luchter is a senior editor of Multichannel News magazine, both in Manhattan.

title: LAKERS SEND FINAL TO GAME 7
description: The National Basketball Association record book is filled with the exploits of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, including the most points scored in the regular season and the playoffs. But few if any of the 41-year-old Laker's accomplishments can match the two dramatic free throws he made with 14 seconds remaining today. Those points enabled the Lakers to edge the Detroit Pistons, 103-102, at the Forum and force a seventh and deciding game in the National Basketball Association final.

title: Road Crash in India Kills 15
description: A truck hit a passenger bus today near the northern Indian city of Meerut, killing 15 people and injuring about 25 others, the United News of India reported.

title: British Inflation Rate Up
description: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 4.2 percent in May from 3.9 percent in April, the Government reported Friday. The Department of Employment, which compiled the data, said higher prices for clothing and food were major factors.

title: Baker Called Calm But Too Cautious
description: As Howard H. Baker Jr. prepares to leave his post as White House chief of staff, critics and supporters say he helped President Reagan survive the Iran-contra scandal but failed to protect the President from a series of damaging setbacks - on judicial selections, veto battles and foreign policy questions.

title: Allison's Place reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a constant concern, that you are at the mercy of the most dishonest person in a very, very long chain of people.'' - Caspar W. Weinberger, former Secretary of Defense, on reports of defense contract corruption. [ A1:1. ]

title: Circuit City Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Takeovers and Buybacks Propping Up Stock Prices
description: With foreign, institutional and individual investors largely on the sidelines, corporate takeovers and stock buybacks have become an especially important prop to the stock market since the October crash, market strategists say.

title: Contractors' Network Led To Questions
description: A constant flow of information, through formal and informal channels, between the Government officers who manage weapons programs and the private contractors who design and build the weapons is at the heart of the Pentagon bribery and fraud investigation.

title: Sports of the Times; Twilight Tension
description: IN the pinkish-blue twilight glowing through the big oak trees at The Country Club, Curtis Strange strode up onto the practice range.

title: Werner Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Promotion Fills Global D'Arcy Post
description: ROY J. BOSTOCK, 47-year-old domestic president of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, has been promoted to president and chief operating officer of the worldwide company. It is a post that has been vacant since Hal Bay resigned a couple of months after the November 1985 merger that brought together Benton & Bowles and D'Arcy MacManus & Masius, of which Mr. Bay was chief executive.

title: Laos to Hold Elections
description: Laos will hold national elections for the first time since the Communists seized power 13 years ago, the official Laotian press agency said today. The voting next Sunday will be for representatives of 113 districts throughout the Southeast Asian nation.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Gone, But Not Invisible
description: Washingtonians have shown a new appreciation for the beauty of their old neighborhoods in recent years, and a preservationist movement has taken hold. But much of the charm and history of the capital were lost to new construction during the building boom of the 1960's and 1970's.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Two Men Who Help Manhattan Stand Tall
description: Irwin G. Cantor relishes the 200-story story, the one about Donald J. Trump and what might become the world's tallest building.

title: Times Sq. by Night: Lurid Drama Beckons
description: In the nighttime glare of Times Square, it is never difficult to find a drama of crime or depravity unfolding on the street, nor is it difficult to find a knot of spectators on hand to watch.

title: Italy's New Look
description: When Italy agreed to provide a new home for a tactical wing of F-16 fighters from Spain it averted a looming squall in the Western alliance. The planes were due to be evicted by 1991 from a base near Madrid, leaving a gap in alliance air defenses. So President Reagan had particular reason for his cordial welcome last week for Prime Minister Ciriaco de Mita.

title: SWEDISH CHORAL SINGING
description: The Hagerstens Motet Choir, from Sweden, is in town for two concerts at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine (112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue), and since the performances are offered as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, both programs are devoted to 20th-century choral music rather than, say, the music of Bach that the ensemble's program biography names as the principal specialty of its founder and director, Ingemar Mansson.

title: Dancers as Models
description: Dancers from the New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater, the Joffrey Ballet and other companies will model costumes created for them by leading fashion designers in ''Designs for Dancing'' tonight at 8:30 at the 48 Laight Gallery, 48 Laight Street. The event is a benefit for Eye on Dance, a television program, with the proceeds to go toward toward the preservation and restoration of the show's deteriorating video archives. Reservations: 725-5530.

title: Miss Zelner Is Married To Seth Jacob Margolis
description: Carole Zelner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton L. Zelner of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Seth Jacob Margolis, a son of Karl L. Margolis of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Marjorie Margolis, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father. Rabbi Jack Stern officiated.

title: Whites in Birmingham Win Ruling on Voting
description: Birmingham's white minority, relying on a tactic similar to one used to increase black representation, has won a ruling allowing it to challenge at-large local elections for allegedly diluting white votes.

title: Views on Beauty: When Artists Meet Surgeons
description: LEAD: Xavier de Callatay believes there is too much ugliness and chaos in the world. As the director of studies at the New York Academy of Art, he can improve the artistic landscape by teaching students to employ the mathematical proportions and physical harmony of classical art in their work.

title: Labatt, John Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Greeks Block Farm Accord
description: Greece blocked agreement Friday over guaranteed farm prices for the European Community's 10 million farmers in 1988-89, surprising and angering its 11 partners.

title: A Push to Save L.I. Turtle Colony From Man's Intrusion
description: In the face of a real-estate boom that is devouring much of Long Island's wildlife habitat, the National Park Service and the American Museum of Natural History have joined forces to sustain a historic colony of box turtles, some of which may have been alive since the Civil War.

title: Faldo Catches Strange to Force Playoff in Open
description: Curtis Strange came out of the front bunker at the 72d hole of the United States Open today to save par, and Nick Faldo of England needed two putts from the fringe to save his par and force an 18-hole playoff Monday for the 88th Open championship.

title: POSTURE AND FITNESS LINKED IN FEHER METHOD
description: WITH age comes stiffness. It is one of the givens of life.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-14

title: Turk, Arm in Sling, Returns to Convention
description: The governing Motherland Party's general congress met under tight security today after an escaped convict shot and slightly wounded Prime Minister Turgut Ozal in the convention hall.

title: Why We've Had Another Songless Spring
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Bases - In My Backyard
description: The Pentagon could save billions by closing obsolete bases, but every time it tries, it is blocked by a Congress loath to vote for closings in members' home districts. The issue inverts the classic politics of Nimby - when neighbors protest a new jail, for instance, with chants of ''not in my backyard.'' When it comes to Congressmen and military bases, the motto is keep it in my backyard.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 19, 1988: MONDAY

title: Thor Energy Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
National Geographic Expands Its Television Horizons
description: In 1888 the National Geographic Society published the first issue of its magazine, a plain-brown-wrapper affair with no pictures and few readers. Its mandate was to promote ''the increase and diffusion of geographical knowledge.''

title: American Greetings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DANISH BALLET'S 'ABDALLAH'
description: The Royal Danish Ballet threw out a bouquet of bright young talent at the close of its all-too-brief season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The last of Saturday's two performances of August Bournonville's ''Abdallah,'' marked by a spate of debuts, left audiences cheering and refusing to leave even as the fire curtain came down. In the afternoon, Lis Jeppesen was seen for the first time as Irma, the heroine in this ballet, and proved to an adoring audience why she has remained a favorite from the company's 1982 visit. Nikolaj Hubbe, one of the season's revelations, made his debut as Abdallah while Mette-Ida Kirk, familiar from past visits, was the new leader of the harem, Palmyra.

title: Visit is On Again
description: A week from today, Poland's Deputy Prime Minister, Zdzislaw Sadowski, will arrive in Washington for talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and with officials of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank on his country's moves to reform its economy, according to knowledgeable officials.

title: Jay Jacobs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Boroughs Will Get Specific Cable Guide
description: Triangle Publications' TV Guide is bringing out its first system-specific cable guide on July 2 in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. It will be available only to subscribers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; DelBello Associates: New Consulting Firm
description: The new age of realism has spawned a company that can give advice on advertising, public relations and solid waste management, all under one roof.

title: Melissa Bern Is Married to Andrew L. Rubenstein
description: Melissa Lynn Bern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Bern of North Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew L. Rubenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Rubenstein of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor Barbara Horowitz, performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Man Is Arrested at Open
description: A man who players say has been harassing Curtis Strange, Jack Nicklaus and Ben Crenshaw, was arrested today on the 12th fairway during play in the United States Open.

title: In California, a Cafe Society Emerges
description: When the affluent bohemians of this scruffy beachside community rouse themselves on Sunday mornings, they are likely to gather these days at Hal's, the latest in a local genre: the haute art-and-architecture restaurant.

title: Clubs Shatter Peace of Gramercy Park
description: The quiet that used to descend on the Gramercy Park area when night fell or the workweek ended has been shattered by the patrons who descend on the new restaurants and clubs along Park Avenue South.

title: India Does an About-Face and Courts the Drug Industry
description: In an about-face, India has decided to court American and multinational drug companies, hoping that they will increase investments and develop more drugs and technologies in a country that has previously tried to keep them at bay.

title: Micron Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest third quarter net reflects a pre-tax provision for process and products rights expense of about $8 million.

title: CIVILIAN PRESIDENT DEPOSED IN HAITI BY EX-ARMY CHIEF
description: The dismissed commander of the country's armed forces took control of the presidential palace Sunday night, apparently ending the four-month-old civilian Government of Leslie F. Manigat.

title: Quilt Unfolds Painful Story of AIDS
description: An enormous national quilt made of panels commemorating those who have died from AIDS - a gesture of vast dimension that is as intimate as each loss - is to be unfolded tomorrow for its first display in New York City. Within a week, it will be joined by a locally made quilt that is now taking shape on West 13th Street.

title: Lilly Industrial Coatings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1987.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
King Ranch Appoints An Outsider Chairman
description: LEAD: In an effort to shore up the many businesses linked to their south Texas cattle empire, the estimated 100 stockholding members of the King Ranch have turned over the reins to a board of outside directors.

title: A GOLFING PRIMER FOR BEGINNERS
description: A senior officer with General Electric Investment in Stamford, Conn., recently called in a junior executive and reviewed his new assignments. ''One more thing,'' he said at the end of the meeting, ''You're not a golfer, are you? You need to take up the game. You don't have to play golf, but it'll sure help you get ahead in the business world.''

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PPG to Leave Top Posts Open
description: PPG Industries said Thursday that it would not replace its president and vice chairman when they retire in the fall.

title: TENSION TAKES THE LIMELIGHT
description: THIS past March 30, under the chandeliers and vaulted ceiling of a ballroom at the Plaza Hotel in New York City, Michael Spinks considered the prospect of fighting Mike Tyson and promptly threw a fit.

title: Countrywide Credit Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Thousands Who Fled Toxic Cloud Return to Homes in Massachusetts
description: More than 20,000 people evacuated for two nights because of chlorine fumes from a factory fire returned home today after firefighters doused the blaze, but thousands of others were still barred from their neighborhoods.

title: Bridge
description: Almost all tournament players make use of the negative double, in varying degrees. In doing so they open up tactical possibilities for the opponents that are generally overlooked.

title: U.S., in an Unusual Move, Tries to Define Racketeering
description: A Federal appeals court is conducting an unusual review of the racketeering law that has been used to convict many mobsters, politicians and others.

title: Furlong Wins
description: Shirley Furlong defeated Sherri Turner in a one-hole playoff to win $45,000 in the Ladies Professional Golf Assocation's $300,000 Lady Keystone Open.

title: Ski Board Comes of Age
description: Water skiing has a new look these days thanks to the ski board. A combination surfboard and ski, the board allows the rider to jump waves or do aerials that traditional slalom skiers never dreamed about.

title: 2 Computers From Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation plans to introduce two personal computers today that are based on different versions of the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor.

title: 5 Hurt, Including Policeman, in a Hit-Run Incident
description: A van struck and injured a police officer, a pedestrian and three people riding in two different cars in a series of accidents on the lower East Side yesterday afternoon, the police said. Two men in the van fled but were captured.

title: Gangs of Armed Men in India Try Anew to Falsify Elections
description: Armed men in three cars pulled up to the voting place here, marched into the building and threatened to shoot the election official if the official did not give the gunmen the ballots. According to one account, the police were sleeping nearby and did not interfere.

title: Japan Asserts American-Style Clout in Toronto
description: Japan's presence at the seven-nation economic summit conference that opened here today is so pervasive that some of the Canadian hosts are referring to the Japanese as the next Americans.

title: Skyline Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included gains on the sale of property of $909,000 for the latest year and $406,000 for 1987.

title: Diane Beltz Wed To B. M. Jacobson
description: Diane Phyllis Beltz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Beltz of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruce M. Jacobson, the son of Judge and Mrs. Burton J. Jacobson of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Driscoll, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt Siegel officiated at the Estherwood estate in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $303,000 from the sale of real estate investments for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Abrams and Brawley Case: Political Future at Stake
description: If ever there was a man on the spot, it is New York State's Attorney General, Robert Abrams.

title: Evidence Supporting Nuclear Tests Is Challenged
description: A senior Federal scientist warned two years ago that arguments by the Government justifying the occasional explosion of stockpiled nuclear weapons to assure the weapons' reliability were on ''thin ground,'' according to documents made public yesterday.

title: Vicki Share Is Married To Michael Eric Fleiss
description: At Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J., Vicki Ellen Share, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Share of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Eric Fleiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel M. Fleiss of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Herbert Kavon and Cantor Morris Wolk officiated.

title: Tultex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1987.

title: Analogic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said in the latest quarter, net and revenue figures were favorably impacted by $6,558,000 and $10,232,724, respectively, due to the inclusion of the gain resulting from the sale to Siemans Medical Systems Inc. of an additional 25 percent interest in a patient monitoring technology joint venture. The latest and the year-ago 9-month periods' net and revenue figures include proceeds from the sale of a 25 percent interest in a patient monitoring technology joint venture, but the size of the proceeds for the 9-month periods was not disclosed.

title: Results Plus
description: Baseball

title: Review/Comedy; Robert Klein's Balance Of Sense and the Absurd
description: Robert Klein stands on the exact dividing line between two generations of stand-up comedians. On one side are toastmaster-quipsters like Bob Hope and Johnny Carson, who maintain an attitude of genteel decorum as they tweak human foibles. On the other are brilliant brats, from Robin Williams to Eddie Murphy, who have re-invented the image of the comedian, as a rude and raunchy surrogate rock star wallowing in cultural trash. At his most incisive, Mr. Klein partakes of the best of both worlds without actually falling into the gutter.

title: Violence Reported After Azerbaijanis 'Incite' Armenians
description: Violence between Azerbaijanis and Armenians broke out last weekend in a town near Yerevan, the Armenian capital, leaving 16 people hurt, radio reports from Yerevan said.

title: Cab Driver Makes an Arrest
description: A cab driver who witnessed a purse-snatching in Greenwich Village chased the getaway van and captured a suspect, the police reported.

title: Justices Back New York Law Ending Sex Bias by Big Clubs
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a 1984 New York City law aimed primarily at requiring the admission of women to large, private clubs that play an important role in business and professional life.

title: Lights at Wrigley Aug. 8
description: The Chicago Cubs announced today that they would play their first night game at Wrigley Field on Aug. 8, against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: U.S.-China Trade Talks
description: Americans preached the virtues of private enterprise while Chinese businessmen hawked their wares in the corridors of the Great Hall of the People today at the largest United States-China trade conference ever held.

title: SMALL FREEMAN AGENCY TAKES TOP CLIO AWARD
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners, the very small and very new New York advertising agency, received the coveted award for best national television advertising campaign last night at the 29th annual Clio Awards ceremony in New York.

title: Science of Courtship
description: The flippant lines that some men use to impress women may actually ruin their chances of landing a date, according to research by Dr. Michael Cunningham, a psychologist at the University of Louisville in Kentucky. But women can say just about anything and men will keep talking to them, his studies found.

title: Marcom Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $215,704.

title: Company News; California Rule Raises Questions
description: The California statute that has temporarily derailed B.A.T. Industries' $4.3 billion takeover bid for Farmers Group Inc. is a little-used law that is likely to create obstacles for other companies seeking to do business in the state, regulators and lawyers said today.

title: Christian-Marxist Dialogue Widens in U.S.S.R.; Let's Try Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: Pledge Allegiance to the Law
description: Vice President Bush seems determined to make an issue of Governor Dukakis's veto of a bill that would require Massachusetts teachers to lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance in school every day. As a Bush aide told Newsweek, ''We can't wait to do an ad on that one.''

title: Contras Reject Offer to Reopen Peace Talks
description: Contra rebels today rejected a proposal by the Sandinista Government to reopen peace talks and said the offer was linked to Washington's consideration of military aid for the rebels.

title: Echlin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Environmental Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From now on, it is not just the army. Everybody is now in the army because it is this army that is going to lead this country as it has to be led.'' - Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, declaring himself President of Haiti. [ A10:1. ]

title: Company News; Settlement Reached In Southland Case
description: The Southland Corporation has agreed to pay nearly $10 million to settle charges that a former division conspired with other producers to fix the prices of milk sold to Florida public schools. The Florida Attorney General, Bob Butterworth, said past and present officials of Velda Farms of Miami, which had been owned by the Dallas-based Southland, had acknowledged that the company participated in price fixing.

title: Damson Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said about $11.6 million of the latest quarter loss was attributable to a writedown to the net carrying value of the company's gas processing facilities, attributable primarily to the company's 11 percent ownership interest in Dorchester Master LP.

title: Finalco Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,623,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. The company changed its method of accounting for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96 issued during the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1987. The statement requires the use of current corporate income tax rates for deferred income taxes and has been applied effective July 1, 1987.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday misidentified a former president of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York who died on June 10, and referred incorrectly to his wife. He was William A. Howes; she is the former Helen Matteo.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Study in Strangeness
description: Leonard Pitt was mighty clever, yet ultimately not quite clever enough, on Sunday night at Performance Space 122. A mime and performance artist from San Francisco, Mr. Pitt appeared in ''Spleenix,'' a 40-minute solo directed and designed by Ellen Sebastian as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: Company News; Computer Trade-In Drive by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was planning a summer sales promotion from July 1 to Aug. 31 to persuade owners of I.B.M. PC models to upgrade to the new Personal System/2 product line.

title: Corporate Management Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Media Business; TV Guide Cable Edition
description: TV Guide will introduce on July 2 an edition tailored for cable customers in specific franchise areas. The publication, to be called Special Cable Edition-New York, will be marketed to subscribers of four cable systems in New York City, its general manager, William Deitch, said last week. Customers will be billed on their monthly cable bill.

title: TOP COMMANDER DECLARES HIMSELF PRESIDENT OF HAITI
description: Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who ruled Haiti for two years before yielding to a civilian President in February, seized power today and declared himself President of a military Government.

title: Court Bars Extradition In Technology Sale Case
description: A Canadian appeals court has ruled that a former California businessman accused by the United States of trying to sell advanced computer technology to the Soviet Union cannot be extradited.

title: Company News; Arkansas Best Bidding Disputed
description: The Razorback Acquisition Corporation, bested last week by Kelso & Company in bidding for the Arkansas Best Corporation, said that the competition had been unfair. In a letter to Arkansas Best, a trucking company based in Fort Smith, Ark., Razorback said it was informed by Arkansas Best late last Wednesday that the bid deadline was 6 P.M. on Thursday. The letter was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Icahn Loss On Texaco Conceded
description: Carl C. Icahn conceded yesterday that he had lost his proxy battle with the management of Texaco Inc. after Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which held the second-largest block of voting rights after Mr. Icahn, said it had voted for management.

title: Cutting Back on AIDS Drug May Hold Risks, Study Suggests
description: A STUDY in England has provided tentative evidence that reducing a patients' dose of the antiviral drug AZT can cause a temporary, dangerous resurgence of the AIDS virus.

title: Swapping Tax Credits For Housing
description: For the first time in at least two decades, a low-income housing complex is being built in New York City without a direct government subsidy.

title: U.S. Judge to Dismiss 25-Year Integration Suit
description: A Federal judge today agreed to dismiss the country's largest desegregation suit, paving the way for an end to the 25-year battle between the N.A.A.C.P. and the nation's second-largest school district.

title: The Man of 3,000 Faces Is Honored at Age 85
description: Nestled snugly in Al Hirschfeld's dining room the other day were Groucho Marx, Mary Martin, Jimmy Durante, Jackie Gleason, Eleanor Roosevelt, Margaret Truman, Winston Churchill, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Bernard Baruch, J. Robert Oppenheimer, Carl Sandburg, Pablo Picasso, Leopold Stokowski, Martha Raye, Ezio Pinza, Esther Williams, Noel Coward, L'il Abner, Daisy Mae, Jose Ferrer, Liberace, Superman, Pogo, Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall, Marilyn Monroe, Truman Capote, Danny Kaye, Richard Rodgers, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Frank Sinatra, Edward R.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, thetable of foreign stock quotations in Business Day on Saturday included incorrect numbers in some editions.

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Steady
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in very quiet trading yesterday, as market participants tried to divine whether the Federal Reserve has again tightened monetary policy.

title: Vac-Tec Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pirates Finally Show Mets Their Stuff
description: For nearly three months, the Pirates had stayed with the Mets like a shadow. But because they appeared only in the standings, their presence was more eerily curious than frightening.

title: Reporter's Notebook; A Brisk Dressing Down Over Not Dressing Up
description: The 14th economic summit conference, Brian Mulroney decided some months ago, was going to be different.

title: Subpoenas For 3 Major Contractors
description: Three large military contractors acknowledged today that they are under scrutiny by the Federal prosecutor in Virginia who is overseeing a major bribery and fraud investigation involving officials of the Pentagon.

title: A Rights Group Attacks Pretoria
description: The Government of South Africa has been stepping up its campaign this year against individuals and organizations monitoring human rights in that country, a rights group asserted in a report yesterday.

title: A Defendant Describes How He Shot a Witness
description: A jury in the Queens trial of three young men charged with murdering a crime witness were shown a videotape yesterday in which one defendant graphically and tearfully recalled how he and another man shot the witness, an elderly woman.

title: The Arts Festival; A Cry for Peace From Argentina
description: With music from Africa, South America and North America, the concert tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall by the New York Choral Society should live up to the internationalism of the First New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: Blount Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
In Haiti: No Democracy to Lose
description: Entrenched dictator deposed . . . Fragile green shoots of democracy sprout up . . . But violence swamps free elections, leading a few months later to a military coup and a new dictator.

title: Excerpts From the Declaration in Toronto
description: Following are excerpts from the political statement issued today by the seven leading industrialized democracies at the economic summit meeting:

title: Short-Term Debt Growing; Sallie Mae Yield Near 7.45%
description: The issuance of short-term debt securities with maturities of up to five years may accelerate this week, according to some underwriters. Many investors, convinced that interest rates are headed higher, can be expected to quickly snap up new short-term issues, the underwriters said.

title: State Dept. Labels Haitian Army Coup 'Blow to Democracy'
description: The United States today condemned the coup in Haiti, saying it was a ''serious blow to hopes for democracy in that troubled land.''

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Catholic Church Gains Step In Tax-Exemption Fight
description: The Supreme Court today gave the Roman Catholic Church a modest procedural victory in a case in which abortion rights advocates are seeking church records for use in a suit to strip the church of its tax-exempt status.

title: Review/Music; 'Tannhauser,' Done on a Budget
description: The Manhattan Opera Association's production of Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' Friday night at the William J. O'Shea Junior High School, reaffirmed that there are a lot of highly competent unknown singers in this city. Vocally, this presentation by one of New York's vest-pocket opera companies was at the very least respectable, on a level with a small German provincial theater like, say, Gelsenkirchen or Detmold.

title: Equity-Loan Bill Passes
description: The House today approved a bill imposing a series of consumer protection measures on financial institutions offering home equity loans, which have soared in popularity because of the new income tax law.

title: Saratoga Standardbreds Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $28,431. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $42,031. The company said year-ago earnings are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: New Test That Finds Hidden AIDS Virus Is a Sleuth With Value in Many Fields
description: THE human brain lay for 7,000 years in a Florida spring, but scientists using a new technique grew multiple copies of its remaining traces of genetic material to help puzzle out the identity of an ancient American.

title: Company News; Electrolux Withdraws Bid
description: The Swedish consumer products giant A.B. Electrolux, which was rejected twice in its efforts to acquire the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, has unexpectedly dropped out of the bidding for the bicycle and lawn mower maker based in Brentwood, Tenn. In a letter dated June 17 to

title: At a Jersey High School, Drugs Are Now Confronted
description: The wild 70's are history here at Summit High School. Roach Hill, once a popular spot for students to smoke marijuana before class, is clean. Students who still use marijuana or other drugs regularly are looked on as losers.

title: Santiago Journal; The Editor: Outspoken by Day, Muzzled by Night
description: When Juan Pablo Cardenas, a magazine editor, checked in recently for his usual night in jail under a sentence for offending the military, he was arrested on another charge and taken to jail in another town.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day on Saturday about a proxy contest at Farmers Group Inc. misstated the number of votes against a proposed takeover of the company by B.A.T. Industries. It was 26.8 million shares.

title: Members Only to Begin Get-Out-the-Vote Ads
description: Next Oct. 17, Members Only, a leading manufacturer of men's outerwear, will begin a three-week, $1 million-a-week advertising campaign aimed at getting out the vote for the national elections.

title: Workingmens Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $404,000 from a reduction of income taxes arising from carryforward of prior years' losses. There were no per share earnings for the year-ago periods as the bank did not convert to the stock form of ownership until the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Famiglia Brands reports earnings for 13wks to April 30
Helene Curtis Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the results reflect a revised policy assigning advertising and promotional costs to quarters within the fiscal year in proportion to sales. Annual results are not affected by this change. The year-ago results are restated.

title: Passport Travel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Rykoff-Sexton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Met Opera Plans Brooklyn Innovation
description: The Metropolitan Opera is planning monthlong experimental seasons at the newly restored Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, beginning in late spring of 1991.

title: Business People; Chief Gets Third Term At Coopers & Lybrand
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the Big Eight accounting firm, announced yesterday that it had named Peter R. Scanlon to a third term, continuing his leadership as chairman and chief executive until October 1991.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Is Indicted In Iran-Contra Investigation
description: The Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair today indicted the former Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica on charges of conspiracy and lying to Federal investigators.

title: Panel Proposes Stiffer Penalties For Bias Cases
description: After a 16-month study, a panel appointed by Governor Cuomo has recommended stiffer penalties for bias-related violence.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
description: The Fox Broadcasting Company, which is trying to start a fourth major television network, is likely to lose $80 million this year, $30 million more than it had anticipated, the chief financial officer of the News Corporation, has predicted.

title: Nation's Suburbs Blamed for Songbird Decline
description: LEAD: EVEN for Homo sapiens, a species obsessed with the visible, a forest is defined by its sounds, especially the chorus of bird song.

title: Bomb Blast Kills 3 in New Delhi Market
