In a petition to the court, the coach's attorney said the Browns had been considering divorce for some time, but waited because of the sensitive nature of his occupation and the team's competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, which the Jayhawks won to become national collegiate champions. Brown contended that news media attention drawn to his divorce proceedings could have been harmful to him and the Kansas program. (AP)

title: DISCOVERING THE 'NORMAL' IN THE WORLD OF THE DEAF
description: Despite, or because of, his long association with public television, beginning with a WNET contract in the early 1970's, Frederick Wiseman is an outspoken critic of the system. In testimony before a Senate communications subcommittee this year, he accused the Corporation for Public Broadcasting of, among other things, being unprofessional and often using panel processes that virtually guarantee mediocre programming. ''Personal politics, the buddy system, jealousy and pop ideology dominate the panel deliberations,'' Mr. Wiseman maintained.

title: Business Cards Tomorrow reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $624,900 from legal expenses and the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: On the Fashion Road With Bill Blass
description: OTHER people can charm the clothes off your back. Bill Blass can charm them right onto you.

title: Brazil Reports Debt Pact
description: Brazil said it had reached an accord with foreign bankers that would cut the interest on $62 billion debt and provide a fresh loan. Page D1.

title: STOCKS REBOUND AND DOW RISES BY 25.24
description: Stock prices rebounded yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25.24 points, to 2,109.17.

title: Results Plus
description: Soccer The Netherlands in Final: A goal by Marco Van Basten in the last minute of regulation time yesterday sent the Netherlands into the final of the European championship with a 2-1 victory over West Germany. Van Basten's score in the 89th minute settled the semifinal in Hamburg's Volksparkstadion after each side had tallied on a penalty shot. It was the first victory for the Netherlands over West Germany since 1956.(AP) Yachting New Yorker Triumphs: Congere, a 77-foot yacht owned by Bevin Koeppel of New York, won the Newport-to-Bermuda Race yesterday. Congere led a fleet of 119 sailboats, from 35 to 81 feet, on the 635-mile passage from Newport, R.I. Congere sailed across the finish line near St. David's Lighthouse at 7:39 A.M., Eastern Daylight time, for an elapsed time of 3 days 15 hours 24 minutes. Second to finish was the 80-foot Boomerang, owned by George Coumantarous of New York, at 8:59 A.M. Golf Champion Falls: John Vuono of Woodcrest yesterday defeated the defender, Jon Kudysch of the Hamlet, 2 and 1, in the opening round of the Union Savings Bank/Long Island P.G.A. Championship at Bethpage State Park. Vuono, however, failed to make the quarterfinals as he lost 2 and 1 to Carl Lohren of North Shore, the 1984 winner. Jim Albus of Piping Rock, a three-time winner of the title, eliminated Kevin Beatty of Glen Oaks, 3 and 2, and then beat Rod Heller of St. George's, 4 and 3. Amateur Qualifies: Jeffrey Thomas of the Plainfield West Country Club, a five-time New Jersey amateur champion, shot a five-over-par 77 yesterday for a 36-hole total of 146 in the United States Golf Association sectional qualifying at the Crab Meadow Golf Course in Northport, L.I. Thomas led two other qualifiers into the tournament, scheduled for July 11-16 at Jackson Hole, Wyo.: Ralph Howe 3d of the Middle Island C.C., who registered a 73-147, and P. J. Cowan of Pine Hills in Manorville, L.I., who carded a 76 for 148.

title: Flight International Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $47,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $400,000.

title: An Assertive Japan at the Summit
description: Exit Ronald Reagan in a display of harmony. Enter Noboru Takeshita with strength not previously seen from Japan. Symbolically, that's the story of the economic summit meeting in Toronto. All the leaders of the industrial world agreed to needed debt relief for the third world's poorest countries; it was an idea Washington had long resisted. Meanwhile, the new Japanese Prime Minister pressed an intriguing broader approach, looking to the biggest debtors as well.

title: Xytronyx Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
Court Backs Newsletter Regulations
description: A Federal appeals court ruled unanimously yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission could obtain court orders requiring investment newsletters to disclose if they had received certain types of payments from companies they praised in articles.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Nashville Legacy With her short-cropped hair and rock-star kineticism, the Canadian singer and songwriter K. D. Lang hardly fits the conventional ''total woman'' image of a female country music star. But Ms. Lang, who recently released her second album, ''Shadowland'' (Sire/Warner Brothers) has been acknowledged in and out of Nashville as one of the most powerful country voices to emerge in the 1980's.

title: LAKERS HOLD OFF PESKY PISTONS TO REGAIN THEIR TITLE
description: The Los Angeles Lakers tonight fulfilled the promise their coach made a year ago, when he said that his team would repeat as the National Basketball Association champion.

title: Article 770588 -- No Title
description: The Federal Government had a $22.46 billion budget deficit in May, after a $13.89 billion surplus in April that stemmed from a seasonal deluge of tax payments, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Alex Goldberger, Insurance Council Aide, 87
description: Alex Goldberger, a former executive director of the Council of Insurance Brokers of Greater New York, died Wednesday in Hollywood (Fla.) Memorial Hospital after a heart attack. He was 87 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: Party Leaders In Bronx Turn From Gentile
description: Democratic and Liberal Party leaders yesterday disavowed the candidacy of the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, and began searching for a new candidate to seek the Democratic nomination in the Sept. 15 primary.

title: Food Notes
description: Succulent Litchis

title: Compumat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Washington State Bond Issues Set
description: The State of Washington is offering $212 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Deposed Haitian Calls for Rejection of Dictatorship
description: The deposed President of Haiti, Leslie Manigat, called on the world's democracies today to reject the military dictatorship that sent him into exile and urged Haitians to continue struggling to achieve democracy.

title: 650-Year Sentence for Rapist
description: The so-called South Shore rapist was given up to 650 years in prison today by Judge Stuart Namm, who called him ''the most despicable man he has ever sentenced.'' But the man, Scott Carroll, a 27-year-old New York City factory worker, would likely not serve more than 50 years in prison because of a state ceiling on consecutive sentences. The case is believed to be the first time in New York that rape victims have identified their attacker from a tape recording. Mr. Carroll was convicted of raping four women and attempting to rape a 10-year-old girl.

title: Trammell's Slam Tops Yanks in 9th
description: In the long and lonely minutes that followed the Yankees' most disheartening defeat of the season, Dave Righetti sought refuge in the runway between the clubhouse and the dugout. He sat alone, his thoughts lost somewhere in the night, his mind perhaps replaying the final inning of a game that was too hard to forget.

title: Meese Urges More Resources To Insure Drug Prosecutions
description: America is gaining in the war on drugs but must insure that money is spent on prosecution and jails as well as in the seizure of illegal drugs, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told state attorneys general today.

title: Times Mirror Fills Position
description: Donald F. Wright, a broadcast and cable executive at the Times Mirror Company, was given responsibility today for supervising the company's smaller newspaper operations in the East. Publishers of The Hartford

title: DINING OUT With Michael Crawford; Feeding the Phantom's Appetites
description: THE dining predilections of famous ghouls and monsters is one field of gastronomic research that has yet to be mined. Frankenstein, in at least one movie, dug into a bowl of stew when he stopped at a blind man's house. Dracula's eccentric drinking habits are well documented, although he never showed much interest in stick-to-the-ribs Transylvanian cuisine. Wolfmen were appallingly indiscriminate, always chowing down on the neighbors' pets.

title: A Bazaar of Exotic Flavors Spices Life in Soviet Georgia
description: AT 8 o'clock on a warm spring morning, all is quiet in the central farmers' market in Tbilisi, capital of the Soviet Republic of Georgia. Vendors are still arranging their pyramids of hot peppers; sprinkling water on the bunches of deep green tarragon and relishing a few more bites of freshly made puri, the flat bread that is served with every meal.

title: Sports People; Federal Intervention
description: In a speech Monday by Representative Tom McMillen, Democrat of Maryland, the former college and pro basketball star, said that Federal involvement in collegiate athletics might be necessary if the National Collegiate Athletic Association fails to balance athletic and academic programs and achievements. In response, Richard Schultz, the executive director of the N.C.A.A., said that his association must let politicians know that it is doing a good job in order to keep the Federal government out of college athletics. Both were speaking at the N.C.A.A. Presidents Commission forum in Kissimmee, Fla. ''We have to do a better job with our Congressmen and Senators of making sure they understand. . . . some of the major progress that's taken place in the last two or three years on academic progress and graduation rates,'' said Schultz. (AP)

title: Price for 'Oz' Shoes Is Over the Rainbow
description: An anonymous man, outbidding a voice on a telephone line to the Christie's East auction house, paid $165,000 yesterday for a rather dowdy pair of crimson low-heel shoes, size 5B, which experts say pinched the feet of their owner.

title: The Welfare Consensus
description: After two decades of periodic attempts to overhaul a welfare system under which generations of poor Americans have lived unproductive lives on the dole, change suddenly appears within reach.

title: Company News; Dow-Exxon Plan
description: Dow Chemical U.S.A. and the Exxon Chemical Company said they had formed a joint venture to manufacture material for adhesives and sealants. The group will build a $20 million plant in Plaquemine, La., where Dow has a manufacturing operation. The companies will share equally in the capital investment and expenses of building the plant and in profits from marketing the styrenic thermoplastic elastomers it will produce, said L. Dennis McKeever, Dow vice president for polyolefins and elastomers.

title: AN AIDE TO ARAFAT COMES UNDER FIRE
description: A dispute has broken out within Palestinian guerrilla organizations over proposals put forward by a close aide to Yasir Arafat for negotiations with Israel.

title: Quick & Reilly Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Book Notes
description: Vietnam Warrior-Guru

title: Video Display Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $235,000. c-After income of $11,000 for the quarter and a loss of $46,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Israelis Shoot 3 Youths In Occupied Territories
description: Three Palestinian youths were shot today in the occupied territories, one of them by an Israeli civilian reportedly firing to chase away stone throwers.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Journalistic Ethics
description: Concerned that many magazine reporters who cover Congress are unwittingly violating the rules, the committee of correspondents that gives them their press credentials has tentatively decided to require that they disclose to the panel how much outside income they earn.

title: Accusations About Advisers Transform the Brawley Case
description: Two weeks after it appeared hopelessly mired, the Tawana Brawley mystery has taken another turn, landing the family's three advisers in the center of accusations that they have been perpetuating a hoax.

title: DEBATE HEATS UP ON COLORING FILMS
description: The war over the coloring of old black-and-white movies heated up today, as opponents and defenders of the coloring process testified before a House subcommittee. Legislators and members of the film industry maneuvered on several fronts to resolve an issue that has been simmering for more than a year.

title: Humana Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Micropro International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Gloria Agrin Josephson, 65, Lawyer, Dies
description: Gloria Agrin Josephson, a lawyer in Manhattan, died of lung cancer Monday at the New York University Medical Center. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge
description: There are two schools of thought about the appropriate behavior for dummy. Some ignore the course of the play, relaxing in preparation for the next deal. Others watch every move like a hawk, and they are better prepared for the post-mortem. If your bidding was suspect, you can perhaps put your partner on the defensive by pointing out that he could have made his contract.

title: Burma Orders Curfew After Riots in Capital
description: The authorities in Burma have imposed a curfew in Rangoon, the capital, after six people were killed and dozens were injured in rioting today, the state radio said. The curfew is to extend from dusk to dawn.

title: Methode Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
The Arts Festival; Dance And Video In a Pool
description: Daniel Larrieu may be the only internationally known choreographer who began his professional life as a gardener. But he is probably best known for the creation of ''Waterproof,'' a dance and video piece that takes place in and at the edge of a swimming pool.

title: Inquiry Latest Blow to McDonnell
description: Even before the Federal investigation of possible fraud and bribery in military procurement reached the doorstep of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation last week, John F. McDonnell, the company's new chairman and chief executive, had plenty to worry about.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Unit In a $475 Million Offering
description: A Manufacturers Hanover Corporation subsidiary is offering $475 million of debt securities backed by a pool of Visa and Mastercard credit card receivables through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Business People; Bone Marrow Company Names Chief Executive
description: Arthur J. Benvenuto's extensive experience in the pharmaceutical field and in top management led to his selection as chairman, president and chief executive of Marrow-Tech Inc., the company said Monday.

title: How to Cure Abandoned Car Blight
description: New York, like a number of other big cities, faces an epidemic of abandoned cars. With Albany's approval, a new plan to get tougher with owners of derelicts could provide an answer.

title: Half of Wheat, Barley and Oats In Northern Plains Lost to Drought
description: At least half the wheat, barley and oat crops in the northern Great Plains have been lost as heat and drought gain a tighter grip on the nation's farmland.

title: Latvian Cultural Leaders Issue Call for a Form of Home Rule
description: In one of the boldest nationalist appeals ever issued by an official Soviet group, unions representing writers and other cultural figures in the republic of Latvia have called on Moscow for a form of home rule.

title: STRIKING WRITERS CLASH OVER NEW CONTRACT OFFER
description: More than 300 members of the Writers Guild of America have called on the guild's 9,000 movie and television writers to accept an offer presented by the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers last week and end the 15-week-old strike.

title: MELLOW RETURN FOR MCENROE
description: For the first time in three years, the name J. P. McEnroe was posted on the green scoreboard behind the baseline on Court 1, which sent a rush of excitement through the stands at Wimbledon.

title: Education; Desegregation Lawsuit Ending After 25 Years
description: Civil rights officials said today that their decision to agree to drop a 25-year-old desegregation suit against the Los Angeles school district reflected a realization that remedies sought in the past would not work in a district where the proportion of white students has dropped to 17 percent from more than 65 percent.

title: 7 SUMMIT LEADERS AGREE ON POLICIES TO FOSTER GROWTH
description: Reaffirming their confidence that the world economy is looking uncommonly robust, the leaders of the seven biggest industrial democracies agreed today to a variety of measures to keep the growth going.

title: A Road Not Taken If at All Possible
description: ''WHENEVER James heard anyone complain about cookbook tours,'' said Marion Cunningham, speaking of the late James Beard, ''he always talked about the time he had to cook on an iron.'' It was the kind most people use on clothes.

title: Former Sharpton Aide Was Disturbed by 'Lies'
description: Perry McKinnon, a former aide to the Rev. Al Sharpton, has said that he was profoundly disturbed by ''lies'' surrounding the Tawana Brawley case, but that he still had no clear idea what had happened to Miss Brawley and little direct knowledge of any doubts about her case that might be harbored by her lawyers, advisers or family.

title: Review/Film; New Laws of Gravity Twist Humor, Too, in 'Roger Rabbit'
description: In a parallel universe near a Hollywood movie studio, the Toons make the rules. Toons are movie actors who also happen to be cartoon characters, second-class citizens by Hollywood standards but a force to be reckoned with just the same. They have their own laws of physics, their own laws of gravity and their own distinctive sense of humor. So a Toon who's under the influence is apt to change color and spiral upward until he hits the ceiling. A Toon sent flying through a window leaves an exact silhouette. Toon shoes, if unpacked by accident, start to dance.

title: Company News; Stake in NAC Re
description: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company. has bought a 5.9 percent stake in the NAC Re Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Kluge said he had purchased the shares of the reinsurance holding company, based in Greenwich, Conn., for investment purposes only. Mr. Kluge has been a director of NAC Re since 1985. NAC Re has 7.07 million shares outstanding.

title: Reviews/Music; Organist Offers Works by Bach In Debut Recital
description: Sylvain Barrette, an organist from Canada, made his New York debut Monday evening at the Church of St. John the Evangelist (348 East 55th Street, at First Avenue), where a nine-week International Organ Recitals series closes Monday. Mr. Barrette, who has won prizes in competitions in Canada and Europe, is an individualist, given to striking juxtapositions of color, and to readings that can seem either quirky or inspired, depending how one is disposed.

title: Sports People; 2-Sport Candidate
description: Florida State's all-America cornerback, Deion Sanders, said yesterday that he would sign a contract with the Yankees today and pursue a two-sport professional career like Bo Jackson. Sanders said his baseball contract would pay for his senior year in college and include a $1 million insurance policy should he suffer a baseball injury that forced him to lose value as a football player.

title: Societe Generale and Suitor Achieve a Tentative Peace
description: The two sides that have been battling for five months for control of Societe Generale de Belgique reached a tentative peace this morning, a half-hour before the company's annual meeting.

title: Savings Loss Is Put at $3.78 Billion
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that the savings and loan industry lost $3.78 billion in the first quarter of the year, prompting members of Congress to call for a re-examination of the adequacy of the industry's deposit insurance system.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Company News; Texaco Stock Rises Amid Speculation
description: Shares of Texaco Inc. jumped $1.625 yesterday, to close at $48.50, amid rumors that the company's management was planning a bigger restructuring or a bigger stock-buyback program than it had previously announced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 Leaders of industrial nations agreed on steps to keep the world economy growing, but they rebuffed President Reagan's demand for an end to governmental farm aid by the year 2000. Page A1

title: Jane R. Condliffe Is Bride Of Joe A. Morris, a Writer
description: The marriage of Jane Rosenthal Condliffe, a clinical social worker, to Joe Alex Morris, a writer and former newspaper reporter and editor, took place yesterday at the couple's home in Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. William B. Davidson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 15.1% on Big Board
description: Both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported gains in short interest for the month ended June 15.

title: Family Farmers Fear Urban Inroads
description: Members of 17 families who have owned their New Jersey farms continuously for more than 200 years met here today to talk about heritage, but the talk rapidly turned to the urban development that one day could take away their farms.

title: INSIDE
description: Latvians Seek Home Rule

title: Ottawa Ousts 17 Soviets Amid Spying Allegations
description: In what is being called the most serious case of its kind in Canada in years, the Government said today that that it had expelled or barred from returning to Canada a total of 17 Soviet diplomats involved in what Prime Minister Brian Mulroney described as ''improper and unacceptable behavior.''

title: McReynolds a Hit As Darling Breezes
description: For Kevin McReynolds, whenever there were runners in scoring position this season, everything he hit seemed to find its way into an opponent's glove. It happened again last night, only this time McReynolds got to trot somewhere other than directly back to the dugout. A Pittsburgh relief pitcher, Barry Jones, had caught his flyball, all right, while standing in the bullpen beyond the fence in left field.

title: American Medical Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $33,900,000 from repurchase of debt and a gain of $50,700,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the latest 9-month results include a gain in the second quarter of $20.4 million from the sale of a 35 percent interest in AMI Healthcare Group Plc, American Medical's United Kingdom subsidiary, offset by the provision of reserves of $20 million for the disposition and sale of several hospital facilities.

title: THOMAS SAVORS PERSONAL VICTORY
description: Isiah Thomas sat in the loser's steamy dressing room, surrounded by cameras and microphones, his hands gripping a bottle of unopened champagne.

title: Sports People; Riggleman Named
description: When the St. Louis Cardinals lost Lee Thomas, their player development director for the last eight years, to the Philadelphia Phillies, where he became their director of player personnel on Monday, the Cardinals were ready with a well-prepared replacement. Yesterday, they named Jim Riggleman, who has managed Cardinal minor league teams since 1982, most recently the Class AA Arkansas Travelers. (AP)

title: Survey Finds Sharp Drop In Tooth Decay in Young
description: Half the nation's schoolchildren have no cavities or other tooth decay in a continuation of gains that health officials say could mean the virtual end of dental disease as a major public health problem, a new Federal survey released today shows.

title: Education; About Education
description: The Business Roundtable, the influential national organization of corporate leaders, prefaced its recent report urging school improvements with the recommendation to its members to ''initiate no further studies on education.''

title: Battle on Solid-Waste Rules Erupting Again in Albany
description: Two months after debate on solid-waste legislation ended in a compromise that most lawmakers called inadequate, regulations proposed by the state's environmental department have touched off renewed argument over how to solve the state's garbage crisis.

title: Education; U.S. School Breakfast Program Lifts Test Scores
description: A Boston study that provides the first clear link between an improvement in pupils' academic performance and their participation in the Federal School Breakfast Program has helped begin a national movement to double the number of schools offering free and reduced-price breakfasts.

title: Good Sign on Inflation
description: The Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the second straight month in which it has slowed. Page D1.

title: James Street, Professor At Rutgers, Dies at 72
description: James H. Street, professor emeritus of economics at Rutgers University, died of prostate cancer Monday at John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Metuchen, N.J.

title: Morgan Stanley's 2-Part Offering
description: The Morgan Stanley Group Inc. is offering notes and debentures in two equal parts totaling $200 million through its subsidiary, Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Company News; Foster Wheeler
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman has decreased his stake in the Foster Wheeler Corporation to 6.2 percent from 8 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Edelman gave no reason for the sale of the Foster Wheeler shares. Mr. Edelman has been selling stock in the engineering and construction concern based in Livingston, N.J., after his holdings peaked at 11.9 percent. Between June 10 and June 17, Mr. Edelman sold 621,600 Foster Wheeler shares on the open market for prices ranging from $12.50 to $15.38 a share. The company's shares closed today at $15.375, up 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Company News; Nestle Extends Bid for Rowntree
description: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A. said it had decided against increasing its offer of $:2.1 billion, or $3.7 billion, to buy the British candy maker Rowntree P.L.C. despite a higher counterbid. In an announcement to the London Stock Exchange, Nestle said it was extending its offer for Rowntree for two more weeks to July 4.

title: Voice of Poland to Go to Munich To Spar With Radio Free Europe
description: Never one to shy from a good tussle, Jerzy Urban, the Polish Government spokesman, offered today to travel to the Munich headquarters of Radio Free Europe to discuss its reporting on Poland.

title: Prosecutors Try To Show Perjury In Wedtech Case
description: Prosecutors in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi introduced a sworn deposition yesterday in which Mr. Biaggi denied approaching Government officials on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Contras Lay Off Political Staff Workers
description: All employees of the Nicaraguan rebels' political support network around the world have received notices of dismissal as of June 30, a senior contra official said today.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday for the first time in nearly three weeks.

title: About Real Estate; A New Manhattan Office Tower Awaits First Tenant
description: In the latest Crocodile Dundee movie, the hero puts out in a rowboat to dynamite the fish in New York Harbor. The biggest flash, however, is seen not from an explosion but onshore, where a brilliant silver pillar rises over Battery Park at the tip of Manhattan.

title: Martin Upset Over Status
description: Billy Martin, who lost an important showdown with the Yankees' new general manager Monday, was still clearly upset today over his defeat. The Yankee manager said he would no longer take part in front-office decisions am and virtually laid the groundwork for his own dismissal, insisting he would step aside if asked but would never return as manager again.

title: T.V.A. Defends Layoff Plans
description: Top officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority sought to assure the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today that a major manpower reduction would not affect the struggling T.V.A. nuclear power program, although it is still plagued by technical problems.

title: Bush Campaign Tactics: Good Guy or Bad Guy?
description: After delivering a blistering attack on Michael S. Dukakis's record in crime-fighting, Vice President Bush sat in the middle of a cornfield in central Illinois recently and heralded the nonpartisan manner in which Democrats and Republicans were responding to the drought in the Midwest.

title: Rep. Chappell Says Lies Are Used to Tie Him to Investigation
description: Representative Bill Chappell Jr., the chairman of the House Defense Appropriations subcommittee, said today that press reports naming him as a target in the investigation of weapons procurement fraud were based on lies and were fueled by election-year politics.

title: Foreign Investment in U.S. Means Lost Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerusalem Journal; Palestinians' Bete Noire: How Will He Play in U.S.?
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin is to leave this week for a visit to the United States, where he will meet with senior Government officials and leaders of American Jewish organizations. By Mr. Rabin's own account, ''I'm not expecting very much applause.''

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: MY vegetable and herb garden on eastern Long Island has hit summer stride, and it seems that my cooking agenda these days is dictated primarily by which plants are tallest. Two herbs that are bullying their way around the patch are rosemary and chervil. Here is a quick chicken dish that uses both.

title: Sallie Martin, Singer, 92
description: Sallie Martin, a singer who was known as ''the mother of gospel music,'' died Saturday. She was 92 years old.

title: You See, a Neighbor's Tree Blocked a TV Channel...
description: Television can do strange things to a man out here in the hardwood hinterlands of northern Fairfield County. Particularly, big-dish 300-channel satellite TV.

title: Market Place; Outlook in Design Automation Field
description: THE pickup in capital spending in the nation's manufacturing sector is expected to help design automation companies, according to several analysts of this growing computer field.

title: Sallie Mae Note Cleared
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has ruled that a debt instrument resembling a futures contract and proposed by the Student Loan Marketing Association, often called Sallie Mae, can be traded off futures exchanges.

title: Littlefield Adams & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $47,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $57,000.

title: 5 Fuller Plays Coming To Black Arts Festival
description: The Negro Ensemble Company will present the first of a series of five new plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning dramatist Charles Fuller at the National Black Arts Festival in Atlanta from July 29 to Aug. 7.

title: Brazil Sees $62 Billion Debt Accord
description: Brazil has concluded negotiations with its foreign bank creditors on a $62 billion rescheduling agreement, Finance Minister Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega said today.

title: Adolfo Embraces 'Reality' for Fall
description: LIKE most other designers, Adolfo has simmered down for fall. ''After the fun comes the reality,'' he said Monday at the St. Regis Hotel. The reality, according to Adolfo, means chemises, dinner suits and trousers, with an emphasis on black.

title: Arbitron 'People Meter' To Measure Purchases
description: The Arbitron Ratings Company announced yesterday that it would introduce a ''people meter'' next year that will not only measure television audiences but also what products the viewers are buying.

title: Wimbledon; Cash Endures For 5-Set Victory
description: In Argentina, grass is for picnics, not playing tennis. In all of South America, for that matter, red clay is the preferred surface, which might explain why Javier Frana absent-mindedly tapped his shoes with his racquet today during his match against Pat Cash of Australia.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Metro Matters; 16 Months in Jail And the Story Of a Father's Lie
description: Now, for the first time, Saleh Rohany's two young daughters will learn the truth about why their father suddenly left home in 1986.

title: Tax Panel Votes Return Of School Aid
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to restore the tax exclusion for tuition payments made under company-sponsored education assistance programs. But in extending the exemption through the end of 1990, lawmakers agreed to restrict the benefit significantly.

title: Alabama Power To Offer Bonds
description: The Alabama Power Company is offering $150 million in first-mortgage bonds due in 2018, won in a bidding by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: GRAINS CONTINUE ADVANCE AS COTTON AND SOYBEANS DIP
description: Prices of grain, soybeans, livestock and cotton yesterday continued to reflect in divergent ways the drought in much of the nation.

title: The Greenhouse Effect? Real Enough.
description: A fierce drought is shriveling crops from Texas to North Dakota and has shrunk the Mississippi to its lowest levels on record. Dry years are part of nature's cycle. Still, it's time to take seriously another possible influence - the warming of the atmosphere by waste gases from a century of industrial activity. Whether or not the feared greenhouse effect is real, there are several preventive measures worth taking in their own right.

title: Casey's General Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 3 cents a share from changes in accounting for the depreciation life of certain plant and equipment. The company said earnings in the latest fourth quarter were affected by tighter margins in retail gasoline due to a merchandising program.

title: 7.1% Zenith Stake Acquired By an Investor Partnership
description: A partnership led by the New York arbitragers Herbert B. Abelow and Nicholas L. Ihasz said today that it had a 7.1 percent stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation.

title: PRAGUE TOUGHENS STAND ON RIGHTS
description: Czechoslovakia's expulsion of 32 foreign participants at a human rights conference indicates an increasingly harsh atmosphere in Prague toward independent movements for human rights and other causes.

title: L.I. Authority Backs Accord On Shoreham
description: The Long Island Power Authority today gave its approval to the accord between New York State and the Long Island Lighting Company to close the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Fire in Egypt Kills 47 Pilgrims
description: A fire caused by sparks from a food stall killed 47 Christian pilgrims who had camped outside a monastery on Tuesday to pay homage to the Virgin Mary, a security officer said today.

title: New Playground Accessible To Children in Wheelchairs
description: Youngsters in wheelchairs will soon be able to play side by side with other children when a specially designed playground at Holmes Elementary School opens to the public.

title: Consumer Rates; Yields Flat During Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly flat for the week ended yesterday. Savings rates are virtually at a standstill in most major banks, except in the Northeast, where some institutions are paying higher yields to support commercial and residential loan demands.

title: A Film Trade Between U.S. And Soviets
description: Representatives of the Soviet and American film industries signed an agreement here today for the most extensive exchange of feature films ever negotiated between the two countries.

title: 10 Die in Burma Riots; State Dept. Notes Concern
description: Riots in Rangoon that claimed the lives of 10 people Tuesday are much more serious than riots earlier this year in the Burmese capital, State Department officials said today.

title: Personal Health
description: The summer heat has finally enveloped most of the country, sending millions of Americans scurrying for cool, refreshing treats. Manufacturers and market analysts report that the demand for ice cream and other frozen desserts is up, both seasonally and annually. Americans now consume an average of more than 22 quarts of ice cream a year, about a cup every four days.

title: Review/Music; Survey of the 20th Century Ends
description: In four programs put together as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has climbed, plateau by plateau, from the first decade of this century to the present moment. If music progressed according to chronology, we ought now to be standing on a dizzying height, breathing heady, rarefied air. Unfortunately, Tuesday evening's concert at Alice Tully Hall did not validate such a simplistic view. Rather, it left one wondering if, after 88 years of huffing and puffing, 20th-century music may be still at the base camp.

title: Brenner Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CSP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Sports People; Looking Again
description: On a nine-game losing streak and having won just 3 of 15 games since dismissing Dick Williams as manager on June 6, the Seattle Mariners are beginning a search for their third manager of the season. The next manager would replace Dick Snyder, who was hired on an interim basis. ''Circumstances force this on us,'' said Church Armstrong, the club president, who prepared to return to Seattle from Texas yesterday after watching the Mariners score only 10 runs in 8 straight road losses. ''When I get back home, I will start making calls.'' (AP)

title: Latest at Tupperware: Shopping by Catalogue
description: Even icons must change with the times. Two weeks ago, a small sampling of Americans got a Tupperware shop-by-mail catalogue. For the first time since 1951, customers could buy the famous plastic food containers, which come with a lifetime guarantee, without having to go to a party.

title: Testimony Resisted in Brawley Case
description: A man who said he had eavesdropped on Tawana Brawley's lawyers balked yesterday at testifying before a Federal grand jury investigating possible fraud in the case, according to law-enforcement officials familiar with the inquiry.

title: How Feud Between Guiliani and Gentile Started and Deepended
description: The controversy between a Federal prosecutor and the Bronx District Attorney over confidential information in Federal Bureau of Investigation files and who leaked it has become a political version of a barroom brawl.

title: Brazil Ousts Petrobras Head
description: The Government dismissed the president of the state oil company, Petrobras, on Tuesday, the presidential palace has announced.

title: Calendar: Summer Pottery Instruction
description: Summer Pottery Program, Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street at Bleecker Street; 212-242-4106.

title: When Inspiration Strikes Twice
description: A. Tuscana chair by Piero Sartogo for Saporiti, introduced in 1986.

title: Cape Canaveral Journal; Holding Their Breath for Space Leap
description: When the space shuttle Challenger exploded almost 29 months ago, killing its seven-member crew, the whole of America shared a sense of anguish. Few places outside the hometowns of the crew members, however, took the loss as personally as the Cape Canaveral area, where the Kennedy Space Center is situated.

title: Dukakis Avoids Taking a Stand On No. 2 Post
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis danced around the issue of the Vice Presidency today, saying that the Rev. Jesse Jackson was under ''very serious'' consideration and that his lack of government experience did not disqualify him from the running.

title: Reaction to Frantic 911 Call Was Delayed, Police Admit
description: New York City police officials acknowledged last night that there had been a delay in the police response to a frantic 911 call for help Tuesday night from a woman who was shot to death shortly afterward in her Queens home.

title: Review/Concert; 2 Masses Approach Folk Music
description: A pleasant approximation of folk music came to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. The New York Choral Society offered two masses - Father Guido Haazen's ''Missa Luba'' and Ariel Ramirez's ''Misa por la Paz y la Justicia'' - both rife with bright folk melodies, as well as three Afro- American work songs sung by Pamela Smith, a contralto, and a set of Argentine pop songs written by Mr. Ramirez and other composers.

title: The Fight Crowd That Will Be at Home
description: ON Monday night in Atlantic City, while the high rollers leave the casinos for the Convention Center and the Tyson-Spinks fight, and movie-theater lines bulge with fans impatient for the closed-circuit broadcast, a new breed of spectator will be preparing to watch.

title: Pension Agency Barred From Making LTV Pay
description: A Federal district judge ruled yesterday that the LTV Corporation could not be forced by a Federal agency to finance and administer more than $2 billion in pension obligations.

title: Company News; Lipton Acquisition Blocked by Court
description: R.C. Bigelow Inc. said that a Federal appeals court injunction on Tuesday had blocked Thomas J. Lipton Inc. of Englewood Cliffs., N.J., from acquiring Celestial Seasonings Inc., pending Bigelow's appeal of the dismissal of its challenge to the acquisition. In reversing a United States District Court ruling and granting a stay, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, found that Bigelow has a substantial chance of prevailing on the merits of its appeal, Bigelow said in a news release.

title: CANADA INDICATES RUSSIANS SOUGHT U.S. NAVAL SECRETS
description: Canadian officials said today that Soviet diplomats had tried to infiltrate a United States-owned military contractor in Montreal that has access to highly classified American naval technology.

title: Company News; Edelman Reduces Stake in Payless
description: A group led by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman has lowered its stake in Payless Cashways Inc. to 8.1 percent from 9.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman gave no reason for the sale of the shares of the building supply chain based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Wacoal Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to March 31 from Aug. 31. The latest period consisted of only 7 months but last year consisted of 12 months and ended Aug. 31. The results are in U.S. currency and for the latest period the exchange rate on March 31 was 125 yen equals U.S. $1.00 and for 1987 the exchange rate on Aug. 31 was 142 yen equals U.S. $1.00. The share earnings are in American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS is equal to 5 shares of Wacoal common stock.

title: AIDS-Infected Marine Sues U.S. Over Transfusion of Tainted Blood
description: A Marine officer infected with the AIDS virus is suing the Federal Government for $55 million, alleging that Navy doctors gave his wife an AIDS-tainted blood transfusion that eventually killed her and their son and caused his condition.

title: Bank Bidder Gives Irving A Deadline
description: Bank of New York executives, disappointed with Irving Bank's inconclusive response to their revised merger offer, said yesterday that the conditions outlined by Irving late Tuesday were yet another tactic intended to prevent the takeover.

title: The Media Business; Astoria Studio Seeks Partner
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company said yesterday that it had been retained by Kaufman Astoria Studios Inc. to find a strategic partner for the production and communications complex. The studio is the largest full-service video and film production operation in New York City, with more that 500,000 square feet of work space at its Queens location.

title: English Charm, Classic Execution
description: Anthony P. Browne, a British-born interior designer who counts among his clients the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and the Washington hostesses and fund-raisers Evangeline Bruce and Deeda Blair, makes achieving classic English design look easy.

title: Drought Disaster Covers 40% of Nation's Counties
description: The Agriculture Department today added 102 counties to the list of drought disaster areas and declared that the drought emergency exists in more than 40 percent of the nation's counties.

title: Company News; ITT to Buy Unit Of Allis-Chalmers
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said it had agreed to sell its pump business for $71 million to the ITT Corporation, marking the final asset sale in its Chapter 11 reorganization. Allis-Chalmers filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on June 29, 1987, and in January sold its solid processing equipment and minerals systems businesses to Sweden's Boliden A.B. for $97.9 million.

title: Steinbrenner Weighs Move; Is There a Martin In Yanks' Future?
description: The man who will ultimately decide whether Billy Martin's fifth term as Yankee manager will conclude soon or continue insists he has not made up his mind. But George Steinbrenner has begun to weigh the matter, and if history is any kind of barometer, Martin's tenuous future may already be decided.

title: Guggenheim Plan Upheld
description: A State Supreme Court justice has upheld the city's approval of the proposed expansion of the Guggenheim Museum.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; In Praise of C-Span
description: After a decade in service, the proceedings of the United States Government as recorded by the C-Span network may have become somewhat humdrum for television consumers in the capital, but in the country beyond it works such wonders as inspiring a retired psychotherapist in Westchester County to write verse.

title: No Headline
description: Forced by a tight labor market to rely increasingly on immigrant workers, a growing number of employers across the country are taking on the additional role of English teacher.

title: A Plant-Closings Bill Worth Passing
description: The political fallout from President Reagan's veto of the trade bill has just hit the Senate floor. His main objection was an amendment that would require businesses anticipating large layoffs or plant closings to give 60 days' notice. His veto was a political windfall allowing Democrats to paint Republicans as uncaring plutocrats.

title: Parent & Child
description: WHEN Sharon Satterfield's daughter was 11 years old, she asked her mother how old she should be before having sex. Dr. Satterfield was taken aback, even though her work as a child psychiatrist at the Program in Human Sexuality at the University of Minnesota should have prepared her for the question.She hadn't expected it till her daughter was older.

title: Company News; Fort Howard Bid Weighed
description: The Fort Howard Corporation, a paper products company, said yesterday that some of its managers intend to explore the possibility of acquiring the company in a leveraged buyout with the help of third parties. The company, based in

title: Corrections
description: A comedy review on Tuesday gave an incorrect closing date for ''An Evening With Robert Klein.'' The final performance will be at 8 P.M. Monday at the Circle in the Square Theater in Manhattan.

title: Tagged Sharks for the Record
description: IT has been 15 years or so since Jack Casey of the National Marine Fisheries Service and I, after a night of too much red wine and spaghetti, went forth in a chartered boat to tag sharks off Rhode Island. That was my first and only trip in which the goal was to affix dart tags into as many of those fish as possible, and I remember it vividly.

title: Finance Briefs; Debt
description: Columbia University said it planned to enter the debt market later this month with a $50 million issue of a taxable medium-term note program. The Morgan Stanley Group Inc. will be the agent for the program.

title: Reagan Remarks Insult American Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 White Men Attack Black Man With Bats and Sticks on S.I. Street
description: A black man walking home from work early yesterday was attacked and beaten by six white men wielding baseball bats and sticks on Staten Island, the police said. Three men were arrested and charged with assault in the incident, which the police said was racially motivated.

title: Business People; A Banking Star Moves To Societe Generale
description: Ever since he joined Chase Manhattan Bank 25 years ago, Herve de Carmoy seemed destined for the upper reaches of European business.

title: Results Plus
description: Soccer Soviet Union Reaches Final: Gennadi Litovchenko and Oleg Protasov scored three minutes apart in the second half and the Soviet Union beat Italy, 2-0, yesterday at Stuttgart, West Germany, to advance to the final of the European championships. The Soviet team will play the Netherlands, who beat West Germany, 2-1, on Tuesday. The final is Saturday in the Olympic Stadium in Munich. Litovchenko put the Russians ahead in the 60th minute after several Italian errors, and Protasov scored his second goal of the tournament in the 63d minute. The Soviet central defender, Oleg Kuznetsov, was given a yellow card card and will miss the final.(AP) Golf Albus Advances: Jim Albus of the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I., who is a three-time winner of the Union Savings Bank/Long Island P.G.A. championship, advanced to the final by defeating Bernie Kosinski of Richmond County, 3 and 2, yesterday at Bethpage State Park. Albus, who routed Gil McNally of Garden City Golf Club, 7 and 5, in the quarterfinals, will oppose Mike Joyce of Huntington, L.I., in the 18-hole finals. Joyce, another former champion, advanced with a 4 and 3 triumph over his brother, Tom, of Glen Oaks.

title: Some 'Tough Choice'
description: Michael Dukakis has a favorite phrase: ''tough choices.'' In a peekaboo appearance before a foreign policy group last week, the Democratic candidate gruffed out ''tough choices'' nine times. That was presumably on the theory that repetition makes reputation.

title: Amfac Adopts 'Poison Pill' Plan
description: Amfac Inc., the hotel, retail and Hawaiian real estate concern, said its directors had adopted a ''poison pill'' to ''protect against abusive takeover tactics.'' Amfac's defensive measure would go into effect if any party acquires 15 percent or more of the company's stock or begins a tender offer.

title: Fighters Unflustered by a Flurry of Questions
description: Dressed in a black warm-up suit and shimmying to rock music, Michael Spinks entered the theater at Trump Plaza for a final news conference before he fights Mike Tyson for the heavyweight title Monday night.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said second quarter performance reflects continued strength in the home building operations in both California and France and a significant increase in revenue from the French commercial operations, including the sale to investors for $372 million of a twin-tower office and commercial complex now under construction in France.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Braniff Inc., Dallas, a subsidiary of Dalfort Corp., said its board had approved the previously announced merger proposal from a group formed by Paine Webber Group Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; Sympathy for Yankee Fans
description: ANYBODY who spent a childhood cringing at Mel Allen's blaring of a Ballantine Blast or a White Owl Wallop does not easily feel sorry for Yankee fans. There is a generation of aging Brooklyn Dodger fans that still feels Joe DiMaggio's spikes running up and down its collective spine.

title: Bush Talks Tough on Crime, Criticizing Prisoner Furlough Program
description: Continuing a series of speeches around the country on crime and drugs, Vice President Bush expressed contempt today for civil libertarians ''who show more compassion for the criminals than they do for the victims of crime.''

title: HEAD OF DEMOCRATIC UNIT WAS 57
description: Richard P. Conlon, executive director of the Democratic Study Group in the House of Representatives, one of the most influential staff members in Congress, died Sunday in a boating accident on the Chesapeake Bay.

title: Bid for Gillette Held Possible
description: One or more of the potential suitors of the Gillette Company in 1986 may be back this fall after two-year standstill agreements expire. Gillette signed the agreements with nine potential acquirers when it was fending off Revlon Group.

title: Ailing Texas Savings Units Lure Out-of-State Investor
description: A healthy, acquisition-minded Phoenix savings bank, Merabank F.S.B., today became the first financial institution outside Texas to invest in that state's ailing savings and loan industry under a Federal program.

title: John E. Nidecker, 75, Ex-Presidential Aide
description: John E. Nidecker, a White House aide in the administrations of Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, and later a lay brother of the Episcopal Church, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Shady Grove Adventist Hospital in Rockville, Md., after a long bout with lung cancer. He was 75 years old and lived in Rockville.

title: Review/Art; The Richest Degas Show Ever Opens in Ottawa's New Museum
description: The Degas exhibition in Ottawa is a glorious affair, and one more than worthy of the new National Gallery of Canada, which opened May 22 to universal acclaim. On a fine summer evening that new gallery is a sight to see as it rides above the Ottawa River, all soft light and clear glass and delicate fantastication. A perfect foil in those respects for the Gothic Parliament buildings that face it across the park, it also turns out to be a museum in which works of art of every date and sort, from antiquity to our own day, are perfectly at home.

title: Baseball; McGwire Homer Sparks Athletics
description: Mark McGwire hit a three-run homer and Dave Stewart continued his mastery of the Milwaukee Brewers to gain his 10th victory as the Oakland Athletics completed a three-game sweep with a 6-2 victory today.

title: New Haitian Regime Reportedly Jails 16 Foes
description: The new military regime in Haiti has jailed 16 supporters of the civilian Government that was overthown earlier this week, former aides to the deposed President said today.

title: All '89 Continentals To Be Manufactured With Dual Air Bags
description: Air bags will be standard equipment on driver and passenger sides of front seats on 1989 Lincoln Continentals, the Ford Motor Company said today, a move that safety advocates said would lead to wider adoption of the bags.

title: Judge to Hear North's Plea for Secrets
description: The Federal judge in the Iran-Contra case today signaled his determination to go ahead with the trial of Oliver L. North, ordering the former White House aide to specify which Government secrets he wants to disclose in court.

title: U.S. FINDS 3 GUILTY OF ARMS DEALINGS
description: Three New York arms dealers were found guilty yesterday of Federal racketeering charges for plotting to ship military equipment illegally to the Soviet Union, Poland, Iraq and Argentina. Of the four shipments, only the one to Argentina actually took place.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo May 31 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago figures are restated to reflect an accounting change. The latest year included a $179 million after-tax writedown, recorded in the second quarter of 1988, resulting from the previously mentioned rate settlement.

title: Mexican Stock Funds Missing
description: Mexico's Stock Exchange said today that it had discovered irregularities in its operations division and that about $7 million was missing.

title: Firstbank in Denver
description: Firstbank System Inc. of Minneapolis signed an agreement Tuesday to buy an 88 percent stake in the Denver-based Central Bancorporation from Ameritrust of Cleveland for $135 million. Firstbank will also buy the interests of minority investors for $17.5 million, bringing the total purchase price to $152.5 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TBWA Named Agency For General Biscuit Line
description: TBWA Advertising, an international ad agency with a Paris office, has been named agency for the LU cookie line from General Biscuit Brands of Elizabeth, N.J., and Oakland, Calif.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; After the Victory, Los Angeles Loses Its Usual Cool
description: They say Los Angeles is a laid-back town, but for the last 24 hours the city has dropped that facade.

title: Civil Service Restraints Are Needed in School Building Program; Tots in the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Life in the 30's
description: ON a trip to the zoo last week, when, as one of two adults, I was frantically trying to keep track of four children who seemed to disappear faster than soft ice cream on a hot day, a thought occurred to me that I have often thought before: there does not exist in the world sufficient compensation for an elementary schoolteacher.

title: Jackson Calls for a National Health Care Plan
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today proposed a ''new direction'' in the nation's health system under which a single federally administered program would guarantee care to all Americans.

title: Canonie Environmental Servces reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
John Collins, 85, Dies; A Catholic Lay Leader, Dies
description: John Timothy Collins, a retired executive in the vending machine business and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died of heart failure Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Panther Being Studied Dies
description: A panther wearing a radio collar for a study of the large cats in Everglades National Park has been found dead, near where she bore a litter, park officials say. Bite wounds indicated the animal, one of seven in the park with the collars had been in a fight, possibly with another panther. Her kittens were not found.

title: Western Culture Course Began in Indoctrination
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; New Quartet by Schuman
description: A tiny audience heard an interesting evening of string quartet music Tuesday at the 92d Street Y, where the Orford String Quartet gave William Schuman's Fifth String Quartet its first hearing as part of the New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: Currency Markets; The Dollar Posts a Big Advance
description: The dollar surged against all major currencies in aggressive trading yesterday, bolstered by the outcome of the economic summit conference in Toronto.

title: Prosecutor in Inquiry on Pentagon Is Said to Hedge on House Targets
description: The Federal prosecutor leading the investigation of fraud and bribery in military procurement assured Congressional leaders today that no subpoenas, search warrants or wiretaps had been ordered against any member of Congress. But he declined to confirm or deny that members of the House were under scrutiny in the inquiry, some lawmakers who were present at the meeting said.

title: Ghost Writing Is a Fact Of Political Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column yesterday gave incorrect dates for performances by Laibach, a Yugoslav rock group, at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street. The performances are at 9 P.M. tomorrow and Saturday.

title: E.P.A. Proposes to Protect Water by Limiting an Insecticide
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed rules today to limit the contamination of underground water by the insecticide aldicarb, a move the agency said could set a precedent for the protection of water supplies from other pesticides.

title:
Business People;
Wall Street Manager Is Deep in Scherer Fight
description: LEAD: Frank A.J. (Tony) Cilluffo is well known on Wall Street as a successful money manager, but he has remained, primarily at his own insistence, relatively unknown to the wider investment public.

title: Angola Eases Stand on a Cuban Pullout
description: In a potentially significant change, Angola said today that it was willing to negotiate the withdrawal of Cuban troops from its territory without first getting an assurance that the United States would stop support for Angolan guerrillas.

title: In a Heat Rare Even for June, Tempers Are Well Done
description: If the angry motorists and the exhaust fumes don't do him in, said Vincent Judge, a New York City traffic agent, then the heat surely will.

title: Review/Television; Kuralt Looks Back to August 1969
description: The team of Robert (Shad) Northshield, executive producer, and Charles Kuralt, correspondent, was the key ingredient in the success and prestige that the weekly magazine ''Sunday Morning'' gained for CBS News. Both men are accomplished veterans of the television-news scene, but, frustratingly enough, they have been unable to find a prime-time format to make the most of their talents. Their latest effort is ''Try to Remember,'' the pilot for which can be seen tonight at 8. Once again, fellows, it's back to the drawing board.

title: How the Years Fly By
description: William Wadsworth, thou shouldst be living at this hour! A business called Priority Management Pittsburgh has released a report about how in getting and spending we lay waste our powers. ''The world is too much with us, late and soon,'' you wrote. Here's what Priority Management discovered: Over the course of a lifetime, the average American spends a year looking for misplaced objects. (Cleaners' slips, no doubt, and glasses and checkbooks.) Eight months is spent opening junk mail. (Some people might find that figure a little low.) And two years are lost trying to return the phone calls of people who never seem to be in.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages on Tuesday about horse racing misidentified the filly that is the first offspring of Slew o'Gold to race. The filly is named Island Escape. Her dam is Angel Island. Yesterday a correction in this space misidentified Island Escape's sire in some editions. He was Slew o'Gold, not Devil's Bag.

title: The AIDS Quilt: Adding Personal Notes to a Poignant Public Message
description: Visitors to the exhibition of the Names Project Quilt at Pier 92 writing on pieces of the quilt reserved for notations. The quilt, 1,700 individual 3 feet by 6 feet panels each bearing the name of an AIDS victim, is at the pier, at the foot of West 52d Street, as part of a national tour. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)

title: INSIDE
description: Contra Split Deepens A contra political leader said he would represent officers and others who want a new military commander, deepening a dispute. Page A14. Vietnam Names Hard-Liner Vietnam's new Prime Minister reportedly directed purges in the ruling Communist Party. Page A12. Money Woes for Hospitals More hospitals are going out of business because of curbs on Medicare payments, a study says. Page A17.

title: Baker Voices Trade Doubts
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d cast doubt today on the ability of countries to open up trade in agriculture. His remarks came just one day after the Group of Seven industrial nations resisted Reagan Administration appeals to work toward eliminating export aid to farmers.

title: BOMB WOUNDS 10 IN JOHANNESBURG
description: Ten people were wounded today when a bomb exploded in a downtown Johannesburg amusement arcade. The blast was another in a series of urban guerrilla attacks that appear to have been conducted without regard for civilian casualties.

title: Afghan Rebel Sees Peril in U.N. Aid
description: An Afghan guerrilla commander says he has told the United Nations that its top priority in Afghanistan should be the creation of a broad-based coalition government to replace the Marxist regime of President Najibullah, and not the provision of aid to Afghanistan.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: U.S. Explodes Turkeys As Fireworks Warning
description: Tourists at the Washington Monument flinched in surprise Tuesday as Federal safety officials blew two turkey carcasses to bits in a demonstration of the dangers of fireworks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two Vice Chairmen Named at Thompson
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has been struggling along of late without a vice chairman, has been given two by its chairman and chief executive, Burton J. Manning. The former executive vice presidents are particularly important because they will serve in place of a chief operating officer.

title: A New Lease for 42d Street
description: The complex project to restore 42d Street's long-gone glamour stirred with life on Monday with the signing of development agreements for a new phase in the life of New York City's best-known thoroughfare. It's cause for celebration.

title: The Name of the Rose Is Elizabeth Scholtz
description: FOR more than a year, the best-kept secret in the garden world has been the existence of a new golden hued rose, named Elizabeth Scholtz in honor of the director emeritus of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Mexicans Seize Heroin
description: The Mexican police seized 15 pounds of pure heroin and arrested three Hong Kong Chinese at Mexico City's international airport, a police official said today.

title: International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Some Precedents Exist For Murdoch Trust Plan
description: By proposing to place his Boston television station in a trust, Rupert Murdoch plans to take a rather unusual step to resolve his problems with the Federal Communications Commission, which bars ownership of newspapers and broadcast stations in the same market.

title: A Three-Day Smorgasbord of Crafts
description: David Ward, a ceramic artist, maintains that his work has two important functions: to collect smiles and to collect dust.

title: Airbus Deal Seen
description: Airbus Industrie, the West European aircraft consortium, is expected to sign a sales contract for three A-310 jets with East Germany's Interflug airline in Toulouse, France, on Friday, industry experts said. Airbus received the go-ahead for the sales earlier this month from the Western alliance's Coordinating Committee for Multinational Export Control, diplomats said last week. An Airbus spokesman refused to comment.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Rulings Curb Protection In White-Collar Crimes
description: The Supreme Court issued two decisions today narrowing the protection against compelled self-incrimination for suspects in white-collar crimes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Russians ousted by Canada for spying were involved in an effort to penetrate the offices of a United States-owned military contractor that has access to classified American naval technology, Canadian officials said. Page A1

title: Home Shopping Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Bridge
description: Some recent history may be on the minds of some American players next year.

title: Nahama & Weagant Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
In War on Drinking, It's Beer for Moscow
description: The Moscow City Council has decided to open 133 new beer bars and automatic beer dispensers in a softening of the Kremlin anti-alcohol campaign, the weekly Moscow News reported today.

title: A Book Of Bovine Madness
description: EMILY GWATHMEY first felt ''the cows coming to me'' about four years ago, when she was spending more and more time leaning over Anthony Babinski's farm fence in Bridgehampton, L.I., staring at the herd of dairy cows and thinking about documenting her passion for bovines. The result is ''Wholly Cow!'' about to be published by Abbeville Press ($19.95).

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Backer Chief Denounces Repetition
description: LARRY LIGHT is the kind of adman consumers could grow to love. If it were up to him there would be no more of those repetitive, nerve-grinding commercials typified by ''Fill it to the rim with Brim'' and ''Ring around the collar.''

title: Three Sentenced in Bomb Plot
description: Three Canadians who smuggled a bomb into the United States were sentenced today to up to 16 years in prison.

title: Gooden Sweats but Mets Win
description: The potential for being burned was there all afternoon, and it had nothing to do with the fact that the sky was hazy and the temperature was 94 degrees. Indeed, Dwight Gooden wasn't safe from the conditions even as he sat in the cool comfort of the clubhouse.

title: Herb Garden, an Oasis in Bronx, Withers
description: The gate is locked at Glie Farms, a South Bronx garden that once delivered herbs to hundreds of fancy New York City restaurants.

title: Japanese Tax Evasion
description: Japan's National Tax Agency said today that a record $525 million in 1987 income had not been reported. In an annual report, the agency said that individuals and organizations had earned a large part of the revenues through stocks or real estate. The agency said it collected $372 million in taxes and penalties from those who failed to report all of their earnings. The amount of unreported earnings in 1987 was $81.6 million more than in 1986 and $30.53 million more than the previous record high of $504.47 million in 1985.

title: Commercial Metals Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Reduced by $1.9 million for the quarter and $4.6 million for the 9 months, respectively, because of the LIFO effect on inventory valuation, and the 9 months also includes a $2.6 million because of expenses associated with the start of production at a new steel minimill.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Cavanaughs' Coming

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Sports Pages yesterday about the Newport-to-Bermuda sailing race gave an incorrect result. The yacht Congere was the first to finish. The overall winner of the race, determined by handicap, is to be announced later this week.

title: Koch to Support Proposal to Seek New Excise Tax
description: Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate yesterday supported a City Council proposal seeking additional excise taxes on alcohol and tobacco products to help close a contested city budget deficit.

title: Civil Service Restraints Are Needed in School Building
description: To the Editor:

title: Forests of Vermont Severely Damaged By Flea-Size Insect
description: As much as a fifth of Vermont's five million acres of forest has been defoliated by insects in recent weeks, raising concern about both the maple syrup industry and the fall foliage season.

title: Vietnam Picks New Premier; Food Shortages Are Reported
description: A longtime revolutionary who reportedly directed purges against corruption in Vietnam's ruling Communist Party was chosen Prime Minister today, the Hanoi radio announced.

title: London Journal; A Whimsical Tory, Quite Bold, Bawdy and Bright
description: Here's the latest from the health and fitness front in Britain. Edwina Currie is pummeling the poor doctors again. According to Mrs. Currie, they haven't been doing their homework on nutrition.

title: Western Culture course Began in Indoctrination; A Little Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Lending Rate Up in Britain
description: Britain's commercial banks, heeding a signal from the Bank of England, raised their base lending rate by half a percentage point today, to 9 percent.

title: Company News; New Delco Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation's Delco Products division announced plans to build an 82,000-square-foot plant that would use high technology and new management techniques to make struts for small front-wheel-drive cars in this Dayton suburb. Production is scheduled to begin next year with 60 people, expanding to 150 by 1992, said a Delco spokesman, Charles W. Kronbach. The plant will be organized in flexible manufacturing cells with increased responsibilities for workers, instead of the traditional assembly line. Mr. Kronbach said the struts had already been accepted for use on G.M.'s new Saturn models and on Toyota Camrys to be built in Georgetown, Ky.

title: Children, Including Several Jews, Linked to Some Israeli Forest Fires
description: Police Minister Haim Bar-Lev said today that children, including several who are Jewish, were responsible for some of the forest fires attributed to Palestinian arsonists in recent weeks.

title: Company News; Mercedes-Benz Venture in Japan
description: A Japanese subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany said it had established a joint venture with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan to market Mercedes-Benz automobiles in Japan.

title: Home Improvement
description: PAINTING wooden double-hung windows - the kind with two vertically sliding halves known as sashes - is tedious because there are so many components. But the task can be easier and less likely to leave sticking parts if you use the right equipment and follow a logical sequence.

title: Verdix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year included a charge of $708,750 related to a legal settlement.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
New Pillsbury Resignation
description: Kyle T. Craig, chairman and chief executive of the Pillsbury Company's Steak and Ale restaurant chain, resigned yesterday, the latest of several top Pillsbury officers who have left the company in recent days.

title: Brazil Debt Pact Called Innovative
description: The agreement between Brazil and its foreign creditor banks to reduce sharply the interest Brazil pays on more than $60 billion in debt and to provide it with $5.2 billion in new loans was described yesterday as innovative and significant by a number of experts on third-world debt.

title: Executive Changes
description: Belding Heminway Co. appointed Ray C. Adam a director. He retired as chairman and chief executive of NL Industries in 1983 to engage in private investment activities.

title: 4 Directors In Seminar On Movies
description: ''I call them movies,'' said the director Sidney Lumet. ''I won't even use the word film, I'm in such protest against it. And the word cinema won't pass my throat.''

title: Disputed Soviet Region Asks For Its Transfer to Armenia
description: Officials in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh have called on the Soviet Parliament in Moscow to consider its transfer from Azerbaijan to Armenia, Soviet television reported today.

title: Material Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. URGED TO RAZE MOSCOW CHANCERY
description: A team of consultants has told the State Department that dismantling part of the new United States Embassy chancery in Moscow will be more difficult and dangerous than razing it before rebuilding, department officials say.

title: Addiction's Hidden Toll: Poor Families in Turmoil
description: As crack causes crime rates to soar and drug bazaars to infect street corners in New York and other major cities, the smokable form of cocaine is taking a hidden but far more devastating toll, experts say, by tearing apart what remains of the fragile ghetto family.

title: Applied Power Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $650,000, or 10 cents a share, relating to income tax loss carryforwards created as a result of the sale of the Blackhawk automotive division to the Hein-Werner Corp. in fiscal 1987. c-Net loss and after a loss of $10,291,000 from discontinued operations. The company said results in the third quarter of 1988 include orders and sales of GB Electrical products as a result of the acquisition of Gardner Bender Inc., on Feb. 16.

title: Yankees Fail at Finish For 3d Game in a Row
description: In the end, the Yankees did their best to prop themselves up and accept the latest defeat with a collective shrug. They had left home nine days ago in first place, and now they were preparing to return in second, a 2-7 trip still in their memories, another loss to sort out.

title: Study Says Acne Drug Averts Skin Cancer in Some
description: A drug that is used to treat severe acne can prevent skin cancer in some people highly susceptible to such cancers, according to a new report. The researchers said it was one of the first reports that drugs could prevent cancer in humans.

title: Company News; Inquiry Set On Farmers Group Trades
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said today that it would consider disciplining some member firms if an investigation under way determines that a ban on after-hours trading in options of the Farmers Group Inc. was violated last week.

title: Review/Dance; Paris Opera Ballet in a Singular 'Swan Lake'
description: No one can accuse the Paris Opera Ballet of doing things by halves. To open its three-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night, Rudolf Nureyev, the troupe's artistic director, offered one of the most peculiar versions of ''Swan Lake'' in existence - his own. Visibly set indoors under a merciless white light rather than by the traditional nocturnal lakeside, the action - we are asked to believe - is purely a projection of the hero's mind.

title: Dissident Holders Claiming Victory in Allegheny Proxy
description: A dissident shareholders committee led by Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York brokerage firm, claimed victory yesterday in a proxy fight against the management of Allegheny International.

title: Car Bomb in East Beirut Kills 2 and Hurts 19
description: For the second time in less than a month, a car bomb rocked Christian East Beirut today, killing 2 people and wounding 19, the police said.

title: Rising Number of Hospitals Forced to Close
description: The number of hospitals going out of business is rising sharply, largely because Medicare no longer pays them as much as it costs to treat their elderly patients, according to Federal and industry officials. The pressure is particularly severe on small hospitals in rural and inner-city areas.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have low-voltage track lights fitted with a dimmer. When the lights are dimmed, they emit a humming noise so loud that ordinary conversation is impossible. The noise doesn't seem to be related to any appliance or other outside interference. Can you suggest anything?

title: William H. Scott, Railway Manager, 100
description: William H. Scott, general manager of San Francisco's Municipal Railway in its most difficult period, died at the age of 100 on Monday.
