title: Custom-Made Lighting In Antique Styles
description: ''ANYTHING with lighting fixtures, I'll do for you,'' said Roy Greenstein, president of Roy Electric. Anything in Victorian or Art Deco lighting is what he means. His Brooklyn shop specializes in original and reproduction lighting from 1850 to 1930, including chandeliers, sconces, pendants and hall lights.

title: A Chance to Talk
description: One of the most important documents in the tormented history of conflict between Israelis and Palestinians has just been published. It is by Yasir Arafat's press spokesman and close adviser, Bassam Abu Sharif.

title: Iceland Says Whaling Accord Averts U.S. Trade Sanctions
description: The Government said today that it had reached an agreement with the United States on the number of whales Icelandic fishermen may catch in the coming year, averting possible trade sanctions by Washington.

title: Durables Orders Fell 2.2% in May
description: A slump in aircraft orders caused a 2.2 percent decline in overall orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods in May, the steepest drop in nine months.

title: HEALTH: Medical Ethics; Hospital Biophilosophers' Help Solve Life-and-Death Issues
description: The physician's urgent call for advice came at 3 A.M.

title: Brightening the Commuter's Space
description: ''T HAT'S our baby,'' said Lev Zeitlin, looking into a window on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal, where intriguing furnishings are on display.

title: Company News; Pepsico in Deal For 2 Bottlers
description: Grand Metropolitan Inc., the giant British company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two soft-drink bottling companies to Pepsico Inc. for $705 million. The bottlers - the Atlantic Soft Drink Company of South Carolina and the Pepsi-Cola San Joaquin Bottling Company in California - were acquired by Grand Metropolitan in 1980 and had sales of $355 million in the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30.

title: Did Masters Pay a Price For Boldness Of Their Art?
description: The painters Rubens, Renoir, Dufy and Klee were noted for use of bright colors. All of them also suffered from rheumatic diseases. Coincidence?

title: New York State Schedules $1.5 Billion in Debt Offerings
description: New York State plans to borrow about $1.5 billion through debt offerings for the third quarter of 1988, with $338.5 million scheduled for next month. Earlier this week, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, announced the schedule for sale to the public of obligations for the state, its major authorities and New York City.

title: Young Architects Meld Latin Heritage And Miami Style
description: FLORIDA has long been a place that conjures architectural fantasies. From Vizcaya, James Deering's 1916 Italian Renaissance palazzo on Biscayne Bay, to the launching pads of Cape Canaveral, the architecture of Florida, as Hap Hatton wrote in ''Tropical Splendor: An Architectural History of Florida,'' has been ''a living, changing testament of historic events and human fantasies, of aspirations and dreams.''

title: Two Nuclear Devices Set Off at Same Time
description: In a rare experiment, two nuclear weapons were detonated simultaneously under the Nevada desert this morning.

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article on Tuesday about Henri Namphy, the military leader of Haiti, misstated his birthplace and the size of his family in some copies. He was born in Grande-Riviere-du-Nord and was raised with two brothers and two sisters. In addition, the rank he attained after putting down a coup attempt in 1982 was given incorrectly in some copies; it was brigadier general.

title: Wiltek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Roundtable Picks Chief
description: The Business Roundtable, a group of about 200 chief executives of major corporations, yesterday elected Edmund T. Pratt Jr., chairman and chief executive of Pfizer Inc., as its chairman. He succeeds Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, who headed the organization for two years.

title: Shorewood Packaging Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary after-tax charge relating to writeoff of deferred debt acquisition costs as a result of prepayment of certain long-term debt. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in the form of a dividend in October 1987.

title: H B Fuller Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Market Place; Arms Contractors Found Attractive
description: THE cloud of uncertainty hanging over military contractors because of the Pentagon bribery and fraud investigation may actually open up some good buying opportunities, analysts and investors say.

title: Sports People; Little Eyes Seahawks
description: Floyd Little of Denver heads a group of black businessmen who are interested in buying the 51 percent ownership of the Seattle Seahawks held by the Nordstrom family, The Seattle Times reported yesterday. The group is seeking to establish the first black-controlled ownership of a major sports franchise.

title: Sinking-Fund Debt From Westvaco
description: The Westvaco Corporation, a paper and wood products company, is offering $100 million worth of sinking-fund debentures due in 2018 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Witness Rebuts A Bribe Charge Against Simon
description: A defense witness in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi testified yesterday that Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, could not have been at a 1984 meeting in which prosecutors say Mr. Simon extorted money from the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Job Cuts at G.M.'s Opel
description: The General Motors Corporation's West German unit, Adam Opel A.G., said Tuesday that it plans to cut 5,200 jobs by 1991 as part of a cost-saving program. The move comes as all of G.M.'s European operations are under pressure to reduce expenses and bolster the auto maker's profitability on the Continent.

title: Contra Split Widens as a Director Vows to Seek Commander's Ouster
description: A split in the Nicaraguan rebel movement deepened today after Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, one of the movement's five political leaders, announced he had agreed to represent a group of officers and civilians who continue to demand the replacement of the military commander, Col. Enrique Bermudez.

title: The Bubble May Have Burst, but Lacroix's Creativity Soars
description: LEAD: The pouf is now part of fashion history. So are its variants the balloon, the bubble and other elaborate shapes. What is happening to Christian Lacroix, the designer who exploded on the fashion scene by promoting these and other whimsical designs?

title: Conferees Said to Scale Back Anti-drug Plan for Pentagon
description: Congressional efforts to step up military involvement in the anti-drug campaign have been scaled back and President Reagan's request for a space-based defense against missiles has been sharply reduced by Congressional negotiators working on budget legislation for the Defense Department, Congressional sources said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A caption with the Advertising column in Business Day last Thursday about a senior vice president of McCann-Erickson misidentified him. He was Robert J. Coen, not Peter J. Coen.

title: Sitting on Top of the Majors
description: Normally, in and around the Friendly Confines, the signal is unmistakable. Hands in front of chest, palms down, suddenly extended toward the sides - safe. But in the office of the manager of the Cubs, as Don Zimmer sat behind his desk beneath the third-base stands at Wrigley Field, the sign had another meaning - no more.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Decker Guertin Wins Connecticut Lottery Job
description: The Connecticut State Lottery has made a winner out of Decker Guertin Cheyne, a $15 million agency in Hartford that will become a $20 million agency July 1 with the addition of the lottery account.

title: Old Troubles And Big Plans In West Bank
description: Col. Joel Singer, head of the Israeli Army's international law department, sat before the television lights this afternoon, trying to explain how his office handles the many legal quandaries presented by the Palestinian uprising.

title: Company News; Volvo to Get 20% of Hertz Parent
description: The Volvo North American Corporation said today that it would pay $100 million in cash to the Ford Motor Company in exchange for a 20 percent interest in the parent company of the Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest rental car agency.

title: Howard A. Knag, College official, 79
description: Howard A. Knag, a former administrator at Queens College, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: Ciba-Geigy AIDS Project
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation said today that it would start human tests soon on a potential vaccine against HIV, the virus that has been linked to AIDS.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Some Expert Advice
description: When Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker of the House, was negotiating the contract for his book, ''Man of the House,'' Lee Iacocca, the Chrysler chairman who is also a successful author, advised Mr. O'Neill to ask for royalties of $4 a book. Instead, he agreed to an advance of $1,050,000.

title: Chappell Tells of Contacts With Weapons Industry
description: Representative Bill Chappell Jr. of Florida is not familiar to most people, but in the world of Pentagon weapons procurement his name is one to reckon with.

title: Democrats Back Palestinians At 7 State Party Conventions
description: Democratic parties in seven states have called for self-determination for the Palestinian people, sometimes urging the creation of a separate Palestinian state. These moves, often prompted by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign, raise an issue that threatens the party with a bitter, emotional conflict at a time when it is seeking harmony.

title: TREASURY ISSUES SURGE IN PRICE
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds surged yesterday on a wave of foreign buying.

title: A Wall Rises From Ashes Of a Shanty
description: The granite remains charred, and the controversy still smolders in the Yale University plaza where an arsonist two weeks ago set fire to a shanty built by students to symbolize their opposition to apartheid in South Africa.

title: NBC Business Broadcast in Danger
description: Even as NBC prepares to start a cable-television channel dedicated to business news, the network has decided that there is not a strong enough market for its daily 15-minute business broadcast, ''Before Hours,'' making that program a probable candidate for cancellation, according to NBC officials.

title: Instant Tradition In Cabinets
description: FOUNDED in 1980, Smallbone, an English company that manufactures traditional cabinetry for kitchens, bedrooms and bathrooms, has an annual turnover of $50 million.

title: Five Ethiopian Boys Given Asylum in U.S.
description: Five Ethiopian boys have been granted political asylum in the United States after stowing away on a ship to escape their country.

title: Rev. James Graefe, Ex-Bishop, Dies at 64
description: The Rev. Dr. James Arthur Graefe, the former bishop of the Metropolitan New York Synod of the Lutheran Church in America, died of cancer of the adrenal glands Saturday at his home in Westtown, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Talking Deals; Behind Icahn Loss In Texaco Fight
description: RETURNS in Carl C. Icahn's unsuccessful proxy fight against Texaco Inc. may not be known for weeks but Wall Street has concluded that takeover battles may never be the same again.

title: 43.03 Surge Puts Dow At 2,152.20
description: LEAD: The stock market soared yesterday in heavy volume, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 43.03 points to close at 2,152.20. The Dow is now at its highest point since the October market collapse.

title: Loan Unit Sets $200 Million Sale
description: The Credithrift Financial Corporation, the consumer loan subsidiary of the American General Corporation, is offering $200 million in debt securities through a two-part financing.

title: Leaks at Bhopal Reported
description: Minor acid leaks from a storage tank at the Union Carbide Corporation's closed plant at Bhopal, India, were detected on two days this week, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: Giuliani Asks Cuomo for Removal of Gentile
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani, formally asked Governor Cuomo yesterday to begin removal proceedings against the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile.

title: Club Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said its second quarter was affected by significant expenses and extraordinary losses incurred in the openings of the new Huatulco village and renovated Blaya Blanca village in Mexico, as well as the closing of its Haitian village.

title: Sports People; Comeback Time
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, who announced his retirement from boxing in May 1987, has been rumored to be eager to fight again. Last week in Washington, his attorney, Mike Trainer, met with Dave Wolf, manager of the World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, Don Lalonde. A Lalonde-Leonard bout, if it ever materialized, could be for Lalonde's light heavyweight (175-pound limit) crown and a supermiddleweight (168-pound limit) title that the W.B.C. would create for the occasion. If Leonard agreed to box him, Lalonde would fight at a weight well under 175 pounds. . . . Art Pellulo, the promoter of the heavyweight Tim Witherspoon, said yesterday that he has a signed agreement from the former heavyweight champion George Foreman for a fight with Witherspoon. The hitch is that Witherspoon, who is scheduled to fight Trevor Curry in Jamaica on Aug. 14, has not yet signed his agreement. Pellulo said he has guaranteed the fighters $200,000 each.

title: Books of The Times; Michener's Cautionary Tale of the 49th State
description: Alaska By James A. Michener Illustrated. 868 pages. Random House. $22.50.

title: Report Said Brawley Didn't Recount Attack
description: Psychiatric examinations of Tawana Brawley performed last December just a few days after her four-day disappearance found that the black teen-ager was able to shed little light in discussions with doctors and nurses on what happened to her.

title: Guess Who's Coming To Baby-Sit
description: ''I NEVER thought I'd be baby-sitting,'' said Nora Joseph, a 37-year-old Hollywood script supervisor who is listed with the Babysitters Guild in South Pasadena, Calif.

title: Wimbledon; Chang's Loss Is Good Lesson
description: At 16, Michael Chang came to Wimbledon for the experience more than with any expectation of writing a storybook ending the way Boris Becker did in 1985. Becker was only 17 when he won Wimbledon for the first time, an accomplishment that appears even more remarkable after listening to Chang explain his goal here.

title: Company News; Suits Are Settled By Cannon Group
description: The Cannon Group tentatively agreed to a $33 million settlement of class-action lawsuits that accused the firm of inflating its stock price. The settlement was $13 million larger than a partial agreement announced in April.

title: Racial Shifts Challenge U.S. Schools
description: Integrating black, Hispanic and Asian-American students in the school systems of large cities may be just as difficult as reconciling differences between blacks and whites, according to researchers at the University of Chicago.

title: The Media Business; Daily Variety Editor
description: Thomas M. Pryor, the 73-year-old editor of the Hollywood trade paper Daily Variety, intends to retire after 29 years. He will be succeeded by his son, Peter P. Pryor, 42, who is currently the paper's managing editor. The younger Pryor will become the fourth editor of Variety in its 55 years. Richard Bozanich, Variety's news editor, will become managing editor. Variety, based in Los Angeles, was acquired last year by the Cahners Publishing Company of Britain.

title: A Mideast Peace - Is It Impossible?
description: LEAD: Was it an accident or an illusion? Wishful thinking perhaps? Gaza seemed calm, if not peaceful. No burning tires, no riots. I saw children going to school. The stores were open. Bathing in dust and sun, just another city in this region whose destiny is named hatred.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Congress; Aid to Elderly Divides Young, Old and Politicians
description: The United States may be a youth culture, but the elderly seem to have cornered the market on political strength.

title: Energy Optics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Oman Stock Market
description: Oman has issued a royal decree setting up its first stock market. Bankers said the decree, issued late Tuesday, would set in motion detailed work on creating a market, but it could be a year before trading begins. Persian Gulf states have been pushing plans to increase the role of private business and diversify their economies in an effort to trim their dependence on oil.

title: Surrogate Mother's Story
description: You won't find the photographs of such pseudonymous authors as William Wharton or Trevanian on the jackets of their books, but photos of the woman who wrote under the pseudonym Elizabeth Kane appear in her recent book, ''Birth Mother.'' Moreover, the publicity packet that accompanied the book, the story of America's first legal surrogate mother, also contains the author's photograph.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's too much racial violence going on. I went against six white guys for a black guy and I'm glad I did. It's a matter of right and wrong, not black and white.'' - Jeff LaMartina, of Staten Island. [ B2:5. ]

title: Judge Acquits Nurse Charged In Deaths of Three Patients
description: A judge has acquitted a nurse accused of killing three patients with injections of potassium chloride, saying no evidence tied her to the deaths.

title: Review/Pop; John Prine's Sad Songs Of Low Expectations
description: John Prine's best songs pour acid on most country music, etching away romantic cliches and homey platitudes until they reach an unsentimental realism. The characters in his small towns are lonely and, as one song puts it, ''twisted all crooked inside'' - maybe vengeful, maybe suicidal, maybe sunk in despair - and Mr. Prine neither coddles nor mocks them. He just sets out the situation with an economy that Raymond Carver might envy. Now and then, Mr. Prine allows himself some sly wordplay or a short-lived joke, but he doesn't aim to be reassuring.

title: Wright and His Ethics Case Pose Problem for Democrats
description: The Democratic Party is grappling with a question that almost no Democrat wants to talk about publicly: Should House Speaker Jim Wright preside over the party's national convention next month?

title: For Soviet Jews, Fear Of Losing a Path to U.S.
description: By 6 o'clock each morning the line has formed outside the Dutch Embassy on Kalashny Lane, Jews from Kiev and Odessa, Minsk and Samarkand, Kharkov and Tbilisi, awaiting passage through the gateway to freedom.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Hungarian Aid Urged
description: Representative Edward F. Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, is circulating a petition that has already been signed by 192 members of Congress, urging the Reagan Administration to provide emergency relief for the thousands of ethnic Hungarians fleeing their Transylvanian homeland in Rumania.

title: HEALTH: Workplace Technology; Vision Problems From Video Terminals Are Avoidable for Many
description: Vast numbers of American workers are suffering eyestrain from prolonged work with video display terminals, most of it avoidable by wearing the proper glasses or changing the work environment, according to experts who have studied the problem.

title: Company News; American Medical Holders' Request
description: A group of Texas investors that controls a 7 percent stake in American Medical International Inc. said it would ask the board of the Beverly Hills, Calif., hospital concern to form a restructuring committee ''to consider and evaluate various alternatives for increasing stockholder value.''

title: Review/Theater; Giving Voice to Beckett's Mordant Band
description: ''Tears and laughter, they are so much Gaelic to me,'' says the title character in Samuel Beckett's novel ''Molloy.'' Those words resonate through ''I'll Go On,'' Barry McGovern's exhilarating one-man play drawn from Mr. Beckett's prose. Mr. McGovern, an actor with Dublin's Gate Theater, is performing ''I'll Go On'' at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. Both the actor and the author are irrevocably linked, as was also the case in 1970 when Jack MacGowran presented his own signature evening of Beckett.

title: Review/City Ballet; 'Gounod Symphony'
description: Amid several debuts at the New York City Ballet on Sunday, Judith Fugate's and Lindsay Fischer's first-class foray into ''Gounod Symphony'' would have looked splendid on any terms.

title: Howard Mitchell, 77, Cellist and Conductor
description: Howard Mitchell, a cellist who was music director of the National Symphony Orchestra for 20 years, died of heart failure resulting from surgical complications Wednesday at Ormond Beach (Fla.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Palm Coast, Fla.

title: Neighbor Denies Setting Fire To House for Foster Babies
description: A man accused of helping set fire to a Queens house that the city planned to use as a foster home for babies took the witness stand yesterday to deny any role in the blaze.

title: Rockwell Pleas Entered
description: The Rockwell International Corporation and two former executives pleaded not guilty Tuesday to Federal charges accusing the aerospace contractor of overbilling the Air Force by $450,000. The pleas were entered in a hearing before United States District Judge Consuelo B. Marshall, who set trial for Oct. 11. A seven-count indictment filed earlier this month charges Rockwell and two former managers at the Seal Beach Satellite Systems division, Donald H. Carter, 59 years old, and Robert Zavodnik, 46, with overbilling a navigation system contract.

title: Syrians Said to Have Located Suspected Site of Hostages
description: A British newspaper reported today that Syria has located the place in Lebanon where 15 foreign hostages are believed held by Iranian-backed guerrillas.

title: Sports People; Brooks Won't Be Back
description: Jack Ferreira, the new general manager of the Minnesota North Stars, said yesterday that Herb Brooks, who coached the team last season, would not be rehired. Brooks and his assistant coaches were dismissed on June 11 by George and Gordon Gund, the owners, in preparation for the hiring of a new general manager to replace Lou Nanne, who has been made president of the club. Ferreira had said last week that no search for a new coach would begin until it was decided whether or not to rehire Brooks. Yesterday, Ferreira said in d a statement: ''After one week of consideration, I have decided to go after a new coach. The tension and misunderstanding evident in my meetings with Herb made me feel unccomfortable having him as coach of the North Stars next season. We want to put past problems behind us. It is time for this organization to have a clean slate. I intend to find a new coach as soon as possible.''(AP)

title: Doll House, Age 72, Has New Decor
description: THE thatched cottage has stood since 1916, when it was built for Peggie Phipps by her parents for her 10th birthday. The family's Long Island estate is now Old Westbury Gardens.

title: TENNESSEAN SEVED 24 YEARS IN CONGRESS
description: Representative John J. Duncan, who served 24 years in the House of Representatives and was the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, died Tuesday after a long battle with cancer. He was 69 years old.

title: Iran Says It Defeated Iraqi Counterattack At Northern Frontier
description: Iran said today that its Revolutionary Guards had repulsed an Iraqi assault in the Mawat region of Kurdistan along the two nations' northern frontier, killing or wounding 3,000 soldiers.

title: Reviews/Theater; Song, Storm and Ritual In an Indonesian World
description: The birds and bees are up to mischief and the other orders of creation baffle imagination. In the performance of ''The Ritual of Solomon's Children'' by the Indonesian company Teater Rendra, two male lizards battle over a female in jungle mists and the winner's position can hardly be called satisfying; insect Rambos knocked off by one another spring back to life only to be dispatched by a spray can in the hands of a woman wearing a police-car dome light; seven sticky people who cannot get away from one another meld into a 14-footed chimera trying in vain to shake itself to pieces.

title: Elgar at Waterloo
description: Gerard Schwarz is to lead the Waterloo Festival Orchestra and the Music chorus in Sir Edward Elgar's ''Dream of Gerontius'' at the Waterloo Festival, Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. (at Exit 25 on Route 80) tomorrow evening at 8:30. The soloists are Mimi Lerner, mezzo-soprano; Vinson Cole, tenor, and Jake Gardner, baritone. Tickets are $17.50 to $22.50, with lawn tickets at $10 available the day of the performance. Information: (201) 347-4700.

title: Toots and the Maytals
description: Toots and the Maytals are to headline Reggae Sunsplash tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). The program, which begins at 9 P.M., also features Yellowman, Pato Banton, Sophia George, Bloodfire Posse and the Sagittarius Band. Tickets are $25.

title: NAVY HAS SHIFTED ON PROCUREMENT
description: The Navy's procurement apparatus went through a sea change during the Reagan Administration, with dramatic shifts in the structure of the bureaucracy, the way suppliers were chosen, and the terms on which contracts were written.

title: Review/Film; Israeli Life Through Arab Eyes
description: ''Wedding in Galilee'' was shown as part of the recent New Directors/ New Films series. These are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 11. The film, in Arabic with English subtitles, opens today at the Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street.

title: Global Warming Has Begun, Expert Tells Senate
description: The earth has been warmer in the first five months of this year than in any comparable period since measurements began 130 years ago, and the higher temperatures can now be attributed to a long-expected global warming trend linked to pollution, a space agency scientist reported today.

title: IMMIGRATION LAW IS FAILING TO CUT FLOW FROM MEXICO
description: The 1986 immigration law is failing to stem the illegal flow of Mexicans into the United States and may be creating new problems on both sides of the border by distorting traditional immigration patterns, Mexican and American researchers say.

title: Catholicism Evolving
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Meese Aide's Wedtech Efforts Detailed
description: In a series of detailed memorandums, E. Robert Wallach, a former lawyer for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, wrote to Mr. Meese and other Reagan Administration officials to plead the case of the Wedtech Corporation and to keep Mr. Meese apprised of the company's efforts to obtain Pentagon contracts.

title: OLD TRACK VERDICTS LEAVE NO DOUBTS
description: Race-track misdeeds and the penalties for them seem constant from one era to another, but the official verdicts nowadays are not as colorfully written as they once were. Consider these penalties issued by the presiding judges at the 1914 Overland Park meeting in Denver under the auspices of the Denver Fair and Racing Association:

title: 70 Senators Sponsor New Trade Bill
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Lloyd Bentsen, said today that he has 70 co-sponsors for the revised trade legislation he has just introduced.

title: Striking Writers Vote Against Producers' Offer
description: Striking screen and television writers have voted 3 to 1 to support their union leadership and reject what film and television producers have called their final offer.

title: POP/JAZZ: Arts Festival; The Hills and Halls Are Alive With Jazz
description: THIS year's JVC Jazz Festival, which opens tonight and ends on July 3, offers jazz for just about any taste, in settings ranging from the confines of Carnegie Hall to the grassy expanses of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, from the 92d Street Y to the Hudson Dayliner.

title: Reviews/Theater; From Cape Town, a Mix Of Humor and Pain
description: The promise of a work created out of the experiences of black South African women is enough to fill the Apple Corps theater with sympathy even before ''You Strike the Woman, You Strike the Rock'' begins, and it can only grow with the appearance of Poppy Tsira, Thobeka Maqhutyana and Nomvula Qosha, hawking their chickens and oranges on the outskirts of Cape Town.

title: F.B.I. IS EXAMINING PRISON SITE CHOICE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was conducting an inquiry into the proposed purchase of land for a Massachusetts prison by state officials but that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was not the subject of an investigation.

title: Operas and Haiku
description: Golden Fleece Ltd., the Composers Chamber Theater, is to present Carman Moore's ''Wakas and Haiku of Grandma Kimi,'' Jon Deak's ''Ugly Duckling'' and Michael Colgrass's ''Virgil's Dream'' in their first staged New York performances tonight at 8 at the Sanford Meisner Theater, 164 11th Avenue, at 23d Street. Mr. Deak's and Mr. Colgrass's works are chamber operas; Mr. Moore's is described as ''a ritual of songs set to Japanese haiku.'' The works are to be repeated tomorrow and Sunday, with performances both days at 3:30 and 8 P.M. Tickets are $7 to $10. Information: 691-6105.

title: Review/Art; Into Kim MacConnel's Giant Fabric Showroom
description: In his new work at the Holly Solomon Gallery, Kim MacConnel, who emerged in the mid-1970's as part of the Pattern and Decoration phenomenon, is negotiating a transition to canvas and also to a relatively pure form of abstraction. In the past, this artist has made paintings by sewing together brightly patterned fabrics or layering cartoonish images over areas of saturated color. He has also been known to paint bright, Matissean designs directly onto old overstuffed chairs and sofas.

title: Review/Art; A Mantegna Masterpiece at the Met
description: A VISITOR to the Metropolitan Museum of Art should march straight up the main staircase, walk toward the collection of Caravaggios and proceed directly forward into a small gallery numbered 32. There hangs ''Christ's Descent Into Limbo'' by the Italian Renaissance master Andrea Mantegna, on loan through Oct. 2.

title: Review/Film; Innocents Abroad, In 'Dudes'
description: When the self-consciously hip central characters of ''Dudes'' leave New York for a cross-country journey, they make enemies in the heartland the way the heroes of ''Easy Rider'' did. Grant (Jon Cryer), Milo (Flea) and Biscuit (Daniel Roebuck) are inexplicably attacked by a band of outlaws led by the sneering Missoula (Lee Ving), who evidently doesn't like their punk-rock looks. In the aftermath of this ambush, which ends in murder, Grant and Biscuit vow to track down Missoula and exact revenge. The film presents this as a rite of passage for bored, city-bred rebels seeking a sense of purpose.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Ancient Form of Appeal
description: Normally one does not expect the Government to devote much time or thought to divination or conjuration. But having concluded that two-fifths of the country is undergoing ''the worst drought in 50 years,'' it is leaving little to chance and has intently followed the work of an Indian rain dancer in the Middle West.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sfuzzi

title: THE LAW: At the Bar
description: Steven Winston started to use cocaine at the age of 30, five years after he began practicing law and a dozen years before becoming the subject of a landmark ruling on addiction and disbarment. It was 1976, a time when Len Bias was still in grade school and ''coke,'' Mr. Winston later recalled, was the ''chic, Upper East Side'' thing to do among his hip theatrical and advertising clients. Besides, like many lawyers he was the overachieving, hyperactive sort, and it helped him endure or unwind from those 20-hour days.

title: Debt
description: Nashville and Davison County, Tenn., are tentatively offering $29 million of tax-exempt electric system revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. Yields on the double-A-rated issue range from 6.40 percent for bonds due in 1993 to 7 percent in 1997. Common Stock

title: Tianjin Journal; Profit Motive Nips a Budding Career in Academia
description: Ouyang Jianfe, baby-faced and bespectacled, roves the halls of Tianjin University a bit like an academic James Dean, flouting convention and mundane expectations.

title: Bid for Irving Is Withdrawn
description: As expected, the Bank of New York withdrew its offer for the Irving Bank Corporation after Irving declined to accept it yesterday.

title: Company News; Vehicle Sales Post 12.8% Rise
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 12.8 percent in mid-June from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: At the Movies
description: His Rabbit's Voice

title: Lomas & Nettleton
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation is making a $200 million debt offering through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The 10 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1993 are priced at par, to yield about 2.25 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue is noncallable and rated Ba-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.

title: No Headline
description: The clamor in Congress last month to enlist the military in the war on drugs has given way to a more sober assessment of what the armed forces can and cannot do to halt the flow of drugs across the nation's borders.

title: Soviets Deploy Troops In Area of Ethnic Crisis
description: The Soviet Union has sent troops into a southern area gripped by ethnic unrest, and the crisis is worsening by the day, the Communist Party daily Pravda reported today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Matchbox Toys Account To Berenter Greenhouse
description: Berenter Greenhouse & Webster reported yesterday that it had been assigned the $12 million Matchbox Toys account. The former agency is Saatchi & Saatchi's AC&R/DHB & Bess, and Stephen Rose, its chief executive, said Matchbox had yet to inform his agency.

title: Pirates Roll Past Expos
description: Sid Bream drove in four runs with a two-run home run in the second inning and a tie-breaking two-run double in the eighth tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates over the Montreal Expos, 6-4.

title: Stiffer Drug Penalties Urged
description: A set of proposals to stiffen penalties against drug users was among recommendations endorsed today by President Reagan's National Drug Policy Board.

title: HUGHES MISSILE WATCHERS FACE LONELY DAYS IN RUSSIA
description: The temperature in winter may on occasion top 11 degrees. The living quarters, outside the 10-foot-tall gates of a Soviet missile factory, will be austere.

title: Tax Reprieve Advances For Fund Shareowners
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today agreed to give mutual fund shareowners a permanent reprieve from a 1986 tax law provision that threatened to cause millions of them to pay higher tax on their fund earnings this year.

title: Lounge Lizards
description: The Lounge Lizards are to perform tonight and tomorrow at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $10, and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Company News; Northern Nekoosa To Buy Paper Unit
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said it had agreed to buy Jim Walter Papers Inc., the paper distribution, envelope and office supply subsidiary of the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation. Terms of the purchase, which is subject to the execution of a definitive agreement, were not disclosed.

title: BRAMWELL FLETCHER
description: Bramwell Fletcher, a veteran stage, screen and television performer best known as an actor in plays by George Bernard Shaw and for a one-man show about the Irish playwright, died on Wednesday at the Maplewood Nursing Home in Westmoreland, N.H. He was 84 years old and lived in Keene, N.H.

title: ARTS FESTIVAL HIGHLIGHT
description: For a recorded complete list of events, the number in New York is 587-1111; from outside New York State, (800) 782-4369. Tickets are available from the individual theaters. FRIDAY JVC JAZZ FESTIVAL, listing of all jazz festival events on page C22. AMERICAN BALLROOM THEATER, 8 P.M., Triplex, 199 Chambers St.; 618-1980. ''ARCHPRIEST AVVAKUM,'' 9 P.M., Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Ave. at 112th St.; 662-2133. ''BOUTIQUE LIVING AND DISPOSABLE ICONS,'' by Momoko Iko; directed by Tisa Chang, 8 P.M., Pan Asian Repertory, Perry St. Theater, 31 Perry St.; 245-2660. Opens tonight. ''A CIRCLE,'' 8 P.M., Theater for the New City. 155 First Ave., at 10th St.; 254-1109. CONTRABAND, 8 P.M., ''Oracle.'' Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage, Cadman Plaza and Front St., Brooklyn; 619-1955. CRICOT 2, 8 P.M., ''I Shall Never Return.'' La Mama E.T.C., 74A E. Fourth St.; 475-7710. ''DEATHWATCH'' 8 P.M., Aaron Davis Hall, City College, West 133d St. at Convent Ave.; 690-4100. ''AN EVENING OF TWO ONE-ACT MUSICALS,'' 8 P.M., Intar Theater, 420 W. 42d St.; 465-1761. EVEN ORCHESTRA, 8 P.M., ''Dog Songs.'' Dance Theater Workshop, 219 W. 19th St.; 924-0077. ''FLOW MY TEARS, THE POLICE MAN SAID,'' 8 P.M., New York University, Tisch School of the Arts, Mainstage One, 721 Broadway, at Waverly Pl.; 998-1850. GERALD BROWN, 9 P.M., ''John Henry.'' Performance Space, 150 First Ave.; 477-5288. ''GREEN CARD,'' 8 P.M., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Ave., at 19th St.; 242-0800. ''I'LL GO ON,'' 8 P.M., Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center; 239-6200. ''JUNO AND THE PAYCOCK,'' 8 P.M., John Golden Theater, 252 W. 45th St.; 239-6200. LAIBACH, 9 P.M., the Kitchen, 512 W. 19th St.; 255-5793. ''LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT,'' 8 P.M., Neil Simon Theater, 250 W. 52d St.; 757-8646, MARATHON OF NEW ONE-ACT PLAYS, 7:30 P.M., Ensemble Studio Theater, 549 W. 52d St.; 247-3405. W. 52d St.; 247-3405. MARTHA CLARKE, 8 P.M. ''Miracolo d'Amore.'' Public Theater, 425 Lafayette St.; 598-7150. NEW YORK SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL, 8 P.M., ''The Death of Garcia Lorca.'' Public Theater, 425 Lafayette St.; 598-7150. ''THE NIGHT OF THE IGUANA,'' preview, 8 P.M., Circle in the Square Theater, 1633 Broadway, at 50th St.; 307-2704. ''V & V ONLY,'' 8 P.M., Circle Repertory Theater, 99 Seventh Ave. at Fourth St.; 924-7100. VIDEO DOCUMENTARY SERIES, 1 P.M., the Kitchen, 512 W. 19th St.; 255-5793. ''YOU HAVE COME BACK,'' 8 P.M., Ubu Repertory Theater. St. Clement's Church, 423 W. 46th St.; 279-4200. ''YOU STRIKE THE WOMAN, YOU STRIKE THE ROCK,'' 8 P.M., the Women's Project. Apple Corps Theater, 336 W. 20th St.; 382-2750. SATURDAY AMERICAN BALLROOM THEATER, (see Friday). ''A CIRCLE,'' (see Friday), 2 and 8. CONTRABAND, (see Friday). CRICOT 2, (see Friday). ''DEATHWATCH'' (see Friday), 3 and 8. EVEN ORCHESTRA, (see Friday). ''AN EVENING OF TWO ONE-ACT MUSICALS,'' (see Friday), 3 and 8. ''FLOW MY TEARS, THE POLICE MAN SAID,'' (see Friday), 2 and 8. ''GREEN CARD,'' (see Friday), 5 and 9. ''I'LL GO ON,'' (see Friday). ''JUNO AND THE PAYCOCK,'' (see Friday). ''LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT,'' (see Friday), 2 and 8. ''MARATHON OF NEW ONE-ACT PLAYS,'' (see Friday), 5 and 9. MARTHA CLARKE, (see Friday), 3 and 8. NEW YORK CITY BALLET, 8 P.M., ''Apollo,'' ''Orpheus'' and ''Agon.'' New York State Theater; 870-5570. NEW YORK SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL, (see Friday), 3 and 8. ''THE NIGHT OF THE IGUANA,'' (see Friday), preview, 2 and 8. ''SAND'' 8 P.M., Sandglass Theater. 92d St. Y, 1395 Lexington Ave.; 427-4410. WASHINGTON SQUARES, 3 P.M., Central Park Band Shell, at 72d St.; 860-1335. WOMEN'S PROJECT LECTURE, 2 P.M.,''On Theatrical Space.'' Japan Society, 333 E. 47th St.; 382-2750. ''YOU HAVE COME BACK,'' (see Friday), 3 and 8. VIDEO DOCUMENTARY SERIES, (see Friday). ''YOU STRIKE THE WOMAN, YOU STRIKE THE ROCK,'' (see Friday), 3 and 8. SUNDAY ''ANTIGONA FURIOSA,'' 3 P.M., Staged readings. Apple Corps Theater, 336 W. 20th St.; 382-2750. ARROW, Central Park Band Shell, at 72d St.; 860-1335. ''A CIRCLE,'' (see Friday), 3. CRICOT 2, (see Friday), 3 and 7. ''DEATHWATCH'' (see Friday), 3. ''AN EVENING OF TWO ONE-ACT MUSICALS,'' (see Friday), 3 and 8. ''FLOW MY TEARS, THE POLICE MAN SAID,'' (see Friday), 2 and 8. HOTHOUSE, 4 P.M., Music and dance improvisation. Performance Space 122, 150 First Ave.; 477-5288. ''I'LL GO ON,'' (see Friday), 3. ''MARATHON OF NEW ONE-ACT PLAYS,'' (see Friday), 5 and 9. MARTHA CLARKE, (see Friday), 3 and 8. NEW STOCKHOLM CHAMBER ORCHESTRA, 5 P.M., Alice Tully Hall; 362-1911. NEW YORK CITY BALLET, 7 P.M., ''In G Major,'' ''Opus 19/ The Dreamer'' and ''Glass Pieces.'' New York State Theater; 870-5570. NEW YORK SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL, (see Friday), 3 and 8. ''THE NIGHT OF THE IGUANA,'' (see Friday), opening, 3. ''SAND'' (see Saturday).

title: Interim District Attorney Drops Out of Bronx Race
description: A political struggle that has ensnared Governor Cuomo and United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani and embarrassed Bronx politicians took an unexpected turn yesterday when the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, announced that he would not be a candidate for election this fall.

title: Allies Wiggle Wings Over Berlin
description: The three Western Allies re-enacted the Berlin airlift today with a nostalgic flight on a vintage C-47 aircraft of the type used in the mammoth supply operation 40 years ago.

title: Ethics Panel Is Silent On Inquiry of Wright
description: After meeting today, the House ethics committee would not say whether it discussed the complaints before it against the House Speaker, Jim Wright.

title: McDonnell Douglas Awarded F/A-18 Jet Fighter Contract
description: The Navy today awarded the McDonnell Douglas Corporation a $963.2 million contract for F/A-18 jet fighters. McDonnell Douglas is the prime contractor for the plane, and the Northrop Corporation is a major subcontractor. The F/A-18 is the Navy's newest carrier-based fighter. It is a twin-engine craft capable of being used either as an air-to-air fighter or as an air-to-ground attack jet.

title: Prices on Notes and Bonds Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were mixed in light trading yesterday.

title: EXIT FOR MCENROE ON CENTRE COURT
description: The scene was a muddle of contradictions for John McEnroe. In one of his darkest hours on Centre Court at Wimbledon, he was cheered by the fans he used to antagonize as they implored him with shouts of ''C'mon, Johnny,'' and applauded when he quietly questioned a linesman's call at the umpire's chair.

title: Sports People; Horner Sidelined
description: Bob Horner, whose left shoulder has troubled him for more than a month, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 20, by the St. Louis Cardinals and will undergo exploratory arthroscopic surgery Monday. The Cardinals called up Mike Fitzgerald from the Louisville farm team. Manager Whitey Herzog said he expected Horner to miss six weeks if ordinary surgery is required and the remainder of the season if major surgery is necessary.

title: High Court Getting Unusual Plea Not to Reverse Key Rights Ruling
description: In an extraordinary massing of political and legal prestige, 60 senators, 47 state attorneys general, the American Bar Association, prominent historians and more than 100 civil rights, religious and civic groups will urge the Supreme Court not to overrule a major 1976 civil rights decision.

title: Stage Critics Can't Get Water Out of Stones; Killing Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Four Perspectives On Free Markets
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN used his final summit conference, in Toronto this week, to hail once again the virtues of the market economy. ''The economies of the summit countries have come roaring back,'' he said, ''driven by a common commitment to replace government control with market-oriented policies.''

title: D.&H. Railway Takeover Set
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission on Wednesday authorized the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway Corporation to take over the railway services of the Delaware & Hudson Railway Company, which sought protection from its creditors earlier this week and ceased operation early today New York, Susquehanna & Western, which is based in Cooperstown, N.Y., is required by the commission to perform, for 45 days, all functions that Delaware & Hudson had performed. A. Dennis Hicks, a commission spokesman, said the I.C.C. was formulating a long-term plan to keep services flowing. New York, Susquehanna &

title: Bridge
description: The fictional international intrigues and deceptions in Casablanca during World War II hardly matched those in the same African city earlier this month. The Moroccan tournament, which began June 10 and lasted a week, attracted stars from three other continents. Who would play with whom led to some devious maneuvering.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an auction of celebrity mementos incorrectly characterized the sale of a pair of ruby slippers from ''The Wizard of Oz.'' While the $165,000 bid for the slippers was the highest price paid for a piece of motion picture memorabilia at Christie's, an Aston-Martin car used in the James Bond movies was sold by Sotheby's two years ago for $275,000.

title: Reviews/Theater; On Flight and Surviving
description: ''The Grand Tour'' took as its starting point S. N. Behrman's version of Franz Werfel's play ''Jacobowsky and the Colonel.'' Tuned into a musical, the tale of a Polish colonel trying to reach London in 1940 in the company of a Polish-German-Austrian-French Jew arrived on Broadway in 1979, with Joel Grey as Jacobowsky. It has now found its way to the Jewish Repertory Theater, where it offers the predictable pleasures of a packaged excursion.

title: Article 251488 -- No Title
description: A Senate panel voted Tuesday to increase spending for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, clearing the way for an $800 million appropriation for a space station.

title: Hiring Procedures for Civil Service Revamped
description: The hiring process for Federal Civil Service jobs will be streamlined under a new Reagan Administration policy that will rely solely on college grades or skills tests, a Government official said today.

title: Company News; CARBIDE TO INCORPORATE ITS 3 KEY BUSINESSES
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday announced a restructuring that would create separately incorporated companies of its three worldwide businesses, with the parent acting as a holding company.

title: INSIDE
description: Pope Meets With Waldheim John Paul II arrived in Austria and met with President Kurt Waldheim, who has been accused of complicity in Nazi war crimes. Page A3. Reading Scores Improve New York City children have slightly improved their scores on reading tests, but they still fall far short of statewide averages. Page B1. 300 Feared Dead in Turkey Mud and rock cascaded down a rain-soaked mountain and smashed into a Turkish village. As many as 300 people were feared dead. Page A9. Veterans' Records Found The Veterans Administration will review disability claims after finding copies of lost records. Page A10. Dennis Day Is Dead The actor, singer and long-time comedian with the Jack Benny troupe was 71 years old. Page D17.

title: 911 Dispatcher Suspended Over Delay in Response to Call for Help
description: The New York City Police Department took disciplinary action yesterday against a 911 operator and a dispatcher in the aftermath of what was termed ''a serious delay'' in reporting a telephone call for help from a Queens woman who was subsequently shot to death in her home.

title: U.S. Judge Dismisses Suit by Two Journalists in 1984 Nicaraguan Bombing
description: A Federal District judge today dismissed a multi-million dollar civil suit filed by two American freelance journalists against 29 people in connection with a terrorist bombing in Nicaragua four years ago.

title: POP/JAZZ: Arts Festival; Where They're Performing
description: Here is the schedule for the JVC Jazz Festival. Festival information: 787-2020. Today

title: Reviews/Theater; O'Neill's Idealistic 'Ah, Wilderness!'
description: It's hard to imagine many showier examples of repertory theater than the pairing of Eugene O'Neill plays brought to Broadway by the First New York International Festival of the Arts. Only days after watching Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst sink into grief as the Tyrones, the embittered parents of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' one can return to the Neil Simon Theater and watch them play the most affectionate and contented couple you'd ever want to meet, the Millers, in ''Ah, Wilderness!'' While both works recollect small-town Connecticut summers (of 1906 and of 1912) in the author's youth, only their surface details overlap. Where ''Long Day's Journey'' offers disturbing emotional fireworks, ''Ah, Wilderness!'' settles for actual fireworks - an Independence Day celebration at the beach.

title: Louganis Aims for Lofty Goal
description: Greg Louganis's diving resume looks like a history book. He is widely recognized in the sport as the best diver ever, with two Olympic, five world, six Pan American Games and 44 United States titles. He won the Sullivan Award in 1984 and the Jesse Owens Award in 1987.

title: On Stage
description: 21st-Century Opera Fans

title: How Israeli Law Justifies Expelling Awad
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Rock; A Spicy Cajun Gumbo
description: Ethnic or geographically defined music tends to be judged by its fidelity to tradition, often placing an unfair burden on young performers. Zachary Richard, a 37-year-old Acadian from southern Louisiana who looks like a Harvard student taking time off to sail boats in the Caribbean, grew up in both Acadian and American cultures. At Mr. Richard's second set at the Lone Star Cafe on Saturday night, his music - neither quite country nor quite city, Cajun or mainstream American rock -showed his background.

title: Solo Timpani
description: Roland Kohloff, the principal timpanist of the New York Philharmonic, is to play the world premiere of Kenneth LaFave's Three Pieces for Unaccompanied Timpani in a concert by the faculty of the Waterloo School of Music tonight at the Richardson Auditorium, Princeton University, Princeton, N.J. Also on the program are works of Bach, Barber, Roussel, Roland-Manuel and Dohnanyi. Among the performers are Nathaniel Rosen, a cellist; Stuart Canin, a violinist; Sol Greitzer, a violist, and Martin Hackelman, a French hornist. Tickets are $10. Information and directions: (609) 452-5000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Acme Precision Products Inc., Detroit, maker of machine tool parts, said Thomas M. Wheeler had resigned as chairman and a director. No successor was named.

title: A Top Scientist's Latest: Math Software
description: A man widely regarded as one of the world's most brilliant scientists formally entered the computer business today with a program intended to do for mathematics what the calculator did for arithmetic.

title: Reviews/Music; New Bargemusic Soloists
description: As its contribution to the First New York International Festival of the Arts, Young Concert Artists presented some of its recent winners in two concerts at Bargemusic, in Brooklyn. The second, on Wednesday evening, was an eclectic sampling of 20th-century works, with repertory staples by Ravel, Bartok and Berio mingling with less frequently heard works in a broad range of styles.

title: Reviews/Music; Blues From the Delta
description: Wearing a bright orange suit, matching shoes and glittering rings on every finger of his right hand, Roosevelt (Booby) Barnes brought raw Mississippi juke-joint blues to Under Acme last weekend in his New York debut. Mr. Barnes, born in 1936, owns a place called the Playboy Club in his hometown of Greenville, Miss., and he hasn't performed much outside the Delta. With James McElroy on bass and Terry Taylor on drums, he played unvarnished, gut-level blues - music made not for posterity, but to stomp hard luck into good times on bandstands and dancefloors.

title: Bayport Journal; Where Nothing Gets Out but News
description: With deadline looming, the newsroom became filled with the old hallmarks of journalism: cigarette smoke and salty language.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the heat wave in New York City defined a megawatt incorrectly and gave an incorrect equivalent measure, in light bulbs. A megawatt is one million watts - the power drawn by 10,000 100-watt light bulbs. New York City used a peak of 9,805 megawatts of electricity on Wednesday, the equivalent of 98,050,000 100-watt light bulbs.

title: Company News; Allegheny Merging Sunbeam and Oster
description: Allegheny International Inc. said it would consolidate the administrative operations of its Sunbeam Appliance Company and Oster into a new company, the Oster/Sunbeam Appliance Company. The two divisions will retain separate sales and marketing departments. Company officials said the consolidation was intended to improve profitability.

title: DENNIS DAY, 71, THE IRISH TENOR AND COMIC FOIL FOR JACK BENNY
description: Dennis Day, an Irish tenor from New York City who made his name and fortune as the perennial adolescent and comic foil on Jack Benny's radio and television shows, died after a long illness late Wednesday at his California home. He was 71 years old and lived in Bel Air, in suburban Los Angeles.

title: Who Censored the Mandela Concert?
description: LEAD: A billion people are said to have tuned in to the recent London concert to free Nelson Mandela. I was proud to have been one of the artists who took part. The show, televised to 60 countries, provided a rare opportunity to focus the world's attention on South Africa and to educate young people about apartheid.

title: Company News; A.T.&T. to Build Plant in Thailand
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans to invest $40 million in Bangkok, Thailand, to build a factory that will produce telephones mainly for the United States market. Work on the factory will begin this fall and is to be completed by 1990.

title: Study Showed That Williamsburg Bridge Could Be Repaired; Not a Navigable River
description: To the Editor:

title: GAF Discloses Inquiry Into Sale of Carbide Stock
description: The GAF Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was under investigation by the United States Attorney in Manhattan for possible securities violations during its unsuccessful bid for the Union Carbide Corporation in 1985.

title: Jackson Advises Students to Persist
description: Mark Jackson remembered the disappointment he and his teammates felt after Auburn eliminated St. John's in the second round of the 1986 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Healthy Rivalry for Clean Campaigns
description: Mayor Koch and New York City's Comptroller, Harrison Goldin, pioneered high ground on the campaign finance issue this week by vowing to forgo a much-abused fund-raising loophole.

title: Soviet Offers to Adjust Imbalance Of Conventional Forces in Europe
description: The Warsaw Pact is prepared to make greater reductions than NATO in conventional forces in Europe to remove imbalances and enhance the prospects for a more comprehensive arms-reduction agreement, a senior Soviet arms control official said today.

title: Pentagon Inquiry Enters New Phase
description: The Pentagon bribery and fraud investigation has entered a new phase in which investigators will sift through reams of documents to confirm, or explore beyond, statements overheard on wiretaps.

title: GENETECH OFFERS FREE DRUG FOR THE NEEDY
description: Genentech Inc. said yesterday that it would provide its Activase anti-clotting drug without charge to hospitals for treating low-income heart-attack patients. The company estimated there are 25,000 such patients a year.

title: MADDUX WINS 13TH
description: The Mets lost a big one today in Wrigley Field: One day and one inning after he returned from the disabled list, Keith Hernandez reinjured his torn hamstring muscle and headed back to the disabled list, perhaps until August.

title: Company News; Shoney's Dividend
description: The shareholders of Shoney's Inc., a large restaurant chain based in Nashville, have approved a $730 million recapitalization plan that includes a $20-a-share dividend. The dividend, which will be paid July 25, comprises $16 in cash and $4 in subordinated debentures. In over-the-counter trading today, Shoney's shares closed at $26.625, up 25 cents.

title: Company News; BAA Buying Stake In Ramada Unit
description: Ramada Inc. said it had agreed to sell 80 percent of its international hotel division to BAA P.L.C., a public company that was formerly known as the British Airport Authority, for $91 million. The hotels in 35 countries, including 5 in Britain, will keep the Ramada name and become part of BAA's effort to develop hotels near airports. Also included in the deal is Ramada's 12-hotel Renaissance chain in the United States.

title: Review/Music; Rock and Reggae By Twin Sisters From Nigeria
description: The Lijadu Sisters, identical twins who are Nigerian pop stars, gave New York listeners just a taste of their repertory Tuesday at Sounds of Brazil. To an American listener, Kehinde and Taiwo Lijadu offer a West African parallel to the Pointer Sisters - smiling free spirits, wearing dresses cut from the same fabric, mixing sisterly banter and flirtatiousness.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FIRSTS AND SECONDS

title: Brawley Figure Agrees to Talk, Prosecutors Say
description: Federal prosecutors have cleared the way for the testimony of a man who says he made secret tape recordings of Tawana Brawley's lawyers voicing doubts about the case, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Our Towns; A Mother Kills And the Blame Must Be Shared
description: One morning this week, in a voice barely audible, Tracey Maye stood in a Bronx courtroom and admitted that she had killed her baby girl. During the 15-minute hearing, she sat hunched over, head down. ''Miss Maye,'' Judge Gerald Sheindlin said, ''on March 20, 1987, at about 7:30 in the morning at 1171 Clay Avenue, you did recklessly cause the death by striking her repeatedly with an electrical wire?''

title: Mr. Dukakis and Jerusalem
description: Michael Dukakis has reached for what may seem a vote-getting idea in urging that the U.S. Embassy in Israel be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Yet it's far from clear the idea will win votes or add to the candidate's stature. To shift the embassy site now would be a needless provocation - but to move it in the context of a peace settlement would be a crowning achievement.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Joe Williams's Blues

title: Company News; Chas. A. Stevens Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Chas. A. Stevens Company, a women's clothing retailer with 29 stores in the Chicago area, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The 102-year-old chain cited ''cash flow problems which have been exacerbated by the general downturn in the women's apparel industry.'' It owes roughly $9 million to its creditors, according to the filing.

title: Appeals Court Extends Rights Of Gay Groups
description: A Federal appeals court, in a decision that gay rights advocates said was a major victory, has ruled that a group of homosexual students at the University of Arkansas has a constitutional right to receive public money on the same basis as other student organizations.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 439 money market mutual funds increased by $908.7 million, to $266.28 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 122 institutional funds increased by $458.7 million, to $70.95 billion. The assets of the 220 general-purpose funds were up by $281 million, to $81.83 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased by $169 million, to $113.50 billion, the Washington-based organization said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Nelson at Nine Under Par: Larry Nelson used strong iron play and a solid putter to shoot a nine-under-par 63 for a one-shot lead in the first round of the $700,000 Atlanta Golf Classic yesterday. Nelson, who lives in a house adjacent to the 18th fairway of the Atlanta Country Club course in Marietta, Ga., held the lead over Bobby Wadkins, still seeking his first PGA Tour victory in his 14th season.(AP) Inkster Grabs Lead: Juli Inkster shot a 4-under-par 67 yesterday for a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the $500,000 L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship in Wilmington, Del. Six players shot 68 and 13 others were at 69 after the first of four rounds over the 6,366-yard DuPont Country Club course. Inkster had five birdies in the round.(AP) Durnian Leads in French Open: Denis Durnian of Britain shot a 5-under-par 65 yesterday to take the first-round lead in the $900,000 French Open in Chantilly, France. Curtis Strange, the winner of the United States Open, shot a 70 over the 7,215-yard course, closing with birdies on 17 and 18. Richard Boxall and Keith Waters of Britain each shot 66 and Mark Mouland of Britain was another shot back at 67.(AP) Joyce Defeats Albus: Mike Joyce of Huntington, the 1983 champion, defeated Jim Albus of Piping Rock, a four-time winner of the event, 2 and 1, to win the Union Savings Bank/Long Island Professional Golfers' Association championship at Bethpage State Park. Joyce had four birdies on the back nine, including the clincher on the par 3, 220-yard 17th hole. Basketball United States Routs Austria: Shelton Jones of St. John's led the way with 17 points as the United States Select basketball team routed an Austrian all-star team, 115-46, last night in Vienna. The victory was the fifth in a row for the American team on the tour to decide additional finalists for the United States Olympic tryout camp in mid-July. Sixteen finalists have already been chosen.(AP) Arena Football Detroit Routs New York: Rich Ingold completed 21 of 31 passes for 226 yards and 5 touchdowns as the Detroit Drive routed New York, 49-9, last night, handing the Knights their eighth straight defeat. Dwayne Dixon, the league's top receiver, caught four touchdown passes, three of them from Ingold and the fourth from Todd Hons, the backup quarterback, who also scored on a 17-yard run. The Knights, who trailed 16-0 at halftime, scored their lone touchdown on a 30-yard run by John Shephard 1:46 into the final quarter.(AP) Cycling Victory for Austrian: Helmut Wechselberger, a 35-year-old Austrian who began as a pro cyclist only last year, won the Tour de Suisse road race yesterday. Wechselberger beat Steve Bauer of Canada and Acacio da Silva of Portugal with an overall time of 44 hours 56 minutes 22 seconds for the 1,121-mile chase through Switzerland. He was 1 minute 27 seconds faster than Bauer and an additional 19 seconds ahead of da Silva. Wechselberger breezed to the overall victory in the 10th and final stage, a 113-mile flat run from Schaffhausen to Zurich that was won by Urs Freuler of Switzerland.(AP) Yachting Conner Finishes Last: Bengal III of Japan took the lead early on the first leg and won the opening race by a margin of 1 minute 27 seconds in the World 12-Meter championships yesterday in Lulea, Sweden. Dennis Conner of San Diego finished 10th, in last place, aboard Kookaburra II.(AP)

title: DEVELOPER OF PERSONALITY THEORY
description: Henry A. Murray, a psychologist and educator who was a pioneer in the development of personality theory, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 95 years old.

title: Goldin to Bar Business Gifts For Campaign
description: New York City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin grabbed the political initiative yesterday and, going a step further than Mayor Koch, said he would accept no corporate contributions at all for his 1989 campaign.

title: Oil Cutback By Norway
description: Norway will cut its North Sea oil production by 7.5 percent in the second half of this year, the Oil and Energy Ministry said.

title: Dukakis Endorses Tax Increases for Massachusetts
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who has promised to raise Federal taxes only as ''a last resort'' as President, approved two measures to raise taxes in Massachusetts today in an effort to balance his state's budget.

title: TV Station Fined in Indecency Case
description: The Federal Communications Commission acted today to levy the first fine for violation of its new decency standards.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is time to stop waffling so much and say that the evidence is pretty strong that the greenhouse effect is here.'' - Dr. James E. Hansen of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A1:3. ]

title: How Israeli Law Justifies Expelling Awad; Not Awads, but Sadats
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: The Senate; Election-year Ritual Snags Appointment Process
description: Susan Wing has learned something about election-year politics in the last few months.

title: Damaged Lawns Replanted
description: A lawn care company is replanting dozens of lawns after accidentally spraying them with grass-killing herbicides last month. Although some children playing on the lawns reported getting rashes, a state health official said the herbicides, used by Tru Green Corporation of Windsor, were ''very, very safe'' and posed no health risk. The company is also providing each homeowner one free year of lawn service and a $200 check to cover watering costs.

title: Singing the Blues
description: Carrie Smith is to sing blues and jazz tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260); Clark Terry on trumpet is to perform with her tonight. Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: DOWN BY 3-0, YANKS RALLY FOR PINEILLA
description: Playing Billyball without Billy Martin, the Yankees won by rallying from a 3-0 deficit last night.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time Ad Incentive Plan Is Extended for a Year
description: Time Inc. has extended its two-year-old advertising incentive program called the Maximum Advertising Exposure Plan for another year.

title: Black Man Beaten in Racial Attack, Police Say
description: In what the police say is the second racially motivated attack in New York City in two days, a black man was beaten by a group of white men yesterday after he went to the aid of a white woman who was quarreling with a white man, the police said.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Willie Stargell, who will be inducted into the Hall of Fame on July 31, has been named honorary captain for the National League team in the 59th All-Star game July 12 in Cincinnati. The American League's honorary captain will be Bobby Doerr, who entered the Hall of Fame in 1986. . . . The contract of John Chaney, who last season led Temple to the school's first No. 1 ranking in The Associated Press basketball poll and to a 32-2 record, has been extended through the 1993-94 season.

title: Japan Taking Australia Beef
description: Japan has agreed to open its market to more beef imports from Australia, Government officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: New Face: Roger Rabbit; Deserving Toon Gets His Big Break
description: Sure, everybody's going around now and saying Roger Rabbit is a star. But it's one of those overnight success stories that was more than 40 years in the making.

title: Rose Franken, 92, Author of the 'Claudia' Stories
description: Rose Franken, a playwright and novelist whose play ''Claudia'' was named by the critics as the best of the 1941 season, died Wednesday night in Tucson, Ariz., where she lived. She was 92 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Gets A Shot at Trump Castle
description: Now it is the turn of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss to be agency for Trump Castle in Atlantic City. The budget last year was $5 million.

title: Reptiles' Link to Birds May Be Settled
description: A larger fossil specimen of the primordial bird Archeopteryx has been discovered in West Germany, and paleontologists believe it should dispel any lingering notion that these fossils were an elaborate 19th-century hoax.

title: Mistrial Is Declared In Newman Lawsuit
description: A judge yesterday granted a mistrial in a lawsuit pitting a delicatessen owner against the actor Paul Newman when jurors said they could not deliberate impartially after getting a look at unauthorized evidence.

title: JOHN PAUL II MEETS WALDHEIM AGAIN
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today for a five-day visit intended to encourage Roman Catholics in Austria and neighboring Eastern European countries, but burdened by the controversy around President Kurt Waldheim and a dispute in the Austrian church.

title: A Law That Can Help Scrub the Air
description: Get ready, America. It's almost time to celebrate our independence -independence, that is, from environmental ignorance.

title: The Media Business; Advo Settles In Times Suit
description: Advo-Systems Inc., a direct-mail advertising sales company, said yesterday that it had reached a settlement in a lawsuit against The New York Times Regional Newspaper Group, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: BASEBALL PERSON STRIKES AGAIN
description: IN the Yankee Stadium team parking lot yesterday evening the cars were coming and going, going and coming, like in a movie with the reels reeling forward and then backward, backward into time.

title: Review/Ballet; Two New Paris Casts in Nureyev's 'Swan Lake'
description: The traditional version of ''Swan Lake'' is already a difficult ballet. Nevertheless, Rudolf Nureyev has added fresh difficulties to it in his curious production for the Paris Opera Ballet. He has created new dances filled with fussy steps and has encumbered the plot with symbolism that may be clearer to him in his mind than it actually is on stage.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Ahmed Abdullah

title: F.B.I. Reports Several New Searches
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today that it had searched the offices of a Long Island paper company and the homes or offices of three people as part of a bribery investigation involving Pentagon officials and some of the nation's largest military contractors.

title: Sports People; McCray to Coach
description: Scooter McCray has been an informal goodwill ambassador for the Louisville basketball program since he ended his college career five years ago. Now McCray, who helped the Cardinals reach the Final Four in 1982 and 1983, needs only administrative approval to become an assistant coach to his former mentor, Denny Crum. On July 1, McCray will replace Bobby Dotson and be a recruiter.

title: Gay Airman Who Fought Ouster Dies From AIDS
description: Leonard P. Matlovich, a former Air Force technical sergeant who became a rallying point for the national homosexual rights movement when he was expelled from the service after publicly declaring his homosexuality, died of complications from AIDS Wednesday at the home of a friend in West Hollywood. He was 44 years old.

title: Rowntree Accepts Bid By Nestle
description: Rowntree P.L.C. today accepted an improved $4.5 billion buyout offer from Nestle S.A., ending a months-long takeover fight for the British confectioner, the maker of Kit Kat chocolate bars.

title: Restaurants
description: Harlequin

title: Five Broadway Shows to Close
description: Five Broadway shows - one musical and four plays, including two by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright August Wilson - are closing this weekend.

title: Stage Critics Can't Get Water Out of Stones
description: To the Editor:

title: The Media Business; Bass Says It Has Financing For Cash Bid for Macmillan
description: The Robert M. Bass Group of Texas said yesterday that it had the necessary financing to make a cash tender offer for Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publishing and information services company.

title: Do Black and White Children Learn the Same Way?
description: The re-emergence of a theory that many black and white children learn differently because of their different cultural backgrounds has set off a political and intellectual debate among New York officials and educators.

title: U.S. Won't Charge Columnist
description: Carl L. Rowan, a syndicated columnist who shot and wounded an unarmed prowler in the backyard of his Washington home, will not be charged with assault, United States Attorney Jay B. Stephens announced today.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in some editions yesterday about a news conference by Mike Tyson and Michael Spinks in Atlantic City misidentified the pictured speaker. He was Mark Etess, the moderator. The caption also misstated the seating order of Bill Cayton and Stephen Hyde. Mr. Cayton, in light jacket and glasses, was at the left of Mr. Hyde.

title: U.S.-Japan Venture Seen
description: Japan and the United States are near an agreement on a project to double Japanese imports of American goods in three years, an official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The campaign, known as

title: Count of Illegal Aliens For Census Is Debated
description: Lawmakers clashed today over the question of counting illegal aliens in the 1990 census, which will be used to determine how many seats each state gets in the House of Representatives.

title: Test Scores Improve a Bit In New York
description: Children in New York City's public school system did slightly better this year on citywide reading and math tests than they did last year, according to results released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: DOW FALLS BY 3.91 TO END RALLY
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average, which on Wednesday surged to its highest point since the October market collapse, fell 3.91 points, to 2,148.29.

title: Profit Taking Ends Rally In Corn and Soybean Prices
description: Heavy selling brought the long advance in corn and soybean prices to a halt yesterday after the commodities had scored limited gains.

title: Pay Now for Thrifts, or Drown Later
description: Sunbelt Savings in Dallas declares a $1.2 billion loss in a single quarter . . . Two bankrupt savings and loans in California are liquidated at a cost of $1.35 billion . . . Regulators estimate thrift industry losses at $15 billion annually . . .

title: Introducing Fairness Into Health-Care Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: When Congress Takes Care of Kids
description: Unmet needs of America's poor children grow more manifest each year, yet it is unrealistic to expect big funding increases for child welfare in an era of huge budget deficits. But Washington dares not overlook the need for steady if small increases. Even modest new investments offer long-term payoffs of increased productivity and reduced crime and dependence.

title: Transactions
description: WEDNESDAY BASEBALL

title: Ottawa Expels Another Soviet Official in Spy Case
description: The Canadian Government expelled a Soviet military attache today and barred another Soviet diplomat from returning to Canada.

title: America Is Buckling and Leaking
description: America is falling apart, literally.

title: Workers at Bus Depots Still Said to Waste Time
description: Two years after Transportation Authority inspectors found New York City bus-maintenance workers arriving late, leaving early, taking long breaks and wasting an hour and a quarter a shift in the process, the situation has not improved.

title: Review/Pop; Old Irish Tunes And Rock Songs To a World Beat
description: An encouraging aspect of what has been called the world-beat movement, in which ancient regional styles are translated into modern electronic pop without sacrificing traditional rhythm and modality, is that no one fusion of old and new sounds quite like any other.

title: Key Howard Beach Witness Sought
description: As one victim of the Howard Beach racial attack testified in a Queens court yesterday, another was being sought by the authorities in Virginia on charges that he shot and seriously wounded his brother this week.

title: Company News; Freddie Mac Plan Backed
description: The head of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, and top savings and loan industry officials today unanimously endorsed legislation that would allow Freddie Mac to sell preferred stock to the public for the first time. The measure is seen as a way to bolster the ailing savings and loan industry.

title: The New Irrelevance
description: For two days men and women of accomplishment and political sophistication, from 60 countries, held a meeting here that was part of the funeral rites of Communism as an intellectual and emotional power in the world.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: Nancy Beck, Cynthia Perry, Maureen Sage and Angelika Thiel have been promoted to senior vice presidents, management directors, at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: TV Weekend; As Harold Prince Sees His Career
description: With commercial and public television deep into rerun territory these days, the time is ripe for poking into cable schedules. There's more to them than movies and music videos. On Sunday at 10 P.M., for one reasonable instance, the Arts & Entertainment network has a profile of Harold Prince, the theater producer.

title: Sports People; Schoolgirls Honored
description: The top 12 female athletes from New York City public high schools were honored last night at the eighth Pegasus Outstanding Athlete Awards Dinner at the Tavern on the Green. The 1988 winners, their schools and sports are Clare Guerriero, Curtis (basketball); Michelle Sansone, Franklin Delano Roosevelt (bowling); Lauren Jacobs, Sheepshead Bay (gymnastics); Lori Ann Gheraldi, New Dorp (soccer); Jennifer Murphy, Bronx Science (swimming); Melissa Franco, Midwood (tennis); Sharon Moore, Boys and Girls (indoor track); Dionnedra Wilson, A. Phillip Randolph (outdoor track); Monica Scarborough, Canarsie (cross-country); Sharon McFarlan, DeWitt Clinton (volleyball); Tracy Schneider, Flushing (softball), and Marjorie Lewis, Morris (handball).

title: Books of The Times; A Deadly Psychopath and Murder Amid Mockery
description: Crimson Joy By Robert B. Parker 211 pages. Delacorte Press. $16.95. Saturday Night Dead By Richard Rosen 274 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: John Collins, 85, Dies; A Catholic Lay Leader
