description: LEAD: What do New England's Georges Bank fishery, the Florida Keys and California's spectacular Mendocino coast have in common? Aside from their internationally famous natural and recreational resources, all may be auctioned off to the oil industry within about a year.

title: Military and Preservationists Clash Over Mojave's Future
description: More than a century after settlers seeking a route to the Pacific fought the Indians for control of the vast Mojave Desert, another bitter battle for this forbidding expanse has been joined.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase 6.9% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 6.9 percent rise in the number of shares sold short that have not yet been covered among the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; School Busing Fee for an Indigent Pupil Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that an indigent North Dakota child who lived 16 miles from the nearest school did not have a constitutional right to use a school bus service without paying a state-mandated fee.

title: The He-Man Market
description: Was it the relentless daily pounding by G.I. Joe and He-Man or the saccharine charms of Pound Puppies? Whatever the motivation, Congress is headed toward passage of intelligent legislation to set advertising limits for children's television and encourage more educational children's shows.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the effects of the drought and the strain it has placed on utilities misstated the change in Lake Michigan's level since 1986. It has fallen about two and a half feet.

title: Early Retirements Pose Possible L.I.R.R. Crisis
description: The Long Island Rail Road, the nation's largest commuter rail system, is facing what could be a ''disastrous'' exodus of its most senior employees through early retirement because of two changes in the Federal tax laws, the railroad's president said yesterday.

title: 2 Pentagon Computers Stolen
description: Investigators from the Defense Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are looking into the theft of two small computers on consecutive nights from the Pentagon's ''Star Wars'' offices, a high-security area.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABI American Businessphones Inc., Irvine, Calif., said it had received an unsolicited $10-a-share offer from a group led by an ABI director, Jean Stiegemeyer. Bercor Inc., La Mirada, Calif., a toys, small appliances and stationery distributor, said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Burlington Industries, Greensboro, N.C., a textiles concern, said it had signed an agreement to sell its Greige Sales division to a group of Burlington management and affiliates of Wesray Capital Corp. Terms were not disclosed. Grease Monkey International, a unit of Grease Monkey Holding Corp., Denver, entered into an agreement with Quaker State Corp. to use its motor oil and lubricating products as the ''products of choice'' at all Grease Monkey centers.

title: Nets Add Assistant
description: Lee Rose, one of three active coaches to have taken two colleges to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament's Final Four, has been hired as an assistant coach of the Nets. Rose, 50 years old, who was an assistant with the San Antonio Spurs the last two seasons, joins Butch Beard on the staff of Coach Willis Reed. In 1977, Rose took the University of North Carolina-Charlotte to the semifinal round and in 1980 he repeated the feat with Purdue.

title: No Penalty in Smoking Death
description: The jury in a case linking the perils of asbestos and smoking found today that the American Tobacco Company was not liable in a former shipyard worker's death from lung cancer but that the company should have put warning labels on cigarette packs sooner.

title: COPING: With Octane Levels
description: Drive into almost any gas station these days and you find leaded and unleaded, regular and super, ethanol and methanol. Octanes vary, as does the quality of the gasoline. What kind of gas does your car thirst for?

title: I.B.M. Challenging Its Competitors' Use Of New Technology
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has begun warning competitors that they may be infringing on patents for the hottest new technology in computer design.

title: Your Money; Municipal Bonds Require Prudence
description: RETAIL brokers have so far enjoyed a banner year in municipal bond sales. Munis, after all, have an appeal that few other investments can match - tax-free income - and, many individuals believe, they are safe and hassle-free. Unfortunately, that is not so. ''Munis are for the astute investor,'' said Jay Goldinger, co-founder and principal of Capital Insight Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., retail and institutional brokerage. He noted that municipal bonds are traded in a bid-and-ask market that has no price-quotation tape and less liquidity than the markets in United States Government securities and common stocks. Therefore, the majority of investors who are attracted to municipal bonds should invest through no-load municipal bond funds, not directly, he said.

title: Review/Dance; 4 Black Choreographers Celebrated in Festival
description: The culminating event in the first year of ''The Black Tradition in American Modern Dance,'' a three-year project by the American Dance Festival, took place on Thursday night in Page Auditorium at Duke University. Dances by four black American choreographers were performed by four companies chosen and overseen by each choreographer.

title: John Paul Meets With Austrian Jews
description: Pope John Paul II met with leaders of the remnant of Austrian Jewry today and visited the site of the concentration camp at Mauthausen, where he condemned the ''lunatic ideology'' that had created the machinery of hatred and death.

title: BUSH WIDENS VOW NOT TO INCREASE TAXES IF ELECTED
description: Vice President Bush expanded his campaign pledge against raising taxes today by ruling out any new or higher taxes or ''revenue enhancers'' if he is elected President.

title: Dollar Rise Lifts Prices of U.S. Bonds
description: Prices of Treasury securities resumed their advance yesterday, with the longest maturities registering the largest gains. Dealers again attributed the rise in bond prices to this week's surge in the value of the dollar.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Crab-Mating Season YOU missed them. But Mindy Block of Port Jefferson, Sylvia Morgenfruh of Amityville and Kathleen Wohlgemuth of East Meadow didn't. Neither did Matthew Scalafani of St. James, Mae Tierney of Centereach and Stella Baker of Smithtown. Of course, they were looking for them; you probably weren't.

title: Rooting Out Illegal Dumping
description: WHEN private garbage haulers in Plainfield, N.J., tripled their rates earlier this year, many homeowners found a simple way to cut costs: They began dumping their trash in schoolyards, parks and vacant lots.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Yorktown's Novel Road to Affordability
description: LEAD: YORKTOWN has added a new twist - flexibility - to an old concept - bonus zoning - in hopes of encouraging development of housing that people with low or moderate incomes can afford.

title: A Doctor's Favorite Medical Start-Ups
description: MANY people think the stock market is so sick, it needs a doctor. D. H. Blair & Company, the Wall Street investment firm, actually has one.

title:
DINING OUT;
Romantic Setting on Glen Island
description: LEAD: SINCE its opening four years ago, this beauty has had a number of setbacks and false starts and shifts in both kitchen and management, but recent visits found the restaurant on its feet and headed for better days.

title: Pasadena's Parade Of 50's Collectibles
description: PASADENA is an old-money city where families like the Huntingtons of the Southern Pacific Railroad, the Wrigleys of Wrigley's gum, and the Gambles of Procter & Gamble built mansions, now museums, and where Los Angeles glitter was consciously eschewed in favor of a low-keyed elegance. This difference remains apparent in revealing details: the casually conservative dress of men and women in Pasadena, and the Eastern-college look of its young people. Los Angeles couples sometimes move to Pasadena when their children approach school age. ''It's real, not a place built on the entertainment industry,'' said a young assistant producer who had recently made this move with his wife (a designer) and their daughter.

title: High-Tech Continued
description: MINOLTA, the company that started most of the auto-focusing fuss with its Maxxum SLRs, has introduced a trio of updated, high-tech cameras. One is a dual-lens compact that has a broad auto-focus sensing area. The others are second-generation Maxxum SLRs.

title: WHO WILL WIN: SPINKS OR TYSON?
description: This fight is not about pugilistic skills. This fight is about money. If the expected gross of this fight is $70 million, can you imagine what the gross on a rematch would be if Spinks beats Tyson? $100 million? $120 million? I predict that fight will go all the way and Spinks will win by a split decision. MICHAEL GREENBERG Lawrence, L.I.

title: POSTINGS: Off New Haven's Green; Second Edition
description: The 1911 Central Library in New Haven was intended by Cass Gilbert to be distinctly neo-Georgian. But will the library's 65,000-square-foot addition, almost twice the size of the original, also be neo-Georgian? ''I don't think Gilbert would think so, no,'' said Hugh Hardy, the architect. The original reflects the look of the three Colonial churches on the Green, which it faces across Elm Street.

title: Being There, At a Price
description: As almost any Englishman can attest, the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club is something of a misnomer, reflecting the same linguistic license by which such exclusive boarding schools as Eton and Harrow are termed public schools. Membership is highly restricted, and so are tickets to the tennis championships.

title: Move Over, Harvey, and Meet Peter B. Rabbit (B as in Bunny)
description: MY grandson, William, and his mother and father and 1 1/2-year-old sister, Emily, recently moved to the Philadelphia area from Washington, D.C. This makes it easier for us to see them but no less expensive to talk to them on the telephone between visits. I think that this is because William appears to have inherited a tendency toward long-windedness from his mother and grandmother.

title: New York Designates 9 New Development Zones
description: Nine economically troubled communities, including East Harlem and Yonkers, have been added to the list of state economic development opportunity zones.

title: Allison Chisolm Becomes a Bride
description: Allison Chisolm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Chisolm of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Holger Hansen, the son of the Rev. and Mrs. G. Holger Hansen of Swarthmore, Pa. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. He was assisted by the bridegroom's father, who is a United Methodist minister.

title: The Industrialized World Shows Its Love for the Farm
description: THANKS to political influence that far exceeds their waning numbers, farmers in the industrial countries receive more than $200 billion a year in subsidies, a level of support that has doubled in the past 10 years. The cost of this aid, at a time when most governments are trying to cut fiscal deficits, is causing a crisis in the trading relationship of the allies.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE NEW BRITAIN MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART;
After 85 Years, a Museum Takes Steps to Be Noticed
description: LEAD: FOR the first time in its 85-year history, the New Britain Museum of American Art is going outside the family, so to speak, for money to support its future.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Medieval Damsels and Pale Ladies of Death
description: LEAD: Founded in England in 1848 by Dante Gabriel Rossetti, John Everett Millais and William Holman Hunt, among others, the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood sought to counter what these artists perceived as frivolity in the painting of the time and return to what they considered the more naturalistic expressions of Italian artists painting before the time of Raphael.

title: THE WORLD: October to June; A Busy Seven Months of Perestroika
description: Oct. 21 - Boris N. Yeltsin, in an outburst at a closed meeting of the Party Central Committee, attacks colleague Yegor K. Ligachev, the No. 2 party leader, as an obstructionist; Yeltsin announces his resignation as Moscow party chief and is later dropped from Politburo. Caution sets in among the perestroika vanguard. Nov. 2 - Gorbachev gives a cautious speech marking the revolution's 70th anniversary. Nevertheless, it opens the floodgates for attacks on Stalin. Jan. 1 - Sixty percent of Soviet industry is given financial autonomy, but bureaucracy impedes change; consumers see no immediate gains. Feb. 5 - Nikolai I. Bukharin, a Bolshevik leader executed by Stalin, is rehabilitated as a perestroika hero, the champion of the socialism that might have been, without Stalin. Feb. 28 - Thirty-two people are killed in Sumgait, Azerbaijan, as territorial dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan presents Gorbachev with his worst domestic political crisis. March 13 - With Gorbachev out of town, a letter in Sovetskaya Rossiya, signed by a Leningrad teacher but bearing Ligachev's fingerprints, rails against Western influence, blackening of Soviet history and permissiveness. For three weeks no one dares respond; panic spreads among liberals. April 5 - Pravda publishes a Gorbachev-inspired rebuttal, a resounding call for change, and advocates of change rush again to the front lines. April 29 - Authorities in Estonia permit creation of the first political force outside the Communist Party. Group combines pro-Gorbachev calls for democracy with strong streak of Estonian nationalism; has grown to 40,000 participants by June. May 15 - Soviet troops begin withdrawal from Afghanistan. May 26 - Party publishes Gorbachev's reform proposals: a call for limiting terms of officials, more democracy, a less intrusive party and legal safeguards on human rights. May 29-June 1 - U.S.-Soviet summit in Moscow. June - Vasily Selyunin, an economics writer, suggests in monthly issue of Novy Mir that the party's abuses started with Lenin. June 5 - Russian Orthodox Church begins celebration of its millennium, enjoying new attention from a state eager to recruit believers in the cause of perestroika.

title: Gender Gaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Draft Day '88: A Strange Voyage
description: Wayne Embry called the National Basketball Association college draft Tuesday a trip into uncharted waters.

title: On the Danube
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the article on the Danube Princess (Travel, March 20). Having made the Danube cruise on that ship two years ago, we would agree that it is a pleasing itinerary and the Danube Princess is generally a good river cruise vessel. I can't help wondering, however, whether the operation still suffers from some inadequacies that we experienced: (1) no life jackets on board; (2) student dining room personnel who, despite enthusiasm and pleasantness, were quite untrained and unable to serve simultaneously the four persons at our table, and (3) a musical ensemble for dancing that was so discordant that people avoided the salon. When we asked why there were no life preservers, the cruise director said that the ship never gets that far from shore so they would be unnecessary! LARRY ALTHOUSE Dallas Fred A. Mayer, president of Exprinter Danube Cruises replies: It is correct that there are no life jackets on board the Danube Princess, but that is by design. The Danube is a very shallow river with a depth of only 2 to 2.5 meters. The Danube Princess was specifically designed to sail on the Danube. It has a draft of 1.7 meters and glides over a space of about 30 to 80 centimeters depending upon the water level. Hence, under any consideration the ship cannot sink; it can only fall by 30 to 80 centimeters. The life-saving equipment that is aboard the ship is in full compliance with strict West German shipping guidelines. It would be both unnecessary and possibly dangerous to use life-saving equipment designed for high seas on a shallow river.

title: The Houses Aren't Selling
description: LEAD: AFTER more than two years of record sales and skyrocketing appreciation in residential real estate, the Long Island housing boom has gone bust.

title: Hemlock Troubles
description: WATER. Shallow-rooted woody plants such as azaleas, rhododendrons, pieris, fruit trees, saplings and container gardens have priority; do not neglect them. Cool season grasses - bluegrasses and fescues -become dormant in hot dry weather. If there are no local restrictions, run sprinklers slowly to soak water deeply into root zones. Where there are restrictions, recycle usable water especially from cooking and dehumidifiers. Insect Alert

title: PLOTTING A THEORY OF THE BRAIN
description: Congratulations on David Hellerstein's engaging article ''Plotting a Theory of the Brain'' (May 22).

title: School in Illinois Cited For Asbestos Removal
description: Workers removing old floor tiles at a suburban high school sent clouds of dust containing asbestos into the air, Federal officials charged Friday.

title: Bed and Breakfast, Southern Style
description: WITHIN the past decade a good deal has been written about the virtues of bed-and-breakfast lodgings, a concept borrowed from small private hostelries in Britain. The idea being, of course, that you check into a private home to spend a night or two and awaken to the smell of freshly brewed coffee, homemade muffins and the sounds of birds chirping or a lawn mower whirring outside the window.

title: Truth in Fiber
description: The nation's diet industry pocketed $50 million last year selling ''all natural'' fiber supplements claimed to promote both slimness and good health. According to the National Cancer Institute, eating more fiber may reduce the risk of colon cancer. Yet most of these costly supplements contain only scant amounts of fiber. The Federal Food and Drug Administration could help consumers by requiring manufacturers to disclose actual fiber content on their packages.

title: Vermont Visits Opened New World to City Girl
description: When she was growing up in New York City, Brenda T. Cobb says, she had the best of both worlds.

title: Review/Theater; Leaving the Veiled Life of Algeria
description: As the lights dim at the start of ''You Have Come Back,'' a play by Fatima Gallaire-Bourega being presented by the Ubu Repertory Theater, the cry of muezzins breaks the pre-dawn darkness, calling the faithful to prayers. Soon an old man enters carrying ever so slowly the heavy suitcase of Lella, a woman who is returning to her native Algerian village after 20 years in France. The tableau sets the pace and tone for the rest of the play.

title: Technology Gets a Helping Hand from Uncle Sam
description: THANKS to the Federal Government, technology companies have become among the fastest-growing Hispanic businesses. The boom has come, in part, from the Section 8(a) of the Minority Small Business and Capital Ownership Development Act, which sets aside a certain number of noncompetitive contracts for minority-owned businesses. This program has helped Hispanic businesses get some of their biggest contracts. In 1986, the most recent year for which statistics are available, revenues at the top 35 Hispanic high-technology companies came to $334.5 million, according to Hispanic Business Magazine.

title: Bloop Hit Decisive After 27 Innings
description: Burlington and Bluefield would have gladly ended their Appalachian League game, but there was nothing to stop them for more than eight hours. At 3:27 A.M. Saturday, the Bluefield

title: The F.B.I.'s War on Spies in the Stacks
description: BY tradition and in most states by law, the relationship between libraries and readers is a private one. What books anyone examines or checks out is confidential information. Whether in a school or public library, record- keeping by pencils or computers is designed to insure a book's return and no more than that.

title:
GARDENING;
Overfertilizing can Turn Out Fatal
description: LEAD: EXCESS salts can hurt plants.

title: A NICE PLACE FOR MASTODONS
description: ALASKA By James A. Michener. 868 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: SPORTS CAR SHOW

title: Mexican Roses
description: To the Editor: The Travel Advisory chart ''The Subject Is Roses'' (Travel, May 1) confirms my suspicion about the way most writers approach third world countries. If one looks for prices comparable to those one expects to pay, then - of course - there will be someplace you can buy whatever it is at an inflated price.

title: The Pear or the Plane Tree?
description: LEAD: DOWNTOWN Roslyn may look prosperous, but merchants along Old Northern Boulevard are worried that a six-month road, sidewalk and curb reconstruction project to ease flooding of their stores could put some of them out of business.

title: 'SO, YOU FELL IN LOVE WITH YOUR BABY'
description: BIRTH MOTHER The Story of America's First Legal Surrogate Mother. By Elizabeth Kane. Illustrated. 294 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95. SACRED BOND The Legacy of Baby M. By Phyllis Chesler. 212 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Poetry Is Tough on Typewriters James Laughlin, a protege and close friend of Ezra Pound, has written a charming, untendentious book about him. This is a vignette of the poet in Rapallo, Italy, from ''Pound as Wuz: Essays and Lectures on Ezra Pound'' (Graywolf).

title: Children's Books That Enchanted
description: HUMPTY DUMPTY SAT on a wall. For Italians, on the other hand, ''La sul gran muro Umtio Dumtio sedeva.'' In Latin, the downfall of Humtius Dumtius is the stuff of which epics are made; and if you speak Welsh, you can learn about the sad fate of Hwmti Dwmti.

title: SAVINGS AND LOAN REGULATOR: M. Danny Wall; Staying Calm - Maybe Too Calm - in the Midst of a Crisis
description: M. DANNY WALL calls himself an optimist. To make the point, he pulls a tortoise-shell comb from his pants pocket. Mr. Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has but a modest rim of hair on his head.

title: A LA CARTE
description: NEW restaurants are blooming on Long Island, and nowhere is the eruption of dining spots more evident than in the Hamptons.

title: Eye of the Beholder
description: The beauty contest, approaching anachronism in the West, emerges in the East. The preliminaries of the Beijing Flower pageant took place in late May. The first beauty contest in more than 40 years in a city where the very concept of beauty had been declared ''feudalistic'' began with a flourish.

title:
ART;
A Three-Part 'Showcase'
description: LEAD: IN order to see all of the Hempstead Artists Association's current exhibition, ''Showcase for Excellence in Art,'' a little wanderlust is required. The show is divided into three sections, two at the association's Glen Cove galleries and the third at the Midge Karr Art Center at the New York Institute of Technology in Old

title: Headliners; Shod?
description: Bidding $165,000 last week for a pair of the ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in ''The Wizard of Oz,'' the fashionably dressed anonymous buyer showed a reticence that would have embarrassed the Cowardly Lion.

title: Magnuson Suffers Attack
description: Former Senator Warren G. Magnuson, whose career in Congress spanned 44 years, has been hospitalized after suffering a slight heart attack Friday. A hospital spokeswoman said that the former Senator from Washington, 83 years old, was responding to medication today and that his condition had stabilized. Mr. Magnuson also has diabetes, which causes poor circulation.

title: Mary E. Horan Is Wed To Securities Executive
description: At St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn., Mary Elizabeth Horan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Horan of Fairfield, was married yesterday to Robert Forrest Lutz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frederick Lutz of Pleasantville, N.Y. The Rev. John Mullen performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Music; Hilton Ruiz's Eclectic Jazz
description: Hilton Ruiz opened the JVC Jazz Festival's piano-solo series (and the festival itself) with an ambitiously eclectic recital Friday afternoon at Weill Hall. Until the hall management started flashing the house lights, Mr. Ruiz touched on styles from ragtime to be-bop to free jazz, with plenty of stops in between. He summoned textures from two-fisted gospel to a percussive Latin vamp to translucent impressionist harmony; he even strummed chords inside the piano and, at one point, placed a piece of paper on the strings to make single notes sound like a music box.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SAIL FOR HUMANITY While sailors are said to be good sports, today more than 250 boaters from the tristate coastal area - sailing everything from high-tech racing machines to cruising boats to windsurfers - will put their reputations on the line for charity. Starting at 10 A.M. and running through the day, the waters of Long Island Sound, between the Throgs Neck Bridge and Hempstead Harbor, will be filled with ships participating in ''Sail for Humanity.'' It's a new event, which its host, the Knickerbocker Yacht Club of Port Washington, hopes to establish as ''the largest charity sailing regatta in the world.'' The Mental Illness Foundation and the Coalition for the Homeless will benefit, to the tune of some $75,000, its organizers expect. RUSSIANS ARE COMING When it comes to entertainment that transcends such artificial barriers as language, the art of clowning has to be right up there at the head of the list. With speech out of the way, that leaves only style to compare, and whether there's any difference between American clowns and Russian clowns, theatergoers can judge for themselves starting Tuesday, when ''The Leningrad Clowns Comedy Revue'' opens a six-performance run in Stony Brook. The latest segment in the International Theater Festival at the State University of New York, the appearance is part of the first American tour by Theater Litsedei, an acclaimed company that already has taken its serio-comic vision of life to audiences throughout Europe and the Far East. For ticket information call 632-7230. 'SUMMERSCAPE'

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Accounting Opportunities
description: LEAD: For the second year, Pace University in Pleasantville will be the host of a weeklong program intended to attract minority students to the accounting profession.

title: Jazz Festival; Impressions of Louis Armstrong
description: ''For the Love of Louis,'' a tribute to Louis Armstrong on the first day of the JVC Jazz festival, started out on wobbly legs, straightened itself up, and flew a steady course for nearly three hours.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ADVICE TO THE PRESIDENT, CONGRESS, AND JUDICIARY. Edited by William T. Golden. (Pergamon, Cloth, $49.95; Paper, $24.95.) The golden age of scientific advice to the President, by most accounts, started when the Soviet launching of Sputnik 1 in 1957 led President Eisenhower to appoint the first White House science adviser and continued through the Kennedy years. In that era, an eminent scientist always served as a full-time adviser to the President, and a panel of distinguished scientists came to town periodically to render additional advice. For the scientists involved, these were heady times when their views received respectful attention. But later the advisory apparatus was largely dismantled by President Nixon, and then restored at a less prestigious level by succeeding Presidents. Today the science adviser toils in obscurity, backed up by a part-time panel that reports to him, not to the President. Now comes this collection of some 85 essays (edited by William T. Golden, president of the New York Academy of Sciences) whose avowed purpose is ''to attract attention to the necessity for quality advice on science and technology issues to the President of the United States, to the Congress, and to the Judiciary.'' The authors are mostly people who have served as part of the Government science advisory apparatus or as close observers of it. Not surprisingly, most favor a stronger science advisory organization at the White House. However, some challenge the notion that today's system is weak or propose new solutions, such as a Cabinet-level Secretary of Science. With few exceptions, the essays are abstract and highly repetitive of one another. The specialist will find most of the arguments familiar; the generalist will find the case asserted rather than proved.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Boston
description: One day this month, winter turned to summer in Boston. Suddenly, it is hot and humid, and the breeze at harborside, where downtown workers seek relief at lunch, does not help. The city's greatest loves, sports and politics, offered some diversion from a chilly, damp spring.

title: SPREADING THE GOSPEL AT HARVARD
description: I am stunned that one of the world's foremost theologians would suggest that a child can grow up in both Jewish and Christian traditions and not violate either one (''Spreading the Gospel at Harvard,'' by Dan Wakefield, May 22).

title: Brooks Robards Marries Jim Kaplan
description: The wedding of Brooks Robards, the daughter of Mrs. Sidney M. Robards of Southern Pines, N.C., and the late Mr. Robards, to Jim Kaplan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kaplan of Cambridge, Mass., took place yesterday at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents in Chilmark, Mass. The Rev. Mary Jenkins Man, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Averell Harriman Mortimer Married to Gigi H. Newhard
description: Gigi Hamilton Newhard, the daughter of Harry Wallace Newhard of St. Louis and Mrs. Richard Pearman of Paget, Bermuda, and New York, was married yesterday to Averell Harriman Mortimer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley G. Mortimer of New York. The Rev. Frederick John Marshall performed the ceremony at Christ Church, Church of Scotland, in Warwick, Bermuda.

title: P.L.O. Agrees on $50 Million to Finance Uprising
description: Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have overcome sharp differences and set aside $50 million to support the six-month-old Arab uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories, Palestinian representatives said today.

title: THE REGION: Goldin's 'Subtleties'; Politics of Campaign Finance
description: WOULD he or would he not?

title:
ART;
A Portrayal of the American Scene, in Southport
description: LEAD: THE Art/Place Gallery in Southport has a stripped-bare look that is a clean background for art. It is an especially advantageous setting for the recent graphic art of Lester Johnson, who portrays the American Scene in its essentials - young men and women together, or women in groups.

title: Aussie Tough
description: I OFTEN THINK I MUST be a disappointment to my American friends. For the idea that the movie hero Crocodile Dundee, played by Paul Hogan, has planted in the popular American imagination is that Australian men are tough in a peculiar, antipodean way. It's an un-self-conscious toughness achieved with a sort of shrugging, Celtic whimsy and fatalism relocated from the auld places, Scotland and Ireland, to another place. To the outback, bush and even the suburbs of what we used to call in the classrooms of our childhood, ''The largest island, the smallest continent and dearest land of all.''

title: THE FAMILY AT HER BEDSIDE
description: SPENCE + LILA By Bobbie Ann Mason. Illustrated by LaNelle Mason. 176 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: CRIME
description: Gerald Petievich, formerly a Treasury Department agent, attracted a good deal of attention in 1981 with his first book -really two novellas - named ''Money Men and One-Shot Deal.'' Both stories dealt with counterfeiters and were unusually realistic - not unexpected, considering the author's background. From there Mr. Petievich went on to several other books (such as ''To Live and Die in L.A.'') in which realism and strong writing dominated. But in his new novel, SHAKEDOWN (Simon & Schuster, $16.95), he has topped anything he has ever written.

title: WHO WILL WIN: SPINKS OR TYSON?
description: The Spinks-Tyson bout will end between rounds seven and nine with Tyson catching up, and stopping his courageous but outgunned challenger. Michael Spinks is a clever boxer-puncher. But he will be battling more than just Mike Tyson. He will be up against inactivity and advancing age. Spinks has not had a fight since he stopped the Great Pretender, Gerry Cooney, last June. Spinks is also 31 years old, and Tyson isn't even 22. ROBERTO EMMENTE Saddle River, N.J.

title: Increase in Charitable Donations in '87 Was Lowest in 12 Years
description: Although Americans contributed a record $93.6 billion to charities in 1987, the rate of increase was the lowest in 12 years, a new report says.

title: Wilander Sets His Own Pace
description: There is no need for an escort to accompany him on the grounds. Spectators don't clamor for autographs or squeal at the mention of his name. After one week of Wimbledon, Mats Wilander continues on the road to the Grand Slam the way he prefers it: quietly.

title: WHO WILL WIN: SPINKS OR TYSON?
description: When all is said and done, Tyson the warrior will channel his frustration into a pounding of Spinks. Iron Mike is a throwback; contrary to reports, he really doesn't care about the money. He wants to fight. Do you think Joe Louis, Joe Frazier or Jack Johnson ever let soap opera surroundings get to them? CHRIS BOTTA Hicksville, L.I.

title: The Risk of Reducing Art to Spectacle
description: WITH ''VITAL SIGNS'' AT the Whitney Museum and ''The Modern Poster'' at the Museum of Modern Art, there are two current shows that stake out ambitious chunks of art-historical terrain - on the one hand, the influence of nature on American abstractionism and, on the other, the poster's century-long history. Each draws exclusively from its own museum's collection. And both suffer for it: Despite their size, these exhibitions lack the depth and curatorial rigor expected from the institutions that sponsored them.

title: DEFECTORS DEBRIEFING THEMSELVES
description: SECRET SERVANT My Life with the KGB and the Soviet Elite. By Ilya Dzhirkvelov. 398 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50. ON THE WRONG SIDE My Life in the KGB. By Stanislav Levchenko. 244 pp. New York: Pergamon-Brassey's International Defense Publishers/Kampmann & Company. $18.95.

title: Haitian Says Drive on Drugs Led to His Ouster as Leader
description: Leslie F. Manigat, deposed by the military as President of Haiti last Sunday, said today that the main reason for his ouster was the resistance of the army and police to his efforts to curb corruption and drug trafficking to the United States.

title: Miss Leness Has Wedding
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Christine Robertson Leness, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Leness of New York and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to David Lawton Boudreau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Boudreau of Plymouth, Minn. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. Oscar Aquino, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE state's most advanced recycling center, West Paterson Auto Recycling Inc., could be forced to close after only a few months of operations unless the West Paterson Board of Adjustment grants it a use variance.

title: Sports of The Times; Piniella Begins Countdown for Henderson's Return
description: AS the obvious successor to Billy Martin in the Yankee dugout, Lou Piniella negotiated from strength. Financially, he obtained a three-year extension through the 1991 season from George Steinbrenner on his two-year manager's contract that would have expired after this season. Socially, he no longer is obliged to be in his hotel room at an appointed hour waiting for the principal owner's phone call, the dispute that disrupted their relationship last season. And strategically, the countdown has begun on Rickey Henderson's future.

title: D'Artagnan on Ninth Street: A Brooklyn Boy at the Library
description: THE library was on Sixth Avenue and Ninth Street on the south slopes of the Brooklyn hills and for a long time in my young life it was the true center of the world.

title: Let the Students Run Schools?
description: ALMOST every Sunday I pick up the newspaper and read articles by some of Long Island's most articulate educators. Their opinions always appear to have merit. Yet when I return to school administration on Monday morning, I cannot seem to find a way to yield to such catch-all phrases as teacher empowerment, academic freedom, higher standards for students and so on.

title: Changes in Store
description: The dates will be earlier and the stakes higher next year for the Doral Open, when $1.3 million in prize money will be awarded comrered with $1 million this year. The tournament, held in early March this year, is scheduled for next Feb. 23-26, officials said this week.

title: Abigail Seymour Becomes a Bride
description: Abigail Comfort Seymour, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus Seymour of Winter Park, Fla., and Stephen Joseph Dubner, a son of Veronica Dubner of Lake Worth, Fla., and the late Solomon P. Dubner, were married yesterday in the Sage Chapel at the Northfield Mount Hermon School in Northfield, Mass. The Rev. Richard P. Unsworth, a Presbyterian minister who is the headmaster of the school, performed the ceremony.

title: Sally Calvin, an Arbitrager, Weds Frank G. Salvaterra
description: Sally Anne Calvin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Calvin of Manhasset, L.I., was married at the Congregational Church there yesterday to Frank Gerard Salvaterra, a son of Antoinetta Salvaterra of Glendale, Queens, and the late Mario Salvaterra. The Rev. Maurice Setty performed the ceremony.

title: Older Drivers
description: To the Editor: I was very glad to read Betsy Wade's ''Back to School for Older Drivers'' (Practical Traveler, April 3). I find the 55/Alive Driving Course praiseworthy and have taken it twice myself. The teachers are excellent and the class very appreciative and responsive. The course is worthwhile not only for the discount in insurance but also as a review of driving rules. I wish every driver could take it, regardless of age.

title: Suburbia's Grass Growers Have Become Zealots of the Lawn
description: THERE is an unwritten rule and ritual in suburbia: Man must toil in the earth to produce the spiritual salvation of the lawn.

title: A WIDOW'S DREAM
description: VALENTINO AND SAGITTARIUS By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by Avril Bardoni. 134 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: British Fans Aren't Alike
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Out of the Barrio and Into the Mainstream
description: BUSINESSES owned by Hispanics are now moving out of Latin neighborhoods and into the mainstream, especially in cities with large Hispanic populations. According to the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Hispanic businesses numbered about 340,000 last year and had revenues of about $20 billion. They include military contractors, travel agencies, banks and auto dealerships. The chamber predicts revenues of more than $25 billion by 1990. ''The Hispanic business community of 10 to 15 years ago is nothing compared to what it is today,'' said Linda Rentz Mayo, executive director of the Ibero-American Chamber of Commerce.

title: Southern Africa Talks to Resume Next Month
description: Representatives of the United States, South Africa, Cuba and Angola today ended two days of talks on the fighting in Angola and neighboring South-West Africa.

title: YOU CAN'T LIE TO A DOG
description: THE WHITE GERMAN SHEPHERD By Vicki Hearne. 205 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: The Problems In Hempstead
description: With regard to the May 22 article ''Hempstead Strives to Change Image,'' I can no longer hold my tongue. There are many problems here in Hempstead, the most significant one being the Mayor, George Milhim.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Listeners' Choice
description: LEAD: Want to upgrade your musical taste a bit? Check out the ''Cafe Society Hit Parade,'' also known as ''The Favorite Songs of the Folks Who Live on the Hill'' or ''The Favorite Songs of the Eastern Establishment.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MILENA. By Margarete Buber-Neumann. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Seaver, $18.95.) After three years in Stalin's gulag, Margarete Buber-Neumann was repatriated in 1940 to Nazi Germany, then Stalin's ally in ''nonaggression.'' For her political crimes, the Gestapo sent her to the concentration camp at Ravensbruck for the rest of World War II.

title: NOTES OF A VISIBLE MAN
description: GOODBYE, SWEETWATER New & Selected Stories. By Henry Dumas. Edited by Eugene B. Redmond. 348 pp. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Not for Brooding
description: THE GOLDEN AGE OF SECOND AVENUE Starring Herschel Bernardi, as narrator. Written and directed by Morton Silverstein. Produced by Arthur Cantor. 1969. Distributed by Arthur Cantor Films, 2112 Broadway, Suite 400, New York, N.Y. 10023. (212) 496-5710.. 70 minutes. $59.95.

title: Riviera Sampler: Cote of Many Colors; Beaches
description: Beaches along the Cote d'Azur are often operated by a plagiste, a person who rents a strip of sand from the town. These beaches, which have their own names, are separated by a long strip of colored fabric. From Cannes as you go east to the Italian border, the operated beaches get increasingly luxurious and well tended, attracting a more fashionable crowd. According to the law, no more than 30 percent of the length of a beach can be operated in this fashion. The rest must remain public and free.

title: Ms. Royster Wed To Paul Kempner
description: Diane Holliday Royster and Paul S. Kempner were married yesterday at their home in Stamford, Conn., by the Rev. Richard Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Jo-Ann Felix Is Married
description: At Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan, Jo-Ann Felix, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Santiago Felix of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Ray Feliciano, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Feliciano of Manhattan. The Rev. Gavin Reilly officiated. Mrs. Feliciano is the director of reservations of the Trans-Lux multimedia show ''The New York Experience'' at Rockefeller Center. Mr. Feliciano is a jeweler with M.B.R. in Manhattan.

title: Samuelson Out
description: SHE won the 1984 Olympic marathon in Los Angeles, but a heavy schedule and the birth of a daughter last fall led Joan Benoit Samuelson to pass up a bid for the women's marathon at the 1988 Games in Seoul. Instead, she said, she would try for the 10,000-meter race. Now, after thinking things over, the 31-year-old Samuelson has decided to pass up the 10,000, too, and focus on a fall marathon.

title: A Folklorist Tells Tales in School
description: LEAD: Mr. Possum was walking in the forest one day and he was having a fine time. Just singing geechee-geechee goo, doodle-doodle doo. He saw a hole and forgot to look in it. So he went back and looked. He saw a snake there with a brick on his back. ON a recent rainy afternoon, Joyce Gilliam-Brown, a folklorist, captivated the attention of 160 third and fourth graders at the Daniel Webster School here while telling them Mr.

title: Leslie Eustis Is the Bride Of Andrew W. Hallowell
description: Leslie Pomeroy Eustis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Eustis of Carbondale, Colo., and Andrew Welch Hallowell, a son of Robin Breed of New York and Washington and Lee Hallowell of Westport, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Community Methodist Church in Carbondale by the Rev. Wallace Finley.

title: Smiles of a Moscow Night
description: YOU SAID YOU WERE for peaceful coexistence,'' Mikhail Gorbachev was reported by Time magazine to have told Ronald Reagan. ''Then why not put [ those words ] in the communique?''

title: Diane Keaton Grapples With Sex and Maternity
description: WHEN LEONARD NIMOY asked Diane Keaton to star in the movie version of ''The Good Mother,'' she was horrified - a response she recalled later in a characteristically Keatonesque volley of breathless, rapid-fire speech, her words tumbling out and ricocheting off each other at crazy angles as she rolled her eyes, buried her face in her hands, fidgeted and made assorted moaning noises.

title: THE NATION: Before and After Atlanta; In His Way, Jesse, Too, Asks, 'What Does Jackson Want?'
description: THE United States Constitution establishes several categories of elected representative, but runner-up for a Presidential nomination is not one of them. Sometimes it seems the Rev. Jesse Jackson would like to change that.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about delays at United States airports carried conflicting entries for the Miami airport. Miami had 31,000 delays of 15 minutes or more for arriving flights in 1986.

title: Now Give the Candidates a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret J. Peters Marries Lee Charles Feldman
description: Margaret Jane Peters and Lee Charles Feldman were married yesterday aboard the yacht Resolute in Narragansett Bay off Newport, R.I. Glenn Nippert, the clerk of the Superior Court of Rhode Island, performed the ceremony.

title: Provence Pilgrimages, High and Low
description: ROSEMARY was the weed outside the door of the house we rented with friends on the skirts of the Luberon mountains in Provence.

title: Dutch Beat Soviets For European Title
description: The Netherlands won its first major soccer trophy today by beating the Soviet Union, 2-0, in the final of the European championships.

title: Iraqi Troops Recapture Big Oil Field
description: In Baghdad's latest campaign to free all Iraqi territory from Iranian occupation, Iraqi troops recaptured the Majnoon oil fields this morning.

title: Mr. Bush, Meet Mr. Lincoln
description: When he received an honorary degree at all-black Central State University recently, Vice President George Bush vowed to ''knock down the walls of indifference'' to minorities. ''We must take specific steps to include those who have been excluded,'' he said, asserting by way of illustration that his own party must ''broaden its base.''

title: Three Cheers For Vander Meer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE FOURTH CODEX. By Robert Houston. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) Traditionally, the United States Customs Service has not enjoyed a high profile in international crime thrillers, but ''The Fourth Codex'' may change all that. Its hero, Quintus Paz, a veteran Special Agent who has tracked smugglers throughout Latin America, has nothing in common with the familiar image of a uniformed passport stamper. As portrayed by Robert Houston - the author of a number of previous novels, including ''Ararat,'' ''The Nation Thief'' and ''Cholo'' - Paz is a man of action, a gaucho like his Argentinian grandfather. Against his natural bent, he has spent the last five years at a dull desk job in Tucson, Ariz., trying to please his safety-conscious wife. Now, divorced and disillusioned, Paz is planning to retire - until he receives special orders to return to Mexico and search for a missing Mayan codex, a priceless document that may already be on its way to unscrupulous collectors in the States. Once south of the border, Paz regains faith in his calling as he follows a dangerous trail that leads from the earthquake-blasted streets of Mexico City to a remote Indian village, the site of the archeological dig that produced the codex - and, it turns out, a far more sinister smuggling operation. Complex as the plot is, it forms only half of ''The Fourth Codex.'' The rest of the tale is a sympathetic account of today's Mexico, a beautiful country whose economic crash has wrought desperation. This is the first volume in a projected series of novels about Quintus Paz and the Customs Service. If Mr. Houston handles foreign locales as convincingly and sensitively in future installments as he does here, his books should attract adventure fans and armchair travelers alike.

title: Town Faces 'Trial' on Landfill
description: LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Conservation is moving to close the Town of Southampton's North Sea landfill, charging that in 1982 clay liners were not installed and that as a result contaminated leachate has been polluting the ground water for the last six years. The town will defend itself at a hearing beginning July 6 at the department's regional headquarters in Stony

title: Ms. Geary, Medical Student, Marries Marc Glimcher, a Doctoral Candidate
description: The marriage of Natalie Wayne Geary and Marc Cooper Glimcher, graduates of Harvard University, class of '85, took place yesterday at Whitefield, an estate in Southampton, L.I. Acting Justice Shirley Fingerhood of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: Brawley Tapes Are All Blank, The F.B.I. Says
description: A man who said he had made secret tape recordings of Tawana Brawley's advisers was charged yesterday with perjury and obstruction of justice after the tapes were found to be blank. The F.B.I. said it appeared that the tapes had never been used.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
A Showcase for Technology
description: LEAD: TECHWORLD, a $342 million mixed-use complex in which a technology trade mart is a major element, has begun to sign up tenants as first-phase construction moves forward. When completed the project will include one million square feet of office and showroom space, a hotel, a conference center and shops and restaurants.

title: Casey, Henrich Strike Again
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Within reason, you can still do hostile deals, but the bigger they are, the harder it is to raise money.'' - Carl C. Icahn, on the implications of his loss in the Texaco proxy fight.

title: Economic Axioms
description: To the Editor:

title: Brennan Misses Court
description: Justice William J. Brennan of the Supreme Court suffered a cut on the head and missed Friday's Court session as he recovered at home, a spokeswoman for the Court said. Justice Brennan, 82 years old, hit his head and received stitches to close the wound, said the spokeswoman, Kathy Arberg. She said that the Justice was doing well but that she was unable to provide additional details.

title: Peter Ruhlin Wed To Holly Troxell
description: Holly Dana Troxell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Chase Troxell of Short Hills, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Eric Ruhlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Ruhlin of New Canaan, Conn., and Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. David B. Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: Maryland Pair Promise College to 55 Fifth-Graders
description: Paris McIntyre works as a teletype operator at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., 20 miles from his home in nearby Hyattsville, but on one recent day he had no intentions of getting there by plane, rocket or hang glider. He was already waltzing on air.

title: No Headline
description: The Sea Cliff railroad station is not in Sea Cliff [ ''Sea Cliff Adjusts to Historic Listing,'' June 12 ] , which should make its listing in the National Register of Historic Places all the more historic.

title: 'Free Zone' Is an Asset For Users
description: LEAD: WHY would a company based in the Middle West decide to set up operations half a continent away, in Port Newark?

title: New York to Buy 240 Acres Along Hudson
description: New York has agreed to buy 240 acres on the east shore of the Hudson River near Beacon to increase the size of a state park.

title: WHO WILL WIN: SPINKS OR TYSON?
description: Boxer vs. puncher is a misnomer; it's nuclear arsenal vs. slingshots. Michael Spinks is not a heavyweight. He has neither the power to hurt Tyson nor the body to absorb Tyson's midsection missiles. The bout is no contest. Michael Spinks may have the greatest manager of all time. Butch Lewis positioned him for a stratospheric payday after two waltzes with an aging shadow of a champ and two knockovers of glassjawed creampuffs. TED GREENBERG New York

title: Grilled FisH is Just The Thing on Warm Summer Evening
description: ON a hot summer evening one of the best - and easiest -things to cook is fish, broiled outdoors. Perhaps the most useful investment you can make is in a two-sided grill, so that you can turn the fish without breaking it. The coals should be red hot and the fish grilled about five inches away from them.

title: Putting the Old Neighborhood in the New
description: The following article was written by Albert C. Moore Jr. and John P. Sullivan, managing partners of Moore & Sullivan Architects in Bronxville.

title: Karen Lee, a Designer, Weds Gregory Caruso
description: Karen Lee and Gregory Caruso, graduates of Skidmore College, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. Hugh Hildesley.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BARS OF AMERICA. By Neil Ferguson. (Faber & Faber, Paper, $9.95.) The rootless, unnamed protagonist of Neil Ferguson's first novel drifts across the United States from New York City to Knoxville, New Orleans, Houston, Phoenix and a few other greasy spots on the map, tippling all the while. If this were the 1940's, Mr. Ferguson's hapless no-name would eventually link up with a blonde who spelled trouble, wander into a couple of ugly murders, come up against a mean cop and suffer more than one nasty hangover. But this is the 1980's and so, although the nomadic English writer (Mr. Ferguson, no surprise, is also English) meets his share of assorted nuts who give the impression that there's a lot going on, nothing really happens. Guns flaunted don't go off, dukes put up come down. Mr. Ferguson is aware of the literary highway on which he travels (his hero kisses off one woman with ''farewell, my lovely'') and has deliberately chosen the theme of frenzied stasis, but he builds little into his narrative to keep the reader interested. The best he does for his hero is to place him where he can eavesdrop effectively. Since ''Bars of America'' can only be the result of a trip Mr. Ferguson himself made, a pertinent question is raised: just how imaginative does current fiction have to be in order to be labeled fiction? The answer offered here isn't very pretty.

title: Misplaced in the Midwest
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Feng Marries W. E. Ford 3d
description: The marriage of Charlotte Amalie Feng, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Feng of Creve Coeur, Mo., to William Edward Ford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Ford of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: School of Arts Becomes An Oasis in the Bronx
description: In the embattled inner-city Bronx neighborhood of Morrisania, it is not uncommon to see schoolchildren playing amid rubble-strewn lots and rows of dilapidated buildings. But here, some schoolchildren also play the cello, the saxophone and other instruments; perform arabesques and pirouettes, and learn to make silk-screen prints.

title: Smiley's 5-Hitter Downs Expos, 5-1
description: John Smiley pitched a five-hitter and Barry Bonds doubled to spark a four-run third inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-1, tonight.

title: HALOS OF THE STARS
description: THE DARK MATTER Contemporary Science's Quest for the Mass Hidden in Our Universe. By Wallace Tucker and Karen Tucker. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Bright Bags
description: POLKA dots, bright colors, tassels and silken cord: that's what Le Oui evening bags are made of. They first appeared last Christmas at Bergdorf Goodman, and are now in stores as far afield as Hemisphere in Paris.

title: POSTINGS: Landmarks Forum; New Proposals
description: Proposed changes in the way New York City designates landmarks have something for everyone - something to agitate building owners and something to terrify preservationists. Both sides will be represented at a public hearing on Thursday at 6:30 P.M. The forum, in the auditorium of the City University Graduate Center at 33 West 42d Street, will be conducted by the Landmarks Preservation Commission to solicit comments on the proposals.

title: STEPS TO CONTROL SURROGATE BIRTHS REKINDLE DEBATE
description: Five months after the Supreme Court of New Jersey outlawed commercial contracts for women to bear children for others there, many state legislatures are moving to impose regulations, outright bans and even prison terms.

title: A Virus Carries Fatal Complications
description: AS long as programmers write programs, some unscrupulous people will concoct lethal ''computer viruses,'' software programs that use computer code to enter other programs and re-program them or destroy data. And some experts have concluded that no protection exists against such viruses. Imagine Wall Street's computers suddenly going berserk, executing thousands of bogus trades until the market is paralyzed, or your company's financial records being wiped out or altered into incoherence - or a space shuttle or a space-based weapon executing orders from such a program.

title: Julia Smith Weds Blair Thompson
description: The marriage of Julia Fontaine Smith, the daughter of Mrs. Preston Reed of Farmington, Conn., and the late Robert G. Smith, to Blair Lee Thompson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Thompson 2d of Berwyn, Pa., took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Farmington. The Rev. James R. Crowder and the Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson performed the ceremony.

title: A Daughter Recalls 'Juno' and Its Creator
description: LEAD: ''JUNO AND THE PAYCOCK'' - now playing on Broadway for the first time, in a limited run at the Golden Theater - has a special meaning to my family. The Abbey Theater's premiere of the play in 1924 enabled my father, Sean O'Casey, to devote himself to his writing. He could no longer work as a laborer, since he was one of Jim Larkin's men, locked out during the strike of 1913.

title: IN HEADY MOSCOW, POLITICAL FERMENT
description: A delegate arriving in Moscow today from the provinces for the Communist Party's national conference next week might well have thought that the Soviet capital had become detached from reality.

title: Needles for Addicts: Test Phase Begins
description: AFTER years of debate, free needles are about to be given to drug addicts in this country in the hope of slowing the spread of AIDS. New York City, which has the highest concentration of both AIDS and drug addiction, hopes to begin its own needle program this summer. But the first needle exchange will begin next month in Portland, Ore., a city with far fewer addicts and far fewer AIDS carriers, but perhaps a wider consensus on how to try to contain these problems.

title: Mayor of Shore Resort Runs 3 Towns in 1
description: LEAD: BEING the Mayor of a Shore resort, says George E. Tompkins, the Mayor of this Ocean County community, ''is like being the Mayor of three different towns all at the same time.''

title: Miss Holmes, Teacher, Weds
description: Katherine Anne Holmes, a history teacher at the Harvard School, and Daniel Kent Chuba, a special-effects animator at Laser Images, both in Los Angeles, were married yesterday in Washington. Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington performed the ceremony at the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral.

title: Williams Museum: Not Sleepy, Not Poky
description: To the Editor:

title: School Reform Needs a Vision Of an Ideal Goal
description: LEAD: THE BIG question in educational reform is: Who is responsible?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Homeless Services
description: LEAD: The Greenburgh Neighborhood Health Center has received $144,000 from the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act to provide outreach services to the homeless at the former Coachman Hotel of White Plains and at other sites in the county.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a June 5 symposium on suggested summer reading for Presidential candidates incorrectly identified a book by Benjamin J. Cohen. The title is ''In Whose Interest? International Banking and American Foreign Policy.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: 1968: A Student Generation in Revolt. By Ronald Fraser, Daniel Bertaux, Bret Eynon, Ronald Grele, Beatrix Le Wita, Daniele Linhart, Luisa Passerini, Jochen Staadt and Annemarie Troger. (Pantheon, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95.) The surprising thing about this oral history of the 1968 student revolts is that the authors' unconcealed bias doesn't entirely destroy the book.

title: AFTER THE KILLING FIELDS
description: THE TRAGEDY OF CAMBODIA IS WRITTEN on the gaunt frame of 48-year-old Sok Kael, and reflected in his mud-floor, bamboo refugee hut - its one luxury a tiny tropical fish swimming in a water-filled plastic bag. It echoes through his account of the destruction of the last refuge left to him as his Cambodian culture disintegrates: his family.

title: Next Week; Should the Yankees Have Fired Billy Martin?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: An East-West Blend
description: For his good looks as well as his obvious musical facility, Ryuichi Sakamoto has commanded attention ever since the days of his progressive-rock/jazz-fusion band, Yellow Magic Orchestra. On his own, he has attracted still more attention, not least for his film acting and his film scores - ''Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence'' and, of course, ''The Last Emperor,'' for which he was principal scorer and for which he and his collaborators (one of them David Byrne) won an Oscar.

title: Caribou Return Down East
description: NATIVE Caribou have not roamed the vast forests of Maine since the early 1900's. So officials there were delighted when the Canadian island province of Newfoundland offered some surplus caribou for a project to reintroduce the species in the state.

title: Madison Avenue's New Directors
description: MOVE over ''Family Ties'' - the new television family vying for viewers' affection is the DeLucas. Tune in and watch Dad try to cook. See Mom overcome anxiety when grandma moves in. But this is no sitcom. The DeLucas are characters in new commercials for Ragu Foods, produced by an ad agency, Waring & LaRosa.

title: Therapy for Allison
description: A week after he suffered a severe concussion and other serious injuries in a crash at the Pocono International Raceway, Bobby Allison remains hospitalized in critical condition, but a new treatment approved by his doctors could speed his recovery.

title: New Play Explores Memories
description: THE setting is a room in a guest house in Canada.

title: Act of Appreciation Assuages Korean War Veterans
description: Joseph Ricker fought in Korea more than 35 years ago, but, he says, he still feels neglected by the country that sent him overseas and never held a parade or formally thanked him when he came home.

title: Don't Raise the Bridge
description: To the Editor:

title: New Season For Studying: Summer
description: LEAD: THIS summer, instead of going to the beach or working, Emer Coyne and Gerry Archambault, two University of Connecticut seniors, are taking a course in biology. They are not alone. More than 11,000 students are expected to enroll in classes at the university this summer, continuing a trend that has seen summer enrollment nearly double in the last 10 years.

title: DATA UPDATE: June 26, 1988
For Better Products, Use Fewer Parts
description: I.B.M. has a reputation as a manufacturer of high-quality products. Dr. Kailash C. Joshi, site general manager of I.B.M.'s Lexington, Ky., plant, which manufactures printers, typewriters and related products, spoke with the Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman about product quality.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE FLIGHT OF THE IGUANA: A Sidelong View of Science and Nature. By David Quammen. (Delacorte, $17.95.) David Quammen is a rarity among those with nerve enough to write about nature. Not only does he have an exceptional eye for detail and a highly original mind, he is absolutely unafraid to voice misgivings, uncertainties and incredulity about the outdoors and the natural sciences.

title: THE OLDEST SPANIARD
description: LEAD: COME SUNDAY By Bradford Morrow. 400 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in By the Numbers last Sunday gave an incorrect score for Margaret Court's singles victory over Billie Jean King in the 1970 final at Wimbledon. It was 14-12, 11-9.

title: Mainers Acting to Curb Rowdyism Along River
description: For several years, groups of drunken men have terrorized canoeists along the Saco River, shouting epithets, brandishing firearms and sometimes even becoming violent. The river, one of Maine's most popular, became a place for people who live in Maine's western mountains to avoid.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the picture credit was omitted May 29 from a photograph of Jack Kerouac and his mother. The photograph, courtesy of Ann Charters, was from the biography ''Kerouac.''

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Vineyard Haven, Mass.; Triplexes Rise On a Big Parcel
description: CONSTRUCTION is under way on one of the larger parcels of land in Martha's Vineyard to have received approval for residential development in recent years. It is an irregularly shaped site of 107 acres in the West Chop area, a mile and a half northwest of Vineyard Haven, where the ferries from Woods Hole on Cape Cod dock.

title: Practical Traveler; How Airlines Pick the Movies
description: GUESS who's having a European film festival? Swissair, among other institutions. While one wouldn't switch to a Swissair flight just to catch up with ''My Life as a Dog'' or ''Au Revoir, Les Enfants,'' the festival may be an attraction to passengers suffering fatigue from ''Three Men and a Baby.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Burlington, Vt.;
A Housing Mix On the Lake
description: LEAD: ON a point of land jutting westward into Lake Champlain a housing development is now rising that mixes condominiums and single-family houses.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Burlington, Vt.;
Mixed Housing For Lakefront
description: LEAD: ON a point of land jutting westward into Lake Champlain a housing development is now rising that mixes condominiums and single-family houses.

title: Olympic Contenders
description: THE Old Guard of the Napoleonic Army, a corps of experienced veterans on whom the Emperor relied in all military crises, fought its last battle at Waterloo. The Old Guard of women bridge-players on whom the United States has relied for two decades may now be in eclipse, judging from the battles in Memphis earlier this month.

title: Pervasive Problems Threaten New York's Economic Base
description: After 10 years of boom times, the economic vitality of New York City is being tested by deeply rooted problems - pervasive poverty and inadequate job training, a shortage of skilled workers and a growing dependence on elite, highly specialized service industries.

title: THE SUNBURNED BRAIN AND KAFKA'S POSTCARDS
description: LAST summer on my vacation I reread ''Remembrance of Things Past.'' On rainy days, on the beach, before going to sleep, I journeyed through dependent clauses, I swam in syntax. The trouble was that when I finished I was talking in these rhythms. Once you get into Proust, you can't get out. People began to move away from me at the beach, at cocktail parties. ''What's wrong?'' my wife said. ''Are you depressed?''

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Anne Marden; American Sculler Rows to Different Tune
description: ANNE MARDEN, who can be a dreamer as well as a pragmatist, sees herself as finishing fourth at the Summer Olympics. In that sense she is being an astute handicapper or, more plausibly, a professional analyst.

title: Outdoor Music Goes Digital
description: NOW, ONCE AGAIN, IS the summer of our discontent - acoustically speaking. You go to a concert in the park - almost any park - and the generally dismal amplification of outdoor music spoils the estival festival.

title: Melissa Rosse and Colm Dobbyn, Lawyers, Marry
description: The marriage of Melissa Thompson Rosse, the daughter of June P. Rosse of Brooklyn and the late Eric T. Rosse, to Colm James Dobbyn, the son of Mrs. Oliver Dobbyn of Cliffside Park, N.J., and the late Mr. Dobbyn, took place yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Henry A. Boyle performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 26, 1988
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 2 10 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 3 2 THE TIMOTHY FILES, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) A Vietnam veteran turned detective checks out dubious entrepreneurs. 4 4 FIRST BORN, by Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $4.95.) The rivalry of sisters and cousins, played out in the worlds of high fashion and politics. 5 4 THE AWAKENING, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) A hot-blooded union organizer arouses the desires of the daughter of a California rancher. 6 1 HEIRESS, by Janet Dailey. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Two sisters - one legitimate, one not - vie for their father's affection and fortune. 7 5 TENDER REBEL, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) A Scottish heiress accepts the aid of a handsome rake in her search for a husband. 8 8 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $4.50.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 3 3 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Dell, $4.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 4 4 CALL ME ANNA, by Patty Duke and Kenneth Turan. (Bantam, $4.95.) The autobiography of the actress and show business personality. 5 2 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 244 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 7 46 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 8 * 1 THE SPY WORE RED, by Aline, Countess of Romanones. (Charter, $4.95.) Recollections of a woman from upstate New York who served as an undercover agent in Europe during World War II. 9 6 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) The information that ''every American needs to know.'' 10 6 LIFE AND DEATH IN SHANGHAI, by Nien Cheng. (Penguin, $8.95.) China's Cultural Revolution as experienced by a wealthy woman. New ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 21 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 3 10 YOU CAN HEAL YOUR LIFE, by Louise L. Hay. (Hay House, $10.) A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 4 4 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 55 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Haiti Faces a Frail Future With an Ailing General
description: In the midst of a five-hour meeting last week with President Leslie F. Manigat, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy began struggling for breath and a doctor was called in.

title: Japan's Garage Gap
description: LEAD: Is the United States' economic dominance on the wane? Not likely, because in the struggle for economic superiority we have one weapon the Japanese will never be able to match: the garage.

title: DATA BANK: June 26, 1988

WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Competitive Sports
description: LEAD: PEEKSKILL'S Little League is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, but league officials say that the city is giving them a slap rather than a present.

title: WHO WILL WIN: SPINKS OR TYSON?
description: Until now, Tyson has simply relied on brute force because that's all he needed to win. Now, many think that Spinks can win by outfoxing, frustrating, and thereby neutralizing Tyson's strength.

title: A NORTHROP PACT BEING SCRUTINIZED
description: Federal investigators looking into the Northrop Corporation's involvement in alleged Pentagon procurement fraud appear to be concentrating on the company's contract to build a Navy target drone, Wall Street analysts and people familiar with the case say.

title: Not a Fan Of Guerrero
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. GRAIN STOCKS PLUNGE AS BUYERS REACT TO DROUGHT
description: The worst drought in half a century is causing traders, grain companies and warehouse operators to buy record amounts of grain and soybeans from the Government, drawing down stocks owned and managed by the Department of Agriculture more quickly than at any time since the early 1970's.

title: Play's the Thing
description: ''ALL THE ENTERTAINMENT that people used to go out for can now come into the home,'' Edwin Schlossberg says. ''I wanted to create something you can't do at home, where you appreciate the presence of other people.'' Better known, perhaps, for his marriage to Caroline Kennedy, the founder of Edwin Schlossberg Inc. has, since 1977, specialized in building educational and interactive environments. Projects have included a learning center at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, and Macomber Farm in Framingham, Mass., where, among other devices, Schlossberg designed masks that reproduce the ocular experience of a given animal: see the world as, say, a goat sees it.

title: The Birth Pangs of Romanticism
description: IT IS THE LESSER COMPOSERS OF the early 19th century who show us how slow and painful the birth of Romanticism really was. At ahistorical distance, the grandeur of Berlioz and the free flights of Schumann appear as faits accomplis, a sort of stylistic ''big bang.'' Yet composers such as Berwald, Kuhlau, Hummel, Moscheles, Danzi and Spohr portray something quite different - a tension between the self-imposed limits of the Classical era and the erosive liberality that Beethoven set loose upon it.

title: County Faces Issue Of Sludge Disposal
description: TWO times each week, a barge leaves Yonkers and moves ponderously down the Hudson, loaded with 5,000 tons of wet sludge from the Yonkers Joint Treatment Plant. At the mouth of New York Harbor, the barge joins numerous similar vessels from New York City, New Jersey and Nassau County and the parade chugs 106 miles out to sea to dump its unwanted cargo.

title: POSTINGS: Feds in Foley Square; G.S.A. Wish List
description: This time the Federal Government is asking for a lot. It wants two large buildings erected for it in lower Manhattan; it wants them ready by the end of 1992; it wants someone else to put up the money, and it wants good architecture.

title: New Stamford Y: More Than Fitness
description: LEAD: A NEW Y.W.C.A. building opening tomorrow in Stamford will address needs on child care , battered women and affordable housing, as well as provide new fitness equipment.

title: Pick-Six Pool to Hit $1 Million
description: If Anka Germania had won the $118,400 Sheepshead Bay Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, three bettors would have won the Pick-Six and shared more than $550,000. Instead, Nastique drew away to a four-length victory as Anka Germania finished third at odds of 2-to-5, creating a Pick-Six carryover pool of $557,967.93 for today's Belmont card.

title: Making Science More Exciting
description: EDDIE ZALUSKI wants to be an astronaut when he grows up. But ''if I don't know about science,'' he said, ''I can't go up into space.''

title: Taxpayers' Option: The Credit Card
description: SOME Connecticut municipalities say they have seen the tax-paying future, and it's plastic. And the future is now in more and more places.

title: 2 Computers Stolen From Pentagon Office
description: Investigators from the Defense Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are looking into the theft of two small computers on consecutive nights from the Pentagon's offices for developing a defense against attacking nuclear missiles.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $410,000 94 Deepwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; basement with workroom, in-law apartment, cul-de-sac, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $5,843. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $357,000 4 Grayrock Park Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old split level; fireplace, family room, den, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $5,400. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $375,000 5 Millard Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; country kitchen, full unfinished basement, screened porch, 1-car garage; taxes $5,326. Glastonbury, Conn. $313,000 25 Old Musket Road 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; in-law suite, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,224. Marlborough, Conn. $100,000 159 East Hampton Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; private lake rights, 2 acres; taxes $1,358. New Britain, Conn. $120,000 319 Glen Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; expansion area in unfinished upstairs; taxes $1,528. OTHER AREAS Hillsdale, N.J. $345,000 96 Winthrop Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; patio, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,070. Livingston, N.J. $236,500 29 Sterling Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old split-level; family room, c/a, screened porch; taxes $3,041. Copiague, L.I. $150,000 130 Kensington Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; basement, attic, 2-car garage; taxes $3,000.

title: HERE IN GOSSIP CITY
description: LEAD: MY LIPS ARE SEALED Confessions of a Gossip Columnist. By Susan Mulcahy. 238 pp. New York: A Dolphin Book/Doubleday. $17.95.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE CRUCIAL INGREDIENT;
Quality Is Not Accidental - It's Designed
description: LEAD: WHEN quality is cited in discussions of United States competitiveness, design is conspicuously absent from consideration.
