However, quality cannot be built-in unless it is first designed-in. About 40 percent of all quality problems can be traced to poor design. It is useful to think about designed-in quality in terms of design integrity.

title: MEN OF INACTION
description: LEAD: DEADLY VIRTUES By Francois Camoin. 190 pp. Corvallis, Ore.: Arrowood Books. Paper, $10.

title: Economic Axioms
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stolen Treasure Gets a New Owner
description: FOR almost 50 years, Julian Altman kept his secret. But as he lay dying of stomach cancer in a hospital in Torrington, Conn., he told his wife that the violin he had been playing at restaurants and society functions -and that he had treated quite casually - was a Stradivarius. It had been stolen from a dressing room in Carnegie Hall in 1936, he said, and he had bought it for $100.

title: R. L. Bowditch 3d And Scottie Beam Wed in Richmond
description: Carol Scott Beam, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elza Beam of Beaverdam, Va., was married last evening to Richard Lyon Bowditch 3d, the son of Phebe Alexander Bowditch of New York and the late Mr. Bowditch Jr. The Rev. Thomas Hicks Markley performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: 7 Marines Are Dead in Crash Of U.S. Helicopter in Japan
description: A United States Marine Corps helicopter crashed into a mountain near a nuclear power station in southwestern Japan today and all seven marines aboard were killed.

title: Trial Begins for Youth Charged in Fatal Blaze
description: A 14-year-old youth who is being tried for murder was described by his lawyer as a ''little boy playing with matches'' when he set fire to an abandoned car in Brooklyn last November, fatally burning a man inside.

title: Margaret Smith Weds Adam Lee Greissman
description: At the Union Presbyterian Church in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, Margaret Garrigues Smith, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan G. Smith of Bay Ridge, and Adam Lee Greissman, a son of Mrs. George S. Gregory of Dallas, Pa., and the late Solomon Greissman, were married by the Revs. Jo and William Tolley.

title: TV Families: Clinging to the Tried and Untrue
description: LEAD: JANE ALEXANDER NEVER thought of playing Maxine Faulk, the plain-spoken, sensual, hard-drinking hotel owner of Tennessee Williams's ''Night of the Iguana.'' The other main female character, Hannah, a New England spinster, seemed more in keeping with Ms. Alexander's usual image: cool and patrician, or darkly emotional, laced with social conscience.

title: Marcia Karetsky, Lawyer, Wed to Brian S. Goldstein
description: Marcia Lynne Karetsky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Karetsky of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married at the Westchester Reform Temple there last evening to Brian Steven Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry L. Goldstein of Rochester. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. officiated. The bride, an associate in the New York law firm of Dreyer & Traub, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and the Emory University School of Law. Mr. Goldstein, a tax lawyer in the New York office of Touche Ross, graduated cum laude from the State University at Buffalo and received a law degree from Emory.

title: THE REGION: New York's Housing; The Other Problem: Buildings That Still Have an Owner
description: MAYOR KOCH's plan to create new apartments in hundreds of abandoned buildings has dominated discussions of New York City's housing over the last two years. But in the push to rebuild, many experts contend, an equally important concern has been overlooked - preserving many thousands of apartment buildings still in private hands.

title: Miss Patterson Married in Jersey To M. I. Fleischer
description: Lucinda Dear Patterson, a daughter of Edward Patterson of New York and Joan P. Roberts of Folkingham, Lincolnshire, England, was married in Far Hills, N.J., yesterday to Michael Irving Fleischer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Fleischer of Vineland, N.J. Mayor Thomas Layton of Far Hills officiated at Pennbrook Farm, the home of Patricia Kean and Robert W. Kean 3d, a sister and brother-in-law of the bride.

title: Suspect in 3 Killings Claims Others, the Police Say
description: The police were searching yesterday for evidence to confirm a murder suspect's account that he had slain at least seven people in Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Kerouac Bibliography
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotel Bombing Kills 13 in Pakistani City Near Afghan Border
description: A bomb ripped apart a three-story hotel in the center of this Afghan frontier city today, killing 13 people and wounding 4, the Pakistani police reported.

title: Penelope Spheeris Finds the Heart of Rock
description: THE QUESTIONS MOST READILY raised by Penelope Spheeris's documentaries are those of how the film maker obtained her information and what she wanted it for. Delving into the world of punk rock for her first ''Decline of Western Civilization'' in 1980, and following with a look at heavy metal (in her current ''Decline of Western Civilization II: The Metal Years''), Miss Spheeris is treading something of a new path. She's not exactly tackling subjects about which most potential viewers crave more data. Nor can the hostile, white male adolescent culture into which she ventures be a realm in which she herself, the mother of an 18-year-old daughter, is automatically welcome.

title: Gender Gaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Shushed
description: Among the most avid listeners of Radio Free Europe are some of its most avid critics - Soviet bloc government officials. The Polish Government, for one, expressed its disagreement by simply jamming Radio Free Europe broadcasts. But the jamming stopped at the beginning of the year, and Warsaw has since expressed its disapproval through Jerzy Urban, the Polish Government spokesman, who has described the station as an ''anachronism'' that operates ''against improvement in East-West relations.'' Last week, Mr. Urban challenged Radio Free Europe to a face-to-face, on-air discussion of the station's reporting on Poland. E. Eugene Pell, the American who directs the Munich-based station, accepted, saying he welcomed the offer and looked forward ''with great interest'' to the meeting. No date was set.

title: Companies Challenge Brooklyn Navy Yard Leasing Practices
description: As Federal authorities investigate a ship-repair company's allegation that it was asked to pay a bribe to obtain drydock leases at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, two more companies have accused yard officials of ignoring their bids for the potentially valuable properties and treating them unfairly.

title: Suns Sue Airline
description: HE averaged only 2.9 points in 57 games in the 1986-87 season, but to the Phoenix Suns, Nick Vanos, the 7-foot-2-inch center who was killed in a plane crash in Detroit last Aug. 16, was an important player.

title: Bournonville Today: For Pure Pleasure
description: A CELEBRATED INSCRIPTION above the proscenium in Copenhagen's Royal Theater warns spectators that they are present ''Not for Pleasure Only.'' Moral edification was the goal in the 19th century, and among those who enthusiastically embraced this stricture was Denmark's great choreographer, August Bournonville. Yet looking at his ballets today, how many of us can take his preaching to heart? We smile rather at the warmth, wit and beauty with which he coated his sermons against excess of the passions. A modern audience might not even notice his conventionally bourgeois outlook and would understandably derive from his ballets ''pleasure only.''

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: JOHN F. REIGER;
'Audubon Isn't Simply For the Birds'
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, the Connecticut Audubon Society was largely an organization of bird watchers from Fairfield County. Today, with more than twice as many members, the society has expanded its interests and has become a statewide advocate of environmental legislation, including open-space preservation and solid-waste recycling.

title: MUSIC: Past joins present for Shore Festival
description: LEAD: THE Shore Festival of Classics will open its 1988 summer orchestra season Saturday at 7:30 P.M. with a program of works by George Gershwin and Robert Suderburg.

title: In the Clubhouse
description: ' It may well be that a considerable amount of private or intimate association occurs in such a setting, as is also true in many restaurants and other places of public accommodation, but that fact alone does not afford the entity as a whole any constitutional immunity to practice discrimination when the Government has barred it from doing so. ' - Justice Byron R. White, writing for the Supreme Court in upholding New York City's prohibition of sex discrimination by large, private clubs.

title: After the Fall: A Mianus Bridge Update
description: LEAD: IT has been five years since the Mianus River bridge collapsed, but the pain, bitterness and repercussions endure.

title: Poland Wrestles With Reinstating PEN Club
description: Nearly eight years after the Government dissolved the Polish section of the International PEN club, the Communist authorities are wrestling with the question of whether to reinstate it.

title: J. P. Verscaj Wed To Martha Wolfe
description: Martha Louise Wolfe, an assistant general counsel at Philip Morris Inc. in New York, and James Phillip Verscaj, an associate in the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. James J. Gardiner, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Big-Band Jazzmen and Rap Musicians: Soulmates
description: A BIG BAND INTENT ON making people dance is an instrument hellbent on being extreme. One minute a reed section will whisper impossibly rich, velvety sighs; the next, mountains will collapse onstage, in perfect rhythm. Unlike small group jazz, where musical arrangements work surreptitiously to give the impression of naturalism - four or five people improvising simultaneously - large band arrangements, at their glossiest, revel in the details of their rococo, obviously man-made splendor.

title: AN UNCOMMON CHEAT AND AN INTERNATIONAL PEST
description: LEAD: THE SECRET LIVES OF TREBITSCH LINCOLN By Bernard Wasserstein. Illustrated. 327 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $27.50.

title: Seattle's Sake-Marinated Fish
description: THE Japanese influence in the United States is much talked about these days. That influence has always existed in Seattle, which sometimes seems to have one foot across the Pacific in Japan.

title: Arts Festival Highlights
description: For a recorded complete list of events, the number in New York is 587-1111; from outside New York State, (800) 782-4369. Tickets are available from the individual theaters. Jazz Festival information: 787-2020. ''A CIRCLE,'' 8 P.M., Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, at 10th Street, 254-1109. A JAZZ PICNIC, 11 A.M., Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. tickets, $12 and $15. AN EVENING OF TAP, 8 P.M., with Bunny Briggs, Steve Condos, Arthur Duncan, Gregory Hines, Sandman Sims, Savion Glover, Honi Coles, Warren Vache, Oliver Jackson, Eddie Jones, John Bunch and Scott Hamilton. Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets, $15, $25, $27.50 and $30. ''AN EVENING OF TWO ONE-ACT MUSICALS,'' 8 P.M., Intar Theater, 420 West 42d Street, 465-1761. ''ANTIGONA FURIOSA,'' 3 P.M., Staged readings. Apple Corps Theater, 336 West 20th Street, 382-2750. ARROW, 3 P.M., Central Park Band Shell, at 72d Street, 860-1335. CRICOT 2, 8 P.M., ''I Shall Never Return.'' La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, 475-7710. ''DEATHWATCH'' 8 P.M., Aaron Davis Hall, City College, West 133d Street, at Convent Avenue, 690-4100. ELLINGTON GALORE, 8 P.M., with Sir Roland Hanna, Jimmy Heath, Maurice Peress, American Composers' Orchestra, Ron Carter, Jon Faddis, Butch Miles and Frank Wess. Carnegie Hall. Tickets, $15, $21, $23 and $25. ''FLOW MY TEARS, THE POLICEMAN SAID,'' 8 P.M., New York University, Tisch School of the Arts, Mainstage One, 721 Broadway, at Waverly Place, 998-1850. HOTHOUSE, 4 P.M., Music and dance improvisation. Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at 10th Street, 477-5288. ''I'LL GO ON,'' 8 P.M., Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, 239-6200. MAKOTO OZONE: SOLO PIANO, 5:30 P.M. Weill Recital Hall. Tickets, $15. MARATHON OF NEW ONE-ACT PLAYS, 7:30 P.M., Ensemble Studio Theater, 549 W. 52d Street, 247-3405. MARTHA CLARKE, 8 P.M. ''Miracolo d'Amore.'' Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, 598-7150. NEW STOCKHOLM CHAMBER ORCHESTRA, 5 P.M., Alice Tully Hall, 362-1911. NEW YORK CITY BALLET, 7 P.M., ''In G Major,'' ''Opus 19/ The Dreamer'' and ''Glass Pieces.'' New York State Theater, 870-5570. NEW YORK SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL, 8 P.M., ''The Death of Garcia Lorca.'' Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, 598-7150. ''THE NIGHT OF THE IGUANA,'' 6:30 P.M., Circle in the Square Theater, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, 307-2704. TRANSCRIPTION OF PORGY AND BESS, 8 P.M., by the Jim Cullum Jazz Band; Jazzbeaux Collins, narrator. Kaufman Concert Hall, 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue. Tickets, $18.50. ''SAND'' 8 P.M., Sandglass Theater. 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue, 427-4410.

title: POETIC INJUSTICE
description: I am aware that there has existed a long tradition of poets' feeling abused and misunderstood by an insensitive public. However, I would like to suggest to Mr. Dana that the problems of isolation and lack of support may lie more with the poets than the culture. Much American poetry has become increasingly hybridized, aloof, conceptual, and has lost the common thread that would make it sing to the public.

title: A DANGEROUS AFFAIR
description: PASSIONATE ATTACHMENTS Thinking About Love. Edited by Willard Gaylin and Ethel Person. 136 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. ABOUT LOVE Reinventing Romance for Our Times. By Robert C. Solomon. 349 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95. DREAMS OF LOVE AND FATEFUL ENCOUNTERS The Power of Romantic Passion. By Ethel Spector Person. 384 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95. THE PSYCHOLOGY OF LOVE Edited by Robert J. Sternberg and Michael L. Barnes. Illustrated. 383 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: JACKSON REBUFFED ON TAX INCREASES
description: The committee preparing the Democratic Party platform today overwhelmingly rejected a proposal by supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson that the party promise to raise the taxes of corporations and wealthy individuals and freeze military spending.

title: Italy Reclaims Its Treasures From the Past
description: POSTERITY MAY SEE THE YEAR 1988 as one in which there was at last a turn for the better in the long and grim story of Italy's irresponsibility toward her patrimony. As a repository of great art and a living museum of great architecture, Italy has few rivals, past or present. But also, and above all since World War II, it has doubled, in that regard, as a hospital for great architecture and a plague ship for great art.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a full basement with a concrete floor. The basement is otherwise unfinished and has ''French drains'' around the edges of the floor and a sump pump to remove excess water. Recently I have noticed patches of a white, fluffy material on the basement floor. Someone told me this was ''cotton mold,'' so I treated the floor three times with bleach and water, each time with a stronger solution. Is this a bleach residue or some form of uncontrolled mold?

title: A Proliferation Of Poster Art
description: THE POPULARITY OF POSTERS - collected in waves since they were new in the 1890's - is once again on the rise. Spurred by the art-collecting boom of the 1980's, poster galleries flourish, specialty auctions register record prices and steady crowds file through the most comprehensive exhibition on the subject held in New York to date - the Museum of Modern Art's show ''The Modern Poster.''

title: The Arts Festival; Some Choreographers Step Out To Speak Out on Dance's Future
description: Dance is likely, in a post-Balanchine era also distinguished by the general institutionalization of modern dance, to continue to fall into the two camps of formalist abstraction and the theatrical.

title: History's History
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OCTOPUS AND THE C.I.A.
description: GUATEMALA Eternal Spring, Eternal Tyranny. By Jean-Marie Simon. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $35. Paper, $19.95.

title: Prospects; A Bigger Tax Bite?
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has proposed a plan to raise revenues. Among other things, the proposal aims to increase taxes on military contractors and to decrease the deductions on certain insurance products and on dividends from one company's investment in another. Revenues from these provisions would be used to pay for extensions of several expiring tax breaks. Are these proposals likely to lead to a larger plan to raise more taxes? Jerry C. Jasinowski Chief economist, National Association of Manufacturers.

title: A Rescue in Texas For 2 Thrift Units
description: A Phoenix savings bank agreed to acquire two ailing Texas savings and loan associations. The move by Merabank was the first by an out-of-state institution under a Federal program to help the deeply troubled industry in Texas. The two institutions, First Financial of El Paso and Brownfield Savings of West Texas, together have relatively small assets, $350 million, but Merabank agreed to acquire another $650 million of Texas assets by this fall. Merabank will put up $27.8 million in its first deal and will be protected against losses from taking on bad assets. Gene E. Rice, Merabank's chairman, said he was confident that the Texas economy had ''bottomed out'' and was starting to recover.

title: Spanish-Language TV: An Even Better Reception
description: SPANISH-LANGUAGE radio and television stations have proliferated steadily over the years. Now, through an influx of corporate advertising money, such stations are becoming more profitable and are giving non-Hispanic stations and networks competition.

title: Outdoors; Fly Fishing Draws a Crowd
description: ONE of the reasons for fly fishing's burgeoning popularity may be that in no other form of angling is one so lightly encumbered with the necessity of bringing home fodder for one's family.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Tower Offices; Both Views and Prestige Draw Tenants to the Top
description: THE view within the top floor of the Chrysler Building was bleak, but Jonathan Morse and John C. Harvey liked what they saw. The two architects-turned-developers, up against an expiring lease, wanted a new office that would rival or surpass the drama of their penthouse space three blocks west in the Conde-Nast Building.

title: CLOTHES MADE THE PRIEST
description: VESTMENTS By Alfred Alcorn. 276 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: Kendra Sullivan Weds
description: Kendra Elizabeth Sullivan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Sullivan of New York, was married yesterday to E. Scott Laughlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stuart Laughlin of Waban, Mass. The Rev. Edward O'Donnell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. Mrs. Laughlin is an administrative assistant at the Boston Consulting Group. Her husband is an area sales manager for Copy Quick in Boston and a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Babson College.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Rock-a-by, Or Else!
description: LEAD: WHEN my children were infants, like most mothers I sang them lullabies. Even when they were toddlers, and later on when they were 6, 8 and 10, when we went camping I put the entire tent-load to sleep with songs.

title: WAR AT SEA
description: The glory of the America's Cup is that it continues a tradition of mankind thousands of years old - namely, man triumphing against the sea. With the advent of the ''maxi'' versus the ''cat'' competition, as described in your article, the test becomes one of competing technologies only. Michael Fay's ''anything goes'' campaign is a call to the designer, not the sailor. At the conclusion of the skirmish, we will know only which was the fastest boat, and this test of an age-old tradition of mankind dies a technological death. CHARLES BRUDER Madison, Conn.

title: At Auto Dealerships, a Mix of Dreams and Drive
description: AS a child in Cuba, Lombardo Perez thought that one day he might like to run his own automobile dealership. When he came to Miami in 1967, he took a job at a Ford dealership in Miami. Today, Mr. Perez owns the fastest-growing Ford dealership in the Southeast, Metro Ford in Miami. Last year Metro Ford had sales of $28 million and Mr. Perez expects his agency, which he started in 1983, to have sales of more than $35 million this year.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: BORGE IN HOLMDEL Victor Borge, who can wring more comedy from a piano keyboard than any man or woman alive, will perform with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra Wednesday evening at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel.

title: Carpetbagging is Not a Real Issue
description: WITH Election Day still a little more than four months away, New Jersey voters are already facing the distinct possibility of hearing an endless round of jabber from both sides on Peter Dawkins's brief state residency and thus the legitimacy of his Senate candidacy.

title: Lelia Dilworth Gwathmey Is Married
description: St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Lelia Dilworth Gwathmey, the daughter of Mrs. Gaines Gwathmey Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., and the late Mr. Gwathmey, to Francis X. B. Harrington, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Harrington Jr. of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. David Dobbins performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John P. Boles, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Turmoil Shows On Mike Tyson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ms. Vande Wiele, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Mary Margaret Vande Wiele, a daughter of Beatrice S. Vande Wiele of Alpine, N.J., and the late Dr. Raymond Vande Wiele, was married yesterday to David Washburn Foster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Foster of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Jack McKelvey performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: Amy Taylor, Teacher, Weds Timothy Evans
description: Amelia Ruth Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Frederick Taylor of Coos Bay, Ore., was married yesterday to Timothy Craig Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Evans of New Milford, N.J. The Rev. Mike Jousan, minister of the New Milford Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony at Ringwood (N.J.) State Park.

title: A Resort Among the Best: Our Own Island
description: I'M always a little surprised when I come up against those malcontents who spend a good deal of time denouncing life on Long Island.

title: CONSUMER RATES
POETIC INJUSTICE
description: Thank you for Robert Dana's article ''Poetic Injustice'' (May 29). The way we treat our poets and poetry is a national shame, and you should be commended for stopping to notice.

title: Aimee Simon Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Aimee Girard Simon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Simon of New Vernon, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., to Joseph Francis Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin L. Bloom of Lauderhill, Fla., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon. Msgr. John F. Corr performed the ceremony.

title: For Teachers Battered by Students, Psychological Wounds Linger
description: Frank Pedulla was proud of reviving the long-dormant sixth-grade band shortly after he began teaching at Intermediate School 53 in Far Rockaway, Queens, last year.

title: Youmans Suspended
description: AFTER failing two drug tests, Floyd Youmans, the Montreal pitcher, was suspended indefinitely by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday. The commissioner's office did not state the reason for the suspension, but sources familiar with the matter told about the drug tests. The commissioner's office said only that Youmans had been suspended pending further evaluation.

title: The Boom in Real Estate Auctions
description: HAVE you ever been tempted by advertisements for real estate auctions that promise a steal of a deal - the chance to purchase a ski condominium in Vail or a town house on the Florida coast for 50 cents on the dollar? If so, you're not alone. Thousands of potential buyers have been flocking to real estate auctions from coast to coast recently, as auctioneers try to upgrade the industry's image.

title: SEX IN THE BIBLE BELT
description: THE PREACHER'S BOY By Terry Pringle. 270 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $15.95.

title: SOLDIERS OF MISFORTUNE
description: SECRET WARRIORS Inside the Covert Military Operations of the Reagan Era. By Steven Emerson. 256 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: Calculating the Consequences of a Warmer Planet Earth; A Worst-Case Forecast
description: SCIENTISTS disagree over just how bad the greenhouse effect will be. According to some of the most dire predictions, this is how bad a summer day might be in the year 2030:

title: With No Campus or Classes, a College is Making an Impact
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Thomas A. Edison State College here has won national prominence as a pioneer in developing higher education for adults, its name is hardly a household word.

title: The Discreet Charm Of Afternoon Dress
description: AS midafternoon settles in, an elegant parade of sorts takes place along Park Avenue. That's when the older women who move about in that wealthy and socially precise purlieu in their ''afternoon dresses,'' the ones they'll wear to tea, to a wedding reception or a cocktail party, and to dinner later on. Almost invariably, these soft and very feminine print dresses have long sleeves, high collars and skirts that end in a flounce of flat pleats for graceful movement. Invariably, they come from Chez Ninon, Scaasi or Adolfo, fashion houses that know the preferences of the regal ladies of Park Avenue.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: MODERN living is fraught with hazards, and not the least of them is recommending something, or someone, to friends and acquaintances.

title: Pioneer in Children's Day Care Turns 110
description: WHILE dozens of Connecticut day-care centers come and go each year, the Leila Day Nursery in New Haven is celebrating its 110th anniversary this year.

title: Shifting Standards for Sovereignty
description: The pious principles of ''national sovereignty'' and ''nonintervention'' have never been absolute except in oratory. They did serve, though, to provide certain standards in a disorderly world and afford arguments to the weak against the strong.

title: TOURING THE ALTERED STATES
description: TRAVELS By Michael Crichton. 377 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: New Artistic Director For the Acting Company
description: Gerald Gutierrez has been appointed artistic director of the Acting Company, the touring professional repertory theater ensemble. He succeeds Michael Kahn, who has been artistic director for both the Acting Company and the Folger Theater in Washington for two years.

title: Open-Air Festivals Highlight the Season
description: THERE is no concert site in Connecticut more beautiful than the rolling lawns of the Ellen Battell Stoeckel estate in Norfolk, and no hall is more historic than the Music Shed where Rachmaninoff, Sibelius, Caruso and Kreisler once performed.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ZERO. By Eric Van Lustbader. (Random House, $19.95.) Philip Doss, a spy engaged in ''wet work'' for a United States intelligence agency operating in present-day Japan, is killed in an automobile accident, presumably murdered. His estranged son, Michael, having spent his youth in the Far East as a student of the martial and mystical arts, is recruited by the agency to investigate.

title: Joanne Green Marries Robert Haber on L.I.
description: Joanne Abbot Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Herschenfeld of Roslyn, L.I., and Robert Keith Haber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Haber of Roslyn, were married last evening. Rabbi Myron C. Fenster and Cantor Avraham Albrecht officiated at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

title:
GARDENING;
Overfertilizing can Turn Out Fatal
description: LEAD: EXCESS salts can hurt plants.

title: E. German Track Women Have World on Run Again
description: The parade began with Sabine Busch and continued with Petra Felke, Marlies Gohr, Silke Gladisch Moller and Heike Drechsler. After three hours at the East Germany national track and field championships, it was pretty clear whose women's team is expected to dominate the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, later this year.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE GREAT HUDSON RIVER REVIVAL;
60's Aren't Gone, They've Just Grown Up
description: LEAD: WERE they 60's kids who had grown up chronologically but spiritually never left that decade? Teen-agers just now picking up on the communal spirit and a trend toward tie-dyed fashion? Or average, ''straight'' folks with a social conscience and a penchant to be moved by music?

title: BOUNTIFUL BASIN
description: IT'S ALMOST HUMOROUS THAT Mediterranean food has been named the latest culinary trend, considering all the shores that touch on the Mediterranean sea. Morocco, Algeria, Spain, France, Italy, Greece, Turkey, Lebanon, Israel and Egypt embrace such a vast territory that the cuisine could hardly be contained in a neat definition. It should certainly enjoy more than its apportioned 15 minutes of celebrity.

title: TV Families: Clinging to the Tried and Untrue
description: DR. CLIFF HUXTABLE, A.K.A. BILL COSBY, IS sitting in his living room. His wife, Clair, walks in from the kitchen. ''Are you free Thursday at four?'' she asks. Huxtable pauses a beat. ''Yes,'' he says. It's late Friday afternoon. Huxtable's son-in-law, Elvin, comes into the kitchen. Clair, dressed for success in a stunning beige blouse and skirt, takes a roast out of the oven and bastes it. ''Would you like to stay for dinner?'' she asks.

title: Staging a Celebration of the Cow
description: Ann Carlson had never really met a cow before she was asked to choreograph a performance for ''Absolute Cow,'' an art exhibit that opened recently in Vermont's capital.

title: Home Care Can Cost More Than Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: State Starts to Revive Oyster Beds in Sound
description: THE state, in an effort to revive the oyster industry, is starting a $3 million three-year project to reseed 3,000 acres of state-owned beds.

title: Is the Documentary Making a Comeback?
description: THE INDEPENDENT DOCUMENTARY is showing tentative but heartening signs of renewed life on television these days. Consider this past week's broadcasts of Frederick Wiseman's nine-hours-plus ''Deaf and Blind'' on Channel 13 and next week's debut, on July 5, of the 10-part series called ''P.O.V.,'' a film-making term meaning point of view. In addition, cable is increasingly getting into the documentary act. Bravo, the pay service, is currently carrying a British essay, ''Nicaragua: Writing and Politics.''

title: WHEN FEMINISM FAILED
description: THE FIRST TREMOR STRUCK ME AT A MEETING one early morning in 1983. I was sitting in my office at the large table where, as editor of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, I planned daily editions with the news staff.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Hillsdale $345,000 96 Winthrop Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; patio, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,070. Livingston $236,500 29 Sterling Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath 38-year-old split-level; family room, c/a, screened porch; taxes $3,041. Maplewood $165,000 2079 Ostwood Terrace 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bathroom, 45-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, 2-car detached garage; taxes $2,900. Middletown $250,000 1265 West Front Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 34-year-old colonial; fireplace in family room, 2-level deck, 2-zone heating; taxes, $3,733. South Orange $330,000 350 Prospect Street 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; fireplace, w/w carpeting, 2-car garage; taxes, $4,574. West Orange $188,000 17 Edgemont Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, fireplace, full basement, garage; taxes, $3,418. OTHER AREAS Mount Kisco, N.Y. $357,000 4 Grayrock Park Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old split level; fireplace, family room, den, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $5,400. Marlborough, Conn. $100,000 159 East Hampton Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; private lake rights, 2 acres; taxes $1,358. Copiague, L.I. $150,000 130 Kensington Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; basement, attic, dining room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,000.

title: Helping Blacks Get Ahead
description: J. BRUCE LLEWELLYN, 60, is the unofficial champion of New York's flourishing black middle class.

title: Camacho Wins, Then Hears Boos
description: Hector Camacho came into the ring tonight in a sleeveless leopard-print robe and matching loincloth over black shorts, dancing vigorously to recorded music.

title: Sherri Cooper Marries
description: Sherri Beth Cooper and Alan Seth Jeffrey Schacter were married last evening at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman. The bride, a guidance counselor in the New York City school system, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Cooper of Wantagh, L.I. Mr. Schacter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schacter of Merrick, L.I., is an associate in the New York law firm of Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom.

title: 2 workers killed in plant shooting
description: A security guard, apparently frustrated with his job, shot six employees Friday night at the plant where he works, the police said. Two people died and one was in critical condition.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending June 11 MANHATTAN Gracie Mansion Area $160,000 530 East 90th Street (Gracie Gardens) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 765-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, East River view; maintenance $957, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) Greenwich Village $470,000 299 West 12th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, large kitchen, Hudson River view; common charge $553, taxes $2,616 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Morningside Heights $175,000 600 West 115th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, windowed, large kitchen, high-ceilings, French doors; maintenance $491, 42% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) TriBeCa $675,000 105 Hudson Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 2,700-sq.-ft. loft-co-op; dining room, recreation room, oak-arched windows, hardwood floors; maintenance $741, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Upper East Side $3.5 million 1060 Fifth Avenue 3-bedroom, 4-bath, 4,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, 3 maid's rooms; maintenance $2,366, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Key Ventures, Inc.) Washington Heights $245,000 200 Cabrini Boulevard (Castle Village) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, sunken-living room, roof deck, Hudson river view; maintenance $795, includes gas and electricity, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Riverdale $205,000 3001 Henry Hudson Parkway (Linden House) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,450-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, gallery, hardwood floors, tennis courts; maintenance $580, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. Goldy) Williamsbridge $210,000 3316 Fish Avenue 2-family, attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; full basement, 22- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,350 (Broker: Albert R. Bryan Real Estate) BROOKLYN Boerum Hill $421,000 158 Hoyt Street 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, single-family, 4-story brownstone; double parlors, large kitchen, 3 fireplaces, original moldings and details; 20- by 80-ft. lot; taxes $1,248 (Broker: Renaissance Properties) Kensington $85,600 415 Beverly Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 812-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $460, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Elise Franco Brown) QUEENS Bayside $160,000 18-55 Corporal Kennedy Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining room, large kitchen, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $522, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Corona $325,000 108-46 42d Avenue 2-family, semi-attached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; full basement, second-floor balcony, 21 1/2- by 100-ft. lot; Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Great Kills $245,000 72 Genesee Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached high-ranch; dining area, large kitchen, den, family room, fireplace, attached 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft, lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate) New Springfield $155,000 9 Sea Signs Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,860-sq.-ft. town-house condo; large kitchen, skylights, hardwood floors; common charge $43, 100% tax-abated (Broker: Weichert Realty)

title: Judge Rules Out His Nomination To U.S. Bench
description: Saying he wanted to spare his family further pain, a State Supreme Court justice from Long Island has withdrawn his nomination for a Federal judgeship.

title: PUNNING FOR THEIR LIVES
description: THE UNIVERSE, AND OTHER FICTIONS By Paul West. 205 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $17.95.

title: Many Schools Canceling Balloon Launchings
description: LEAD: FIRST there is the countdown, and then a great cheer goes up as the children let go of their strings, filling the sky with a multitude of bright balloons, each one encasing a slip of paper containing the name, address and school of the sender. Everybody wonders: Whose balloon will travel farthest and actually be found?

title: Melissa S. Warner, Art Director, Weds
description: Melissa Smith Warner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Smith Warner of Fairfield, Conn., was married at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Lawrence Alleyn Norton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Norton of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Thomason Newcomb performed the ceremony.

title: On Trail of Butterflies In Massachusetts Wilds
description: There is more to catching a butterfly in a long-handled net than the casual pursuer might think, Brian Cassie warned the group of Massachusetts Audubon Society volunteers he was preparing for the chase.

title: Renaissance for A Native Shrub
description: THOSE who think mountain laurels have only near-white flowers are in for some surprises. There are mountain laurels with pink flowers or pure white flowers. Some have petals with dark maroon bands, others have petals with ''freckles.'' A few shrubs have red buds. One mountain laurel has no petals at all.

title: Gandhi Shifts Cabinet After Political Troubles
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi carried out a sweeping change of his Cabinet and the leadership of two populous Indian states today in a move to shore up his political standing after several recent election defeats.

title: Simon Wiesenthal Shepherds His Life's Story
description: FOR YEARS, SIMON WIESENTHAL, who since his liberation from Mauthausen concentration camp in 1945 has not relented in the self-imposed labor of bringing Nazi war criminals to justice, resisted proposals to make a film of his life.

title: Capri
description: To the Editor: Walter Lister's article (Travel, April 24) on the eternal resort, Capri, brought back memories of long, lazy days spent wandering up and down the hills of the island and of afternoons sunning on large white stones near the shore.

title: Puzzle for Salvador Rebels: Turning War to Power
description: Salvadoran Marxist guerrilla commanders are involved in a major re-evaluation of strategy at what appears to be a key moment in their eight-year war against the Government, according to rebel officials and diplomats who monitor the guerrillas.

title: U.N. Struggling With a Disarmament Declaration
description: Representatives of the 109 member countries of the United Nations worked today to complete a declaration outlining a new program for global disarmament.

title: Longest Days, Sweetest Days Wandering at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, the electronic message board says. Via Earl's Court - 4 Mins.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 26, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to Paris in the 1920's to contemporary New York. 2 3 16 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 3 2 10 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 4 4 34 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 5 5 7 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York society and one man's role in it. 6 6 4 CRIMSON JOY, by Robert B. Parker. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The private eye Spenser in pursuit of a serial lady-killer in Boston. 7 7 10 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 8 8 6 FREAKY DEAKY, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) A Detroit police detective investigates a series of crimes with its roots in the 1960's. 9 11 19 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 10 9 15 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 11 14 8 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars. 12 * 12 5 SCORPIUS, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $12.95.) James Bond on the tortuous trail of a global czar of vice and terrorism. 13 10 6 PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION, by Isaac Asimov. (Foundation/Doubleday, $18.95.) An overture to the five-volume science fiction saga about the Foundation empire. 14 15 15 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 15 13 2 QUINN'S BOOK, by William Kennedy. (Viking, $18.95.) An orphan's quest for his own identity and true love in tumultuous mid-19th-century Albany. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 10 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 2 3 2 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 3 1 5 FOR THE RECORD, by Donald T. Regan. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $21.95.) The recollections of President Reagan's former Treasury Secretary and chief of staff. 4 4 28 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 5 6 2 RIDING THE IRON ROOSTER, by Paul Theroux. (Putnam, $21.95.) A yearlong journey by train through China. 6 8 10 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 7 5 8 MOONWALK, by Michael Jackson. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The autobiography of the performer. 8 7 21 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 9 1 PICASSO, by Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A portrait of the artist as ''creator and destroyer.'' 10 15 2 ROBERT KENNEDY: In His Own Words, edited by Edwin O. Guthman and Jeffrey Shulman. (Bantam, $22.50.) A collection of interviews with Robert Kennedy about his career and his brother John. 11 11 2 A TRAIL OF MEMORIES, edited by Angelique L'Amour. (Bantam, $12.95.) Quotations from the works of Louis L'Amour, compiled by his daughter. 12 9 33 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) Ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 13 2 SHOW TIME, by Pat Riley. (Warner, $17.95.) The coach of the Los Angeles Lakers reviews last year's championship season. 14 15 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 15 12 9 1999, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The former President outlines a program to assure the survival of the United States. 16 * 13 4 FREUD, by Peter Gay. (Norton, $25.) A reanalysis of the life and legacy of Sigmund Freud. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 51 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 3 12 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 2 143 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 4 34 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 10 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) INDECENT DREAMS, by Arnost Lustig. (Northwestern University, $17.95.) Three tough novellas, set in Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia, dealing with the heroic - or at any rate decisive - acts of unimportant people in a world of chaos and cruelty; originally published in Prague in the early 1960's. THE MIDDLEMAN: And Other Stories, by Bharati Mukherjee. (Grove, $15.95.) Ms. Mukherjee's stories are peopled with immigrants to America, compulsive talkers and travelers at full throttle in this country's fluid physical and moral geography. NORA: The Real Life of Molly Bloom, by Brenda Maddox. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) A fascinating and arduously researched biography of the audacious, sexually assured Galway woman who bore James Joyce's children and finally married him. THE COLLECTED POEMS 1931-1987, by Czeslaw Milosz. (Ecco, $30.) Poems from the whole career of the Polish Nobel laureate who lives in California, translated by several hands in an extraordinary collaboration with Mr. Milosz himself. TOSCANINI'S FUMBLE: And Other Tales of Clinical Neurology, by Harold L. Klawans. (Contemporary, $17.95.) Vivid case studies that show us how parts of our character can be deleted or rearranged or distorted in bizarre ways by strange diseases. TUPELO NIGHTS, by John Ed Bradley. (Atlantic Monthly, $17.95.) Comic and horrendous by turns, this fine first novel explores such polarities as heroism and desertion, mother love and incest. MARIO CUOMO: A Biography, by Robert S. McElvaine. (Scribners, $19.95.) Mr. McElvaine, a historian, admires his subject but not blindly; his version of Mr. Cuomo reflects the frustration experienced by many who have tried to figure the Governor out.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TELL IT TO THE KING. By Larry King with Peter Occhiogrosso. (Putnam, $16.95.) Sometimes propinquity to the famous is enough to produce another kind of stardom - someone known for knowing the known. The radio and television talk show host Larry King has been sitting right next to the famous for almost 30 years, eliciting the sort of chitchat found in People magazine.

title: Merril R. Bernstein, Lawyer, To Marry Michael R. Lissack
description: Merril R. Bernstein, the daughter of Dr. Gerald Sanford Bernstein and Lorraine Irene Bernstein, both of Pasadena, Calif., and Michael R. Lissack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Lissack of Marblehead, Mass., plan to marry next year.

title: Taking the Big Business Out of the Taxi Business
description: THE one-man taxicab entrepreneur, sweating it out in the city's streets in pursuit of the American dream, has been a recurring theme among those who have sought to improve New York City's often rough and rude taxi industry.

title: Albany Notes; Mario Cuomo Rediscovers 'Real People'
description: Drivers here might want to be a little more cautious next time they ignore a stop sign or run a red light. The driver in the next car just might be Mario Cuomo.

title: Black vs. Arab View of African Conflict Collapses Under Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOCUS: Barn Houses;
The Supply of Antiques Is Dwindling
description: LEAD: THE supply of old post-and-beam barns in good enough shape to disassemble, restore and rebuild in another location as the core of a new house is running out, builders and preservationists say.

title: Catherine Ryen Wed To John H. Simmonds
description: Catherine Elizabeth Ryen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rollin Ryen of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to John Harding Simmonds, a son of Barbara Smith Simmonds of Chevy Chase, Md., and Albert Carleton Simmonds 3d of Washington. The Rev. Robert Fretz performed the ceremony at the Oradell Reformed Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Kenneth Roeltgen, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Egypt Silent Over U.S. Charges of Smuggling
description: Egyptian officials maintained silence today over charges that two Egyptian Army colonels were involved in a scheme to smuggle highly sophisticated American-made chemicals to Egypt.

title: Thomas J. Main Weds Carla T. Post, a Lawyer
description: Carla Tanya Post, the daughter of Edith E. Post of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Albert Post, and Thomas James Main were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, George J. Main and Maureen E. Main, in Huntington Station, L.I. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz officiated.

title: Marta Abba Dead in Milan at 88;Actress Worked With Pirandello
description: Marta Abba, a leading Italian stage performer of the 1920's and 30's and the lifetime companion of the playwright Luigi Pirandello, died after suffering a stroke on her 88th birthday Friday in a Milan nursing home, her family announced today.

title: Large L.I. Hospital May Lose Funds
description: The Nassau County Medical Center, the largest hospital on Long Island, has failed to meet certain Federal health-care standards and as a result could lose its Medicare and Medicaid funds, according to people in the State Health Department familiar with a Federal review of the hospital.

title: YANKEES REBOUND BEHIND JOHN
description: Ol' Man River never kept rolling along as smoothly as Tommy John.

title: Theories as the Building Blocks for a New Style
description: THERE ARE TWO CHALLENGES presented by ''Deconstructivist Architecture,'' the new exhibition that opened Thursday at the Museum of Modern Art. The first is the work itself, much of which is arcane, difficult and disorienting. The second is the problem of separating this show from the flurry of controversy and media attention that has surrounded it.

title: New Series Mixes Classical and Pop
description: A FEW weeks ago, we were all saddened to hear of the demise of the Summer Music on the Hudson Festival -popularly known as the Lyndhurst concerts because they took place on the grounds of that landmark Tarrytown estate. There will, however, be music at Lyndhurst this summer after all; not orchestral concerts, it's true, but an intriguing new threeweek, six-performance series called ''Sunset Serenades.''

title: Elizabeth Levitt Wed To Dr. L. A. Resnick
description: Elizabeth Levitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Levitt of Paramus, N.J., and Dr. Lawrence Andrew Resnick, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Resnick of Red Bank, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in Manhattan.

title: STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions; A Mailbag of Gargoyles, Dormers, Towers and Stables
description: Q. Can you tell us the significance, if any, of the gargoyle figures on the facade of Intermediate School 52, at the northwest corner of Academy Street and Vermilyea Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan? - Joseph DeCaro, Manhattan.

title: WAR AT SEA
description: Al Jackson, a pitcher on the roster of the famed 1962 New York Mets, was reported to have stepped off the rubber several innings into a game in which his teammates' ineptitude cost him a spate of unearned runs. He then looked around from his perch on the mound and proclaimed: ''Everybody here crazy!''

title: Diana Williams Wed to Steven Peter in Brooklyn
description: At the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights, Diana Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Williams of Brooklyn and Strafford, Vt., was married yesterday to Steven Eric Peter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon D. Peter of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin performed the ceremony.

title: Weighing the Soviet Party Congress
description: Moscow's Americanologists assiduously analyze every Presidential election, trying to figure out the next twist and turn in United States policy. American Kremlinologists usually assumed Soviet policy would be unchanging - until now. In a remarkable shift, Americans will hang on every development reported from the extraordinary Communist Party conference that Mikhail Gorbachev has convened in Moscow this week.

title: Israel Accedes to U.S. Rights Monitoring
description: The United States has expressed concern to Israel about human rights abuses in the occupied territories and has established new procedures to consult regularly with Israeli officials on specific problems.

title: Why Pressure The Graduate?
description: James B. Schomburg's advice to recent graduates (''Advice for the Bewildered Graduate: Relax,'' Opinion page, May 22) comes as a relief, I suspect, to many dazed recent graduates who have just received their sheepskin eviction notices (as the president of my alma mater put it) from colleges and universities around the country.

title: South of the Border
description: IF at first you don't succeed, or for that matter, if at eighth you don't succeed, try, try again. That would seem to be the philosophy of Steve Howe, the 30-year-old former major league pitcher whose career has been plagued by alcohol and drug problems.

title: In Class for the Disabled, A Future in Computers
description: Dave Webb wanted to be a doctor. He had graduated from Cornell University and was applying to medical schools. Then, on New Year's Eve 1987, he was mugged in the 179th Street subway station in Jamaica, Queens, and pushed in front of a speeding E train.

title: Dukakis Holiday: The Reading Is Serious but the Shoes Aren't
description: Unlike many New Englanders who flock to this picturesque island for vacation, Michael S. Dukakis is not reading fiction and is not going to the movies this weekend. The issue of shopping remains unresolved. ''Not a bit of it,'' the penny-pinching Massachusetts Governor and probable Democratic Presidential nominee said in a casual conversation with reporters.

title: Prison Farm Raising Low-Cholesterol Beef
description: THERE IS new hope on the hoof here for beef lovers who have had to cut down because of the high cholesterol levels in red meat.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: American Shakeout; In the Darwinian Age Of Global Finance, Only Megabanks May Survive
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON wrote in 1799 that ''banking establishments are more dangerous than standing armies,'' and, indeed, since the earliest days of the nation, the fear of concentrated economic power has permeated public opinion and Government policy. But almost two centuries later, attitudes seem to be changing as the American financial system enters the era of big banks and financial conglomerates.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a full basement with a concrete floor. The basement is otherwise unfinished and has ''French drains'' around the edges of the floor and a sump pump to remove excess water. Recently I have noticed patches of a white, fluffy material on the basement floor. Someone told me this was ''cotton mold,'' so I treated the floor three times with bleach and water, each time with a stronger solution. Is this a bleach residue or some form of uncontrolled mold?

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Midwood
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Midwood was headed downhill. Stores were closing, houses were up for sale and apartments were beginning to crumble. Longtime residents advised arriving families not to get too comfortable.

title: Reviews/Music; Bernstein's Vision of Shostakovich
description: The 20th-century-only policy of the New York International Festival of the Arts, though it is far too broad to provide any real focus for the musical programs, has one distinctly beneficial effect: The visiting American orchestras are compelled to present the mid-century classics they tend to play best, and are prevented from padding them, as they otherwise would, with the Beethoven and Brahms they tend to play boringly.

title: After 25-Year Hiatus, a Writer Finds a Publisher
description: For many writers, a 25-year dry spell would be discouraging enough to quit writing. But James Hayford stuck with it and shortly before his 74th birthday had his first children's book published.

title: Yachting; Cup Legal Battle Doesn't Stop Crews
description: The legal cloud that hangs over the future of the America's Cup is casting its shadow on a planned September regatta, but not on the efforts of both sides to get ready.

title: LURE OF THE LOIRE
description: ONE CHILLY NIGHT MANY years ago, I wandered into a pleasant looking restaurant in Tours, looking for some dinner. I had plenty of time; I was alone and had nothing to do until the next day, when I was meeting a friend. So after downing a half-bottle of Chinon, I accepted the patronne's invitation to try the other well-known red wine of the region, St.-Nicolas-de-Bourgueil.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has a full basement with a concrete floor. The basement is otherwise unfinished and has ''French drains'' around the edges of the floor and a sump pump to remove excess water. Recently I have noticed patches of a white, fluffy material on the basement floor. Someone told me this was ''cotton mold,'' so I treated the floor three times with bleach and water, each time with a stronger solution. Is this a bleach residue or some form of uncontrolled mold?

title: Exploiting Racial Tension
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pair of Bishops Beats a Straight
description: ONE wonders, when one sees a pair of bishops doing its magical work on a semi-open board, what prompted the opponent to defy them.

title: Lilco Accord: Second Thoughts
description: AT first, the relief was almost palatable.

title: Exploring Ireland's Achill Island
description: ''IF you could live on scenery,'' a local saying goes, ''Mayo would be the richest county in Ireland,'' and nowhere is its wealth more in evidence than on Achill Island. This mass of mountains, sheltered harbors and bold peninsulas stand sentry to Blacksod Bay and the Mullet Peninsula to the north, Clare Island to the south, and Clew Bay to the southeast. Though tucked away at the western edge of Ireland's remote and traditionally untamed province, Connaught, Achill (AK-el) has attracted tourists since the 18th century, for the harmony of the island's topographical features makes every view worth lingering over, whether draped in sea mists or brilliant in a wash of sun.

title: Tigers Snap Stieb's Nine-Game Streak
description: It figured that Doyle Alexander, the former Toronto Blue Jay, would have something to do with the end of Dave Stieb's winning streak.

title: SYMMETRY, NOT SUMMITRY
description: AMERICAN POLICY toward the Soviet Union is essentially made at the top. Congressmen and commentators, the expert and the influential, public opinion and the press, all now play significantly greater roles in foreign affairs decision making than they did during my years in the White House. But in our relations with the world's only other superpower, both the tone and the direction of our posture are primarily set by the man whose finger is on the button.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A New Road to Housing the Urban Needy
description: LEAD: OVER the last 18 years, New Jersey's supply of rental housing has dwindled as construction of new apartments declined and existing ones were converted into condominiums.

title: When a Sidewalk Tilts
description: CONCRETE sidewalk slabs sometimes settle unevenly if soil beneath them compacts or is washed away.

title: You Can't Get There From Here
description: SEVERAL years ago, after receiving numerous complaints from students, faculty and visitors about inadequate directional signs on the Long Island Expressway, I wrote to the New York State Department of Transportation and requested that signs be placed at the exits serving the three campuses of Suffolk County Community College. I noted that on some days more than 20,000 individuals travel to our campuses, and for visitors, in particular, it would be helpful to have some indication as to which exit led to each campus.

title: Rutgers Expanding Alcoholic Treatment
description: LEAD: AFTER three years of planning and several months after a fraternity pledge drank himself to death, Rutgers University is preparing to open an innovative treatment center for students who are alcoholics.

title: Williams Museum: Not Sleepy, Not Poky
description: To the Editor:

title: A 10-Unit Harlem Condo Without Subsidy
description: ONE of the first of what might eventually be a small wave of modest apartment rehabilitation projects in Harlem buildings has recently been completed on St. Nicholas Avenue after almost a year of renovation.

title: Trees Return to St. Helens, But Do They Make a Forest?
description: One of the oddest modern stories in natural history is unfolding on this wounded volcano as three distinct forests, each reflecting the character of its caretakers, are flourishing on land once dismissed as a sterile moonscape.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Reports a Victory

title: Xiaowei Yu, a Student, Weds Arthur Waldron
description: Xiaowei Yu, a second-year law student at Columbia University, and Arthur Nelson Waldron, an assistant professor of history and East Asian studies at Princeton University, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl performed the ceremony.

title: Top Bush Aides Favor Bob Dole For the 2d Spot
description: Because of his experience, regional appeal and campaign skills, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas is emerging as the early choice of top aides and advisers to Vice President Bush for the second spot on the Republican ticket.

title: Headliners; Shunned
description: New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner seems to juggle managers as routinely as some managers juggle batting orders. Last week, Billy Martin was fired from the job for the fifth time and was replaced for the second time by Lou Piniella. Mr. Steinbrenner was reportedly unhappy not just about the Yankees' most recent road trip, during which they lost seven out of nine games and slipped into second place in their division, but also about Martin's behavior on and off the field. The scrappy Martin was involved in a fight outside a topless bar in Dallas earlier this season and was recently suspended for throwing dirt on an umpire. Even so, Martin seemed taken aback by his dismissal. ''Why me?'' he asked. ''I'm still the best manager in baseball.''

title: Calculating the Consequences of a Warmer Planet Earth
description: WITH evidence mounting that the earth is becoming a hotter place to live, the United States and many other nations are beginning to plan for climatic change caused by what environmentalists call the greenhouse effect.

title: 'Character': What Matters?
description: To the Editor:

title: A LESSON AT CASTLE VOLTAIRE
description: LINES OF LIGHT By Daniele Del Giudice. Translated by Norman MacAfee and Luigi Fontanella. 154 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BENEFIT POLO MATCH

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: Why not take a cue from the season and let summer reading inspire new excursions? ''The Poconos: An Illustrated Natural History Guide,'' by Carl S. Oplinger and Robert Halma (Rutgers University Press, New Brunswick; $30; paper, 12.95), opens our eyes to the wonder of the Poconos, the 2,000-square-mile plateau just past New Jersey's western border.

title: In New Rochelle, Plein-Air Tradition
description: PLEIN-AIR painting goes back at least to the mid-18th century, when landscapists, Claude Lorrain among them, frequently made preliminary oil sketches on the spot. But the notion of portraying nature on is own terms came out of the Romantic movement and no one expressed it better than John Constable.

title: An Angry Response To Actions on AIDS Spurs F.D.A. Shift
description: Ripples of fear and resentment spread among AIDS patients and their advocates last week as the Food and Drug Administration threatened to restrict access to a substance thousands of patients are taking in the hope it might help fight their disease.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A WOMAN NAMED DROWN, by Padgett Powell. (Owl/ Holt, $7.95.) In this novel by the author of ''Edisto,'' the son of a millionaire manufacturer drops out of graduate school and wanders across the South, determined to live outside the boundaries of middle-class existence. Last year, our reviewer, T. Coraghessan Boyle, called this ''a potent, funny, one-of-a-kind sort of book. It is rich in character and observation, by turns outrageous and deadly serious in its satire.''

title: Review/Jazz; Abstractions By a Quartet And a Trio
description: Two radically different approaches to improvisation were presented on a double bill at the Knitting Factory's jazz festival on Wednesday.

title: Sarah Lawrence Reaches Accord With Neighbors on Boundaries
description: THE Lawrence Park West Neighborhood and Homeowners Association and the Sunnyside Park Community Association have signed a 10-year agreement with Sarah Lawrence College detailing the uses and the restrictions on properties inside and outside the college's immediate area.

title: Regen Horchow Married in Texas
description: The marriage of Regen Horchow and Rockwell Dole Pillsbury Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pillsbury of Dallas, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Roger Horchow of Dallas, parents of the bride. The Rev. Dr. William Joseph Ambrose Power, an Episcopal priest, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: A Guide to Fidelity Funds
description: THE universe of mutual funds is so large that many investors can easily get lost. But some investors have guidebooks to one of the larger fund galaxies.

title: Baseball Destined to Grow, But Not Any Time Soon
description: IN dealing with expansion, some people feel, baseball officials move with glacier-like speed. The glacier, however, eventually gets where it's going; skeptics aren't too sure about expansion.

title: Williams's Broken Women And Macho Men Endure
description: LEAD: ''IN THE WINTER OF CITIES'' is the name of one of Tennessee Williams's two luminous volumes of poetry. However, in the winter of critics, Tennessee Williams did not fare very well. In the last 10 years before he died in the Elysee Hotel, his new plays were met with anger, disdain and indifference.

title: Motivating Students
description: LEAD: IN 1981, John F. Holtz applied for a job in the governmental affairs department of a major utility. After interviews, he was chosen from among 200 applicants.

title: Affordable Housing: The Continuing Quest
description: David Emilita's letter to the Long Island editor on May 29 in response to Charles Mancini's letter on April 24 should not go unanswered. While trying to assess blame for the failure to build affordable housing on Long Island (at either end) may be an interesting exercise, it won't produce any of this much needed commodity.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Cluster Zoning Is Anathema to Manorville
description: LEAD: THE question of whether clustered houses, even in a small development, are suitable for Manorville has residents of this rural Suffolk County community considering whether to incorporate as a village to control local zoning decisions. The zoning powers of a village supersede those of a town.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: How to Avoid Passport Lines

title: Aiding Families of Homicide Victims
description: LEAD: EVERY morning, Charles A. Lexius reads the newspapers, looking for homicides.

title: Advice on Making Americans Better
description: To the Editor:

title: BACK FROM THE BOTTOM
description: BRIAN WILSON IS ALONE.

title: Art of 2 Cultures And 2 Generations
description: LEAD: IN 1980, as a grown woman and mature artist, Li-Lan visited the tiny rural village in China that 59 years before, her father, Yun Gee, a leader in early 20th-century avant-garde American art, had left as a 15-year-old to emigrate to San Francisco.

title: Q and A
description: New Hampshire

title: Zoning: The Urban Power Tool for the 90's
description: OVER its brief history, zoning has acquired an image of protectionism. Deservedly so, in many cases.

title: CRIMINALS NOT SO LONG AGO
description: BACK ROOMS Voices From the Illegal Abortion Era. By Ellen Messer and Kathryn E. May. 224 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95. ROE v. WADE The Untold Story of the Landmark Supreme Court Decision That Made Abortion Legal. By Marian Faux. Illustrated. 370 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $22.50.

title: Deborah Kesselman, A Lawyer, Is Married
description: Deborah Kesselman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kesselman of Woodmere, L.I., and Joseph Giovanniello Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Giovanniello of Cedarhurst, L.I., were married yesterday by Justice Beatrice S. Burstein of State Supreme Court at the Lawrence (L.I.) Club.

title: The Holocaust From Students' View
description: We attend the Arrowhead School and we're in Mrs. Warfield's fifth-grade reading group. We read Rena Kunis's letter to the Long Island editor on May 15, and we disagree with it.

title: Damn the Barricades! Bring On a Good Revue!
description: I KNEW I WAS BEING RIDICULOUS, and yet there was some sense in my little daydream. About three-quarters through one of those big - very big - British musicals that are sweeping all before them these Broadway nights, I suddenly fancied that a backdrop descended. It was a white backdrop, glistening in its purity and reflecting light like crazy, and all over it were splashed meteorlike sweeping strokes of red and green and yellow and blue, with joyous curlicues of leftover purple paint dancing here and there in the empty spaces.

title: Fight Over New York Power Line Going to Court
description: A new high-voltage power line through southeastern New York went into operation this month, but the controversy it inspired lingers on.

title: John Drew Theater Starts Afresh
description: LEAD: DESPITE years of solid experience in the professional theater, Zachary Russ considers himself Mr. Average Theatergoer. And it's as this potential ticket-buyer, the average theatergoer, that he has approached his new job as managing producer of the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall.

title: Nancy Seline Is Married
description: Nancy Emily Seline, the daughter of Kathleen D. Seline of Omaha and the late S. Allen Seline, was married yesterday in Bethesda, Md., to Lieut. (j.g.) Stuart Tracey Foster, U.S.N. the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Foster of Monkton, Md. The Rev. Dr. Carroll Gunkel performed the ceremony at the Bethesda United Methodist Church. Mrs. Foster was until recently the director of provider and professional affairs for the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington. Her husband, an oceanographer and meteorologist, is stationed at the Aviation Supply Office in Philadelphia.

title: 'Jury Is Still Out' On Pre-K Benefits
description: In his letter to the Long Island editor on June 5, Thomas Meehan, pre-K coordinator of the Middle Country Central School District, Jericho, avoids the issue I raised on May 8 [ ''Are Schools Just a Line on the Welfare Budget?,'' Opinion Page ] : what happens if and when we look to our schools first for social services, and only second for education - and instead defends his turf, pre-K. Too bad, for he only underscores the feelings of many that when educators are challenged, they simply circle the wagons like all good bureaucrats.

title: POSTINGS: By Deadman's Brook; 'Pocket Mansions' for $1.5 Million
description: Richard Sloper bought a piece of land a block from Main Street in Westport, Conn., and then began developing it as if it were in the middle of Fairfield County horse country. Rather than apartments or town houses, he is building four ''pocket mansions'' on Evergreen Avenue.

title: As Roy Neuberger Reaches 85, Art Remains His Passion
description: LEAD: IF plunging headlong into both career and avocation is the prescription for happiness, then on his 85th birthday Roy Neuberger is ready to compete for the title of ''World's Happiest Millionaire.'' He still puts in a full day at his money-management firm, Neuberger & Berman, but his passion is art.

title: Mysteries of the Truss
description: THE CAPE ANN By Faith Sullivan. 342 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $18.95.

title: 'THE SHAME ON BASEBALL'
description: EXTRA INNINGS By Frank Robinson and Berry Stainback. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $16.95.

title: To '48 Olympic Medalist, Time Enhances Honor
description: LEAD: JOHN KINGSBURY talks about the day he may properly mount and display the Olympic bronze medal he won in 1948. Though his family tells him he should do it, he has kept it tucked out of sight in a drawer for 40 years.

title: ALL BOSSES ARE TYRANTS
description: BEHIND THE VEIL OF ECONOMICS Essays in the Worldly Philosophy. By Robert L. Heilbroner. 207 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: Mothers Deserve A Better Reception
description: How much better it would have been if you had simply let Mother's Day pass unmentioned rather than have yourself represented by the sad, cynical column by Barbara Klaus [ Long Island Sound ] . Expressions of love and regard deserve a more gracious reception than ''it's the thought that counts.'' JOELLEN MCNAMARA Setauket

title: TALKING: Old Houses; Inspection Critical for The Buyer
description: BUYERS of old houses are the stuff of legend. They walk into a vintage house - normally built before 1930 - and fall in love with its nooks and crannies, wide floorboards, moldings and trim and the ghost who lives in the hall closet. And before an hour is up they are hooked.

title: Layne Halstead, Dietitian, Weds
description: At the Congregational Church in Peru, Vt., Layne Adrienne Halstead, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Scott B. Halstead of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Peru, was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Caleb Dixon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris S. Dixon Jr. of Cleveland. The Rev. William A. Nelson performed the ceremony.

title: Hailing the 4th: Music Fairs and Fireworks
description: LEAD: FROG JUMPING, fireworks and a boom-box parade will enliven the Fourth of July for those do not want to stay at home. And if the day has poor weather, New London, as it has done for years, will offer fireworks, river cruises and a visiting tall ship the next weekend.

title:
FOCUS: Barn Houses;
The Supply of Antiques Is Dwindling
description: LEAD: THE supply of old post-and-beam barns in good enough shape to disassemble, restore and rebuild in another location as the core of a new house is running out, builders and preservationists say.

title: New Play by Slade Opens Westport Season
description: THE setting is a room in a guest house in Canada.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BALLET RUSSE DESIGNS Costumes and set designs for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, created during the company's golden years from 1909 to 1929 by legendary painters, will go on display at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford on Saturday.

title: The Rocky Road to Tenant Management
description: HER passage from tenant to owner took Charlene Stroh most of a lifetime, but she says it was worth the wait. It was not until six hard years ago, when she was 65, that Miss Stroh got the chance to buy - for $250 - her two-bedroom apartment in a fragile city-owned tenement that the former landlord had abandoned.

title: WHO WILL WIN: SPINKS OR TYSON?
description: The answer is obvious: both. With the money they are both making how can they lose? JEFFREY COHEN Bayside, Queens

title: Lakes
description: To the Editor: Alison Lurie's article on Lake Como, ''A Moody Retreat Under Italy's Alps'' (Travel, April 3), brought back vivid memories of our recent visit to Como and what we consider one of the finest World War II monuments, the Memorial to the European Resistance.

title: Take Your Pick
description: Sam Goldaper assesses Tuesday's National Basketball Association draft. LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS 1,6 Is there a point guard to go with Danny Manning? INDIANA PACERS 2 The talk of trading the pick is diminishing and 7-4 Rik Smits is expected to be the choice, but some say he may be a few years away. PHILADELPHIA 76ers 3 The glaring problem is at shooting guard. Will it be Hersey Hawkins, Mitch Richmond or Rex Chapman? NETS 4 There are a lot of holes to fill, with the biggest at center. Would go for Smits if he should slip down. If not, Charles Smith of Pittsburgh is a strong possibility. GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS 5 The worst shot-blocking team in the league has traded for 7-6 Manute Bol. Now for a rebounder who can score. How about Tim Perry of Temple? He was very very impressive in Orlando Classic. PHOENIX SUNS 7,14 Name it and the Suns need it. Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons would like to see Richmond there at No. 7. If not, Jeff Grayer, 6-4, of Iowa State. CHARLOTTE HORNETS 8 Expansion teams need big people right away. Could go for Rony Seikaly of Syracuse or Will Perdue of Vanderbilt. MIAMI HEAT 9, 20 Miami figures to go big with first pick and a guard at No. 20. SAN ANTONIO SPURS 10 Will Perry still be there? If not, Chris Morris of Auburn, Horace Grant or Grayer may be around. KNICKS 11 Need a forward who can score. Can they get lucky again the way they did a year ago with Mark Jackson? General Manager Al Bianchi is hoping for Morris, the best all-round talent in the draft. WASHINGTON BULLETS 12 A rebounder. Moses Malone's free agency makes the need even more urgent.
