The year-ago earnings are restated to reflect a change in accounting for S E G Stores Inc. from the consolidation method to the equity method.

title: Rowing; Drama and Laughs In Dragon Festival
description: China and Canada provided drama today and a contingent of National Football League players provided comic relief on the final day of racing at the 13th annual Hong Kong International Dragon Boat Festival.

title: ISLAND VISIT MEANS WORK FOR JACKSON
description: Most Presidential candidates do not make appearances in the Virgin Islands even in the midst of a tight race, but the Rev. Jesse Jackson campaigned here today even though the Democratic contest is over.

title: Bush Calls for Turning Some Bases Into Prisons
description: Vice President Bush today called for closing domestic military bases that are ''not needed.'' Some could then be turned into state prisons to alleviate the shortage of such facilities, he said.

title: Boxing; Foreman Scores Easy Victory
description: George Foreman, the 40-year-old former heavyweight champion, disposed of Carlos Hernandez tonight in four rounds of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight, then called for a bigger challenge.

title: Hans von Balthasar, 82, Swiss Theologian
description: The Rev. Hans Urs von Balthasar, a prominent Swiss theologian who was appointed a cardinal four weeks ago by Pope John Paul II, died today, church officials said. He was 82 years old.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 26, 1988: MONDAY Ameron Inc BellSouth Corp Boeing Co Standard Products Unocal Corp TUESDAY Centerior Energy Fleming Cos Hydraulic Co Montana Pwr Pub Srevice Co Colo Rubbermaid Inc Signet Banking WEDNESDAY Block (H&R) Iowa Resources Redman Indus Washington DC Gas Lt THURSDAY Birmingham Steel Corp Carolina Freight Cascade Nat Gas Harsco Corp Holly Farms Corp Super Valu Stores FRIDAY Nevada Pwr

title: Litter Laws and the Real World of City Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Official Denies Seeing U.S. Phone Bids
description: A former General Services Administration official who helped design the Federal Government's proposed new telephone system contends that he never saw confidential bid information for the system and that Congressional and G.S.A. concerns about the bids being compromised are unfounded.

title: Season Could Start Without Officials
description: Contract negotiations between the National Hockey League and its officials' union have had such a strained start that both groups have confirmed the possibility that the league could open the 1988-89 season without its established referees and linesmen. The league and the union have been at odds since the officials staged a walkout that jeopardized a playoff game in New Jersey last month.

title: Poseidon Pools of America reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included a pre-tax inventory loss of $235,000 from a flood.

title: New Delhi Journal; Prophet for the Humble: Will They Inherit India?
description: Anyone who finishes third in a local election in India can usually start thinking about retirement. But the recent third-place showing in a parliamentary race by Kanshi Ram, a fiery champion of the rights of untouchables and other low castes, was strong enough to shake India's political establishment and force the country's leadership to pay attention to his demands.

title: Sports of The Times; Spinks Will Foil Tyson
description: IN his dressing room inside the same Convention Hall where he will box Mike Tyson tonight, Michael Spinks already had the gloves on for his light-heavyweight title defense against Dwight Braxton five years ago. Suddenly there was a knock on the door. And then the boxer's 2-year-old daughter, carried into the room by her aunt, jumped into her father's arms.

title: Nelson Loses Big Lead but Wins With Birdie on Last Hole
description: Larry Nelson blew a four-shot lead today before coming back with two birdies in the final five holes to shoot a one-over-par 73 and capture the Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Ned Chase, Man Behind the Books
description: When Larry Speakes wrote in his manuscript that he had been a Mississippi journalist before going to work for Senator James O. Eastland in 1968, the editor of his recent book told Mr. Speakes, the former White House press secretary, not to leave it at that - that he should make clear in the book, ''Speaking Out,'' whether he shared the segregationist attitudes of his former employer.

title: Texaco Deal: A New Saudi Strategy
description: By the end of this year, if all goes as planned, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia will be one of the biggest marketers of gasoline in the eastern United States, in a huge shift from the strategy that has been used by petroleum-exporting countries for more than a decade.

title: At Carnegie, A Very Hardy Perennial
description: Ella Fitzgerald delivered two strong sets Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. While the 70-year-old singer's voice isn't as blithely girlish as it was in past decades, and parts of her first set were shaky, she can still cruise through songs with the playful agility that makes her an American treasure.

title: Heading the Field
description: Following are the top five players by position which Marty Blake, who heads the National Basketball Association's Scouting Service, has recommended to the league's general managers. Centers

title: JAPANESE OFFICIAL IN VISIT TO ISRAEL
description: Japan's Foreign Minister spent the day in Israel today, a visit more remarkable for the fact that it occurred than for anything that resulted from it.

title: Ahold NV reports earnings for 16wks to April 23
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. All results translated at today's exchange rate of Dfl 2.0210 equals U.S. $1.00. Share earnings for the first quarter of 1987 have been adjusted to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend in June 1987.

title: Prices Continue to Soar For Cable Acquisitions
description: The price of cable television company acquisitions continues to soar at a time when the broadcasting business is suffering and growth in the sales of video cassette players has slowed.

title: Review/Art; As Venice Biennale Opens, Jasper Johns Takes the Spotlight
description: The Venice Biennale, the granddaddy of international art exhibitions, opens Sunday looking a little younger and more secure than it has in a while. This vast show, with art from over 40 countries, is better organized, with a solid selection of artists and an attention to sculpture that reflects the current vitality of sculpture throughout Europe and the United States.

title: Raymond J. Hellriegel, Photographer, 73
description: Raymond J. Hellriegel, who became one of the first official photographers for the New York City Fire Department in 1939, died of heart failure Saturday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Resort Is 100 (But Keep It Quiet)
description: For all of its hundred years, Twilight Park, a resort that clings to a rocky mountainside near this village in the Catskills, has kept quietly to itself.

title: Books of The Times; How the Rich Are Different
description: Old Money The Mythology of America's Upper Class By Nelson W. Aldrich Jr. 309 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Financial Scandal Is Talk of Britain
description: For the last few weeks, a financial scandal that centers on the unlikely character of Peter Clowes, a portly 45-year-old investment manager, has been Britain's most enthralling popular drama, surpassing anything in the West End theaters or on Wimbledon's grass courts.

title: Mr. Shultz Turns to Nicaragua
description: As Secretary of State George Shultz embarks Wednesday on a four-nation swing through Central America, he has two main options: He can work with regional allies to revive the now-suspended talks between contras and Sandinistas. Or he can write off the peace talks and return to the stubborn pursuit of military aid to the contras.

title: Addi-lyn Swartz and Joel B. Rosen Marry in Jersey
description: Addi-lyn Swartz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry M. Swartz of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Joel Bruce Rosen, the son of Mrs. Lester A. Rosen of Boston and the late Mr. Rosen. Rabbi Jeffrey Segelman performed the ceremony at the Swartz home.

title: Report Finds Fault in Health Agency's Studying of Medicare and Medicaid
description: A Congressional report released today says studies by the Federal agency that monitors Medicare and Medicaid have often been poorly planned and executed, and altered when they disagreed with Administration policies.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Poland will increase new car prices by 40 percent on Monday, the state news agency said. Increased costs of materials and changing currency rates were cited as the reasons for the increase on both Polish-built and imported cars. The price of the country's most popular economy car, the tiny Polish-built Fiat 126-P, will cost one million zlotys (about $2,325), and Poland's top-of-the-line Polonez will start at 2.5 million zlotys (more than $5,800).

title: National Trauma Played Out Again at Gettysburg
description: A century and a quarter later, the pilgrims are converging from everywhere, by the thousands, on this little Pennsylvania town with its immortal name.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone's Chairman Assails Exploitive Ads
description: Because increasing pressure in business can easily lead to excesses in advertising, Norman W. Brown, chairman and chief executive of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, offers a simple method to keep advertisers out of trouble. He calls it the ''E'' test: does advertising enhance or exploit the consumer?

title: 24 Pick-6 Bettors Collect $45,713
description: Grecian Flight won the Vagrancy Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park in an excruciatingly tight finish that earned $52,740 for her owners and $45,713 for each of the 24 horseplayers who had to sweat out a five-minute wait before learning who had won the photo-finish.

title: Head of Pillsbury Unit Joins Williams-Sonoma
description: Kent C. Larson is moving to the kitchen from the supermarket. Instead of determining the types of foods available on grocery shelves, as he did for the Minneapolis-based Pillsbury Company, Mr. Larson will help to shape the array of utensils used in food preparation.

title: Shifts in Haitian Politics Laid to Spread of Drugs
description: Before dawn one morning earlier this year, villagers on the south coast of Haiti watched men in olive drab uniforms unload duffel bags from a small plane on a remote salt flat. Other Haitians said the bags contained cocaine.

title: Employers Test New Ways To Shift Risk on Health Costs
description: Frustrated by largely unsuccessful attempts to hold down medical costs, some major corporations are beginning to try health plans that shift far more of the financial risk to employees, insurance carriers and the medical community.

title: A Pox on Duke and Stanford
description: LEAD: In the conflict between the right and left over what college students should be required to read, no one is talking about pleasure - the reason one reads in the first place.

title: Lauri Lowell and Isaiah Cooper Marry
description: The wedding of Lauri Jan Lowell, a daughter of Vivian Lowell of New York and Stanley H. Lowell of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., to Isaiah David Cooper, the son of Florence Cooper of Middletown, N.Y., and the late Paul H. Cooper, took place yesterday at the Park Slope Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Jeffrey Marker officiated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My corn is only two feet tall. It needs to be four feet tall, or Americans won't believe it's corn.'' - Brian Frankish, a movie producer filming ''Eight Men Out'' in Iowa. [ A16:3. ]

title: National Health Enhancement Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
New Life for Davids Island
description: For more than 20 years, Davids Island, off New Rochelle in Long Island Sound, has remained an ugly nuisance. Now developers propose a 2,000-unit residential community. Nearby towns worry that the project will harm the Sound's waters. With reassurance on that point, however, the plan deserves to go forward.

title: 2 Big Bands With Contrasting Styles
description: Though it was titled ''Battle of the Big Bands,'' Saturday night's JVC Jazz Festival concert at Town Hall featuring Toshiko Akiyoshi's Orchestra and the Mel Lewis Big Band, was less a battle than a celebration. Both orchestras are authoritative big bands: precise and polished, with distinct personalities, they swing hard.

title: Lottery Winners Say They Will Pay Debts
description: A couple who filed for bankruptcy six weeks before winning $4.6 million in a state lottery say they will pay their debts even though they are not required to by law.

title: Tendency of U.S. Trash to Travel Irks Britons
description: The trans-Atlantic traffic in wretched refuse from teeming shores has taken on an entirely new meaning in Cheshire and Cornwall, where local residents are alarmed about a proposal to import millions of tons of garbage from the United States for disposal in far-from-merry Old England.

title: As Class-Cutting Rises, 'Snowball Effect' Is Feared
description: Cutting class has become such an everyday fact of life in New York City's high schools that many educators now view it as a dangerous first step on the road to academic failure for many young people.

title: Celebrating the Legendary Nureyev Legacy
description: Everybody from Miss Piggy to Dame Margot Fonteyn is ready to march onstage at the Metropolitan Opera House to honor Rudolf Nureyev tonight. The gala evening with the Paris Opera Ballet, directed by Mr. Nureyev since 1983, is ostensibly a mammoth 50th birthday party - 3 months and 10 days late - that has been timed to take place in the city that encompasses his most loyal public.

title: Yanks on Upswing; Mets Slide; Henderson Scores Winner
description: In the ninth inning yesterday, with the game tied and the winning run at second base, Lou Piniella looked down the length of the Yankee dugout for a pinch-runner. The first face he saw belonged to Rickey Henderson.

title: General Building Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 A new French jetliner crashed, killing at least three people and injuring about 50. The Airbus A320, considered the most advanced commercial jetliner, was on a demonstration flight in eastern France. Page A1

title: Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for 12mo May 31
description: b-After a gain from an asset sale of $21,680,000.

title: Fencing; Upsets Mark Matches
description: The National Fencing Championships ended yesterday in Chicago after a grueling 10-day run marked by some startling upsets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Ogilvy Unit Looks For Trends
description: ''W E'RE trying to get down to street level and identify the seeds of trends to see what people are really doing,'' said Jane R. Fitzgibbon last week, letting it be known that something is in the wind at Ogilvy & Mather, U.S.

title: Communications Group Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $202,660 and $152,730 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Hildi V. Rosenfeld, Teacher, Marries
description: The marriage of Hildi Victoria Rosenfeld, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Isadore Rosenfeld of Harrison, N.Y., to Richard Warren Silbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Silbert of Boston and Chestnut Hill, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Jay J. Sangerman performed the ceremony.

title: Reagan Gets Role in Foreign Indictments
description: The Reagan Administration has adopted a new policy under which Federal prosecutors must obtain the President's approval before a foreign leader can be indicted by a Federal grand jury.

title: Human Rights Lawyer Is Killed in Philippines
description: One of the Philippines' most respected human rights lawyers has been shot dead, the police said this weekend.

title: Sports World Specials
description: A League of Their Own

title: Pamela Krupman Is Wed to Student
description: Pamela Hope Krupman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Krupman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and James Hislop Allyn 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Allyn of Longmeadow, Mass., and Mystic, Conn., were married yesterday at the Biddle mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. The bride, who will begin teaching in the New York City school system in the fall, graduated from Amherst College and received a master's degree in education of the deaf from Teachers College of Columbia University. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Jackson, Lewis, Schnitzler & Krupman.

title: Costar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Includes a credit of $89,000 representing the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $162,000 and $369,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $530,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and a tax loss carryforward of $307,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said all year-ago figures have been restated for change from LIFO to FIFO accounting for inventories.

title: In Japan, Shinto Revival Transcends Nationalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting to Stay Exempt
description: For a bunch that does not believe in Federal regulation, the insurance industry has invested the United States Capitol with an army of lobbyists.

title: Swim Fin Gives Divers More Thrust
description: Fins are as essential to a scuba diver as hiking boots are to a mountaineer. Now there is a fin designed to create the same kind of lift and forward thrust as an airplane wing. Scubapro, a company based in Rancho Dominguez, Calif., has a fin whose blade is shaped like an air foil. Scubapro says that lift is created as water moves with unequal pressure across the top and bottom of the blade.

title: Ohio Mattress Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
New York City Is Challenged As Giant of Global Economy
description: At a time when the global economy is being tied together as never before in a network of financial markets and professional services, New York City is facing new challenges to its position as the world's leading center of business.

title: Review/Music; At Caramoor, the Sounds of Nature and of Art
description: This is the time of year when music leaves the safe harbor of the concert hall and does battle with nature. Such sorties go under various names: music on the lawn, concerts under the stars, opera in the parks, chamber music in the dell. Most bear a broader title of festival, like the one here at Caramoor that began its 43d summer season tonight. John Nelson conducted the Orchestra of St. Luke's in music by Haydn, Mozart and Stravinsky. Peter Serkin was the pianist in the Ravel Concerto in G. Whether Caramoor and festivals like it celebrate the man-made artifacts we call music or else music's natural enemy - the great outdoors - is also a matter of some confusion to the people who put on such events. Hoped for, I imagine, is beauty by addition whereby two nice things lumped together end up doubling our pleasure. One comes away, however, thinking that concerts, even ones as well played as this, are still better off inside where it's safe. Airplanes and helicopters overhead may seem the immediate danger but they are not the ultimate ones. More insidious are the sounds of nature: the wind rushing through the trees, causing canvas overhangs to flap, or the small bird that cheeped through the Haydn ''Feuersymphonie.'' These are more unsettling for they do more than disrupt, they confront - offering a competing beauty so overwhelming and so alien from counterpoint, sonata form or other puny human constructs that works of art are made to seem not just superfluous but painfully out of place.

title: Nichols Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Film Producer Marries Miss Dauphin, Actress
description: Antonia Beresford Dauphin, an actress, and Peter Ross Newman, a film producer, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Newman, in Bedford, N.Y. Rabbi Murray Grauer officiated.

title: Paris Plans 1998 Referendum for New Caledonia
description: The French Government announced today that it would organize a referendum on self-determination for New Caledonia in 10 years and offer an immediate plan of economic improvement for the Pacific colony.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Merabank's Top Officer Helps Failed Institutions
description: LEAD: Despite the serious problems of the savings and loan industry, not all the savings institutions in the Southwest are suffering. Gene E. Rice is chief executive of one of the region's strongest units, the Phoenix-based Merabank, which has $6 billion in assets.

title: Communications & Cable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the prior year's 6 months are not comparable because of the restructuring of the company's business and assets. The year-ago quarter's results are from Jan. 14, 1987, following restructuring of the business and assets of the company. There were no operations from Jan. 14, 1987 to Jan. 31, 1987.

title: Riders Eye Seoul
description: The team that will defend the United States gold medal in show jumping at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, will be selected after two competitions in New York in the coming month.

title: Track and Field; Schonlebe Is No. 1 In E. German Meet
description: When Thomas Schonlebe registered for the East Germany national track and field championships, he was issued the number 1 to pin on his jersey.

title: Calstar Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Included $327,822 of non-recurring income. The company said fiscal 1987 net income has been restated to reflect a change in the company's method of accounting for a portion of its inventories from LIFO to FIFO.

title: Johnson Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $184,000 for the quarter and $201,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also includes income from discontinued operations of $104,000.

title: Soviets Raise Grain Bonuses
description: The Soviet Government has sharply raised the bonuses it pays to farms for grain in a significant new effort to stimulate production and cut imports, Tass, the official press agency, reported Thursday.

title: Agency Issues New Guidelines on Heat Illness
description: After studying more than 1,700 heat-related deaths in a 1980 heat wave, the Federal Centers for Disease Control have recommended that government and community groups change the way they try to prevent heat deaths among the poor and elderly.

title: Gay Marchers Send Up Bevy of Balloons in Tribute
description: LEAD: The 19th Gay and Lesbian Pride March on Fifth Avenue came to a halt at 2:30 P.M. yesterday, and the songs and chants fell silent as marchers released 10,000 balloons, clumps of blue, yellow and red that soon disappeared beyond the skyscrapers.

title: Edgar W. B. Fairchild, 82, Dies; Led Family Publishing Company
description: Edgar W. B. Fairchild, chief executive of his family's publishing company until his retirement in 1970, died of complications from pneumonia Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: Gerry Mulligan In New Attitude, With a Quartet
description: Gerry Mulligan, leading a quartet in New York for the first time in six years, played a program Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y in the JVC Jazz Festival (which is part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts) that suggested his arrival at a new stage in his career.

title: Democrats Set Change in Tone, Using Unity in Passing Platform
description: Setting aside differences for the sake of victory in November, Democratic Party committees adopted a platform and a set of delegate-selection rules this weekend in a rare atmosphere of unity.

title: ADVANCED JETLINER CRASHES IN FRANCE, KILLING AT LEAST 3
description: A new jetliner considered by many aviation experts to be the most advanced commercial plane on the market crashed today on a demonstration flight in eastern France. At least three people were killed and about 50 injured, Government officials said.

title: Fitness; Could There Be Exercise Prescriptions for 'Runner's High'?
description: AT some point during their training, young doctors dream of the brilliant discovery that will will secure a foothold in medicine: faculty appointments, a corner office and a reserved spot in the parking lot hang in the balance.

title: A Bronx Landfill Raises Concern Over Diseases
description: Since helping set up a hot-line telephone number a few months ago, Patricia Nonnon has been the chief monitor of reports from people in the northeastern tip of the Bronx about diseases and serious health problems. She maintains a loose-leaf notebook, neatly separated, by illness, into color-tabbed sections.

title: Cognos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Experts Say Tyson Is a Cinch
description: All along Michael Spinks has said that Mike Tyson -good as he may be - is a man like any other man and susceptible to the wiles of a shrewd boxer.

title: Bone in The Throat
description: The Rumanian leadership under President Nicolae Ceausescu is widely regarded as one of the most repressive of Communist regimes, and so it came as no surprise when a prominent critic, Sylviu Brucan, was placed under house arrest in Bucharest last winter.

title: Intelligent Business Communication Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Thomas Gass Weds Miss Azimi-Sanavi
description: Sousan Azimi-Sanavi, a daughter of Touran Mollah-Jafari and Hussein Azimi-Sanavi, both of Teheran, Iran, was married yesterday to Thomas Evan Gass, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manus G. Gass of River Edge, N.J., and Southampton, L.I. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Gass home in Southampton.

title: Diving; Neyer Wins a Personal Battle
description: Megan Neyer looked back at her early years in diving and told a frightening tale.

title: China's Private Sector
description: China said Friday that it had more than 225,000 private companies and that they were increasingly important to economic growth. The Worker's Daily said these companies employed more than 3.6 million workers and accounted for 1 percent of the nation's industrial production. China's Communist leaders began a series of economic changes in 1978, encouraging growth in the private sector.

title: Market Place; Optimism Grows On I.B.M. Outlook
description: HAS the International Business Machines Corporation turned the corner? Last week I.B.M. shares made their strongest move upward since the market's October crash, and many analysts say that, after three years of declining earnings, the computer giant is ready for growth again.

title: Ad Award Events Come in Three Flavors
description: Advertising's awards season is over. To those who persist in seeing the ad industry as a monolithic manipulator, the three major shows that took place in New York this month reveal that the cultures and styles of the advertising game are actually varied.

title: Student Wins the Right To Race in Wheelchair
description: In his final two seasons as a member of the high school track team, Scot Hollonbeck raced only against himself. An athlete who must use a wheelchair, he took to the track alone, forbidden to compete with able-bodied runners in meets.

title: American Business Needs More Risk Takers; Not Perfect, of Course
description: To the Editor:

title: St. Gillian: Striking It Rich In the Mainstream
description: Back in 1972, Kay Unger had a small dress business that was limping along because she was basically a designer and knew nothing about running a business. Then one evening she invited two acquaintances from the garment district in Manhattan to her apartment and suggested that they go into business together. Four weeks later they shipped their first order.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, two picture captions in the ''Street Fashion'' grouping on Sunday were reversed. The woman at the upper right, wearing a print dress with a pleated flounce, was Olivia Alexander. The woman at the lower right, in a flowered Scaasi, was Edna Morris.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; If You Can't Beat Them
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, acquired a reputation, deserved or not, as a Japan basher both from the oratory he occasionally employed as a Presidential candidate and as the author of an amendment to trade legislation that would have imposed stringent sanctions on Japan. Both his Presidential hopes and his amendment were defeated last spring.

title: Gasoline Prices Off a Bit
description: Gasoline prices dipped a quarter of a cent a gallon in the last two weeks, the Lundberg Survey, a nationwide poll of more than 12,000 stations, has found. The survey said the average price of all grades of gasoline offered at all types of service stations was 99.98 cents a gallon on Friday, down from $1.0023 a gallon on June 10.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Batts Inc., Zeeland, Mich., a hanger manufacturer, appointed William F. Silvia president and chief operating officer. He will also serve as a director of Batts and its holding company, Batts Group Ltd.

title: Thortec International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The year-ago figures have been revised.

title: Horner Out 6 Weeks
description: The St. Louis Cardinals were told yesterday that the first baseman Bob Horner will not require extensive surgery on his sore shoulder but that he will be out for at least six weeks.

title: A Report on Ulster Killings Assails British Use of Force
description: Amnesty International asserted today that Britain had been so permissive in the use of lethal force in Northern Ireland and so lax in investigating abuses that it had lent credibility to charges of official involvement in deliberate police killings of unarmed Irish civilians.

title: I.B.M. Seen Offering Job Transfers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will offer transfers tomorrow to at least 1,000 workers, and perhaps many more, as part of its continuing effort to cut costs and reduce overcapacity, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Paroles Aren't Denied To AIDS Inmates
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Opinions by Justices on Immunizing Contractors From Suits
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today granting broad immunity to military and other Government contractors against suits for deaths and injuries caused by negligently designed equipment they sell the Government. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote the opinion. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the dissent, while Justice John Paul Stevens dissented separately. FROM THE OPINION By Justice Scalia

title: G.M. Confirms Departure
description: As expected, the General Motors Corporation announced today that Elmer W. Johnson, its executive vice president for legal, operating and public affairs, would be leaving to return to law practice.

title: Allison Improves
description: Bobby Allison's condition improved from critical to guarded yesterday as he continued to recover from injuries suffered in a crash at the Nascar Miller 500 in Long Pond, Pa.

title: Court Upholds Ban on Picketing a Home
description: In a case pitting free speech rights against residential privacy, the Supreme Court today upheld a Wisconsin town's ban on picketing ''focused on, and taking place in front of, a particular residence.''

title: No Liability Amnesty for Pharmaceuticals
description: To the Editor:

title: Sage Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Status of Major Insider Investigations
description: While Wall Street digests the lastest insider trading scandal, it is also waiting to hear the outcome of several other major insider cases or investigations. These include the sentencing of an investment banker, Martin A. Siegel, and a trading executive, Boyd L. Jefferies. Both are believed to be cooperating in providing information to the Government in exchange for lighter sentences. Among other pending insider trading cases or investigations are these: Drexel Burnham A huge investigation of the corporate takeover and junk bond trading practices of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has been under way since shortly after the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky reached an agreement to cooperate with Federal prosecutors in the fall of 1986.

title: Amre Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes $250,000, or 3 cents a share, attributable to FASB No. 96, a change in the method of accounting for income taxes.

title: American Business Needs More Risk Takers
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway and Canada Call for Pact to Protect Atmosphere
description: The Prime Ministers of Canada and Norway called today for a binding international agreement to protect the atmosphere from pollution.

title: In War on Coca, U.S. Weapon Is Bogged Down in a Dispute
description: Almost invisible inside one of the thousands of bright green coca fields that cover the Upper Huallaga Valley in Peru is a tiny brown plot with dead plants that represents the United States' latest hope of winning the war against cocaine.

title: Catholic Bishops Vote to Retain Controversial Statement on AIDS
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops voted today to leave in place a controversial document about AIDS, but they acknowledged that it had shortcomings and agreed to work on a further statement of policy.

title: Apple Unit Buys Software Concern
description: The Claris Corporation, the software subsidiary of Apple Computer Inc., said it had bought Styleware Inc. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Styleware, a privately held software company based in Houston, publishes 10 software products for the Apple II computers, including Multiscribe, a word-processing program.

title: Citicorp-Led Group To Take Over York
description: The York International Corporation, a leading manufacturer of air-conditioners, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a group led by Citicorp's venture-capital unit for $57.50 a share in cash and securities. The total takeover deal was valued at about $750 million.

title: Historical Society Is Planning Cuts To Meet Crisis
description: The New-York Historical Society, the state's oldest museum and the owner of important collections of early American manuscripts, Hudson River School paintings and other art and Americana, is facing a severe financial crisis that has led its trustees to plan to dismiss between 20 and 30 percent of its staff and to plan to close two of its four floors of galleries.

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Drop
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved lower in light trading yesterday, pushed lower by sell orders from Japanese investors and by a sharp increase in commodity prices. Interest from domestic investors remained virtually nonexistent, dealers said.

title: Qatar Rejects U.S. Demand For Return of Illicit Stingers
description: The tiny Persian Gulf sheikdom of Qatar, which has traditionally sought good relations with the United States, is defying the Reagan Administration by refusing to turn over American-made Stinger missiles that it bought on the black market.

title: Jay J. Swift, 62, Former New York Official
description: Jay James Swift, a former official of the New York City Environmental Control Board and of the city's Addiction Services Agency, died of cancer Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Picketing Restriction Upheld
description: The Supreme Court upheld a Wisconsin town's restrictions on picketing in a case pitting free speech rights against residential privacy. At issue was the right of abortion foes to protest outside a doctor's home. Page 18.

title: Market Place; Savings Industry: Seeking Quality
description: IN spite of the recent failures among savings and loan institutions and the consequent shunning of the industry by many investors, several select thrift industry stocks continue to offer good value, according to some industry experts.

title: Japanese Cities Most Costly
description: Japanese cities remain the most expensive for foreign business executives, with Teheran, Iran, and Oslo close behind, a private consultant group said today. The survey by the group, Business International, of living costs in 103 leading cities showed that Tokyo and the Osaka-Kobe urban area in Japan topped all other major metropolitan areas for the third straight year. Teheran ranked third, followed by Oslo, Zurich, Geneva and Helsinki, Finland.

title: Univar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Prosecutor Race in the Bronx Could Foreshadow City Politics of the 1990's
description: After weeks of on-again, off-again candidacies, political maneuvering and mudslinging that reached to Albany and Washington, the Bronx district attorney race is developing into a battle that could foreshadow New York City's politics in the 1990's, when minority-group politicians are expected to control City Hall.

title: Cartwright Traded To Bulls for Oakley
description: Bill Cartwright, who has never been thrilled with his role as a backup center to Patrick Ewing, got his wish to be traded last night.

title: Brown & Williamson Gives Esty a New Job
description: The William Esty Company, one of the multitude of agencies to bear the Saatchi & Saatchi stamp, has gotten an additional creative assignment from Brown & Williamson Tobacco, a subsidiary of Batus Holdings.

title: Allwaste Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-ago periods have been restated to include acquistions.

title: Rite Aid Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $47,059,000 and a gain from an accounting adjustment of $3,712,000.

title: Contras Say They Don't Plan To Resume War in Nicaragua
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders said today that rebel troops in Honduran base camps had begun returning to their field positions in Nicaragua, but they insisted that they had no plans to resume offensive military operations against Nicaraguan Government forces.

title: Quality Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Federal Agency Unveils Plan For Easing A-Plant Licensing
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today unveiled a proposal aimed at making it easier to license new nuclear power plants, and it warned that no one will ever build a plant again unless the bill, or a similar one, is adopted.

title: Jackson Addresses Convention of PUSH
description: Speaking before the civil rights organization he founded, the Rev. Jesse Jackson asserted Sunday night that critics who accuse him of being ''out of the mainstream'' are correct.

title: VWR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $570,000 from the cumulative effect of an income tax accounting change.

title: Unified Fight On Mail Cost Is Organized
description: UNITED by adversity, the Magazine Publishers of America and the Direct Marketing Association are planning to work together for the first time in a search for a way to alleviate the impact of higher postal rates.

title: Review/Music; Ellington's 'Drum Is A Woman'
description: Duke Ellington's ''Drum Is a Woman,'' a jazz allegory with songs by the Duke and Billy Strayhorn and a narrative in the Duke's ironic and sometimes florid prose, was composed and recorded in 1956. A year later, it was adapted for a television production. In the more than three decades since then, it had never been performed. But on Friday it was given its stage premiere at Symphony Space by an 11-piece orchestra and 3 singers conducted by the pianist and arranger Chris Cherney.

title: Cherbourg Journal; Civil War Drama Under Way, 30 Fathoms Deep
description: Mint juleps and Scarlett O'Hara do not jump to mind when people visit this gray, wind-swept port on the English Channel.

title: Gary Towlen, Pianist, 45
description: Gary Towlen, a concert pianist and teacher, died of complications from AIDS on Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital in Charlotte, N.C. He was 45 years old.

title: Article 262088 -- No Title
description: The board of the Fort Howard Corporation, the giant maker of paper products, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the company to a group led by senior management for $53 a share, or $3.57 billion.

title: A Safer Infant Formula Promised
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about the Carnation Company's new infant formula misstated the market shares for soy-based and milk-based infant formulas. Soy-based formulas account for 22.27 percent of the market, and milk-based formulas 69.70 percent.

title: State Youth Aide Is Held in String Of Child Molestations in Queens
description: A supervisor of children's activities for a state agency was arrested in Queens Sunday as a suspect in a yearlong string of at least 17 child molestation cases. He was captured, the police said, after he assaulted a 10-year-old girl in her apartment elevator in Elmhurst and was pursued by her enraged father.

title: No Haitian Elections, Military Ruler Declares
description: Lieut. General Henri Namphy, the self-proclaimed President of Haiti's military Government, said in an interview published today that he believes his country is not ready for elections.

title: Meredith Is Planning Cross-Stitch Magazine
description: The Meredith Corporation is set the bring out a new six-a-year magazine called Cross Quick that will have a circulation from both subscriptions and single copy sales of 750,000. It will not, however, carry any advertising except the ads promoting some Meredith products.

title: Texaco Contests Some Bankruptcy Fees
description: Requests by financial and legal professionals for more than $50 million in fees for their work on Texaco Inc.'s huge bankruptcy proceeding provoked name-calling and bickering yesterday at the Federal Bankruptcy Court here.

title: Topics of The Times; Sweet Temptation
description: Where there's been enough rain, the end of June in farm country means ripe strawberries, and obsessive fanciers know enough to go straight to the farm stand.

title: Corning Glass Works reports earnings for 12wks to June 19
description: b-Includes a one-time after-tax gain on sale of stock of $19.8 million, or 44 cents a share for the 12 weeks, and tax credits of $1 million for the 12 weeks and $1.3 million for the 24 weeks. c-Includes tax credits of $1 million and $2.2 million for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks, respectively, and the 24 weeks also includes a credit of $14.2 million representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Ban on Parole Upheld For California Killing
description: The California Supreme Court ruled today that a state parole board did not err when it rescinded the scheduled parole of Gregory Ulas Powell, who killed a policeman in an onion field.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Audiotronics Corp., North Hollywood, Calif., a marketer of instructional programs, said it had discussed possible business combinations with two unnamed companies.

title: Is This Any Way to Grow Old?
description: LEAD: My father has an organic brain disease. It's Parkinson's disease, and in his case it has led to the additional trauma of Parkinsonian dementia. He is in and out of reality. At times, he is as clever as can be -until he sees snakes or space stations or trucks in his room.

title: On Horse Racing; Pick-6 Dreamers Bound to Try Again
description: Last weekend's stakes races at Belmont had figured to be the dullest of the summer, the epitome of the annual letdown between the Belmont Stakes in early June and the parade of good races over the Fourth of July weekend. The Sheepshead Bay Handicap for older fillies on the grass Saturday and the Vagrancy Handicap for older filly sprinters Sunday were intriguing contests, but of little national significance or emotional appeal.

title: Europe Weighs Central Bank Idea
description: Leaders of the 12 nations of the European Community gathered here today to take stock of progress toward the creation of a single European market by 1992.

title: Business and Health; Credit Ratings Cut at Hospitals
description: AS their operating surpluses have dwindled because of a squeeze on health care payments, many hospitals have seen their credit ratings reduced, which only adds to their costs. The hospitals say the main sources of the payment pressure are the Federal Government and health insurance companies, which are seeking to control rising costs.

title: Carrington Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
News Summary
description: International A2-15 Sporadic gunfights in Nicaragua have broken out between Sandinista patrols and contra troops near Quilali. Residents fear that the three-month-old cease fire may be falling apart. Page A1 Aerial spraying of coca in Peru with a herbicide that killed the plant in tests is being delayed by a dispute among the Reagan Administration, environmental groups and the herbicide's manufacturer over its safety. A1 A strike in the Soviet Union ended as residents of the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region returned to work. Speakers at a meeting argued that the strike would harm Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies, Soviet officials said. A13 Arab proposals for talks with Israel put forward by an aide to Yasir Arafat are intriguing, American officials say. They say the proposals represent a softening of the P.L.O.'s line but lack authoritative support from the leadership. A3 Suggestions for ending the uprising in Israeli-occupied terrritories have again been offered by the underground leadership of the Palestinianrevolt. An Israeli official rejected the proposals, saying they were neither new nor acceptable. A3 A French pilot was flying too low in demonstrating a new Airbus A320 when it crashed in eastern France, Government officials said. They said there was no evidence that the plane had malfunctioned. D24 Discovery of a Confederate privateer that sank near France has excited residents of Cherbourg, who want to make the ship the centerpiece of a museum. Some Americans want the Alabama returned to the United States. A4 British policy in Northern Ireland in using lethal force and investigating abuses lends credibility to charges of official involvement in deliberate police killings of unarmed civilians, Amnesty International asserted. A3 Train crash kills 20 in Paris A4 Angolan rebel leader, in U.S., appeals to Congress for aid now A6 Vote fraud feared in Mexican elections A8 U.S. aides are split on Soviet treaty compliance A15 National A16-23 Contractors have immunity against liability for deaths and injuries to members of the armed services and others in many cases caused by negligently designed equipment, the Supreme Court ruled, by 5 to 4. A1 A Wisconsin town's ban on picketing, adopted to stop pickets by anti-abortion protestors in front of the home of a doctor who performed abortions, was upheld by the Supreme Court, 6-3. A18 Pentagon action against contractors accused of wrongdoing may be taken before convictions in the investigation of procurement fraud, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci 3d said. But he said more information was needed. A21 An analyst sold insider information to a Taiwanese national, who earned more than $19 million by using data on takeovers in which Morgan Stanley & Co. acted as an adviser, the S.E.C. charged. A1 Shortcomings in an AIDS policy, which was issued last December, were acknowledged by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops, but they voted to let the document stand while they begin work on a further statement. A1 The Presidential AIDS commission gave its final report to President Reagan, who did not comment on its call for an executive order or Federal laws to prevent discrimination against individuals carrying the AIDS virus. A16 Drug tests at the Justice Department may be carried out later this summer, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced. A group of senior employees said they would file a lawsuit to block the testing. A16 Houston journal: Chess thrives in laissez-faire land of oil A16 Agency unveils plan to ease licensing of nuclear plants A21 Politics A23 George Bush is running behind President Reagan's 1984 performance in most electoral groups, according to a poll, which also found that Michael Dukakis's supporters were not yet firmly committed to him. A23 Jesse Jackson's critics are correct when they say he is out of the mainstream, Mr. Jackson said in a speech before a convention of Operation PUSH, the civil rights organization he founded. A23 Washington Talk A22 Old rivals make peace to write housing bill Regional B1-5 A poll of views on the Brawley case among New Yorkers found that an overwhelming share of whites and a solid majority of blacks say Tawana Brawley's mother and advisers have not handled the case responsibly. A1 A new president for Hunter College was named by the City University's board of trustees, which also announced the selection of a Harvard scholar as the new president of Medgar Evers College. B1 Manslaughter charges were dropped against two men and five teen-agers in the death of a man who was beaten by a mob in East Harlem after he took $20 from a woman. Charges still remain against one man. B1 Andrew Stein has matured politically since the days when he was considered the bad boy of New York City politics, according to some politicians. The City Council President's detractors are skeptical about the changes. B1 The race for Bronx District Attorney could foreshadow New York City politics in the 1990's, when minority-group politicians are expected to control City Hall. B4 A $50,000 payment from Wedtech to the former Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simom, was an unsolicited campaign contribution, not an extortion payment, Mr. Simon testified in the Wedtech racketeering trial. B3 The talk of Ironbound: Prosperous, but isolated B1 Man says detectives forced him to confess to killing B3

title: Simon Denies Extorting Wedtech Funds
description: Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, testifying yesterday in the Wedtech racketeering trial, said that he had received $50,000 from Wedtech as an unsolicited campaign contribution, and not as an extorted payment for winning city approval for a lease.

title: Poor Nations Plagued With AIDS Pose Haunting Ethical Questions
description: AS medical researchers make slow progress toward developing drugs to treat AIDS and the diseases that strike its victims, experts are turning to the thorny question of when and how promising treatments should be distributed in poor countries of Africa and elsewhere where AIDS is spreading.

title: Efforts to Extend Run of 'Juno' Fail
description: Efforts to extend the run of the acclaimed production of Sean O'Casey's ''Juno and the Paycock'' by the Gate Theater Dublin have failed. The play will close after Sunday's performance, as originally planned.

title: Suspect's Childhood Goal: Money
description: This was to have been the week that Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr. completed the two-year financial analysts' program at Morgan Stanley & Company. Instead, he was suspended under a cloud of scandal.

title: In a Thriving Community, Ties That Bind Also Chafe
description: The noon rush had subsided, and the talk at the Iberia Restaurant turned to how the Portuguese immigrants who make up the majority of residents in the Ironbound section here tend to speak almost exclusively in their native language.

title: Texan to Address Democrats
description: Ann Richards, State Treasurer of Texas, will give the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention, Paul G. Kirk Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced today.

title: Diablo Pact Could Leave Utility Wary
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said today that a proposed agreement in the rate case involving the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant would require it to take a $500 million after-tax write-off that would virtually wipe out its 1988 earnings.

title: Koch Says He Will Not Pay to Retain Two Firehouses, Period
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that even if the New York City Council and Board of Estimate restore money to his budget to reopen a firehouse in Brooklyn and prevent the closing of another in the Bronx, he will not spend the money because the firehouses are not essential.

title: Voodoo, Too
description: The man who heckled Ronald Reagan for ''voodoo economics'' in 1980 is now beating the drums for his own version. Vice President Bush flatly rules out tax increases and new taxes to balance the budget if he's elected President. He claims that the budget can be balanced with a ''flexible freeze'' on spending, increased revenue from growth, and savings from lower interest on the national debt.

title: Excerpts From Ruling In Picketing Ban Case
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding a Wisconsin town's ban on picketing focused on and taking place in front of a particular home. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the opinion, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Harry A. Blackmun, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Byron R. White filed a separate opinion concurring in the judgment. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. dissented, joined by Justice Thurgood Marshall. Justice John Paul Stevens dissented separately. FROM THE OPINION By Justice O'Connor

title: Court Rules Triangle Plant Cannot Move From Duluth
description: In a ruling that could affect public programs to aid businesses, a Minnesota district judge ordered an out-of-state company to return equipment to Minnesota that it bought with the proceeds of tax-exempt bonds issued by the City of Duluth.

title: Citicorp Is Said to Study First Republicbank Data
description: A large team of bankers from Citicorp, the nation's largest bank-holding company, are poring over loan documents and other financial details this week at the Dallas headquarters of the troubled First Republicbank Corporation, a spokesman for the Texas banking company confirmed late today.

title: Tokheim Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The second quarter earnings were favorably impacted by about $320,000, or 5 cents a share, resulting from gains realized on the sale of fixed assets. The implementation in the first quarter of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 96, accounting for income taxes, increased earnings $2,390,000, or 37 cents a share, in the first quarter and 6-month periods.

title: Allegheny Proxy Vote
description: Allegheny International Inc. said yesterday that it had retained control of its board in a proxy fight with a group of dissident shareholders led by the New York brokerage firm of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, according to preliminary results of the voting.

title: Stocks Retreat Broadly as Dow Falls 34.50
description: Stock prices fell across a broad front yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 34.50 points, to 2,108.46.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Bisconti Shares Ike Lead: In his attempt to match the golf achievements of his father, Peter Bisconti is beginning to run into a problem involving his name, which is rather familiar to golfers in the metropolitan area.

title: Minkow Enters Plea
description: Barry Minkow, the whiz kid entrepreneur who turned a garage-based carpet-cleaning service into the multimillion-dollar ZZZZ Best Co. before it went bankrupt, pleaded not guilty today to modified fraud charges. The plea came on a revised indictment that supersedes the earlier charges. The new indictment added several fraud counts while deleting one racketeering charge. Minkow, indicted in January, is accused of defrauding investors and banks out of more than $24 million by claiming his company was richer than it actually was.

title: Topics of The Times; Terror Toads
description: Little did a man named Jim Bartlett of Orlando, Fla. know what he was doing this week when he splinted a toad's broken leg with a paint stirrer. Mr. Bartlett thought he was doing a favor for a fellow creature. He was, but not, perhaps, for us mammals. Not if this particular toad turns out to have been an enemy scout.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am afraid we are going to start having funerals here again.'' - Rev. Camilo Sevilla, a Protestant pastor in Nicaragua, on the civil war's shaky cease-fire. [ A1:1. ]

title: Sports of The Times; He Rules The Planet
description: IT was bigger than the world championship, or at least more far-reaching. The Tyson-Spinks fight had interplanetary implications.

title: PATTERNS
description: Men's suits - serious suits - are making fashion news. First of all, at a time of soft sales in women's apparel, suits are selling, retailers and manufacturers say. But the well-tailored man may be in for a shock this fall, when the price of his uniform, led by the soaring cost of raw materials, takes the biggest jump in history.

title: 2 Scherer Holders Plan Proxy Fight
description: The children of the founder of the R. P. Scherer Corporation said they were planning a proxy fight to force a sale of the company, which makes soft gelatin capsules. Karla Scherer Fink, the biggest stockholder and daughter of R. P. Scherer, and her brother John Scherer, who together control about 38 percent of the shares, said they had told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they intended to solicit proxies.

title: Sudan Hides Its Famine
description: Ethiopia deserves the worldwide condemnation it has received for blocking shipment of food to northern regions afflicted by famine and insurgency. But why has Ethiopia's huge neighbor, the Sudan, escaped comparable criticism for what looks like the same offense, in its stricken south?

title: Man Says Detectives Forced Him to Confess to Killing Witness
description: In sobbing and pleading tones, a young man said in a Queens courtroom yesterday that he had falsely confessed to the execution-style killing of an elderly crime witness because detectives had beaten and threatened him.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Father Replaces Son At Steak House Chain
description: LEAD: T. Mark McCall, president and chief executive of Ryan's Family Steak Houses Inc. of Greenville, S.C., resigned yesterday to pursue other interests, the company said in a statement.

title: Washington Talk: The Legislative Process; Old Rivals Make Peace To Write a Housing Bill
description: It was a chance encounter between opponents that led to a new alliance in Washington politics.

title: On Eve of Soviet Party Talks, Strike in Armenian Area Ends
description: Residents of a disputed southern Soviet region have ended a tense monthlong general strike, relieving Mikhail S. Gorbachev of a potentially embarrassing problem on the eve of a national Communist Party conference, according to official reports.

title: Decision to Williams
description: Carl Williams won a unanimous 12-round decision from Trevor Berbick tonight at Convention Hall to become the International Boxing Federation's mandatory heavyweight challenger.

title: Angolan Rebel Asks for U.S. Aid
description: Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan guerrilla leader, asked Congress today to provide more aid to his organization to support its war against the Luanda Government.

title: Dodgers Win to Pull Away From Astros
description: Shawn Hillegas combined with three relievers on a five-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Houston Astros, 4-0, to win for the ninth time in their last 10 games.

title: Books of The Times; Free Will and Making Sex Sinful
description: Adam, Eve, and the Serpent By Elaine Pagels 189 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Laos Holds Nationwide Vote For the First Time Since '75
description: Laos held its first nationwide elections Sunday since the Communists seized power in that Southeast Asian nation 13 years ago, the official Laotian press agency said.

title: S.E.C. Discloses Insider Scheme Worth Millions
description: In a court filing suggesting that blatant insider trading is far from dead, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that a 24-year-old junior analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company had sold confidential information on at least 25 proposed corporate takeovers.

title: Bridge
description: There are some maneuvers in play that are common in textbooks but extremely rare in practical play.

title: Corrections
description: The Q&A column in Science Times last Tuesday referred incorrectly to the Austrian animal behavior expert Konrad Lorenz. He is alive, near Vienna.

title: Tigers Stretch Lead to Two
description: The lineup might have been the one that Lou Piniella had been hoping to see, but the result was something less than the new manager expected. The Yankees, who had climbed back to within one game of the division lead, were beaten again by the first-place Detroit Tigers last night.

title: Plan to Evict Drug Dealers Should Help in the Fight on Crack
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyson Knocks Out Spinks at 1:31 of Round 1
description: Mike Tyson's reign of terror continues.

title: U.S. Aides Are Split on Soviet Treaty Compliance
description: Facing sharp divisions in their ranks, top Administration officials plan to meet on Tuesday to consider what to do about a disputed Soviet early-warning radar in central Siberia, officials said today.

title: In Analyst Programs, Access to Inside Data
description: Programs for financial analysts, like the one that Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., worked in at Morgan Stanley & Company, have flourished at major Wall Street investment houses since the heyday of the bull market.

title: A Home PC? Fantasy And Reality
description: EXPERTS estimate that there are 12 million to 18 million personal computers installed in the world. I wonder if they are counting all the PC's gathering dust in closets and attics.

title: Charges Dropped Against 7 in Fatal Beating
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has dropped manslaughter charges against two men and five teen-agers in the death of a man caught and beaten by a mob in East Harlem last March after he snatched a $20 bill from a woman in a bakery.

title: Houston Journal; Chess Texas Style: No Quarter Given
description: Early in the evening they saunter in one by one, coolly sizing up the competition, ready for combat.

title: London Sugar At 5-Year High
description: Sugar prices hit five-year highs in London today, bolstered by drought in the United States and supply problems in the Caribbean area.

title: A $1 Per Gallon Gasoline Tax, Without Tears
description: LEAD: Staring us in the face is a relatively painless solution to the budget crisis.

title: Lightning Leads To Many Delays On the L.I.R.R.
description: About 60,000 Long Island Rail Road commuters were delayed by as much as 78 minutes yesterday when dozens of morning rush-hour trains were forced to a crawl after track signals were damaged by lightning.

title: Home Resale Rise Posted
description: Sales of existing homes climbed 3.1 percent in May, pushed up by fears of rising interest rates, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Datamag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pillsbury Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a net restructuring charge of $140.9 million. c-Included a net restructuring charge of $21.6 million for the quarter and year; the year also included a net gain of $9.7 million from asset sales.

title: Reviews/Music; Britten's Fairies And Love
description: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Benjamin Britten's marvelously wrought Shakespeare opera, is getting a great deal of American exposure these days, perhaps enough to make it truly well known to a small core of the audience and performing community. If that happens, its perpetuation in the repertory will be assured, which would be wonderful. The June Opera Festival here has been offering a creditable, well-prepared, understandingly performed representation of the work.

title: Review/Television; Violence in the Home, on 'Frontline'
description: Despite the tabloid title, ''My Husband Is Going to Kill Me'' is a sober report on a subject of much concern these days. Tonight's ''Frontline,'' on Channel 13 at 9, tells the story of a 30-year-old woman who was killed by her husband after a decade or more of abuse and months of threats and shows of violence that might have alerted the police and the courts to the fact that this man was dangerous.

title: AM Plans Sale Of Press Group
description: AM International Inc. said today that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Harris Graphics Web Press Group to the Komori Printing Machinery Company for about $250 million.

title: New Shuttle: Hundreds of Safety Changes Also Add Risks
description: AFTER two years and more than $2 billion, the space shuttle has been completely rebuilt in a process involving hundreds of changes to key systems and support gear. Experts say they believe the winged spaceship is safer than ever and nearly ready to fly, but they note that the multitude of design changes, never before tested in flight, introduce new risks of their own.

title: Lendl Survives In 5th Set
description: Ivan Lendl may never win Wimbledon, but he will have at least earned the respect and admiration of people here for his capacity to survive. Time and time again, he has been taken to the limit on the grass courts that are like hot coals under his feet, tormented by serve-and-volley specialists or lower-ranked players who sense his vulnerability and play the match of their lives.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Braniff Leader Hopes To Restore Profitability
description: LEAD: Less than a year after being appointed chairman and chief executive of Piedmont Aviation Inc. William G. McGee has accepted the top position at Braniff Inc., the struggling airline in which a New York-based investment group bought a controlling interest over the weekend.

title: Stride Rite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Irving Paparo, Maker Of Women's Slacks, 64
description: Irving Paparo, a retired clothing manufacturer, died of cancer of the liver Saturday at his home in Mahopac Falls, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Chess
description: Double-round competitions with a small number of participants seem to be increasing in popularity, maybe because they save on playing fees and expenses. Anyhow, this was the system adopted for the Trnava 750 International Tournament held to celebrate the 750th birthday of the Czechoslovakian city.

title: Wind Helps Lewis to 9.95
description: Carl Lewis overcame a slow start and won the 100-meter dash in a wind-aided 9.95 seconds tonight in the Paris international track and field meet.

title: Crash Just the Latest Of Airbus's Troubles
description: Even before Sunday's crash in eastern France of one of its A320 jetliners, Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium, was having serious problems.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Juilliard Library Gets New Preservation Grant
description: The Lila Acheson Wallace Library of the Juilliard School has received a second consecutive New York State Discretionary Grant for conservation and preservation of library research materials.

title: Heart Association To Endorse Some Foods
description: The American Heart Association has decided to identify and endorse processed foods that meet its dietary guidelines, mainly for salt, cholesterol and fat content. Items bearing the group's ''heart healthy'' seal of approval are expected to reach shelves within a year.

title: A Voice of the Uprising Offers to Talk
description: The Palestinian uprising's underground leadership is again offering the Israeli Government a list of suggested ways to end nearly seven months of violence, a Palestinian close to the leadership said today.

title: Fed Is Said To Act Amid Dollar Rally
description: The dollar continued its rally yesterday before retreating slightly in the face of reports of Federal Reserve intervention and some profit taking.

title: Brawley Figure Held on Tapes Is Ordered Freed
description: Samuel M. McClease, who was arrested Friday after he gave blank tapes to a Federal grand jury in the Tawana Brawley case, won a court order for his release yesterday, but the order was held up until today to permit the Government to appeal.

title: A 'Porgy' for Jazz Band
description: Although ''Porgy and Bess'' is not a jazz opera and none of the songs that George Gershwin composed for it have become as firmly entrenched in the jazz repertory as such Gershwin tunes as ''I Got Rhythm'' or ''Oh, Lady Be Good,'' there have been several attempts at jazz versions of the score of ''Porgy.''

title: A Parley of Tapping Feet
description: Honi Coles, himself a distinguished tap dancer, called Sunday night's program at Avery Fisher Hall a tap dancers' summit meeting. That it was. ''An Evening of Tap'' brought together seven formidable powers of the tap dancing world. But unlike some political summits, this was a gathering at which joy prevailed.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Assails Mexico For Releasing Militant
description: The State Department today expressed outrage at the decision by Mexico to release a Puerto Rican nationalist wanted by the United States for terrorist activities.

title: Head of Seabrook Utility Sees Way to Raise Rates
description: The president of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire said today that bankruptcy would allow his company to escape state regulation and have its rates controlled by the Federal Government instead. Such a move might enable Public Service to raise rates by 45 percent to help pay for the Seabrook nuclear power plant, whether or not it ever operates, he said.

title: Editor of Weekly Indicted For Libel in S. Carolina
description: The editor of a small weekly paper who wrote that two local politicians were involved in ''corrupt dealings'' was indicted today on charges of criminal libel.

title: Canada Seeks an End To Feud With Soviets
description: Canada took steps today to end a two-week-long dispute over spying with the Soviet Union in which the two nations have expelled or barred a total of 32 diplomats from the missions that each country maintains in the other.

title: Donald Driver, Writer for Stage, Screen and Television, Dies at 65
description: Donald Driver, a Broadway writer and director, died of AIDS yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65 years old.

title: Reviews/Theater; Marathon of One-Acts
description: In Romulus Linney's one-act play, ''Juliet,'' a saturnine young director, fresh from a success staging ''Romeo and Juliet,'' is given the opportunity to do Ibsen's ''Ghosts.'' Fascinated by the drama, he is eager to preserve its integrity, to present it - in his producer's words - ''as written.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. After seeing the movie ''The Gods Must Be Crazy,'' I've been dying to know if rhinos really do stamp out fires.

title: High Court Gives Police More Leeway in Searches
description: The Supreme Court today made it easier for the police to use in criminal prosecutions evidence that they initially saw in an illegal search and then later seized after obtaining a search warrant.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Education page last Wednesday about student government elections at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst misidentified a student and his position. He is Jason Rabinowitz; he was elected student government co-president, with Shari Silkoff.

title: S.E.C. Seeks Market Bill
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today formally sent Congress its proposed legislation to reform the nation's financial markets.

title: Potential AIDS Drug May Help Fight a Form of Leukemia
description: AN experimental drug that is being developed as a possible treatment for AIDS is unexpectedly showing promise as a treatment for a common, devastating form of leukemia.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court gave military and other contractors broad immunity against liability for deaths and injuries caused by negligently designed equipment. The 5-to-4 decision was a major victory for contractors. Three dissenters accused the majority of ''absolving multibillion-dollar private enterprises from answering for their tragic mistakes.'' [ Page A1. ] Excerpts from the opinions. [ A20. ] The Senate defeated the last major Republican effort to derail a bill that would force companies to give advance notice of factory closings or large-scale layoffs. [ D1. ] The Pentagon would not necessarily wait for convictions in the current Federal investigation of procurement fraud before taking steps against contractors, Defense Secretary Carlucci said. [ A21. ] A Minnesota judge ordered an out-of-state company to return to Minnesota equipment that it purchased with the proceeds of tax-exempt bonds issued by the city of Duluth. [ D5. ] MARKETS The S.E.C. accused a 24-year-old junior analyst at Morgan Stanley of selling information on corporate takeovers. The activity produced profits of more than $19 million, the S.E.C. said. [ A1. ] Prices of grains, soybeans, oilseed products and cotton soared to their allowable limits as the drought continued and severe wind damage was reported. [ D1. ] The dollar continued its rally, reaching highs before retreating amid reports of Federal Reserve intervention. [ D1. ] Stock prices fell across a broad front and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 34.50 points, to 2,108.46. Fears of inflation fueled the decline, market participants said. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved lower in light trading, pushed by sell orders from Japanese investors and a sharp increase in commodity prices. [ D19. ] COMPANIES Carnation will introduce an infant formula that it says relieves milk allergy symptoms in babies. The product is based on whey, which is treated with enzymes to ''pre-digest'' it. [ D1. ] Fort Howard's board agreed to a management-led buyout of the paper products company for $53 a share, or $3.57 billion. Some analysts said they expected a higher offer to emerge. [ D1. ] I.B.M. will offer transfers to at least 1,000 workers, and perhaps many more, as part of cost-cutting. [ D5. ] Pacific Gas and Electric will take a $500 million write-off under a proposed agreement on the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant. [ D2. ] Public Service of New Hampshire could switch from state to Federal regulation, its president said. [ D2. ] Allegheny International retained control of its board in a proxy fight with dissident shareholders, preliminary results showed. [ D7. ] Citicorp bankers are studying First Republicbank, a spokesman for the Texas banking company said. [ D5. ] Name-calling and bickering marked a Bankruptcy Court hearing on $50 million in fees for work on Texaco's bankruptcy. [ 38. ] York International agreed to be acquired by Citicorp for $57.50 a share, a total of about $750 million. [ D5. ] AM International will sell Harris Graphics Web Press Group to Komori Printing Machinery for about $250 million. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Leaders of the European Community gathered to discuss how to proceed toward dropping all trade barriers by 1992. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Many hospitals have seen their credit ratings reduced, which only adds to their costs. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Several savings industry stocks continue to offer good value, according to some industry experts. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 22 about an auction of celebrity items carried an incorrect description, provided by auction officials, for bidding on a pair of ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' A telephone bidder dropped out toward the end; the last bidder to drop out was present at the auction. The article also misstated the size of the slippers; they were 6B.

title: INSIDE
description: Plot Against Pope Reported As Pope John Paul II ended his Austrian tour, a news report said a new plot by Turkish extremists to assassinate the Pope had been foiled in Vienna. Page A6. Strike Ends in Soviet Union On the eve of a national Communist Party conference, residents of a disputed southern Soviet region ended a monthlong general strike. Page A13. Knicks Trade Cartwright The Knicks traded Bill Cartwright to the Chicago Bulls for Charles Oakley, who led the National Basketball Association in rebounds. Page B7. Criminal Libel Charged A South Carolina weekly newspaper editor who accused local politicians of involvement in ''corrupt dealings'' was indicted on a rare charge of criminal libel. Page C19. Relief for Infant Allergies Carnation will market a formula for babies allergic to milk. The formula uses whey, a component of milk, that has been treated with enzymes to ''predigest'' it. Page D1.

title: Stein, Once Politics' Bad Boy, Is Putting on a New Face
description: It used to be, well, different to talk to Andrew J. Stein. Other politicians would bob, weave and obfuscate about their ambitions, but not Andrew Stein. What's wrong with being ambitious, he used to say. Or, sure, I want to President - why not? Or, yes, I may run for governor or for senator or for whatever, whenever.

title: Blacks and Whites, in a Survey, Are Critical of Brawley Advisers
description: New Yorkers - an overwhelming share of whites and a solid majority of blacks - say Tawana Brawley's mother and advisers have not handled her case responsibly and that the advisers are using it ''for their own personal advantage,'' according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: Careers; Less M.B.A. Interest in Wall St. Seen
description: IT was predictable that there would be less interest in Wall Street-type jobs, especially in investment banking, among members of the class of 1988 at major graduate schools of business. And recent reports bear this out.

title: Boeing and Aloha Line Clash Over Maintenance
description: The Boeing Company and Aloha Airlines sharply disagreed over maintenance of the airline's older jets before one of them was ripped open on a flight in Hawaii in April, according to documents released by the Government today.

title: Tests for Drugs Prompt Dispute In Justice Dept.
description: As the Justice Department warned employees today that they could face random drug testing later this summer, a group of senior department employees announced that they would file a lawsuit to block the testing.

title: Strategic Planning Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Drought Threatens Duck Species As Their Nesting Areas Dry Up
description: DROUGHT has dried up many prairie wetlands in the western United States and Canada, placing severe new strains on many species of ducks and other waterfowl.

title: Plan to Evict Drug Dealers Should Help in the Fight on Crack; Issue Warrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Importer Pleads Guilty In Tainted Cheese Plot
