description: A millionaire businessman pleaded guilty in Federal court today to charges that he illegally imported Romanian cheese contaminated with a cancer-causing pesticide.

title: Vote Fraud Charges Fill Mexican Air
description: With presidential and congressional elections here nine days away, opposition parties and civic groups say there are signs that the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party is preparing to rig the vote.

title: Soviets to Play N.H.L.
description: Two top teams from the Soviet Union will play 14 games against National Hockey League teams next season.

title: Interco Incorporated reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Trains Collide at Paris Depot; 21 Are Killed and 32 Injured
description: A commuter train that had apparently suffered a brake failure slammed head-on into a stationary train Monday at an underground platform in the Gare de Lyon in eastern Paris, killing at least 21 people and injuring 32, fire officials said today.

title: New Superconductor
description: Researchers in New Mexico say they have succeeded in creating the first multi-crystal film for conducting electrical current without resistance that shows potential for practical use.

title: Reviews/Theater; Puppetry and Dreams In 'Sand' at 92d St. Y
description: There's a lot of sand in ''Sand,'' the intriguing, often lovely display of the magic of puppetry at the 92d Steet Y. It streams down silently like a shaft of light; it showers down; it cascades down on the blanket that serves as the set for the tiny puppet stage. Perhaps there's a bit too much of it. After an hour or so the effect diminishes, and you begin to think how scratchy life must be getting for the people trying to sleep under that blanket.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report yesterday in some editions of SportsMonday about the national fencing championships omitted the winner and second-place finisher in the men's foil competition. They were Gregory Massialas of San Francisco and Michael Marx of Portland.

title: Pilot Error Is Blamed in Airbus Crash
description: Several Government officials investigating the crash of an Airbus A320 in eastern France said today that the pilot was flying dangerously low in demonstrating the new plane before an air show. They said there was currently no evidence that the plane had malfunctioned.

title: P.L.O. AIDE'S PLAN HAS U.S. INTRIGUED
description: Reagan Administration officials say proposals put forward by a close aide to Yasir Arafat for negotiations with Israel represent a softening of the P.L.O.'s line, but lack authoritative support from the group's leadership.

title: Agency Sells Tokyo Offices
description: Britain's WPP Group has sold the J. Walter Thompson Company's office building in Tokyo to the Nippon Life Insurance Company for $205 million, John Symonds, WPP chairman, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting in London. Thompson will stay in the building under a leasing arrangement.

title: Cricket Frogs' Vocal Dialect May Hold an Evolution Clue
description: RESEARCHERS from the University of Texas have found that two geographically close populations of cricket frogs ''speak'' different ''dialects'' when making mating calls.

title: Our Towns; Foster Families Feel the Anguish Of a Girl's Death
description: Baby Tess Maye was born prematurely. Her grandmother believes it was because the baby's father beat the baby's mother during pregnancy.

title: Computer for a Novice
description: IT has often been said that the ideal computer would be like any other home appliance: a toaster, say, or a television set. You would plug it in, turn it on and use it, with nary a glance at the manual. The Headstart by Vendex is not quite that simple, but it comes about as close as a PC can.

title: Jackson Tours Trump Plaza
description: Donald L. Trump led the Rev. Jesse Jackson through the the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino tonight before attending the world's heavyweight championship fight here. The Secret Service, which is guarding Mr. Jackson, had arranged a back entrance into the convention center, where the fight was held. But Mr. Trump grabbed Mr. Jackson at a pre-fight party and gave him the tour. Dozens of onlookers stumbled over one another, and the weight of the entourage caused an escalator to jam, sending Mr. Jackson and the others sliding forward.

title: Crucial Component
description: Some of the greatest care and attention in overhauling the space shuttle has been devoted to redesigning the solid-fuel booster rocket, whose leaky joint touched off the Challenger disaster in January 1986.

title: Yale vs. Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Increased Treatment For Addicts Is Urged
description: The nation is losing the war on drugs by concentrating on catching traffickers rather treating abusers, according to a new report by the board of trustees of the American Medical Association.

title: Lotus Minard to Get S. C. Johnson Billings
description: Lotus Minard Patton McIver, the ad agency staffed for most part by women, has won at least $3 million in additional billings from the S. C. Johnson Company.

title: Investors Acquire 5.89% EDO Stake
description: A investors group led by the National Patent Development Corporation said it had acquired a 5.89 percent stake in the EDO Corporation and might seek control of the electronics manufacturer. The group bought its 351,600 EDO shares for $14.36 a share. EDO's shares jumped $3 today, or 20.7 percent, to $17.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Report by AIDS Panel Gets Muted Reaction by Reagan
description: President Reagan today received the final report of his AIDS commission with praise for its work but without commenting on its call for an executive order or new Federal laws to prevent discrimination against individuals who carry the AIDS virus.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Scuttle Diplomacy
description: Senator Jesse Helms is apparently still waging his war of attrition against the State Department, particularly against the career Foreign Service. The latest maneuver by the North Carolina Republican, according to other members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is aimed against Harry E. Bergold, President Reagan's nominee as Ambassador to Morocco.

title: Ransburg Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3,449,000 for the quarter and $5,406,000 for the 6 months; tax benefits of $187,000 and $269,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Tracy-Locke to Handle Dial's New Products
description: Tracy-Locke, Dallas, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group, has gotten a new job from the Dial Corporation, for which it began doing new product work earlier this year. It has been appointed agency of record for all of Dial's spot TV and spot radio buying for consumer products.

title: Redken Bid Lifted
description: The RLI Acquisition Corporation said it had raised its offer for Redken Laboratories Inc. of Canoga Park, Calif., by 2.3 percent, to $34.90 a share, to settle shareholder lawsuits. RLI was formed by Redken's the company's founder, Paula Kent Meehan, and her husband, John E. Meehan, to take the hair-care products company private. The Meehans want to buy the 52 percent, or 1.4 million shares, of Redken they do not already own for about $48.9 million.

title: U.S. Says Afghan Insurgents Have Captured Strategic City
description: State Department officials today reported heavy fighting in Afghanistan and said the guerrillas there had apparently captured a second provincial capital.

title: Carlucci Hints Pentagon May Act On Suppliers Before Convictions
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that the Pentagon would not necessarily wait for convictions in the current Federal investigation of procurement fraud before taking steps against contractors who are accused of wrongdoing.

title: Pianistic Pyrotechnics From 1 Hand
description: Billy Taylor opened his solo piano performance in Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon playing ''Gone With the Wind'' with his left hand alone. And he closed his program an hour later playing ''All The Things You Are'' with his left hand alone.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Valvano has resigned as men's basketball coach at St. Francis of Brooklyn. Valvano has accepted a job as head coach of Alvik, a team in Sweden's top division, a college spokesman said. In four years at St. Francis, Valvano coached the Terriers to a 38-74 record, including 11-18 this past season.

title: Irving Suitor Wins Ruling
description: Winning one battle in its long war aimed at acquiring the Irving Bank Corporation, the Bank of New York said yesterday that a New York State court had ruled that a simple majority vote of Bank of New York shareholders was sufficient to authorize the issuance of stock.

title: Probing the Enigma of Multiple Personality
description: WHEN Timmy drinks orange juice he has no problem. But Timmy is just one of close to a dozen personalities who alternate control over a patient with multiple personality disorder. And if those other personalities drink orange juice, the result is a case of hives.

title: A Decade of Defiance in Yonkers
description: The Supreme Court refuses to second-guess two lower court rulings that Yonkers, N.Y., deliberately promoted racial segregation in housing and education for nearly 40 years. While fighting the rulings, Yonkers officials have made progress in desegregating schools but made none on housing. With their legal responsibilities now settled, they can provide the nation with a model for low-income housing, equitably administered.

title: Review/Dance; Paris Opera Ballet Shows Off Its Students
description: Let's say it straight out. History will record the United States debut of the Paris Opera Ballet School this past weekend as one of New York's most memorable cultural events.

title: Integrators Chief Offers a Buyout
description: James Lennane, chairman and chief executive of Systems Integrators Inc., offered $7.25 a share, or about $47.1 million, to acquire all of the company's common stock not owned by him or his family. System Integrators' stock jumped $1.50 today, or 22.9 percent, to $7.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The gain was the largest in percentage terms for the day.

title: Prosecutor in Pentagon Case: Quiet 'Bulldog' and Moralist
description: In a professional lifetime in law enforcement, Henry E. Hudson has never lived or worked more than a few miles from the Pentagon.

title: NICARAGUAN TRUCE BEGINNING TO FRAY
description: Although this part of northern Nicaragua is still at relative peace, sporadic gunfights have broken out between contra and Sandinista Government patrols in recent days, and residents fear the three-month-old cease-fire may be falling apart.

title: JUSTICES, 5-4, GIVE U.S. CONTRACTORS LIABILITY IMMUNITY
description: The Supreme Court, by 5 to 4, voted today to give military and other Government contractors broad immunity against liability for deaths and injuries to service members and others caused by negligently designed equipment, ranging from fighter aircraft to mail trucks.

title: Albert Johnston, 87, Focus of Film on Race
description: Dr. Albert C. Johnston, a black radiologist who passed as a white in the 1930's and was the subject of a film ''Lost Boundaries,'' died Thursday at Castle Medical Center, Honolulu, where he was being treated for chest congestion, according to his son, Albert C. Johnston Jr. Dr. Johnston was 87 years old.

title: 3 Philippine Soldiers Freed
description: Communist rebels freed three soldiers from 54 days of captivity today, saying a ''people's court'' had cleared them of ''crimes against the people.'' A human rights lawyer who witnessed the release in a remote mountain village near the town of Sipalay, about 400 miles south of Manila, said it was the first time rebels had freed captured soldiers since President Corazon C. Aquino took office in 1986.

title: Electronic Mail Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain from a recapitalization of $1,393,764. The company said losses for the quarter were affected by more than $500,000 in one-time charges associated with its continued restructuring program.

title: STUDY FINDS SHIFT IN G.O.P. SUPPORT
description: Vice President Bush is lagging behind President Reagan's 1984 showing in virtually all groups, but he is faring particularly badly among disaffected, financially pressed voters who embraced the President four years ago, according to a study released today.

title: Pope Leaves Austria; Death Plot Is Reported
description: As Pope John Paul II ended his Austrian tour today with warm thanks to President Kurt Waldheim, a news report said a new plot by Turkish extremists to assassinate the Pope had been foiled in Vienna.

title: Chunk of Stone Falls From Trinity Church
description: From the tall tower of Trinity Church, that otherwise imperturbable symbol of faith at the foot of Wall Street, a five-pound chunk of stone has fallen mysteriously, prompting parish authorities to close the south churchyard and to erect a protective shed at the building's base.

title: Super Rite Foods reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Republican Alternative Bill On Plant Closings Defeated
description: The Senate today defeated the last major Republican effort to derail a a bill that would force companies to give advance notice of factory closings or large-scale layoffs.

title: Nunn Says He Will Not Give Vice-Presidential Information
description: Senator Sam Nunn said today that he would not provide background information that the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the probable Democratic Presidential nominee, was seeking from prospective running mates.

title: Review/Music; Insurance Fantasy in Staged Works
description: Golden Fleece Ltd., a chamber theater group that devotes itself to new and predominantly American music, presented the first staged performances of four modest and eclectic but decidedly agreeable works in a recent run at the Sanford Meisner Theater.

title: Readicare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Surrogate Parenthood Banned
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard today signed a bill making Michigan the first state to outlaw commercial contracts for women to bear children for others.

title: NO SOVIET OFFERS, SOLZHENITSYN SAYS
description: Soviet officials have not approached Alexander Solzhenitsyn about publishing any of his works in his native country, despite reports from Moscow that negotiations are under way to publish the novel ''Cancer Ward,'' the author's wife, Natalya, said today.

title: Jazz Festival; Ellington and the Symphony Orchestra
description: Duke Ellington's greatest works were written for the Duke Ellington Orchestra, his piquantly balanced band of hand-picked soloists. But a different kind of orchestra - the symphonic one - still reigns as America's symbol of musical seriousness and legitimacy, and on occasion Ellington addressed himself to that more balky, less swinging ensemble. Maurice Peress, who worked with Ellington and has recently been reconstructing Ellington's legacy, led the American Composers Orchestra in an all-Ellington concert on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. Some pieces were patchworks of European and American music, but in ''Harlem,'' commissioned by the NBC Symphony under Toscanini in 1950, Ellington made the symphony triumphantly his own.

title: Crop Prices Advance by Daily Limit
description: Prices of all grains, soybeans, oilseed products and cotton soared to their allowable limits yesterday as the weekend brought no relief to the nation's drought-seared croplands.

title: Garrison Confident In Topping Sabatini
description: If the members of the All England Club could be persuaded to change the surface from grass to clay, then perhaps Wimbledon would have the tennis queen it pines for in Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina. Photographs of Sabatini are featured in the British tabloids almost every day, and even the more serious newspapers speculate about such compelling matters as whether she is more attractive than smart.

title: A Motto For Americans
description: There is a little sign American shopkeepers often tack on their walls. It would make a superb motto for the United States in its dealings with Mikhail Gorbachev over the next couple of years.

title: Seize the Moment
description: The United States is confronting a new but perhaps final ''moment of opportunity'' to meet the Soviet Union halfway in putting an end to an arms race and a cold war that hamper the security and prosperity of both.

title: ICN Biomedicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $247,000 and an accounting change for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a $168,000 gain for an extraordinary item and an accounting change. Results for the year-ago 6 months have been restated to reflect the adoption of FAS No. 96 relating to income taxes.

title: The Arts Festival; Dance Theater Bases Work on John Henry Legend
description: John Henry was that legendary steel-driving man whose feats of strength are celebrated in folk tales and ballads. He is now the hero of a new Arthur Mitchell ballet, which will be performed by the Dance Theater of Harlem in a one-week season that opens tonight. John Henry's feats might also be symbolic of the company, which, founded by Mr. Mitchell just 19 years ago, has just returned from a successful tour of the Soviet Union.

title: Garden Is a Big Draw for Closed Circuit
description: A crowd of about 18,000 turned out at Madison Square Garden last night to watch the closed-circuit telecast of the Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks fight.

title: By Design; Creatively Cool
description: Everybody is familiar with the suggestions for dressing in blistering weather. Most of them make sense. For example, nothing looks as chic and beats the heat as well as a simple chemise dress in a crisp fabric worn with hair slicked back in a chignon.

title: Hambletonian to Stay
description: Brooklyn lost the Dodgers, Baltimore lost the Colts and now it seems DuQuoin, Ill., has lost the Hambletonian.

title: Spinks Didn't Fight According to Plan
description: For weeks, the trainer Eddie Futch had told Michael Spinks to box and move in the early rounds against Mike Tyson, but tonight Spinks tried to ''get respect'' from the undisputed heavyweight champion. And that preference resulted in Spinks being knocked out after only 91 seconds of the first round.

title: New Shuttle Is Readied for Launching Pad
description: Completely rebuilt with hundreds of changes to im-prove performance and safety, the space shuttle Discovery is nearly ready to be rolled to the launching pad for the first shuttle mission since the Challenger disaster more than two years ago.

title: A Chamber Orchestra From Sweden
description: The New Stockholm Chamber Orchestra, a seven-year-old ensemble with a luxurious string sound, made its United States debut at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon with an American conductor, Gilbert Levine, on its podium. The Swedish soprano Elisabeth Soderstrom was its soloist and principal box-office draw.

title: Nordiques Fill Slot
description: The Quebec Nordiques yesterday named Martin Madden as their general manager and appointed Jean Perron, who left the Montreal Canadiens' coaching job last month, as Madden's assistant.

title: The Arts Festival; How a Dublin Actor Metamorphoses Into Cringing, Drooling, Evil Joxer
description: When first confronted with the spectacle of Joxer Daly, one scarcely knows whether to laugh, to weep or to shrink back in horror. Of indeterminate age and indescribable filthiness, he shambles onstage with the rolling, unsteady gait of the perpetual drunk, his clothes so tattered they look as if they had been chewed by starving animals. His rotten teeth habitually bared in an ingratiating grin, Joxer cringes like a beaten cur, feigning abject obeisance while furtively scanning his surroundings, always alert for a crust of bread or a bottle of stout to steal when no one is looking.

title: CUNY Names New Leaders Of 2 Colleges
description: A veteran administrator of the City University system was chosen yesterday to become president of Hunter College, one of the most academically prestigious branches of the City University of New York. And in a second, surprising appointment, a Harvard scholar and internationally known explorer was named the new president of Medgar Evers College, a small and troubled community college in central Brooklyn.

title: At Sea Vent 8,000 Feet Deep, One Fish Didn't Get Away
description: FISHING in some of the strangest waters on earth, where cracks in the ocean floor vent hot, mineral-rich water, marine biologists have landed such bizarre specimens as giant clams and crabs and tube worms six feet long. The creatures thrive in a dark environment where chemicals leeching into the seawater support a whole chain of living organisms that get along without sunlight.

title: SmithKline Sets Distribution Deal
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said it had agreed to be the overseas distributor for the human-growth hormone developed by the Bio-Technology General Corporation, a genetic-engineering concern. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Beckman has been trying to develop new sources of revenue by 1994, when its patent expires on Tagamet, an ulcer-treatment drug with annual sales of $1 billion. The company said in May that it had agreed to invest $49 million in the Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation, a small drug-research company that is working on a new cold remedy and other drugs, including potential treatments for diseases of the central nervous system.

title: Hits Missing, and It Shows
description: Are the Mets losing their grip? Could be. At least, they lost for the fourth time in five games tonight when Mike Dunne outdueled Dwight Gooden and pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 2-1 victory that chopped the Mets' dwindling lead to three and a half games.

title: Key Sections of Gorbachev Speech Given to Party Conference
description: Following are key sections of the speech Mikhail S. Gorbachev delivered yesterday in Moscow, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans to raise a sunken Civil War vessel off the Normandy coast referred to the ship incorrectly. It was a Confederate Navy warship, not a privateer; privateers were privately owned and operated vessels that preyed upon enemy commerce.

title: Aparicio Mendez, 84, Uruguay Ex-President
description: Former President Aparicio Mendez, who served for five years as the figurehead chief of state when Uruguay was ruled by the armed forces in the late 1970's and early 1980's, died Sunday after a long illness, officials said. He was 84 years old.

title: Aetna Life Announces Management Changes
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, one of the nation's major insurers, announced the promotion yesterday of Ronald E. Compton to president and the retirement of William O. Bailey as vice chairman.

title: Books of The Times; Something Rotten (Even Satanic) in the Breadbasket
description: M31 A Family Romance By Stephen Wright 214 pages. Harmony Books. $17.95.

title: Inaccuracies in Wang's Resume
description: Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., the 24-year-old Morgan Stanley analyst accused of participating in an insider trading scheme that the Securities and Exchange Commission says earned $19 million in illegal profits, provided inaccurate details about his background in a resume circulated on Wall Street last year.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Official Denies Charges In Iran-Contra Conspiracy Case
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's former Costa Rican station chief pleaded not guilty today to five charges in the Iran-contra case. His lawyer said his client had merely been following United States policies.

title: Congress Kills District Police Residency Rule
description: The House killed a residency requirement for District of Columbia police officers today, reflecting Congressional concern that the rule was hurting recruiting while the crime rate went up.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bargains in Beef The Nevada Market has been one of the best butchers on the West Side since 1948, changing only its address (from Columbus Avenue and 68th Street to Broadway and 68th Street in 1960), not its high standards. Now, to celebrate its 40th year in business, Fred and Mark Oppenheimer, the owners, are holding a sale.

title: Shuttle Flight Delayed Again
description: The space agency said today that it was delaying the first space shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster until Sept. 4 because preparation of the shuttle Discovery was taking longer than expected.

title: Exploring Nuts and Bolts of Rhythm
description: No unit in jazz is more fundamental than the basic piano trio. Not only does the format allow the essential musical elements of rhythm, melody and harmony to be shuffled and balanced into an endless variety of combinations, it also permits exploration of extremes of improvisatory boldness and formality sometimes within the same composition.

title: Big Band Gathers for Boxing and the Blues
description: While celebrities were convening to watch the Tyson-Spinks bout in Atlantic City on Monday night, local jazz royalty were convening to watch the fight at Irving Plaza, and to play. The music was more satisfying, as decisive, and lasted a lot longer than the fight.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PALESTINIAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Drug Used in Treating Gout Found Effective for Cirrhosis
description: A drug used for centuries to treat gout promises to be the first to effectively slow the damage of cirrhosis of the liver, according to a new study. Cirrhosis is a major hazard of alcoholism, viral infections and poisonings and a leading cause of death throughout the world.

title: EATING WELL
description: THAT slippery, shiny coating on the fruits and vegetables in your supermarket or corner produce store is not achieved by polishing the items with a cloth. The sparkle comes from a can of wax.

title: Midtown Drug Sweep Results in 63 Arrests
description: More than 100 narcotics officers arrested 63 people in a 14-hour drug sweep yesterday in the area west of Times Square, the police said.

title: Investor in Insider Case Is Described as Honest
description: Fred C. Lee, the investor who is accused of making more than $19 million by trading on inside information, has been described by business associates as an honest, affable, exceedingly well-connected man who jetted between homes in Taiwan, Hong Kong and the United States.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Libel Trials Help Keep The Press on a Leash
description: To the Editor:

title: Extension for Bass On Financial Corp.
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it has extended to Aug. 1 the deadline for the Robert M. Bass Group to complete negotiations about the possible acquisition of the Financial Corporation of America's thrift industry unit, American Savings and Loan Association.

title: VCS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain from extraordinary items of $103,963.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday incorrectly characterized the end of the relationship between the Sony Communications Products Company and Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein. The agency resigned the business.

title: For Dinner, No Exceptions: Jacket and Tie Are Required
description: ONE well-known newspaper gossip columnist was famous for the line she used after she exposed a particularly juicy morsel in her syndicated column, ''Ear.'' ''Where,'' she would intone, tongue firmly planted in cheek, ''are standards?''

title: American General
description: The American General Corporation offered $200 million of 9 5/8 percent 12-year bonds at par yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The insurance holding company's issue is noncallable. It yields about seven-tenths percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity and is rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: Judge Declares 2d Mistrial In Larry Davis Case in Bronx
description: In another bizarre twist in the latest trial of Larry Davis, the judge declared a mistrial yesterday at the request of the defense and the prosecution after a dispute over the removal of the only white juror.

title: Tab Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Judicial Activism, Reagan-Style
description: In granting Government contractors broad protection from lawsuits for badly designed products, the Supreme Court hands private industry a prize it couldn't get from Congress. The ruling traduces traditionalists' distaste for judicial activism while trespassing on the rights of states to set rules of liability.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
St. Paul
description: LEAD: ONE of St. Paul's favorite spots for Sunday brunch and weekday lunch isn't listed under ''Restaurants'' in the Yellow Pages. Tucked away on the top floor of the Jemne Building, a small Art Deco jewel that houses part of the Minnesota Museum of Art, is the Deco Restaurant.

title: Rev. John F. McConnell, Priest, 79
description: The Rev. John Francis McConnell, a Roman Catholic biblical scholar and a Maryknoll priest, died of heart failure on June 19 at the Maryknoll residence in Los Altos, Calif. He was 79 years old.

title: Sports People; Allison Is Improving
description: Thanking thousands of supporters for their cards and prayers, Judy Allison says her husband, the stock-car racer Bobby Allison, is steadily recovering from injuries suffered June 19 at Pocono International Raceway.

title: Dollar-Yen Exchange Rate To Affect Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association tapped the debt market yesterday with a $110 million issue of 10.95 percent, five-year fixed-rate notes, which are tied to the exchange rate between the American dollar and the Japanese yen, through Morgan Stanley & Company. Sallie Mae, a federally chartered, stockholder-owned corporation, is the main financial intermediary serving the education credit market.

title: Golf; Byrnes Captures The Ike
description: Robert Byrnes, a 21-year-old senior at Elon College in North Carolina, shot a five-under-par 68 in the second of two 18-hole rounds today and captured the Ike Championship golf tournament by a stroke.

title: In Thatcher's Britain, Affluence Breeds Hostility
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Victories for Myricks and Kingdom: Larry Myricks won the long jump and Roger Kingdom took the 110-meter hurdles yesterday as the United States dominated an international track and field meet that inaugurated Chapin Stadium in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain. Myricks leaped 26 feet 11 3/4 inches to beat Bruny Surin of Canada, who jumped 26-1 3/4. Kingdom won in 13.20 seconds. In the women's 100-meter run, Nelly Cooman of the Netherlands defeated Evelyn Ashford, the world-record holder. Cooman won in 11.30. Ashford's time was 11.31.(AP) Yachting New Sweden Wins Again: New Sweden made up a deficit of 4 minutes 30 seconds yesterday to beat Kookaburra III of Australia in the world 12-Meter championships in Lulea, Sweden. New Sweden, the former South Australia, designed by Ben Lexcen, won by 9:56. The Swedish yacht's record is to 4-0 in the round-robin semifinal portion. (AP)

title: Alert Issued for 4 Fugitives
description: A nationwide alert was issued Monday for four prisoners who escaped after overpowering a guard with a homemade knife, officials said today. The four escaped Saturday from the medium-security House of Correction on Saturday.

title: F. Colman Greene, Lawyer, 65
description: F. Colman Greene, a lawyer and an expert in New Jersey municipal law, died of a heart attack Sunday at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Pawling, N.Y.

title: Wimbledon; Connors Falls to Tenacious No. 90
description: The perils of Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl have dominated Wimbledon thus far, relegating the most recent champions, Boris Becker and Pat Cash, to unaccustomed supporting roles. But that will no longer be true after today. Playing on a shredded Court 2, where he thought tennis was more a guessing game than a test of his ability, Connors met his demise at the hands of a hard-serving West German whose name, surprisingly, was not Becker.

title: In Thatcher's Britain, Affluence Breeds Hostility; French Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brawley Figure's Spotty Past
description: Samuel M. McClease, who vaulted to prominence last week by saying he had secret tapes of Tawana Brawley's advisers casting doubt on the black teen-ager's charge of abduction and rape by white men, has a checkered work and military record that has compounded questions about his truthfulness and reliability.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Kenneth E. Caffrey and Keith Bantick have been elected directors of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide.

title: Bonds and Notes Up in Busy Day
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose in brisk trading yesterday, bolstered by falling commodity prices and a firmer dollar on foreign currency markets.

title: 3 in Surrogate's Office Charged With Thefts
description: Three investigators from the Brooklyn and Bronx Public Administrators' offices were arrested yesterday and charged with falsifying public records and stealing valuables from rooms they believed had been occupied by people who died without leaving a will.

title: A.M.A. Opposing Mercy Killing
description: The nation's largest organization of doctors reaffirmed its opposition to mercy killing today but rejected a move to restrict its medical journal from publishing articles about euthanasia.

title: Chicago
description: ARCHITECTURE inspired culinary artistry in Prairie, a Chicago restaurant that opened last January in the Printer's Row area south of the Loop.

title: Signs of Satiation In New York's Appetite For Chic Restaurants
description: LIZ SILVERSTEIN, a 28-year-old New Yorker, keeps up with restaurants the way some people keep up with movies or plays or music. She knows, for instance, that everyone is going to Il Bianco, and that M.K. is a must-see. ''I figure I can sit home when I'm 90,'' she said. ''I want to go out now.''

title: Lennar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Six Plead Guilty In Federal Court In Esposito Case
description: Six people have pleaded guilty to Federal tax crimes, and, as part of their plea agreement, will cooperate in the Government's case against Meade H. Esposito, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Pretoria Says Cuba Downed A Plane to Prevent Defection
description: Cuban forces shot down a Soviet-built plane in Angola, killing a Cuban general and 26 officers, because some of the officers were defecting to South Africa, the Government-run South African television network said today.

title: Mitterrand Picks Ministers
description: President Francois Mitterrand named a new Socialist minority Government today, to be headed by Prime Minister Michel Rocard and to include several political independents. Several prominent figures, including a leading cancer expert and a popular historian, were among the new members of the otherwise largely unchanged administration. The changes follow this month's inconclusive elections, in which the Socialists failed to win a parliamentary majority.

title: Managed, or Mismanaged?
description: IN the other corner, Michael Spinks was perspiring, the sweat glistening on his face above the white towel inside his white satin robe. Across the ring, Mike Tyson, as usual, was not wearing a robe. But as he prowled back and forth waiting for the introductions to end, his face was dry. So were his hunched shoulders and his torso except for a little shiny sweat in the small of his back just above his black trunks. And when Michael Spinks was counted out only 91 seconds after the bell rang, Mike Tyson had hardly sweated any more.

title: Macmillan 'Outraged' by Bank's Bass Aid
description: Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that it was ''suprised and outraged'' at the behavior of the Security Pacific National Bank, which agreed to help finance Macmillan's restructuring, then agreed to act as the lead bank in a syndicate providing financing for a tender offer by the Robert M. Bass Group.

title: Jack Moore, 62, A Choreographer, Dancer and Artist
description: Jack Moore, a founder of Dance Theater Workshop and a dancer, choreographer, teacher and artist, died of lung cancer last Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: After Hall at British National Theater
description: Richard Eyre, who takes over from Sir Peter Hall as director of Britain's National Theater on Sept. 1, managed to sound simultaneously upbeat and somber when he met the press Monday.

title: Despite Cost and Risk, Plastic Surgery Thrives
description: LEAD: THERE was a time when you could never be too rich or too young. Now, it seems, you cannot be too beautiful. Never before have so many people desired flawless features and luminous skin, and been willing to pay so much to have them, despite risks.

title: Article 532688 -- No Title
description: Monet's ''Camille in the Meadow,'' a light-washed painting of the artist's wife from 1876, was sold last night at Sotheby's in London for $24.3 million. The price was the third highest paid at auction for any artwork and four times the previous record price paid at auction for a Monet.

title: Penobscot Shoe Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Christopher J. Carven, Oil Executive, 59
description: Christopher James Carven, an executive of the Exxon Corporation, died of leukemia Saturday at his home on Kiawah Island, S.C. He was 59 years old.

title: U.S. and Soviets Give A-Test Data
description: The United States and the Soviet Union exchanged information today about the size of some of their past nuclear tests, American officials said. It is the first time the Soviet Union has disclosed the size of its nuclear explosions.

title: New Strategic Treaty and New Arms Race; Bipartisan Consensus
description: To the Editor:

title: Flowmole reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $221,000 and $563,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: S.E.C. Said To Broaden Its Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is examining securities trading records at six brokerage firms in its insider trading investigation of an investor from Taiwan and a young Wall Street analyst, people with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Arts Festival Report Card A Mixed One
description: Midway into the third week of its four-week run, the First New York International Festival of the Arts has won a series of highly favorable reviews, with mixed results at the box office.

title: Shultz Begins Latin Trip Today as Policy Is Reviewed
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is to leave Wednesday on a quick trip to Central America as the Reagan Administration reassesses its policy toward Nicaragua.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Memo by Top Official at Pentagon Urged Curbs on Plant Searches
description: The Pentagon's top contracting official, irritated with the ''sensational'' conduct of Federal agents looking for evidence of fraud, last month tried to limit searches of military plants by investigators.

title: Death Toll Now 59 in Paris Train Crash
description: The death toll in a crash at a Paris railroad station rose to 59 today as rescue workers continued to remove bodies from the wreckage. Officials said a brake failure was responsible for the train wreck, the worst ever in Paris.

title: Chung Ping Tom, 69, Leader in Chinatown
description: Chung Ping Tom, a leader of the Chinatown community and a restaurateur and theater owner, died of pneumonia Thursday after surgery at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AMC Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter and year included a $4 million estimated loss on the future disposition of assets.

title: Education
description: Eleanor P. Noel is an 18-year-old junior at Jamaica Plain High School in Boston. R. Arthur Arnold, 41, is from The Hague and is the manager of the Algemene Bank Nederland, in New York.

title: Telecredit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The losses in the latest quarter and year included after-tax costs of $20,783,000 associated with the restructuring of the company's Light Signatures Inc. subsidiary.

title: European Panel to Plan For a Monetary Union
description: Leaders of the European Community agreed today to set up a committee of central-bank presidents and experts to propose concrete steps toward a European monetary union by next year.

title: Murray J. Rossant Is Dead at 65; Journalist Led 20th Century Fund
description: Murray J. Rossant, a veteran journalist who for the last two decades headed the Twentieth Century Fund, a public-policy research foundation, died of stomach cancer yesterday at his Manhattan home. He was 65 years old.

title: San Mateo Journal; Suburb Is Reliving Two 60's Love Stories
description: Twenty years ago, when this affluent suburb adopted an infantry company, Jane Baker was a housewife who made tollhouse cookies for lonely, frightened soldiers in the jungles of Vietnam.

title: U.S. Recalls Mexico Envoy Over Militant's Release
description: The United States has recalled its Ambassador to Mexico to protest Mexico's decision to free a Puerto Rican nationalist wanted by the United States for terrorist activities.

title: Record Handle for OTB
description: The New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation announced yesterday that it had broken the billion-dollar handle mark for the 1988 fiscal year, which ends on Thursday. As of last Sunday, OTB had taken in $1.021 billion, the largest total handle in the corporation's 18-year history.

title: Mets Find Power And Stop Pirates
description: Dave Johnson searched his soul, lectured his troops and revamped his lineup. Darryl Strawberry flew back from New York on no sleep and started swinging. Three guys even took their bats back to the hotel and tucked them into bed for the night, and Kevin Elster took his bat to lunch.

title: Real Estate; Builder Plans L.I. Complex Near Campus
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago great patches of woods existed in Long Island's Suffolk County. One of them was outside the village of Stony Brook, but a lot of things have changed since then. Soon they will change still more as an elaborate complex arises on the region's largest remaining undeveloped commercial tract.

title: International Dairy Queen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Diversified Retail Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Fiscal 1987's net included a gain of $44,242 from the sale of assets. The company said it received a term loan commitment from Sovran Bank N.A. for $950,000 to open new stores and to make an acquisition in the specialty retail field.

title: Sports People; Whalers Sold
description: ''Maybe I've done a favor for all the other owners in the N.H.L., now that we see what the Hartford market is worth,'' Donald G. Conrad, the Whalers' new co-owner, said yesterday in Hartford, where the Whalers were sold for $31 million. The sale, pending the approval of the team's 16 community partners, represents the biggest cash price ever paid for a National Hockey League team.

title: Mexican Party Practices Protests Over Vote Fraud
description: Manuel Clouthier, the presidential candidate of the right-of-center National Action Party, recently warned that his followers would ''paralyze all of Mexico'' if fraud occurred in the voting next week. At a civil disobedience training session here on Saturday, Luis Morfin de la Parra prepared party supporters to do just that.

title: A Call for Change, But . . .
description: Following are some of the proposals included in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech, along with some ideas put forth in public debate leading up to the conference that he did not endorse. Political System: A new ''Congress of Peoples Deputies'' would become the supreme government body, consisting of 1,500 deputies elected by region and 750 picked by Communist Party committees, trade unions, the Young Communists League and other organizations. It would select the national legislature and a president, who would exercise broad government powers. Mr. Gorbachev rejected proposals in the press for direct public election of a president. Local Government: Government councils would be given new power and revenues from taxes on local industry. Local party leaders would be nominated to head the councils, assuring a strong party role. Electoral Changes: The secret ballot and competitive elections would become the norm in selecting party leaders and government officials. Constitutional Commission: The new congress would create a commission with authority to review laws and make sure they are consistent with the Constitution. No such constitutional review now exists. Courts: He called for ''major reform of our courts'' to create greater independence and protect rights of defendants. He hinted that he favored moving toward a jury system, but gave few details. Ethnic Minorities: He said the conference would discuss minority relations. He rejected calls for redrawing boundaries, apparently in answer to the call by Armenians for reunification of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region. He condemned ''regional egoism'' but hinted at support for greater economic independence in republics, as Baltic republics and others have demanded. Alternative Political Groups: Mr. Gorbachev firmly rejected the idea of competing political parties, but he said ''civic organizations,'' including non-Communists groups, should play a more active role in political affairs. He did not specifically support the idea of ''peoples' fronts'' with power to nominate candidates for office and propose laws. Changing Leaders: He rejected a purge of ''dead wood'' in the party and opposed a mandatory retirement age. He supported a limit on terms of office, but the conference must decide if two or three terms will be allowed. History: Mr. Gorbachev strongly defended the critical exploration of Soviet history, but did not, as some had hoped, level sharp new criticism at past leaders. He mentioned Stalin only twice, and Brezhnev not at all. Glasnost: He condemned ''uniformity, monotonous conformity and mediocrity'' in cultural life and said that ''there is no need to fear the novel, unconventional character of some opinions.'' He did not mention letters to the press calling for publishing the party's budget and transcripts of important party meetings. Proposals to televise the conference itself were rejected, except for Mr. Gorbachev's opening and closing remarks. Religion: He renewed his appeal for ''freedom of conscience'' and condemned ''administrative pressure'' on religious believers, but provided no details of forthcoming laws on religion. Individual Rights: He called for laws to protect the ''inviolability'' of the home, telephone calls and the mail. But he did not mention other proposals raised in the press, such as abolishing travel restrictions. Privileges: One of the most popular ideas put forth in the press is abolishing the privileges of party and Government officials, but Mr. Gorbachev did not mention this.

title: Perceptronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $157,800 from a tax benefit for the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: Wimbledon; Navratilova Plays Catch-Up, Briskly
description: This is expected to be just a formality, probably requiring less than an hour of her time. Because of the rain delays the last two days, there is still an opening for one player in the women's semifinals at Wimbledon. Martina Navratilova is expected to fill the position Wednesday.

title: Illinois Gas Utility
description: The Northern Illinois Gas Company, a unit of Nicor Inc., is offering $75 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 1996 at a price of 99.55 to yield 9.331 percent. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets is the lead manager for the offering, priced to yield about 55- hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity. The utility's bonds, noncallable for five years, are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: Bush Backs Protection Of AIDS Victim Rights
description: In contrast to President Reagan, Vice President Bush today quickly endorsed legislation and other Federal measures that would prohibit discrimination against AIDS victims.

title: Pulling of TV Ad Angers Chilean Opposition
description: Despite Government promises of a free electoral environment for a coming plebiscite, an advertisement by a group promoting voter registration has been taken off Chile's leading television network.

title: Review/Film; African Prince in Queens
description: Eddie Murphy's new film has a good title,''Coming to America,'' a possibly funny idea (a black African prince travels incognito to New York to find a wife) and a screenplay that seems to have escaped its doctors before it was entirely well.

title: No-Lose Road Game for White Sox
description: In this city where politics is considered a big-time sport, Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Einhorn are proving themselves major league players.

title: White House Revisited
description: The White House staff is taking on a new complexion in its sunset months as President Reagan's top aides depart to pursue careers outside the Administration and new appointees are named. The latest announcement came yesterday: a new deputy chief of staff.

title: DePaul's Strickland to Knicks
description: Knick fans were euphoric yesterday over what Coach Rick Pitino called a blockbuster trade - the deal Monday night that sent Bill Cartwright to the Chicago Bulls for 24-year-old Charles Oakley. But many fans were puzzled by the team's pick of Rod Strickland, a 6-foot-3-inch point guard from DePaul, in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft at the Felt Forum.

title: Washington Scientific Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 5
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months' results included a restructuring charge of $2,429,000.

title: Good, but Simmered
description: To The Living Section:

title: Motown Sold To MCA
description: Motown Records, the company that introduced some of popular music's biggest stars, including Michael Jackson and Stevie Wonder, has been sold to MCA Inc. and an investment banking firm for $61 million, it was announced today.

title: About New York; A Southerner, Until She Heard The City Crying
description: People drift here for every reason under the sun, but all share one quite obvious thought: No one enters intending to fail. A few even manage not to. Many do, though, and leave a little broken for the experience. Still others stick it out because they were willing to compromise, or serendipity struck happily, or something. June Mann appears to be a case of something. She runs a suicide hot line.

title: New Zealand To Sell Bank
description: The New Zealand Government said today that it would sell its merchant bank to the country's largest pension fund and the Salomon Brothers investment bank of New York for $77 million.

title: New Strategic Treaty and New Arms Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Must Shun Uprising Violence, Rabin Is Told
description: The Reagan Administration told Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin today that Israel should not use violence to quell Palestinian unrest in the occupied territories.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WITH farm markets and produce stands in full bloom, I am always experimenting with new recipes to take advantage of the seasonal bounty. The recipe given here is a variation on pasta primavera, a dish that has countless incarnations, although the classic version calls for a wide assortment of vegetables and a cream-based sauce.

title: 3 INDICTED BY U.S. IN '87 MOB SLAYING
description: Three reputed organized-crime figures in New Jersey were accused today of murder and conspiracy in the gangland-style slaying last August of Irwin Schiff in a Manhattan restaurant.

title: Reviews/Music; The Bach Aria Festival
description: The Bach Aria Group holds a summer residency at the State University Center at Stony Brook, L.I., from which it sets out on a modest tour. The group's 1988 Bach Aria Festival and Institute ended Monday evening with a lively and unconventional performance at Merkin Concert Hall in Manhattan.

title: Oh, the Challenge! The Glory! Barbecue as a Rite of Passage
description: LEAD: IT is little known that after a hard day hammering out the Declaration of Independence, our forefathers forged a lesser-known document, the Declaration of Immolation. This guaranteed that every man, woman and child would have the right to put fire to food.

title: Financing Plan For Public TV
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today approved significant changes in the way Federal money is distributed to public television stations.

title: G.O.P. Officials Say Kean Will Give Keynote Speech
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey, one of the nation's most popular Republican chief executives, will deliver the keynote address at the Republican National Convention, Republican officials said today.

title: A Master of Piano Styles
description: The pianist Jay McShann, who cut a smiling, avuncular figure as he walked out to the piano at Weill Recital Hall on Monday afternoon, is one of jazz's underestimated talents. Not only is he a virtuoso (as his concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, showed), he's also a master of the many different styles that make up the piano tradition in America.

title: The Editorial Notebook; In the Light of 'Urban Blight'
description: The terrain covered by ''Urban Blight,'' a wickedly funny musical revue at the Manhattan Theater Club, far transcends literal rubble-strewn lots and bricked-up brownstones. The revue, of about 30 skits by talented playwrights and songwriters, captures the loneliness and menace of the American city, filled with alienated souls who awkwardly reach out, and only rarely connect.

title: Scherer Investors Employ Salomon
description: Two New York investment firms that hold a combined 13.6 percent stake in the R. P. Scherer Corporation said they have hired Salomon Brothers Inc. as financial adviser about their investment in the pharmaceutical concern based in Troy, Mich.

title: A Move to Drive Out Bad Apples
description: Biting into a crisp apple loses some of its appeal when a mushy bruise is encountered hiding beneath the glistening skin. Bruised apples also fetch less in the marketplace, so agricultural engineers have turned to miniature electronics to find ways to reduce the jostling an apple receives.

title: Spirit of Mingus Revived
description: Charles Mingus's compositions got a rousing workout on Monday at the Kaufman Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y. It was nearly a model for a JVC Jazz Festival repertory concert (although it lacked program notes, or even a program). Jimmy Knepper led an 11-piece band (including a handful of Mingus Jazz Workshop alumni) to revive large-scale Mingus works, including the symphonic-length dance score ''The Black Saint and the Sinner Lady,'' with care and gusto. While the group wasn't as seasoned as a working band - and could not reproduce the deep-bottomed swing of Mingus and his longtime drummer, Dannie Richmond - it captured a good part of Mingus's roistering, bluesy spirit and the tenderness behind it.

title: Book Notes
description: Cheever Legal Wrangle An auction of the paperback rights to ''The Uncollected Short Stories of John Cheever,'' edited by Franklin H. Dennis, is scheduled for today. It is scheduled for hard-cover publication in September by Academy Chicago, and Dell Publishing has offered a $100,000 minimum guarantee for the reprint rights. But the auction has been complicated by last-minute legal maneuvering.

title: PLEA FOR TROTSKY IN A SOVIET PAPER
description: A Soviet newspaper today published a plea for the legal vindication of Leon Trotsky and for the release of the Bolshevik outcast's writings in the Soviet Union.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The Pop Life
description: Mathis Makes Changes ''It may not be easy, but it's fun to try and get into the mainstream of pop music 20 to 30 years after the fact,'' Johnny Mathis said recently in a rare interview. Although ''Once in a While,'' Mr. Mathis's newest Columbia album, will not drive people to tear up dance floors, this collection of ballads, smoothly arranged in a conservative pop-soul style, is decidedly perkier in rhythm than typical Mathis records. Its selections include glossy remakes of several oldies, among them the 1973 Four Tops hit ''Ain't No Woman (Like the One I've Got),'' Little Anthony and the Imperials' 1964 hit ''I'm on the Outside (Looking In),'' and the title song, a 1937 perennial that became a rockand-roll ballad hit for the Chimes in 1960.

title: Autodie Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $758,000. c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 21 about a theory of drugs' effect on the brain misstated the affiliation of Dr. Leon Hollister. He is at the University of Texas Medical School at Houston.

title: Detroit Citizens Join With Church to Rid Community of Drugs
description: In Detroit's humblest neighborhoods, where drug dealers move surreptitiously among as many as 10,000 abandoned houses, almost everyone has lived next to or across from a crack house in recent years.

title: Michigan Primary Advances
description: The Michigan House Elections Committee voted unanimously today to reinstate a Presidential primary in 1992. The bill, calling for advance party registration, now goes to the full House. The last time both major parties participated in an open primary in Michigan was 1976.

title: American Claims Evaluation reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Metro-North Workers Appeal Dismissal After Fatal Crash
description: Four Metro-North Commuter Railroad employees dismissed after they failed drug tests given in the wake of a fatal crash last April are appealing the dismissals, union officials said today.

title: 2 Harvard Professors Get World Order Prize
description: Two political scientists at Harvard University are the first recipients of a prize for ''ideas improving world order.''

title: Clarcor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Wisconsin Toy Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Dow Adds 22.41, to 2,130.87; Trading Slows
description: Stocks rallied yesterday, continuing the roller-coaster pattern of recent days.

title: Economic Scene; Trench Warfare In Lotusland
description: FANTASY-DRENCHED Los Angeles, home to Forest Lawn, 24-hour sushi bars and Cher, seems an unlikely locale for a sobering war of attrition between management and labor. But as the Writers Guild strike against producers of television and feature films enters its 17th week, jokes about the small blessings of the stalemate -empty tables at La Scala, the opportunity to reread Heidegger - are ringing hollow.

title: Bork Battle Revisited
description: The battle over Judge Robert H. Bork's failed nomination to the Supreme Court seems fated never to die, but the latest round has apparently fizzled.

title: Corning Glass Works reports earnings for 12wks to June 19
description: b-Includes a one-time after-tax gain on sale of stock of $19.8 million, or 44 cents a share for the 12 weeks, and tax credits of $1 million for the 12 weeks and $1.3 million for the 24 weeks. c-Includes tax credits of $1 million and $2.2 million for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks, respectively, and the 24 weeks also includes a credit of $14.2 million representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Yesterday's earnings report should have used revenue instead of sales.

title: Single-Parent Homes: The Effect on Schooling
description: The more time that children - especially boys - spend in one-parent homes, the less schooling they are likely to complete, a new study says.

title: Libel Trials Help Keep The Press on a Leash; Hope It Gets Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Hungarians March to Protest Rumanian Plan
description: Tens of thousands of Hungarians marched to the Rumanian Embassy on Monday to protest plans by President Nicolae Ceausescu to destroy more than half of the villages in Rumania, many populated by ethnic Hungarians.

title: Centel Confident of Proxy Victory
description: John P. Frazee Jr. the chairman and chief executive of the Centel Corporation, said today that he thought the company had won a proxy fight with an investor group led by the New York financier Asher B. Edelman.

title: In Bristol, R.I., a Small-Town Fourth in the Yankee Tradition
description: THE Fourth of July Military, Civic and Firemen's Parade is as central to life in this sleepy seaside town as fishing and clam digging; so central, in fact, that Bristol has marked the Fourth in this manner for 203 years, come Monday, without a miss. The parade is considered the oldest Independence Day observance in the United States.

title: Housing Law: A Wooden Sword
description: For all of America's recent progress in breaking down racial barriers, society still stabs daily at the self-respect of black citizens looking for decent, integrated housing. Yes, there has been a Federal Fair Housing Act since 1968, prohibiting discrimination in housing. Yes, it is full of good intentions. But using it is like fighting the devil with a wooden sword.

title: U.S. Military Aide Killed in Athens Car Bombing
description: The United States military attache here was killed by a car bomb today as he drove to work from his suburban home, police and embassy officials reported. A far-leftist group was suspected of having planted the bomb.

title: European Intervention Is Overcome by Dollar
description: The dollar rode out intervention by eight European central banks yesterday, recovering from sharp declines in Tokyo and London to reach a new high against the Japanese yen and reclaim the lost ground against the West German mark.

title: Crop Prices Fall by Limit In Futures Profit Taking
description: Waves of profit taking swamped the soybean, grain and cotton markets yesterday, and prices fell the maximum amounts allowed in a trading session. Yet crops continued to wither under the unrelenting drought that has gripped much of the nation.

title: Police Inaction Led Restaurant Row to Bring In Guardian Angels
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece Assails Farm Pact
description: Greece has threatened a European Community accord on farm prices for the second time this month. It said a deal as described by the community's executive commission did not increase its farmers' incomes enough, a European Community official said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, the parent of American Airlines, said it would acquire Simmons Airlines Inc., a Midwest regional carrier for about $78 million.

title: Morrison Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $258,000 for the quarter and $848,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $208,000 for the quarter and $617,000 for the year. The share earnings for the year-ago quarter and year were adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split paid in December 1987.

title: Landmark Restaurant Burns
description: The Stonehenge Inn, a landmark restaurant housed in buildings from the early 1800's, was destroyed by fire today, but there were no injuries. Louise Davis, wife of co-owner David Davis, said the fire, reported at 4:40 A.M., destroyed the main building, the original old farmhouse that the restaurant was built around. She said the fire did not spread to other buildings on the site, off Route 7 in the town's commercial district. Smoke alarms failed to go off, she said. The cause of the fire was being investigated.

title: Hipotronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: The company said its results reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split declared in May and to be distributed July 1.

title: Frank J. Warnke, Educator, 62
description: Frank J. Warnke, a former chairman of the department of comparative literature at the University of Georgia, died Monday of injuries suffered when he was struck by an automobile in Antwerp, Belgium. He was 62 years old.

title: For News Magazines, Growing Identity Crisis
description: Time, Newsweek, and U.S. News & World Report are immersed in an effort to answer a question that all three view as critical: what should a news magazine be in the 1990's?

title: A Cautious Speech
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed the creation of a powerful new post of president of the Soviet Union and a partial transfer of power from the Communist Party to popularly elected government bodies.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ARCO, Los Angeles, the oil and natural gas company, named Kenneth R. Dickerson, general tax officer, to the additional position of senior vice president of government affairs, succeeding Willard T. Chamberlain, who retires early next year.

title: Boxing; Tyson's Next Bout: Legal Case With His Manager
description: Mike Tyson's 91-second fight with Michael Spinks Monday night, as it turned out, was far less complicated than life after Spinks is likely to be for the heavyweight champion.

title: Roy W. Anderson, Press Group Official, 63
description: Roy W. Anderson, a vice president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, a publisher trade group, died of liver cancer Sunday at his home in Baltimore. He was 63 years old.

title: U.S. Sues to Oust Teamster Chiefs; Seeks Trustee to Oversee Election
description: The Justice Department filed suit today to oust the senior leadership of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, charging that the union had made a ''devil's pact'' with organized crime.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Compassionate View of Human Frailty and Cruelty
description: The stage was filled with towering mounds of earth, and the first person to enter was an enigmatically grinning armless woman. Anyone familiar with contemporary dance would have had no trouble recognizing that this was the beginning of a work by Pina Bausch, who specializes in choreographic grotesquerie.

title: Woman Is Arrested As Drunken Driver In 2 Hit-Run Deaths
description: A 52-year-old Long Island woman was arrested yesterday on charges of driving while intoxicated and of leaving the scene of an accident in which two construction workers were killed and two other workers were injured, officials said.

title: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Prague Spring Revisited
description: Twenty years ago Alexander Dubcek, the Communist Party leader in Czechoslovakia, oversaw a short-lived change in his country with a goal of creating ''socialism with a human face.''

title: Hillenbrand Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Belzbergs' Penalty Set
description: A Federal judge has ordered a holding company owned by Canada's Belzberg family to pay $476,000 in interest penalties on the $2.7 million in stock trading profits it must forfeit for violating a Federal securities law.

title: Education; Oxford Hires American
description: A Nobel Prize-winning American professor will become head of the Oxford University college where he once taught and studied, a college official said.

title: Education; Groups Charge Bias in Merit Scholarship Testing
description: The competition to determine winners of the prestigious National Merit Scholarship awards for high school students is substantially flawed by reliance on a test that is ''biased on the basis of sex, race and family income,'' according to an group that monitors standardized testing.

title: With a Wink at Past, Dukakis Courts Congress
description: Ask Christopher Edley to name the people on whom Michael S. Dukakis relies for advice and Mr. Edley, the candidate's issues director, starts sounding like the Congressional Directory.

title: Efforts to Revamp Welfare System Face Steep Hurdles in Congress
description: While the House and Senate agree that the nation's welfare system needs a far-reaching overhaul, their approaches differ enough that negotiators have significant work to do before a final bill can be sent to the White House.

title: I.B.M. to Market Image Processing
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it plans to enter the image processing market, providing image storage and retrieval systems for large corporate users. I.B.M. introduced a set of component products ranging from data base management software to an optical disk storage system that will be marketed under the name Imageplus. The storage systems will range from $200,000 to $15 million and are intended to work with the company's mainframe computers or the new minicomputer line, AS/400. The system will use the company's new PS/2 computers with special high-resolution monitors as work stations.

title: A Gala at Tanglewood For Bernstein at 70
description: Beverly Sills will be the host of the Boston Symphony's Leonard Bernstein Gala Birthday Performance at Tanglewood on Aug. 25, the date of Mr. Bernstein's 70th birthday, the orchestra has announced. Proceeds from the concert - ticket prices range from $1,000 for patron seats to $200 to $50 for lawn admission - will benefit the Tanglewood Music Center.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Boston Agency Gets Banking Assignment
description: Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson of Boston has been named to handle the corporate advertising program for Keycorp, a regional bank-holding company with offices in Albany.

title: Brazil Parley Aims to Save Rain Forests
description: The tropical rain forest, nature's great but beleaguered treasure house, may face a somewhat less gloomy future if experts gathered here have their way.

title: Page America Group reports earnings for Year to March 31
Corrections
description: An Associated Press photograph on Monday with an article about the ballet legacy of Rudolph Nureyev was published in error. It showed Yuri Soloviev, who was Mr. Nureyev's colleague in the Soviet Union's Kirov Ballet, and not Mr. Nureyev at the time of his defection in 1961.

title: Tax Plans Would Net $5.5 Billion
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today agreed to various proposals that would raise the tax burden on military contractors and other segments of the business community by about $5.5 billion over the next three years.

title: Review/Film; In Beirut, Struggle as Way of Life
description: ''Beirut: The Last Home Movie'' begins in a New York subway, when Gaby Bustros steps on the J.F.K. Express and heads for a plane to the city she left 15 years before. ''Shells have landed in my family's garden,'' she says, and we quickly follow her through the rubble of bombed-out Beirut, with clouds of smoke hovering over empty buildings, to arrive at her family's home - a 200-year-old house fronted by a huge marble staircase and filled with chandeliers and Oriental rugs.

title: 3 Found Shot Dead In Coney I. Project; Drug Tie Suspected
description: Two young women and a 14-year-old girl were found shot dead in a Coney Island housing project early yesterday in what appeared to be a drug-related triple homicide, the police said. All three had been shot in the head. Investigators said there were no suspects, no signs of forced entry or indications of a struggle at the murder scene, a fourth-floor apartment in the Surf Gardens Housing Project, 2926 West 25th Street, near Mermaid Avenue.

title: Sports People; Referees Dislike Ratings
description: The union for the National Hockey League's referees and linesmen said yesterday the league's proposal for a new system to rate on-ice officials could lead to dismissals based on personality clashes rather than performance.

title: Reviews/Dance; Balloons and Confetti at Gala for Nureyev
description: There is only one Rudolf Nureyev, and true to form the gala in his honor, ''Nureyev: A Celebration,'' was unlike any other.

title: Juno Lighting Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
China Grain Rise Seen
description: China's grain production may increase by as much as 25 percent, to around 500 million metric tons, by the year 2000 from an average of 394 million tons in the 1980's, an Agriculture Department report said Monday. ''Area sown to grain probably will decrease over the next 12 years, but improved yields could boost total output,'' the report said.

title: Gorbachev's Two Hands
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has two hands. No doubt he could use 20 to cope with his vast task of remaking Soviet society. But two are enough for the balancing act of on-the-one-hand and on-the-other-hand that he seems to be performing.

title: Tokyo Journal; Making the Grade in College: Major in Table Tennis
description: When Hiroshi Yamamoto goes for his first job interview and is asked what he did in four years of college, he plans to look his potential employer in the eye and tell him the truth: he played table tennis.

title: Of Arms, and Men You Can't Trust
description: Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, musing on the latest Pentagon scandal, blamed at least part of it on the appointment of prejudiced and inexperienced officials. ''The criteria for hiring people,'' he said, ''was more related to ideology than it was to management experience.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a powerful new post of President of the Soviet Union and a partial transfer of power from the Communist Party to popularly elected bodies. Page A1

title: Education; Lessons
description: There is no doubt that computers are proliferating in American classrooms. New figures from a market-research concern in Denver, Quality Education Data, show that 95 percent of all public schools have at least one microcomputer and that there is now one computer for every 32 pupils, four times as many as there were four years ago.

title: WINE TALK
description: Robert Mondavi turned 75 years old the other day, so his children put on a birthday party at the winery. A thousand or so of his intimate friends turned up.

title: Sports People; Penguins Name Coach
description: Gene Ubriaco, the coach of the Baltimore Skipjacks of the American Hockey League for the last five years, was named yesterday to succeed Pierre Creamer as coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Bridge
description: In a general way, experts can benefit by reading advanced books on play and defense. They can keep their analytical abilities sharp between tournaments. More rarely, they can learn a tactical trick and squirrel it away for future use.

title: Scandal Pushes Apart 2 Worlds Under One Roof
description: Day by day, military officers and civilian officials work in the Defense Department in an atmosphere of apparent amity. In reality, they operate in vastly different cultures, which has once again become evident in the Pentagon procurement scandal.

title: KEY RATES
INSIDE
description: Kean to Be Keynoter

title: 4 Killed in Cyanide Accident at Indiana Plant
description: A plant worker mixing chemicals apparently released a poisonous gas that killed four people and left 20 injured early today at a northeast Indiana plating company, officials said.

title: The A320's Fly-by-Wire System
description: Shortly after the crash of a French Airbus A320 at an airshow on Sunday, the French pilots' union attributed the accident to the plane's innovative fly-by-wire control system.

title: Rates Contrast At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title:
Market Place;
The Big Growth In Machine Tools
description: LEAD: THIS week's report that machine-tool orders in May were the highest in seven years, and that orders in the first five months were up 82.6 percent from a year ago, has put the industry's two large publicly traded companies in a more favorable light.

title: Tigers Tighten Yoke
description: Critical question as the baseball season nears the halfway mark: Can the Yankees win the American League East championship without beating the Detroit Tigers?

title: Data Translation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Syphilis Surge With Crack Use Raises Fears on Spread of AIDS
description: Health experts are becoming increasingly concerned that crack use in poor neighborhoods may be accelerating the spread of AIDS among heterosexuals.

title: Simon Testifies Financial Data Had Omissions
description: Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, yesterday admitted having regularly filed incomplete financial statements since 1980 and helping friends and associates obtain jobs with the State Assembly and various Bronx community boards.

title: Queens Republicans Back Maltese in Race
description: Queens Republican leaders, in an unusual move, have agreed to support the Conservative Party state chairman, Serphin R. Maltese, as the candidate to succeed Martin J. Knorr, the Republican State Senator who is retiring.

title: Calais, Vt.
description: VISITORS may appreciate the countryside surrounding the White House Restaurant in Calais, Vt., for its lush beauty. But Leo Romero and Iory Allison, who opened the inn three years ago, know it as a source of food. They even employ a professional forager to bring them the wild leeks and ginger, mushrooms and watercress, fiddlehead ferns and cattails that appear on their menu.

title: Ameron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included $5.8 million, or $1.19 a share, of net non-recurring income principally from the sale of assets.

title: Review/Television; Problems of a Big City
description: ''Metroline,'' Channel 13's series about New York City's problems, comes to an end tonight after three earnest years. The problems, unfortunately, remain and the final half hour, at 8:30 P.M., takes on three perennials the producers deem most urgent: education, housing and bridges and roads, otherwise known as infrastructure.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign By Women's Voter Group
description: THE League of Women Voters of New York State, an outgrowth of the women's sufferage movement and almost 70 years old, is preparing to mount its first advertising campaign seeking new members and donations.

title: New Apogee Chairman
description: Russell H. Baumgartner, the founder of Apogee Enterprises, a glass fabrication company based in Minneapolis, resigned the chairmanship yesterday in favor of his handpicked successor, Donald W. Goldfus, who has been president for four years and chief executive for two.

title: Henley Opens Today
description: With a record entry of 386 boats and a record United States entry of 42, the opening races of the 144th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta will begin Wednesday morning.
