title: Reviews/Music; The Montreal Symphony
description: Every concert has its high point, even if in some cases that happens to be the moment when it is over. The program played by the Montreal Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening went from one heady peak to another, continuously dramatizing the international quality of the ensemble and its taut responsiveness to Charles Dutoit's leadership. However, the high-water mark of the concert, a New York International Festival of the Arts event, came in a ferociously driven reading of the second movement of Prokofiev's Symphony No. 5. There was a knife-edged brilliance and breathtaking impetus to this Allegro Marcato that only an optimist would demand of an orchestra and that only a virtuoso could carry off without disaster.

title: Bondholders Sue Brands and E-II
description: A group of institutional bondholders sued American Brands Inc. and E-II Holdings Inc. in Federal District Court yesterday charging that American Brands fraudulently told bondholders in January that it planned to operate E-II as a subsidiary. The holders are asking for an undetermined amount of damages.

title: Review/Theater; A Writer's Persecution
description: The title is the only straightforward thing about ''The Death of Garcia Lorca.'' The play by the Venezuelan writer Jose Antonio Rial is a paella of posturings and polemics, thickened with scenes that manage to be obscure and obvious at the same time.

title: Tepid Response in Albany Slows Council Bid for Rise in Excise-Tax
description: Governor Cuomo and state legislative leaders refused yesterday to commit themselves to increasing excise taxes on liquor and cigarettes in New York City, leaving the City Council virtually no choice but to raise property taxes to balance the city's budget today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cost of Sales Calls Up
description: As it does every other year McGraw-Hill comes up with the cost of an average sales call in hopes of shocking industrial companies into putting more of their sales dollars into advertising. The 1987 figure is $251.63, a 9.5 percent increase from the $229.70 in 1985. It also continues the up trend that has seen an increase of 160 percent in a decade. The data come from the Laboratory of Advertising Performance, a division of Mc-Graw-Hill Research.

title: Drought Stirs Debate on Wheat Export Subsidies
description: Dwindling grain stocks, higher domestic prices and fear that the drought could drastically tighten supplies are raising concern about a three-year-old program to subsidize exports of American wheat.

title: California Housing Issue Is of 2 Types
description: The California Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $246.8 million of home mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: 24 NEW CARDINALS INSTALLED BY POPE
description: Pope John Paul II installed 24 cardinals today, offered them as symbols of church unity and urged the followers of Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the dissident French cleric, not to break with the papacy.

title: Sports People; Reds Get Pep Talk
description: Marge Schott, the majority owner of the Cincinnati Reds, gave a pep talk last night in an attempt to shake the club out of its doldrums.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Pasco, Wash.
description: LEAD: IT has become something of a tradition for the families and friends of the nine partners who own Sagemoor Farms in southeastern Washington: at the end of each Bing cherry harvest, they gather on the property for a picnic. But last weekend they celebrated the farm's 20th anniversary, and the picnic was more of a feast.

title: Salvador's Ruling Party Splits Over Candidates
description: Despite efforts to end its bitter internal feuding, the ruling Christian Democratic Party has formally split into two factions, which are now denouncing each other.

title: Turner Stock To Time Unit
description: A unit of Time Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an additional 959,901 shares of Turner Broadcasting System's class B common stock for $15 a share from the company's chairman, Ted Turner.

title: Summagraphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
New York's Wineries Chart Their Move Toward Vinifera
description: NEW YORK STATE'S wine revolution was born here in 1963 on a scenic slope overlooking Keuka Lake in the Finger Lakes region. Today, according to vintners who attended a symposium in mid-June, the 25-year-old revolution is accelerating faster than ever. It is a revolution based on European vinifera grapes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shift by Bradlees
description: Mintz & Hoke Advertising and Public Relations of Boston and Avon, Conn., will be doing the advertising and strategic development for the 168-unit Bradlees Discount Department Stores, which formerly did its advertising in-house. Media buying will continue to be the responsibility of Konjolka & Company of Boston, which also buys for the Stop & Shop Companies, the parent company of Bradlees. Bradlees stores are on the East coast from Maine to North Caro-lina.

title: N.B.A. Draft; Manning, Then 3-Way Trade Give Hope to Lowly Clippers
description: It took the Los Angeles Clippers 28 seconds yesterday to make Danny Manning of Kansas the first choice in the National Basketball Association draft. The Indiana Pacers then used their full allotment of five minutes before they selected Rik Smits, the 7-foot-4-inch center from Marist.

title: Killing of Grand Jury Witness Is Called Coldly Planned Murder
description: The case of three men charged in the murder of a grand jury witness in Queens went to the jury yesterday after the prosecution called the crime an attack on the criminal-justice system itself.

title: Guidry to Start Friday Night
description: Ron Guidry, who hasn't pitched since last Sept. 5, passed his final test yesterday and was named the Yankees' starting pitcher for their game in Chicago Friday night. ''I was a little hesitant after the other day, but I thought he threw free and easy today,'' Stan Williams, the pitching coach, said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ex-Meese Aide Joins Law Firm
description: Arnold I. Burns, the No. 2 official at the Justice Department when he resigned last spring to protest the leadership of Edwin Meese 3d, said yesterday that he and two associates from the department would be joining a New York law firm. Mr. Burns, who resigned in

title: Baseball; Cubs Rally to Win 4th in Row
description: Shawon Dunston singled home two runs with a two-out, bases-loaded single, capping a four-run eighth inning today as the Chicago Cubs rallied to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-4, for their fourth straight victory.

title: A Tongue-Twister
description: To The Living Section:

title: Court Overturns Goetz Sentence
description: In a victory for Bernhard H. Goetz, an appeals court has struck down the six-month sentence Mr. Goetz received last October for carrying an unlicensed pistol in the shooting of four young men aboard a subway train in 1984. The case will go back to the trial judge for resentencing July 18.

title: Egypt Recalls 2 in Missile Affair
description: Egypt has recalled two military officers from Washington after they were implicated in a suspected conspiracy to illegally export materials to make ballistic missiles, American and Egyptian officials said today.

title: Chancellor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Southland Communications reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Month-Old Agency Has Been Acquired
description: With the fearsome foraging going on, all an advertising company has to do to get scooped up is show the whites of its eyes. Or, at least, so it seems.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Turandot' in the Park
description: The Metropolitan Opera, having effectively said through its advertising that ''Turandot'' is the show to see and that Franco Zeffirelli's megaspectacular set is the reason to see it, might be thought rash to give the opera in Central Park without benefit of scenery. But the weather Monday evening was heaven sent, and the color-streaked cloud banks quickly put all Zeffirelliana on the back burner of memory. Puccini, moreover, is perfect for the parks: he's full of subtleties, but comes across well even when they are lost.

title: In Moscow, Change Is Debatable
description: For several hours today, Russians who gathered in a park in downtown Moscow seemed to be acting out Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recent comment that the country had become one big debating society.

title: L.I. Hospital Disputes Inspectors' Findings
description: The Nassau County Medical Center today disputed the findings of an inspection that said the hospital did not comply with five Federal health-care guidelines.

title: Naomi M. Kanof, Dermatologist, 76
description: Dr. Naomi M. Kanof, who edited The Journal of Investigative Dermatology for 50 years, died at George Washington University Hospital here Sunday after a heart attack. She was 76 years old.

title: New Ads by Philip Morris Stress Power of Smokers
description: Battered by growing bans on public smoking and a recent court decision finding a tobacco company liable in the death of a smoker, the nation's largest cigarette maker is planning to spend up to $5 million in an advertising campaign that will emphasize the economic power of smokers.

title: Ballot Altered, Irving Says
description: Lawyers for the Irving Bank Corporation have complained of ballot-tampering during the company's proxy battle last month with the Bank of New York Company.

title: Education; Pursuing an Education by Degrees, A Course at a Time Lasting Weeks
description: For most college students, the school year is a smorgasbord. They have an hour of French, try an hour of mathematics, then nibble on an hour of organic chemistry. They may go back the next day to gobble up another hour or so of French and chemistry while trying a taste of Milton.

title: British Raise Rate on Loans
description: Britain's commercial banks, heeding a signal from the Bank of England, today announced an increase of half a percentage point in their base lending rate, to 9.5 percent.

title: Lear Siegler Buys AFG Subsidiary
description: In a move to bolster its position as the nation's largest auto glass installer, the Safelite Glass Corporation said it had acquired an 84-store rival, AFG Industries' auto glass unit, based in Kingsport, Tenn. Terms were not disclosed, but the deal will give Safelite, a unit of the Lear Siegler Diversified Holdings Corporation, a total of 500 stores in 40 states.

title: Where the Bronx Burned, A Fight for a Firehouse
description: Evelyn Stirvis was burned out of her apartment in the South Bronx a decade ago when the superintendent of her building did not pay his gambling debts and ''some people decided to throw a little fire party,'' she recalls. She escaped only because of the quick arrival of firefighters from the nearby Engine Company 41.

title: Mr. Gorbachev Stays the Course
description: Anyone who thought that opposition to Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms would blunt his determination got a surprise yesterday. In a speech opening the extraordinary Communist Party conference in Moscow, he pressed his campaign for political and economic reforms and told an assembly dominated by state and party officials that the biggest obstacle to perestroika is the heavy-handed management style they refuse to relinquish.

title: Morris of Auburn Is Nets' Top Pick
description: By choosing Chris Morris in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft today, the Nets not only got the player they said they wanted, but also the one who will apparently replace Orlando Woolridge, their free-agent small forward.

title: LA Gear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press yesterday about statements on the Tawana Brawley case made by Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan misstated the scope of his view. In criticizing Miss Brawley's advisers, Mr. Dinkins accused them of damaging the effort to end inequities in the criminal justice system, not the civil rights movement.

title: Hot Dogs: New Guises for the All-American Food
description: FIREWORKS are the entertainment for the Fourth of July, and hot dogs are the food. By the time the last Roman candle has faded from the sky, Americans will have consumed nearly half a billion hot dogs for the holiday, according to industry estimates.

title: Rehabilitation for Trotsky?
description: A Soviet newspaper published a plea for the legal vindication of Leon Trotsky and for the release of his writings in the Soviet Union. Page A9.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What is happening is a lot of people are feeling their oats.

title: Agents Search Home Of Ex-Congress Aide In Pentagon Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that its agents had searched the home of Richard Seelmeyer, who was an aide to the late Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens, as part of the continuing investigation of fraud and bribery in Pentagon weapons procurement.

title: Education; Green Faulted on Hispanic Dropouts
description: A group of Hispanic officials and educators severely criticized Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green yesterday for his handling of Hispanic dropout figures, saying they are ''significantly and scandalously higher'' than statistics released by the Board of Education last week.

title: Dukakis Says He Would Commit $3 Billion to Build New Housing
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, standing before a row of attached single-family homes financed through a Massachusetts program, pledged today that as President he would commit $3 billion for similar projects nationwide.

title: Wells American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Hutton and 2 Ex-Officers Censured by Big Board
description: E. F. Hutton & Company and two former officials have been censured by the New York Stock Exchange, which accused them of violating exchange rules and securities laws in an illegal check-overdrafting scheme at the firm in the early 1980's, the exchange announced yesterday.

title: Pillsbury's Net Up 51.3% in Quarter
description: The Pillsbury Company said today that its profit rose 51.3 percent in the fourth quarter, but that its earnings for the 1988 fiscal year fell 62.1 percent because of a huge restructuring charge.

title: Speeding Up The Changes
description: The transfer of power was Mikhail S. Gorbachev's theme today as he opened a national conference of the Communist Party, but it was clear from the text that a major motivating force was his disappointment with the economy.

title: Van Zandt Ellis, Pianist, 44
description: Van Zandt Ellis, a concert pianist, died of AIDS Friday in New York. He was 44 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Land Mine Kills 18 Afghans
description: A land mine killed 18 people on a bus Monday in the eastern Afghan town of Jalalabad, the Kabul radio said today. The radio, monitored here, blamed the incident on Moslem insurgents fighting the Afghan Government.

title: Micro Healthsystems Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Talking It Up
description: Author of ''Pruning the Insolent Wisteria,'' Sheppard Hepps found himself on Phil Donahue's talk show. The studio audience threatened to prune him limb by limb.

title: Report on Drought Due
description: New projections of how much damage the drought has done to this year's harvests will be issued in two weeks by the United States Department of Agriculture. The special forecast will be in the department's regular crop report on July 12 and will include new figures adjusted for damage done by this year's heat and drought, Assistant Secretary Ewen M. Wilson, who oversees the department's economic and statistical services, said Monday.

title: National HMO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Hungary's '88 Began in '56
description: LEAD: At an elegant dinner party in the American Embassy in Budapest, memory is also a guest. Seated at Ambassador Mark Palmer's linen-covered table are members of the Hungarian Communist Party, its media leaders and myself, a Hungarian-born American. One of the party's foremost propagandists enters and, bowing deeply, greets me in a manner reminiscent of the court of the Emperor Franz-Josef: ''I kiss your hand.

title: 3 Are Appointed by G.M. To Vice President Posts
description: As part of its biggest management reshuffle in four years, the General Motors Corporation appointed three new executive vice presidents today, widening the field of potential successors when its chairman, Roger B. Smith, retires in 1990.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I COULD go through the entire summer without writing a word about bathing suits. There are other, more serious issues to be explored, like bad haircuts and mean men. There are elections to be analyzed and politicians still to be made fun of. I could claim that this was not my summer to consider the issue, since I will be wearing a maternity bathing suit, which is as different from the regulation model as, say, typhus is from cholera. I could pretend that I am not interested and let sleeping monokinis lie. I could. But it would be wrong.

title: Bonilla Leads Schmidt
description: Bobby Bonilla, the Pirates' third baseman, who is trying to become the first Pittsburgh player since 1981 to win election as a National League starter in the All-Star Game, leads Mike Schmidt of Philadelphia in the latest fan balloting.

title: Review/Jazz; An Avant-Garde Merger
description: The Knitting Factory's jazz festival encourages collaborations between musical schools that might not get together otherwise, and that is a good thing. The duet on last Saturday night by Elliott Sharp, a guitarist, saxophonist and composer, and Deidre Murray, a cellist and composer, represented the merging of the jazz avant-garde. Ms. Murray is a member of Henry Threadgill's Sextett and Mr. harp is one of the major downtown improvisors.

title: MARTHA CLARKE EXPLORES THE CLASH OF THE SEXES
description: In ''Miracolo d'Amore,'' her Italianate reverie about romance and its discontents, Martha Clarke pushes beyond the musical theater experiments of her previous ''Garden of Earthly Delights'' and ''Vienna: Lusthaus.'' Call ''Miracolo'' a dance-theater piece if you wish, but, unlike the other works directed by this one-time Pilobolus dancer, it contains no dancing. Text has also vanished now, to be replaced by an all-purpose Italian double talk, Peter Brookish bird noises and untranslated song lyrics from Petrarch. A show that sounds like opera and looks like a distorted, Fellini tour through the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''Miracolo d'Amore'' may passingly remind visitors to the Public Theater of Robert Wilson or Pina Bausch or Stephen Sondheim, but, more than ever, Martha Clarke is shaping a dreamy theatrical form that is unmistakably her own.

title: New Pride Changes Japan's View of U.S.
description: A television commercial here shows what Japanese now see when they look at the United States. Two American workers, panting from their exertions on an assembly line, turn to each other and say, ''I guess we just can't keep up with the Japanese.'' Only when they drink a Japanese health tonic can they go on.

title: Pierre R. Bretey, Railroad Analyst, 89
description: Dr. Pierre R. Bretey, a former Wall Street executive and a leading railroad analyst, died of heart failure Tuesday at his Manhattan home. He was 89 years old.

title: Golf; Kestner Triumphs In Semifinal Round
description: Darrell Kestner of Sunningdale was the only metropolitan area club professional to qualify for the United States Open, but his confidence was shattered when he carded an 83 on opening day and missed the cut of that prestigious golf tournament.

title: Tridex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary gain of $469,000 on the extinguishment of debt.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alleco Inc., Cheverly, Md., said a special board committee had received two conditional indications of interest in buying Alleco for terms that are superior to a revised proposal made by the Lapides Corp.

title: Wayne, N.J., Mayor Is Arrested by F.B.I. On a Bribery Charge
description: The Mayor of Wayne, N.J., was arrested yesterday by Federal agents and charged with accepting a bribe to influence the decisions of the Wayne Planning Council, F.B.I. officials said.

title: TV Notes
description: Monty Python Fourteen years after alighting in New York, ''Monty Python's Flying Circus,'' the wacky series from the BBC, is leaving Channel 13. The station's rights to the series are about to expire, and only an immoderate farewell, it says, will do. So it has planned three late night sessions of Python fare, starting July 14 at 11:20 P.M.

title: Pretoria Says Angola Raid Is Threat to Talks on Peace
description: South Africa asserted today that a surprise ground and air attack against its forces in southern Angola had jeopardized peace talks for the region.

title: Allied Stores Official to Quit
description: Harold Leppo, executive vice president and chief merchandising officer of Allied Stores, said yesterday that he would resign at the end of July to devote his time to buying the Ann Taylor fashion chain from Federated/Allied. Mr. Leppo, who is 51 years old, is a former president of Lord & Taylor. He joined Allied a year ago. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette

title: Article 819188 -- No Title
description: Ronald Redmond, 23 years old, was arrested Tuesday after a telephone tip to the police and was charged with stealing 723 books and 56 record albums over two years from the library of the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. The books and records are valued at more than $23,000, university officials said. Mr. Redmond, who graduated from the university last year, told the police he wanted to add to his collection, an officer said. He was released after being charged with one felony count.

title: DMI Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Police Say Friends Dumped Youth Officer Killed in Robbery Attempt
description: Five classmates from a Bronx prep school set out to raise some quick cash Saturday night, the police said yesterday. Hours later, the authorities said, the foray ended tragically, when one youth was shot and fatally wounded by an off-duty policeman during a robbery attempt, and his panicked friends dumped his body in a deserted park.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in moderate trading yesterday, as market participants decided to take profits rather than pay attention to another big drop in commodity prices and continued strength in the dollar.

title: New H.U.D. Notes Yield Up to 9.40%
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is offering $57 million of notes maturing from 1989 to 1998 via underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Westwood One to Acquire 50% Stake in WNEW-AM
description: As part of an ownership reshuffling involving several radio properties worth $156 million, Westwood One said today that it would buy a 50 percent interest in WNEW-AM in New York.

title: Elizabeth Orellana Marries Dr. Seymour Halpern
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ruth Orellana, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgardo Orellana of Puerto Cortes, Honduras, to Dr. Seymour Lionel Halpern, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Halpern of New York, took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg, assisted by Cantor Ephraim Biran, performed the ceremony.

title: A Gardener's World; Summer Books, With a Nod To Horticulture
description: NOW that the heavy spring chores of the gardener's year are reduced to matters of simple maintenance, like mowing the lawn and watering the flower beds, there's time to loll in a hammock and do a little reading.

title: 15-Year-Old Palestinian Dies In Clash With Israeli Troops
description: Israeli troops killed a 15-year-old Palestinian today and the police fired tear gas at Arab schoolgirls protesting peacefully outside the United States Consulate in East Jerusalem, witnesses said.

title: Clinical Data reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains of $131,000 for the quarter and $310,000 for the year from utilization of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income d-After gains of $221,000 for the quarter and $463,000 for the year from utilization of tax loss carryforwards, and a $271,000 gain on settlement of debt for the quarter and year. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year were affected by previously reported writedowns and reserves of $630,000 and $450,000, respectively, for its Vital Scientific N.V. subsidiary.

title: Photronic Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Group 1 Software Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
Washington Talk: State Department; For Envoy Nominee, Long Road to a Hearing
description: Timothy L. Towell had a date with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, an occasion for which he had been preparing for the last six months or, if you like, the last 26 years. It was the committee's first hearing on confirmation of his nomination as an Ambassador.

title: Explorer Denies Taking Top Post At Evers College
description: Two days after the announcement of his appointment as president of the City University of New York's troubled Medgar Evers College, a prominent Harvard scholar and internationally known explorer said yesterday that he had not accepted the position, only ''the honor of the offer.''

title: A.T.&T. Leasing Cordless Phones
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said customers will be able to lease cordless phones for the first time starting tomorrow. ''We're leasing cordless phones in response to requests made in thousands of customer interviews,'' said Douglas Quinn, vice president of lease services.

title: Baseball Notebook; Would Reds Dismiss Rose?
description: George Steinbrenner has never had a problem dismissing the ever-popular Billy Martin or Lou Piniella, but Pete Rose's popularity would be a severe test for Marge Schott if the Cincinnati owner becomes sufficiently disenchanted to dismiss him.

title: Big Bear Inc reports earnings for 13wks to May 28
Death Toll in Paris Revised
description: The French police today revised the death toll in the crash of commuter trains Monday at the Gare de Lyon to 56, down from a reported 59. Officials said confusion had arisen because the bodies of many of the victims had been dismembered.

title: Furloughs From Common Sense
description: Who would give a weekend pass to a convicted murderer? Massachusetts prison officials have done that during the administration of Gov. Michael Dukakis. The practice hardly warrants Vice President George Bush's mock shock. But it deserves more explanation.

title: Journal Publishes Theory in Disbelief
description: For the first time in the memory of its staff, the prestigious scientific journal Nature has intentionally published a research report that the editors consider utterly implausible.

title: Rally Protests Proposal To Alter Landmark Law
description: In an unusual show of force and anger, several hundred preservation-minded New Yorkers rallied yesterday outside Pennsylvania Station to denounce a Koch administration proposal to overhaul the way landmarks are designated.

title: How to Make Better Use Of the Airports We Have
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 The U.S. cannot force the P.L.O. to close its observer mission to the United Nations, under a ruling by Federal District Judge Edmund L. Palmieri in Manhattan. Page A1

title: Untangling a Savings Failure
description: When savings and loan institutions fail, as hundreds of them have in recent years, government officials picking through the rubble usually have no problem identifying the cause.

title: Murder Jury Rejects Fantasy-Game Claim
description: A jury yesterday convicted a man of murdering his parents, rejecting a defense contention that he believed he was under the spell of a character in the game of Dungeons and Dragons.

title: Airlines Reach Listing Accord
description: British Airways and American Airlines have settled their legal battle over their computer reservation systems, with both airlines agreeing to change the way flights from the overseas carriers are listed in their reservation systems.

title: Crack-Possession Law Is Stiffened in New York
description: The penalties for carrying crack will be toughened under a bill Governor Cuomo signed today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: As the season for Lyme disease approaches its annual peak, health officials say they are walking a tightrope between alerting people to the importance of preventing this tick-borne ailment and unduly alarming them about what is usually a mild illness that only sometimes causes severe disability.

title: AN EFFICIENCY APARTMENT FOR 8 WEIGHTLESS PEOPLE
description: THE home for space-station astronauts that is being built here at the Marshall Space Flight Center might irk Capt. James T. Kirk, commander of the starship Enterprise in ''Star Trek.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Islanders signed two left wings, Greg Gilbert and Dale Henry, and Shawn Evans, a free-agent defenseman who last played for Nova Scotia of the American Hockey League, to contracts of undisclosed length and value. . . . Gene Tenace, a former catcher and first baseman with the Oakland A's, was named yesterday to replace Wally Moon, a former center fielder with the St. Louis Cardinals, as manager of the Prince William Yankees in the Class A Carolina League. Tenace has been a minor league hitting instructor in the Yankee organization. Moon, who guided Prince William to a 31-38 record in the first half of the season, is the first manager in the 10-year history of the franchise to be dismissed in the middle of a season. . . . Christopher Scherf has been named administrative director of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of North America, succeeding J. B. Faulconer. Gerard J. McKeon, president of the T.R.A. and of the New York Racing Association, was elected chairman of the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau.

title: Emirates Called Ready To Exceed OPEC Quota
description: The United Arab Emirates appears to be making good its threat to flout the OPEC production quota by significantly increasing its output of crude oil.

title: Senate Struggle Splits New York G.O.P.
description: The battle over who will be the next majority leader of the State Senate has turned into a broader struggle for control of the state's Republican Party, setting off a feud among Republican leaders that includes Alfonse M. D'Amato, the United States Senator.

title: Family Dollar Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Currents; Reflections Of a Vienna Long Gone
description: YOU can almost imagine Schubert being played on a piano these days at the Austrian Institute, 11 East 52d Street, where the ground floor has been furnished as if it were the apartment of a well-to-do family in 19th-century Vienna.

title: HOUSE FAVORS PANEL TO ADVISE ON COLORING FILMS
description: The House of Representatives yesterday approved by acclamation a proposal to establish a national film commission that could designate classic movies that would have to be labeled if they were colored.

title: Wilander's Grand Slam Bid Ends
description: There was more than the customary intrigue surrounding Wimbledon this year. Steffi Graf and Mats Wilander came here with their Grand Slam hopes alive, Martina Navratilova was vying for a record ninth singles championship, and Boris Becker was trying to reclaim the championship that Pat Cash won last year and that Ivan Lendl would trade a couple of his United States Open titles for.

title: Lorimar Posts Loss
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, the television and motion-picture company that has agreed to be acquired by Warner Communications Inc., yesterday reported a net loss of $4.2 million for its fourth quarter ended March 31, compared with a $62.7 million loss in the 1987 quarter.

title: SAVE FUEL TO CUT HOUSING COSTS, COALITION URGES
description: A coalition of business, Government and consumer leaders has reported that increases in energy efficiency can make housing substantially more affordable.

title: Officer Arrested in Robbery of Bronx Drug Dealers
description: A New York City policeman was arrested yesterday in an investigation into what senior police officials said appeared to be a small ring of officers who robbed drug dealers in the South Bronx.

title: Brawley's Aunt Jailed In a Bad-Check Case
description: Juanita Brawley, the aunt of Tawana Brawley, is serving a 15-day jail sentence stemming from a charge involving a bad check, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about a Federal proposal to deal with aging airliners misstated main points of the proposal and gave its status incorrectly. A corrective article appears today on page A15.

title: Laxity on Breast X-Rays
description: American women are not being screened for breast cancer as often as they should, according to preliminary results from a survey by the National Cancer Institute that were released Tuesday.

title: The Gorbachev Plan: Restructuring Soviet Power
description: Currently, the Communist Party of the Soviet Union holds all political power, centered in the Central Committee Politburo and Secretariat. All important decisions are made there and carried out by the subordinate apparatus of the Government and the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature, which lacks independent power. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in his speech Monday, referred to the party the political vanguard of society, but called for transferring some party power to popularly elected government bodies called Soviets of People's Deputies, which are now little more than tools of -and rubber-stamps for - the party. He proposed making these soviets the chief organs of local, state and regional government, and called for a reorganization of the central Government. THE PARTY Communist Party Congress

title: A TASTE OF VINTAGE BLUES
description: The blues don't get any better than the set B. B. King played Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Headlining the JVC Jazz Festival's annual blues show, Mr. King delivered blues that were sly and desolate, danceable and private, tormented and celebratory - blues in which timeworn structures support infinitely nuanced emotion.

title: Leonie Adams, Poetry Consultant, 88, Dies
description: Leonie Adams, who served as a consultant in poetry to the Library of Congress in 1948 and 1949, died of heart disease Monday in the Candlewood Valley Care Center, a nursing home, in New Milford, Conn., where she made her home. She was 88 years old.

title: Dukakis Searches Capitol for a Partner
description: Michael S. Dukakis went to Capitol Hill in search of a running mate today, and some of his aides and other knowledgeable Democrats said they believed he was looking especially hard at two Senators from states with large electoral college votes, John Glenn of Ohio and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas.

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY CUTS STAFF IN BUDGET CRISIS
description: The New-York Historical Society dismissed 21 members of its staff yesterday in what officials said was one of the steps necessary to close a ''looming budget gap that threatens the integrity and very survival of our institution.''

title: Officer Goes From Ogilvy To Academia
description: CHARLES (CHUCK) R. GUARIGLIA is a 45-year-old senior vice president at Ogilvy & Mather Direct who has said, ''I'll be an Ogilvy man until the day I die.'' But he's leaving. For a long time, Mr. Guariglia, a Brooklyn boy transplanted to Middletown, N.J., has had a profound desire to be part of campus life. To do something to help young people.

title: Yields Show Little Change
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were little changed during the week ended yesterday. Short-term rates have risen just a tenth of a point in four weeks and longer-term rates only half as much.

title: JUDGE RULES P.L.O. CAN RETAIN OFFICE
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the United States Government could not force the Palestine Liberation Organization to close its observer mission to the United Nations in New York.

title: Rains Cause Crop Prices To Plummet
description: Unexpected rains over much of the nation's parched Farm Belt caused panic selling of soybeans and other agricultural commodities yesterday on futures exchanges.

title: Community Psychiatric Ceners Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
For Fireworks Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: Crafts Fair at Lincoln Center
description: American Crafts Festival, Lincoln Center, Columbus Avenue at 64th Street; 212-677-4627.

title: Account Changes Set By a Number of Clients
description: As if getting ready for the Fourth of July break, a number of clients announced account assignments yesterday instead of waiting until later in the week.

title: Management Co Entertainent Group reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a $76,339 charge from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. The company said the latest year also included a tax benefit but it did not give the amount. The company went public in August 1987.

title: French Prime Minister Vows That His Policies Will Not Be Divisive
description: Prime Minister Michel Rocard declared today that the priorities of his new Socialist minority Government were not ''those of one-half of France against the other but those of all the French.''

title: Savings-Unit Status Report
description: The head of the agency that regulates federally insured savings institutions said today that the cases of 259 ''grossly insolvent'' institutions would be resolved by 1990 at a cost of $17.4 billion.

title: Truck Production Shift Set by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation announced that some light-duty truck production would be moved from Janesville, Wis., to Flint, Mich., to make way for production of a new medium-duty truck in Janesville. G.M. said production of cab chassis and crew cab models will move in the spring of 1989 from Janesville's Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group plant to the Flint Truck and Bus plant.

title: Panel Approves Bill for Veterans' Department
description: Senate leaders cleared the way today for approval of a bill that would elevate the Veterans Administration to Cabinet rank. But the issue may become enmeshed in bitter debate over veterans' court appeals of decisions affecting their benefits.

title: 7% Debenture Sale By Lafarge Begins
description: The Lafarge Corporation, a major cement producer, is offering $75 million of 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2013 at par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: KEY RATES
Washington Talk: Briefing; Asking the Possible
description: In the final working draft of the 1988 Democratic national platform is a call for a ban on armor-piercing ammunition that has ''no purpose other than the killing and maiming of law-enforcement officers.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * CPAC Inc., Leicester, N.Y., appointed Steven D. Johnson executive vice president and general manager of its Allied Photo Products Co. subsidiary in Atlanta.

title: Slain Youth 'Got On Wild Side,' Neighbor Says
description: The head of his school said he was ''a fine young man'' who was planning to go to college in the fall, and a next-door neighbor said of 18-year-old James Patrick Cooney, ''In my book, he's the greatest kid in the world.''

title: THE SUPREME COURT: Church and State; Ruling Upholds Law on Grants for Counseling on Sex
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law providing money to religious groups to counsel teen-age girls to abstain from sexual relations and to avoid abortion.

title: Rubber Consumption
description: World consumption of natural rubber is expected to grow much faster than production in 1988, the International Rubber Study Group said today. The producer-consumer statistical group put consumption at a record 4.935 million metric tons in 1988, which would be 140,000 tons more than the forecast. Traders said the increasing shortfall in world supplies had pushed average prices for natural rubber to their highest level in about eight years, with the latex grade trading at record levels of above $1,000 a ton. Demand for latex, which is used for surgical gloves and condoms, has been stimulated by the AIDS crisis, analysts said.

title: Executives At Northrop Subpoenaed
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that three of its current and former top executives had been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury investigating the aerospace company's efforts to sell a fighter plane to South Korea.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with a Supreme Court article about a Wisconsin town's ban on picketing was published in error in some editions. The photo, with bookshelves in the background, showed Justice William J. Brennan Jr., who was among the dissenters. Justice Byron R. White, who concurred in the majority opinion, was shown correctly in other editions, against a plain background.

title: The President's Men, Under Law
description: For the Reagan Administration, it was humiliating. For almost everyone else, yesterday's Supreme Court decision on special prosecutors deserves celebration, starting with the main point: When the President's men come under suspicion, the nation need not helplessly leave the investigation and prosecution to the President's men. Congress has the power to create a court-appointed counsel to conduct an independent investigation when the need arises.

title: U.S. Backs Appeal In Zoning-Bias Case
description: The United States Solicitor General has asked the Supreme Court to hear an appeal from the Town of Huntington in a case that could affect zoning laws nationwide.

title: Blunt Chinese Comentary Says Gorbachev Is Meeting Resistance
description: In its first comment on the Communist Party conference in Moscow, China said today that although Soviet leaders have recognized the need for political and economic change, they are confronted with serious difficulties and resistance in that effort.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Urban Plan Dying
description: Congress is about to ''take the oh-so-rare step of killing a costly Federal program that has provided great political advantage to many members of Congress,'' according to Senator William Proxmire.

title: Bush and the 'Gender Gap' From Another Angle
description: To the Editor:

title: RELIGIOUS SYMBOLS FROM PARIS TROUPE
description: The mixed bill the Paris Opera Ballet presented Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House revealed this company to be both a guardian of tradition and a promoter of innovation.

title: Jazz Festival; Lincoln Center Festival Offers Traditional Jazz
description: The second annual ''Classical Jazz'' festival at Alice Tully Hall in August will include five concerts devoted to traditional jazz. It will open Aug. 5 with Tommy Flanagan, Kenny Washington and others performing music by the composer Tadd Dameron.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson-Bruno Bout: Maneuvers Begin
description: A handshake agreement exists for Mike Tyson to fight Frank Bruno on Sept. 3 in London, but the deal was made by Bill Cayton, who Tyson has said is no longer his manager. Tyson has sued Cayton in an effort to break their relationship.

title: Bondholders Form Group
description: Bondholders, who often complain about their treatment in corporate takeovers, yesterday announced the formation of the Institutional Bondholders Rights Association. Its aim is to put bondholders on a par with stockholders, who often reap huge gains from corporate restructurings while credit downgradings send the value of bonds down. If necessary, the group said it might seek legal action to protect bondholder interests.

title: 2 WEST AFRICAN ROCKERS UPDATE THEIR TRADITIONS
description: Around the world, traditional music is hooking up to modern technology. As musicians pick up electric guitars and choose sounds for synthesizers, they decide what to retain, what to update and what to change; the sum of their choices will supply a pop tradition for the next generation that is both local and international.

title: Alpha Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Canada Passes Law To Ban Tobacco Ads And Curb Smoking
description: After years of struggle between the tobacco industry and the anti-smoking lobby, Canada has adopted some of the world's toughest anti-smoking laws, including a ban on all forms of advertising and a requirement that every cigarette pack contain a detailed leaflet warning of the fatal diseases that have been linked to smoking.

title: MENTAL-INSTITUTION DRAMA
description: Several months ago, Esther Shapiro, the creator of ''Dynasty,'' brought forth on ABC the limited-run series ''Heartbeat,'' set in a hospital established by women. Doctors and patients called one another by their first names. Tonight at 9 o'clock on ABC, Jay Presson Allen, creator of ''Family,'' brings us ''Hothouse,'' set in a family-owned psychiatric institution just outside Boston. Guess what? Doctors and patients call one another by their first names. Evidently, these things run in cycles. Maybe if we close our eyes and wish real hard, they'll go away soon.

title: Transpirator Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GILLESPIE AND MCRAE SHARE BILL
description: It is hard to imagine two more dissimilar sensibilities than Dizzy Gillespie and Carmen McRae, the jazz giants who shared the bill at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. Mr. Gillespie, who led his 17-member big band, is a powerful, sunny-spirited force of nature whose music is stamped with an irrepressible gregariousness. Miss McRae, by contrast, is a hard-bitten sage from whom expressions of sentiment are almost as rare as pearls.

title: Heritage Entertainment Year reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $36,000 and a gain of $994,000 from an accounting change for income taxes. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $342,000.

title: 7-1 RULING IS REBUFF TO REAGAN; SCALIA IN DISSENT
description: In one of its most important interpretations of the doctrine of separation of powers, the Supreme Court today upheld the Federal law that provides for independent prosecutors to investigate suspected crimes by high-ranking officials.

title: Westinghouse Cuts
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would cut 380 jobs from its energy systems business, which now employs about 7,000 people, because of tougher worldwide competition. All but 100 of the jobs to be cut are in the Pittsburgh area, where 4,000 of the 7,000 energy jobs are located.

title: Becker, Tops Cash In Straight Sets
description: For a year now, Boris Becker has lived with a loss that was more crushing that anyone could have imagined. Wimbledon had given him everything, he said today: fame, fortune and, perhaps, even the feeling that he was invincible. But when Pat Cash of Australia lifted the trophy on Centre Court after last year's final, he took the symbol of all that success, and Becker wasn't even there to put up a fight.

title: Metro Matters; Why Prosecutors Are Waging War On One Another
description: It's unseemly: the Bronx District Attorney and a Federal prosecutor publicly feuding; the Manhattan District Attorney investigating allegations of irregularities commmitted by his Queens counterpart. What's going on? It's arguable whether these are anything more than isolated events, tied together only by timing.

title: Reviews/Music; Canadian Folk-Rock Trio
description: The ways of the commercial music business can sometimes seem very curious indeed. The McGarrigles -the Canadian sister folk-rock group - have persevered for years, turning out some of the most moving songs and heartfelt singing within the entire vernacular tradition. But they have not had any sort of real record contract for years, and as a result, their late show Friday night at the Bottom Line - part of a three-day stand there that ended Saturday - was only half full.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Writerproof' Season With the writers' strike threatening the fall TV season, NBC made plans for ''writerproof'' programs, including remakes of old series. Page C22. House Passes Housing Law The House approved a bill to toughen enforcement of laws prohibiting dis-crimination in the sale of rental of public or private housing. Page A20. Three U.S. Jets Crash In training flights over West Germany, two Air Force F-16's collided in midair and a third crashed near a resort. One pilot was killed. Page A3. T.V.A. to Lay Off 7,500 The financially troubled Tennessee Valley Authority announced that it would lay off 7,500 employees, 20 percent of its work force. Page A14.

title: Tigers Beaten In Two Events
description: The American results on the first day of elimination races at the 144th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta today caused more champagne bottles to be popped to assuage disappointments than to celebrate victories.

title: No to King George
description: The most audacious effort in generations to exalt the constitutional power of the President has been decisively turned back. That is the larger meaning of the Supreme Court's decision yesterday in the independent counsel case.

title: Limited Insurance Changes Are Accepted by Tax Panel
description: Bowing to intense lobbying from the insurance industry, the House Ways and Means Committee agreed tonight to only a limited cutback in the tax advantages of investment-oriented life insurance products.

title: Dollar Off a Bit After Selling Spree
description: The dollar rose again early yesterday but finished slightly lower after a late wave of selling by traders.

title: NEW HOME FOR PRINCE: IT'S BRITISH AFTER ALL
description: BUCKINGHAM PALACE is expected to announce next week that a British company will replace Parish-Hadley, the New York concern chosen to decorate the mock-Tudor house being built for the Duke and Duchess of York near Windsor Castle.

title: Micro Bio-Medics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: New Polls Show Bush Shaves Dukakis Lead
description: Two new national polls released yesterday showed Michael S. Dukakis's lead over Vice President Bush narrowing to only a few percentage points.

title: Market Place; Carnation's Move In Infant Formula
description: THE plans of the Carnation Company to become a new force in the $1.6 billion infant-formula market are expected to put pressure on profit margins of the industry's three established formula producers, but the move is not viewed as hurting overall earnings projections, at least initially, food industry analysts said.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: One of every six American children under 18 years old lives in a stepfamily, according to a 1984 Census Bureau study. By 2000, that proportion will grow to about one in four, Government studies estimate. For many children, and parents, too, the transition to a new family is upsetting. Even the most psychologically astute parents often find that they are unprepared for the effects the new marriage may have on their children.

title: Exciting Weekend for Boaters in New York City
description: CANOE and kayak enthusiasts in New York City will soon have seven Parks and Recreation Department launching sites at their disposal. In celebration of this, there will be a somewhat bizarre boat-building contest and boat race at the West 79th Street Boat Basin in Riverside Park this weekend.

title: Rhodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Page One Editor Resigns At The Wall Street Journal
description: Lewis D'Vorkin, the Page One editor at The Wall Street Journal, resigned yesterday for unspecified ''personal reasons,'' a Journal spokesman said.

title: Currents; Design for Work Spaces at Home
description: AN estimated 23 million Americans work out of their homes, and on July 14 that phenomenon will be discussed in a symposium, ''Home Workstyle,'' at the Barbizon Hotel, Lexington Avenue and 63d Street.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I splashed some black driveway sealer on the white vinyl siding on my house and have tried, without much success, to wash it off with turpentine, alcohol and detergents. Where I washed, the siding is now brownish. Can I restore the white?

title: I.B.M. Set To Close 5 Factories
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would phase out manufacturing at five domestic factories and further reduce its headquarters staff.

title: Ignoring Veto Threat, House Votes $10.8 Billion Transportation Bill
description: The House today approved a $10.8 billion transportation spending bill that includes more money for the Coast Guard and aviation, and seeks to shield a Civil War battlefield from development.

title: Excerpts From Ruling Upholding Independent Counsel Law
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's opinion upholding the constitutionality of the provisions of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, which permit the appointment of an independent counsel by the Justice Department. In doing so, the Court reversed a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: Rumania Trade Status
description: President Reagan has signed an order withdrawing trade concessions from Rumania under the most-favored-nation program. The order that Mr. Reagan signed Tuesday was a formality since Rumania informed the State Department earlier this year that it would not seek a renewal of its special status, which expires this Sunday. United States officials said earlier this year that Rumania appeared willing to give up the preferential treatment rather than address American concerns about reported abuses of human rights in Rumania. The special status was said to be worth $250 million in trade annually to Rumania.

title: H&R Block Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
Town & Country Jewelry Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
President Gorbachev?
description: In proposing a strong Soviet president - probably himself - Mikhail S. Gorbachev hopes to break free of the restraints of party conservatives. News analysis, page A12.

title: Airbus Jet Order
description: A joint venture company formed by the GATX Leasing Corporation, a subsidiary of the GATX Corporation, and Credit Lyonnais of France announced an order for 10 Airbus Industrie A320 planes. The order by GATX/CL Air was the first for the plane produced by the European aerospace consortium since an Air France A320 crashed on Sunday at a French air show. The total value of the contract for the 10 planes exceeds $325 million.

title: John H. Schwieger, 75, Wall Street Executive
description: John H. Schwieger, a stockbroker and former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in New Paltz, N.Y., and in the Parkchester section of the Bronx.

title: Groans and Cheers in Britain for Secrets Plan
description: The Government outlined its long-promised bill to revise the Official Secrets Act today. The action drew groans from civil libertarians and cheers from supporters of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's legal campaign against publication of classified information.

title: Pullman May Get Bid To Be Taken Private
description: The Pullman Company, a manufacturer of truck trailers and industrial components, said yesterday that members of its senior management were considering making a proposal to take the company private in a transaction that the group valued at $7.50 a share, or $295.4 million.

title: Duchess of York Plans Two Children's Books
description: The Duchess of York has signed to write two children's books for Simon & Schuster. Publication of the two stories, about a helicopter called Budgie, is planned for August 1989.

title: Bruce Signs Pact
description: Earle Bruce, who was dismissed as the football coach at Ohio State just before the season's final game against Michigan last fall, will return to coaching this fall at the University of Northern Iowa in Cedar Falls.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In this case, however, we do not think it impermissible for Congress to vest the power to appoint independent counsels in a specially created Federal court.'' - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. [ A18:1. ]

title: Levolor Gets New Head From an Air Courier
description: Charles A. Lynch is leaving his post as chairman and chief executive of DHL Airways Inc., an air courier, to head Levolor Lorentzen Inc., the company best known for its window blinds.

title: Prices Paid Farmers Rose 3.7% in June
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products rose 3.7 percent in June above May's levels, a drought-related jump that carried the overall price index up 6.9 percent from a year ago.

title: Talking Deals; Just a Few Days To Find a Partner
description: IN real estate, where deals often take months or even years, the recent sale of the J.C. Penney headquarters in Manhattan shows how an aggreement can be reached in a matter of days. What it took was a real estate broker who scrambled to salvage a deal after one partnership split apart and a buyer who was willing to yield on a key issue to bring in a new partner.

title: Kean Gets Bipartisan Advice on Speech
description: Governor Kean's telephone rang this morning at 7:30 at his home in Livingston. It was Governor Cuomo with some words of advice about how to deliver the keynote speech at a national political convention. Mr. Kean learned a day earlier that he will keynote this year's Republican convention in New Orleans.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about the Carnation Company's new infant formula misstated the market shares for soy-based and milk-based infant formulas. Soy-based formulas account for 22.27 percent of the market, and milk-based formulas 69.70 percent.

title: Value Line Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included capital gains of $370,000 for the quarter and $535,000 for the year. c-Included capital losses of $311,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $2,634,000 for the year.

title: Fetters on the Executive; By Finding No Threat in Prosecutor Law, The Court Rejects a Constitutional Vision
description: On one level, the Supreme Court decision upholding the law on independent prosecutors is a footnote to history, ratifying one of the major legacies of the Watergate experience. The Court removed all lingering doubt about the constitutionality of the steps Congress took to spare the country the trauma of a repetition of the Saturday Night Massacre in which President Nixon ordered the dismissal of the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Sand Technology Systems International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Currents; Where Masters Ply Their Trade
description: STUCK in the 20th century? New York's Gothic cathedral still under construction, St. John the Divine at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, has masters and apprentices at work carving and fitting stone in much the same way as was done centuries ago.

title: Saudi Oil Shake-Up Seen
description: Saudi Arabia is considering a further shake-up of its domestic oil industry - a move that could lead to a new refinery company, industry sources said today.

title: Reagan Denounces Dukakis as a Tax-Raiser
description: President Reagan, in his first stump speech in behalf of Vice President Bush, criticized Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today, calling him a ''true liberal, who, instead of controlling Government spending, raises taxes.''

title: Tracy-Locke Fills A Dual Post at the Top
description: Phil Slott, 45, backed by years of creative experience in New York and even a little in London, has shifted his flag to Tracy-Locke, the Sun Belt agency, of which he will be chairman and chief creative officer. The main office is in Dallas, there is another office in Atlanta and a third in Los Angeles, where Mr. Slott will be found.

title: The Bureaucracy To the Rescue!
description: LEAD: One common thread connects Pentagate, Irangate and Watergate.

title: Naomi M. Kanof, Dermatologist, 76
description: Dr. Naomi M. Kanof, who edited The Journal of Investigative Dermatology for 50 years, died at George Washington University Hospital here Sunday after a heart attack. She was 76 years old.

title: Chief of Combustion Is Now Chairman, Too
description: Charles E. Hugel, who has been president and chief executive of Combustion Engineering Inc. since 1984, has taken the title of chairman, and the company elected George S. Kimmel president and chief operating officer..

title: Hershiser Blanks Astros On 2 Hits
description: Orel Hershiser pitched a two-hitter today for his fifth consecutive victory, outdueling Nolan Ryan as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Houston Astros, 2-0.

title: National Semiconductor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-Net loss The results for the fiscal year 1988 included 8 months of sales and operating performance of the acquired Fairchild Semiconductor business, which was accounted for by the purchase method of accounting. Both year-ago periods have been restated to reflect the early adoption and retroactive application of a change in accounting for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: Retirement Announced
description: Pierre Harvey, whose prowess in cross-country skiing and cycling made him the only Canadian male athlete to attend two Olympic Games in the same year, announced yesterday that he is retiring from World Cup and Olympic competition.

title: Festival's Impact Estimated at $400 Million
description: Martin E. Segal, chairman of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, said at a news conference yesterday that he expects the festival to generate $400 million for the economy of New York City.

title: Japanese Images Of Water Lilies
description: Kazuo Ohno's ''Suiren,'' subtitled ''Water Lilies,'' was inspired by a walk across the lawns and past the river of an old Roman castle, a walk that prompted a vision of Monet's ''Water Lilies.'' But the hourlong piece, presented on Tuesday at the Asia Society as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, is Mr. Ohno as usual. And that is a state that can reach rare heights of performing artistry.

title: John Groth Dies at 80; Illustrator and Teacher
description: John Groth, an artist who illustrated many books and was best known for his depictions of combat, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: ANNA WINTOUR TRANSFERRED TO HEAD VOGUE MAGAZINE
description: Anna Wintour, editor of HG, the former House & Garden, is to take over Vogue magazine, S. I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of Conde Nast Publications Inc., announced yesterday. The move has been rumored for months and consistently denied by spokesmen for Conde Nast, which owns both magazines.

title: Korean Surplus Widens
description: The surplus in South Korea's balance of payments grew in May despite labor disputes and continued appreciation of the nation's currency, the Bank of Korea said today. The current-account surplus, which covers trade in both goods and services, rose to $892 million from April's $878 million.

title: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A.M.A. Backs New Category of Hospital Worker
description: Against strong opposition from nurses' groups, the American Medical Association today approved a plan to create a new category of hospital workers to alleviate a shortage of nurses.

title: What's in a Cream Filling? A Candy Dispute in Albany
description: When lobbyists for New York City set out to change a Prohibition-era law that prohibits the sale of alcohol-filled candy in the state, they thought their task would be as easy as stealing liquor from a baby. After all, the candy is already made and sold legally in New Jersey, and the change, they said, could encourage candy makers to expand their operations in New York.

title: Documents Destroyed by Targets Of Pentagon Arms Fraud Inquiry
description: A Federal prosecutor disclosed today that people under investigation in the Pentagon bribery and fraud case had destroyed documents, and he expressed fear that others were ready to do the same.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST older homes and apartments have plaster walls and ceilings.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: MCA Inc, the entertainment conglomerate, said it expects to take a $35 million after-tax charge against its second-quarter earnings because of losses on its Gotcha! toy gun line and its investment in Coleco Industries, the troubled toy maker. The announcement Tuesday was made after a review of MCA's LJN toy business and its stockholdings in the Hartford toy company, MCA said.

title: Young & Rubicam Buys Stake in Lisbon Agency
description: Young & Rubicam, the world's largest ad agency, has acquired a minority interest in Team, a Lisbon agency, which is the largest independent agency in Portugual, billing about $14 million.

title: 2 Months in the Recall of a Suspect Drug
description: On April 29, the Food and Drug Administration and the manufacturer began a time-consuming voluntary effort to mislabeled drug bottles presumed to pose a serious danger. Some key events: April 28 - A Pennsylvania drug chain discovers that several bottles labeled as ipecac, a drug used to induce vomiting in emergencies, actually contain poisonous eucalyptus oil. It notifies the maker, Humco Laboratory of Texarkana, Tex. April 29 - Humco confirms the error in some bottles, recalls all one-ounce bottles in distribution, stores or homes, and notifies the F.D.A. district office in Dallas, which in turn notifies the agency's Emergency Operations Branch in Rockville, Md. The agency determines there is a high risk and releases an alert to national news media. News coverage is sparse. April 30 - Dallas F.D.A. inspectors visit Humco to get samples and distribution information. The company notifies distributors by certified mail. May 4 - The Dallas recall officer formally files a recommendation for an agency procedure to follow up on the company recall. May 5 - Washington approves the recall procedure. Express mail letters are sent to the 20 other F.D.A. districts, instructing them to check local distributors to confirm receipt of the company letter, do weekly reports on the number of bottles found and send the results to the Dallas office. May 6 - In the hope of wider news coverage, a second news alert is issued after the agency discovers thousands of suspect bottles were distributed free nationally for Poison Control Week. June 24 - With 101,480 bottles returned out of an estimated 200,000 to 400,000 covered by the recall, the agency calls the rate of return good, but critics say the process was too slow. Officials say that the effort could continue for several months, but that none of the retrieved bottles has contained the poison. Any 1-ounce bottles of Humco brand ipecac still in homes or on shelves should be discarded or returned to the store; the brand is not now being sold in this size. There have been no reports of deaths or poisonings.

title: Rebel Archbishop Ready to Defy Pope in a Schism
description: Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, a traditionalist Roman Catholic who has called some of the Vatican's pronouncements ''satanic,'' prepared today to defy the Pope by ordaining four bishops on Thursday and bringing on the penalty of excommunication.

title: Albany Leaders Agree on a Bill On Malpractice
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders agreed today to extend the state medical malpractice insurance law for three years in a way that would raise doctors' premiums 5 percent annually, less than had been expected earlier in the week.

title: Jackson Plans Hostage Move
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he planned to press an effort to win the release of the Americans missing in Lebanon and might visit the Middle East to try to do it.

title: A Soviet President?; Gorbachev Offers Some New Politics And Few Doubt He Intends to Lead
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has offered his people the design for a prodigious new political contraption, and few doubt that he intends to be its driver.

title: HIRING SECRETARIAL HELP
description: GETTING out from under the pile of papers at home often requires a helping hand. In response to the increase in home offices, several agencies now employ skilled workers who can be hired for special tasks.

title: Odyssey Entertainment reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company was in the development stage in the prior year and had no revenue. The fiscal 1988 loss included a writeoff of about $1.7 million on the company's investment in its first two films and a writedown of about $1.3 million to reflect the company's estimated net realizable value of its investment in Heritage Entertainment. The company's 1988 revenue was almost totally attributable to the operation of Odyssey Filmakers, which was acquired in September 1987.

title: Irving Suitor May Revive Bid
description: The Bank of New York Company said today that it was prepared, under certain conditions, to revive its sweetened $1.4 billion bid to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation.

title: 'JOHN HENRY' AND 'BILLY THE KID,' A FEAST OF FOLK
description: One byproduct of the current First New York International Festival of the Arts is that the dance works it has commissioned have all been on the festive side.

title: Players International Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
ETHNIC IDENTITY CONFUSION FOR JAPANESE-AMERICANS
description: Momoko Iko's ''Flowers and Household Gods'' centered on the funeral of the matriarch of the Kagawa family. The time was the late 1960's and the past, with the memory of internment during World War II, was recalled with anger as well as recrimination. In the sequel, ''Boutique Living and Disposable Icons,'' presented by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, the Kagawas return almost 20 years later - and in crucial ways the terrain has changed.

title: Procurement Hearings Open; Pentagon Criticized in House
description: Senior officials of the Defense Department marched up Capitol Hill today to assert that the Pentagon's system for procuring weapons works well. They ran into sharp criticism from liberal Democrats and an occasional shot from conservative Republicans, too.

title: NBC PLANS A 'WRITERPROOF' SCHEDULE
description: With the four-month-old writers' strike threatening the fall television season, NBC announced yesterday that it plans to concoct an emergency fall schedule of ''writerproof'' programs, including foreign shows, variety programs and old series remakes.

title: IMPRESSIONISTIC STANDARDS FROM A PIANIST
description: Makoto Ozone, a pianist who played Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, wears his influences as discreetly as cat hair on a blue blazer. Throughout his concert, the styles of the pianists Bill Evans and Chick Corea permeated the room, making the show seem like a recital by a technically gifted student.

title: U.S. Nannies Seek Regulation Of Their Profession
description: Anne Recchia graduated from one of England's most selective training schools for nannies. She helped raise the children of a duke and a duchess. She has worked as a nanny for the children of the actor Michael Caine, as well as for some ''very lovely ordinary families,'' as she put it.

title: Mafia Suspect Held in Miami
description: The United States Marshals Service said today that it had arrested a suspected leader of the Italian mafia wanted since 1983 by the Italian police on charges of corruption, embezzlement and illegal weapons possession. The agency said in a statement that the 51-year-old suspect, Gaetano Corallo, was a ''major criminal'' accused of organizing and directing a gang of thieves that tried to control gambling in Italian casinos. Mr. Corallo was arrested without incident in a hotel room in nearby Coral Gables early today, officials said.

title: Indian Housing Bill Signed
description: President Reagan signed legislation today establishing separate statutory authority for Indian housing programs, the White House announced. The bill also authorizes a mutual help homeowners opportunity program for Indian families, establishes a self-help housing program and makes other changes in existing Indian housing programs, the White House said. The President was in Miami to deliver a speech for Representative Connie Mack 3d, a Republican senatorial candidate.

title: Spencer Case Suspect
description: Jerry Poreba, a police captain in Riviera Beach, Fla., reported yesterday that a construction worker named Leon (Lump) Daniels was arrested on Tuesday in the June 3 shooting death of Brian Spencer, a former National Hockey League player. Spencer played from 1969 to 1979 with the Islanders, Toronto Maple Leafs, the Buffalo Sabres and the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES I.B.M. will phase out manufacturing at five domestic factories and reduce its headquarters staff in Westchester County by several thousand employees. I.B.M. said 10,000 of its 228,000 domestic employees would be affected. [ Page D1. ] Michael D. Dingman will pay $103.9 million for the 17.2 percent stake in Henley Manufacturing held by two foreign investors. Mr. Dingman, the chairman of Henley Group, said he would like to buy the remaining public shares of Henley Manufacturing. [ D1. ] NBC will concoct a schedule of ''writerproof'' programs, including foreign shows, because of the writers' strike. [ C22. ] McGraw-Hill will reorganize into three operating companies. One analyst said the setup appeared to be a defensive move. [ D22. ] Westwood One will buy a 50 percent interest in WNEW-AM, New York, as part of an ownership swap of radio properties. [ D22. ] Northrop said subpoenas were issued to two executives and a former executive by a Federal grand jury investigating its efforts to sell a fighter to South Korea. [ D5. ] Pullman's management is considering making a proposal to take the company private in a $295.4 million transaction. [ D5. ] Bank of New York said it might revive its $1.4 billion hostile bid for Irving. [ D5. ] Lorimar-Telepictures reported a net loss of $4.2 million for its fourth quarter ended March 31. [ D22. ] The Page One editor of The Wall Street Journal resigned for unspecified ''personal reasons,'' the newspaper said. [ D22. ] THE ECONOMY Tax writers agreed to limit reductions in the tax advantages of investment-oriented insurance producers. The decision followed intense lobbying by the insurance industry. [ D1. ] Documents were destroyed by people under investigation in the Pentagon fraud case, a Federal prosecutor said. [ A21. ] Pentagon procurement procedures were criticized on Capitol Hill. [ A21. ] The S.E.C. is negotiating with the Swiss Government for information about Swiss bank accounts that it believes were used for insider trading by Fred C. Lee, a businessman from Taiwan. [ D7. ] The index of leading indicators dipped 0.1 percent in May, the first setback since January. [ D6. ] Sales of new homes edged down 0.3 percent in May, the first decline in four months. [ D6. ] Senate Democrats failed to stop debate on the plant-closing bill but said they had the votes to pass the bill eventually. [ D13. ] Prices farmers received for raw products rose 3.7 percent in June above May's levels, bolstered by the drought. [ D6. ] MARKETS The dollar rose, then fell, as traders appeared to be taking profits. Currency dealers said they had yet to see a ceiling set by the central banks on the dollar's recent rally. [ D1. ] Panic selling of soybeans and other farm commodities followed unexpected rain through much of the Farm Belt. [ D1. ] The stock market ended moderately lower, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.89 points, to 2,121.98. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in moderate trading. [ D18. ] Yields on C.D.'s, money market accounts and money market mutual funds were little changed in the recent week. [ D17. ] INTERNATIONAL The United Arab Emirates appears to be making good its threat to flout OPEC's production quota. [ D2. ] Canada has adopted tough anti-smoking laws, including a ban on all forms of advertising. [ A1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The sale of the J.C. Penney building survived the last-minute collapse of a partnership. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Carnation's bid to become a force in infant formula is expected to put pressure on industry profit margins. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Lorimar Telepictures Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $16,121,000 for the quarter and $18,155,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,477,000 for the quarter and $20,663,000 for the year. The company said the loss in the latest fourth quarter is primarily attributable to interest expense and to writedowns on new television series, television pilots and a feature film. It also said much of the 1988 fiscal year loss was attributable to $49 million in writedowns from the company's motion picture division and $22 million in reserves taken in the home video division. The year-ago periods were restated to reflect advertising as a discontinued operation because of the sale of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc., and Poppe Tyson Inc., in February 1988.

title: Singapore's Growth
description: Singapore's economy will probably maintain its 8 percent annual growth rate this year despite labor shortages, according to a United States Embassy report released today. The nation's economy is dependent on foreign trade and continues to recover because of strong demand in the United States and other industrial countries, the report said. The economy stumbled into recession in 1985, partly recovered with a 1.8 percent growth rate in 1986 and then surged to 8.8 percent last year.

title: Yonkers Faces Court Control Of Housing
description: A Federal judge, responding sharply to defiance by the Yonkers City Council, began a process yesterday that could take a housing desegregation plan out of the hands of the city's elected officials.

title: S.E.C. Tells of Tracking Down Taiwan Investor
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today disclosed details of the investigation into suspicious stock trading that led the S.E.C. to Fred C. Lee, a businessman from Taiwan, and Stephen S. Wang Jr. of Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Correction Officer Indicted in Slaying
description: A New York City correction officer has been indicted in the shooting death last year of a man in East Harlem.

title: New-Home Sales Off 0.3% Last Month
