description: Sales of new homes edged down three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first decline in four months.

title: Currents; Chicago Exhibition Back Home
description: AFTER highly successful runs at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris and the German Architecture Museum in Frankfurt, the exhibition ''Chicago Architecture 1872-1922: Birth of a Metropolis'' returns to its roots to open at the Art Institute of Chicago July 16. The show surveys 50 years of Chicago architecture, from the aftermath of the Great Fire of 1871 to the Chicago Tribune Tower Competition of 1922 (the winner is shown below). Organized by John Zukowsky, curator of architecture at the institute, the sweeping exhibition includes more than 300 building models, objects of decorative art, architectural drawings and archival photographs.

title: The Gamblers
description: There stood Mikhail Gorbachev, delivering a three-hour harangue to the first emergency confabulation of the Communist Party in a half century, pretending not to be in any way responsible for the economic mess the Soviet Union is in.

title: ROMANTIC BE-BOP HARMONY
description: The pianist Duke Jordan's concert at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday afternoon, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, was full of contradictory elements. Mr. Jordan, a fine composer and a pianist rooted in be-bop, has an immense harmonic knowledge. Throughout the concert, his treatments of standards spilled chords, obscuring the original harmonic framework of the tunes. And as a soloist, he knows the intricate details of be-bop.

title: Marriott to Buy 91 Wag's Restaurants
description: The Walgreen Company agreed to sell 91 Wag's family restaurants to the Marriott Corporation, a move that will enable it to focus on its drugstore chain, which is the largest in the United States. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Dow Slips by 8.89, to 2,121.98, in Slow Day
description: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.89 points, to 2,121.98.

title: AN ARCHITECT RAISES A 'GREEN MANSION' ABOVE THE EAST SIDE
description: YOU could say that Paul Rudolph, the modernist architect, has built his own hanging garden of Babylon, 20th-century Manhattan style. Cascading plants cover tier upon tier of slender steel beams and wires along the exterior of Mr. Rudolph's quadruplex apartment.

title: Mislabeled Poison Prompts Criticism Of Government's Recall Procedure
description: The discovery two months ago that bottles of a common medication contained poison instead of the drug triggered a nationwide recall procedure that continues today.

title: Student's Violent Death Shakes a Prep School
description: The Fordham Preparatory School, from which James Patrick Cooney and his companions graduated three weeks ago, is a boys' day school in the Bronx whose students, almost without exception, go on to college.

title: Officials Link Plot on Gotti To a Mafia Struggle for Turf
description: A rivalry over a fallen mobster's empire in New Jersey and the breakup of organized crime's governing council were the key factors in a conspiracy to kill John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: Labor Relations; Unions Limited in Use of Dues and Fees
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a union cannot require nonmembers to help finance union political lobbying for positions with which they disagree.

title: Japanese Stars Top U.S. Team
description: Jim Abbott of the University of Michigan held the Japanese all-stars scoreless for five innings but Japan rallied to edge a touring American collegiate squad by 4-3 tonight before a crowd of 20,000.

title: CBS Radio Chief Named
description: Nancy C. Widmann, a 16-year CBS employee, was named yesterday to head the CBS Radio division in New York, succeeding Robert L. Hosking, who will take early retirement. Ms. Widmann, who is 44 years old, was a vice president with responsibility for CBS-owned radio stations since 1987 and had been general manager of WCBS-FM in New York for six years. Mr. Hosking, who is 56, has been president of the radio division since 1981.

title: Vote on Plant Closings Is Delayed in the Senate
description: Senate Democrats failed today to shut off debate on a bill requiring companies to provide 60 days' notice of layoffs and factory closings. But the Democratic leadership insisted it would have the votes to pass the legislation over a threatened veto.

title: Simon Admits Wedtech Donated to Campaigns
description: Stanley Simon, the former Bronx Borough President, acknowledged yesterday at the Wedtech trial that over a four-year period he received $25,000 in campaign contributions from Wedtech, as well as donations from major contractors in the Bronx, his wife's employers and the former law firm of Representative Mario Biaggi.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: Capital Punishment; Justices Put Age Limit on Executions
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 3, that states may not execute people for crimes committed when they were less than 16 years old, at least not unless particular states adopt new legislation explicitly providing that people under 16 may be executed.

title: SUPERCONDUCTIVITY: BREAKTHROUGH AND POLITICS
description: The Breakthrough The Race for the Superconductor By Robert M. Hazen Illustrated. 271 pages. Summit. $18.95.

title: Major Reorganization Begun by McGraw-Hill
description: McGraw-Hill Inc., the publishing company that has been the focus of takeover speculation recently, said yesterday that it would reorganize into three new operating companies, effective tomorrow.

title: Spraying Coca Opens a Genetic Pandora's Box; Blatant Disregard
description: To the Editor:

title: Nu Horizons Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Chicago White Sox misidentified the Sara Lee Corporation's founder. He was Nathan Cummings. Charles Lubin founded a division, the Kitchens of Sara Lee.

title: IN THE HAMPTONS, GENTILITY REGAINED
description: TWO grand old Long Island houses - Keewaydin, a stately home in Southampton, and Meadowcroft, an arts-and-crafts residence in Quiogue - will be open to the public as decorator show houses this summer.

title: Currents; To Recline, With a Sense of Humor
description: DAKOTA JACKSON, a New York designer, recently unveiled two new furniture collections, the Kazoo Collection and the PFM Chair line, for residential and corporate use. The first includes the angular but comfortable Kazoo chaise, below, which lists for $5,460. A club chair is $3,750. The Dakota Jackson showroom is at 306 East 61st Street; 212-838-9444.

title: HAND OF TECHNOLOGY
description: The double bill at the Beacon Theater on Sunday night, featuring the pianists Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea, was a telling tribute to technology. With Mr. Hancock, the concert was a vain attempt to coax the futuristic sounds of his albums out of machines more at home in recording studios than onstage.

title: On Sixth Attempt, Yanks Beat Tigers
description: There had been some frustration in the first five games, even if the Yankees kept insisting it was only June. The Tigers had swept them last week in Detroit, had taken over a division lead that the Yankees owned for 48 days and had won twice this week in the Bronx.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Paper Chase
description: As part of the investigation of the Pentagon, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched last week for documents at the Space and Naval Systems Command and found them in the office of George Stone, director of communications acquisitions. He is one of those under investigation. The F.B.I. asked the Navy to make photocopies.

title: T.V.A. Slashes Work Force And Holds Off on 2 Plants
description: The chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, saying that the ''glory days'' were over, today announced a 20 percent cut in the work force of the troubled Federal power agency.

title: Dalai Lama Reportedly Asks For Formal Talks With China
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader, has sent a message to Chinese leaders seeking formal talks to resolve the political difficulties in his homeland, a Tibetan spokesman said today.

title: STUDENTS TACKLE ISSUES OF VIOLENCE
description: ABOUT a third of American families experience domestic violence, according to the family research laboratory at the University of New Hampshire in Durham. At least 1.8 million women are assaulted by their husbands every year and more than 1.6 million children are abused by parents.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Ballesteros Shares Lead: With a late flurry of five birdies in six holes, Severiano Ballesteros of Spain grabbed a share of the lead yesterday after the first round of the $374,000 Monte Carlo Open.

title: In Pesticide Crackdown, One Culprit Is a Surprise
description: New York State's effort to crack down on illegal pesticide users has snared an unlikely perpetrator: a state park here.

title: Sterling to Buy Plastics Supplier
description: Sterling Engineered Products, a subsidiary of the Trinova Corporation, will buy a West German plastics company, Trinova's president and chief executive said.

title: At St. Bart's, Good Works Sink Under the Burden of a Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Shakespeare Wrote 'Between You and I'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Clock Ticks on the State Budget
description: When Governor Cuomo presented the Legislature his plan for eliminating the state's unexpected budget shortfall, he rightly warned that ''time is of the essence.'' That was three weeks ago. Yet the Governor, the Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson, and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller remain without agreement on terms of a new plan.

title: Santiago Journal; With a Thunderclap, Leftist Breaks Chile's Silence
description: In a country awakening politically from 15 years of military rule, the television debut of Ricardo Lagos hit with the force of an earthquake.

title: Bridge
description: If you have to go out when storms are threatening, it is unwise to put on your best suit. And if you have to select a contract when distributional storms are threatening, your best suit should usually be rejected in favor of no-trump.

title: Bush and the 'Gender Gap' From Another Angle; Look at the Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico's North Is Election Battlefield
description: An adage dating back to the days of the Mexican Revolution says ''change begins in the north.'' As Mexico's presidential campaign draws to a close, both the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and the opposition hope that saying again proves to be true.

title: Deals Totaling $925 Million Announced by Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, yesterday announced the sale and the pricing of about $925 million in debt securities through two separate transactions.

title: Penney Purchases Stores in Cincinnati
description: The J. C. Penney Company purchased the three suburban Cincinnati stores vacated earlier this month by L. S. Ayres & Company, a move that Penney says will double its presence in the Cincinnati area. Agreement on the sale was reached Tuesday between Penney and the May Department Stores Company, the parent company of Ayres. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: Federal Agency Considers Tests on Aging Planes
description: Concerned about the safety of aging airliners, the Government is considering a requirement that manufacturers test planes to develop information that could be used to improve schedules for the repair or replacement of key parts.

title: Talks on Westland
description: The United Technologies Corporation said it was holding preliminary talks with Fiat S.p.A. on buying the Italian company's interest in Westland P.L.C., the British helicopter manufacturer. United Technologies already owns 15 percent of Westland on a fully diluted basis, and Fiat is seeking to sell its 21.8 percent stake, which it no longer regards as strategic. The two companies acquired their stakes early in 1986.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; In-House Triumph
description: It's not exactly the sort of legislative accomplishment that will set voters' hearts aflutter, but it was enough to set off a round of boisterous applause and self-congratulations on the floor of the House of Representatives.

title: NICARAGUA ALONE, SHULTZ DECLARES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in Central America tonight and denounced Nicaragua as ''the odd man out'' in a region where democracy has replaced dictatorship.

title: 3 U.S. Jet Fighters Crash in Germany
description: Three United States Air Force F-16 jet fighters crashed over West Germany today, bringing the number of crashes to five in three months and insuring a new outcry from West Germans against low-level training flights over their land.

title: Mets Tie Pirates in 9th, Win by 8-7 in 11
description: ''Something was missing,'' Roger McDowell said, remembering how the Mets had been tamed for a month. ''Maybe the positive attitude. We missed winning. But I think we got it back.'' They got it back tonight, all right, with full flourishes, and McDowell supplied most of them. He pitched three daredevil innings with the game on the line. He fielded his position like a tiger. And he hit a double in the 11th inning and scored the winning run as the Mets survived four hours of high risk to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8-7.

title: Spraying Coca Opens a Genetic Pandora's Box
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Says U.S. Should Continue Its Arms Buildup
description: Vice President Bush today called for continuing support for military spending, arguing that the Reagan Administration's arms buildup had pushed the Soviet Union toward domestic reform.

title: Banker's Pay: Dispute Ends
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association said today that Federal regulators had dropped their dispute about the pay of its chief executive, Thomas Spiegel. Mr. Spiegel, who received $5.46 million last year in salary, bonus and pension contributions, was the industry's highest-paid executive.

title: Future-Trend Index Slipped 0.1% in May
description: The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge dipped slightly in May, the first setback since January, but most economists said the tiny downturn was no threat to the economy's outlook for the rest of 1988.

title: Dingman Puts $103.9 Million In One of His Henley 'Dogs'
description: Michael D. Dingman, the chairman of the Henley Group, said today that he had purchased another 17.2 percent of the Henley Manufacturing Corporation for $103.9 million, or $55 a share.

title: 3 Secret Service Aides Disciplined Over Drugs
description: Three employees of the United States Secret Service have been put on administrative leave from their jobs as a result of an investigation into cocaine use, an Government spokesman said tonight.

title: U.S. and Israel to Build Defensive Missile
description: The United States and Israel signed a memorandum of understanding today to jointly develop and produce a new defensive missile.

title: Soviet Party Conference Delegates Turn Anger on Press and Economy
description: Delegates to a special Communist Party conference expressed irritation today with the recently emboldened Soviet press and complained bitterly about economic problems.

title: Cleopatra Kohlique Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: House Backs Move to Strengthen Enforcement of Housing Rights
description: The House of Representatives today approved a measure to provide tougher enforcement of laws that prohibit discrimination in the sale or rental of any public or private dwelling. It was the first strengthening of the nation's laws on fair housing in 20 years.

title: BLEATING-SHEEP PRELUDE
description: Listeners arriving at Weill Recital Hall for a performance by the Circle Chamber Players on Sunday afternoon were greeted by the sound of bleating sheep coming from a pair of speakers on the stage. Before the concert, Mary Chaves Ibrahim, the ensemble's director and the composer whose music was featured, explained that she had written many of the works on the program during her years running a sheep farm and that ''I wanted to have my friends with me.''

title: Ex-Gruner + Jahr Head Joins Working Woman
description: John J. Beni, 56 years old, is joining Working Woman/McCall's Group as president and chief operating officer, a little more than a month after he quit as president of Gruner + Jahr USA Publishing.

title: No Quick Answers on Draft
description: On the day after the draft, most of the National Basketball Association's general managers and coaches spent yesterday evaluating their own choices, seeking to determine if they have filled their needs, and assessing the picks of the other teams.

title: Boesky Move Speculation
description: There was growing speculation yesterday that Ivan F. Boesky, the former investor imprisoned for insider trading, was transferred from a California prison to Manhattan to testify before a grand jury investigating John F. Mulheren, a takeover stock speculator.

title: Entree Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $4,244,000 for inventory writedowns and expected costs of a subsidiary's sale. c-Net income

title: Telecommunications Network Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: All share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1986.

title: Italy-Argentina Accord
description: The Argentine Chamber of Deputies today approved an economic cooperation accord with Italy covering $5 billion of credits and investment in Argentina by the end of 1992. Under the agreement Italy will provide either low-cost official export financing or direct investment for Argentine ventures. Diplomats said that Mexico and Venezuela had both shown interest in reaching similar accords with industrial countries.

title: Agreement on Lease
description: The battle for the possession of the Chicago White Sox continued on two fronts Tuesday. Officials of the state of Illinois announced that they had reached a lease agreement with the White Sox for a new stadium in Chicago under which the White Sox would get a new $150 million stadium, a $2 million annual operating subsidy, and free rent if the team draws less than 1.2 million fans.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Chicago White Sox misidentified the Sara Lee Corporation's founder. He was Nathan Cummings. Charles Lubin founded a division, the Kitchens of Sara Lee.

title: The Ring Of Fear
description: AN image of Michael Spinks remains in the mind well beyond the fight, well beyond the sight of his eyes rolling back in his head as he took his second and last tumble in the ring to conclude his evening's work in 91 seconds of Round 1 Monday night.

title: Mr. Dinkins and the Brawley Fireballs
description: Manhattan Borough President David Dinkins is the highest-ranking black elected official in New York City and is frequently mentioned as a candidate for Mayor. Good for him, then, for joining the small handful of black leaders willing to criticize publicly the advisers in the Tawana Brawley case. But what took so long? The Rev. Al Sharpton and attorneys Alton Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason advise the family of Tawana Brawley, a black teen-ager from Dutchess County who claims to have been abducted and raped by a group of white men last November. So far, however, their advice has served merely to keep Miss Brawley from cooperating with the authorities. They, meanwhile, have hurled an assortment of charges, none backed by evidence.

title: Soviet Rock Music: Sounds of Glasnost
description: LEAD: The Soviet struggle for change is taking place not only at the Communist Party conference in the staid atmosphere of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses but also in rock clubs and concert halls all across the country.

title: Hood River Journal; Lure of a Wild Wind Revives a Region's Economy
description: At home they may be lawyers, architects or homeowners, but here in the Columbia River Gorge they are boardheads. To a true boardhead, heaven is a 30-mile-an-hour wind. This month heaven is at its peak.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Greek Terrorists Admit Killing of U.S. Attache
description: A Greek terrorist organization blamed for previous assassinations of American diplomats claimed responsibility today for a car bombing that killed the United States military attache as he drove to work.

title: Excerpts From Decision on Separation of Church and State
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding a Federal law providing, with an important qualification, money to religious organizations to counsel teen-age girls to abstain from sex and to avoid abortion. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the opinion, joined by Justices Byron R. White, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor filed a separate opinion concurring in the judgment.

title: California Utility's $100 Million Issue
description: The Southern California Edison Company tapped the corporate debt market yesterday with a $100 million competitive issue of first and refunding bonds with final maturity in 2020.

title: Acclaim Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Comparative results for the prior periods are not applicable since the company was founded in March 1987, and did not began shipping products until August of that year.

title: Notes From the Underproductive: A Soviet Plant Manager's Blunt Words
description: Applause and grins greeted a speech delivered at the Soviet party conference today by Vladimir P. Kabaidze, general director of the Ivanovo Machine Building Works north of Moscow, which was broadcast in a television report on the conference. Following are excerpts from the speech, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Advisory Role For Martin
description: Billy Martin, dismissed last Thursday as Yankee manager after serving 68 days, met yesterday for more than an hour with the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, and left with an old job: top adviser.

title: New York Gets An Accord On a Budget
description: After weeks of a contentious fiscal tug-of-war, the Koch administration, the City Council and city's Board of Estimate agreed early this morning to a $25.2 billion spending plan that depends in part on a $71.9 million property tax increase that Council leaders had earlier promised they would never pass.
